title: A Bush Parry for 'Campaign Manager' Clinton
description: A day after President Clinton used a fund-raising speech to belittle Gov. George W. Bush's views, Mr. Bush said today that the president was acting like Vice President Al Gore's campaign manager.

title: In a Dhaka Slum, the Grisly Fate of 'Handcuff' Babul
description: ''Handcuff'' Babul got his bloody comeuppance a few weeks back, a rare occasion for common joy in the teeming and miserable Dhaka slum known as the B.N.P. Bustee.

title: Ramos to Miss Matthaus's Home Debut for MetroStars
description: Lothar Matthaus will make his Giants Stadium debut tonight when the MetroStars face D.C. United, the defending champion of Major League Soccer. But the MetroStars will be missing their best playmaker, Tab Ramos, who has a slight tear in his left calf.

title: An Actor Escapes Cairo, But It's Only for a While
description: ''El Medina'' begins with a passage, displayed on the screen in Arabic and English, from the Greek poet Constantine Cavafy proposing that wherever you go, ''the city will follow you.'' Cavafy was speaking of an Alexandria that has long since vanished. Yousry Nasrallah, directing from a screenplay he wrote in collaboration with Nasser Abdel-Rahmane and Claire Denis, applies the poet's words to the bristling urban reality of modern Cairo.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL STEADY. Crude oil prices were steady as OPEC's decision to increase output convinced the market that industrial nations would have enough supplies. The May contract rose 20 cents, to $26.90 a barrel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Group Led by AT&T Invests In Web Phone Call Provider

title: State Warns Of Takeover In Camden
description: A day after Milton Milan became the third Camden mayor in 20 years to be indicted while in office, state officials swooped down today on this destitute river city to give him 15 days to produce a credible fiscal plan or face a possible state takeover.

title: Consumer Spending Surges As Growth in Incomes Slows
description: Consumer spending surged in February, even though income growth slowed, government data showed yesterday.

title: QUEBECOR PRINTING WILL SELL SOFTWARE OPERATIONS
description: Quebecor Printing Inc., the world's largest commercial printer, agreed yesterday to sell its software manufacturing operations in Fife, Wash., and Westborough, Mass., for $63 million to the Q-Media Services Corporation. Q-Media provides manufacturing services for software companies. The deal between the two Canadian companies consists of $59 million cash and $4 million in stock. Quebecor said it was shedding its noncore operations to focus on its core printing business. The company prints books, magazines, phone books, retail inserts and catalogs. It had $5 billion in revenue last year.

title: Beliefs; Running in the fast lane but behind schedule, who among us has time for some good deeds?
description: The train from Washington was somewhere south of Wilmington, Del., running behind schedule. The Weary Religion and Ethics Columnist (WREC to his friends) was also running behind schedule. Although the date was March 28, he was reading the March 13 issue of The New Republic. In the middle of a book review he was jolted by the following sentence:

title: Actor Interviews Clinton
description: The actor Leonardo DiCaprio, the star of ''Titanic,'' assumed a new role today, interviewing President Clinton about global warming for ABC News.

title: Church, State and Football
description: When the Supreme Court heard arguments this week on the constitutionality of prayer at high school football games in a small Texas school district, what was remarkable was that the opposing parties appeared to agree on the same governing standard: A school may not itself sponsor or promote prayer, but student religious expression, including prayer, is both permissible and protected.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Foreign Conservationists Under Siege
description: Some of the world's most dedicated human rights activists have started as campaigners for the environment. Ken Saro-Wiwa's initial cause, for example, was the devastation that Royal Dutch/ Shell's oil spills inflicted on Ogoni land in Nigeria's delta region. As the dictatorship fought back, he found himself taking on more traditional human rights battles -- for the rights of the Ogoni, against the military's burning of delta villages and its shooting of protesters and, finally, against the sham judicial process that led to his execution in 1995.

title: Safir Denies Release of Record Broke Law
description: At a contentious hearing, police officials and city lawyers yesterday denied that the Giuliani administration broke the law in releasing the sealed juvenile record of Patrick M. Dorismond after he was killed by the police last month.

title: DIGITAL INSIGHT, FINANCIAL SERVICES COMPANY, EXPANDS
description: The Digital Insight Corporation, a financial services technology company, said yesterday that it was entering the online lending market by acquiring the privately held AnyTime Access in a $140 million stock deal. Digital, based in Calabasas, Calif., said the purchase of AnyTime Access, which provides Internet and call-center loan services, will allow it to deliver multichannel loan-decision and origination services to its clients. AnyTime Access, based in Sacramento, Calif., serves 170 financial institutions with round the clock call-center service. Digital also announced the start of AXIS Online Lending, where clients will be able to offer their end-users loan products. Shares of Digital Insight plunged $6.75 each, to $51.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Mets Prepare for 2nd Opener
description: They had to travel back in time to do it -- so to speak -- but the Mets arrived in New York yesterday afternoon after opening the season with two games in Japan. The Mets' 12-hour flight left at 5:20 p.m. yesterday, Tokyo time, and arrived at Kennedy Airport at 3:21 p.m. yesterday, Eastern time. The team will hold 1 p.m. workouts at Shea Stadium today and tomorrow and then hold its home opener on Monday afternoon at 1:10 against the San Diego Padres.

title: Who Are Friends Of Elian Gonzalez?
description: To the Editor:

title: At Basketball Central, Anything Is Possible for the Underdogs
description: Downtown in the capital city of the Hoosier State, intersections are decorated with painted silhouettes of basketball players and diagrams of plays.

title: Hoop Dreams
description: Sue Bird led UConn over Penn State last night, and to an N.C.A.A. title game against Tennessee tomorrow night. Page D1.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the Harvard historian Adam Ulam yesterday referred incorrectly to the city of Lvov, which was part of Poland when he was born there in 1922 and is now Lviv, Ukraine. It is not the largest city in Ukraine; Kiev is.

title: OFFER FOR MANNESMANN UNIT
description: Germany's biggest steel company, Thyssen-Krupp A.G., offered as much as 8.75 billion euros ($8.4 billion) for the industrial business of Mannesmann A.G. as it seeks to build up its auto-parts and engineering units. Mannesmann did not immediately comment on the bid. The German company is being bought by Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. for $190 billion. An acquisition by ThyssenKrupp would create an auto-parts supplier with about 12 billion euros in annual sales and help Vodafone cut debt after the acquisition of Mannesmann. The unit also makes plastics technology and offers logistics services.

title: Campaign Briefing; SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- No public events this weekend; Aliquippa, Harrisburg and Hershey, Pa., on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about research on cooperation among Balkan peoples during the Ottoman Empire misstated the timing of the founding of the modern states of Greece, Romania, Serbia, Bulgaria and Albania. They were all created before World War I, not when the empire broke up after the war.

title: Nasdaq Posts Its First Gain Of the Week
description: Technology stocks remained the market victors in the first quarter, but old standbys like Intel seemed to be eclipsing Internet darlings by the end.

title: Connecticut on an Express Route to the Final
description: Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma took point guard Sue Bird out of tonight's game with 1 minute 1 second remaining. She had already delivered her Huskies to their destination, the only one they had in mind at the beginning of this season.

title: Adventures in Ritalin
description: For the last two years I have been in recovery from drug addiction. Mostly, this means I spend an uncomfortable number of hours each week in 12-step meetings in church basements full of strangers, drinking bad black coffee and saying, ''Thank you for sharing.'' Before this I spent four months in inpatient drug rehabilitation, followed by a six-month outpatient program. As I like to joke, it has been more expensive to get off drugs than it ever was to use them.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB PLANS TENDER OFFER FOR WESLEY JESSEN
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it would make a tender offer for all outstanding shares of Wesley Jessen VisionCare Inc., after the company, a maker of colored contact lenses, rejected an unsolicited $666 million buyout offer late on Thursday. Bausch & Lomb, which is trying to expand its vision-care business, said it would offer Wesley Jessen shareholders $34 a share in cash. The stock closed yesterday at $36, down 25 cents. Bausch & Lomb wants Wesley Jessen to drop its proposed purchase of Ocular Sciences Inc., which would create a large competitor for Bausch & Lomb, based in Rochester. Bausch & Lomb rose $3.1875 each, to $52.1875.

title: Gisele Freund Is Dead at 91; Photographed Paris Writers
description: Gisele Freund, the German-born photographer who was best known for her portraits of France's literary elite and was a founding member of Magnum Photo Agency, died today in Paris. She was 91.

title: Antidrug Tactics Exact Price On a Neighborhood, Many Say
description: A few months ago, narcotics detectives in Brooklyn began to swarm about a tree-lined stretch of Rugby Road about a mile south of Prospect Park. Their main target was Jose Sierra, a short, chunky 32-year-old with a gold tooth who lives with his wife and three children in a $400-a-month apartment at the intersection of Rugby Road and Newkirk Avenue.

title: O'Neal's Brother To Attend L.S.U.
description: LOS ANGELES LAKERS

title: Laser Maker to Cut Costs
description: Summit Technology Inc. will take a first-quarter pretax restructuring charge of $3 million and eliminate 20 jobs as the company, the No. 2 United States maker of surgical eye lasers, cuts costs to make up for price reductions caused by competition. Summit will take the charge to speed its integration of the laser equipment maker Autonomous Technologies, which it bought last year for $224 million in stock and cash.

title: Time Warner-ABC Cable Dispute Extended
description: ABC and Time Warner Cable have agreed to another extension of negotiations in their dispute over rights for Time Warner to carry ABC's stations over its cable systems.

title: So Cool It's All Right to Be Corny
description: The name of Doris Day is not taken in vain in ''Betwixt,'' the sweet and salty new evening of monologues by David Cale. Let others born in the era of ''Pillow Talk'' sneer at the professional virgin who captivated their parents. Mr. Cale's characters know that, as one of them says, ''There's more to Doris Day than meets the eye.''

title: Holyfield Challenges Tactics of Lewis
description: Evander Holyfield, the former heavyweight world champion, has come out swinging against the current champion, Lennox Lewis. In a memo that Holyfield faxed to reporters, Holyfield said Lewis was not abiding by the rules of the boxing sanctioning organizations.

title: Pools Worthy of Boom Times; Striving for an Aquatic Paradise in Suburban Backyards
description: They started digging behind George and Anne Magnifico's new 7,000-square-foot country French manor house in Hewlett Harbor, N.Y., early last month. Using a hydraulic excavator, they carved out the hole for a 20-by-45-foot free-form pool on top of 80 piles sunk into the ground on the one-acre waterfront plot.

title: The Big City; Hey, Rudy G.: Bring Back The Sopranos
description: FOR a devotee of the ''Godfather'' movies, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a shocking gaffe during this year's State of the City address. It came right after he described his crusades against organized crime at the Fulton Fish Market and the carting industry.

title: Japanese Unemployment at Record High Ahead of Elections
description: The number of Japanese workers looking for jobs climbed to a record high in February, casting another shadow over the ruling party's prospects ahead of an election that must be held by October. And government officials warned today that joblessness in the next few months may be even higher.

title: Facing Surgery, Richter Ends Season
description: The Rangers have four games left to play, but Mike Richter's season ended today when he decided to undergo surgery to repair a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee.

title: A City of Visions, Large and Small
description: To the Editor:

title: Signs of Conflict in Murder Trial of Mother and Son
description: At times during the seven-week trial of Sante and Kenneth Kimes, the mother and son accused of murdering an Upper East Side millionaire, their defense lawyers have appeared to question witnesses at cross purposes.

title: The Rural Life; Beneath the Spring Garden
description: If you let a leek winter over in the ground -- winter over all the way till spring -- it grows into a monster, a pale, thick-necked, grasping Medusa. The leaves will have dwindled to a few dry rasps. They may even have rotted away. But that white-haired leek-head, thrust so obdurately crown-downward into the loam, will not come up without the soil it has annexed over the winter. Shake it like a chunk of sod, to dislodge the dirt, and the garden fills with white rootlets and the powerful, lingering odor of the leek that would not let go. To eat leeks young is a kindness to them.

title: Union and City Trade Blame After Merit Pay Talks Fail
description: City Hall and the teachers' union accused one another of bad-faith negotiating yesterday, as their continuing dispute over merit pay for summer school escalated.

title: No What-Ifs as Lady Vols Defeat Rutgers
description: A month ago, Coach Pat Summitt questioned whether her Tennessee Lady Vols had the competitive drive, determination and leadership to advance to the Final Four. While the Lady Vols did not lack talent, they seemed to lack the urgency to confront another team's challenge.

title: The Magic All but Ends The Nets' Playoff Hopes
description: Possession after possession, Stephon Marbury dribbled downcourt like an average point guard. His cocky bounce was gone, his right knee aching badly from tendinitis.

title: AT&T Pledges $1.4 Billion for a Stake in Net2Phone
description: March 31, 2000

title: HANDSPRING, A COMPUTER MAKER, FILES PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Handspring Inc., which makes handheld computers similar to the ones from Palm Inc., filed yesterday to sell up to $300 million of common stock in an initial public offering. The terms of the offering were not disclosed in the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Mountain View, Calif., company was founded by Donna Dubinsky and Jeff Hawkins, the original developers of the first Palm computer. Their Visor line of handhelds uses the Palm operating system under license. The company plans to use proceeds from the offering for general corporate purposes, including working capital.

title: Chiefs Were Unaware of General's Sex Harassment Complaint
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and Gen. Dennis J. Reimer, the former Army Chief of Staff, said today that they had not been made aware of a sexual harassment complaint by the Army's highest ranking woman, who has alleged that another general made an unwanted sexual advance in 1996.

title: Officers Kill 2 Men
description: Two men were killed in Brooklyn last night by undercover officers involved in an Operation Condor sweep who said the men were trying to rob them. The authorities said the suspects were brandishing what turned out to be toy guns.

title: U.S. ANTIDUMPING LAW RULED ILLEGAL
description: The European Union has won another trade victory over the United States with a challenge to an 84-year-old antidumping law on the grounds that it violates global trading rules. A World Trade Organization panel struck down the United States Antidumping Act of 1916, deciding its provisions for civil and criminal sanctions contravene global trade pacts. Steelmakers in Europe said the seldom-used law threatened trade because importers faced lengthy and costly procedures that amount to harassment. Elizabeth Olson

title: Seeking a Seal of Approval for Socially Aware Coffee
description: Starbucks, the world's largest specialty coffee company, is deluged with requests for coffee that tastes good but is also good for the cause.

title: 2 Auction Sites on Web Accede To Federal Product Safeguards
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that two of the biggest Internet auction sites had agreed to new safeguards to protect people from buying dangerous second-hand products via the Web.

title: N.C.A.A. Looks to Clean Up Its Basketball Act
description: Four months ago the National Collegiate Athletic Association signed a $6 billion, 11-year television contract for its centerpiece event: the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. This weekend, four teams -- three of them unlikely participants -- will try to cap an entertaining and unpredictable run of pressure-packed games by competing for the national title.

title: Seeking Speed, Yankees Take a Look at Johnson
description: Lance Johnson has 1,556 hits in a good major league career, 325 stolen bases, and he's led the American League or the National League in significant categories 10 times. But his performance in a minor league game Saturday may go a long way to determining whether he joins the Yankees and fills the role of 25th player.

title: Sports of The Times; A Seating Upgrade For April
description: DICK BENNETT will wake up this morning and finally experience what he has missed for 34 years. The 56-year-old Wisconsin basketball coach will discover that Final Four Saturday is the best day of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. His Badgers will play Michigan State in a national semifinal game. Bennett has waited three decades to coach in a game of this magnitude.

title: Closing the Gender Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD FINANCIAL SEEKS ALL OF LIFE INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Hartford Financial Services Group offered yesterday to buy the 18.5 percent of its life insurance unit, Hartford Life Inc., that it does not already own for $1.14 billion. Hartford Financial, the ninth-largest United States insurer, offered to pay $44 a share for the remaining stake in Hartford Life. About 26 million Hartford Life shares are owned by the public. The chief executive of Hartford Financial, Ramani Ayer, said the offer was part of a plan to reorganize the company into two major operating entities: worldwide life operations and worldwide property-casualty operations. Hartford Life appointed a special committee of directors to evaluate the offer. The shares of Hartford Financial jumped $6.375 each yesterday, to $52.75, and Hartford Life was up $1.8125, at $46.875.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: THE 'HE' HORMONE -- As testosterone becomes increasingly available for medical use, more is being learned about how men and women are not created the same. A report by Andrew Sullivan in The Times Magazine.

title: Abroad at Home; Elian And the Law
description: The case of Elian Gonzalez, with all its heartbreak and controversy, now poses a critical question: Are we going to be governed in this country by law or by mob?

title: NBC Chooses Cantor for Olympics
description: Andres Cantor, whose Goooooooolllll! call punctuated his fast-paced work on Univision, will announce soccer for NBC Sports and its cable outlet, MSNBC, during the Summer Olympics in Sydney.

description: Percent

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Carl S. Shoup, the economist who oversaw the creation of Japan's postwar tax system, misspelled his daughter's surname. She is Dale S. Mayer, not Meyer.

title: Battery Reminder
description: Daylight time begins at 2 a.m. tomorrow; clocks should be set ahead an hour.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS UNION BACKS US AIRWAYS AGREEMENT
description: The executive council of the flight attendants' union voted unanimously yesterday to recommend that the 10,000 attendants at US Airways ratify the tentative agreement the two sides reached last Saturday. The nine-member board of the Association of Flight Attendants recommended an agreement that calls for several concessions on vacation and sick pay, a 5 percent cash bonus and an 11 percent wage increase over the contract's five years. Union officials said the attendants would vote on the agreement in the next five weeks. Steven Greenhouse

Giuliani said yesterday that Elian Gonzalez, the 6-year-old Cuban boy living with relatives in Miami, should not be compelled to return to his father in Cuba. Mr. Giuliani said the boy should be granted full United States citizenship.

description: A shuttle van headed to Atlantic City from New York City collided with a flatbed truck yesterday morning on the Garden State Parkway, injuring 17 people, 3 of them critically, the authorities said.

description: Are children better off if their parents remain in a troubled marriage or split up? Do children of divorce fare better if their parents remarry? And if there are ill effects, how long do they last?

description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that she had dropped her objections to $500 million in loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank to a Russian oil company that had been accused of fraud.

title: Xerox to Take $625 Million Write-Off and Eliminate 5,200 Jobs
description: The Xerox Corporation, which faces increasing competition while it grapples with internal disarray, said yesterday that it would cut 5,200 jobs and farm out some of its manufacturing operations.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: ROYAL AHOLD N.V., Amsterdam, a retailer, said its Tops Markets unit would take over the Sugar Creek convenience store chain. Financial details were not released. Sugar Creek has 87 stores and annual sales of $142 million.

title: Albany Misses Budget Deadline Again
description: As the midnight deadline for adopting a New York State budget neared, negotiations between Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature remained deadlocked today, meaning the state budget would be late for the 16th consecutive year.

title: Agassi Cannot Defeat Kuerten or an Injury
description: Andre Agassi realized early in the Ericsson Open semifinals today that a sprained right ankle would significantly restrict his mobility. And the world's No. 1 player quickly became a tournament footnote.

title: Red Satin And Heels For Strutting And Shaking
description: It is possible to go home again in dance. That was the message of a superb revival of Alvin Ailey's ''Quintet'' by Ailey II on Thursday night at Aaron Davis Hall. The seldom performed signature work was the high point of the first-rate program that opened the company's four-day 25th-anniversary season at the hall at City College, West 134th Street and Convent Avenue, Hamilton Heights.

title: In Mexico, Top Newsman And Network Part Ways
description: An extraordinarily influential television newsman and an extraordinarily powerful network have reached an abrupt parting of the ways.

title: Security Council Votes to Let Iraq Buy Oil Gear
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to allow Iraq to import $1.2 billion in spare parts and other equipment this year for its ramshackle oil industry, so that more oil can be pumped efficiently and safely to pay for civilian goods and public service projects.

title: With Bach as Point and Counterpoint
description: Of all the commemorations of the 250th anniversary of Bach's death taking place this year in New York, Lincoln Center, in its Great Performers series, has gone the farthest. Too far, some will say on April 9, when the period instrument group Amsterdam Baroque revives the lost St. Mark Passion, reconstructed at length by Ton Koopman on a wisp and a prayer.

title: FAMILY LOOSENS HOLD AT HYUNDAI
description: Bowing to pressure from the government and shareholder rights advocates, South Korea's largest business conglomerate, the Hyundai Group, will dismantle its top decision-making body, the C.E.O.'s Council. Chung Mong Hun, 52, the chairman of the conglomerate, said he would concentrate on the management of Hyundai Electronics and Hyundai Engineering and Construction, while delegating full managerial power over other affiliates to nonfamily managers and directors. To promote board-based management, Hyundai will fill half of all affiliates' boards with outside directors. Samuel Len

description: GENES, PEOPLES AND LANGUAGES

title: A Vicious Swing With a Dry Humor
description: It's hard not to like and respond to Herbie Nichols's music: it contains much that there is to like and respond to in postwar jazz. It can swing viciously and it has a dry sense of humor. Like Thelonious Monk, Nichols (who died young, in 1963) isolated short, punchy themes -- headlines, as they've been called by one of his admirers, the trombonist Roswell Rudd -- but wrote clever harmonic movement and built widely contrasting sections in most of his music. Even with only piano, bass and drums, his arranger's hand was heavy, and listening to his small output on the Blue Note and Bethlehem labels you feel that a superior talent wasn't properly used: he could have found his Xanadu with a five- or six-man group.

title: SEEKING ANSWERS, CENSUS IS STIRRING PRIVACY QUESTIONS
description: Saturday is Census Day, the day the government takes a demographic snapshot of every man, woman and child in America to find out how many of them there are and where they live and how old they are and what race they consider themselves, and to make it possible to tabulate, among dozens of other factors, their education, marital status, income and housing conditions.

description: Ever mindful of the need to stay au courant, Mattel staged a makeover this year for Barbie, the 41-year-old fashion doll with $1.3 billion in annual sales. She emerged with a navel and a smile that shows some teeth, giving her a slightly more natural look.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen posted its biggest gain against the dollar in a month amid optimism that the Japanese economy is recovering from recession. In New York, the dollar settled at 102.8 yen, down from 105.4 on Friday.

description: A livery cabdriver who was robbed and stabbed Thursday evening in Queens followed his attacker in his car until the police arrived to arrest the man, the police said.

title: FRENCH JOBLESS RATE DROPS
description: The unemployment rate in France slid in February to its lowest level in nearly a decade as the nation's economic recovery continued to gather speed. The jobless rate was at a lower-than-expected 10.2 percent in February, down from 10.5 percent in January and its lowest level since April 1992, the Labor Ministry said. Analysts had expected the decline in job seekers and the unemployment rate to continue, but by a smaller amount.

description: There were exasperating moments when the whip-quick Michael Dickerson left Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy slinging his fist into the scorer's table.

description: For four years, members of New York City's largest janitors' union have picketed outside the Port Authority Bus Terminal to protest its use of a nonunion cleaning contractor.

description: Donald Gean is ''running clean.''

description: In his first official trip since being elected president, Vladimir V. Putin visited one of Russia's leading nuclear weapons design centers and vowed to preserve the nation's nuclear might.

What a marvelous show the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg is putting on at City Center. Anyone interested in ballet with a difference should not miss it.

title: Money-or-Jail Offer Posed To Couple in Fraud Case
description: Looking coldly at Patrick R. Bennett, a man convicted of one of the largest financial swindles in American history, Judge John S. Martin of United States District Court in Manhattan issued an extraordinary pronouncement yesterday: that Mr. Bennett's prison sentence will be either 20 years or 30 years, depending on whether or not his wife turns over their house and other property to creditors.

title: Homework Helps Devils Solve Thrashers
description: Two days of nearly two-hour practice sessions helped the Devils strengthen a few weaknesses that had been so evident in their two losses under Coach Larry Robinson. The extra work showed tonight in a 6-0 trouncing of the Atlanta Thrashers.

description: ''This is a city that is separate. We now have our own local foreign policy.''

title: Officials Defend Spraying to Curb West Nile Virus
description: City officials yesterday defended their use of certain pesticides last summer to kill mosquitoes, telling people at a hearing in Queens that their actions were necessary to prevent the spread of the West Nile virus, which killed seven people in the metropolitan region in 1999.

title: Conseco to Sell Loan Unit, Giving Up Brief Effort to Diversify
description: Conseco Inc., the once highflying insurance company that stumbled badly when it diversified into consumer lending, said yesterday that it would sell the lending operation, the former Green Tree Finance, which it bought in 1998 for stock worth $7.6 billion. It will take a write-off of at least $350 million after taxes.

title: Gary Allan Polis, 53, an Expert On Scorpions and Desert Ecology
description: Dr. Gary Allan Polis, a zoologist, an ecologist and one of the world's foremost experts on the dreaded scorpion, drowned on Monday in a boat accident off Mexico in the Sea of Cortez. He was 53 and lived in Davis, Calif.

title: Lawyers for Boy's Miami Relatives Rule Out Directly Releasing Him to His Father
description: In a sign of growing entrenchment, lawyers for the Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez said today that they would not turn the boy over to his Cuban father, even if he came for a visit, and suggested that they might not hand him over to the authorities even if they lost their custody case.

title: Tired of Her Life, She Makes a New One
description: Solange is 30, and that feels old. She works as a meter maid in a small French city and spends her days being cursed at and called names by the people she tickets. (Not to mention that she hates the ugly blue uniform.) Her husband, who works at a morgue, buys her a coffeemaker for her birthday. The couple are buying a new house, one of many identical blue-roofed ones in a new development, but that doesn't excite her. The only thing that really brings Solange pleasure is reading to her elderly grandmother, who inexplicably prefers hearing recipes from her favorite cookbooks than novels or short stories. No wonder Solange sinks into a depression after seeing her old school friend Mylene again.

title: Barmore Still a Winner After Being Defeated
description: After his team's 86-65 loss to Penn State in the Midwest Regional final Monday night, Louisiana Tech Coach Leon Barmore said a quick goodbye to the women's basketball program that is, and always will be, synonymous with his name.

title: Nassau Civil Service Union Accepts Plan to Defer Pay
description: In an effort to avoid layoffs threatened by the Nassau County executive, members of the county's largest municipal workers' union have voted overwhelmingly to accept a plan that will defer 10 days' worth of pay.

title: Screaming for Help, With No One to Hear
description: Although it bears the title ''Two Women,'' Tahmine Milani's film is really about one. And her name is legion.

title: Farmers Are Scaling Back Genetically Altered Crops
description: For the first time since 1996, American farmers expect to plant fewer acres with genetically engineered crops, largely because of concerns about selling those crops in international markets, the government said today.

title: No Commitments for Ewing
description: Dave Checketts discussed the sympathy he had for Patrick Ewing's early-season discontent and restated his desire to see the Knicks' aging superstar retire with the team. But Checketts, the Madison Square Garden president, could not assure a happy ending.

title: She Caught a Sparkler, A Bit Too Hot to Handle
description: In the early decades of the 20th century, Charles Lindbergh was a hero for all seasons, and his wife, Anne Morrow Lindbergh, was a treasured writer. But as tomorrow's ''Biography'' reports, their shining careers, shadowed by early tragedy, never quite lived up to their expectations and desires.

title: A Triangle With Mother
description: What is most surprising in several of Candido Tirado's plays is that the leading character survives to the end after what the author likes to put them through. In ''Rey Sin Castillo'' (''King Without a Castle''), in production by the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater in Spanish on weekends and English on Wednesday through Friday, there are only three people and two are alive when the curtain falls, which seems almost a miracle.

title: Cutting Crime, Keeping Our Rights
description: The police shootings of Amadou Diallo and Patrick Dorismond exposed a seemingly intractable problem. How can police aggressively keep guns and drugs off the street, while respecting the civil rights of citizens? The Op-Ed Page asked a few experts.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Classical Music and Dance Guide of Weekend yesterday for a symposium today about Aaron Copland and Roger Sessions referred incorrectly to the admission. The program, sponsored by the American Composers Orchestra from 10 a.m to 5 p.m. at Weill Recital Hall in Manhattan, costs $75; it is not free.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 23 about Iranian rugs referred incorrectly to the time when there were famous weaving centers in Persia. It was before the country's name was changed to Iran, not before Iran existed as a nation.

title: On a Not-So-Deserted Isle, Robinson Crusoes Compete for Riches
description: KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia  On a "deserted tropical island" several kilometers off the northern tip of Borneo, a group of Americans equipped with only basic supplies is competing to see who will survive the longest in the island's steamy jungles  and walk off with dollars 1 million in prize money

title: A City of Visions, Large and Small
description: To the Editor:

title: Latinas Get A Chance To Speak for Themselves; Encyclopedia Focuses On an Unsung Group
description: They grew up separated by hundreds of miles and different cultural environments, one a descendant of Mexican pioneers of the American West and the other a daughter of urban Puerto Ricans who settled in New York more than half a century ago. As young women, they achieved academic success in mainstream America but felt the powerful pull of their Hispanic roots and knew that the stories of their country's Spanish-speaking communities, especially the women, had never been told in fullness, honesty and depth.

title: Putin and Lenin
description: To the Editor:

title: Pioneer Among Rabbis Helps Extend Blessing of Unions
description: RABBI Shira Stern counts herself among the ''first 50,'' which is shorthand for saying that she belongs to a pioneering generation within Judaism's Reform movement, that early group of women who first claimed a place in pulpits once reserved for men.

title: Gateway Buys Stake in Hispanic Web Site Quepasa.com
description: Gateway Buys Stake in Hispanic Web Site Quepasa.com

title: Executive Leaving Salomon for the Internet
description: Salomon Smith Barney Inc.'s Terry Kawaja is joining the Internet communications service provider Evoke Inc. as chief financial officer, becoming the latest investment banker to leave Wall Street for a dot-com company.

title: A Perennial Runner-Up Pair With a Sense of Foreboding
description: Many years ago, Ben Hogan stood on the first tee of the United States Open and asked, ''Who's going to be second?'' He duly won the tournament.

title: British Internet Provider to Pay Physicist Who Says E-Bulletin Board Libeled Him
description: A British Internet service provider has agreed to pay a substantial sum to a physicist who says he was libeled in messages posted on electronic bulletin boards carried by the company, in a move that lawyers fear will severely curtail people's ability to speak freely in cyberspace.

title: Judge Says State Officials Misdirected $1.5 Million
description: Seven years ago, New York State investigators cut a deal with an air freight company they had caught working with the mob: forfeit $2.5 million said to have passed through the hands of the Mafia and avoid the embarrassment of criminal charges.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Court May Narrow Disparity in Way Illegal Re-entry Is Handled
description: When Alex Sanchez was picked up by the Los Angeles Police Department and handed over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service in January, he was but one of thousands of immigrants who re-enter the country illegally each year after having been deported at least once before.

title: Civic Duty and the Census
description: Some Congressional Republicans are seriously undermining the 2000 census by suggesting that the national head count, which officially takes place today, is an invasion of privacy. That bizarre complaint could discourage the public from participating in a project that is crucial to the functioning of state and federal government.

title: Taiwan Is Putting U.S. on the Spot by Campaigning for Better Missile Defenses Against China
description: On a mountaintop south of Taipei, a cluster of American-made Patriot missile launchers, draped in camouflage netting, stands pointed toward the Chinese mainland 130 miles away.

title: IDEAS & TREND: The Joy, the Chagrin; Sex Became Him
description: ALEX COMFORT, who died last Sunday, personified the sort of tweedy English intellectual who could gracefully range from subject to subject. He was a physician, poet, novelist, anarchist, pacifist and a leading researcher on how people age.

title: Seeking Reality Check, Not Blank Check on Schools
description: As senior citizens and long-term residents of Pleasantville, we are concerned about the significant increase in taxes resulting from current construction figures, which exceed $29 million. The Board of Education and the superintendent have yet to provide a definitive price tag on their recommendations for improvements on all buildings and grounds, and future estimates can only rise with inflation. They need a reality check, not a blank check for their wish list.

title: Riley Wins Title
description: Schuler Riley rode the Dutch-bred Ilian to a score of zero faults over all eight fences on the jump-off course in 40.91 seconds to win the $150,000 American Invitational grand prix last night in Tampa, Fla.

title: For Worst Performance by a Car: The Envelope, Please . . .
description: IF you thought all the lists of the best this or that of the last 100 or 1,000 years had been compiled, think again. While the Car of the Century has been selected (the Ford Model T, anointed by an international panel of experts), what about the flip side: of the tens of thousands of automobile models produced since the 1880's, which were bad enough to warrant special recognition?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Treatment
description: Richard Rushfield's scabrously funny first novel, ON SPEC (St. Martin's, $21.95), is a cautionary tale about Hollywood and a contemporary take on a morality play, or rather, script. ''Don't Put Your Daughter on the Stage, Mrs. Worthington,'' and if she dreams of using an Ivy League degree to become a development girl on the way to producing films, read this first. Rushfield's book is not much longer than a script, and it is structured as entries from the diaries, letters and memos of six characters -- a D-girl, an agent, a writer, a studio head, a producer and a bimbo. The story begins, as all such tales do, with a high-concept film proposal. Stu Bluminvitz, a Reed College grad and all around schlep who lives with his parents in Hollywood, is looking for a buyer for ''Kennel Break,'' his ''Tarantino meets 'Turner and Hooch' spec'' in which he tries to ''take a reverential approach toward kitsch.'' Deana Cohen (who went to Brown) shares her dreams of power and marriage in a ''nightly development-support group conference call,'' except when she gets a better offer. Todd Hirtley (who attended Penn) is by his own dictated account a member of a ''party-boy agenting juggernaut.'' He tells his assistant that ''history will want to study'' the way he sells a script. At a communications workshop at the Celebrity Center, Chelsea Starlot remembers ''being the sole object of lust for a tiny Indiana town'' and latches onto something like Scientology, more coke and an aging producer -- a winning combination. Eric Whitfield is the energetic if dimwitted producer who dreams of putting it all together with Jerry, who runs the Japanese-owned Hotatsi Studios. Rushfield, who writes the ''Intelligence Report'' column in Vanity Fair and is a partner in Agent X, a trend-spotting company, has complete command of his intricate plot, in which tinsel rises to the top. Eden Ross Lipson

title: Whether You Mow Or Moan
description: THE days are getting warmer, the nights are getting shorter, and the sun is moving higher in the sky. It is the time of year when homeowners reclaim their yards and gardens. And what could be more inviting than the idea of meandering around the yard enveloped by spring breezes, bird songs and the muffled roar of a self-mulching gas mower?

title: And the Winner Is . . .
description: IT lacked the glamour of the Academy Awards, but Westchester honored its own filmmakers last week as winners were announced at the county's Film Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, STEN HELGE
description: CARLSON-Sten Helge, 67, of Wellfleet, MA on March 23. He was educated at Choate, Yale, Columbia, and the Army Language School in Monterey, CA. A commercial fisherman, he worked the Grand Banks and the South Carolina coast and consulted to fisheries in Haiti and Africa. He leaves his wife, Jeanne Woodes Carlson, her three children, Celeste Langlois, Gregg and Joel Woodes, and two step grandchildren, Rebecca and Cassie. He also leaves his first wife, Jocelyn Baltzell, and his two daughters, Justina Carlson and Julie Carlson Groves and two grandchildren, William and Darcy Groves. He is also survivied by his two brothers, Arne and Lars, both of Minnesota. Memorial services will be held later this spring.

title: On Politics; Those Hills Are Filling Up, But Not With Republicans
description: As the state's frontier hills and meadows fill with new housing, they fill with new voters, mysterious and intensely interesting to the political powers in places like Somerset, Hunterdon, Warren and Sussex. And they may be doing damage to a Republican landscape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, THEODORE
description: SMITH-Theodore. March 27, 2000. Of Sarasota, FL. Graduate of Rutgers University, member of football and lacrosse teams. Served as a WWII lieutenant in the company that built the Burma Road. Owner and President of P. Feldman & Sons Scrap Metal Business. A summer resident of East Hampton, NY, retiring to Sarasota in 1980. A member of the Palm Aire Country Club. An avid golf and tennis player. Ted possessed a warm and generous spirit. Loved by his family and friends for the truly kind and compassionate man he was. His greatest joy was children. He was a man amongst men. Widowed in 1972, he is survived by his longtime companion Sandra Miles of Sarasota and his son Richard Wade Smith of New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Florida West Coast Symphony, Ted Smith Memorial, 709 Tamiami Trail North, Sarasota, FL 34236.

title: Film; Keeping Faith With 'High Fidelity'
description: IN the transition from novel to film, Rob, the hero of ''High Fidelity'' -- Nick Hornby's 1995 novel, Stephen Frears's new film -- undergoes some minor transformations: he ceases being British and becomes American, relocates from London to Chicago and sees his last name change from Fleming to Gordon. The first two changes were no doubt to accommodate the casting of the Chicago native John Cusack; the last you can speculate about on your own. Otherwise, much remains the same. Rob is still the owner of a marginally failing vintage record shop, still called Championship Vinyl, which is still manned by ''the musical moron twins,'' Dick and Barry; he is still moping about his love life, especially his recent dumping by his girlfriend, Laura; and he is still the gloomy underachiever whose relentless navel-gazing is made palatable by his honesty about his shortcomings and his often quite funny insights about men, women and romance. As film adaptations go, this one is almost fiercely faithful.

title: NEWARK AND CHILDREN
description: Births to teenage mothers in Newark decreased by more than 13 percent between 1994 and 1997, the latest year for which birth numbers are available, according to a study released last week by the Association for Children of New Jersey, its fourth report on children and Newark. Juvenile arrests declined 35 percent between 1996 and 1998, as did the number of violent incidents in the schools. However, the number of children who are HIV positive increased by 131 percent between 1996 and 1999 and Newark's 1997 infant mortality rate, at 13.3 deaths per 1,000 live births, was double that of the rest of New Jersey. The association will release statewide in a few weeks. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Zimbabwe Protesters Are Beaten by Government Supporters
description: A peaceful anti-government march in Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, erupted in violence today as a group of armed men wielding machetes and clubs attacked the crowd of several thousand marchers, leaving several people seriously injured.

title: RECALCULATING PENSION CONTRIBUTIONS
description: Governor Whitman last week signed a law that saves cities and towns $45 million in pension fund contribitions this year to the statewide police and firemen's pension fund. The law permits the worth of the fund to be calculated much closer to the current market value of its investments, rather than the much lower figure for dollars paid into it. The new calculation means future contributions can be lower. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: Marijuana Smoke In the Halls
description: Q I live in a co-op in Carnegie Hill. Our building consists of families, working professionals and retired people. Recently, an apartment was sold to a young couple in their late 20's. Our problem is that now, at all times of the day, morning and night, the odor of marijuana permeates the halls and our elevator, too. We have young children, pregnant women and law-abiding citizens who live in our building, and never has a problem like this occurred. What can be done to stop this? . . . A. Smith, Manhattan

title: Good Deeds Rewarded
description: Parties benefit the arts, charities, and a college.

title: Theater; At Last, Playing Grandma, She Gets to Be the Star
description: YOU may not know the name, but you know the face: the big baggy eyes, the sensual mouth with the overbite. And then there is that deep hoarse voice and that sulfurous laugh.

title: Frances Gray Patton, 94, Writer Of Stories and 1954's 'Miss Dove'
description: Frances Gray Patton, a writer whose short stories appeared in The New Yorker through four decades and whose works included the popular 1954 novel ''Good Morning, Miss Dove,'' died Tuesday at Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. She was 94 and lived in Durham.

title: Lakeville's 2 1/2 Cheers For High-Tech Plans
description: RESIDENTS and town officials are welcoming plans to build a high-tech center on a 94-acre site in Lake Success that once housed the United Nations, provided that efforts continue to clean up toxic wastes in one 10-acre corner of the site.

title: Vendors of Antiques Fear Unplanned Obsolescence
description: In February, most of the roughly 150 dealers renting space in the Chelsea Antiques Building at 110 West 25th Street were told by the landlord to vacate the building by April 29, when the building would close.

title: March 26-April 1; Agent Orange Link Suggested
description: The Pentagon came closer to acknowledging what some Vietnam veterans have alleged for years: that they were made sick by exposure to Agent Orange, a herbicide used to destroy the forest camouflage of the Vietnamese Communists.

title: As Others Squabble, Lakers Are Peaceful
description: In the last week, Vernon Maxwell threw a dumbbell in the vicinity of Gary Payton, who picked up a chair in order to counter his Seattle teammate. In Utah, Coach Jerry Sloan and Karl Malone exchanged angry words during the first half of a game. Asked whether his relationship with Sloan would recover, Malone replied, ''I don't know.''

title: Music; Fiddling While the Old Barriers Burn
description: WHEN the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the bassist Edgar Meyer and the violinist Mark O'Connor take the stage on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall to play selections from their best-selling album, ''Appalachia Waltz,'' and its new sequel, ''Appalachian Journey,'' most eyes will be on Mr. Ma. The trio's celebrity, its meal ticket, he is a classical-music superstar, perhaps the greatest string player of our time. But he's not as remarkable a musician as his ensemble-mate on violin.

title: In Brief; Cancer Cases Decline In Nassau and Suffolk
description: Provisional state data for January show that the overall incidence of cancers in Nassau fell 3.4 percent from a year earlier; the incidence of breast cancer fell 2.1 percent. Overall, cancers fell one-tenth of 1 percent in Suffolk, but the incidence of breast cancer there rose 1.8 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOMJY, GEORGE S.
description: MOOMJY-George S. On March 31, 2000 of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of Angele. Dear uncle of many nieces, nephews, and grand nieces and nephews. In repose The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Monday 3:00-5:00 and 7:009:00 P.M. Funeral service at Church of Our Savior Lutheran, 1901 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Tuesday, 11:30 A.M. Interment Cedar Grove Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Church of Our Savior Lutheran, 1901 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY 11030

title: Travel Advisory; Landmark Status for Stonewall
description: The Stonewall area in New York, a famous setting in the history of gay and lesbian rights in the United States, was among 18 new National Historic Landmarks created by the Interior Department last month.

title: Belichick Shows His Relaxed Side
description: Bill Belichick is having a glass of orange juice in a ballroom at a luxury Florida hotel, his sips being interrupted by glances at the sandy beach 30 feet away. The green and blue water seems to be having a calming effect on one of the most intense head coaches in professional football.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Who Killed Hollywood?

title: Mary Fowler Brennan, 83, Justice's Widow
description: Mary Fowler Brennan, the widow of Justice William H. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Arlington, Va. She was 83.

title: Messages From the Dim Past to the Hazy Future
description: Over the century, the box sat quietly in the Mount Holyoke College library, then in the comptroller's office, then on a shelf in the school archives, and finally on the dorm room floor of Sara Hines, president of the class of 2000.

title: On The Towns; Cuban Art
description: Adrian Infante's artwork will be on display, along with works by 17 other contemporary Cuban painters and printmakers.

title: Jennifer Thurston, Buck Glenn
description: Jennifer Leigh Thurston, a daughter of Lisa and Robert Thurston of Overland Park, Kan., was married yesterday to Benjamin Duke Glenn III, the son of Lynn Glenn McAtee of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Glenn Jr. The Rev. Benjamin L. Wren, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Bradish Johnson House, a historic home in New Orleans.

title: Turning a Kiosk Into a Borough Gateway
description: Saying Brooklyn deserves a visual gateway to welcome visitors, community groups have long pushed for restoration of a graffiti-covered kiosk that once housed a subway entrance and newsstand. But now that the city plans to renovate the 92-year-old kiosk, on a traffic island bounded by Flatbush, Atlantic and Fourth Avenues, there is disagreement on what it should be used for.

title: Springing Forward With New Stock Issues
description: IT'S not often that the stock market acts like the bond market, but over the next couple of months there may well be a resemblance between the two, particularly in Nasdaq stocks.

title: Add Yoga and Shake Well
description: Sometimes there's no better way to extend the shelf life of a popular hit than to mix it with another one, like Carlos Santana pairing up with Rob Thomas of Matchbox 20 or the Flintstones visiting the Jetsons. And so it makes sense that in the ever-expanding world of fitness, yoga is coupling up. This month, Equinox Fitness Clubs introduce yogilates, in which students execute the popular Pilates method exercises on floor mats and specially designed equipment, while incorporating the breathing and meditative techniques of hatha yoga. And on the heels of the popular yoga-ballet exercise called nia, the Reebok Sports Club this week is starting fluidity, a workout that integrates the principles of yoga, ballet, therapeutic movement, stretching and weight resistance -- performed holding on to a portable version of a ballet barre, dubbed the fluidity bar. Bottoms up!

title: Crime
description: Aurelio Zen, the philosophical police detective in Michael Dibdin's dark crime novels, has always dreaded being assigned to Sicily, a brooding land of intrigue whose austere beauty and arrogant insularity offer no comfort to strangers. ''This will end badly,'' he says in BLOOD RAIN (Pantheon, $23) when he realizes that his appointment to Catania is tantamount to a spy posting. His adopted daughter, Carla, is also in Sicily, investigating a security breach in the new computer system that the government has set up for its Mafia prosecutions. When Carla's friendship with one of the anti-Mafia magistrates ends in violence, Zen finds a personal motive for trying to penetrate the sinister network that links the criminal underworld of Catania with friends in high political places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MARGO
description: KAUFMAN - Margo. Beloved daughter of Gloria Asnes and Alan Pearlstein. Step-daughter of Paul Asnes and Rose Pearlstein. Devoted sister to Laurie Goldberg and Robert Pearlstein. Adored wife of Eric Mankin. Loving mother of Nicky Ross. Her courageous spirit will always live in our hearts.

title: Footlights; Backstage Pass
description: The throng in the gilded, red-carpeted loge of the State Theater in New Brunswick next Saturday won't be attending a play. It will consist of people looking for jobs as stagehands, set designers, lighting technicians, arts educators, marketing and personnel staff, and other positions at a job fair. The fair, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., is sponsored by the New Jersey Theater Group, an alliance of professional Equity theaters, among them the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in Madison, the American Stage Company in Teaneck and George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. will be there. Dan Bauer, director of publicity at the McCarter Theatre in Princeton, got his job at the fair. ''I wouldn't be here today if it weren't for the job fair,'' he said. ''The people who make New Jersey Theater happen behind the scenes are all there.'' Actors will have to do it the traditional way: audition. More information: (973) 593 0189. MARGO NASH

title: Bring On the Sauces. Hold the Noise
description: IF you enjoy being addressed with ''Well, guys, ready to order?'' as well as ''O.K. guys, want some dessert?'' then you might enjoy Bella Luna in the Springdale section of Stamford. Our table -- two couples -- did not.

title: Rangers, Out of the Playoffs, Suspend Disgruntled Quintal
description: In his first major personnel decision as the Rangers' de facto general manager, Dave Checketts, the Madison Square Garden president, suspended defenseman Stephane Quintal without pay for the rest of the season late Friday night ''for conduct deemed detrimental to the hockey club.''

title: Where the Armorers No Longer Thrive
description: THE roar of a jet engine rumbles across the stubbly wheat fields near Boeing's Aero Vodochody factory here on the outskirts of Prague, as a Czech test pilot puts an L-159 fighter-trainer through its paces.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-2-00: Word & Image; A Television High
description: I should have remembered before I became addicted to ''Millionaire'' -- and witnessed the crowning of one -- what newspapers do when they need a circulation fix. To avoid going under, they use their habitual lifeline: a lottery built around a game that promises rich reward to a lucky few. That, precisely, is the essence of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' the brilliantly superficial suspense drama that has rescued the Disney Company's ABC network, overturned America's prime-time schedule, robbed me of three hours a week and reaffirmed the commonality of television tastes around the world.

title: Bach to Hendrix, From a Violin Mixmaster
description: IT has been said that the English classical violinist Nigel Kennedy was the epitome of a violin virtuoso. A child prodigy who was Sir Yehudi Menuhin's most famous protege before moving on to study at Juilliard, Mr. Kennedy took the classical music world by storm more than 20 years ago when he started his adult career.

title: Women's Final Four Has the Right Timing
description: There is a growing movement to shift the women's Final Four to a weekend separate from the men's Final Four, which would be the worst decision since women were forced to play six against six, and midcourt was a forbidden border crossing in the gender wars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, FLORENCE
description: ISAACSON-Florence. March 27, 2000. To our loving mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Your life will live forever in our memories. Arlene, Irv, Harold, Tammy, Beth, Chris, Miriam, Benjamin, Zachery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIRD, WARREN W.
description: BAIRD-Warren W. Of Burlington, CT, a teacher and administrator at Kingswood-Oxford School in West Hartford, CT, for 33 years, died Thursday, March 30, at Hartford Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old. He joined the Kingswood-Oxford faculty as an English teacher in 1967 and served as chairman of the English department from 1972 to 1992. In 1983, he founded the school's English Symposium, which has brought renowned authors such as Arthur Miller, E.L. Doctorow and William Styron to campus. He also served the school as director of professional development, coordinator of Advanced Placement programs, director of publications and public relations, co-chair of the diversity committee and faculty advisor to the student newspaper. He served as chairman of the Burlington Town Democratic Committee from 1992 to 1998. He also served on the Board of Education for Regional District #

title: Yes, There Is Still a Place for Stock-Picking
description: I HAVE a new entry for Ripley's Believe It or Not: Even if you believe no portfolio manager can consistently pick winning stocks, you should still keep the bulk of your portfolio in actively managed mutual funds, not indexed ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, WILLIAM COOK
description: SIMPSON-William Cook, suddenly on March 29, 2000. Age 81. Beloved husband of Sylvia P. Father of W. James (Leslie), Webster Young and Scott Young (Lolet). Brother of Mary. Grandfather of Abigail McKenzie, River Young, Pearl Young and Grace Young. Service First Presbyterian Church, Oyster Bay, Monday, April 3rd at 11AM. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers a donation may be made to the church.

title: Rare Sight, Urban Delight: Birds of Prey on the Wing In the Concrete Canyons
description: Not everyone would have noticed. But about five weeks ago, Laurel Fox, an occupational therapist at St. Luke's Hospital, was watering some African violets and hibiscus in the hospital's ninth-floor solarium when she spied a large red-tailed hawk swooping between her building and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Music; Tucker, a Multi-Everything Performer
description: NANCY TUCKER is a marketing nightmare. She is an accomplished singer-songwriter, musician and comedienne just as comfortable performing a 10 a.m. kids show as a 10 p.m. show for their parents. How can people remember her when they never see her do the same show twice?

title: Toscanini at La Scala
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline last Sunday about President Clinton's meeting with Pakistan's ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, misstated the ruler's title in some copies. The general, who seized power in October, named himself chief executive, not president.

title: The Ugliest American
description: Hamdi Shabiu is an almost excessively humble man, grateful for attention, quick to provide coffee and a seat in the one warm room of the poor little house he and his family occupy in the Kosovo town of Vitina. Shabiu is a refugee, the house a temporary refuge from the harsh winter of Kosovo and from the harsh war that preceded it. But when the 41-year-old Albanian brings an American visitor barely 20 yards from his front door to the dingy basement of a nearby building where an American sergeant is accused of sexually assaulting and then murdering his 11-year-old daughter, his politeness splinters, cracks and drops away in jagged pieces, and Shabiu finally sobs, propped against the filthy wall.

title: In Brief; Preserving 100 Acres
description: Emphasizing his commitment to the preservation of open space, County Executive Andrew J. Spano joined Gov. George E. Pataki and other officials last week in announcing the protection of Harbor Hills, 100 acres along the Hudson River in the town of Cortlandt. The property is adjacent to George's Island, a 204-acre, county-owned park, which is one of the few points of public access to the Hudson River in Westchester.

title: INVESTING WITH: Jackson W. Robinson; Green Century Balanced Fund
description: WHEN he's not at work, or sailing in Maine's Penobscot Bay in a Wianno Senior -- a 25-foot-long wooden-hulled sloop -- Jackson W. Robinson tends to the organic vegetables in his garden.

title: Beating a Vast Underground Conspiracy
description: THE extra hour of daylight is a gift for gardeners. They can go at it with alacrity and speed.

title: Asian Values, Trumped By the New Economy
description: WHATEVER happened to ''Asian values?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, EUGENE
description: KATZ-Eugene. On March 28th. Beloved husband of Zeborah Schachtel and the late Florine Klingenstein. Mourned by children Barbara Eisold, Daniel and John Katz, 7 grand and 5 great grandchildren. A pioneer at Katz Communications and past Chairman of the Board at Planned Parenthood, NY. We will never forget his ongoing capacity for concern.

title: In All 5 Boroughs, High Goes Higher

description: Nineteen-year-old twin brothers were found shot in the head early yesterday, their bodies dumped into the middle of a residential street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn.

title: Conversations With Sondheim
description: Sondheim continues to distract from his own genius by his inability to appreciate those who came before him. To say that my uncle (Hart of Rodgers and Hart) wrote nothing but ironic love songs is the same as saying Shakespeare only wrote about kings and murder. As to the ''sloppy'' work, my uncle hated conformity and deliberately broke the ''rules'' of writing lyrics (and just about every other rule around) to tweak the nose of the establishment. At a mature age, Sondheim should be comfortable enough with his own talent to lighten up a little.

description: A young man walked over to another man who was sitting at a table, leaned over and embraced him, placing the side of his face against the older man's back for emphasis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JAMES C.
description: SMITH-James C. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James C. Smith, associated with The Times from 1965 until retiring in 1984.

title: Characters and the Streets That Are Their Stage
description: CHARACTERS: New York is full of them. Here are three recent books that contain some vivid portraits. The first is a collection of nonfiction by Lawrence Weschler, a staff writer at The New Yorker. Among them is a profile of the cartoonist Ben Katchor, a man who seems to thrive in the city's more desolate corners. The second is Mitchell Duneier's study of street vendors in Greenwich Village, among them Hakim Hasan, who left the corporate world to sell books on the sidewalk. Finally, there is Chuck Katz's guide to Manhattan film locations, a book in which the city itself is the biggest character.

title: Elisa Kashar, Bruce Akrongold
description: Elisa Ann Kashar and Bruce Robert Akrongold were married last evening by Rabbi Yisroel Jungreis at the Pierre in New York.

title: Saving the Snake River Salmon
description: The Clinton administration has been willing to challenge 70 years of accepted public policy that hydroelectric dams are by definition a good thing. Led by Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt, it has pressed the contrarian notion that dams that are doing more harm than good -- to fish stocks, to watersheds and to the environment generally -- ought to come down. Several dams have in fact been destroyed in the last few years. But these dams have been relatively small, and the administration now faces a huge test of its resolve -- whether to order the breaching of four large hydroelectric dams on the lower Snake River in eastern Washington State. The purpose would be to restore 140 miles of the river to its natural free-flowing state and greatly increase the chances for survival of the river's depleted salmon populations.

title: The Guide
description: Art Exhibition

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the cover of The Times Magazine today for an article about an American Army officer accused of the rape and murder of an Albanian girl in Kosovo refers imprecisely to the status of the case. The officer has been charged but has not yet been brought to trial.

title: A Beer Hall With Home-Grown Czech Nostalgia
description: Absinthe as described by Oscar Wilde to Mrs. Leverson, his hairdresser: ''After the first glass, you see things as you wish they were. After the second, you see things as they are not. Finally, you see things as they really are and that is the most horrible thing in the world!''

title: By The Way; High Art
description: There are so many planes in the air, most of us barely notice. But members of the American Society of Aviation Artists are not a bit jaded. About 150 of their loving portrayals of aircraft are on display until April 15 at the Art for Living Gallery in Butler, in ''Masterpiece Aviation Art Miniatures.'' Among the painters are some of the big names in aviation art, including Keith Ferris, Gil Cohen and Nixon Galloway. Another artist is Michael O'Neal of New Brunswick, whose focus is on World War I. His ''Sharks,'' shown here, is one of a series documenting the flying career of Quentin Roosevelt, youngest son of Theodore Roosevelt. ''Sharks'' shows two German Albatros fighters, the type that shot Quentin Roosevelt down. The Art of Living Gallery, 1360 Route 23 North, Butler, (973) 838-7767, is open Tuesdays to Fridays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Saturdays 9 to 4, and Sundays 11 to 4. Admission is free. Fifty of the paintings can be seen on the gallery's Web site, www.ArtForLivingGallery.com.

description: SCHWARZER - Selma. Beloved wife of the late Nathan, devoted mother of Edward and Ellen, cherished grandmother of Suzanne and Karen, dear sister of Shepard Levinsky and loving aunt. Donations may be made to Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisades Ave., Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: A Literary Ghost In the H.M.O Debate
description: GIVEN the transformation of American medicine over the last 75 years, Dr. Martin Solomon, a central figure in this Tuesday's edition of the PBS documentary series ''Frontline,'' has little in common with Dr. Martin Arrowsmith, the hero of Sinclair Lewis's famous 1925 novel that bears his name. But they share a chronic discontent: a feeling that they are trapped between the duty to practice their profession conscientiously and the pressures of a market society. The complaint, rooted in a clash between the principles of Hippocrates and those of Adam Smith, may not be fully curable.

title: Filling Seats With Online Discounts
description: TICKET discounts for online customers, already favored by the airlines for filling empty seats, are rapidly spreading to sports -- and entertainment might be next. But the same technology that allows discounts is also likely to allow higher prices for some of the sports and entertainment seats that everyone wants.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: IN examining executive compensation, Money & Business sought this year to capture the differences between the pay practices of companies in the old economy of industrial, service and financial concerns and those in the new economy of Internet and related businesses.

title: Conversations With Sondheim
description: You brought back memories of conversations I had with Stephen Sondheim as we traveled by train together at holiday times, in 1945-46, from our Manhattan homes to the George School in Bucks County, Pa., where I was a freshman and Steve a senior. Four years later, I was a freshman and he a senior at Williams College, where, in 1950, he wrote an original musical comedy, ''Phinney's Rainbow.'' James Phinney Baxter 3rd was president of Williams at the time. The show was hilarious (sophomore humor?), and I wonder if Steve still has the score.

title: Dining Out; Good- Looking Food With Taste To Match
description: UNLESS you're a golfer, you've probably never heard of Alfred's at the Colonial Springs Golf Club. My first assessment of this newcomer was: gorgeous dining room, standard surf and turf stuff, probably more show than go. I was wrong. There is someone in the kitchen with talent and style adding sparkle to a mundane menu. That someone is Glenn Mitchell, a German-trained chef, who was most recently at the Hamlet Golf and Country Club in Commack.

description: A federal appeals court has rejected the latest effort by an inmate to avoid execution next week, 18 years after he was convicted of killing a Memphis police officer in an armed robbery.

title: In the Studio With/Jerry Silverman; Chronicling Music of the Holocaust
description: MOST folksinger-songwriters are content to write and sing folk songs, but ever since Jerry Silverman of Hastings-on-Hudson devoted his master's thesis to blues guitar technique, there has been more than a bit of the teacher in him.

title: No-Worry Beads
description: Last year, Stella Pace's power-bead bracelets were the way to love and good fortune. This season, Paige Roberts's chakra bracelets, named for what yoga regards as the body's centers of psychic power, take beads to another level. A set of seven ($68 at all Intermix stores) come in colors for each ailing chakra. The store owners report that turquoise (''I am creativity'') and orange (''I am passion'') are most sought after. The line also includes indigo (''I am insight''), red (''balance'') green and pink (''love''), yellow (''confidence'') and purple (''I am infinite''). Who wants to feel finite?

title: Buried in Clothes, a Closet Cries Out
description: MY bedroom closet -- the walk-in variety -- was out of Edgar Allan Poe. Every time I tried to enter, the walls seemed to close in on me. Sweaters were piled six deep, purses toppled off dusty hat boxes, and costume jewelry was tangled up with Halloween costumes. Looking for my favorite fleece dog-walking outfit, I was often buried beneath a heap of feather boas.

title: Travel Advisory: Coorrespondent's Report; New York to Hong Kong Via the North Pole
description: LOPPING hours off flights between North America and Asia, regular commercial jet service over the North Pole is to start July 1, the fruit of a growing partnership between Canadian and Russian air traffic controllers.

description: STANLEY TUCCI has a special allegiance to the grand movie palaces of yesteryear and to the Paramount Theater in particular, a childhood stomping ground and community treasure that he and others are striving to safeguard.

title: Frugal Traveler; Wine and Mud in Napa
description: MUD was on our minds. We imagined its weight, its density, its smell. During the long month leading up to our three-day February getaway, my friend Karrie and I anticipated our trip to the Napa Valley in a string of eager e-mail messages. Napa, with its natural mud baths and hot springs, is no news to Northern Californians, of course -- for them it is weekend getaway central, as Woodstock or the Hamptons are to New Yorkers. But Napa was a novelty for Karrie, recently transplanted to San Francisco, and for me.

The money will be used to refurbish all 15 city schools -- 11 elementary schools, 2 middle schools and 2 high schools -- and wire them for the Internet. The state will reimburse the district $72 million for the repairs.

title: Conversations With Sondheim

At the age of 58, Irving Berlin turned out, arguably, his greatest score, ''Annie Get Your Gun.'' At 57, Cole Porter composed ''Kiss Me Kate.'' And at 55, Sondheim stunned us with ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' which won a Pulitzer.

title: I.R.S. Sees Increase In Evasion of Taxes On Gifts to Heirs
description: To save on taxes, Americans routinely understate the value of what they give their heirs, particularly stock in family-owned businesses and real estate, new data from the Internal Revenue Service shows. But the agency has almost no resources to stop the problem, and a recently passed law has only increased the chances of not getting caught.

title: A Lesson in Turning Memories Into Memoirs; In the Pink and Oh So Proud
description: While my mother was pregnant with me, the doctors told her to expect a boy because the baby inside her was always kicking and tossing . . . . A son was exactly what she didn't want; and she hoped and prayed to anyone who was listening that her child would be born a girl. She declared the date of my birth the happiest day of her life because she got exactly what she had requested: a girl. However, sometimes it is thought that she asked too much or prayed too hard for a daughter -- I grew to be so much of a stereotypical girl that I was unrecognizable to my bold mother . . . . When she was a toddler, my sister's curly brown hair was cut short and my mother always dressed her in OshKosh B'Gosh corduroy overalls -- usually navy blue, just like my mother's outfits. Even though I worshiped my big sister, I wouldn't dream of wearing her filthy hand-me-downs. Not me, the Princess. Blue was definitely not an accepted part of my two-year-old wardrobe. My outfits were arranged in red and pink. Pink was the most precious thing on earth, and any object colored with it was beautiful, especially my clothing. A dress covering my little body put a smile on my face and turned me into this gorgeous celebrity that would sing and dance around the slippery living room floor in socks until she collapsed from exhaustion. . . .

title: Susan Dillon, R. Mark Cox
description: Susan Alexandra Dillon, a daughter of Maureen and Donald Dillon of Teaneck, N.J., was married last evening to R. Mark Cox, a son of Evelyn and Herbert Cox of Cornelius, N.C. The Rev. title: The Tax Man
description: RAY CICCONE, painfully stuttering through his youth, rose from poverty to become the architect of the accounting systems for some of Atlantic City's biggest casinos and the savior of a chunk of Donald Trump's empire.

title: Dimmed Promise in Prague
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright expected a warm reception when she visited her native Prague last month. But even she was surprised to learn shortly before her arrival that President Vaclav Havel intended to propose her as a possible successor. Beyond his admiration for Dr. Albright, Mr. Havel was trying to register a larger point. In the decade since the Velvet Revolution against Communist rule, Prague's political leaders have compiled a record of disillusioning failure, including the fracturing of Czechoslovakia into separate Czech and Slovak states in 1993. No one of Mr. Havel's stature has yet emerged to replace him when his term expires in 2003.

title: After the Explosion, The Aroma Still Pleased
description: What was baking in our oven was not a cake or even a souffle: it looked more like a mini (not so mini actually, since it filled much of the oven before it exploded) Mount Etna, Mount Kilimanjaro or Mount Fuji -- even after I had reduced the baking powder and baking soda to a quarter of the amount.

title: The Man With the X-Ray Eyes
