Rather, it was the shabbier fringes of the spruced-up district, where old buildings like a gaudy adults-only theater on Eighth Avenue called the Playpen stand like relics of another age.

title: A Clock to See You Through The Next 10,000 Years
description: WITH a clickety-click and a Zen Buddhist gong punctuating the ceremony, some of the people most associated with the dizzying acceleration of the culture ushered in slowness as the new frontier. They activated the prototype of The Clock of the Long Now, the tool designed to measure the next 10,000 years and beyond.

title: Dance; Moving, Joyfully and Carefully, Into Old Age
description: A couple years ago I was teaching a technique class in Athens, bringing my usual mix of youthful vigor and sorrowful limitation due to age. At one point I apologized for being old, and a chorus of Greek voices called out, Oh no, you are very young. Without thinking, I responded: You're right, I am young. But my spine is old.

title: Travel Advisory; From Dallas to Dulles And Back for $306
description: Legend Airlines, which will offer all first-class seating at coach prices, was scheduled to begin flying on Friday from Love Field, near downtown Dallas, to Dulles Airport in Washington, Los Angeles and Las Vegas. In response, American Airlines, which dominates traffic at Dallas-Fort Worth airport and which went to court to block the new carrier, said it plans to offer similar service from Love Field as quickly as possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOGHUE, NORA ANN

Adored daughter of Martin and Peggy Furey. Cherished sister of Mary, Margaret, Helen, Micheal, Theresa, Martin and Ann. Loving aunt, sister-in-law and daughter-in-law. title: Time for Pruners

Cut back lateral growth to three to five dormant buds. A plant started from seed will take decades to bloom and even the best grafted specimens may take three or more years.

description: The review of Purdys Homestead in North Salem [''Dining Out: New Restaurant in an Old Farmhouse''] on March 12 mentioned not only some of the delicious dishes served but also the delightful new decor, including many ''contemporary paintings.''

title: At Meeting, 3 Workers Tell Their Stories

Mr. Diakite, who works at the Food Emporium at 74th Street and Broadway in Manhattan, said that until a recent promotion he was paid just $1 for each delivery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGFAN, MARION A.
description: LANGFAN-Marion A. On March 30, 2000. Beloved, beautiful and devoted wife of William K. Langfan. Loving, caring, wise and most precious mother of Robin Hammer, Mark Langfan and Dayna Langfan. Caring and thoughtful motherin-law of Jay Hammer and Lawrence Heller. Nurturing and kind grandmother of Benjamin Hammer, Justin Langfan, David, Bennett, Penelope and Eve Heller. Cherished sister of Ruth Howard and Harriet Steinfeld and brotherin-law Philip Steinfeld. You shared with us your love of music, art, literature and style, and encouraged us to look for beauty within. Your beauty, spirit and devotion touched us all and will be with us always. Memorial service Friday, April 14, 2:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory can be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: A La Carte; Slice of the Auld Sod in Garden City Park
description: EVERY day is St. Patrick's Day at McGillicuddy's Irish Inn. There's Irish soda bread on the tables, bangers and mash on the menu and songs from the auld sod in the air at this neat nook at 2232 Jericho Turnpike in Garden City Park (516-746-7590). Spiffy lasses attired in white shirts and emerald-green ties provide smooth service in a dining room of tasteful green sponge-painted walls, white table cloths and green napery. The decorative mirror in the bar proclaims Guinness, and the brew is put to good use in a dish or two as well as in many a glass. To the frequent accompaniment of bagpipes, drums and fifes playing gigs and reels (no, it isn't exactly dinner music, but it fits), neighborhood patrons, many of whom seem to know each other, eat not sublime, subtle gourmet morsels, but big blunt country fare.

title: Echoes of a Closing Door

In 1997, he set up the Blanche and Julian Robertson Family Foundation with $18 million, about half in cash, the other half in his hedge fund. ''Our success depends in part on its success,'' said Federal District Court Judge Bill Kluttz, the foundation board president, after hearing of the planned shutdown. But as Judge Kluttz said, even a somewhat reduced foundation would have a great impact on a town of 25,000. It has already given nearly $3.5 million to education, neighborhood revitalization, youth health and community planning. DEAN SMITH

title: Stretching for Fashion
description: Now that yoga has achieved a higher plane of style consciousness, saffron robes are just too bland. Men and women sport Speedos and bikinis to sweat in high-temperature bikram yoga classes, and students wear shimmering gold harem pants and hand-painted tank tops at the Jivamukti Yoga Center. To keep apace, clothing manufacturers are creating yoga collections. Next month, the model Christy Turlington, with Puma Sport, will introduce Nuala, above, a line of soft neutral pants, shirts and hoodies designed for yoga use ($60 to $110). Zen Sport by Danskin offers knit drawstring pants ($78), tanks ($56) and waffle shorts ($52), all at Saks Fifth Avenue. J. Crew has stretchy yoga pants ($48), bras ($24) and sleeveless tops called Om shells ($28). The Jivamukti center and Equinox Fitness Clubs are selling their own yoga lines (popular at Equinox are $28 shirts silk-screened with Chinese characters that translate as ''energy, harmony, Equinox''). And street wear like Muriel Brandolini's brightly painted drawstring scrubs ($250 at Bergdorf Goodman) and American Eagle's embroidered Indian-inspired tanks ($15.50) and keyhole T-shirts ($24) are being adapted for the mat. Aren't such fashion concerns too material for yogis? ''A large part of yoga is about trying to look your best, dressing for God or the beloved,'' said Adrienne Burke, head of the teaching program at the Jivamukti center. ''You want to look good because you want to see the divine in yourself. If you look divine, you feel divine.''

After making unannounced visits to the hospital the monitoring committee's report said: ''Idle patients are living in a physical and psychological environment that, at best, strains the meaning of 'humane.' Patient rights to privacy and safety are not ensured.'' It was one in a long series of problems reported over the years about the hospital. In the mid-1990's the hospital was put under special supervision because of reports of female patients being sexually assaulted by staff members, escapes of criminal patients and a suicide while staff members slept. title: Out of Order; If You Ask Me, It's All a Waste of Time
description: A DOCTOR'S office is a good place to study the different styles of wasting time. Patients are stacked up like jets waiting to land. The sign-in sheet reveals that two or three patients have been scheduled in every time slot, and that my own appointment (so carefully confirmed over the phone) bears about as much relation to reality as a presidential campaign promise. Some people bring books to read, or bury themselves in important-looking paperwork. More technologically up-to-date patients occupy themselves with laptops and cell phones. Those who arrived empty-handed, with a pathetic faith in their appointment time, are reduced to reading about the forgotten celebrities of last month in old copies of People magazine. The more elderly and infirm are asleep, or perhaps dead. The doctors are apparently out to lunch, or on vacation, but the unflappable receptionist will never admit it. If wasting time is a sin, then medical offices are dens of iniquity.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Snapshots of a Nation
description: Ambitious, intellectual and prickly, Walker Evans (1903-75) was driven to stake out territory not already claimed by Stieglitz and Steichen, the two reigning American photographers in the early 1930's. The goal Evans set himself was to tell the truth, and for him the truth resided in the unvarnished ordinary. Like many artists from a privileged background before and since, he searched for authenticity among the urban working class and the rural poor and in the commonplace, man-made landscape -- buildings, signs, storefronts. He created a photographic style that gave the illusion of objectivity and, as proof of his success in elevating the status of the documentary photograph, the Museum of Modern Art chose him as the first photographer to have a solo exhibit, in 1938. In 1994 the Metropolitan Museum of Art acquired the entire Evans collection, an unmined trove of papers, personal memorabilia and disintegrating negatives. Five years of sifting, sorting, conserving, printing, researching, writing, organizing and fund-raising have resulted in a notable archive, a major exhibition and a masterly catalog, WALKER EVANS (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Princeton University, $65). Maria Morris Hambourg, Jeff L. Rosenheim, Douglas Eklund and Mia Fineman, curators and scholars from the museum, have contributed the book's six learned and lucid essays, which focus on Evans's artistic development and distinct phases of his work as well as his lesser-known photographs. The rich reproductions show the range of Evans's work, while the essays provide context for his achievements and, by showing his influence on leading members of the next generation like Robert Frank and Lee Friedlander, establish Evans's seminal importance in the evolution of the documentary photograph. UNCLASSIFIED: A Walker Evans Anthology (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Scalo, $39.95), a further collaboration of Rosenheim and Eklund, gives a more intimate look at the Evans archive with reproductions from the photographer's family albums, contact sheets, correspondence and working notes. Rosemary Ranck

title: The He Hormone
description: It has a slightly golden hue, suspended in an oily substance and injected in a needle about half as thick as a telephone wire. I have never been able to jab it suddenly in my hip muscle, as the doctor told me to. Instead, after swabbing a small patch of my rump down with rubbing alcohol, I push the needle in slowly until all three inches of it are submerged. Then I squeeze the liquid in carefully, as the muscle often spasms to absorb it. My skin sticks a little to the syringe as I pull it out, and then an odd mix of oil and blackish blood usually trickles down my hip.

description: SOSIS-Ruth. Wife of the late Zachary. Mother of Dr. Howard, Dr. Mitchel and Syrena. Donations to needy individuals rather than organized charities would be appreciated.

title: Conversations With Sondheim
description: At 70, Sondheim looks as if he's ready to play Tevye in ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' Kudos to Frank Rich for his up-to-the-minute portrait. It was a delight to find him once again writing about the theater and its people.

title: Cambodia
description: To the Editor: While many of your readers undoubtedly appreciate knowing about inexpensive accommodations in Siem Reap, some may be interested in a delightful and more expensive alternative mentioned briefly by Ms. McLane. The closest hotel to the Angkor temples is the Grand, also in Siem Reap. Thoroughly redone some two years ago, the Grand Hotel has the comforts, charm and luxury associated with other hotels run by the operators of Raffles in Singapore. They have done a superb job: the rooms are lovely (and air-conditioned), the public spaces open and appropriately furnished, the amenities ample, and the food as good as any in the area. After a day scampering in the heat, a respite at the Grand is soothing and restorative.

title: Vast Trade in Forced Labor Portrayed in C.I.A. Report
description: As many as 50,000 women and children from Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe are brought to the United States under false pretenses each year and forced to work as prostitutes, abused laborers or servants, according to a Central Intelligence Agency report that is the government's first comprehensive assessment of the problem.

description: A YEAR ago, Rachel Griffiths was an Oscar nominee for her supporting role in ''Hilary and Jackie''; this year, the Australian actress, who looks like Juliette Lewis without the hurt eyes, spent Oscar week driving cross-country with her brother Samuel.

The Borgata, looking as much as it can like a Tuscan village, will open its doors on an expanse that used to be a city landfill, putting 3,000 more people to work and paying more than $10 million a year in property taxes.

description: Only 18 months ago Julian Robertson's Tiger Management had $22 billion in capital, and could leverage that capital into huge speculative positions. Whole nations trembled at the prospect that the mighty hedge fund might attack their currencies or stock markets. But by last week, between heavy losses and withdrawals by disillusioned investors, Tiger was down to $6.5 billion; and on Friday Mr. Robertson announced he was closing up shop.

title: Television/Radio; Why America Has to Judge Amy's Mother
description: THIS is a cultural quiz. What is the name of Amy's mother, played by the feminist icon Tyne Daly, on the CBS series ''Judging Amy''? For those unaware that network television is providing a fascinating but in some ways depressing representation of relations between a mother and her adult children, drop in on the show. It has been in the top 10 in the Nielsens. The series demonstrates what a vigorous life maternal stereotypes lead in America despite three decades of feminist activism.

title: You Know, Mom, What's That Guy's Name? You Know, Mom, He's Sorta Like -- Dick Clark
description: Sometimes on MTV's ''Total Request Live,'' there is a contest to guess the identity of a music group based on a teasing snippet from one of its videos. Because thousands and thousands of the show's teenage viewers phone in, just being the one who makes it through is itself a triumph. But when Christina from Massachusetts called one Friday, her voice conveyed none of the usual excitement. If anything, she sounded sad and unsure of herself.

description: WESTON-Jeffrey. To Beverly, the late Mac, Irene, Samantha, and Burton, we mourn your great loss. So many years of joy and sorrow together. Our heartfelt sympathy. The Winikoff Family

title: March 26-April 1; A Film Triumph Is Born
description: What began as one of the tightest and least predictable Oscar races in years ended up as a fairly predictable love fest for ''American Beauty,'' a comedy about suburban dysfunction that quietly grew in the weeks since the nominations were announced to become the obvious favorite. The film won awards for best picture, Kevin Spacey's lead performance, for the first-time director Sam Mendes, for the veteran cinematographer Conrad L. Hall and for the first-time screenwriter Alan Ball. Many thought it would also win best actress for Annette Bening, but that award went to a relative newcomer, Hilary Swank, for her widely praised performance in ''Boys Don't Cry.'' The film that was expected to give ''American Beauty'' its biggest competition, Lasse Hallstrom's ''The Cider House Rules,'' came away with two awards, for Michael Caine's supporting performance and for John Irving's adapted screenplay. ''The Insider,'' which came into the awards with seven nominations, and ''The Sixth Sense,'' which came in with six, went home empty-handed.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Strengthening Retail on Garden City's Franklin Ave.
description: WHEN Gary Kahres, an owner of the Medical Shop at 949 Franklin Avenue, took over his Garden City store 20 years ago, he recalled recently, business was booming along the avenue, a thoroughfare that stretches southward from Old Country Road.

description: RODNON-Dorothy S., (nee Schonfeld) of Hollywood, Florida, formerly of New York City and Jersey City, New Jersey, passed away March 29, 2000. Beloved sister of Bernard M. Schonfeld of Aventura, Florida. Survived by adored nieces Rita Alter, Sybil Preisler, Norma Feldman, Sheryl Greenberg, and nephew Dr. Sanford Shapiro. Also survived by cherished grandnieces and grandnephews, great-great grandnieces and great-great grandnephews as well as a stepchild, step-grandchil dren and step-great grandchildren. Graveside services Sunday, April 2 at 11:00 A.M., Knollwood Park Cemetery, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice. In Groton, a large blue plywood cutout of a submarine welcomes visitors to the ''Submarine Capital of the World,'' and few places can dispute that title.

title: Art in Venice
description: To the Editor: Your European survey (''What's Hot at the Museums,'' March 12) says that ''Any excuse to stay a spell in Venice is the right excuse.'' But it leaves out a wonderful exhibition, ''Cosmos,'' which opened in Venice on March 26 at the Palazzo Grassi. I saw the version that just closed in Barcelona. It was an amalgam of oil paintings, sculptures, photographs and mixed media, including a Goya oil from 1815 showing the Montgolfier balloon, an 1854 solar eclipse series of daguerreotypes, and a gouache from Miro's Constellation series. Because of the many works of art being added, I would love to see the new version before it closes on July 23.

But nowhere in the country are the increases more astounding than in California, where they have even become noticeable to people not accustomed to worrying about such things.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Building a Neighborhood, Not Just a Subdivision

title: Forcing Hawks To Work for a Living
description: I was appalled to read that the president of the Connecticut Ornithological Society continued to leave his feeders up after it was clear that a sharp-shinned hawk had taken up residence in his yard (''Birds Hit the Feeder, Hawks Hit the Birds,'' Feb. 20). Shame on him for behavior that effectively entrapped 20 to 25 unsuspecting birds. Double shame for allowing others to believe that the proper response to a bird-eating hawk is to stand by and watch. What he should have done was to take his feeders down immediately, thereby forcing those birds taking seed or suet to disperse, which would in turn force the hawk to work for a living.

title: Art/Architecture: HERBERT MUSCHAMP; Huntington Hartford's Generous Folly
description: LAST month the city reopened the process of choosing a buyer for 2 Columbus Circle, the white marble campanile that faces Columbus Circle's southern arc. Completed in 1964, the building has stood vacant since the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs left the premises two years ago. It's an important site, partly because of the architecture and partly because of the layers of historical meaning that have settled over it. The building became eligible for landmark status in 1990. Should it be landmarked? Probably not. Which isn't to say the building isn't worthy of landmark designation. In my view, it should be the other way around. Why not spare the building and tear down our landmarks laws? Landmarking today has become a matter of some people wanting to force others to live with their childhood memories. The city is rapidly becoming one big boohoo corner, a place to lament lost Rosebuds and madeleines.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Bus Stop; The Lost Promise Of School Integration

description: During the 1940's the Palisades were alive with the sound of big bands, and so were radios picking up live broadcasts from the cliffs above the Hudson, including Frank Sinatra singing atthe Rustic Cabin in Englewood. An echo of those days can be heard Wednesdays from 7 to 10 p.m. as the Tony Corbiscello Big Band, an 18-piece ensemble is broadcast live from the Palisadium, a restaurant in Cliffside Park, over WJUX, 103.1 FM. Mr. Corbiscello is a drummer who once toured with Frank Sinatra. He is also the son of the former mayor of Fort Lee. His group will be playing at the Palisadium for five weeks and possibly longer. His CD, ''In Full Swing,'' was released in September by Alanna Records. MARGO NASH

title: The Color Of Bones
description: When Will Thomas and Dave Deacy waded along the western shore of the Columbia River one hot Sunday afternoon in 1996, they were not expecting to spark a crisis in American anthropology, or fuel a debate over the peopling of the Americas or further poison relations between Native Americans and the rest of society. The young friends were trying to sneak into the Water Follies, an annual event for residents of Richland, Kennewick and Pasco, three riverside Washington towns just north of Oregon that are known as the Tri-Cities. Then Thomas hit something hard and round with his foot. He picked it up and saw that it was a skull. Thomas and Deacy stashed it in some bushes, then turned their attention to the final Columbia Cup hydroplane race, the highlight of the follies.

title: Cell Calls
description: To the Editor: Frank Gasparro, in his letter about Amtrak (''Train or Plane,'' March 5), put his finger on the reason why I will choose the plane rather than the train. He wrote: ''With space, my laptop and my cell phone, I can accomplish a lot as I travel to Philadelphia.'' The last time I took Amtrak to Washington, I was in cell-phone torment for the whole trip, so until Amtrak puts on cell-phone-free cars the way they used to have nonsmoking cars, I will continue to fly. title: Gym Dandies
description: As the season changes to spring, the fashion world is changing its handbag -- from the familiar Fendi baguette shoulder bag to a utilitarian gym bag, the kind young people carried before backpacks. Many of the fashion editors and their followers in Paris and New York, who were first to carry the baguette two years ago, are now carrying this Miuccia Prada bag, which captures the plainness that Ms. Prada champions. This sudden change plays out the old-fashioned axiom of the eye tiring of the overly familiar and embracing the opposite aesthetic -- in this case, small to large.

title: Dallying Along the Lackawanna Trail
description: THERE is an American tradition, nearly a century old, of hopping into the family car and heading out into the countryside without an itinerary, without the need to be anywhere at a certain time. At the peak of this carefree style of travel, back in the early 20th century, it was called ''gypsying.'' Instead of a map, these weekend wanderers were guided by curiosity.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: Have there ever been more gorgeous close-ups than those of the 19-year-old Elizabeth Taylor and Montogmery Clift, a mature 31, in A PLACE IN THE SUN (1951)? From the moment George Steven's adaptation of Theordore Dreiser's novel ''An American Tragedy'' hit the screen, it was declared brilliant. Clift is touching as a poor but ambitious young man who takes a job at his rich uncle's factory and gets more than he bargained for. The boss's daughter turns out to be the heartbreakingly perfect Ms. Taylor, who adores him back (''Tell Mama all''). Unfortunately George already has a girlfriend, a colorless co-worker (Shelley Winters) who has the bad timing to become pregnant - and the bad luck to fall out of a rowboat, accompanied only by a man who has mixed feelings about saving her. Dreiser's themes - morality, cowardice and the boundaries of guilt - have never been more poignantly explored - Sunday at 8 p.m. and Sunday/Early Monday at 2:30 a.m. on AMC.

description: MANAGEMENT experts and institutional investors constantly lobby American executives to own more stock in the companies they run. Unlike options -- which, at worst, are worth nothing -- ownership of actual shares brings a downside. When investors lose money, so do the people running the company.

title: Elie Tahari and Rory Green
description: ANY working woman older than 30 in New York can probably remember her first Tahari suit. Somewhere between Armani and Talbots in price, they are often bought by women after their first promotion. I remember buying my first Tahari in 1992, the year my bank account leapt from three digits to four. It was purple, with gold buttons like stars, and while I could wear it to the office, it had the tight-fitting, slightly subversive feel of a cat suit.

title: Film; This Time, the Sex Pistols' Point of View
description: EARLY on in ''The Filth and the Fury,'' the new documentary about the British punk-rock band the Sex Pistols, the group's endlessly quotable lead singer John Lydon (a k a Johnny Rotten) observes that the group was ''a bit like a Harold Pinter play: it shouldn't work, but it does.'' The same could be said of the movie that Julien Temple has assembled from footage of the band in performance, along with new and archival interviews with the band members, their supporters and their detractors.

title: 'Leave Him Alone'
description: Did you really buy Steve Salerno's Lives column (March 12) about aiming a rifle at two cops in 1975? I believe he carried a rifle in his car. I believe he witnessed a couple of cops beating up a black guy. The rest of it is liberal guilt and ''Lone Ranger'' fantasy. Who was that masked man?

title: Condom Giveaway Urged For Infected in Putnam
description: WITH Putnam County facing an increase in sexually transmitted diseases, Robert J. Bondi, the county executive, has recommended that condoms be distributed -- at taxpayers' expense -- to infected residents.

title: Theater; In Default on the Rent, In Default on Life: One Can Be Cured
description: John Clancy, the artistic director of the Present Company, a nonprofit theater on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, was notified in early January that the company owed its landlord, Brookshire Equities, $137,000, which it would have to pay almost immediately. A settlement was ultimately worked out, but the experience prompted Mr. Clancy, a co-founder of the New York International Fringe Festival, to write a one-man show titled ''Notice of Default and Opportunity to Cure,'' which he is performing at the Present Company Theatorium on Stanton Street through April 22. Here are excerpts from the show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, DOROTHY T.
description: KAUFMANN-Dorothy T. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Dorothy T. Kaufmann, associated with The Times from 1927 until retiring in 1973.

title: Television/Radio; Remembering A Sensation In Cincinnati
description: EXACTLY 10 years ago this Friday, Dennis Barrie woke up in a good mood, went to work and became the first American museum director known to be indicted for doing his job. Mr. Barrie, then 42 and director of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati, was well aware that there were objections to the new exhibition there: photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe, which included depictions of sadomasochistic homosexual acts and portraits of nude children. Business leaders had pressured the center to cancel the show, but the opening for museum members the evening before had gone smoothly, so Mr. Barrie was optimistic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article last Sunday about the yachtsman Bill Koch and articles he recently wrote misidentified the publisher of an Internet sailing newsletter, Scuttlebutt. It is published by Tom Leweck in Southern California in partnership with boats.com, a San Francisco-based Internet group, not by the Bayview Yacht Club in Detroit.

title: Music; A Pop Beat and Playful Lyrics
description: THE first thing you notice about any of the Kennedys' songs is the duo's unabashed pop beat and playful lyrics. That, combined with an excellent sense of musicianship, makes them hard to resist.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about shopping for fashion bargains in discount stores, many of them making well-designed consumer products accessible to the average buyer, misstated the given name of the designer who has created a line of housewares for Target stores. He is Michael Graves, not Robert.

description: WILLA CATHER AND THE POLITICS

title: Immigrants Flock to Union Banner at a Forum
description: Immigrant workers, a huge but often voiceless group, were given a chance to speak up yesterday, and speak they did: about abuses on the job, about mandatory 70-hour weeks, about not being allowed to take bathroom breaks, about making just $2 an hour.

title: March 26-April 1; Failure Is Reported For Clean Air Act
description: When Congress enacted amendments to the Clean Air Act in 1990, environmentalists hailed them as powerful weapons in the fight to reduce acid rain. But a new federal report showed that many lakes, ponds and streams in the Northeast, particularly in the Adirondack Mountains, are continuing to turn acidic and are in growing danger of becoming lifeless.

title: Footlights; The Kind of Shooting You Want
description: California, of course, has more films made than any other state. New York is No. 2, no surprise either. But New Jersey is in the big leagues itself, at No. 5, according to a recent survey by Variety about location shooting. (Nos. 3 and 4 were Florida and Illinois.) Joseph Friedman, director of the New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission, was pleased and a bit surprised. ''We used to consider ourselves in the lower part of the top 10,'' he said. Among Jersey-location movies coming soon are Keeping the Faith'' Nd ''Shaft Returns.'' CARL SOMMERS

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-2-00: Questions for Ryan Zacharia; Big Bull on Campus
description: Q: You are the C.E.O. of Zeal Network, which you recently incorporated. What does the company actually do?

title: The View From/New Haven; At Film Festival, 60 Movies Over Three Days
description: REMEMBER when the Sundance Film Festival was a radical idea? These days, film festivals are a dime-a-dozen, or so claims Nina Adams, director of Film Fest New Haven 2000.

title: The Fight for a Home for Ailing Children
description: THE health care community recognized the need for hospice care in adults about 30 years ago, but is slower in its thinking about end-of-life care for children. Amy S. Kuhner, a pastoral counselor with a master's degree from Yale Divinity School, said she believed that dying children belong in a place of their own. She said England has 19 children's hospices; the United States has not one.

title: Shad and Sorrel, a Marriage That Fits the Season
description: THE point when winter turns to spring is marked by the arrival of shad and shad roe in the market. ''It is the last word of Lent but a word that triumphs!'' wrote a Frenchman, Charles Monselet, in the 19th century, adding, ''What a beautiful fish, shining with silver! The banks of the river are all but lighted by it when the fishing boats are emptied at twilight. It is the aquatic hazelnut!''

title: March 26-April 1; OPEC Votes to Raise Oil Production
description: After one of its most raucous meetings in years, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to pump a modest additional amount of oil, a move that should at least slow the recent surge in oil and gasoline prices. Iran tried to rebel, arguing that OPEC was caving in to political pressure from the United States. But Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest producer by far, ultimately forced it and all the other countries to raise their official quotas by 1.7 million barrels a day.

title: A Lesson in Turning Memories Into Memoirs; The Icing on the Cookies
description: From diapers, straight up through the middle of elementary school, my after-school schedule was set. My life was at Town Hall. I lived, worked, and played beside my mom and her co-workers. Sure, I had no idea what anybody was working on, but I knew it was important.

title: CHINA INDICATING CAUTION ON TAIWAN
description: Chinese leaders have told the United States that they plan to stick with a ''wait and see'' attitude toward Taiwan's new president and that they are open to resuming a dialogue with the estranged island, a senior administration official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLBEN, SONJA
description: KOLBEN-Sonja. On March 29, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Felix. Loving mother of Alex and Nancy and Irene and Michel. Adoring grandmother of Kevin, Deborah, Nathalie and Jonathan. She will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Travel Advisory; Van Gogh Portraits Tour the United States
description: Van Gogh lovers, take note: museums in Detroit, Boston and Philadelphia have found a new theme for exploring the artist's perennially popular works -- ''Van Gogh: Face to Face,'' the first exhibition to focus on his portraits.

title: March 26-April 1; Rising Death Toll in Uganda
description: The death toll in Uganda rose day after day, as investigators turned from a theory of mass suicide to mass murder, one of the largest in history. In all, at least 725 bodies have been unearthed at four sites, all members of a doomsday cult called the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God. Many were strangled. But many show no wounds, which investigators say may suggest poison. The discoveries may not be over: the nation's president, Yoweri Museveni, said he feared the final count could reach 5,000, which appears to have been the cult's membership. IAN FISHER

title: Three Young Boxers Fighting for Respect
description: Brett Morgen recalls being somewhat skeptical when his filmmaking collaborator, Nannette Burstein, proposed that they make a documentary about boxing. Because it's a subject that's been done many times over, he knew that financial backing would be hard to come by. But Ms. Burstein was very persuasive. She had been working out for nine months with a trainer at a tiny, inner-city gym in Brooklyn and was moved by the people there and the stories they told.

title: A Slimmer Alternative: Bifold Doors
description: BIFOLD doors are a practical alternative to the swing-out doors and the sliding doors usually found in homes. They require less clearance than swing doors to open, and unlike the sliding doors installed on closets, bifold ones fold back to expose the entire contents of the closet.

title: UConn-Tennessee: Game 3 Today Is What Counts
description: There was an air of inevitability to this national championship game.

title: Is the Dutch Advantage Unsettling Europe?
description: PERHAPS you think Gucci is an Italian leather-goods maker. Perhaps you think an American company sells European teenagers those swash-logo sneakers. Or that the Rolling Stones are an English rock band.

title: Film; Hip-Hop, How They Love Ya
description: MIDWAY through ''Dogma,'' Kevin Smith's unlikely stew of millennial theology and turn-of-the-century pop culture, Loki, the voluble, sociopathic angel of death played by Matt Damon, muses on his shortcomings as a prophet of mass taste. Specifically, he still can't believe that ''E.T.'' was the Hollywood blockbuster of the 1980's, instead of ''Krush Groove,'' Michael Schultz's rags-to-riches showbiz parable featuring the rap group Run-D.M.C.

title: Michelle Horowitz, Matthew Bagan
description: Michelle Horowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Horowitz of Willowbrook, Staten Island, was married last evening to Dr. Matthew Robert Bagan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Bagan of Bridgeton, N.J. Rabbi Brian Nevins-Goldman officiated at the Westin Hotel in Bridgeton.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Talking Bluntly, Carrying a Torch
description: WHEN he ran USF&G, the insurer, in the 1990's, Norman P. Blake Jr. had such a passion for football at Purdue University, his alma mater, that he scheduled visits to the company's regional operations in the Midwest to coincide with the Boilermakers' games.

title: Zero Down, And Maybe Something To Gain
description: WHILE house-hunting in Fayetteville, N.C., a few months ago, Suzanne and Curtis Walker found themselves in an enviable quandary: they had discovered the expansive ranch house they were dreaming of, yet were reluctant to sell their investments to buy it because the stock market was performing so well.

title: A Little League Boss Shrugs Off Other Pinstripers Nearby
description: Many New Yorkers blossomed with enthusiasm for the Yankees last season, but at least one baseball fanatic said the whole thing was a bore. ''I got my own league here, I don't care what they do,'' said 88-year-old Alfredo Nazario.

title: Long Island Journal; When Medicine's Loss Is the Law's Gain
description: OTHER fathers taught their sons how to throw curveballs. Leonard Rivkin's taught him to read X-rays. And Mr. Rivkin knew what an articular fracture was before he could roller skate.

title: IDEAS & TREND: No Room for Gypsies; Across a New Europe, a People Deemed Unfit for Tolerance
description: ON the night of Feb. 7, Tibor Tancos and Vlasta Tancosova were walking along the edge of the street with their 12-year-old son, Tomas, when a drunk in a blue-green Honda ran them down with his car. Tomas survived, but his parents died.

title: Blockade Is Raising Tension for Serbia's Smaller Partner
description: Once, even after the old Yugoslavia disintegrated in bloodshed, a traveler might barely have noticed that there was a border in the mountains between Serbia and Montenegro. Other republics left the Yugoslav fold, but those two were still joined in a federation, and relations were so good that there was no need for the police to oversee the lively traffic on a practically invisible border.

description: Lecture on American Tribes

title: Eat, Drink and Be Flexible
description: Perhaps inspired by Banana Republic's yogathon to introduce its stretch line at Grand Central Terminal last fall, the latest twist on glitzy promotional events and opening parties in New York will offer not just canapes and goody bags, but also Champagne with a side of yoga. Last month, the Avon Spa entertained guests at cocktails with instruction in both yoga and reiki, a form of healing massage. Gazelle.com, an online leg-wear company gave a yoga-inspired party at the Puck Building, with Indian music, incense, aromatherapy, reflexology and foot massage. In February, the invitation to the introduction of Sundari's Nighttime Nourishing Oil promised that Sharon Gannon ''will guide us through a basic yoga class and educate us about the philosophy of ayurveda.'' And in May, the Shiseido Studio in SoHo plans to start a series of Beauty From Within yoga events for editors and customers. But when you're in a half-seated spinal twist position, how do you hold a cocktail?

title: Wall Street Conquered. And Next, The World.
description: NEVER underestimate the power of Abby Joseph Cohen. Last week, a warning about stock prices from Ms. Cohen, the formidable chief investment strategist for Goldman, Sachs & Company, singlehandedly caused a broad sell-off in markets worldwide. It left even the most seasoned traders quivering. ''When she speaks, markets move,'' one marveled to Bloomberg News.

title: One Traveler's Credo: Don't Tell, Ask
description: DON'T tell me about your trip. In gratitude, I won't tell you about mine.

title: Theater; Creation, Without Bagels
description: DURING the out-of-town tryout of my play ''Taller Than a Dwarf,'' the producer Julian Schlossberg told me that if I did a 1,000-word interview with the director Alan Arkin, The New York Times might print it and that would save him an enormous amount of money on advertising. Arkin, who meditates in between rehearsals and prays after every preview, was at first reluctant. ''I'm rehearsing and meditating and watching previews and praying,'' he said. ''When will I have the time?'' He finally agreed to answer written questions I sent him, on the condition that I never discuss the answers with him.

There Luther suggested sanctions for Jews who would not embrace his Christianity: burn their places of worship, destroy their homes, seize their prayer books and Talmudic writings and finally expel them from areas of Europe. (Lutheran church bodies have officially repudiated Luther's anti-Jewish writings.)

The additions, built in the early 1970's, are a gymnasium with a swimming pool and a building with classrooms and a cafeteria.

title: Beyond Bach the Monument, Who Was Bach the Man?

No stone or sign marked the grave site, but the excavators, guided by archival documents to look for an oaken coffin and by an oral tradition to seek a spot six paces from the south door of the church, believed they had found the earthly remains of Johann Sebastian Bach, laid to rest on July 30, 1750.

description: THE only thing, it seems, that can slow down the hyperkinetic conductor and composer Robert Kapilow is traffic on the George Washington Bridge. But he finds a great analogy to classical music in the tortuous rubbernecking.

description: New Jersey residents, businesses and towns have received more than $277 million in federal assistance to help repair damages from million in federal assistance to help repair damages from Hurricane Floyd last September, according to statistics from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Agency officials, however, are still sifting through $12.7 million in pending claims from New Jersey and expect an additional $8 million to reach the state by April 1. Several members of Congress announced last week that they would visit the congressional districts hit hardest by Floyd to listen to local officials' concerns about disaster aid. WENDY GINSBERG

title: SOUTH CAROLINA BOYCOTT
description: A coalition of state lawmakers last week introduced a resolution to boycott all official state travel to South Carolina until legislators there agree to remove the Confederate Flag from the roof of its statehouse. The resolution would prohibit elected officials from attending conferences in South Carolina because the flag ''symbolizes hatred and bigotry,'' said Assemblyman LeRoy J. Jones, Jr., a Democrat from East Orange, who sponsored the resolution in the Assembly. Governor Whitman said she opposed the resolution because New Jersey lawmakers rarely travel to South Carolina for conferences. WENDY GINSBERG

title: Air-Conditioner Viewed as an Unwelcome Backyard Guest
description: Neighbors of Mishi Asa, a Japanese restaurant that plans to open on East 49th Street between Second and Third Avenues, have been keeping their eyes on its backyard. As a result, the city has halted work on what it says was an unauthorized extension to the building.

description: TAIWAN just elected a president who has historically advocated independence for his island nation. China has repeatedly warned that any move in that direction will ignite a war. So how did investors in greater China react?

title: Footlights; Clubs Hop in Asbury Park
description: Club hopping in Asbury Park could be back, just as it was in the town's rock 'n' roll heyday of the late 1960's and the 70's. The renowned Stone Pony will ride again starting Memorial Day weekend when the new owner, Dominic Santana, plans a weekend-long series of indoor and outdoor events, including lots of live music. Now, the Fast Lane, a few blocks away on Fourth Avenue and another hot blues and rock club from back when, will reopen Friday and Saturday with a lineup of New Jersey rock 'n' roll and blues musicians, many of whom helped make Asbury Park famous three decades ago. The club plans to operate at least on weekends thereafter. Tickets for the opening concerts, which will end with a jam session each night, can be obtained through Ticketmaster. The Fast Lane's owners, Ron DeLuca, Walter Burns and Maurice Roberson, also own the Baronet Theater next door and want to reopen it for movies and cultural events. These two clubs join The Saint and the Moon Rock, which cater mostly to the musical tastes of a younger audience. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE CLAIRVILLE, RAYMOND
description: de CLAIRVILLE-Raymond. Resident of Manasota Key, Englewood, FL and former resident of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, New York, died peacefully at home at age 86. Beloved husband of Gwendolyn Gwynne de Clairville for 64 years, father of Wendy Kemper of New York City, Clauie Lauren of Sarasota, FL, and Sandy Rath of Wellesley, MA. He is also survived by 10 grandchildren and 6 great grandchildren. Born in New York City. He was a partner of a New York Stock Exchange Specialist firm, Wisner & de Clairville and subsequently a partner of Spear Leeds and Kellogg. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Amber Lake Wildlife Refuge, 297 Artists Ave, Englewood, FL 34223 or to Hospice of Southwest, FL, 5955 Rand Boulevard, Sarasota, FL 34238. A memorial service will be held in late spring.

description: The Massachusetts attorney general is to announce on Monday that he will begin carrying out the strictest and most comprehensive handgun safety laws in the nation, banning all gun makers and dealers doing business in the state from selling handguns that do not have tamper-proof serial numbers, trigger locks and safety devices enabling a user to know whether the gun is loaded.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the rejuvenation of the Detroit Institute of Arts misstated the year that a benefactor, DaimlerChrysler, was formed through a merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler. It was 1998, not 1997.

Florida has closed off the dribbler and now the passing lanes are being sealed. Every Florida Gator is in position to make the steal. Or, O.K., the trap has been tripped. Rotate. Get back. Play hard.

title: A Covey of Maestros in Action as a Future Beckons
description: This was not exactly how things had been planned. Franz Welser-Most, who was to have conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall, found it necessary to cancel because of a subsequent engagement: his appointment as the next music director of the Cleveland Orchestra.

title: Sports of The Times; Between Generations, but in the Title Game
description: THE hot young Florida Gators have torn through the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament. They have pressed and trapped and run the legs off the opposition. Along the way, Billy Donovan, the young Florida coach, has ousted some of the pillars of the industry: Oklahoma State Coach Eddie Sutton and Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski. On Saturday, Florida smothered North Carolina, and Donovan got the best of Bill Guthridge, the Tar Heels' venerable coach.

title: At a Beijing Aquarium, Dolphins Are Hostages
description: When it opened last June to huge crowds, the Beijing Aquarium seemed destined for success: a high-tech blue glass dome housing a rain forest, shark pools, fish and corals galore and -- as its centerpiece -- a serene island habitat complete with caves and bridges, the stage for its dolphin, sea lion and whale show.

title: Rivera Says Contract Is Possible
description: Mariano Rivera, the Yankees' closer, said today that he was hopeful of reaching agreement on a long-term contract shortly into the season. ''I think we could get something done,'' he said. ''I'm not looking to get all the money.''

title: Metro Matters; Inertia Makes A Rusty View From the Park
description: IT is indisputably ugly, a blot on one of the loveliest urban vistas in New York, if not the country. And nobody is doing anything about it.

title: People
description: * Ian McGregor was named executive vice president and general manager at the Los Angeles office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, succeeding Hank Wasiak, who will take a senior post at McCann-Erickson Europe, London. Mr. McGregor had been executive vice president and managing director at the Los Angeles office of Campbell-Ewald, which like McCann-Erickson is part of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: Beirut Journal; U.S. Angel of Mercy Stayed for a Merciless War
description: At the height of Lebanon's civil war in the 1980's, when every other American working at the American University of Beirut had been driven out of the country by hostage-taking, assassinations and threats, a lone American woman remained, earning a reputation among her colleagues at the university's medical center, and among victims of the fighting, as a ministering angel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMARIN, LEO
description: KOMARIN-Leo. Beloved husband of Franci. Loving father of Gary and the late Peter. Beloved brother of the late Paula Trost and Regina Salzberg. Loving father-inlaw of Sharon. Adoring grandfather of Jenna, Zoe and Wyatt. I read of a man who stood to speak at the funeral of his friend. He referred to the dates on his tombstone from the beginning...to the end. He noted that first came the date of his birth and spoke of the second with tears, but he said that what mattered most of all was the dash between those years. For that dash represents all the time that he spent alive on earth, and now only those who loved him know what that little line is worth. For it matters not, how much we own, the cars, the house, the cash. What matters is how we live and love when we're living out the dash. If we could just slow down enough to consider what's true and what is real, and always try to understand the way other people feel. And...be less quick to anger and show appreciation more, and love the people in our lives like we've never loved before. If we treat each other with respect, and more often wear a smile, remember that, this special dash might only last a while. So, when your eulogy is being read with your life's actions to rehash...will you be pleased with what there's to say about how you spent your dash? Marlene Feldman, Niece

title: Toontown Wizard in Land of Geeks; Setting the Standard in Computer-Generated Animation
description: John Lasseter pulled close a yellow chair and turned it so its egg-yolk surface met the sunlight. ''Look at this,'' he said. ''In the real world, this is about as close as you can get to a perfect, simple object.'' The chair's wooden back and seat are bright yellow, no other color. ''But look closer,'' Mr. Lasseter said. ''See, there's a little black mark here. And look, here's some kind of a blemish. And if you look really close, you can see the grain of the wood through the paint.''

title: The Gentlemen and Their C's
description: In 1988 I was one of the journalists participating in the vice presidential debate between Lloyd Bentsen and Dan Quayle. Our moderator, Judy Woodruff, then with PBS, suggested in a pre-debate discussion that we raise the issue of Mr. Quayle's college grades, which reportedly were undistinguished at best. My fellow panelists, Brit Hume, then of ABC News, and Jon Margolis, a political reporter for The Chicago Tribune, and I had a swift and common reaction: No way.

title: Where Ordinary Meets Extreme
description: Saying Lou Reed is arrogant is like saying Julia Roberts is attractive. The 58-year-old rocker is famous for his irascible behavior in life and art. His music has always been equal parts vulgar and pretentious, as he has lorded his authority over both the art gallery and the gutter. He's a self-styled irritant, rubbing the mugs of his followers into the dirt of his obsessions, from drugs and sadomasochism in the 1970's to his much-flaunted current romance with the performance artist Laurie Anderson. In his music Mr. Reed says whatever he pleases. What he can't seem to do is lay off.

title: Peabody Winners Include 2 New Series
description: Two prime-time series that made their debuts last year, ''The West Wing'' and ''The Sopranos,'' as well as millennium offerings from ABC, ESPN and National Public Radio, are among the winners of the 59th annual George Foster Peabody Awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALEXANDER
description: COHEN-Alexander. 83, of Englewood, NJ; April 2. Devoted husband of Lorraine. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLISH, PAUL WARD
description: ENGLISH-Paul Ward. Professor and former chairman of the Geography Department at the University of Texas, died on March 30 in Austin at age 64. He first joined the UT faculty in 1963 and over the years served the University in several capacities. From 1973 to 1979 he was Director of the distinguished UT Center of Middle Eastern Studies, and Professor English had earlier established his reputation as an expert on Iran and Afghanistan. His 1966 book, ''City and Village in Iran,'' won the Herfurth Award, and in 1977, at the age of only 41, he was given a Golden Medallion for ''outstanding contributions to Iranian geography'' by the Association of Iranian Geographers. He was also an extraordinary and charismatic teacher. His introductory course in world cultural/regional geography, which he taught at UT for 35 years, became legendary among UT undergraduates. Innovatively taught, with abundant visual and auditory aids, the course was the subject of an article in ''Alcalde,'' the UT alumni magazine, as early as 1968 and was instrumental in Dr. English being named one of the most outstanding college teachers in America by ''Change'' magazine in 1978. Each semester saw hundreds of UT students enrolled in this class. Its legacy lives on as part of their education and in two widely used textbooks, at the college and high school levels. Upperclass and graduate students perhaps treasure most highly his seminar in the Geography of Religion, a course that many found truly inspirational. Paul also helped launch the Oxford Summer Program in Geography, in which UT undergraduates and graduate teaching assistants spent six weeks exploring the wonders of England. Paul was a frequent participant in this program and was particularly drawn to Glastonbury, where his Celtic spiritual heritage remains so pervasive. Born February 20, 1936, in Worcester, Massachusetts, Paul was an unreconstructed Irish Catholic Yankee. In mindset and dialect, he remained true to this heritage and was totally impervious to the regional Texan culture. He sounded like a Boston Kennedy and played touch football with the same reckless abandon. His parents, Mary (nee Riley) and James (''Mickey'') English, preceded him in death, as did his dear young daughter, Elisabeth Ann. Paul received a bachelor's degree from Clark University in his native Worcester-an institution most famous for its geography program, a master's degree from Johns Hopkins University, and his doctorate from the University of Wisconsin at Madison. We will sorely miss his wit, intellect, and expertise; his personal magnetism, friendship, loyalty, and tolerance; the twinkle in his Irish eyes. Paul is survived by two sons, Dr. Paul Ward English II, with wife Leslie, of Houston and Dr. Peter Herbert English of Washington, DC, by two grandchildren, Ava Elaine and Paul III, and by his loving devoted fiancee, Annie Delano, whose constant presence and care comforted Paul in his final month and eased his passage. Annie, we, his family and friends, consider you one of us and will always be grateful. You are a true angel of mercy. Paul's numerous friends and colleagues attended a visitation at Weed-Corley-Fish Funeral Home, Saturday evening, April 1, 2000. On Sunday, Paul was returned to his native land for burial in that mystical place he loved best, Cape Cod. Rest well, you happy pilgrim. For information contact Weed-Corley-Fish Funeral Home, Austin, Texas.

These four are among seven new crew chiefs on the umpiring staff that merges National and American League umpires for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREW, WILLIAM T.
description: DREW-William T. Of Port Washington, L.I., died on February 29, 2000 after a five year residency at Ozanam Hall Nursing Home. His career spanned the Broadway Theater to niteclubs and TV. After retiring as a dancer, he continued as an entertainer and cruise director aboard several of the largest liners. He is survived by two brothers, Russell and George, and two sisters, Kate Kivlen and Mary Bertrand. A Memorial Mass will be held on April 8th at 1PM at Ozanam Hall, Bayside, Queens.

description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: In Intrastate Rivalry, Spartans Redraw the Map of Michigan
description: Four years ago, when Mateen Cleaves was trying to decide on a college, he got into a sport utility vehicle with several members of the Michigan Wolverines basketball team. Cleaves was a promising high school senior and the college athletes were taking him out for a night on the town, which happened to be Detroit, quite a distance from the Ann Arbor campus and from Cleaves's home town of Flint.

title: Bestfoods introduces new products and enlists Derek Jeter's help on the peanut butter front.
description: TRYING to get itself noticed in the intensely competitive world of packaged foods, Bestfoods International, is introducing a flurry of new products, leaning heavily on the established appeal of some of its brands.

description: They are at the age where this year could be the last in a baseball career, and like two old fishing buddies dangling lines from a pier, David Cone and Paul O'Neill have stood in the outfield during batting practice this spring and had big-picture conversations, about their team and its niche in history.

description: The prime minister of Japan, Keizo Obuchi, has suffered a stroke and was temporarily relieved of his duties today, the government announced.

description: Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of Zimbabwe's biggest opposition party, got out of bed today, the morning after, and counted the week's casualties.

title: Holocaust Documentary Explores One Man's Truth
description: ''There were other towns near camps, and no one mentions them; I'm offended by it,'' says a current resident of the city of Dachau in the documentary ''Martin.'' This film is a complicated story about the nature of truth, both for the people who live in that city in the wake of one of the 20th century's greatest horror stories, and for Martin Zaidenstadt, one man whose mission is to tell what he thinks is the most pertinent version of the truth.

title: BASEBALL; Daylight, Nightmarish Pitching and a Boston Loss, for Openers
description: It was the spring of 1900, and the United States was in transition from the antiquated ways of the 19th century to the exciting technology of the 20th. One thing, though, promised to remain the same: baseball, the national pastime since shortly after the Civil War, was as popular as ever.

title: Long Arm of the Law Gropes in Cyberspace
description: PARIS  Technology continues to outpace the law. The Internet knows no national boundaries, and last week, a U.S. judge in Massachusetts issued an injunction regarding the Internet to the world at large.

description: AT an embassy that is not an embassy, the ambassador who is not an ambassador can only imagine what it is like to be a full-fledged member of Washington's diplomatic corps.

title: Hans Gustav Guterbock, 91, Expert in Ancient Languages
description: Hans Gustav Guterbock, a retired University of Chicago professor who was one of the world's foremost scholars of the languages of the ancient Middle East, died on Wednesday at his home in Chicago. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPAPORT, ARTHUR
description: RAPAPORT-Arthur. Passed away April 1, 2000. Surived by his children Susan Klein and Matthew Rapaport. Services are private.

title: E-Commerce Report; Running a joint promotion with Yahoo, Pepsi is in the Internet generation.
description: PEPSICO'S recent announcement that it would conduct a joint promotion of its products with Yahoo, one of the most popular sites on the Internet, is promising news for Web site operators that have struggled to persuade the richest advertisers to spend their money online.

title: Perfect Place to Rediscover Two Renaissance Masters
description: In his day job George Steel oversees concert programming at the Miller Theater, and in two seasons his adventurous programming has transformed that hall into one of the liveliest musical institutions in New York. But before he became an arts administrator, Mr. Steel was a singer and choral conductor, and he has been determined not to retire that side of himself. Several times a year he directs a concert with the Vox Ensemble, the freelance choir he formed in 1992.

title: Queens Marsh Fire Seen as Bit of Spring Cleaning
description: Yesterday afternoon, 24 hours after a six-alarm brush fire in Alley Pond Park in northeast Queens, the smell of wet ashes was overpowering, and the mile-long strip of marsh -- once thick with wildlife -- had become a smear of mud covered by a netting of charred reeds.

description: ''Microsoft is now back in the legal quagmire, and nothing good is going to happen to the company anytime soon.''

title: To the Barricades for an Idea: Then, Now and Always
description: Strange how potent ideas (even cheap ones) are. And stranger still how seldom we encounter them in places like the theater or the novel. (We're quite accustomed to their absence in politics.) When a century changes, there is a power struggle between what we know and what we can imagine, or just the habit of the familiar versus the ruptures of what hasn't been fully or even partly tried. Subtle or violent, we feel this push-pull everywhere: in politics, technology, art; in all the conventions of caste and class that so shaped who we are or who we no longer wish to be.

title: Deceptive Home Loan Practices
description: State attorneys general and consumer advocates increasingly have expressed alarm over abusive practices in the ''subprime'' home equity market, which caters to people with blemished credit records and charges them higher interest rates and fees. Practices like tacking exorbitant fees onto loans without adequate disclosure can cause unsuspecting consumers to borrow more than they can repay, driving them into default and resulting in the loss of their homes.

title: New Home At Columbia For Center For Jews
description: As an undergraduate at Columbia University in the early 1960's, Robert K. Kraft sought spiritual and cultural solace at the campus Jewish Office, which was crammed into spare space in the basement of an academic building.

title: M.T.A.'s Plan Spawns Warnings Of a Debt Crisis and Higher Fares
description: In the last month, government and private analysts have developed a striking consensus that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's five-year, $16.5 billion capital improvement plan is a disaster-in-waiting, built on a mountain of borrowed money, that would force a major fare increase.

title: The Unfinished Nuclear Agenda
description: Vladimir Putin has made clear that he intends to maintain Russia's nuclear defenses. But he also faces sharp reductions in the number of long-range nuclear weapons capable of reaching the United States. His election as president should revive stalled arms negotiations between Washington and Moscow. Completing a treaty that would lock in deep new weapons cuts by the time President Clinton leaves office is a realistic target. A new agreement should also incorporate changes in the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty that would allow both countries to deploy limited defensive systems to protect against threats from rogue states like North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, RABBI ISRAEL
description: SCHORR-Rabbi Israel. On March 31. Beloved father of his daughter Gail and son-in-law Dr. Lawrence Horowitz. He was the revered rabbi of Congregation Beth El-Young Israel of Boro Park for 60 years and past president of Hapoel Hamizrachi. A rabbinic scholar with an insatiable love of learning, keen intellect coupled with kindness, humor and tenderness. He was a true renaissance man who will be sorely missed by his family and all who were privileged to know him. He left a void that can never be filled. The Horowitz Family

title: Protest March Against Flag Attracts 600 In S. Carolina
description: More than 600 South Carolinians began a five-day protest march to the state capitol in Columbia today to press legislators to remove the Confederate battle flag from the Statehouse dome.

title: Beyond Computers in Computer Security
description: For all the power and complexity of modern computer networks, practical computer security against cybervandals may ultimately be found in the commonplace concept of a burglar alarm.

title: Energy Dept. Drops a Plan for Lab Employees to Wear ID's Stating Their Nationalities
description: Heeding the objections of scientists, the Energy Department has dropped part of a plan to make foreign nationals at its laboratories wear badges stating the countries they are from.

title: Patents; What's in a name? A sign of other changes at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
description: WITH a couple of minor changes, officials at the federal agency responsible for patents and trademarks last week began what they say is a makeover to render the organization more efficient and responsive to inventors, patent holders and intellectual property lawyers.

title: Leetch Studies His Role In the Rangers' Decline
description: Brian Leetch is three games removed from some much-needed closure to one of the most frustrating seasons of his career. Few would question his credentials as the Rangers' best player. After 13 seasons, Leetch is still a member of the National Hockey League's defensive elite.

title: Britain's HSBC Buys CCF of France to Gain Foothold in Euro Zone : A Big Leap For Banking In Europe
description: LONDON  The shift to pan-European banking got a push over the weekend when Credit Commercial de France agreed to be bought by HSBC, the largest cross-border takeover in an industry where consolidation has been largely frustrated by national sensitivities.

title: Justice for the Khmer Rouge
description: More than two decades after the mass slaughter in Cambodia, a critical moment is at hand in a long-overdue attempt to bring the killers to justice. United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan will soon decide whether the U.N. should participate in a criminal court that will try surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge, whose members killed more than a million Cambodians between 1975 and 1979. The court will be in Cambodia and needs the approval of Cambodia's strongman, Hun Sen, who is doing all he can to impose conditions that would enable him to manipulate the trials. Mr. Annan must make clear that the U.N. will not abide by those conditions.

title: OFFICIALS WORRIED OVER A SHARP RISE IN IDENTITY THEFT
description: Law enforcement authorities are becoming increasingly worried about a sudden, sharp rise in identity theft, the pilfering of people's personal information for use in obtaining credit cards, loans and other goods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROPPER, ROBERT
description: PROPPER-Robert. On April 2, 2000. Husband of the late Barbara. Beloved father of Patti and Steve Aretz, and Leslie and Andy Propper. Brother of Joan and Stanley Shapiro, Donald Propper and brother-in-law of Dorothy Koeppel. Loving grandfather of Danielle, Rachel and Chloe Aretz, and Matthew and Joey Propper. Burial will be at El Camino Mortuary, San Diego, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, STRATFORD E.
description: MOORE-Stratford E. At age 38. Beloved son of Dolorita and James J. Moore, brother of James and Edmund and brother-in-law of Margaret. Died March 30 in his family's home in Hampton Bays, NY, from a sudden heart attack. Stratford, a kind, gentle and loving person, will be missed by his uncles and aunts, Mr. and Mrs. William D. Powers, Mrs. Julia Wallace, Mr. and Mrs. Stratford C. Wallace and Mr. and Mrs. William F. Wallace, and his many cousins. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. at 84th St., Monday, 10:30 AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Hampton Bays Beautification Society or the Riverhead Train Museum.

title: California Repeats In the Copley Cup
description: The University of California at Berkeley's men's varsity heavyweight crew, last year's national collegiate champion, picked up where it left off, decisively winning the featured Copley Cup race of the 27th annual San Diego Crew Classic yesterday for the second consecutive year. Rowing with precision, the Golden Bears, understroking the six-boat final at a 33-stroke cadence, pulled away from a bunched field at the 500-meter mark of this 2,000-meter course to gain a boat-length lead on Harvard and Washington.

title: Diaghilev's Greatest Hits
description: Second impressions can be better than first. When the Ballet de l'Opera de Bordeaux came to Brooklyn College in January, it seemed a pleasant company. But it presented a tepid version of ''Romeo and Juliet'' with settings so minimal as to look skeletal.

title: Britain Raises Barriers High Against the Asylum Seekers
description: In the latest effort by a West European government to stem the tide of immigrants flowing into the region, many of them from war-ravaged, post-Communist Eastern Europe, a sweeping law takes effect in Britain on Monday that aims to make the country far less attractive to asylum seekers.

description: Tamika Catchings collected two more player of the year awards this Final Four weekend to make this season's collection complete, yet she does not know where the trophies are. Nor does she seem to be worried about it.

title: A Tight and Tired Sampras Prevails in 4 Sets
description: With chants of ''Let's go, Pete!'' reverberating in his ears, Pete Sampras outlasted the Brazilian Gustavo Kuerten today in a 3-hour-18-minute final of the Ericsson Open spiced by three tie-breaker sets.

The Detroit Pistons' Jerry Stackhouse and Grant Hill did most of the teaching, and their convincing demonstrations came in ways that were stylish and entertaining.

description: There was a time when a producer could throw a Confederate flag into a television shot and no one would say boo. And, back then, good old boys were, well, just good, old boys.

description: In the weeks since Stephen King's e-novella made its debut with the unexpected fury of Carrie at the high school prom, traditional publishers are quickening their entrance into the emerging market of digital books with a mix of anxiety about security issues and optimism about nurturing new forms of literature.

title: The Gypsies of Slovakia: Despised and Despairing
description: Darina Horvathova, 23, lives with her baby on the crumbling remains of an abandoned iron and mercury mine, without a husband, a job or indoor plumbing. The soil, under the mounds of uncollected trash, is known to be contaminated. But 500 Gypsies, or Roma as they are also known, live here in sickness and squalor in the shadow of a factory shut down when Communism died.

title: Retaliating Against Smith & Wesson
description: The National Rifle Association and gun dealers are foolishly trying to punish Smith & Wesson, the nation's largest gunmaker, for striking a deal with the Clinton administration to embrace new safety restrictions in exchange for ending threatened lawsuits against the company. They are angry because Smith & Wesson, by breaking ranks, has demolished the claim of gun-control opponents that built-in trigger locks, better policing of gun dealers and other safety measures would impose an impossible burden on the industry.

title: Uganda Survivor Tells of Questions When World Didn't End
description: The police say he appears to be the only survivor, and today Peter Ahimbisibwe, 17, said members of a doomsday cult in Uganda began to rise at church services after Jan. 1 and to ask cult leaders a difficult question.

title: Kirshenbaum Gets Hilfiger Fragrances
description: Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York has been selected to create domestic and international campaigns for the Tommy Hilfiger fragrance line sold by the Aramis division of the Estee Lauder Companies in New York. Billings were estimated at $20 million for the next three years.

description: You would have to live under a rock in a particularly desolate stretch of the Sahara to not know who Oprah Winfrey is.

title: Choreography That Explores Love, Often From a Distance
description: It was a surprise to discover that ''The 'L' Word,'' the intriguing title of a new piece presented by Janis Brenner and Dancers on Tuesday night at Playhouse 91, referred to loving. True, the dancers did disperse into couples regularly. There was a repeated phallic sight gag and gentle manipulation by one dancer of another's hand and head. But what stood out most about the piece was Ms. Brenner's gift for arranging bodies in space.

title: Ex-Aide Says Reno Didn't Discuss Inquiry Decision
description: The prosecutor who once led the investigation of Democratic fund-raising said today that Attorney General Janet Reno had never discussed with him why she rejected his recommendation that an independent counsel be appointed to investigate the involvement of President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore in fund-raising abuses in the 1996 campaign.

title: Separate Paths Converge For Spartans and Gators

The Duke Blue Devils had just beaten the Spartans in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, and Coach Tom Izzo gathered his players in a crowded room and told them they'd be back exactly where they were today.

title: T-ONLINE PRICES ITS SHARES
description: The German Internet portal T-Online International A.G. will price its shares at a less-than-expected 26 euros to 32 euros in a public offering. That would value the service, an unprofitable division of Deutsche Telekom A.G., at as much as 38.4 billion euros ($36.3 billion). Deutsche Telekom shares fell as the price -- less than the 35 euros a share analysts said they expected -- means less money for T-Online to expand outside its German-language markets.

description: The Nasdaq stock market, the source of much of the new wealth created during the 1990's, lost a big chunk of its value yesterday, recording its fifth-biggest decline ever in percentage terms.

title: HEXCEL TO SELL AIRCRAFT INTERIORS LINE TO BRITAX
description: The Hexcel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Bellingham aircraft interiors business to Britax International P.L.C. of Britain for $116.9 million in cash. Hexcel, based in Stamford, Conn., said the sale followed its previously announced plan to review its engineering products business. The Bellingham business generated revenue in 1999 of $69.1 million. Britax, which is based in Warwick, England, is the world's No. 1 maker of automotive exterior mirrors. The company's aircraft interior systems unit makes seats for airplanes and in-flight food service equipment.

title: Despite a Stricken Leader, Japan Keeps a Level Head
description: The reaction to news that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi was in the hospital was testament to the Japanese determination to maintain the ''wa,'' the social harmony that this country so greatly prizes.

title: With Japan's Premier in a Coma, Succession Moves Get Under Way
description: Japanese politics were thrown into disarray today by the news that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi was in a coma and was being kept alive on a respirator after suffering a stroke on Sunday.

title: Coke to Disband In-House Agency That Handles Its Flagship Brand
description: In another sign of how extensively Coca-Cola plans to overhaul the sales and marketing of its soft drinks, the company will disband the unconventional in-house advertising agency that has led the way in creating campaigns for its flagship brand.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil slumped as traders considered how long it would take OPEC to move extra oil to refiners. In New York, crude oil for May delivery fell 47 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $26.43 a barrel.

description: GOLDWATER-Berton. On April 2, 2000. Beloved husband of Judith. Cherished father of Amy Goldwater, Marcy Dorfman and father-inlaw of Ron Dorfman. Loving and adored grandfather of Kate, Chaz, Claire and Joseph. Services Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Day of Faith and Cut Fastballs
description: Al Leiter kept marching from the mound to the first-base dugout, where he would slip on his blue Mets jacket and pace some more. He was a little eager and a little worried. Leiter prayed that the gray afternoon would not remain so gloomy for the Mets and hoped that they could finally score a run in the United States.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Weighing Restrictions On Legal Aid for Poor
description: The highly charged question of what strings the government can attach to the use of federal money reached the Supreme Court again today, this time in the context of legal services for the poor.

title: Benitez At Home As Mets' Closer
description: Armando Benitez strode in from right field yesterday afternoon just as he had dozens of times before. At the conclusion of an oddly quiet and unemotional game, Benitez, too, seemed to have curbed the swinging emotions that worried his bosses earlier in his career. The Mets have seen no outbursts since acquiring him in December 1998, and he barely wasted any motion yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MECCA, ANTHONY S.
description: MECCA-Anthony S. With profound sorrow, the faculty, students, staff, and alumni of the New York University College of Dentistry record the passing or our beloved Professor, mentor, benefactor, and colleague, Dr. Anthony S. Mecca. A man of rare devotion to family, alma mater, community, and profession, Dr. Mecca enjoyed the distinction of having taught more oral surgery to more New York dentists than any other teacher. NYU's Dr. Anthony S. Mecca Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery recognizes his extraordinary professional contributions, loyalty, devotion and friendship. To his sister Marie and his entire family, we offer heartfelt condolences. Michael C. Alfano, DMD, PhD, Dean
