title: Union Cleared For Students Who Teach
description: Graduate students who work as teaching and research assistants at New York University may organize a union, the regional director for the National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday. The decision could alter the relationship between graduate students and their professors at private colleges and universities across the United States.

title: Jets' Preseason Opening Early
description: The Jets will get an early start to the exhibition season this summer when they play Ricky Williams and the New Orleans Saints on July 29 at the Meadowlands. The game, to be played the same weekend as the annual Hall of Fame game in Canton, Ohio, will be the first for the Jets' new head coach, Al Groh.

title: Regents Panel Approves 10 Charter Schools and Rejects 4 Applications
description: A panel of the State Board of Regents today approved opening 10 new charter schools this fall to serve more than 2,000 students across the state. But it rejected four others after misgivings expressed by several regents, including questions about the schools' impact on neighboring public schools.

title: Microsoft's Illegal Monopoly
description: With settlement talks having broken down, the judge overseeing the government's antitrust case against Microsoft issued a stinging ruling yesterday that Microsoft had violated antitrust laws by abusing its monopoly position over Windows, the operating system that controls the vast majority of personal computers. The ruling, which supported most but not all of the government's accusations, deserves wide credence. It was carefully grounded in antitrust doctrine and the facts presented at trial.

title: LUCENT SELLS PART OF OFFICE-PHONE BUSINESS
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the No. 1 telephone-equipment maker, yesterday sold part of the office-phone business it plans to spin off this year to a NorthWestern Corporation unit for $259 million in cash and securities. Expanets, based in Berkeley Heights, N.J., the networking arm of NorthWestern, paid Lucent $64 million in cash, $50 million in notes and $145 million in preferred stock in exchange for 1,800 employees who sell phone and data systems to 700,000 small and midsize companies. Shares of Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., rose 75 cents, to $61.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. NorthWestern rose $1.3125, to $21.9375.

title: U.S. Judge Says MicrosoftViolated Antitrust LawsWith Predatory Behavior
description: U.S. Judge Says Microsoft Violated Antitrust Laws With Predatory Behavior

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EXCHANGE APPLICATIONS INC., Boston, a software company that helps Web sites collect customer information, said it had bought the closely held Knowledge Stream Partners, Boston, a consulting and software company, for about $52 million in stock and changed its name to Xchange Inc.

title: Police Head In Yonkers Is Expected To Retire
description: After serving for 35 years in a variety of police posts, the last two as Yonkers police commissioner, Joseph P. Cassino will announce his retirement on Tuesday, Mayor John D. Spencer said today.

title: Bush Plans to Ease Rules For Use of Polluted Land
description: Unveiling his first set of detailed environmental proposals since he began his presidential campaign, Gov. George W. Bush announced a plan today to hasten the cleanup of contaminated, abandoned industrial sites by easing certain federal regulations, protecting redevelopers from federal liability and giving states broader discretion over the use of federal funds.

title: CROSS TIMBERS OIL BUYS OUT LEHMAN NATURAL GAS STAKE
description: The Cross Timbers Oil Company said yesterday that it had bought the remaining 50 percent stake in natural gas fields in Arkansas and Oklahoma from Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. for $111 million. The two companies bought the fields from Ocean Energy Inc. in September for $231 million. Cross Timbers partly financed the purchase of Lehman's stake by selling producing properties in Texas and New Mexico for $68.3 million. Cross Timbers, based in Fort Worth, said it would post a first-quarter gain of $13 million from the property sales. The company expects another $9.5 million gain from selling most of its stock portfolio during the quarter for $42 million.

title: SHARES FALL AS STAFF LEASING DROPS SALE OPTION
description: Shares of Staff Leasing Inc. fell 28 percent yesterday after the company said it planned to remain independent after evaluating buyout options and other alternatives. Staff Leasing is a professional employer organization based in Bradenton, Fla. The company's shares closed at $4.1875, down $1.625, in Nasdaq trading, after an announcement that a committee of its board had concluded that the company should remain independent and publicly traded.

description: BOGOFF-Irene. On April 2, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of Ansi Boudin and Zona and Edward Kaufman. description: Underscoring Stanford University's deep relationship with Silicon Valley, John Hennessy, the provost and a professor of electrical engineering and computer science who founded a semiconductor company, today was named president of the institution.

The swivel chairs and the bubble hair dryer are tucked in a corner. But jars of aqua-blue Barbicide, hairspray and pomade still line the counters as men and women sway forward and back across the wine-red plywood floor.

title: Echoes Across the Centuries In a Perpetual Revolution
description: The second of Maurizio Pollini's magnificently heterogeneous part-choral programs, presented by Carnegie Hall at the 92nd Street Y on Thursday evening, was a journey from the early Baroque to 1960 and back again. In another sense, though, we stayed in the same place. When Schoenberg's Second Quartet followed Monteverdi's madrigal version of his ''Lamento d'Arianna,'' it came seamlessly, putting the same kinds of pressures on the language of tonal harmony in the interests of expressing lassitude and dejection. When five Gesualdo madrigals completed a second half begun by choral songs of Luigi Nono's, there were echoes across the centuries.

title: An Abrupt Transition in Japan
description: Japan is suffering from a leadership crisis far deeper than the sudden disability of Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi. A new prime minister will soon be named to replace Mr. Obuchi, who was left in a coma by a stroke over the weekend and is not expected to recover. But none of the current contenders are likely to have the political clout or daring needed to energize Japan's creaky government machinery or to jolt its economy out of an almost decade-long recession.

description: Neve Savage, vice president for client results at Avenue A, Seattle, was named president at a new international division, to open in London.

title: Surgery With Dairy Pump and Beer Hose
description: Surgeons in early 1954 had not perfected a way to correct the most life-threatening defects inside the heart. Death by uncontrolled bleeding resulted if the heart was cut and left open, and while clamping off the vessels into and out of the heart solved that problem, the oxygen-deprived brain would soon die. Some surgeons were experimenting with heart-lung machines, designed to support a patient's life while the heart was clamped off -- but with one notable success early efforts all ended with the patient's death.

title: Honoring a Visionary If Not His Vision
description: A half-century ago a quixotic architect built this village from scratch, or rather from bricks made of sun-dried mud and straw. That architect, Hassan Fathy, created vaulted roofs punctured by small openings to direct and cool the prevailing winds, courtyards to give each owner a ''private piece of sky,'' crooked streets to emphasize the intimacy of houses, communal wells to invite neighborly chats.

title: HSBC'S SHARES DROP
description: The shares of HSBC Holdings P.L.C., Europe's biggest bank by market value, fell as investors expressed concern that its $10.5 billion offer for Credit Commercial de France is too high. HSBC's shares in London fell 41 pence, to 700 pence, while C.C.F. rose 21.2 euros, to 151.7 euros. HSBC agreed to pay one billion euros ($960 million) more than ING Groep offered for C.C.F. in December. The takeover would bring HSBC one million more European clients and might help it compete better with Citigroup and UBS. ''We both have a strong focus on private banking,'' said Sir John Bond, chairman of HSBC.

But I did stay in Venezuela long enough to realize that many people were asking the same thing about President Hugo Chavez's leadership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKIN, SOLOMON
description: BARKIN-Solomon. Devoted husband and loving father, died at his home in Leverett, MA. on March 29 at age 92. His long productive life affected and improved the lives of many people. His dedication to the labor movement spanned 25 years as economist for the Textile Workers Union of America, now joined to UNITE. In academia, his prolific scholarly writings influenced the thinking of many students. As an internationalist, he executed and directed numerous studies during five years in Paris with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, in Rotterdam at Erasmus University and as an professor Emeritus at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Married almost 60 years to Elaine Rappaport, he is survived by their children, David, Roger, and Amy, and three grandsons, Adam, Michael, and Benjamin. A memorial service will be held May 26.

title: Bills to Stop Executing the Innocent
description: The battle to reform administration of the nation's deeply flawed death-penalty system gained momentum last week with the introduction of legislation in the House that would provide important new safeguards to lessen the chance of executing innocent people. The enlightened measure, the Innocence Protection Act, would require preservation of biological evidence, make DNA testing available to federal and state inmates, and set national standards to ensure competent lawyers for indigent defendants accused of capital crimes.

In its day, the high-pressure water system was considered the ultimate in firefighting technology, but like most innovations, it eventually outlived its usefulness.

title: ANADARKO TO BUY UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES
description: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, the Houston-based independent energy company, agreed yesterday to buy the Union Pacific Resources Group for $4.43 billion in stock. Anadarko will pay 0.4550 share for each share of Union Pacific of Fort Worth, valuing the company at $17.60 a share. The deal will create a new company with proven reserves of 1.94 billion barrels of oil and about 11.65 trillion cubic feet of gas. About 80 percent of the reserves are in North America and 20 percent overseas. Based on 1999 data, Anadarko said it expected the combined company to rank as the sixth-largest natural gas producer in North America and the fifth-largest holder of natural gas reserves. Union Pacific's shares rose 18.75 cents, to $14.6875, and Anadarko's shares fell $4.1875, to $34.50

It dispels the academic air that might cling to gathering old tunes and it provides a convivial contrast to songs about love and death. With Johnny Cunningham, a fiddler, and his brother Phil, an accordionist, the jokes and stories approach the skill of the music, and at Symphony Space on Friday their sets seesawed between impressive virtuosity and laughter.

title: CBS's Morning News Show Loses Ground to Competitors
description: Last fall, CBS invested more than $30 million in revamping its morning news show. It brought in one of the pre-eminent stars of morning television, Bryant Gumbel, as well as one of its most experienced producers, Steve Friedman, and declared that after more than four decades of futility it was finally making a serious bid to be competitive in the morning.

title: Times Co. Appoints A Vice President

Abbey National also will assume debt amounting to approximately $1.1 billion. Porterbrook is one of the three operating companies created by the privatization of British Rail.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; Of Pills, Pressure and Diabetes Risk
description: A new study has found that one important class of high blood pressure medication, thiazide diuretics, does not increase the risk of diabetes, as had previously been suspected. In fact, patients taking these drugs developed fewer cases of diabetes than people not taking them.

description: Silently, mostly out of sight and unknown to all but a handful of the millions of people who live along the Hudson River, a subtle but elegant ecological drama is under way that may determine whether the revivified, revitalized river can continue its hard-won recovery from decades of pollution and degradation.

title: Railroad Taking a Charge

The company estimated the charge at 16 cents a share. Before the announcement, Norfolk Southern had been forecast to earn 6 cents share, according to securities analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. The company had expected about 800 of the 1,180 eligible employees to accept the early-retirement terms.

title: Helen Martin, 90, an Actress On Broadway, Film and TV

No overpriced flowers either; let the roses wilt. No, Derek Bell gave his mother a unique present and he sent it special delivery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, ISRAEL, RABBI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWER, PRENTICE WILLETTS,
description: BROWER-Prentice Willetts, died on Saturday, April 1st at his home on Hilton Head Island. Mr. Brower was born in Roslyn, NY on April 23, 1914 to Marion Willetts Brower and Ernest Cuyler Brower. For the past 18 years he has resided with his wife, Mary Francis Brower in the Hilton Head area. He attended the Pomfret School, New York University and New York University Law School. At the outbreak of World War II, Mr. Brower joined the Navy, serving until the end of the war. As a Lieutenant Commander, he had command of the Destroyer USS Barker, providing convoy protection in the North Atlantic. After the war, he entered the practice of admiralty law with the New York firm of Kerlin, Campbell, Hickox and Keating. He later became a partner in the law firm of Toaz, Buck, Myers and Brower. He served as president of both the Huntington Country Club and the Lloyd Neck Bath Club. Most importantly, he was a true gentleman & a wonderful listener. He was interested in everything & everyone. He was an insightful and loving husband, father, grandfather and friend. He was always there for all of us. He is survived by his wife Mary Francis Brower; two sisters, Elizabeth Brower and Marna Brower Royal; sons Peter P. Brower and George E. Brower II; daughters Anne P. Brower and Deborah W. Brower; and twelve grandchildren. He is predeceased by his son, Prentice W. Brower, Jr. Services will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church on Hilton Head Island at 3 PM on April 4, 2000. A reception will follow at the Brower home at 55 Outerbridge Circle. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Hilton Head Regional Habitat for Humanity, PO Box 5725, Hilton Head Island, SC 29938. For information Island Funeral Home, Hilton Head, South Carolina.

title: Surgery, With Help From a Robot
description: A robot with three tiny metal arms, operated by a surgeon at a computer console, is performing heart operations that require incisions not much larger than a pencil. Heart surgeons say this sort of operation, still in the testing phase, could transform the profession. Eventually, they say, the doctor will not have to be in the same room, or even the same country, as the patient. Surgeons say that while there is intense interest in doing heart bypass surgery with robots, the methods also could be used for other kinds of microsurgery, like sewing fallopian tubes or working on blood vessels in the brain. Science Times, Page F1.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; Surgery, Under the Influence of Herbs
description: Half of the surgical patients surveyed in a University of Colorado study used herbal or alternative medicines or vitamins in the days before their operations, although many of these substances could have interfered with their anesthetics, prolonged bleeding or affected blood pressure.

title: CHEVRON JOINS OIL VENTURE
description: Moving a World Bank loan closer to approval, the Chevron Corporation has agreed to take a 25 percent stake in a long-delayed Exxon Mobil Corporation-led oil production and pipeline project in Africa. Participation in the $3.5 billion Doba oil fields project, which is expected to yield 1 billion barrels over as long as 30 years, would build on the company's existing West African production, Chevron said. The pipeline, which would run from Chad to Cameroon in West Africa, has encountered repeated opposition. The opponents say that government corruption would siphon off pipeline revenue meant to ease poverty in the region, and that the project lacks safeguards against pollution.

title: When Theater Sends Up Itself to Save Itself
description: ''I mean, this is driving me crazy!'' says the actor planted in the audience, interrupting the play and causing the actors onstage to confront the impertinent intruder directly. ''This is the whole problem with 20th-century theater. This is part of the reason nobody wants to buy a ticket. We used to get stories; now we get interpretations.''

description: The state's highest court today upheld the repeal of New York City's commuter tax for state residents and ruled that the tax must also be eliminated for out-of-state commuters -- a double blow to the Giuliani administration that will cost the city $360 million a year.

title: Budgeting for New York State
description: With unexpected speed, Gov. George Pataki and the New York State Legislature have agreed on a framework for a new $77 billion budget. Producing a framework does not mean the Legislature has actually produced a budget on time -- a feat that has not been achieved in Albany for the last 16 years. This budget was officially late last Saturday. But the agreement on a budget outline is definitely a sign of progress for legislators prodded by an election this fall and the loss of their paychecks until the budget is officially finished. Last year the Legislature reached this point in its budget negotiations in mid-July.

title: BAIN CAPITAL DROPS PLAN TO BUY VDI MULTIMEDIA
description: VDI MultiMedia, whose film editing and distribution services are used by Universal Studios and Disney, said Bain Capital Inc. had canceled a plan to acquire it for $200 million. The shares of VDI fell $5.625, or 40 percent, to $8.375 in Nasdaq trading. VDI said Bain had canceled the purchase because its senior lender would not finance the transaction, citing the amount of debt as too high. VDI, based in Hollywood, edits and distributes television programming and commercials, movies and other video products. It had 1999 revenue of $78.2 million. The Boston-based Bain Capital manages investments valued at more than $6.6 billion.

title: Water Main Break Floods Picturesque Long Island City Block
description: As a broken water main turned a stretch of 23rd Street beneath the elevated No. 7 train in Queens into a canal early yesterday, firefighters turned a corner in Long Island City into a makeshift Venice.

title: Carrying On as Stardust Permeates the Garden
description: On Monday, during the first of three shows at Madison Square Garden, David Crosby, Stephen Stills, Graham Nash and Neil Young invited fans to return to an era when rock stars still called their female friends ''Lady''; when young people were not embarrassed to utter phrases like ''We are stardust''; and when four gifted, egotistical artists could unite to indulge their whims and be inspiring, not tired.

In fact, I had to watch him make it for months before he would let me near the stove.

Survived by wife, Natalie, son, Kenneth, daughter-in-law, Beth, and sister, Dolores Harris. He was a Vice President of investments for Solomon Smith Barney. A 1959 graduate of Rutgers College of Pharmacy, a Fellow of The American College of Apothecaries and a Past President of The New Jersey Society of Pharmacists. title: ENERGIZER SHARES RISE IN FIRST TRADING AFTER SPINOFF
description: The shares of Energizer Holdings Inc., the battery maker, rose yesterday in their first day of trading after a spinoff by the Ralston Purina Company, which is focusing on its more profitable pet food business. Energizer rose 6.25 cents a share, to $21.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange, valuing the company at $2.1 billion, about 25 percent less than analysts had expected. The shares, which have traded on a when-issued basis for six days, have declined 10 percent in that time. Ralston, the largest United States pet food maker, issued about 100 million shares in Energizer Holdings, giving out one share for every three held by Ralston shareholders. Both companies are based in St. Louis. Ralston fell 25 cents, to $21, yesterday.

description: Swiss authorities have brought the first charges in a case involving at least $654 million in bank accounts here that were connected to the Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha, his family and associates.

description: A former New York City jail guard was sentenced today to 5 to 15 years in state prison for driving drunk in a fiery 1998 New Year's Eve crash that killed three people on the Long Island Expressway.

title: Reckonings; Roller-Coaster Markets
description: If you are one of those people who, despite all the evidence, retain some lingering illusions about the rationality of financial markets, yesterday should have cured you. And yesterday's events also proved that worries about the growing practice of buying stock on margin -- in effect, borrowing in order to speculate -- are completely justified.

title: Mercurial Markets
description: Volatility was redefined on Wall Street yesterday. First the Dow fell more than 500 points by 1:15 p.m. Then, miraculously, it gained back all but about 57 points by the 4 p.m. closing. The Nasdaq dropped 574 points before it too roared back to end down 74. Comparing start and finish, there was not that much change. But for investors already jittery after Monday's biggest point drop ever on the Nasdaq, 349, yesterday's whiplash market was jarring.

title: Duval's Time Is Now; Norman Is Near End
description: As the start of the Masters drew closer today, so did the anticipation among the players. Greg Norman, preparing for his 20th Masters, is running out of time to win a green jacket. David Duval, the world's No. 2-ranked player, has been blunt about his intentions to win a major this year. Tiger Woods, with three victories and three second-place finishes in his last seven starts, has never entered a major with more momentum.

title: MANAGEMENT: You've Got Inappropriate Mail; Monitoring of Office E-Mail Is Increasing
description: Andrew Quinn, a systems manager at a toy company near Montreal, is starting to learn more about his fellow employees than he had ever wanted to know. He gently pours it over the vegetables, and before your eyes the dish comes to life: so fragrant, limpid and beautiful that it hardly deserves such an ordinary name.

title: NTT DOCOMO FILES TO SELL BONDS
description: Japan's biggest company by market value, NTT DoCoMo Inc., applied to sell as much as one trillion yen ($9.5 billion) of bonds, as the company, a mobile phone operator, prepares to make acquisitions outside Japan. In one of the biggest registrations yet in Japan, the company applied to regulators to raise the money within the next two years. Under its president, Keiji Tachikawa, DoCoMo is trying to build itself into the global leader for mobile Internet services. It has said it plans to buy stakes in overseas carriers. The bond sale would be DoCoMo's first in about two years.

title: Times Reporters Cited for Excellence
description: Selena Roberts of The New York Times won first place in The Associated Press Sports Editors national contest for her May 16, 1999 account of the New York Knicks' Game 5 victory over the Miami Heat during last season's National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: A Neighborhood Place Without Boundaries
description: SCRATCH the surface of the most sophisticated diner, and you'll find a simple soul yearning for a neighborhood restaurant. Like the family farm that politicians love to invoke, or the ivy-covered cottage in the country that every apartment dweller dreams of, this restaurant is about nine parts myth, but no less powerful for that. It is small but tastefully decorated. The owner knows his customers, and his face lights up with joy on seeing them. The menu is short but inventive. The wine list, too, is brief but enthralling. The prices are reasonable.

description: Japan's languid economy slid into another recession late last year, companies are struggling to overhaul themselves, the government's debts are piling up and the prime minister is comatose with a stroke.

title: U.N. Says Bad Government Is Often the Cause of Poverty

title: Red Wine Sauce
description: The primary component of this sauce is the marinade we used earlier. It needs to be cooked again to reduce it, which intensifies the flavor, and also to pasteurize it, since it was used with raw poultry. For color and extra flavor, we're going to add some fresh blueberries at the very end. Be careful to simply warm them, not cook them.

description: In a bold display of the optimism that has characterized its growth predictions in the past, the Coca-Cola Company told investors yesterday that it expected its sales volume to increase 7 percent to 8 percent a year over the long term and that it planned to increase earnings by 15 percent a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMEL, CLAIRE
description: BAUMEL-Claire, 71, of Delray Beach, FL, on April 1. The members of Women's American ORT are deeply grieved over the death of Claire Baumel, an Honorary Vice President who was the embodiment of public service for more than 40 years. Passionate and vibrant, an inspiring personality and speaker, Claire was an active member of the national leadership, serving as Vice President, Chairwoman of the National Organization Subcommittee, National Financial Secretary and NAtional Treasurer. In her work for ORT, she traveled extensively throughout the United States and abroad, conveying her fascination with ''an organization devoted to freeing people from hopelessness through education.'' We extend our loving sympathy to Claire's husband, Win, her children, Mally, Jeff and Ellin, and her grandchildren, Brian, Danny and Matthew. A memorial fund in memory of Claire will be established at Women's American ORT, 315 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10010. We will sorely miss her.

title: Duck Breast
description: The trick to making great duck breast is to use its natural fat to cook it, rendering the fat at the same time so that only a thin, crispy layer is left at the end. Duck breast, considered by many to be a red meat, is treated like beef, so it should be cooked, ideally, to medium rare. Cooked longer than that, like beef, it begins to toughen.

title: The Pursuit of Justice in Bosnia
description: With the arrest this week of Momcilo Krajisnik, the international war crimes tribunal is closing in on the architects of the mass killing of Muslim civilians during the 1992-95 Bosnian war. For the past four and a half years, NATO troops have kept the guns of Bosnia silent. But NATO has been hesitant to pursue the top officials responsible for the slaughter, fearing reprisals or even a renewal of ethnic warfare.

title: A White-Collar Innocent In Blue-Collar Territory
description: ''Human Resources'' begins innocently enough as the story of an eager beaver fresh out of business school who returns from Paris to his home in the provinces to take a white-collar job at the factory where his father has worked for 30 years. In these opening scenes, Frank (Jalil Lespert), the pride of his blue-collar family, is a veritable Boy Scout: a little overconfident perhaps but also a model son and, once he lands a job in the factory's human resources division, a dutiful, enthusiastic employee bursting with new ideas.

title: ALBANY'S LEADERS REACH AGREEMENT ON SPENDING PLAN
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature agreed today on the outlines of a roughly $77 billion spending plan that generously finances education, health care, transportation and tax cuts, clearing the way for one of the earliest budgets in a decade.

title: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEWS; In a Drama of Brooklyn, Real Life Is a Co-Star
description: ''Our Song,'' which will be shown tonight and tomorrow night as part of the New Directors/New Films festival at the Museum of Modern Art, follows three young friends through the languid, anxious days of a summer in Brooklyn. In the course of the film, which moves with the ease and warmth of its season and place, Lanisha, Jocelyn and Maria face the usual dilemmas and frustrations of teenage life in America -- and in the movies -- today. They shop (and shoplift), daydream about their futures, boys and exotic ice cream flavors, anticipate the coming of the school year and navigate the treacherous tides of sexuality, social ambition and loyalty to one another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKIN, SOLOMON
description: BARKIN-Solomon. Devoted husband and loving father, died at his home in Leverett, MA. on March 29 at age 92. His long productive life affected and improved the lives of many people. His dedication to the labor movement spanned 25 years as economist for the Textile Workers Union of America, now joined to UNITE. In academia, his prolific scholarly writings influenced the thinking of many students. As an internationalist, he executed and directed numerous studies during five years in Paris with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, in Rotterdam at Erasmus University and as an professor Emeritus at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Married almost 60 years to Elaine Rappaport, he is survived by their children, David, Roger, and Amy, and three grandsons, Adam, Michael, and Benjamin. A memorial service will be held April 27.

Nortel will buy testing, manufacturing and repair services from Solectron. Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, is the No. 2 phone-equipment maker in North America after Lucent Technologies. It is selling plants to focus on product development. Solectron's shares rose $4.1875 each, to $43.4375. Nortel's stock fell $5.3125, to $114.4375.

It made the disclosure in a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The purchase, which Century hopes to complete by the end of the second quarter, depends on Century's completing a labor contract with the United Steelworkers of America. title: JDS UNIPHASE TO PURCHASE CRONOS IN STOCK DEAL
description: The JDS Uniphase Corporation, a maker of equipment for fiber optical systems, agreed yesterday to acquire Cronos Integrated Microsystems Inc. for $750 million in stock. Cronos, based in Research Triangle Park, N.C., makes small mirrors known as micro-electro-mechanical systems, or MEMS, which can route data in optical systems. JDS Uniphase, based in San Jose, Calif., said MEMS technology was expected to play a leading role in a wide variety of future lines of optical components, including switches. The number of shares in the deal will be determined based on the price of JDS Uniphase stock preceding the closing, which is expected later this month. JDS Uniphase stock fell $4.625 yesterday, to $107, in Nasdaq trading.

title: A Question of Literary Ethics
description: In an irritable little book published late last year about The New Yorker magazine, Renata Adler suddenly veers from her literary prey to take a swipe at one of the heroes of the Watergate era, Judge John Sirica. The passage, in ''Gone: The Last Days of The New Yorker,'' is written as an aside, a dismissal of the respected jurist as a ''corrupt, incompetent, and dishonest figure, with a close connection to Senator Joseph McCarthy and clear ties to organized crime.'' Since Judge Sirica is dead, he is unable to sue for libel. But that does not lift the ethical burden from Ms. Adler to support her charges with evidence she says exists -- evidence that she and her editors at Simon & Schuster, for some unfathomable reason, omitted from her book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAULA, WILLIAM
description: KAULA-William. Professor William M. Kaula, passed away April 1, 2000 from complications of cancer. He was born 1926 in Sydney to Edna Mason, an Australian of British descent, and Edgar (Ed) Kaula, an American of Czech descent. He graduated from West Point Military Academy in 1948. In addition to teaching classes, Bill served UCLA twice as a department chair, and twice as a member of the council of academic personnel. He frequently served NASA as a project participant (e.g.,team leader for the altimeter on Apollos 15, 16, & 17); proposal reviewer (e.g., chair of the Lunar & Planetary Review Panel); and program advisor (e.g., twice member of Space Science Board). His other principal association outside UCLA was with the American Geophysical Union (AGU), as section officer, journal editor, and advisory committee member. In the mid 1980's Bill took leave from UCLA to serve three years as head of the National Geodetic survey (NGS) in NOAA. He received three honors: The Whitten medal of the AGU; The Brouwer medal of the American Astronomical Society; and, in 1987, membership in the national Academy of Sciences (NAS). Bill is survived by three daughters and his wife, Gene Hurley Kaula.

title: UNISYS STOCK FALLS AFTER COMPANY WARNS ON REVENUE

Shares of Unisys, based in Blue Bell, Pa., were down $2.1875, at $23.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Unisys said it expected revenue of $1.66 billion to $1.69 billion in the first three months of 2000, pointing to a slow recovery in its financial services division after the year-end switch as well as continued weakness in its federal government business and negative effects from currency conversions.

title: Introduction

For others, the problem is basic: they lack the fundamental skills that can cut the time and aggravation so dramatically that the sense of drudgery slips away and the pure enjoyment of the act itself grows into the kind of true gratification that all creativity brings.

title: PEAPOD SAYS IT HAS OBTAINED LOAN, SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS

Peapod, an Internet grocery delivery service, said it had obtained a commitment from the party for an immediate bridge loan, subject to various conditions. Shares of the 11-year-old company have fallen about 58 percent since March 16, when its chief executive, Bill Malloy, resigned for health reasons. The resignation prompted the cancellation of a $120 million investment by Apollo Management L.P., the Yucaipa Companies, Pequot Capital Management Inc. and GRP II L.P. title: Dining With the Leaping Deer
description: When it comes to creating furniture, Paul Mathieu likes to work in a few mysteries. ''I like people not to know all of it at once,'' Mr. Mathieu, a French designer, said. Hence the subtleties of Elementaire, Mr. Mathieu's line of dining tables (Eau is at top; Air, above) and assorted cabinets for Donghia. Inspired by nature -- as seen near his home in Provence and as expressed in poems by Michael Ray, his late companion and partner -- the pieces invite not just use but contemplation. ''It is social furniture,'' the designer added. Handles cast branchlike shadows, ash veneer is used for its watery grain, and the arched legs of one dining table recall Mr. Mathieu's surprise encounter with a deer. ''It was so heavy, so much part of the earth, and then it sprang up, so light,'' he said. Prices range from $6,625 for a buffet to $14,085 for a sideboard. To the trade at Donghia; (800) 366-4442.

title: Retracing an Ill-Fated Shackleton Expedition
description: Sir Ernest Shackleton's great renown as an explorer is not based on what he discovered, but on what he survived. The captain of the British ship Endurance set out in 1914 to become the first man to cross the Antarctic continent. Four months after the Endurance was caught and crushed in ice, Shackleton and five crewmen set out in a 22-foot boat, hoping to reach a whaling station on South Georgia island, some 800 miles away. Remarkably, their attempt was successful and the rest of Shackleton's crew was rescued 22 months after their expedition began.

title: CHINA TELEPHONE COMPETITION
description: In the first real challenge to the dominance of China Telecom, the country's former telephone monopoly, the No. 2 Chinese telecommunications operator, China Unicom, has begun offering fixed-line service in 25 cities at rates 20 percent to 25 percent below those of China Telecom. Established nearly a decade ago to create competition in telecommunications, China Unicom has fought bureaucratic barriers that until recently had kept it from offering much more than cellular telephone services. Most recently, the company was forced to dissolve joint ventures with several foreign companies. China Unicom plans to list its shares overseas this year. Craig S. Smith

By a vote of 275 to 147, the House approved legislation that would move authority to decide how organs are distributed across the country from the Department of Health and Human Services, where it belongs, to the private agency now under contract with the government to coordinate distribution, the nonprofit United Network for Organ Sharing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOOB, LEONARD W. STERLING
description: DOOB - Leonard W. Sterling Professor Emeritus of the Department of Psychology at Yale University died peacefully at the age of 91 on March 30, 2000. He joined the Yale faculty in 1934 after receiving his Ph.D from Harvard. He was at Yale thereafter, except during World War II when he was with the U.S. office of War information. He was most active shortly before his death with his most recent book (Pursuing Perfection: People, Groups and Society) having been published in 1999. He was predeceased by his wife, Eveline Bates Doob, and leaves his sons, Christopher, Anthony, and Nicholas, and grandchildren, Gabriella, Joshua and Crockett. An informal gathering of family and friends will be held at the Hawley Lincoln Memorial, 493 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, Sat, April 8, at 2 PM.

title: A Legendary Shop Shuffles Off to a New Home
description: Madeleine Castaing hated selling things. So Castaing, the legendary decorator and dealer, would be distraught that her shop at 21 rue Bonaparte, above, where she worked until her death in 1992, will trade hands next month. Its new owner will be Laduree, the luxury bakery. ''Sad isn't the word; it makes me sick,'' said the shop's manager, Laure Lombardini, adding that Castaing's son Michel has already sold her above-the-shop apartment to Ismail Merchant. The shop has a moody Balzacian decor -- the mold on the mint-green walls is real -- but the star was always Castaing, left, whose brown wig was secured by a highly visible elastic chin strap. The shop's goods will move to a smaller location nearby, at 30 rue Jacob. ''We're still in business,'' Mrs. Lombardini said. ''Just around the corner.''

title: The Quest of Juan Gonzalez
description: Juan Miguel Gonzalez has made the right decision to travel to the United States today to affirm his desire to be reunited with his son, Elian. His presence on American soil is necessary to dispel doubts about his fitness as a father -- raised maliciously by Elian's Miami relatives -- and to end speculation that he is indifferent about reclaiming custody of his son. With Mr. Gonzalez all but out of sight in Cuba, the relatives have had a free hand to distort the case with bogus legal arguments and unsubstantiated claims that Elian is afraid to see his father.

title: Drouot's Grande Dame Sheds the 70's
description: Sotheby's and Christie's, take note. Challenged by those companies' entries into the French marketplace, the consortium of auctioneers that makes up Drouot, the 150-year-old Paris auction house, hired Jean-Michel Wilmotte, an award-winning minimalist architect, to revamp its headquarters on the rue de Richelieu. It's about time. An elegant 19th-century building that was clumsily refaced in 1980 with a brutalist ''Bladerunner'' reflective metal facade, right, not to mention an exterior waterfall splashing into a pile of artistic rubble, Drouot Richelieu is arguably the ugliest building in the city. ''It is not very fashionable, too much like the 70's,'' said Virginie Burnet, a Drouot spokeswoman. Nor very pleasing to visit. Mr. Wilmotte and the project architects, Fabrice Drain and Astrid Courtois, will streamline the warren of cramped escalators, hard-to-find entrances and sales rooms clad in grimy red and orange velvet. (The team's sleekly hip design, below, won a Drouot-sponsored contest; the grand-luxe decorator Jacques Garcia came in second.) The renewed auction house will offer user-friendly services like a cafe and a bookshop. Construction will begin in late July, when Drouot Richelieu closes for the summer, and be completed by mid-September, when it is scheduled to reopen.

title: Choices, Choices: A Modern Morality Play
description: IN 10 years, we might look back at the game Central High and view it as a small token of desperation in the aftermath of the shootings at Columbine High School. Central High, a new game from Destiny Interactive, is a poignant attempt to help patch up a society gone wrong: a computer game produced by adults in the hope that it will teach teenagers that it's a bad idea to torture their misfit peers. The concept is doomed from the start.

title: Higher Voltage for High-Tech Cars
description: ELECTRICAL systems in cars are about to hit their limits. DuPont said it would save $80 million in the moves and would take a second-quarter pretax charge of about $55 million. The job cuts will be mostly in Europe, where the Herberts paints unit, which it bought from Hoechst of Germany, is based. DuPont said in July it would eliminate 1,300 positions in the coatings unit, or 8.7 percent of the work force at the time, and shut six Herberts plants in Europe, Mexico and Brazil.

title: PEREGRINE TO BUY HARBINGER FOR $2.1 BILLION

Peregrine will exchange 0.75 of its shares, valued at $43.50, for each share of Harbinger stock. The price was more than 80 percent above Harbinger's closing price yesterday of $24.125, up $2 a share. Peregrine expects to issue about 36 million shares for the acquisition. The purchase would help Peregrine provide a more complete selection of software to let companies use the Internet to purchase supplies, manage catalogs and keep track of the availability and cost of facilities and resources. title: School Cuts Are an 'Admission of Failure,' Mrs. Clinton Says
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that plans to sharply cut back summer school in New York City represented a ''terrible admission of failure'' on the part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mrs. Clinton attacked Mr. Giuliani's push for teacher merit pay, the issue that led to the breakdown in talks over the school program, calling it a crude and ineffective way to improve public education.

title: When Follies Move Indoors
description: Bernd Dams, an architect, and Andrew Zega, an artist and writer, live in Paris and collaborate on erudite but popular books on fanciful buildings of the ancien regime. But, Mr. Dams said, ''all that research left us wanting to do something else with our hands.'' The result was linden and beech obelisks, above and below. Made to order by European woodworkers, they are available in two sizes -- nine-inch tabletop follies and five-inch place-card holders. Prices start at $350 each. They can be ordered by fax: (011) 33-1-40-13-91-16.

title: Greenspan Treads Softly After Market's Gyrations
description: A day after Wall Street endured one of its most unnerving rides, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered soothing words to investors today, saying as explicitly as he ever has that the central bank's interest rate increases are not intended to drive down stock prices.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMAZON.COM, Seattle, the biggest Internet retailer, opened a lawn-and-patio store on the Web to sell a wider range of yard tools, furniture and decorations.

title: Sports of The Times; Retouches For Golf's Mona Lisa
description: IF Cypress Point, out there with the surf and the seals on the rocks of the Monterrey Peninsula in California, is considered the Sistine Chapel of golf courses, Augusta National is the Mona Lisa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWICZ, DINA
description: ABRAMOWICZ-Dina. The National Yiddish Book Center mourns the passing of Dina Abramowicz. She knew more about Yiddish books and culture than any person alive, and graciously shared her knowledge with three generations of scholars. May her memory be a blessing for us all. Aaron Lansky, President National Yiddish Book Center Amherst, MA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ARTHUR S.
description: FRIEDMAN-Arthur S. of Harrison, New York on April 3, 2000 at age 58. Devoted husband of Helaine (nee Consor) and beloved father and best friend of David Eliot, son of Oscar, adored son-in-law of Mollie Consor. Brother & brotherin-law of Harvey & Yvette Consor and Steven and Ann Friedman. Loving uncle of Glenn, Jill and Lisa Consor and Alan and Jennifer Friedman. He practiced law in New York for thirty years. His sage advice and wonderful friendship will be missed by all who knew him. The funeral will be Thursday April 6 at 1:30 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Interment immediately following at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York. The family will sit shiva at their home in Harrison, New York.

title: Quick Paper Profit for Bank One's New Chief
description: The Bank One Corporation's chairman and chief executive, James Dimon, who was hired less than two weeks ago, has already made at least $14.9 million on paper from stock the bank paid him and gains on shares he bought himself.

title: Lockheed Charged With Violating Export Laws
description: The State Department has charged the Lockheed Martin Corporation with 30 violations of arms export laws in connection with its help in evaluating problems in Chinese-made satellite technology in 1994.

title: Drug Price Issue Catching Fire in Senate
description: A Republican senator said today that he was drafting legislation to reduce price disparities that forced consumers to pay much more for prescription drugs in the United States than in Canada or Mexico.

title: FOAMEX NEGOTIATIONS WITH POTENTIAL BUYER BREAK DOWN
description: After being left at the altar once again, Foamex International Inc. has hired the investment bank J. P. Morgan & Company as an adviser and is looking for another buyer. Foamex, based in Linwood, Pa., is a maker of polyurethane and polymer foam products. It said yesterday that discussions between the company and an interested ''buying group'' had broken down. A company spokeswoman said the company hired J. P. Morgan to review strategic alternatives and was interested in finding another buyer. In August, the privately held Sorgenti Chemical Industries and Liberty Partners Holdings reportedly offered to buy Foamex for $287.5 million, but talks ended when the sides were unable to agree on the price.

title: Mirrors Grab Center Stage
description: THESE days, mirrors are doing more than just reflecting; they're being cast as the star attraction. Peri Wolfman, a designer, selects enormous mirrors, each taking the place of a painting, for the walls of her SoHo loft. ''I never could make a commitment to a large painting,'' she said. ''Anyway, I would get tired of it too quickly to make the investment worthwhile. But mirrors fill the space and add reflections as well.'' And for light-deprived spaces, mirrors add welcome reflected light.

title: Virtual Garage Sales, With No Haggling
description: WHEN I heard about a new online site called Half.com, where you can buy and sell used books, software and music CD's for up to half their list prices, my initial reaction was fear. Here, I figured, was another gimmicky site that would turn out to be sort of like eBay, but not really, and might be fun to use once, but only if you have a lot of time on your hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRILLMAN, RABBI SOLOMON E.
description: DRILLMAN-Rabbi Solomon E. Glenwood Jewish Center-Brooklyn, and Ramat Modiim-Israel record with deep sorrow, the passing of our beloved Rabbi, Teacher, & friend. He served our community for over 37 years, and left is imprint on hundreds of families. We extend our condolences to his wife, children and family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Pres. Wm Posner GJC-Brooklyn Pres. Steve Blitz GJC-Israel

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special E-Commerce section on March 29 about the Web's expansion of the reach of college radio misstated the call letters of Boston University's station. It is WTBU, not WBTU.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can't wage war without money, and diamonds are money.''

title: Essay; Ally Vs. Customer
description: Israel is on the brink of endangering its strategic alliance with the United States. Its leader seems to place higher priority on a lucrative sale to China of Awacs spy planes equipped with the most sophisticated Israeli-developed technology. Beijing could then far better manage any battle with Taiwanese and American forces in the Taiwan Strait.

title: Metro Matters; The Column Never Sleeps: Some Updates
description: With Metro Matters about to take a vacation, an update on a few columns.

title: A Loyal Party Man: Yoshiro Mori
description: In Nagatacho, Tokyo's political hub, Yoshiro Mori, who was elected prime minister today, is often referred to as ''an elephant with a flea's heart,'' a reference to his 220-pound frame and what many of his critics say is his indecisiveness, especially under fire.

title: Little Access to Pain Drugs in Some Areas
description: Cancer patients and others with severe pain who live in black, Asian and Hispanic neighborhoods may have trouble getting medicine for their pain, because their local pharmacies often do not stock morphine and related drugs, doctors are reporting.

title: Israel Frees One of 16 Lebanese It Held to Trade for Its Soldiers
description: Israel today freed one of 16 Lebanese prisoners who have been held without charges as ''bargaining chips'' for the potential release of Israeli soldiers captured in Lebanon.

description: Valley Cool to Reno Crime Plan

We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Klein family. Gladys George, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater New York Hospital Assn

title: Gap Reports 11% Drop in March Sales
description: Gap Inc., the largest United States clothing chain, said today that its sales at stores open at least a year fell 11 percent in March -- more than forecast -- as sales dropped at its Gap and Old Navy stores in the United States.

title: A Concert With a Point: Mercurial Imagination
description: Carnegie Hall's Perspectives series, in which Daniel Barenboim, Pierre Boulez and Maurizio Pollini have been given blank slates to fill as they like, lends itself to overarching statements about music and its history. The degree to which all three musicians have jumped at this opportunity has been heartening, as has the freshness they have brought to programming at Carnegie in particular and the New York concert world more generally. And although each has taken a distinct approach, one impulse is shared by the three prongs of the series: a desire to make sense of the 20th-century's music by putting it in a historical context.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILBERT, THOMAS JR.
description: HILBERT-Thomas Jr. in Fairfield, CT., April 4, 2000. Age 85, husband of the late Jane Bracken Hilbert, retired Chief Labor and Employment Law Counsel for the General Electric Co. A Trustee of the College of Mt. St. Vincent, and a member of the Board of Directors of Calvary Hospital. Father of Thomas F. Hilbert III, Lawrence Hilbert, Rev. Michael P. Hilbert S.J., and Anne Hilbert. Memorial Mass will take place Friday, April 7th, 10:30 A.M. in St. Pius X Church, Fairfield. title: Primaries in Pennsylvania Put Focus on Congressional Races
description: With polls showing Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush running neck-and-neck for Pennsylvania's 23 electoral votes, the state was already one to watch in November. Now the results from Congressional primaries on Tuesday make it even more interesting.

title: Rib Injury Quickly Sidelines Brosius
description: Scott Brosius couldn't wait to start this season. After spending the off-season dealing with the death of his father last September, he felt physically sound and wanted to get a fresh start on his baseball career.

title: Despite Opposition, Ikea Starts Buying Land for Superstore
description: Although it faces mounting community opposition and is still months from obtaining city approvals for its plans to build a superstore here, Ikea, the Swedish furniture company, this week bought its first piece of property in the neighborhood that it covets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHNER, IRVING
description: KIRSCHNER-Irving. The Board of Directors and residents of 14 Beekman Place Corp. mourn the loss of former Director, Irving Kirschner, and extend their sincere condolences to the entire Kirschner family. Arthur J. Margolin, President

title: The High Cost of Underestimating Lightning
description: DAVID SILVESTER, owner of Zeus Lightning Rod Inc. in Hopewell, N.J., knows that proselytizing is hopeless: not until an electrical storm gives homeowners firsthand experience -- when it blows their chimneys apart, zaps their computer disk drives and fries their air conditioners -- do they think of buying a lightning rod. Until then, they consider the chore as pressing as recaulking the windows. ''You think about it after you've been hit,'' said Karen Shapiro, who bought a lightning rod after her Georgian-style home in Croton-on-Hudson was struck last summer. ''Something that sounded like a cannon went off next to the house,'' she recalled, and -- mid-e-mail -- her computer screen went black. Much of her and her husband's other electronic equipment also went down, and the laptop computer was destroyed. They bought a $3,000 lightning protection system with lightning rods and surge suppressors for the electronic equipment.

description: Add to the casualty list of collateral destruction by horrible divorces the New Hampshire Supreme Court.

title: The Star of Bangladesh; In New York, Don't Take 'Indian' Food Too Literally
description: Farasath Ali, who owns the Great India restaurant on Second Avenue at East 82nd Street, doesn't come from India. Neither does Mohammed Karim at the Indian Spice House, a definitive Asian grocery store on East Sixth Street. The Spice House anchors a block of restaurants with names like Taj Mahal, Gandhi, Kohinoor and Windows on India.

title: Sports of The Times; McEnroe Expects No Surprises
description: HERE were no heads of state surrounded by armed guards here yesterday at the Davis Cup draw, only the presidents of various tennis federations. Following the African-inspired first-round intrigue in Zimbabwe two months ago, it's back to more basic cup business, a conventional competition that is likely to be as inspiring as a Lakers home date against the Clippers.

description: William H. Gates is on videotape again. And the antitrust case against his company is again the backdrop. But this time he is taking his case directly to the people.

description: After weeks of angry shouts, name-calling and vows that little Elian Gonzalez will be taken from his relatives' house only over their dead bodies, demonstrators outside the home in Little Havana adopted a fresh tactic here today.

description: The air was thick with incense and the cacophony of homemade horns recently as the people of this tiny village on China's southern coast prepared to celebrate their most sacred holiday.

title: U.S. Reduces Forecast For Gasoline Prices
description: The Energy Department said today that gasoline would cost a good deal less this summer than what had been forecast just a month ago, though the typical household was still expected to spend $170 more to fuel up the family car than last summer.

description: SEOUL  The National Election Commission added ammunition Thursday to the nationwide civic action movement with the revelation that some candidates for the National Assembly have criminal records.

title: School Board Considers Deal To Swap Ads for Computers
description: A task force of New York school officials and executives of several big computer companies is proposing to distribute laptop computers to city schoolchildren and to create a school Web site that would give the companies advertising space in exchange for services and equipment.

title: Assembling of the Genome Is at Hand
description: Dr. J. Craig Venter told a Congressional committee today that his company, the Celera Corporation, had finished analyzing all necessary pieces of human DNA and would assemble the whole human genome within three to six weeks, far earlier than expected.

title: Free Speech at City Hall
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's cramped view of free speech rights has produced yet another embarrassing legal defeat for him and his enablers in the City Law Department. In a sound decision yesterday, Federal District Judge Harold Baer Jr. declared unconstitutional the tight restrictions imposed by the mayor on the use of the steps and plaza in front of New York's City Hall for public demonstrations.

title: Injuries Minor For Marbury And Kittles
description: The Nets dodged a backcourt disaster yesterday when magnetic resonance imaging scans performed on the achy knees of guards Stephon Marbury and Kerry Kittles showed no major damage that would require surgery. Both players had M.R.I.'s at Beth Israel North in Manhattan, and the results were evaluated by the Nets' team orthopedist, Dr. Michael Kelly.

title: Personnel File of General Bore No Hint of Harassment
description: When the Army's top leaders appointed him deputy inspector general, the personnel file of the general accused of sexual harassment by the service's highest-ranking woman included no indication that she had ever complained about his behavior, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNDHEIM, MARSHALL A., M.D.
description: MUNDHEIM-Marshall A., M.D. Words cannot express my sadness at the death of Dr. Mundheim. He saved my life 33 years ago, and made it worth living ever since. His oldest and most grateful patient, Kathy Dobkin.

title: Devils' Hold on the Top Spot Is Slipping
description: Frustrated and confused, the Devils were finally pried away from the Buffalo Sabres as they shoved and pushed after the conclusion of a game that had been over long before the final horn. While it was the Sabres that the Devils were lashing at, the anger that was boiling in the Devils was truly aimed at themselves.

title: Tribe Wins Federal Approval for Casino in the Borscht Belt
description: The federal Interior Department approved plans yesterday for a $500 million casino to be operated by the St. Regis Mohawk Indian tribe in the Catskills, where local officials, hotel owners and many residents have long hoped that gambling might bring an economic revival to the depressed resort area once known as the borscht belt.

title: Foe's Strength Forces Putin Into a Humbling Reversal
description: As President-elect Vladimir V. Putin flew north beyond the Arctic Circle this week to ride a nuclear-powered submarine and burnish his image as commander in chief, the event that was making political waves was the scuttling of his hand-picked candidate for governor of his home region here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEELY, ROBERT M.

Memorial service will be held at 3PM on Monday, April 10, 2000 at the Unitarian Church of all Souls, Lexington Ave. at 80th St. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations be made to the Class of 1950 Scholarship Fund at Williams College, PO Box 231, Williamstown, MA. 01267 or The Cornwall Library Capital Project, Cornwall, CT. 06753.

title: Big Board Suggests Ending Links Among Exchanges
description: The torturous process of reorganizing United States securities markets took another turn yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange called for ending the aging system that provides rudimentary links between the Big Board, regional exchanges and the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Rivera Hurt By Ailment In Opener
description: Mariano Rivera allowed a run for the first time since last July in Monday's season opener, but there were mitigating circumstances that he never mentioned after the game. The closer had been horribly sick early in the game with some sort of stomach ailment.

title: Oh, It's a Wonderful Life! (If Only She'd Realized It)
description: Which of us hasn't wondered in a moment of despondency whether life might have turned out for the better had a former relationship not been discarded? That big what-if drives ''Me Myself I,'' a sugarcoated romantic comedy that is just clever enough to make you wish it were three times as smart and only a third as sweet.

description: The Insider

title: Judge Strikes Down Rule Limiting City Hall Protests
description: A federal judge in Manhattan yesterday struck down a city regulation governing the number of protesters allowed on the steps of City Hall, ruling that the city had unfairly restricted access to a favored spot for everything from demonstrations to news conferences.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Lee Petty, 86, Racing Family Patriarch, Dies
description: Lee Petty, a champion stock car racer in the 1950's who was the father of the sport's greatest driver, Richard Petty, died Wednesday in Moses Cone Hospital in Greensboro, N.C. Petty, who was 86, had been hospitalized for several weeks after surgery for a stomach aneurysm.

title: Beirut Says It Can't Prevent Palestinian Attacks on Israel
description: In a new sign of Arab unease, officials here warned today that they could not, and would not, prevent Palestinian militants from using Lebanese territory to mount attacks on Israel after its army withdraws unilaterally from southern Lebanon.

title: An unconventional Madison Avenue initiative wins positive reviews as its second year begins.
description: A YEAR after the start of an unusual collaboration between a giant agency and seven creative ''hot shops,'' the participants are giving the experiment generally high marks despite some disappointments.

title: Body and Skull Found In Separate Incidents
description: A man fishing in the lake in Prospect Park in Brooklyn yesterday hooked a human body, the police said. The corpse, which appeared to be that of a man in his 50's, has not been identified, nor was it clear how long it had been in the murky water, said Officer John Giammarino, a police spokesman.

title: Scientists Retract Claim of Planet Discovery
description: What some astronomers believed to be the only planet ever directly observed outside the solar system has turned out to be an ordinary dim star, NASA announced yesterday.

description: Shares of QXL.com, a British Internet company, soared 132 percent yesterday after an analyst for one of the brokerage firms that underwrote QXL's offering six months ago forecast that the shares would rise more than tenfold.

title: She Gets His Wife's Heart (Literally), and Him, Too
description: You can hear lots of hearty laughter from the kitchen of O'Reilly's, the Irish-Italian restaurant in ''Return to Me,'' a faltering new romantic comedy directed by Bonnie Hunt. It's about a heart, and an irreplaceable, deep-seated love that can be passed from one person to another. At least, this love can be passed from a heart's donor, Elizabeth, to its recipient, Grace (Minnie Driver). After Elizabeth dies in a car accident, the sickly Grace gets her heart, and a wondrous romance begins to bloom between Grace and Elizabeth's husband, Bob (David Duchovny).

title: When the Journalist Is the Star
description: It seems that ABC may be shamed out of airing Leonardo DiCaprio's interview with President Clinton on global warming, apparently because it didn't live up to some notional idea of what an interview with the president should be. ''We did not send him to interview the president,'' David Westin, the president of ABC News, said of Mr. DiCaprio in a press release. ''No one is that stupid.''

title: Once Again, Jets Field Offers for Johnson
description: Coach Al Groh acknowledged yesterday what seemed to have been obvious for a month, that the Jets would listen to the right offer for a trade involving Keyshawn Johnson, and he indicated that the team thought the wide receiver was expendable.

title: Brazil Planning Early Payments to International Lenders
description: In perhaps the strongest sign yet that the Brazilian economy is recovering from last year's currency crisis, the country's central bank will repay early a large part of a $41.5 billion emergency loan package provided by the International Monetary Fund and other lenders.

title: Paying Court To a Wry Master Of the Baroque
description: IS there a Baroque beyond Bach? Yes, though you may be hard put to find it this year, with performers and record companies tripping over one another to commemorate the 250th anniversary of the master's death.

title: Wallowing in the World of Wrestling
description: ''Ready to Rumble'' is a courageous, devastating expose of the brutality, misogyny and homophobia that pervade the so-called sport of professional wrestling. The film goes to shocking lengths to show how this wildly popular form of entertainment transforms its young male fans into uncouth, slack-jawed dolts who think that punching women in the face is an acceptable mode of foreplay, and who are entirely unable to distinguish fantasy from reality. The movie also explores, with candor and sensitivity, the undercurrent of sado-masochistic homoeroticism that has made wrestling a big-money attraction for the whole family.

Rangel will ask the Justice Department today for an examination of whether top New York City officials have tried to derail judicial reviews of three recent fatal police shootings by releasing or trying to uncover derogatory information about the victims, a government official said.

title: Buttressing an Old City With New Artistic Girders
description: Like the fantasy pleasure dome of Xanadu, the term movie palace conjures up a magical image: a romantic time when the film world was bursting with technological advances, complemented by live entertainment. In downtown Pittsburgh alone, there were once eight such extravaganzas within a few blocks' radius, and in their heyday, the 1920's and 30's, people flocked to the cinema and to vaudeville acts in an atmosphere that dripped with gilded plaster and crystal chandeliers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HAROLD

Adored son of Florence. Devoted father of Douglas and Mara. Service is on Friday, 11:30 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, corner of 91st Street.

title: Long March Ends in South Carolina, But Little Time Is Left to Lower Flag
description: By his own estimate, Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston had walked nearly 275,000 steps when he turned the corner onto Main Street this morning and finally saw the Confederate battle flag that he and hundreds of others had been marching since Sunday to remove.

title: Charismatic Curmudgeon vs. New Yorker Writer
description: The great British actor Ian Holm has had many juicy film roles, but none has placed him so ferociously front and center as the title character of ''Joe Gould's Secret.'' Sir Ian's ranting, fiery-eyed performance is the brilliant spark that ignites this otherwise rather somnolent film, adapted by Stanley Tucci and the screenwriter Howard A. Rodman from Joseph Mitchell's famous New Yorker profiles, ''Professor Sea Gull'' and ''Joe Gould's Secret.''

title: RANGER OIL GETS OFFER
description: Another Canadian oil company with poor stock performance has drawn a hostile takeover bid. Shareholders of Ranger Oil Ltd. of Calgary have been offered 1.6 billion Canadian dollars (about $1.1 billion) in cash or stock by Petrobank Energy and Resources Ltd., also of Calgary. Ranger called the proposal inadequate and said it would seek better offers. On Wednesday, Ulster Petroleums Ltd. rejected a $353 million hostile bid from the Hunt Oil Company of Dallas. title: Nevada Power Plant Set

The cost of the project was not given. Southern Energy, which is based in Atlanta, develops and operates power production and delivery facilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMINGDALE, EILEEN CRUTCHLOW, PH.D.
description: BLOOMINGDALE-Eileen Crutchlow, Ph.D., 83, of Cape Coral. Died April 5 peacefully of natural causes. Dr. Bloomingdale was born in Montreal, P.Q. to Marguerite Laviolette, wife of a wellknown physician, Charles Crutchlow, MD. Her older brother, Everett Crutchlow, MD and sister, Winifred Crutchlow, are deceased. Dr. Bloomingdale graduated from McGill Univ. where she captained the women's basketball team for four years and was nicknamed ''Crutch'' subsequently, during WW II she was a psychologist for the Canadian Veterans Affairs, becoming Chief Psychologist for St. Anne's De Bellevue Veterans Hospital. The noted Neurologist, Sir Wilder Penfield, referred some of her first private patients. She married Lewis M. Bloomingdale, then a medical student at Harvard Medical School. She received her Ph.D in clinical psychology from Harvard Univ., taking her oral examination while pregnant. The Bloomingdale doctors engaged in their individual private practices as psychologist and psychiatrist for over 50 years in Scarsdale, NY. She tested patients days and typed reports until early mornings, seeing 3-5 patients a day. anywhere in Westchester County, she rarely failed to meet someone who would say: ''Dr. Bloomingdale! you remember testing my child (25 years ago). You were right, now (s)he's a (doctor, Lawyer, merchant, beggarman, thief).'' Occasionally, when she arrived in Europe or other countries, she would be greeted by patients she had tested that morning or the previous day. As a forensic psychologist, she was consultant to many attorneys representing prominent plaintiffs and defendants. Bereaved are her husband and son, the psychiatrists Lewis & Kerry Bloomingdale, MD. In memoriam gifts to Harvard Medical School, the Humane Society or to your favorite charity will be appreciated.

title: Welcome Home, Imperialist Dogs
description: After World War II the Soviet government undertook a propaganda campaign to entice Russian emigres in the West to return home. Thousands accepted the offer of Soviet citizenship and the chance to help rebuild their devastated motherland. In return for their devotion, most were summarily executed or imprisoned, victims of either Stalin's paranoia -- he thought that they must be imperialist spies -- or of a state that reserved some of its greatest cruelties for those who trusted and believed in it.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY OFFERS PLAN TO STAY INDEPENDENT

Mitchell, based in Woodlands, Tex., hired investment bankers in October to explore a possible sale or merger. The company now plans to combine its Class A and Class B stock into a single class in late June and buy back as many as 2.5 million shares, or about 5 percent of the total outstanding. Mitchell's Class A shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $21.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Its Class B shares rose 18.75 cents, to $21.375.

title: PEREGRINE SHARES DROP ON HARBINGER DEAL
description: The stock of Peregrine Systems Inc. shed more than one-third of its value after the software company agreed to acquire the Harbinger Corporation in a stock-swap deal valued at about $2.1 billion. Several analysts downgraded the stock on news of the deal, which was announced after the market close on Wednesday. Shares of Peregrine fell $21.25 each to $36.75, while shares of Harbinger rose $2.4375, to $26.5625. Peregrine, a San Diego-based provider of infrastructure management and e-procurement software, will exchange 0.75 of a Peregrine share for each share of Harbinger common stock. Harbinger is an Atlanta-based provider of business-to-business e-commerce software, services and solutions.

title: INTEL IN ACCORD TO ACQUIRE KUCK & ASSOCIATES
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest semiconductor maker, agreed yesterday to acquire Kuck & Associates Inc. for an undisclosed price to add software used in computing with multiple processors. The closely held Kuck & Associates will become a unit of Intel when the transaction closes within the next 30 days. David Kuck, the company's chairman and chief executive, will join Intel as a general manager in its microprocessor products group. Kuck & Associates, based in Champaign, Ill., makes compilers and programming tools used to develop multithreaded software. Multithreaded applications allow more efficient computing by spreading tasks over more than one computer processor. The stock of Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., slipped 6.25 cents, to $129.8125.

title: Desperation of the Dot-Coms

This week's roller coaster ride emphatically does not herald the end of the 1990's bull market.

title: Social Combustion in China
description: Reports are only now reaching the United States of serious unrest in the northeast Chinese mining city of Yangjiazhangzi almost six weeks ago. An account in The Washington Post this week described three days of violent rioting over job cuts and corruption that overwhelmed local police forces and continued until regular army troops arrived. This is just the kind of social upheaval that terrifies the leadership in Beijing, who well know that protests by disenchanted citizens could someday escalate again into a serious threat to Communist rule. Hundreds of economic protests, some of them violent, have erupted across China in recent years, rarely, if ever, reported in the Chinese news media.

title: AETHER SYSTEMS BUYS IFX, A FINANCIAL DATA COMPANY
description: Aether Systems Inc., which develops stock-trading software for handheld computers, said yesterday that it had acquired IFX Group , Europe's No. 1 provider of mobile financial data, for $85 million in cash. Aether said IFX would become part of a planned venture with Reuters Group to provide data services for mobile phone users in Europe. The venture, introduced in February, will be called Sila Communications. Aether will own 60 percent. IFX has about a 60 percent share of the market for real-time financial information services in the countries where it operates. Shares of Aether, based in Owings Mills, Md., rose $1.625, to $139.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, RUTH
description: STERN-Ruth. On April 3, 2000 after a short illness. Beloved wife of Walter, loving mother of Michelle and her husband Andrew and devoted sister of Zsuzsa Dank. A long-time resident of Englewood, NJ and Ocean Beach, Fire Island. She survived Auschwitz, Bergen Belsen etc. together with her sister and went on to become one of the first hundred employees of El Al. She settled in America to enjoy a happy family and professional life. A beautiful and courageous human being who will be missed by everyone who got to know her. Funeral services will be at ''Riverside'', 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave., NYC, on Sunday April 9 at 11:15 AM. Shiva visit can be on Sunday after interment and Monday April 10. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Holocaust Museum in Washington, DC.

It ushers the visitor into a world of high-definition muscles, low-definition sex-linked characteristics and gender-bending ambiguity.

title: VF MAKES $40 MILLION BID FOR H.I.S. SPORTSWEAR
description: The VF Corporation, the maker of Lee and Wrangler jeans, said yesterday that it had offered to buy H.I.S. Sportswear A.G., the German jeans maker, for about $40 million to bolster its share of the women's jeanswear market in Germany and Europe. VF, the world's biggest clothing maker, signed a letter of intent with Chic by H.I.S. Inc. to acquire its 56 percent stake in H.I.S. Sportswear. It also offered other H.I.S. holders 9.25 euros ($8.87) a share for the remaining 44 percent. VF, based in Greensboro, N.C., acquired global trademark rights to the Chic brand and rights to the H.I.S. brand outside Europe for an undisclosed price.

title: It's a War Out There, Soldier, and the Uniform Is Made of Cynicism and Pain
description: A bitter veteran looking to gain a shot at long-lost glory takes on one last big job, maybe even against his better judgment. That's Tommy Lee Jones, the star of ''Rules of Engagement.'' He plays a Marine lawyer who barely escaped Vietnam with his life and now takes on a court case to defend Samuel L. Jackson, as the man who got him out alive. But that plot line could also describe the trajectory of William Friedkin, whose seminal genre films ''The French Connection'' and ''The Exorcist'' put him on Sugar Mountain in the 1970's and who has been trying to rekindle the legend ever since.

title: MERITOR AUTOMOTIVE AND ARVIN WILL MERGE
description: Meritor Automotive Inc., the world's largest maker of heavy-truck axles, and Arvin Industries agreed to combine, creating an auto-parts company with $7.5 billion in sales and the ability to sell the fuller systems that automakers are demanding. The transaction values Arvin, which is based in Columbus, Ind., at about $670 million. Arvin's shareholders will receive one share of the new company, ArvinMeritor Inc., and $2 in cash for each of their 25.6 million shares outstanding. Meritor holders will get 0.75 ArvinMeritor shares for each of their 66.7 million shares and will own about 66 percent of the new company. The move adds shock absorbers and exhaust systems to Meritor's products, helping position ArvinMeritor as automakers push suppliers to build bigger chunks of a car to trim costs.

title: Charges of Harassment by a General
description: The sexual harassment charges filed by Lt. Gen. Claudia Kennedy, the Army's highest ranking woman, against a male general shows that much more needs to be done to end harassment in the military. The case is particularly embarrassing to the Army because General Kennedy is one of only three women in the armed services who are three-star officers, and the accused officer, Maj. Gen. Larry Smith, was appointed last summer to be the Army's deputy inspector general, a post that investigates allegations of sexual misconduct.

title: Intimate Look at a Boy Navigating a Fetid Glasgow Landscape
description: ''Ratcatcher,'' the brilliant directorial debut of Lynne Ramsay, is a gorgeous blend of beauty and squalor, packed with imagery that will play over and over in your head for weeks. It begins with a boy named Ryan spinning while wrapped in his mother's curtains, the cream-colored lace covering his face like a shroud, and the scene shifts from slow motion to real time as his mother angrily pulls him out of the fabric. It's one of the many deft pieces of foreshadowing that Ms. Ramsay allows to seep through the film, the story of 12-year-old James (William Eadie) during a few weeks of his life in the early 1970's.
