title: Foreign Affairs; Elian And the Panderers
description: Visiting Colombia today is a very clarifying act. This is a country where things that we value and take for granted in our own society -- the safety of our children, the right to speak one's mind freely, respect for the rule of law -- are threatened every day. Being here you are reminded not only of how much you cherish these things as an American. You are reminded of the sheer political courage it takes to fight for them in a country where speaking truth can cost you your life or get your kids kidnapped with the snap of a finger.

title: SOFTBANK'S OUTLOOK WORSENS
description: Shares of the largest Japanese Internet investment company, the Softbank Corporation, fell 4 percent, to 70,500 yen ($673) apiece, after the company issued an earnings warning on Thursday. Softbank said it would post a 55 billion yen ($525.4 million) loss for the year that ended on March 31, far below expectations. Investors are also increasingly concerned that the company will have trouble paying capital gains taxes as it starts cashing out of some of its older, larger investments. Stephanie Strom

title: Israel Plans a Test for Wagner
description: Is Israel finally ready to abandon its zealously sustained taboo against public performances of music by Richard Wagner, the Nazis' favorite composer and a symbol of unreconstructed anti-Semitism?

title: Gunman Kills Two and Injures One in a Westchester Hamlet, Then Kills Himself
description: A man, apparently in a jealous rage over a former girlfriend, entered a bakery here this morning and shot three men, killing two, as children and parents stood outside at a school bus stop. The gunman killed himself hours later after a standoff with the police, officials said.

title: No Stroke on the Green Means No Green Jacket
description: What Tiger Woods hoped would be a special Masters has been a struggle. On a day when he needed to make a move, when many others made moves, Woods shot an even-par 72 to remain three over par for the tournament, tied for 39th place, nine strokes behind the leader, David Duval.

title: Peacekeeping in Sierra Leone
description: For most of the past decade the West African nation of Sierra Leone has been riven by a vicious civil war as rebel groups terrorized the country. Last fall the United Nations sent a peacekeeping force to carry out a tenuous peace accord and disarm the combatants. But in recent months rebels have ambushed and disarmed some of the peacekeepers. In February the Security Council nearly doubled the force, from 6,000 to 11,000 troops. The move is clearly needed, but it will benefit no one and could damage the credibility of U.N. peacekeeping efforts elsewhere if the troops continue to be ineffectual.

title: Heart-Holding Tale Starts With 2 Diamonds
description: Since Harold Vanderbilt introduced contract bridge to the world in 1925 and followed up with the Vanderbilt Club System, dozens of methods have used one club as an artificial strong opening. The most popular and durable has been Precision Club, devised by a Chinese-American shipowner, Charles Wei, in 1963.

title: Defenseman Wins Hobey Baker Award
description: Mike Mottau, the Boston College defenseman and a draft pick of the Rangers, beat out two teammates and seven others yesterday to win the Hobey Baker award as the top player in college hockey.

title: Bush, in Reversal, to Meet With a Gay Republican Group
description: Gov. George W. Bush said today that he had invited a small group of gay Republicans to talk with him at the governor's mansion in Austin, Tex., next week, a development that stood in contrast to his longstanding refusal to meet formally with the Log Cabin Republicans, a leading gay political organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEELY, ROBERT M.
description: FEELY-Robert M. The Board of Directors and shareholders of 1220 Park Avenue Corp., mourn the loss of their fellow Director and neighbor. A member of the Board for over 30 years and having served as President, his wise counsel will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family.

title: China's No. 1 Oil Company Goes Public With Whimper
description: Stalked by protestors, spurned by investors, and star-crossed by a fickle market, China's flagship oil company, PetroChina Ltd., plodded through its first day of trading in Asia, closing 5 percent below its offering price on a day when the Hong Kong market rose.

title: Times Names TV Critic
description: Julie Salamon, an author, journalist and critic, has been named a television critic for The New York Times. Her appointment was announced yesterday by the paper's culture editor, John Darnton. Ms. Salamon was the film critic for The Wall Street Journal for 11 years and has written many magazine articles. Her books include ''The Devil's Candy,'' ''The Net of Dreams'' and ''The Christmas Tree.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDART, FRANK, JR., M.D.
description: HARDART-Frank, Jr., M.D. Of Bronxville, NY. 0n April 6th, 2000. Beloved husband of Frances (nee O'Connor). Devoted father of Frank, George, Richard, Tracie, Christopher & Michael. Delighted father-in-law of Karen and Katie. Proud grandfather of Kent Francis. Loving brother of Evelyn Hardart Murray and the late Thomas R. Hardart. Wolfe Street, Baltimore, MD 21287.

title: GTECH, LOTTERY SYSTEMS MAKER, HALTS ON-POINT BID
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation, the No. 1 maker of lottery systems, yesterday called off its $48.6 million purchase of On-Point Technology Systems Inc. after On-Point said it would restate its 1997 and 1998 earnings. Gtech said it would continue discussions with On-Point's management over its interest in On-Point's instant ticket vending technology. The discussions, though, may not result in a new agreement between the two companies, Gtech said. Gtech, based in West Greenwich, R.I., agreed in January to buy On-Point, based in San Marcos, Calif., to expand in the instant lottery ticket business.

Contributions to the Ridgefield VNA or the Keeler Tavern Preservation Society.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Salomon Adds Many Perks To Retain Junior Employees

title: Antidrug Units Will Lose Part Of Their Funds
description: A third of the overtime money earmarked for an ambitious, but much criticized, anti-narcotics initiative known as Operation Condor will be used instead to pay for increased uniformed patrols that will pursue a variety of other offenses, police officials said yesterday.

title: PRISON REALTY, JAIL OPERATOR, AGREES TO REVAMPING
description: Prison Realty Trust Inc., the largest private prison owner and operator in the United States, has agreed to a $200 million restructuring plan with a shareholder, the Pacific Life Insurance Company, spurning a previous agreement with the Blackstone Group. The company, a real estate investment trust in Nashville, reached an agreement in December with Blackstone, but investors called the terms too onerous. Under the new agreement, the company will give shareholders rights to buy up to $200 million of stock. The price will be the lower of $4 a share or 65 percent of the average market price of Prison Realty's shares on the three trading days before the rights offering. Prison Realty's shares rose 93.75 cents each yesterday, to $3.375.

title: Toronto Exchange Struggles to Hold Its Own
description: It is not uncommon for the creaky computers that run the Toronto Stock Exchange to crash for a few minutes or even longer. But that may be the least of the exchange's problems.

title: Bullets Found in Home Of Club Owner on Bail
description: A Miami Beach nightclub owner accused of robbing a Staten Island bank in 1992, taking part in the slaying of a Staten Island woman in 1993 and of working with the Brooklyn mob was taken before a federal judge yesterday after the authorities said a box of bullets and a marijuana cigarette was found beneath a mattress in his home.

title: Making Use of a Democrat in a G.O.P. Primary
description: As the Republican primary campaign for the United States Senate enters its final two months, a familiar battle cry is beginning to fill the air, and its name is Jim Florio.

description: LAWNICZAK-Edward John, S.J. Beloved uncle of Robert, John Osalkowski and Patricia Harris. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road. Visitation Sunday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Murray Weigel Hall Chapel, Monday 11:30 AM. For information, contact Farenga Brothers, Inc., Directors.

title: Cambodia's Mountains Hide a Wildlife Refuge
description: Until recently, nobody ventured into the Cardamom Mountains. Rising into the monsoon clouds in a remote corner of Cambodia, they were one last enclave of Khmer Rouge guerrillas, impenetrable and seeded with land mines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, MILDRED (NEE VATHAUER).
description: COLE-Mildred (nee Vathauer). Of Manhattan. Passed away April 4, 2000. A life-long resident, she was preceded in death by her husband Allen Cole. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment to follow at the Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale.

title: DISMISSALS PLANNED IN CONSUMER LONG-DISTANCE UNIT
description: The AT&T Corporation, the largest United States long-distance company, said yesterday that it would lay off workers in the consumer long-distance division after retirements and resignations failed to reduce the staff sufficiently. The company, seeking to cut $2 billion in costs this year, said in a letter on March 31 that employees with at least five years of service and whose age and service totals 65 years will get expanded retirement benefits for leaving in a so-called force management program. Others have 60 days to find a new AT&T job, or be dismissed.

title: The Big City; Kept Women: Nearly Extinct For a Reason
description: IT was billed as Girls' Nite for Helen Gurley Brown and a select group of customers at Henri Bendel, which seemed the ideal opportunity for a sociological inquiry: Whither the kept woman?

title: COMPUSA SET TO DISMISS ABOUT 1,500 EMPLOYEES
description: CompUSA Inc., which was bought last month by Grupo Sanborns S.A. of Mexico, said yesterday that it planned to dismiss about 1,500 employees, or 7.5 percent of its work force, to reduce expenses. The company is eliminating 2,150 back-office and other support staff while adding 650 in sales and customer service. Some of the employees whose positions are being eliminated will receive new jobs. CompUSA has been reorganizing to cut costs after being acquired by Grupo. The company abandoned its Cozone.com Internet sales Web site last month. CompUSA, based in Dallas, has 218 stores and also sells its own custom-made personal computers. An average of four to five positions will be cut from each of its stores, the company said.

title: As Zimbabwe Falters, Doubts About Who Is Really to Blame
description: The aging warrior resurrects the old battle cry, and the crowd roars. The fire still burns in his voice, the dress uniform still hangs smartly from his shoulders, and he still shakes his fist as he warns the whites and the world that he will not be cowed.

title: U.S. SET TO ORDER A SPEEDY RETURN OF BOY TO FATHER
description: Attorney General Janet Reno announced today that government lawyers would prepare an order as early as next week to allow the father of Elian Gonzalez to return with his 6-year-old son to Cuba, and she issued an emotional appeal to the boy's Miami relatives to turn over the child to the authorities promptly and peacefully.

title: Sports of The Times; Big Bucks Generate Highest Of Hopes
description: WE in New York are not impressed with the whining from the hinterlands. Baseball fans in Kansas City and a new owner in Miami are lamenting that they cannot keep up with the Steinbrenners and Wilpons of the world. Tough.

title: The Latest Internet Millionaire Wears a Crown
description: With regal insouciance, Queen Elizabeth II rode this week's dot.com roller coaster, held on to her stake and emerged today as one of her nation's newest Internet millionaires when an Internet company she backed went public.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about political coverage on television referred imprecisely to the location of a ''virtual skybooth'' that ABC News is considering for the presidential conventions this summer. While not in the main hall, it would indeed be within the convention center.

title: Doctor Spurns Euphemism in Pursuing Abortion Rights
description: DR. LeROY CARHART never set out to be an abortion doctor, let alone a crusader for abortion rights. He would make an unlikely crusader for any cause: he spent 21 years in the Air Force, which paid his way through medical school, before retiring in 1985 as a lieutenant colonel. His last assignment was as chairman of the surgery department at the hospital at Offutt Air Force Base in Omaha, and because his children were happy there, Dr. Carhart, a New Jersey native, decided to stay in Omaha and open a medical practice.

title: Arthur C. Ruge, Inventor of Vital Stress Gauge, Dies at 94
description: Arthur C. Ruge, who invented a fingernail-sized gauge that helped the United States win World War II and revolutionized the way things are weighed and tested for stress, died Monday at his home in Lexington, Mass., according to his daughter, Claire Bertucci. He was 94.

title: Police Find Newborn Girl Abducted From Hospital
description: A 2-day-old baby girl was abducted from a bassinet in her mother's room at University Hospital at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, but was found hours later after an intense search by the police, who said the infant had been taken by a 17-year-old girl.

title: Knicks Call Starks, But He Can't Help
description: Once again this season, John Starks came tantalizingly close to resurfacing in a Knicks uniform. This time an arbitrator did not rule against him, but it was Starks who turned down the chance today to sign with his former team for the remaining eight games of the regular season.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits in Weekend yesterday with a film review of ''Ratcatcher,'' in the New Directors/ New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art, omitted the distributor. It is Merchant-Ivory Productions.

title: Reed Gives a Break to the Relief Staff
description: While Rick Reed ate his pasta lunch at a Manhattan restaurant with his wife yesterday, he started to worry. The stiff neck that had bothered him since returning from Japan last week was still a problem, and the Mets right-hander was not sure he could make his start last night.

title: Carrying A World's Woes Oh So Lightly
description: Tere O'Connor Dance once again greeted the world's problems comically when this group offered Mr. O'Connor's ''Hi Everybody!'' on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop. The piece, with choreography and text by Mr. O'Connor and a recorded score by James Baker, had its premiere last year. Akin to a revue in format, it is a fast-paced series of dances and sketches on such topics as illness, economic problems, war and homophobia.

title: Methane Boom in Wyoming Proves to Be Mixed Blessing
description: An energy boom is roaring through the Powder River Basin here in northeast Wyoming. Methane Madness, some locals call it. Others compare it to the Gold Rush. It is a race to some of the richest methane gas deposits in North America, in a place industry executives call ''the Saudi Arabia of coal.''

title: Don Quixote's Delusions Made Real

Mr. Hoskins's turn as Sancho Panza, all delightful mugging, is the strongest asset of ''Don Quixote,'' the film that TNT is offering tomorrow night.

title: Old Urban Legends Never Die (But They Don't Get Any Truer)
description: Heard the one about the poisoned cat? A cat nibbled on the fish that a hostess was cooking for guests. After dinner, the cat was found dead in the driveway. The frantic hostess announced that the cat had sampled the fish, and everyone raced to the hospital to have their stomachs pumped. When she returned, she found a note on the door from a neighbor: ''Please accept our apologies for running over your cat. We will be happy to replace him.''

title: BRAZIL AUTO OUTPUT RISES
description: Brazil's automobile production climbed 14 percent in March as growth returned to the economy, according to the country's association of automakers. However, sales fell 14 percent from the corresponding month a year earlier, largely because Carnival was celebrated in March this year, instead of February. Sales in March rose 4.3 percent from February. Simon Romero

title: THE SUBURBAN NATION
description: There's nothing ''sub'' about the suburbs anymore. A special issue of The Times Magazine details the blurring of boundaries between city and suburb, and the result: that none of the generalizations about the Levittowns of America still fit, even in Levittown itself.

title: With STP, a Hard Sound Expands
description: It's easy now to root for Stone Temple Pilots, who resurfaced at an unadvertised Irving Plaza show on Wednesday. The group's original reputation as soulless copycats surfing the wake of Nirvana has faded along with the listening public's concern for issues of artistic integrity. STP, as the band calls itself, got slightly more serious as rock grew much less so, and the band now meets the status quo on comfortable middle ground.

title: Gore Campaign Chief Wears Many Other Hats
description: Since he resigned from Congress in 1989 over a controversial junk bond investment, Tony Coelho has mixed business with politics. But a close look at his business interests suggests that Mr. Coelho, the chairman of the Gore campaign, is much more skillful at politics.

title: Don't Victimize the Constitution
description: Some bad ideas keep recycling back. The latest version of the so-called ''victims' rights amendment'' to the Constitution, a pandering and potentially disruptive measure, is being readied for a full Senate vote by the end of the month.

description: The International Monetary Fund is ready to pursue a new relationship with Russia as soon as President-elect Vladimir V. Putin acts on his promise to build a better foundation for the country's still shaky market economy, a top official of the organization said today.

title: Vigorous Economy Adds 416,000 Jobs
description: The economy added 416,000 nonfarm jobs in March, a total higher than most economists had anticipated and the biggest surge since February 1996, when the number of jobs increased by 454,000. Even so, the unemployment rate remained at 4.1 percent. Workers continued to benefit from the tight labor market as employers paid more to retain them. Average hourly earnings rose 5 cents for the month.

description: One of these things is not like the other: the air-kiss superficiality of Hollywood tributes, the schmoozy performances of stars at such events, and the deep, uncompromising music of Joni Mitchell.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS' GORES UNIT TO BUY SYSTEM SOFTWARE
description: The Gores Technology Group of Texas Instruments, which acquires and manages technology companies, agreed to buy System Software Associates Inc. for $52 million in cash plus stock to gain its software and services. System Software, based in Chicago, a pioneer in software that links operations within a company, expects to file next week for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. System Software will use the cash from the sale to pay the company's secured lenders. Unsecured creditors will receive a 25 percent stake in the unit that Gores formed to buy System Software. Texas Instruments is based in Dallas.

title: Starbucks Founder Is Taking New Role
description: Howard Schultz, the founder, chairman and longtime chief executive of Starbucks Coffee, said on Thursday that he would take on a new role in the company. His replacement is the Starbucks chief operating officer, Orin Smith.

title: LEVITZ AND SEAMAN FORM MANAGEMENT AND SERVICES UNIT
description: Levitz Furniture Inc., a retailer based in Boca Raton, Fla., that has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy since 1997, said yesterday that it had formed a management and services alliance with the privately held Seaman Furniture Company as part of a plan to emerge from bankruptcy. Under its plan, Levitz will form a new holding company called Levitz Home Furnishing Inc. that would own all of Levitz and a majority of Seaman. Levitz and Seaman would keep their brands and operate as separate companies, but Seaman would manage the 20 Levitz stores on the East Coast and provide accounting, human resources and computer services to all of Levitz's stores. Levitz will continue to direct its 44 stores on the West Coast.

title: Pakistan's Questionable Verdict

His leniency may also have been a response to President Clinton's appeal last month to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the coup leader, not to execute the former prime minister. But the trial of Mr. Sharif was itself of dubious legitimacy. It only underscores the need for Pakistan to move more quickly to restore democracy and rescue the integrity of its justice system.

title: A Cartel for Doctors
description: The House is preparing to vote on a bill that would permit independent physicians to bargain collectively with health plans -- in effect to form a union -- even though they do not work for a common employer or work together in any other way. This is a terrible idea. The bill would invite doctors to form cartels, jack up prices, boycott health plans and exploit consumers in ways that are permitted to no other independent businessmen in the economy. The legislation may induce physicians to pour contributions into the campaign chests of politicians during an election year, but patients would suffer the nasty consequences. That is why the Consumer Federation of America, the Department of Justice, the Federal Trade Commission and many leading antitrust authorities oppose the measure.

It is a classic of sorts, by one of the most revered of the old New Yorker writers, Joseph Mitchell; and until the book-length version was republished recently by the Modern Library, copies of the original magazine articles, bleary from over-Xeroxing, were passed around in certain circles like samizdat. But the action, such as it is, is largely interior; ''Joe Gould's Secret'' is sometimes called a ''writer's book,'' and not without reason: it's a story that in part is about writing, a theme whose track record up on the screen is not terribly encouraging. title: The Way We Live Now: 4-9-00: Salient Facts: Tear-Downs; Scraping By
description: HOME EC 101Just how hard is it for well-heeled homebuyers to find what they want where they want? So hard that they are not only bidding up prices way beyond what was originally asked, they are paying those extra hundreds of thousands of dollars for houses only to tear them down as fast as they can and start over. ''I've heard of a one-acre lot in Atherton that went up for sale on a Saturday as a $3 million tear-down -- and sold for $7 million on Sunday,'' says Tom Quaglia, a real estate developer based in San Jose. Demolition plans are under way. Last year, nearly 10 percent of the 1.3 million single-family home starts nationwide were begun on lots recently cleared of existing houses, according to estimates from the National Association of Home Builders. Mark Calabria, a senior economist with the National Association of Realtors, says that two factors are behind tear-downs, or scrapers: a shortage of large houses and the renewed appeal of older, first-generation suburbs where little open land remains. Calabria highlights California as a prime example: ''It's such a tight market, and there's such huge demand, you can't find lots there. The markets are crazy. And suddenly it makes a lot more sense to tear down: you've already got a site that has infrastructure, and it's easier to get a permit.'' Barring a stock market correction, says Leslie Appleton-Young, an economist with the California Association of Realtors, scraping ''looks like a trend that will only accelerate.''

Friends and neighbors turn over every four years as the political tides shift. There is a peculiar tension in this pathologically khaki place -- people live in fear of standing out, of being seen. The C.I.A. and F.B.I. go door-to-door collecting information the way the Alzheimer's foundation collects dollars. They ring the bell. ''Are you the lady of the house? We're reviewing the security clearance of one of your neighbors -- we can't tell you which -- and we're wondering if you've noticed anything unusual lately? title: Imagination In The Burbs; Children of the Cul-de-Sac
description: Suburbia used to be seen as a green-lawned paradise. But scorched-earth satires like ''Welcome to the Dollhouse'' and ''The Ice Storm'' have burned that image away. Today, Hollywood sends out the message that perversity lurks behind every picket fence, that split-levels are really prison cells. How well does the suburbia that is portrayed on screen (or on the printed page) match up with reality? To explore the connection between suburban life and art, we set up a conversation between six creative minds whose work tackles the world of subdivisions and strip malls. Our panel included Alan Ball, a screenwriter whose script for ''American Beauty'' won an Oscar for best original screenplay; Gregory Crewdson, a photographer whose show ''Twilight'' recently appeared at the Luhring Augustine gallery in New York; A.M. Homes, a writer whose latest novel is ''Music for Torching''; Tamara Jenkins, a filmmaker who wrote and directed ''The Slums of Beverly Hills''; Eric Mendelsohn, the director and writer of ''Judy Berlin''; and David Schisgall, the director of the documentary ''The Lifestyle.''

title: The Triumph of Burbopolis

It has been nearly 30 years since I left, and at least until a couple of months ago, I could think of no reason to go back: no people to see (everybody I knew had also left), no curiosity to satisfy. In my imagination Juneau Boulevard is the same as it ever was, except maybe for the cars and the people, which I assume have been regularly updated. Isn't that the way it has always been in the burbs -- change without history? More of the same?

But in an unexpected counter trend, the latest fund-raising reports show that the mayor has raised far more money than the first lady. His campaign has a balance of $19 million compared with her $12 million. With seven months to go, this race could devour as much as $70 million or $80 million for a single Senate seat.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Procreation Anxiety
description: It was bound to happen. The 30-ish heroines of all those I-Must-Have-a-Man books would grow a bit older and decide they must have babies. Enter Ellen Franck, the 35-year-old narrator of Laura Zigman's second novel, DATING BIG BIRD (Dial, $22.95). Ellen is funny, smart and successful, in a particularly Manhattan sort of way, and she excels in (but hates) her high-profile fashion industry job. She could slip right into the cast of ''Sex and the City'' and kvetch with the best of them. Ellen is an older version of Jane Goodall, the protagonist of Zigman's first novel, ''Animal Husbandry.'' The only difference is that while Jane was obsessed with finding a man, Ellen, her biological alarm clock ringing, has to have a baby. The other women in her life are all procreating like mad. Alas, the once-famous writer she is involved still suffers from the pain of his own child's death and can't imagine having another one. ''My vision had never included a baby,'' Ellen insists. ''It took until I grew tired of myself . . . until the nights became too quiet and too lonely to bear.'' Zigman indulges tired female stereotypes, portraying Ellen and her childless friend Amy as perhaps too desperate. (Amy even stops using birth control to trap her boyfriend into having a baby.) The story picks up when Ellen finally decides to have a child on her own, trolling through sperm-donor biographies with her humor in tow. Ellen is undeniably likable, and she'd be fun to have drinks with. Unfortunately, her likability can't save her from becoming a caricature. Lori Leibovich

title: Enrique Espinoza, 87, Artist Who Set Scene For Christmas
description: Enrique Espinoza, an artist who with Loretta Hines Howard created elaborate Christmas trees displayed annually at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the White House, died March 21 at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. A resident of Manhattan, he was 87.

title: Getting the Most From Circular Saws
description: THE most popular power tool for professionals and do-it-yourselfers, after the portable electric drill, is the circular saw. It can make most of the cuts done by table or radial-arm saws, and it has the added advantage that it can be carried to the job site. Fitted with the right blade, a portable circular saw can cut through almost any material, and obviously, faster than a hand saw.

title: Teen Startup: 18 and Wired For Business
description: THE executives of the company running the school district's computer system don't need to be told a thing about the network or fiber-optic cables or even which teacher is all thumbs on a mouse. All they need is a call every morning about 8 from the district secretary, Pat Raynor, to make sure they're awake.

description: The Big Picture

title: Genoa, City Of Contrasts
description: LAST October I had the good luck to spend some time in Genoa in the company of some Genoese. The experience affirmed for me an old truism of travel: you cannot really know a city until people who live there invite you to dinner. And show you how they cook and dress and do up their houses; and tell you something about daily life; and teach you a few words, preferably racy, of the local dialect. And, after a glass of wine -- in a living room befogged, as so many in Italy still are, with cigarette smoke -- speak of the things they love about their city and those they love less.

title: OPINION; New York's Garbage Is Not Ours
description: LONG ISLAND communities currently generate 3.5 million tons of garbage a year, and they have worked hard over the last decade to recycle 35 to 40 percent of this amount. It has not been easy to develop waste-management plans because garbage is managed at the town and city level. Coordination is not easy because of the diverse communities on the Island and their diverse waste streams.

Although most developed countries now have pollution and safety standards that differ from those in the United States only by matters of degrees, foreign manufacturers still must certify that all the cars they export to this country comply with American standards.

Beloved sister of Winifred Breuning and the late George Kinzler. Remembrances to: The Hazel K. Goddess Fund for Stroke Research in Women at NY Community Trust, 2 Park Ave., NYC 10016.

title: Kofi Annan's Millennial Vision
description: Part of Kofi Annan's job as secretary general of the United Nations is to think big thoughts about the future of the planet. Last week he made the most of that responsibility by outlining an audacious vision for the world organization in the 21st century. It would be easy to dismiss Mr. Annan's comprehensive vision as, in his own words, ''absurdly ambitious.'' But it deserves a wide audience.

title: A Snowbird's Week on Sanibel
description: CAN I ride my bike across the causeway?'' my husband, Reb, the cycling enthusiast asks the toll collector, as we halt our luggage-laden rented minivan at the entrance to the three-mile-long series of bridges that links Sanibel Island to the West Coast of Florida. He hands over $3, a small price to leave behind the strip malls of Fort Myers and enter paradise.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Open Windows; The New Math Of Monopoly
description: THE scorecard in the Microsoft case, according to Attorney General Janet Reno, is simple: Microsoft lost and America's consumers won.

title: Education In The Burbs; Migration of the Melting Pot
description: Inside Mrs. Bloetner's English-immersion class, a group of fourth and fifth graders is struggling to communicate. Today's lesson focuses on how to pronounce words beginning with the letter B. As her classmates sound out ''brown'' and ''brave,'' Zumaykira, a Panamanian girl in pigtails, leans over to Indunil, her Sri Lankan neighbor. She asks for a piece of paper: ''P1/3same el papel.'' Indunil smiles back uncomprehendingly.

title: For a Beloved Old Enclave, the End of the Road
description: Elvia Suter moved into a condominium two weeks ago in New Springville, Staten Island, just a chip shot away from the La Tourette Golf Club. ''It's gorgeous,'' she said. ''But it's not the same as my old house. That was very dear to me because my father built it. There are a lot of memories.''

title: Fuel Cells: Energy Partners at Odds
description: THERE was something about the white canopy covering the rows of metal folding chairs -- and about seeing Christie Brinkley perched on one of those chairs -- that lifted the drab surroundings at the Brookhaven National Laboratory into the surreal.

title: Renovation Set for Purchase Center
description: AS theatrical spaces go, nothing in Westchester compares with the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, a five-theater complex on a campus specializing in professional training in the arts. The center serves Purchase students, community ensembles and touring international arts companies, yet it has always been something of an embarrassment. How to describe the forbidding, windowless structure except as a fortress?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MILTON L. ''JIMMY''
description: ROSENBERG-Milton L. ''Jimmy''. April 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Joan. Loving father of Peggy Hirschberg and Andie, step-father of Maxwell Davidson and Anne Averbuck and the late Lynn Tyree. Cherished grandfather of Stacy and Amanda Hirschberg, Lindsey and John Gordon, Maxwell IV, William and Charles Davidson and Sam Tyree. Interment private. Memorial service Tuesday, April 11, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: The Big Choose
description: When Sasha Kramer from Sherburne, N.Y., visited Reed College in Portland, Ore., her favorite flowers -- forget-me-nots -- were blooming everywhere, small classes were meeting on the lawn and a fountain filled with fresh water for dogs marked a place where her ''best friend'' would feel welcome. The juxtaposition of a full library on Friday night and a sizable number of students with purple hair made Reed feel right. She chose it over Brown, which her parents had recommended for its excellent curriculum in the sciences and outstanding record for sending undergraduates on for Ph.D's.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHMAN, JULIUS
description: FISHMAN-Julius. March 26, 1980. Although 20 years have passed, we will cherish our memories of your guidance, warmth and love. You are forever in our hearts. Annamae, Children, Grandchildren and Great-Grandchildren

title: Status In The Burbs; The $4,000 Barbecue
description: Many, many years ago, all it took to impress the neighbors was a two-car garage. But now the focus is less on vehicle capacity than on what else you put in there. Yes, today's monster garages are receptacles for a whole slew of suburban status symbols: high-design gardening equipment, name-brand power tools, restaurant-quality grills and precision-engineered leisure goods. For example, a Swedish-made Husqvarna chain saw with a gentle low-emissions engine and a big nasty blade. Or Viking's top-of-the-line barbecue grill, nearly four grand worth of gleaming stainless steel. ''Our customers are the kind of guys who back their Maseratis out of the garage, then roll out their grills with equal pride,'' says Dale Persons, a Viking executive.

Should I have tripped him? I was in no danger -- I'm bigger, and there were people everywhere -- but I might have misjudged the situation, and I could have injured him, hardly just punishment for a petty crime. To complicate matters, he was black, his pursuers white. / Bill Wasik, New York

title: Editorial Observer; The Perils of Growing Comfortable With Evil
description: Most us have witnessed things that we would be better off never having seen. The writer Susan Sontag applies this distinction to the Holocaust photographs she stumbled upon in a bookstore at the age of 12 in 1945, years before she could conceptualize what the Holocaust even was. Writing of the experience in her landmark book ''On Photography,'' Ms. Sontag recalled that when she looked at those photographs ''Some limit had been reached and not only that of horror . . . something [in me] went dead; something is still crying.''

title: Cruise Insurance

Because of their advanced ages we usually accompany them on trips. As required by Renaissance, the entire $10,800 was paid up front for all four of us. I purchased trip insurance from CSA Travel Protection in San Diego. Money well spent.

title: The Galapagos
description: To the Editor: Aaron Latham's article (''The Galapagos, a Bold Eden,'' Feb. 20) gives the impression that the area is one large petting zoo. I took a 10-day cruise last June with Galapagos Travel, and our naturalist guide, Ron Sjostedt, seriously enforced the rules of the park, which state that visitors must not get closer to the animals than six feet. Sometimes the animals approached us, but that is allowed. Ron firmly insisted that we stay on the paths and not crowd the animals.

Franco's face was a picture of disbelief. Had he really botched a four-run lead in the ninth inning? Had he really turned a rewarding afternoon for Pat Mahomes and Jay Payton and the rest of the plucky Mets into a forgettable afternoon? He had.

I've been a resident of Westport, Conn., for almost three decades -- 28 years -- and it makes me sad just to think about leaving my beloved Turkey Hill house. Mr. Clay practiced law for 41 years, and was employed as a corporate attorney for General Electric from 1948 until retiring in 1971. He lived in the Village of Nissequogue where he served as Village Justice from 1988 to 1991. Survivors include his wife, Helen LeRoy Clay of Nissequogue; and two children, William Law Clay III of Staten Island, New York, and George Miller Clay of San Diego, California.

As often as not, those rooms are what we see reflected back at us: a couch planted squarely in the thoroughfare between front door and kitchen, with a staircase slanting upward behind it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENBER, HERMAN C.
description: DENBER-Herman C., M.D., Ph.D. The staff of the Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute of the Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Herman C. Denber, M.D., Ph.D., Adjunct Professor of Medicine, Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Dr. Denber began his medical career following his graduation from the University of Geneva School of Medicine. His long relationship with Cardiology was through his interest in supporting young leaders in the field of clinical and investigative Cardiology. He established an endowment fund which awards the ''Denber Award for Excellence in Research in Cardiovascular Diseases''. His warmth, skills and wit were appreciated widely and will be missed deeply. Our profound condolences to his wife, Suzanne and his daughter Michelle. Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D. Director, Cardiovascular Institute Mount Sinai School of Medicine

title: My Suburb; Ridgewood, N.J.
description: I admit to you, it's sort of a monster. Made completely of 10-gauge stainless steel, inside and out -- grill head, cart, sidebar shelves that a set of chubby twins could sit on. Beneath the cover, I've got a porcelain-mesh infrared rotisserie and two heavyweight cast-iron burners that blow 50,000 B.T.U.'s. Oh yes, this is a gas machine. On a hot July night with the knobs maxxed out I think I can almost reach fission. Some grill, you say. Though you, of course, believe in the flavor of charcoal, you believe in the ancient rites of the fire, you believe in the waiting and the sometime heartbreak and you believe in nature and the fates. All this is mature, and good. But out here, on the wide, rectangular pad of my driveway, on the knife edge of these taintless streets, I favor the dream of mastery. I like rolling my grill to the cool of the grass, as far out as the orange extension cord will run, which snakes from inside the garage to the plug end of the rotisserie motor. I like having a couple of trussed chickens fixed on the spit, their skins paprika-rubbed and lumpy beneath with garlic cloves and veins of rosemary. I like reaching underneath and releasing the valve of the propane tank -- I've got another in the shed, full and ready, because you run out only when you're grilling -- and then flipping the spark igniter, which never works the first time or the second and so makes you cringe, anticipating the basso whoomp of the burn. I like waiting there, nearby, however long, taking an 8-iron to the patches of crab grass, gathering the overripe tomatoes, sipping my near-frozen-cold can of Old Milwaukee, until Michelle calls out from the side door, Are we ready? And I lift the cover, the birds crackling and the barrage of smoke sweet enough to breathe, breathe in deep, though I can't, and I can only whisper, Oh yeah we're ready, we're ready.

I'm in my element weaving through the suburban streetscape of Bethesda, Md. I'm hunting for a parking spot, passing by the Ancient Rhythms furniture gallery, the Outrage Cafe and Terra Cognita, a Material Culture-type store that sells tribal rugs, folk art and kilims. Parking is supposed to be easy in the suburbs, but it's always tough in a retail hub like Bethesda. My eyes narrow with that sharp, hungry look I used to get when I lived in Manhattan, hunting for an apartment or on rainy evenings desperate for a cab. Finally, I spot an empty space up the street in front of Three Dog Bakery, which makes fat-free apple-oatmeal biscuits, cheese and herb treats and gourmet carob chips -- for dogs.

title: Grown-Ups In The Burbs; We Stayed For the Kids ... and Stayed and Stayed
description: I know all the arguments against suburbia. I invented some of them: that the suburbs literally shrivel the brain, for example. I also know that suburbs have become aluminum-sided theme parks -- celebrations of sameness -- and that nowhere else on earth can you find architecture of such awfulness and pretension. ''Get me out of here!'' I used to announce periodically when the children were small. ''I can't last a minute longer.'' My wife and I would look through the Manhattan real estate ads, in search of some steerage-size apartment that might fit our budget. Then we'd factor in the cost of private schools and of an occasional weekend trip, because we thought we deserved to see grass and trees at least once in a while, and even before we totaled it all up, I'd slink off, my heat spent. We had to stay for the kids, we told ourselves, and because we couldn't afford anything better.

title: American Beauty
description: THE building looks as if it had stood here for at least a century, a stolid pile of brick with severe mansard roofs. In fact, it's hardly older than the Friendly's across the street. It was built around 1970 as a steakhouse, then became Le Chateau, a temple of what passed in those days for fine dining in Bergen County. By the late 90's, when Tenafly had grown weary of Le Chateau (or vice versa), it closed and stood empty, waiting for a tenant, or a wrecker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, FRANCES (NEE STAVENHAGEN)
description: WASSERMAN - Frances (nee Stavenhagen). Died on April 6 after 94 years of giving joy to all who knew her. The beloved wife of the late Saul J. Wasserman, mother of Ernest and the late Regina. She will be sorely missed. Services Sunday 10:00 AM at Parkside Memorial Chapels, Flatbush Avenue and Avenue V, Kings Plaza.

title: PrivateSector; A Child Thanks 3Com But Overstates the Case
description: Eric A. Benhamou, 45, 3Com's chief executive, learned last week that even if Lindsay Powell, age 9, doesn't quite know his company's name, President Clinton does. In a speech last Tuesday on eliminating the digital divide, the president highlighted 3Com's pledge of $3 million to the Y.W.C.A. over three years to provide technology training and mentors for girls.

title: Tough Smoking Law
description: Putnam County is considering the adoption of one of the toughest antismoking laws in the state. If it is approved by the county's Board of Health, even bowling alleys would be off-limits to smokers.

title: Colleges Need Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: Marriage a la Market
description: In his article, Jack Hitt referred to ''old-school climbers who shed one legal spouse after another, like Pamela Churchill Harriman.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Edward Weston and Modernism in Boston
description: Edward Weston's images -- the elegant seashell, the voluptuous pepper, nudes melding into the landscape, landscapes sinuous as nudes -- are so familiar that it is easy to forget his pioneering role in American modern art. ''Edward Weston: Photography and Modernism,'' on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, through May 29, presents 140 of his vintage prints alongside nearly 60 works by modernist masters, including Georgia O'Keeffe, Diego Rivera, Brancusi and Picasso as well as the photographers Alfred Stieglitz and Imogen Cunningham.

title: Seattle Protesters Are Back, With a New Target
description: For Beka Economopoulos, a 25-year-old environmental campaigner with a premature streak of gray in her long black hair, the drive to shut down the world's financial institutions began in Seattle's King County Jail.

title: COMMUTERS' REFUNDS
description: New Jersey residents who work in New York City won a court battle early last week when a New York State Court of Appeals declared the commuter tax imposed on out-of-state residents as unconstitutional. The 240,000 New Jersey commuters then got an added bonus Wednesday when New York said it would immediately refund the tax money rather than make people wait until tax returns are filed next year. Refund forms for the money paid in so far this year will be mailed to commuters over the next several weeks, said Marc Carey, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. For the tax paid from July 1, 1999, to Dec. 31, 1999, those who have not yet filed their 1999 tax returns can change the amount due. Those who have already filed their returns can file an amendment. Instructions will be available by calling (800) 225-5829ok (CALL-TAX) or at the Web site, www.tax.state.ny.usa. The tax has been in effect since 1966, when it was imposed on New Jersey, Connecticut, Long Island and other New York State residents who worked in New York City. But the New York Legislature amended the law in June 1999 exempting Long Island and other New York State residents, which prompted a suit by New Jersey and Connecticut on the ground that the tax could not be selectively imposed. The court upheld that argument, and refunds are retroactive to the time the change was made last year. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Sophistication and Elegance, With a Bite
description: FAR from the embattled Biennial at its parent museum in Manhattan, the branch of the Whitney Museum in Stamford currently has a blithe two-man show featuring the painter Guy Pene du Bois and the sculptor Elie Nadelman. Both artists embody the jazz age. The exhibition is titled ''Talk of the Town'' after the lead-off column in the New Yorker magazine which began publishing in 1925.

title: Play Ball!
description: Forget robins, equinoxes and daylight saving time: spring has begun. On Monday, after a peculiar road trip, during which several teams played their first league games in Japan, baseball really got under way again.

title: Girls Just Want A School Of Their Own
description: ANYONE who spent time at a girls' school in the mid-1960's will immediately recognize Miss Godard's School in the new film ''All I Wanna Do.'' In fact, when Lynn Redgrave first appeared on screen as Miss McVane, the headmistress of the film's fictional New England boarding school, circa 1963, I had to restrain myself from involuntarily standing up and rolling the waist of my skirt down so she wouldn't discover the shocking thing I had done with the length. One look at Miss McVane and I knew I could be quite capable of being asked to spend a great deal of time in her office.

title: South Jersey Is Friendlier? Oh, Shut Up And Drive
description: PEOPLE in South Jersey are friendlier than people in North Jersey. Hey, don't blame me. That's what a recent poll came up with.

title: A Welcome Refund, But, Oh, the Paperwork
description: THE ruling on Tuesday by New York State's highest court to uphold the repeal of New York City's commuter tax has left commuters, tax preparers, and even Connecticut tax officials scratching their heads as to how to reclaim about $20 million that had already been withheld from the paychecks of residents and how it affects their other tax returns.

title: Fidelity: A Major Investor in Real Estate, Too
description: THE Financial District headquarters of Fidelity Investments, the mutual-fund giant that manages $1 trillion, couldn't be more modest. With no views, low ceilings and a rabbit warren of corridors, the nine-story building where the company was founded 54 years ago gives no hint of the real estate empire that is rising from Fidelity's financial success.

title: The Risky Territory Of 'American Psycho'
description: MY first encounter with ''American Psycho'' should have prepared me for the trouble to come. This was in London, in 1991, shortly after the novel by Bret Easton Ellis was published. I was working for a BBC arts program, which was doing a segment on the controversy surounding the novel, and heard the producer in charge exclaiming that the book was vile and should not have been published. I found out later she had not read it. Curious, I bought a copy and began reading it on the subway, braving the horrified glances of other passengers. Nothing I had read about the controversy prepared me for what kind of book it was. The story of Patrick Bateman, a status-obsessed Wall Street executive who commits frenzied murders in his spare time, was not a slasher novel. It was a surreal satire, and although many scenes were excruciatingly violent, it was clearly intended as a critique of male misogyny, not an endorsement of it.

title: The View From/New Rochelle; Giving Renewed Life To a Model A Ford
description: WHEN Alice Megaro was 8, she made a list of things she wanted to accomplish: ''I wanted to go up in a hot-air balloon. I wanted to race horses, and I wanted to restore and own an antique car.''

title: Freaked Out In The Burbs; The Serpent In the Garden
description: Following the custom of subdivisions, Canyon Gate is named after the quality least in supply. There are no canyons. There is one gate. When Chris and Christina Foley drove by, after the birth of their second child, they saw little more than scraped earth and the gate, which was enough to make them stop.

title: Casting Keeps Chekhov Relevant: Jane Alexander in 'Cherry Orchard'
description: BECAUSE Jane Alexander, once the country's official emissary of the arts, is playing Lyubov Andreyevna Ranevskaya, owner of the classically imperiled estate of all time, it is all too obvious to interpret a role in a play as a metaphor for an actress's life in politics.

title: Why I Was in Vietnam
description: Your writer isn't alone in having trouble ''letting go of the war.'' March 29, for instance, was the 31st anniversary of the shooting down of my brother, U.S. Air Force Maj. Frederick W. Hess Jr., his classification as Missing in Action and his subsequent reclassification as Killed in Action. Neither I, nor his wife nor daughter, has the option of letting go, because it is not possible under the circumstances.

title: The Walls Around Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Kimberly Light, Michael Cornell
description: Kimberly Lauren Light, the daughter of Lois and Warren Light of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Chad Cornell, the son of Jane and Alan Cornell of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Postings: A 46-Story High-Rise Co-Owned by Marymount and a Developer; Dorms Below, Condominiums Above
description: With only a single building on its campus at 221 East 71st Street, plus six floors of a 21-story apartment building facing 72nd Street that has classrooms, the library and a theater, Marymount Manhattan College has long had to resort to deft juggling to provide housing for students. Its 518 residential students are housed in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Heights, the 92nd Street Y, Manhattan Park on Roosevelt Island and Rupert-Yorkville Towers at 92nd Street and Third Avenue.

title: Yankee Victor Wins Aqueduct Feature
description: Yankee Victor, who likes to take the lead and keep going as long as possible, kept the lead for the entire mile yesterday as he outran the favored Golden Missile by nearly four lengths to win the 72nd Westchester Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: The Invisible Poor
description: While flipping through ''The Invisible Poor,'' I found myself face to face with a full-page advertisement for ''luxuriously comfortable'' pashmina mattresses. My guess is that Carolyn Bieber, the pregnant homeless woman who died of a seizure two days after The Times took her photograph for its exposition of modern poverty, sure could have used that mattress.

title: Red Faces in High Places
description: The Army, already battered in recent years by sexual misconduct scandals, was jolted again with the disclosure that a general accused of sexual harassment by the Army's highest-ranking woman was appointed last August to be the service's deputy inspector general.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNZWEIG, ZIGMUND
description: GRUNZWEIG - Zigmund. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center expresses great sorrow on the passing of Zigmund Grunzweig, beloved father of Milton Grunzweig, MD, esteemed attending in the Department of Medicine. We extend our profound and heartfelt condolences to his wife Irene, daughter Marta and the entire family. Edwin L. Schulman Chairman, Board of Trustees David I. Schachne Chairman, Executive Committee Alvin I. Kahn, MD President and CEO Richard J. Fogler, MD Sr. Vice President and CMO

title: Blackboard: Registration; Classes On the Block
description: Most people surf digital auction blocks for old LP's, cheap air-conditioners, original Beanie Babies. Now they can bid on learning.

title: Conversations With Sondheim
description: As an Ethel Merman fan, I saw ''Annie Get Your Gun'' some 25 times and ''Gypsy,'' 35. Never once did I catch Merman just walking through a performance. I went to a matinee of ''Gypsy'' on a hot day in June and noticed a number of empty seats. The show had been playing a very long time. Now, I thought, I will see what I have been told about Merman. But she gave that audience a thrilling performance and they gave her a standing ovation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINACH, FRANKLIN H.
description: REINACH-Franklin H., 86, on April 1, 2000, formerly of Roslyn, NY. 20 year resident of Poughquag, NY. Dear husband of Gloria and devoted father of Barbara, Richard, Cynthia, Victoria, and Wendy. Father-in-law of Patrick Sheils and Guy Dominick. Loving grandfather of Lindsay and Brendt Hansen. Memorial donation to NY Hospice.

title: Your Home; Making Dissenters' Voices Heard
description: WHETHER a co-op building has six apartments or 600, one thing is fairly certain: there will rarely be a time when there isn't at least one shareholder who believes that the building could be run better by someone else. And while the naysayers may be wrong at least as often as they are right, there are ways for dissatisfied owners to ensure that their voices are heard and their votes are counted.

title: Relaxing Like a Celebrity
description: FRANKLY, I was seduced by the brochure. After all, I had never been to Parrot Cay, the new Caribbean resort in the Turks and Caicos Islands, nor did I have friends who had visited. But my husband, Tim, and I were both exhausted and, this January, desperately wanted to indulge ourselves with a world-class rest.

title: Kosovo Neighbors' Charity Is Repaid in Grief
description: A year ago, the people of this little town took in tens of thousands of refugees from the Serbian rampage through Kosovo.

title: Of Two Minds on Microsoft: Wall Street After the Ruling; The Bulls: Hey, the Worst Is Over
description: Investors in Microsoft were busy last week, buffeting the stock in the wake of Monday's antitrust ruling against the company by Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. The shares ended Friday at $89.0625, down 16 percent for the week and 25 percent from their high of $119.125 on Dec. 27. With the company's future uncertain, should investors buy on the dip? Run for the doors? Here are best cases for hanging on or cutting back.

title: Redskins Control Future of the N.F.C. East
description: When the Washington Redskins officials and scouts gather for their draft meetings, there is almost a giddy feeling in the room. That is because they know what every other team knows: the Redskins will control the direction of the National Football League draft next Saturday and Sunday.

title: The Biography of a Gun
description: IN America, more than 200,000 guns are traced by law enforcement each year. This is the story of one of those weapons -- named after its serial number -- No. 997126, a 12-shot, 9 millimeter Jennings semi-automatic.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 15 of Education Life today, with an article about choosing a college, reverses the identities of Kelly and Brenda of ''Beverly Hills 90210.'' Kelly is No. 3 in the photograph, Brenda No. 5.

title: A Factory That Wove Rugs and Bound a Town Together
description: For more than half of the 20th century, life in Freehold, the county seat for Monmouth County, revolved around the Karagheusian Rug Mill, which employed 1,700 people at its peak operation in the 1930's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEIL, JOHN J.
description: O'NEIL-John J. On Wednesday, April 5, 2000 of Bethesda, MD. Beloved husband of 41 yrs. to Helene Connellan O'Neil, Jr. Father of Helene O'Neil Cobb and her husband Andrew, Washington, DC; John J. O'Neil, Jr. and his wife Shawn, Tiburon, CA; Ann O'Neil Gradowski and her husband John, Bethesda, MD and Jane O'Neil, Bethesda, MD. Grandfather of 9. Brother of Grace O'Neil Regan, Bronxville, NY and Jerry O'Neil, Akron, OH and Jupiter, FL. Friends will be received at Pumphrey's Bethesda-Chevy Chase Funeral Home, 7557 Wisconsin Ave, Bethesda, MD on Sunday from 2-6:30 PM. Mass of Christian burial will be offered at the Church of the Little Flower, 5607 Massachusetts Avenue, Bethesda, MD on Monday, April 10 at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Silver Spring, MD. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to Catholic Relief Services, 209 West Fayette St., Baltimore, MD. 21201-3443.

title: A Miffed Moscow Means Headaches for Ikea
description: AGREED. It wasn't such a good idea for Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer, to try to open its advertising campaign in the Moscow Metro for its first Russian store with a picture of a bed and the slogan, ''Every 10th European was made in one of our beds.''

title: My Suburb; Santa Barbara, Calif.
description: Lawns, shade trees, the boxy big car to take you to the mall, hay fever, drunks encamped in the undergrowth, skinny kids suspended over the narrow whirring tires of hurtling bicycles: this is my suburbia, the one stored away in memory. I grew up in northern Westchester, in Emery Hill Gardens, a development of look-alike houses built in the late 40's and early 50's. When I first came west, to L.A., and lived in Tujunga, my suburbia also included motorcycle gangs, killer dogs, dysfunctional cars up on blocks, chop shops and methamphetamine labs. My next destination -- Woodland Hills in the San Fernando Valley -- added garbage-addled coyotes into the mix, along with bull snakes, trapdoor spiders and one intrepid roadrunner (which bounced over a six-foot fence and skirted the blue tongue of the pool to give me a beaky sidelong glance).

title: Andrea Ganz, Robert Vogel
description: Andrea Daryl Ganz and Dr. Robert Barry Vogel were married last evening by Rabbi Robert Orkand at the Union League Club in New York.

title: Balancing Act for a Party of 18
description: EARLY last spring, my extended family began planning a combined reunion and winter vacation. We would be 18 people in all, from age 5 to past 70, with at least as many opinions about what constituted a good vacation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, GENE
description: SCHWARTZ-Gene. May 4, 1999. The melody lingers on. Barbara-Toni-DougBob-Vickie-JulieGloria-Jean

title: A Heroic Tenor Who Aims for the Nuances
description: ONE last question for Stig Andersen (the G is silent), the athletic tenor from Denmark. Suppose singing had not worked out. What would he have done instead?

title: Julie Lloyd, Graydon Forrer
description: Julie Lloyd and Graydon John Forrer were married by the Rev. J. David MacMillan, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Friends Meeting House in Washington.

title: Steinbrenner Said to Seek Additional Shares in Nets
description: Members of the Nets organization have been walking lightly and glancing over their shoulders ever since George Steinbrenner became involved with the franchise through the YankeeNets merger completed last fall. In the eyes of many of the club's employees, as well as the public and the news media, Steinbrenner would soon have as much control over the Nets as he does over the Yankees.

title: The View From/New Haven; Open to Suggestions On Vision for the Parks
description: WHEN it comes to visions of what New Haven parks might look like 10 years from now, there are plenty of visionaries.

title: Many Farmers Getting Back to Nature
description: ORGANIC farming, which ranges from a hobby to serious business, is growing around the state, with most farms growing vegetables and fruit, but some even producing flowers and raising livestock.

title: Perfume Attacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts Leave Social Workers, and Clients, at Sea
description: I'M exhausting my savings and all of my resources,'' said Irene Dortch, a social worker who has been working without pay at Operation Get Ahead since January, when the Freeport youth agency lost its funding in a round of county budget cuts.

title: Capturing Cold War Fears, Live and in Black and White
description: George Clooney figured it this way: if he was going to come back to television, he might as well do something different. After all, its why hed opted to leave NBCs ''E.R.'' after five years playing maverick pediatrician, Dr. Doug Ross. ''I didnt need to come back to TV,'' says Mr. Clooney who has subsequently starred in the feature films, ''Out of Sight,'' ''Three Kings'' and the upcoming ''The Perfect Storm.'' ''My feeling was, if Im going to be the 800-pound gorilla, I might as well get people to do things they ordinarily wouldnt do.''

title: In the Region/New Jersey; 10 Projects Will Produce 2,900 New Hotel Rooms
description: AS the economic boom keeps rolling across New Jersey, so does the march of hotels, despite a modest dip in occupancy rates and a supply that is growing faster than the demand for rooms.

title: The Invisible Poor
description: Your article manages to reinforce the invisibility of the poor by spending time psychoanalyzing those who are too busy and too rich to care about other people. The accompanying photographs and captions do little more than further the image of poor people as losers and mental defectives.

title: Blackboard: Pedagogy; Supertramp Vs. Superego
description: A picture may paint a thousand words, but nothing illustrates the inner workings of the psyche like a song. ''Theories don't turn students on,'' said Fred Ribich, who analyzes pop lyrics in his introductory psychology class at Wartburg College in Waverly, Iowa. ''But to help them understand the richness of a theoretical framework, using a musical tool has gotten their minds churning.''

title: Prince, Princess, You're on Candid Camera
description: ALTHOUGH Princess Marianne Sayn-Wittgenstein had landed at Newark Airport only a few hours earlier, she wasted no time getting started on the party circuit. ''Doesn't Inmaculada de Habsburgo live around here?'' she asked last Monday night as she was driven to a town house in the West 40's, referring to a Spanish relation to the Austrian royal family. ''I went to her house once with two sisters, Princess Maita di Niscemi and Princess Mimi Romanov, the wife of Prince Alexander, the great-grandson of Czar Alexander III. It was a spooky evening because the two sisters sang.''

title: Hanging On In The Burbs; Too Rich For Their Blood
description: Pete Cross bought the big white house on Ridgewood Terrace in Maplewood, N.J., in 1972. It was a good time. He had just made the jump from teaching phys ed at Maplewood's Columbia High School to being a guidance counselor, his lifelong dream. He and his wife, Jeanmarie, his high school sweetheart (they both graduated from Columbia High in 1954) had four healthy children, three boys and a girl, ages 5 to 12. They'd been bursting the seams of their old house, a small three-bedroom near the high school. So, in the midst of a brewing energy crisis and a down housing market, they pulled off a bit of real estate prestidigitation, selling the old place for $35,500 and buying the white 1910 Colonial with two-story pillars on the front porch, a stained-glass window on the stair landing and a big backyard, in an equally good neighborhood, for $33,000. Taxes were $4,000 a year -- a stretch, but Pete and Jean figured they could just make it.

title: Conversations With Sondheim
description: A bow of appreciation to Frank Rich (March 12) for his article on Stephen Sondheim. True, that glorified mug shot of a cover took some getting used to. But with Sondheim, in his life as in his art, it does well to look beyond the obvious. That whiskered tease of a smile and the challenging gaze tell us all we need to know. How good to find him, at 70, in such typically quirky form.

title: Megan Boyle, Mason Flinn
description: Megan Maura Boyle, a daughter of Thomas M. Boyle of Williamsburg, Va., and the late Mary Elizabeth Boyle, was married yesterday to Mason Stanfield Flinn, a son of Kendall M. Hetterly of Elfand, N.C., and George H. Flinn II of Locust, N.J. The Rev. James T. Dever performed the ceremony at Our Mother of Consolation Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ISABEL M.
description: HECHT-Isabel M. On April 7, 2000. Beloved wife of Judge Burton G. Hecht. Loving mother of Mindy and Howard, Audrey and Jeffrey and Allen and Amy. Adoring grandmother of Diana, Daniel, Sara and Allison. She will be profoundly missed and will always be in our hearts. Visiting Saturday, 7-9 PM. Service Sunday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALSOP, JOHN
description: ALSOP-John. 84, of Old Lyme, CT, died on April 6, 2000. Husband of Augusta Alsop; father of Mary Culver, Augusta Alsop and John Alsop. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, April 12, 2000 at 11 AM in St. Ann Church, Shore Rd., Old Lyme, CT. Burial will be private. There are no calling hours. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Ann Church, Shore Rd., Old Lyme, CT 06371.

title: Technology; Virtually Science
description: Since the 1800's, generations of students have played mad scientist, mixing potions, dissecting dead animals and constructing string models of the physical world. As the physicist and Nobel laureate Richard Feynman told fellow scientists nearly a half century ago, ''The test of all knowledge is experiment.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONACCI, LANDO E.
description: MONACCI-Lando E. 96. Resident of Flushing for 76 years. Passed away April 8, 2000. Born February 10, 1904, in NY, NY. Lando graduated from Cooper Union College, NYC, Class of 1928. He was an electrical engineer employed by Consolidated Edison for 45 years retiring in 1969 as a Supervising Engineer for the Inside Plant Bureau. Lando was a member of American Institute of Electrical Engineers and was a New York Professional Engineer. Lando always found his greatest joys in family activities. He is predeceased by his wife of 48 years Rose P., son Thomas O., and brother Emil. He is survived by his daughter Adele M. Henrick of Oakland, ME, son Robert W. of Yardley, PA, daughter-in-law Lucy of Bayonne, NJ, six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Reposing at the Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass St. Andrew Avellino R.C. Church, Monday, 10:15 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATT, PAULINE
description: PLATT-Pauline. Of Riverdale. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Elaine and Jack Stahl. Dear grandmother of Zari Stahl Payones and Shana Naccarella. Devoted greatgrandmother of Jacey and Evan Naccarella and Corey Payones. Graveside services, 1:15 PM, Monday, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: No Reward for the $61 Million Risk
description: Hockey's version of the worst team money could buy ends its season in profound indifference at Madison Square Garden this afternoon, when the Rangers play host to the Philadelphia Flyers on the final day of the National Hockey League's regular season.

title: Good Times Could Burden An Incumbent In Greek Vote
description: For Greeks, their economy, their standing in Europe and even their tense relationship with Turkey are better now than at any time since World War II.

title: Blundering In The Burbs; That Sleek Suburban Political Machine
description: When it comes to government, city folks have always felt inferior to suburbanites. Rudy Giuliani notwithstanding, New Yorkers believe that theirs is a land of big-spending pols and inefficient public services. They also take it on faith that the suburbs have small, cost-conscious work forces monitored by diligent chief executives who came up through the ranks of the League of Women Voters.

title: Blackboard: The Arts; In New Jersey, Be Creative or Else
description: For New Jersey youngsters, the stakes in learning a new song or drawing a picture could soon be a lot higher than impressing Mom and Dad at the school pageant or creating a masterpiece for the family refrigerator.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bellport, N.Y.; Where Summers Are Still Long and Lazy
description: EMILY CZAJA, a lifelong resident of Bellport, a village of venerable colonial-style houses with white picket fences on the South Shore of Long Island, has noticed significant changes in the habits of the summer people, who have been fixtures for more than a century.

title: Conversations With Sondheim
description: I eagerly read your discussion of Sondheim's life and legacy of music and lyrics. I have long been a fan and did not miss the opportunity to see ''Saturday Night.''

title: Art in Indianapolis
description: To the Editor: Douglas Wissing's article ''What's Doing in Indianapolis'' (Feb. 27) hardly did justice to that city's growing importance as a major art center. In addition to its remarkable collections of Oriental art and works by J. M. W. Turner, the neo-Impressionists and other Western artists, the Indianapolis Museum of Art boasts one of the finest collections of African art in this country -- the Eiteljorg collection.

title: Precautions Could Help Minimize Another Floyd
description: It was interesting to compare the length some municipalities will go to prepare for bad storms with my own town, Cortlandt Manor, which suffered damage during Floyd [''Stuck With a Mortgage for a House That's Gone,'' March 19]. My neighborhood in Cortlandt suffers flooding during lesser storms so after having watched the Weather Channel, we knew we were in for a problem days before. I guess our town doesn't get the Weather Channel.

title: NUDE BEACHGOERS' VERDICTS
description: Just as the weather started to turn a bit warmer, nude sunbathing got a little boost last week when Superior Court Judge Albert Garofolo ruled that Bill Vogt, 44, was within his rights to take off his clothes on federal land along Higbee Beach last summer in Cape May County. But Judge Garofolo ruled against Mr. Vogt's wife, Arlene, who defied a local Lower Township ordinance when she removed her bikini top on Higbee Beach land owned by the state of New Jersey. Lower Township had passed an ordinance prohibiting nudity at Higbee long after it said it found evidence of homosexual activity there. The Vogts say they will appeal Mrs. Vogt's conviction, saying that she was arrested while wearing a bottom, just as Mr. Vogt was beside her, and was thus discriminated against because she was a woman. ROBERT STRAUSS

title: The Liberating Arts
description: Yuri Solonin, the dean of the philosophy department at St. Petersburg State University, is a man of apparent self-assurance. He is tall, trenchant, tough-minded. But his wife is worried about him. Of late, he has appeared agitated. ''She realizes I am not quite normal at the moment,'' Mr. Solonin said. ''And she wonders if I should not drop this project that is making me so nervous.''

title: Alice Waters Cooks Her Turkey Too Long
description: I enjoyed Jonathan Reynolds's description of how to make the perfect turkey. He calls up the Wise Women of the kitchen -- Julia Child and Alice Waters -but fails to contact my mother. She knows the secret to a memorable bird: bacon!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCALES, LILA NEE WARSHAW
description: SCALES-Lila nee Warshaw, of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved wife of Dr. Harold. Devoted mother of Lorna Goldberg and Jeffrey Scales. Dear sister of Emanuel and Milton Warshaw. Loving grandmother of Benjamin Goldberg and Aaron and Will Scales. Services Gutterman-Musicant, corner of Passaic and Park Sts., Hackensack, NJ, on Sunday at noon. The memorial period will be observed at the Goldberg residence. Contributions to Alzheimer's Association or the Teaneck Jewish Community Center would be appreciated.

title: Say It With Lycra
description: This season, love is a many silk-screened thing. Chloe's ''I Love You'' T-shirt is the garment of the hour for fashion stylists, models and actresses. Those three glittery little words have stretched across the chests of Cerys Matthews, the leader of the band Catatonia, on the cover of this month's Details; Daryl Hannah in last week's New York magazine; and the ''Summer of Sam'' actress Jennifer Esposito and a gaggle of her friends at the New York premiere of ''Boiler Room.'' In blue or mustard capped-sleeved ($90), tank ($90) or long-sleeved ($110) styles, the shirt has already sold out at Saks Fifth Avenue and at Ron Herman/Fred Segal in Los Angeles; a few remain at the Chloe boutique at 850 Madison Avenue (70th Street). ELLEN TIEN

title: The Knicks Needing Houston's Touch
description: So often, it's as if Allan Houston needs his shooter's touch as much as an artist needs his brush. He is helpless without it, flustered when it disappears, crestfallen when a defender takes it away.

title: The Chinese Stool, Humble Yet Wondrous
description: WILLIAM LIPTON remembers the first time he saw Chinese stools. It was the late 1950's, and he was 5. A pair of barrel-shaped stools, in blue and white porcelain, flanked the sofa in his grandmother's parlor in Dallas. ''Even on a hot summer day, they felt icy,'' he said. ''They were plump and smooth and had wonderful pictures of tall sailing ships in a harbor all around the sides.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHODES, MARGARET DURYEE
description: RHODES-Margaret Duryee. Wife of the late A. Whitney Rhodes. Died peacefully at home in her 96th year on April 4, 2000. A lifelong resident of Englewood, N.J., she was the loving mother of Barbara R. Zinke of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. and Douglas B. Rhodes of Providence, R.I., and beloved grandmother of eight and great grandmother of thirteen. Interment will be private.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 9, 2000
description: Weeks

description: GET HAPPY
