description: Lost at Sea

title: A Life With History in Black and White
description: BACK in the early 50's, when Milton Meltzer and no less a luminary than Langston Hughes were shopping around a book on black history, they were rejected by at least 10 publishers. Negroes do not read and there is little interest in such a peculiar topic, Mr. Meltzer recalled being told.

title: Spotlight On Woods But Love's Just as Hot
description: Davis Love III is dead even with the golfer everyone is talking about here. He has posted the exact same scores as this other golfer, who is the favorite of the fans and the news media and is known mostly by his first name. But while Tiger Woods attracted all the attention today as he played himself into contention, Love drew barely any notice at all.

title: North Dakota Rallies to Deny Boston College and Win N.C.A.A. Title
description: North Dakota won its seventh national hockey championship tonight, scoring three third-period goals to beat Boston College, 4-2, at the Providence Civic Center.

title: A Roomy Old Place Rich in History and Spirit
description: YUJI YODA and Michelle Marroquin wear the joyful expressions of children lost in a candy store. But they are not children, nor are they surrounded by sweets; they are grown-up dancers who have just stepped into New York City's oldest synagogue building, on Manhattan's Lower East Side. Mr. Yoda and Ms. Marroquin, members of Zvi Gotheiner and Dancers, are the first to arrive for rehearsal at the site of Mr. Gotheiner's new work, ''The Amber Room.''

title: The Invisible Poor
description: Thanks to James Fallows for his article (March 19) and to Taryn Simon, Jeff Riedel, Brenda Ann Kenneally and Lauren Greenfield for the portraits titled ''In the Shadow of Wealth.''

title: SMART HIGHWAY SIGNS
description: Northern New Jersey commuters can begin looking up to see what is in front of them on the roadway this week as the state Department of Transportation begins using its $44.7 million road sign system to convey traffic information to motorists. For the first few months, the signs will convey information gathered by the police or motorists and relayed to the transportation network by telephone or radio. But by summer the signs should be gathering information from satellites, lasers and road sensors and instantly relaying that to drivers, said Jim Berzok, transportation department spokesman. The real-time information system relies on a million feet of fiber optic cable and covers 70 miles of roadway mostly on Routes 80, 46, 287 and 17. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Amy Craft, Alexander Beard
description: Amy Annette Craft, a daughter of Annette Carbo Craft and Roy Garvice Craft Jr. of Alexandria, La., was married there yesterday to Alexander Sherwood Beard, a son of Patricia Beard of Millbrook, N.Y., and Samuel Beard of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Edwin Rodriguez performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Cathedral.

title: Starring Role in the Off Broadway Awards
description: WHEN Lucille Lortel established her namesake award for Off Broadway excellence, there was truly only one. It went to the Lincoln Center Theater in 1986 for producing the ''Woza Afrika'' festival. It wasn't until 1989 that the Lortel officially became the Lortels. And two of the three prizes that year went to the Connecticut-based playwright A. R. Gurney and the director John Tillinger, each destined to be more than just a one-time winner.

title: RESTAURANTS; American Beauty
description: THE building looks as if it had stood here for at least a century, a stolid pile of brick with severe mansard roofs. In fact, it's hardly older than the Friendly's across the street. It was built around 1970 as a steakhouse, then became Le Chateau, a temple of what passed in those days for fine dining in Bergen County. By the late 90's, when Tenafly had grown weary of Le Chateau (or vice versa), it closed and stood empty, waiting for a tenant, or a wrecker.

description: Vera: (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov)

title: David Duchovny, With Facial Expressions
description: IT'S a Tuesday morning on the set of ''The X-Files'' and David Duchovny is working three jobs. He has just changed out of his F.B.I. agent suit -- the uniform for the brooding but sartorially conformist Fox Mulder -- into an orange T-shirt and jeans, director chic. The episode he is directing (and wrote) is about an old 60's activist who becomes Jesus, and something supernatural called the Lazarus Bowl; one character is called the Cigarette Smoking Pontiff.

title: Raleigh
description: Dubbed the City of Oaks soon after its founding in 1792, Raleigh in spring could just as easily be called the city of redbuds or crape myrtles or Yoshino cherries. This time of year, balmy temperatures coax into bloom a sea of tulips, azaleas and irises.

title: My Suburb; EdenView, U.S.A.
description: A few years ago, my wife and I had a child. This is the only part of the story that's true. Or rather, she had the child, while I hyperventilated and prayed that it would all end before I had completely dishonored myself. And it did, it did end, and when it did, I had only partially dishonored myself, and we had a beautiful child. Our child made us feel happy, fulfilled and also a little suspicious that everyone we met was trying to kill us and thus deprive our child of ''a good life.''

title: Cruise Insurance
description: To the Editor: Having recently been involved in the quest for trip cancellation insurance for a Renaissance cruise we booked for the end of May, my husband and I read ''Renaissance Loses Insurers'' with particular interest in the Practical Traveler (March 26).

title: Corrections

description: DUBINSKY-Sarah (Sally). Of Boynton Beach, FL, on April 6, 2000. In loving memory you will always be in our hearts. Survived by children Alan Dubinsky of Brooklyn, NY and Karen Long of Fairfax, VA. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association or Fight for Sight.

title: PrivateSector; Hiking New York Because It's There
description: Last week, Paul Grand, in full hiking gear, was traversing Manhattan's Washington Heights, up one street, down another, going slowly enough, as he put it, ''to be available for serendipity and surprises.'' He has found a good deal of both since he began methodically walking the streets of Manhattan in 1997, mostly during the cooler seasons. His goal is to cover all of the island's 504.3 paved miles by the end of this year.

title: Medical Center Can Now Reach Potential
description: Free of the yoke of county government, the private owners of the Nassau County Medical Center are facing a daunting job. The hospital is a huge facility with very expensive upkeep, and it has been deteriorating since it opened in 1972.

title: A Dad, Surrounded but Alone
description: From the start the obvious solution to the Elian Gonzalez crisis was to invite the boy's father to the United States so that he could determine his son's future freely and without fear. Americans have taken some time to realize this, preferring to debate Elian's future in such ideologically loaded terms as ''politics versus a child's welfare'' or ''anti-Communism versus family values.''

title: The Forecast for the Draft
description: Bill Parcells, the Jets' director of football operations, says that the bus station is full of guys who were once compared to Lawrence Taylor. That may be so, but in the first round of the N.F.L. draft on Saturday, Parcells swings for the fences and grabs Penn State linebacker LaVar Arrington, who scouts believe really is the next L.T. Parcells trades one first-round selection and a second-round pick plus receiver Keyshawn Johnson to Cleveland for the top pick. MIKE FREEMAN

title: Backtalk; When E-Mail And Opinions Are Welcome
description: Now that our forum is off and running at the mouth, just a click away on your e-mail dial (TheLipsite@aol.com), your only excuse for not participating is the continuing confusion over college sports: is it professional, semiprofessional, amateur? Are these labels without meaning? Why should we care?

title: Sudden Defection Scrambles Venezuela's Election Script
description: For the second time in two years, a former military officer vowing to dismantle a corrupt and incompetent status quo has emerged to challenge Venezuela's political establishment. This time, though, Hugo Chavez is not the leader of the insurgency, but its main target -- and it is one of his closest comrades in arms who is trying to drive him from the presidency he has held for just 14 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERICSSON, GARY JOHN
description: ERICSSON-Gary John. Died Thursday, April 6, at the Mount Sinai Hospital, NYC. Mr. Ericsson was born in NYC and was 48 years of age. He lived in Queens, moving to East Brunswick 12 years ago. He was employed by the New York Times since 1980 and was an N.M.D.U. member for 30 years. Surviving are his wife Benay Spero Ericsson, his father Carl (Sonny) Ericsson of Ohio, two sisters, Fern Parkin of Warwick, NY, and Kelly Ericsson of Missouri, three brothers, Wayne Ericsson of Queens, Leif Ericsson of Ohio and Eric Ericsson of Missouri. Services will be Monday, 1 PM, from Rezem Funeral Home, 457 Cranbury Rd., East Brunswick, 732-257-1191. Burial will be at Washington Monumental Cemetery, South River, NJ. There are no calling hours.

title: Bargaining With Banks
description: Tired of settling for whatever interest rate your local bank pays on certificates of deposit but hesitant to send your money thousands of miles away to get a better one? The creators of Shoprate.com, in Winchester, Ky., propose to resolve your problem.

title: Alice Waters Cooks Her Turkey Too Long
description: Your food column was a feast to read. I don't know Jonathan Reynolds, and furthermore I detest turkey. But Reynolds evidently knows about food, and he knows how to talk to me. He's fun.

description: MILLER-Stanley S. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member Stanley S. Miller, and offer their deepest sympathy to his wife Martha, his children and the entire Miller family. Alpine Country Club Harvey Nagin President

title: PULSE; Wheels That Fly and Fold
description: If Bart Simpson is to remain an animated purveyor of cool, it's time he trade his skateboard for a Razor. Weighing just over six pounds, this nonmotorized skateboard-scooter ($129) has become popular around town since it was imported from China last November. Unlike Rollerblades and bicycles, the Razor folds into half its size and can be carried by its handles or tucked into a messenger bag. Its sleek aluminum finish appeals to the design-minded as well as the hurried masses. Recent spottings include a Razor-borne mother and daughter whizzing through SoHo, a 30-something man pushing a Razor along 42nd Street and a couple of teenagers joy riding around Chinatown. But are they safe? ''You have to be always on the lookout for potholes and cars,'' cautioned James Yu of Basic Wheels, on Hester Street, which sells about 50 Razors a month. Potholes aren't a problem for employees at Razorfish, a digital media firm, who use Razors to race around their 28,000-square-foot office on Mercer Street. NANA ASFOUR

title: Players Take a Step Backward, but Find a Reason to Look Ahead
description: Mike Caruso, Javier Valentin and Brett Tomko spent the past two seasons in the major leagues. All have started this season in the minor leagues. So have Joe McEwing, Jason Johnson, Chad Allen and Doug Mientkiewicz. All thought they had left the minors behind, but it is back to buses and fast-food dinners.

title: Goodbye, Columbus; Hello, City Island
description: After eight years selling artistic, imported home furnishings and trinkets, Exotiqa, a small Columbus Avenue shop, closed on April 1. The items in the store, from jewelery and incense, to modern African stone and wood sculptures, were moved to the store's sister location on City Island in the Bronx, which was opened a year and a half ago in anticipation of the move, said Paul Klein, the store's owner.

title: Sangeeth Gnanasekaran, Christopher William

title: O'Neill Snaps Yankees Out Of Doldrums In the Ninth
description: Paul O'Neill bent at the knees in the Yankees' clubhouse this morning and the joints in his legs cracked and snapped loudly, like wishbones being pulled apart. ''C'mon, body, get going,'' he said, trying to shake off the morning sluggishness.

title: Dreaming of Airships in the Skies Above Queens
description: Alan Gross wants to dot the sky over College Point with the lozenge-shaped profiles of blimps.

title: Van Program for Teenagers Expands
description: A YEAR-OLD program that offers youngsters in White Plains free van rides to housing complexes and neighborhood recreation centers is expanding next month to include baseball diamonds, lacrosse fields and tennis courts.

title: A Viola Work Takes On The Spirit of Gospel
description: EVEN experienced musicians sometimes confuse the viola's tone quality with the clarinet's. The instruments' ranges are certainly similar. So it's not a total surprise that ''Soul Garden,'' the new viola piece to be introduced in Montclair on Saturday, was composed by a clarinet player.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Hope Abandoned
description: The shadowy entrance to a hospital in the Chechen capital, Grozny, portrayed in the frontispiece of the deeply disturbing photographs collected in INFERNO (Phaidon, $125) seems reminiscent of Barry Moser's illustration of a hooded Dante ''within a shadowed forest.'' It is a cautionary sign for readers to abandon every hope if they enter Chechnya, Rwanda, Bosnia, Somalia and Kosovo through James Nachtwey's lens. Neither hospitals nor relief camps nor schools nor houses of worship could provide proper sanctuary for the victims of the unfathomable violence and devastation wreaked on the most afflicted places of the 1990's. French soldiers bulldozing corpses of refugees in the Congo (then called Zaire); Bosnians ritually washing their dead in the shadows of their mosque; an impossibly emaciated, naked Sudanese man crawling into an emergency-relief tent; the headless Rwandan torso of a little girl still wearing a flowery sundress; a family of ''untouchables'' in India prepare their evening meal by cooking skewered rats on an open flame -- it seems unimaginable to absorb these horrifying images. Nachtwey's eye is impeccable, but photo after photo of misery quickly becomes numbing. Maybe that is the point of this war photographer, who, he notes, would rather be considered an ''antiwar'' photographer. Lance Gould

title: G.O.P. Races Adjust as Bush's Glow Dims
description: A year after House Republicans spoke glowingly of Gov. George W. Bush as a life raft who would carry them to victory, Congressional leaders and Bush aides have scotched talk of a common legislative agenda and are pursuing distinct electoral strategies of their own.

title: Athens Expands Metro, Unearthing Antiquities
description: In anticipation of its role as host of the 2004 Olympics, Athens is expanding its metro system. The $2.5 billion project includes two new lines, adding more than 12 miles and 21 stations. Expanded service began in January with the opening of 13 new stations. The fare is now 70 cents.

title: The Buzz That Comes With Bill And Hillary
description: SUSAN HODARA was starting to feel a little left out. After all, the president and the first lady moved here several months ago, and nearly everyone else in town, it seemed, had already met them. ''I kept hearing about people having their Hillary encounters -- first all my friends, and then my daughter at school, and then I started feeling -- Hey, what about me?'' Ms. Hodara said.

title: So Much to Read, Too Many Who Can't Read
description: THE origin of language is one of the great mysteries. How did we get all the way from primitive grunts of ''duh'' and ''yeah, right'' and ''cool'' to the language of Shakespeare and Whitman and then all the way back again? The arts of reading and writing are even more mystifying. Why would anyone start to write when nobody could read? You have to imagine the scene, somewhere in Egypt about 7,000 years ago.

title: The Personal Shopper
description: Edward O'Sullivan, a personal shopper at Prada who grew up in a tiny village in Ireland, has a flair for pairing the gritty and the urbane. His latest style quirk is an ascot, which he gives a new, bad-boy twist by skipping the smoking coat and sporting it with jeans and a dark blue leather racing jacket ($1,780 at Prada, 724 Fifth Avenue near 56th Street).

title: Hot Goods
description: Border guards in the former Soviet republic of Uzbekistan seized a radioactive cargo on an Iranian truck bound for Pakistan, State Department officials said.The material, found in 10 lead containers about the size of a thick briefcase, was being tested by officials in neighboring Kazakhstan, where it originated, to see if it could have been used to make a nuclear weapon. Pakistan has a history of smuggling nuclear components, and is believed to have built about a dozen warheads. TIM WEINER

title: Around The World Of Music
description: ETHNOMUSICOLOGISTS are rarely accused of getting popular music right. More often, they're engaged in pursuits that seem excessively narrow and clinical -- pitch variance among Central African xylophones or Connecticut River Valley fife-and-drum history. Individual projects of ethnomusicology are often hard to read and feel abstracted from what most of us consider the important stuff: the music that we have emotional attachments to, the music that our commercial society points us toward.

title: The Corporation As Fantasy Villain
description: MIDWAY through ''Erin Brockovich,'' I began to peel off from that hugely likable movie and consider its curious new genre, whose template has already hardened. Once again, as in ''The Rainmaker'' and ''A Civil Action,'' a David law firm was suing a Goliath corporation on behalf of the company's victims. Once again, the corporation was responding with a conspiracy of silence and intimidation. And once again I had that uneasy feeling that something was missing: a credible, complex opponent.

title: Exemption From Levy In a Co-op
description: Q: I am a physician practicing on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. My office, which I have owned since 1982, is in a prestigious co-op building. Last year, the board imposed an assessment on all shareholders in the building. The total assessment was for roughly the same amount as the real property tax abatement that residential tenants in the building received. I am aware that as a commercial tenant-shareholder I am not entitled to the abatement. At the same time, however, I am being required to pay an assessment that is being levied as a result of benefits received only by the residential shareholders. My question is, can the board rescind or reduce the assessment to me and other professional shareholders in the building if they wish to do so? . . . Dr. Kenneth N. Weinstein, Manhattan.

description: There is still time to start seeds of warm-season vegetables like tomatoes, peppers and eggplant indoors, even as you plant cool-season vegetables outdoors.

title: Politics In The Burbs; Soccer Mom 2000
description: For months now, Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster who studies Americans with the discipline and delight of Darwin in the Gal1/3pagos, has been conducting a focus group of just one. Every once in a while he calls up Ruth Cullison, a homemaker and former art teacher in the suburbs of Baltimore whom he has come to think of as the quintessential swing voter. Like a lot of Americans, Cullison is following the presidential campaign at a distance, with a keen sense of anticipatory disappointment.

title: Conditions Cancel Princeton Regatta
description: Princeton played host to crews from Rutgers, Columbia and Georgetown on its Lake Carnegie course yesterday. However, only 4 of the 27 scheduled races between the Tiger men's heavyweight and lightweight teams, and the women's open class crews were rowed before unsafe water conditions forced the coaches to cancel the remainder of the regatta.

title: Czechs Put U.S. Backs to the Wall
description: John McEnroe's Davis Cup team apparently has the knack that he had for living on the edge. For the second straight match in two months, McEnroe's first two as captain, the United States is going into the reverse singles needing to win them both against a heavy underdog.

title: When Asserting A Self-Image Is Self-Defense
description: WHEN it comes to reputation, good images go down the drain fast. Ask Bill Clinton. Ask Gary Hart. Negative images are a lot tougher; they've got real staying power. Ask Michael Dukakis about the tank, or Edmund Muskie about his tears. President Ronald Reagan, who knew a lot about image power, had a habit of arranging important ribbon cuttings or attendance at charitable events whenever he had just done something unpopular, so the good image would upstage the bad.

title: For the Disabled, Barriers to Online Study
description: Frances Moyer has macular degeneration and other diseases that have left her blind in one eye and with limited vision in the other. Despite the impediment, she is studying online for a master's degree, in the education of the disabled, from Western Michigan University in Kalamazoo.

title: Nouvelle Cuisine Meets Japanese Fare
description: IS Maguro the most expensive restaurant on the Island?'' asked the woman on the phone. ''We spent more there than at Panama Hatties,'' she said. That is easy to do when sushi assortments cost $30 to $70, the majority of hot entrees are $35 or more and appetizers (most in the teens) go as high as $25. The only way that reader escaped with next week's grocery money was by ordering a few hand rolls. (There are pitfalls here, too. The dragon roll is $20. It goes for $7 to $7.50 at nearby Japanese restaurants.)

title: Where Food Shops Are a Declining Species
description: Lee Epps, 69, said last week that she had changed her supermarket five times in the last eight years as, one by one, the stores have moved out of Elmhurst.

title: Dressing the Part
description: O.K., so ''Aida,'' the Disney extravaganza by Elton John and Tim Rice, may not be the most fashionable new play in town. But it's definitely the most fashion-fluent. Sherie Rene Scott plays Amneris, a style-savvy princess with the dazzle of Diana, Princess of Wales, and the campy pizzaz of Bette Midler. With shoes as high as her hair, Amneris makes 12 costume changes, wearing everything from a pyramid hat three feet high and topped by a plastic cat to a wedding gown made entirely of satin ribbons. She is hailed as ''first in beauty, wisdom and accessories'' by a handmaiden, and her big production number about clothes (''I would rather wear a barrel,'' she belts, ''than conservative apparel'') is capped by a runway show with hats to rival Philip Treacy's and gowns that make John Galliano's look puritanical. Bob Crowley designed the costumes and sets. ''Is that the latest fashion?'' asks Radames (Adam Pascal) when Amneris, his betrothed, appears in an outrageous purple and chiffon gown dripping with crystals. ''It is now,'' she replies. BOB MORRIS

title: Trying to Put Down Roots on a Brooklyn Fire Escape
description: I HAVE the worst kind of garden lust. No 40-year-old woman wants a baby the way I want a little plot of earth. If I had one, I'd go out every morning, barefoot, coffee in hand, to smell lavender and soil, to admire grapevines and wisteria. I fantasize about herb gardens and trailing vines, exploding from giant terra cotta planters on each corner of the patio. Forget about boring suburban lawns; I'd have just a wide slate path to part the masses of flowers and vegetables.

title: Mindshare Sets Team For North America Unit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, BESSIE GRAHAM HOBSON
description: BLACK-Bessie Graham Hobson. (Known to her wide circle of friends as ''Graham''), lost her six year battle with melanoma and quietly slipped away on April 7, 2000. She was 77 years old. Her family surrounded her at her home at 12305 S.W. 73rd Avenue, in Miami, as her life ended. She was a lady of class. Graham filled her life and those around her with beauty, dignity, grace and love. A stunningly beautiful woman, Graham's optimistic humility inspired whomever her life touched to feel warm and good about themselves. She never disrespected anyone for any reason including race, religion, disability, sex or economic status. Graham also excelled in matters of the intellect. She graduated from Bryn Mawr College on a full academic scholarship with highest honors. She remained a thorough scholar, researcher, editor and reader throughout her life. Graham had a ''green thumb.'' Every plant she touched thrived and in her last days, she lay outside on her patio enveloped by brilliantly colored orchids of her own creation. The late United States Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black, her father-in-law, adored Graham. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Hugo L. Black, Jr., a veteran Miami trial attorney; their three children and spouses: Elizabeth Black and spouse Peter Goodfellow of Auckland, New Zealand; Margaret Black and spouse John Gallardo of Los Angeles, California, and Hugo Black III and wife Jeannine Crowell Black of Miami. She is also survived by her brothers, Richard R. G. Hobson of Alexandria, Virginia, and Archer Hobson of Staunton, Virginia, and the 11 children of her late brother Edwin Hobson of Rye, New Hampshire. Graham was a founder of Saint Andrews Episcopal Church at the corner of Old Cutler Road and Mitchell Drive in Miami and took much pride in her service on the Landscaping Committee that wove the church and its buldings into a natural and spiritual setting. Graham was a member of the Royal Palm Tennis Club, the patrons of the Museum of Natural Science, the South Florida Orchid Society, Coral Pines Garden Club, Fairchild Tropical Gardens, St. Andrews Book Club, the Tropical Fruit Society and the Villagers. Services will be conducted at St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Miami by Bishop Calvin Schofield and the Rev. Marta Weeks at 4:00 PM on Monday, April 10, 2000, followed by a reception at the St. Andrews Parish House. Services will also be held on Wednesday, April 12, 2000, noon at Immanuel Church On The Hill in Alexandria, Virginia, followed by interment at Ivy Hill Cemetery in Alexandria, Virginia. The family suggests contributions in Graham's memory to the St. Andrews Episcopal Church Landscaping Committee or Fairchild Tropical Gardens. For further information contact Stanfill Funeral Homes at 10545 South Dixie Highway in Miami.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCY, GEORGE T.
description: PIERCY-George T. Piercy died Thursday evening at his home in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. He was born in Eau Claire, Wisconsin on November 29, 1915, and graduated from the University of Minnesota with a degree in chemical engineering in 1938. On graduation he joined the Exxon Corporation as a process engineer in Baton Rouge, LA. In 1964, he was elected to the Board of Directors of Imperial Oil Limited, Exxon's Canadian affiliate, and in 1965, he moved to London where he became Middle East Representative for Exxon. Returning to the United States in 1966, shortly after, he was elected a director of Exxon. During the oil crisis of 1973-74, Mr. Piercy was responsible for many negotiations with OPEC, representing the petroleum industry. He retired in 1981, as a senior Vice President and Exxon Board Member, expanding his career to 42 years. Mr. Piercy also served as a Director of the Chemical Bank and Chemical New York Corporation; Board Member of the Princeton Theological Seminary and Center of Theological Inquiry in Princeton; Trustee, President and Chairman of the Board of Educational Broadcasting Corporation of New York; President and Chairman of the University of Minnesota Foundation; and Chairman of the Teagle Foundation. His former wife of 30 years, Virginia Boudreau died in 1979. Mr. Piercy is survived by his wife Janet Aldridge Piercy, of 18 years, two daughters, Nancy P. Murray of Elkton, MD, and Susan P. McCarthy, of Arden Hills, MN, and five grandchildren. A memorial was held in Mr. Piercy's home on Saturday, April 1st for family and friends with Dr. Jack Swann presiding. Memorial services will be held in New York City at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Chapel with Dr. Thomas K. Tewell, Sr., Minister and Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland, Minister Emeritus presiding at 1:00pm, on Monday, April 10. A service at the University of Minnesota and Interment in Eau Clare, Wisconsin will be held April 12. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the University of Minnesota Foundation for the George T. Piercy Wing at the Department of Chemical Engineering and Material Science. Attn: Gerald B. Fischer, 200 Oak St. S.E., Suite 500, Minneapolis, MN 55455-2010.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMANOFF, HANNAH
description: KOMANOFF-Hannah. On April 9, at the Long Beach Medical Center in Long Beach, New York. Beloved and devoted wife of Isidore Komanoff, a stock broker and philanthropist who died in 1985; mother of Frederica Miceli, Ruth Underwood and Charles Komanoff; grandmother of Andrew Miceli, Dorian Bandy, Amalia Bandy, Daniel Komanoff and Alexander Komanoff. After graduating from the New York University School of Commerce in 1931, she enjoyed a successful career in merchandising with Abraham & Strauss. In 1947 she and her family moved from Brooklyn to Long Beach, where she dedicated her life to the care of her family and friends and to the service of her community. As a Long Beach resident for 53 years, she was in the forefront of volunteer civic work and progressive political activities, serving as an elected member of the Board of Education from 1957 to 1973 and as the Supervisor of Long Beach on the Nassau County Board of Supervisors from 1974 to 1985. With her husband and on her own, she was a generous benefactor to many local institutions and national organizations. Her Supervisor's salary was donated to charity. The Hannah and Isidore Komanoff Center for Rehabilitative Medicine and Geriatric Care, part of the Long Beach Medical Center, has been in the vanguard of its field since its inception almost 30 years ago. Decent, fair and compassionate, her life was a testimoy to her belief in the dignity, equality and inherent goodness of all people. With intelligence, humility, charm and kindness, she always put the well-being of others before herself. She will be profoundly missed and lovingly remembered. A funeral service will take place at Temple Israel of Long Beach, 305 Riverside Boulevard at Park Avenue, Monday, April 10, at noon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, HENRY
description: HOROWITZ-Henry. April 11, 1994. To My Father A giant pine, magnificent and old, stood staunch against the sky and, all around shed beauty, grace, and power. Within its fold birds safely reared their young. The velvet ground beneath was gentle, and the cooling shade gave cheer to passers-by. Its towering arms a landmark stood, erect and unafraid, as if to say, ''Fear naught from life's alarms.'' It fell one day. Where it had dauntless stood was loneliness and void. But men who passed paid tribute-said, ''To know this life was good, it left its mark on me. Its work stands fast.'' And so it lives. Such life no bonds can hold-This giant pine, magnificent and old. In loving memory-always. Linda & Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMANOFF, HANNAH
description: KOMANOFF-Hannah. On April 9, at the Long Beach Medical Center in Long Beach, New York. Beloved and devoted wife of Isidore Komanoff, a stock broker and philanthropist who died in 1985; mother of Frederica Miceli, Ruth Underwood and Charles Komanoff; grandmother of Andrew Miceli, Dorian Bandy, Amalia Bandy, Daniel Komanoff and Alexander Komanoff. After graduating from the New York University School of Commerce in 1931, she enjoyed a successful career in merchandising with Abraham & Strauss. In 1947 she and her family moved from Brooklyn to Long Beach, where she dedicated her life to the care of her family and friends and to the service of her community. As a Long Beach resident for 53 years, she was in the forefront of volunteer civic work and progressive political activities, serving as an elected member of the Board of Education from 1957 to 1973 and as the Supervisor of Long Beach on the Nassau County Board of Supervisors from 1974 to 1985. With her husband and on her own, she was a generous benefactor to many local institutions and national organizations. Her Supervisor's salary was donated to charity. The Hannah and Isidore Komanoff Center for Rehabilitative Medicine and Geriatric Care, part of the Long Beach Medical Center, has been in the vanguard of its field since its inception almost 30 years ago. Decent, fair and compassionate, her life was a testimoy to her belief in the dignity, equality and inherent goodness of all people. With intelligence, humility, charm and kindness, she always put the well-being of others before herself. She will be profoundly missed and lovingly remembered.

title: Taking a Close Look at Earth's Strange Neighbors

Guided by gentle shoves from small thruster rockets, the craft, NEAR Shoemaker, is taking up a circular orbit 62 miles from the center of the asteroid Eros for more detailed studies.

title: Plan Your Family Reunion In Rehab
description: Supertitles keep the audience apprised of the passage of time in Beth Henley's tedious new play, ''Family Week,'' which opened yesterday at the Century Center on East 15th Street. ''Day 1 of Family Week,'' the first one says, before the lights come up on a series of vignettes depicting a reunion of one of Ms. Henley's signature dysfunctional families. ''Day 2 of Family Week,'' the second one says, before the lights come up on another series of vignettes. By the time Day 7 (I can't get myself to repeat the whole phrase yet again) arrives, the repetition has, in only 90 minutes, created a remarkable sense of real time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNITT, ROY F., JR.
description: BARNITT-Roy F., Jr., actor, businessman and attorney, of NYC, suddenly on Friday, April 7, 2000. Beloved son of the late Roy F., Sr., and Beatrice Ward Barnitt. Dear brother of Richard P. Barnitt. Uncle of Richard, David, Patrick and Christopher, and five grandnieces and nephews. Brother-inlaw of Kathleen W. Barnitt. Roy graduated from St. Peter's College, Jersey City, in 1954 and then went on to become a Fulbright Scholar at the Sorbonne Univ. in Paris, France. He then taught English at Regis H.S. and was interpreter for the French Line. Roy earned his Law Degree from Harvard Univ. in 1956. He held positions at the law firm of Cadwalder, Wickersham and Taft, NYC. He eventually went on to become the President of JC Penney Real Estate Subsidiary. Throughout his life, Roy was actively involved with theater and performed in many Off-Broadway Productions such as Dreamer Examines His Pillow, Long Day's Journey Into Night, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, and many others. He most recently appeared in the production of Whoa-Jack at the Worth Theater Company. At the age of sixty, Roy retired and pursued his passion for acting. His film credits include Oliver Stone's JFK and Nixon, and the feature film, Harvest. He was a member of the Screen Actors Guild and Actors Equity. Memorial Mass Wednesday, April 12, 10AM, at St. Malachy's Church, 239 W. 49 St., NYC. Interment of ashes at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Michael Howard Studios, 152 W. 25 St., NY NY. For information, Greenville Memorial home, Jersey City, NJ.

In Nasdaq trading, the shares of Digital Insight rose 12.5 cents, to $46.50. 1View will continue to operate in San Francisco, as a division of Digital Insight.

description: Carl C. Icahn reached an agreement yesterday with the Nabisco Group Holdings Corporation that will allow him to see the company's books and solicit partners for his $4.7 billion takeover offer. In return, Mr. Icahn agreed to drop his proxy fight for control of the Nabisco Group's board. The Nabisco Group which owns 80.6 percent stake in the cookie and cracker maker Nabisco Holdings. Last week, the Nabisco Group, based in Parsippany, N.J., invited Mr. Icahn to work with its financial advisers a day after he offered to buy the company for $16 a share. title: Yesterday's Orchard, Today's Dot-Com Target
description: Emily Mann's adaptation of ''The Cherry Orchard'' at the McCarter Theater here opens in somber fashion, with a violin solo in the discordant contemporary mode and the image of a young boy tossing a ball up and down behind a screen so he appears almost as a silhouette. The ball -- it must be a balloon -- rises and falls in watery slow motion; the boy is Grisha, the drowned son who lingers in the memory of his mother, Lyubov Ranevskaya, the haplessly sad-hearted landowner in the throes of heartbreak and disenfranchisment in Chekhov's last play.

title: Intel Adds Phone Products

Picazo makes hardware and software to combine different telephone system functions onto the same computer platform.

Brothers, Sidney and Jack. Robert resided both in NYC and Athens. He wrote for the Atlantis, Hellenic Star and Greek American and other publications. A member of the Overseas Press Club. title: GTE INCREASES PLANS FOR CAPITAL SPENDING
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its capital spending plan to enable the Genuity unit, formerly GTE Internetworking, to accelerate building its network infrastructure. The project will require capital expenditures of up to $2 billion in 2000 and between $11 billion and $13 billion over five years, the company said. Spending will rise by about $1 billion in 2000. Genuity also filed for an initial public offering of its shares. GTE said its expected its acquisition by the Bell Atlantic Corporation to be completed this quarter. Converting Genuity to a public company is part of the proposal to the Federal Communications Commission for completing the merger. Shares of GTE, based in Irving, Tex., closed at $72.5, down $2.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Blame in the Chinese Embassy Bombing
description: Nearly a year after the American bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during last spring's NATO air war against Yugoslavia, the Central Intelligence Agency has done its part to investigate and punish those who were responsible for the disastrous mistake. The question now is whether the Pentagon and NATO will look as squarely at their own roles. While the C.I.A. made the pivotal error that misdirected the bombs, military commanders failed to review the agency's target selection adequately.

title: Saving Light, or What?

title: What Children Do When Home and Alone
description: Twelve to 14 percent of American children ages 5 to 12 spend some time home alone after school, a new study has found, but the period without adult supervision averages only an hour, most of the children are older, and many seem to welcome a measure of privacy and independence.

title: LAW FIRM MERGER TALKS
description: As consolidation within law industry continues throughout Europe, Britain's fourth-largest law firm, Freshfields, said it was in negotiations to merge with Bruckhaus Westrick Heller Loeber, a firm in Germany. Freshfields, which worked on some of the largest transactions in Europe last year, is seeking a foothold on the Continent. If the two firms merge, the combined company would have a total of 1,850 lawyers. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Happy Birthday, James, And Hello Again, Dizzy
description: A benign ghost hovered over the celebration of James Moody's 75th birthday (which was actually March 26) at Avery Fisher Hall. The concert was as much a tribute to Dizzy Gillespie as it was to Mr. Moody himself, and rightly so. Mr. Moody played saxophone in Gillespie's groups in the 1940's and 60's. As he joined Gillespie in the bebop revolution, he soaked up Gillespie's disarming stage manner, using cornball comedy to ease audiences into bebop's convolutions.

title: Drug Prices and Medicare
description: The Department of Health and Human Services issued a report yesterday that highlighted alarming disparities in prescription drug costs for Medicare beneficiaries. The Medicare recipients who lack drug coverage are charged significantly more -- and are thus forced to do without medicine more often -- than Medicare recipients who have obtained drug coverage one way or another.

title: Philippines Set to Privatize Power Company

title: The Cuban-American Heartland, Northern Chapter
description: Eyes wide with rage, their voices raw from shouting, the graying Cuban exiles marched through the streets last week carrying posters of Elian Gonzalez, votive candles and American or Cuban flags. Some wept as they chanted ''Libertad para Elian'' while others nearly hissed as they offered unkind words for Fidel Castro. Mostly Cuban-born, a number of them former political prisoners, the 200 or so demonstrators had come from across the metropolitan area to add their voices to the louder, more potent outcry from their compatriots in South Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEITZER, DOROTHY C.
description: SCHWEITZER-Dorothy C. of Wayne, PA., formerly of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. on April 9, 2000 in her sleep, after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Martin. Devoted mother of Seth, Lawrence (Beth), Sarah Leah, & Jane (Douglas). Adored grandmother of Aaron, Eric, Jenny, Emily, Benjamin and Max. Dorothy Schweitzer was professor emerita of anatomy and physiology at CUNY for twenty years and at Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing for ten. She previously taught biology at Brooklyn College. She published pharmacology research at CIBA and helped develop techniques in micromanipulation that ultimately led to cloning. She was an award-winning orchid grower and president of the Long Island Orchid Society. But most important to Dorothy Schweitzer were her four children, who all grew up to be successful professionals. Her triumphs over calamities, bureaucracies, setbacks, and illness are too numerous to mention here, but helped shape our characters and ethical standards. To us, she was the gold standard, a brilliant, take-charge woman to the end, yet always humble about her talents. Funeral services are on Tuesday, April 11th at 12 noon, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Treatment, Not Cure, For Coach Of Yanks

The disease is considered incurable, with most patients surviving only three or four years after diagnosis. But in recent years, new treatments have prolonged patients' lives several years, and there are promising new therapies on the horizon, experts said.

title: Saving Colombia
description: I had a chat in Bogota the other day with a group of government officials and businessmen, and I asked them all one question: When you go outside, how many security guards do you take with you? The answers were: 20, 6, 1, 8, 10, 2, 3, 8 and 5. No surprise. Some 3,000 people were kidnapped here last year by guerrillas, and many judges and journalists threatened with chilling messages, such as having funeral wreaths sent to their homes -- with their names on them.

title: The Thrill of Live Faces, the Whiff of Blind Nostalgia
description: The impact was in the close-ups. When the naked television camera came in tight on Richard Dreyfuss or Brian Dennehy, when their anguished faces filled the screen and their characters' souls filled your heart, then it was clear that the drama transcended the stunt. In those moments the CBS adaptation of ''Fail Safe,'' broadcast live to much of the country on Sunday night, lived up to its billing as an event. It proved that this medium's intimate immediacy is an underused asset waiting to be exploited in the service of compelling storytelling.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS TO SELL DOCUMENT SERVICES UNIT
description: The Reynolds & Reynolds Company, which provides information management systems to the automotive and general business markets, said yesterday that it would sell or spin off its document services unit and focus on the automotive retail systems business. The Information Solutions Group accounted for about half of Reynolds's revenue of $1.56 billion in 1999. Shares of Reynolds, which is based in Dayton, Ohio, rose 25 cents, to $27.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Reynolds provides document and information services to 90 percent of the car dealerships in North America.

title: Reginald Laubin, 96, Performer Of Authentic Plains Indian Dance
description: Reginald Laubin, who performed dances of American Plains Indians in the 1930's, 40's and 50's, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Urbana, Ill. He was 96 and lived in Urbana and in Moose, Wyo.

description: KURSHAN-Charlotte, peacefully in her sleep on April 10th, 2000 after celebrating her 82nd birthday. Survived by her husband Norman, daughters Nancy and Louise, and grandchildren Rosa, Michael, Nicholas and Sally.

title: As Columbine Anniversary Nears, G.O.P. Leaders Push Through Gun-Crime Bill
description: Conceding vulnerability on a hot campaign issue, House Republican leaders today sent to the floor a popular gun-crime bill, written by Republicans, and passed it so they would have something to show before next week's anniversary of the fatal shootings at Columbine High School.

title: Bad Tax Cuts Inside Good Bills
description: Congress is trying to push through unfair, damaging tax provisions by attaching them to two popular bills, one designed to raise the minimum wage, the other to protect patients in managed care. The bills have passed both Senate and House and are headed for conference. None of the tax provisions deserve to survive.

title: ELECTRICITY INCREASE SUSPENDED
description: Itamar Franco, the former president of Brazil who is now the governor of Brazil's state of Minas Gerais, suspended the federally authorized 12 percent rate increase by the state's partly privatize electric utility, Companhia Energetica de Minas Gerais. Mr. Franco, whose defiance of federal decrees played a role in Brazil's economic crisis last year, has consistently opposed the privatization of electric power in the country. Under his suspension order, the state utility must first study on how the higher charges would affect the poor. Simon Romero

title: FIRSTAR PLANS SHARE REPURCHASE IN LIGHT OF EARNINGS
description: The Firstar Corporation, the 13th-largest United States bank, said yesterday that it planned to buy back 100 million of its shares in the market, deploying some $2.5 billion in excess capital. The bank, which is based in Milwaukee, reported its first-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, exceeding expectations, as it reaps new business and cost savings from its takeover of Mercantile Bancorp last year. The bank said first-quarter operating earnings rose to $342.4 million, or 35 cents a diluted share, from $297.3 million, or 29 cents, a year earlier.

title: Lobbyist Apologizes
description: Ralph Reed, a senior consultant to Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign, apologized for lobbying the governor on behalf of Microsoft and promised not to lobby him again on behalf of Microsoft or anyone else. The Bush campaign, irritated to learn that Mr. Reed was also lobbying the campaign behind the scenes, said he ''made the right decision.''

title: Breast Cancer Is Pinpointed By ZIP Code
description: The State Health Department today published breast cancer rates by ZIP code for the entire state, the first time such widespread mapping of a cancer has been produced in such detail.

title: Draft of U.S. Report Is Said to Fault City's Policing
description: The staff of the federal civil rights commission that held hearings into New York City's policing practices plans to offer a draft report of its findings that is sharply critical of the Police Department, according to two people familiar with the report.

title: Sports of The Times; A Green Ship Lost at Sea Once Again
description: TWO years ago, someone on the good ship Jets shouted: ''Land, Ho!'' Maybe Bill Parcells called land; maybe it was Leon Hess. In any event, for long-suffering Jets fans, this Promised Land was a sight for sore eyes: the Super Bowl was close.

title: Metro Business; Big Push for Bonds Lets City Cut Yields
description: New York City was able to cut yields yesterday on its sale of $577 million in bonds through its Transitional Finance Authority as the securities drew strong demand from a supply-starved market.

description: WADE-Joan Kehoe, on April 11, 2000. Beloved wife and best friend to Peter H. Wade; cherished mother to Kevin, David and Tim Wade, Jennifer Garrity, and Laura Farley, who were at her side when she died. She also leaves behind her dear sisters Anne Hollrock and Mary Marbach, and was preceded in death by her parents John and Theresa Kehoe, and her brother Roy. Others deeply saddened by her loss include her daughters-inlaw Sasha, Jeannie and Janine, her sons-in-law Joe and Tom, her eighteen adoring grandchildren, and her countless friends. Reposing at Horn and Thomes Funeral Home in Pawling, N.Y. on April 13. Funeral Mass at 11 am on April 14 at St. John The Evangelist R.C. Church, Pawling, N.Y. ''May your days be filled with love and laughter, and may the last voices you hear be ours.'' And so it was. God Bless Joan.

title: Payton Could Benefit From Injuries for Once
description: Tom Robson has seen it happen before. A player spends too much time in the weight room, and his upper body swells. Instead of using the physical ''core'' -- the abdominal muscles and hips -- as the source of his movements, a player starts swinging with his upper body. His flexibility gone, the player cannot make adjustments, and his overall skills diminish.

title: Across Buenos Aires, a Tango With Empanadas
description: IT is not that I didn't expect to try empanadas during a visit to Buenos Aires, but rather that I never guessed they would become an obsession. I had eaten empanadas, those crisp, flaky half-moons of pastry puffed with savory meat fillings, in other parts of Latin America and at home in New York. I wondered how much better they would be in the country that seems to have the grandest passion for them.

title: Catholic High Holdout Will Make Room for Girls
description: Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens, with its century-old traditions, is a throwback to an earlier era of Roman Catholic education: neatly uniformed boys in blue or white dress shirts sit shoulder to shoulder in tight rows in classrooms and at lunchroom tables.

title: Albee Takes His Disappearing Baby to Houston
description: In Edward Albee's new play, ''The Play About the Baby,'' which opens on Wednesday at the Alley Theater, a young married couple have a baby and soon find themselves bedeviled by two strangers, an older man and woman. Eventually the child disappears. Truth? Illusion? What happened to the baby? As usual, Mr. Albee leaves it to the audience, except to say, yes, there was a real baby.

title: Omnicom takes another seemingly fearless step to expand its interactive empire.
description: IN another step to expand an already extensive interactive empire, the Omnicom Group in New York is investing in an innovative agency that specializes in creating offline campaigns for online marketers.

title: A Salute to Clive Davis, Ousted at Arista Records
description: Clive Davis, the beleaguered chief executive of Arista Records, celebrated the 25th anniversary of the label he founded with performances by some of its best-known acts on Monday night at the Shrine Auditorium here. The ceremony stretched from three hours to an audience-wearying six so that it could be taped properly for broadcast on May 15 on NBC. Among those performing were Santana, Sarah McLachlan, Toni Braxton, Puff Daddy, Barry Manilow, Alan Jackson, Patti Smith and Whitney Houston.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a lobbying campaign by Microsoft misstated the company's explanation at one point for hiring Century Strategies, Ralph Reed's firm. As the article noted, a Microsoft spokesman said Century Stategy's specific aim was to counter a lobbying campaign against the company being waged by its competitors. The spokesman did not say that its aim was to curry favor with Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Tandoori In a Flash
description: THERE are two ways to think of tandoori chicken. Strictly defined, it is chicken marinated in yogurt and spices and cooked in a tandoor, a clay oven that is most often used to bake bread. But you can also think of it as chicken in a yogurt and spice sauce that is simply broiled.

title: ABC News Using DiCaprio Work
description: After deliberating for days over whether to use it at all, ABC News announced yesterday that it would show some of an interview of President Clinton by the actor Leonardo DiCaprio in a special on the environment.

title: CHINESE SLUMP MAY BE ENDING
description: A slump in foreign investment in China appears near an end, according to figures published by a state-owned newspaper. The publication, the International Business Daily, said contracted foreign investment -- investment deals signed but not yet implemented -- surged to $2.8 billion in February, up 17.4 percent from a year earlier. Craig S. Smith

title: Doubts About Tape Spur Plea Deals in Officer's Shooting
description: The trial of four men accused of the attempted murder of a police captain in 1996 ended before it began yesterday, with three defendants pleading guilty in deals that will allow them to go free almost immediately. All charges were dropped against the fourth man after prosecutors said that it appeared that a tape on which it seemed he had implicated himself and the other defendants had been faked by a police informer.

title: Relatives to Give Cuban Boy To His Father, Officials Say
description: The relatives of Elian Gonzalez, the 6-year-old Cuban boy at the center of an international custody battle, decided today to turn him over to his father here on Wednesday, government officials said tonight. But later the boy's great-uncle said in Miami that the meeting was off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIM, PETER
description: KIM-Peter. The students and families of the fifth grade class at The Allen-Stevenson School mourn the untimely passing of Peter Kim, beloved father of our dear friend and classmate, Justin. We extend our prayers and heartfelt sympathies to the Kim family.

title: Group to Challenge Suspension Of Kindergartners in New Jersey
description: A conservative legal group said yesterday that it would challenge the school district in Sayreville, N.J., for suspending four kindergartners who pretended to shoot at other students on the playground by aiming their fingers at them.

title: With New Hope, Adelphi Welcomes President
description: Adelphi University, once a battleground where students and professors warred with administrators, was a decidedly calmer place today as it welcomed its new president.

title: NCR ACQUIRES CERES INTEGRATED IN A $90 MILLION DEAL
description: The NCR Corporation, a former computer maker that now develops database software, said yesterday that it had bought Ceres Integrated Solutions for $90 million in cash and stock. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Ceres provides software and other customer relations services. Ceres will be folded into a new unit called NCR CRM Solutions Division, which will store customer databases for its clients. NCR is also taking over Ceres's 25 percent equity stake in Acxiom Corporation, the largest builder of databases for direct marketing.

title: Curtains for a 2nd Season Of Lust, Death and Ziti
description: Meadow may be going off to college, but she's still Daddy's little Mafia princess. The second season finale of ''The Sopranos'' (to be repeated tonight at 9 and Saturday night at 12:15 on HBO) may have focused on the death of Big Pussy, who had spent the season wearing a wire for the F.BI. and weeping in Tony Soprano's bathroom about his betrayal. ''You were like a brother to me,'' Paulie Walnuts said, before he and Tony and Silvio shot Pussy and dumped him in the ocean. (They made sure they removed his diamond horseshoe-shaped pinkie ring first.)

title: Tin Tin, a Rhino, Meets a Monkey, and ...
description: A monkey and a rhinoceros fall in love in ''Animal Magnetism.'' It is in every sense a wild affair for an hour and a half. But they come to a bad end, which, violent as it is, is shockingly funny.

description: He has received the likes of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, bearing comfort for the spirit, and Vicki Martin of Madison, Wis., bearing cheese for the stomach.

title: CISCO TO BUY THE REST OF PENTACOM FOR $118 MILLION
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the global leader in networking for the Internet, said yesterday that it would buy the privately held Pentacom Ltd. for about $118 million in stock. Pentacom, based in Herzliya, Israel, makes products using Spatial Reuse Protocol, which doubles bandwidth -- or data transfer capacity -- in metropolitan Internet networks. The acquisition follows an 11 percent investment in Pentacom in June 1999. Cisco said it expected a one-time write-off of up to 1 cent a share for purchased in-process research and development expenses. Shares of Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., fell $2.5625, to $70.

title: MANAGEMENT: A Tale of Muscle and Morale; Why Home Depot Employs Olympic Athletes
description: When the Olympic Games open in Australia this summer, about 30 athletes will represent Egypt. Sixty will make up the contingent from Turkey. Eighty will run, jump, swim and play for Ireland.

title: Lebanon Chafing as Syria's Partner
description: A huge billboard faces the hotels that line the seafront here. It shows a smiling President Hafez al-Assad of Syria with his arms outstretched like a welcoming host. ''We did not create the bond between Syria and Lebanon,'' he is saying. ''God did.''

title: Prosecutors and Defenders May Get Student Loan Relief
description: On most days, John M. Ryan, a senior prosecutor in Queens, and Susan L. Hendricks, who oversees criminal defense lawyers for the Legal Aid Society, make their living on different sides of the courtroom.

title: Going Out Blazing
description: Demonstrating that it is not just a critical favorite but an out-and-out hit television show, ''The Sopranos'' reached a new ratings high for its season finale on Sunday night, pulling in more viewers than any other original entertainment program in the history of HBO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINKLER, STEFAN, M.D.
description: WINKLER-Stefan, M.D. April 2. Born Gleiwitz, Germany (Poland), to Guenther and Berta Winkler, March 18, 1933. Fled to Cuba, 1939. Settled in Astoria, NY, 1945. Holocaust survival led to life commitment to social justice. Graduate of Cornell University, Tufts Medical School. Radiologist 30 years Madison, WI, VA., and UW hospitals. Researched cerebral blood flow with MRI. Intelligent, kind and compassionate. Survived by sisters Maja Gorland and Helga Schwartz, wife Marjorie Green, children Anne, Michael, Daniel, David and their families.

description: Britain's biggest cement maker, Blue Circle Industries, said it would buy back stock worth as much as $:800 million ($1.3 billion) in a last-minute attempt to fend off a hostile bid of $5.4 billion from Lafarge S.A.

title: SUPPORT FOR BANK EXECUTIVE
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Bank, Rolf Breuer, left, has the ''total support'' of the bank's supervisory board chairman, Hilmar Kopper, the management board said in a memo to the bank's German employees. Mr. Breuer has been under pressure to resign after the planned $29 billion takeover of a smaller rival, Dresdner Bank, collapsed last week. Mr. Breuer's counterpart at Dresdner, Bernhard Walter, has already resigned.

title: A Steady Hand at 110 Livingston
description: City Hall and the New York City Board of Education should welcome the news that Harold O. Levy, the interim schools chancellor, is willing to serve beyond his initial contract, which expires on June 30. Since he assumed the job in January, Mr. Levy has made a good start toward managing and reshaping a bureaucracy that has historically resisted change. Strong leadership is always important. But continuity will be especially crucial over the next two years, a period that will bring a new mayor to City Hall and as many as five new faces to the Board of Education itself.

title: Man and His Son's Slayer Unite to Ask Why

The return address was a post office box in Norfolk, Mass., near Boston where, Mr. Gibson knew all too well, there is a state prison.

title: INSO SHARES DROP AS COMPANY ANNOUNCES REVAMPING
description: The shares of the Inso Corporation shares fell almost 40 percent after the company, the maker of electronic-business software, ruled out a sale of the company and said it would sell all but its DynaBase Internet publishing system unit. Inso shares fell $3.9375 each, to $5.96875. Its shares have fallen 81 percent this year. The company's DynaBase unit makes text-conversion software that companies can use to publish information online. The Boston-based Inso also said Stephen Jaeger, 55, would resign as chief executive and Kirby Mansfield, 45, would step down as president and chief operating officer as it reorganized its management. The company will close its headquarters next month and consolidate operations in Providence, R.I., where its eBusiness Technologies unit is based.

Microsoft bought the entire 60 percent stake in Titus Communications held by the United States cable television company MediaOne Group, according to Yoichi Hiraoka, a Titus spokesman. Financial terms were not disclosed though reports last year said Microsoft was prepared to pay close to $1 billion for the stake. Japan's former telephone monopoly, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, has dragged its feet on offering low-cost access to the Internet.

title: An Indian Place Takes a Few Liberties With Tradition
description: HERE are two things you almost never see in Indian restaurants: pork spareribs and a dining room decorated in a zebra-skin motif. Diwan's Curry House, which opened recently on the Upper West Side, has them both.

title: Charity Promises Sweeping Changes After Review
description: Acknowledging for the first time that its organization lacked proper oversight, the charity Operation Smile notified its chapters last week that it was enacting sweeping changes at the suggestion of an outside lawyer retained by the organization to review its conduct. The changes are aimed at addressing criticism that arose last year over the charity's management and the quality of its medical care.

title: SONY PLANS BROADBAND SERVICE
description: Taking another step toward transforming itself into an information technology and network company, the Sony Corporation announced plans to begin offering corporate clients broadband Internet access over a wireless telecommunications system this summer. The service, initially aimed at small- and middle-size businesses, will be introduced in July in major metropolitan areas like Tokyo, Osaka and Nagoya. For a basic rate of 70,000 yen ($654) a month Sony's clients will be able to send and receive data using a broadband telecommunications networks operating at a rate of 1.5 megabits a second. Stephanie Strom

title: PROXICOM ACQUIRES A BRITISH WEB CONSULTING COMPANY
description: Proxicom Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the British company Clarity IBD Ltd. for $72.8 million in stock and cash. The purchase combines two companies that help other companies set up and run online businesses. Proxicom, which is based in Reston, Va., said the deal would expand its presence in Europe, allowing it to serve international customers with local consultants. Proxicom had $82.7 million in revenue last year and has a market value of $2.4 billion. Its stock dropped $2 a share, to $42.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Ethan Allen Going a Bit West for Its Flagship Store
description: For many furniture retailers, a comparatively low rent that permits a large display area is crucial to success. So Ethan Allen Interiors, the manufacturer and retailer of home furnishings and furniture products, has leased 20,000 square feet way west in Manhattan, far from the usual retail-chain haunts.

title: With Clean Slate, Teams Face Off for a Polished Cup
description: Hockey people like to think that players and teams can redeem a bad or mediocre regular season with a good showing in the Stanley Cup playoffs. In this spirit, perhaps the National Hockey League as a whole can use the tournament, which begins tonight, to burnish an image left smudged by some events of the 1999-2000 season.

title: A Year After a Death in Police Custody, a Man's Family Still Seeks Answers
description: A year to the day after a man died in police custody following the slaying of a police officer here, his family and supporters gathered outside Police Headquarters tonight to express frustration with the pace of an investigation into his death.

title: Two Boys Are Held in Rape Of Girl, 9, at a Harlem School
description: Two 12-year-old boys were arrested on Monday and charged with raping a 9-year-old girl inside a Manhattan public school, hours after she was coerced into sex in the same spot with an 11-year-old boy, who was also arrested, a police official said.

title: Fund Manager Resigns as Tumult Grows
description: Frank P. Slattery V, who had a phenomenal first year as a manager of the PBHG New Opportunities Fund but then stumbled over the last month amid market turbulence, resigned yesterday and said he would pursue other opportunities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNUNU, VICTORIA DADA
description: SUNUNU-Victoria Dada passed away on April 10, 2000 at her home in Gulf Stream, FL. Mrs. Sununu was born in San Salvador, El Salvador on Sept. 17, 1912 and was a longtime resident of Forest Hills, NY until 1979, when she and her husband John moved to Gulf Stream, FL. ''Toya'' was the mother of Governor John H. Sununu of New Hampshire, Dr. Alexandra Sununu of New York City and Charles Sununu of Gulf Stream, FL. She was also the grandmother of Congressman John E. Sununu of Bedford, NH, 11 other grandchildren and 5 great grandchildren. Mrs. Sununu was a devoted member of St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church in Delray Beach, FL. Friends may call on Wednesday April 12, 2000 from 2 PM to 4 PM & 6 PM to 8 PM with a 7:30 PM scripture service at the Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, 745 N. Federal Highway, Delray Beach. A funeral mass will be celebrated on Thursday April 13, 2000 10:30 AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church, 840 Geroge Bush Blvd., Delray Beach. There will also be a funeral mass on Friday April 14, 2000, 11:30 AM at St. Matthew's Catholic Church in Windham, NH with interment at Pine Grove Cemetery, Salem, NH. Memorial gifts may be made to St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church Delray Beach, FL or St. Mary's Antiochian Orthodox Church, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Latin Cuisine, Abundantly Explained
description: Mr. Rodriguez knows how to put on a show. At Patria, he brought a highly distinctive brand of Latin to Manhattan, a sexy, seductive reinterpretation of South and Central American cuisines that managed to be sophisticated, exotic and fun all at once. At Chicama, which takes its name from a Peruvian coastal town, he's operating in a slightly more casual setting, and the menu has a breezier feel to it. It also reaches out to newcomers, offering the definition and pronunciation of unfamiliar words like tiradito and anticucho, or even quite familiar ones like ceviche. The urge to clarify enters a manic phase, however, in the recitation of the daily specials. Mr. Rodriguez uses many, many ingredients, and the waiters list each and every one, in mind-numbing performances that had me drifting off at the halfway point.

title: All Boats Rise. Now What?
description: Thanks to the economic boom, and despite much hand-wringing to the contrary, there are signs that America's rising income inequality that began in the early 1970's is finally in remission.

title: Flawed Election in Peru
description: Peru's presidential election reeks of fraud. This is not surprising, given President Alberto Fujimori's disdain for democratic principles, but even he should recognize that the balloting irregularities invalidate the re-election victory he is eager to claim. There must be a new, independently monitored election.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN I was a child, I would spend Sundays in my grandmother's kitchen in Toulouse, watching her prepare dinner on a coal-burning stove. In fact, seeing her take command of those meals was one of my first inspirations to become a cook.

title: Gefilte Fish: The Next Generation
description: FOR almost 80 years, first in Russia and then in America, Dora Solganik of Cleveland has been performing the gefilte fish ritual for Passover: schlepping to the fish market, choosing the best fish ''by the look in its eyes,'' and transforming it into the quintessential Seder dish. Using a wooden bowl and a half-moon-shaped chopper, she cuts up the fish with onions, crying a little, chopping a little, until her mix is just the right consistency. Then she molds it into oblong patties. Every year she makes 25 pounds, and this year, her 94th, is no different.

title: Reckonings; No Tipping, Please
description: More than 20 years ago I fell in love, as young social scientists will, with nonlinearity -- and in particular with the idea that large effects could have small causes. I was inspired by the economist Thomas Schelling's classic little 1978 book ''Micro motives and macrobehavior,'' with its illustrative models of how seemingly trivial individual concerns (such as a mild desire to have some neighbors similar to yourself) could lead to extreme social outcomes (such as complete racial segregation). And I dreamed of a theory of everything -- of fashions and fads, booms and slumps, economic miracles and social catastrophes.

title: Swiss Holocaust Sentence
description: A Swiss man who denied that the Nazi gas chambers existed was sentenced today to a year in jail for violating a 1995 law that makes it a crime to ''deny, grossly minimize or seek to justify genocide or other crimes against humanity.'' Prosecutors said the man, Gaston-Armand Amaudruz, had denied, in books and in a magazine, the existence of Nazi gas chambers, and insisted that the killing of six million Jewish civilians during World War II was impossible. ''For my part, I maintain my position,'' said Mr. Amaudruz, who was convicted in Lausanne after a three-day trial. ''I don't believe in the gas chambers.''

title: S3 SHIFTS ITS FOCUS TO HAND-HELD INTERNET APPLIANCES
description: S3 Inc. said yesterday that it was shifting its focus from making chips to making hand-held Internet appliances. As a first step, S3 agreed to sell its majority stake in its graphic chip joint venture to the Taiwanese chip maker VIA Technologies Inc., the other partner in the venture, for $323 million in cash and stock. S3 will keep a a minority stake in the venture, which was formed in November. S3, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has been involved in making graphic chips since 1989. It will now concentrate on making noncomputer devices that have Internet connections. The company already sells Rio, a digital music player, and HomeFree, a portable device that allows multiple computers in a home to share an Internet connection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNSTEIN, LILLIAN HERLANDS
description: HORNSTEIN - Lillian Herlands, Professor Emerita of English, Washington Square College, New York University died on April 10, 2000 at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital. Beloved wife of the late George D. Hornstein, Professor of Corporation Law, NYU. She was predeceased by her brothers, Hon. William B. Herlands (Federal Judge, Southern District of New York) and Hon. Herbert S. Herlands (Superior Court, Orange County California). She is survived by her brother, Dr. Robert E. Herlands of Stamford, CT, sisters-inlaw, three generations of adoring nieces and nephews and a legion of appreciative students. Prof. Hornstein was a distinguished scholar, teacher and renowned literary critic of Medieval Literature during a 50 year career at NYU. Her rare talents as educator, researcher, author and administrator were recognized by NYU in conferring their Distinguished Teacher Award and Presidential Citation of Achievement, among other numerous accolades. Funeral service will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, Wednesday, April 12, 2000, at 1P.M.

The producer and director, Eyal Sivan, has compiled and assembled black-and-white footage of the trial of the SS officer and war criminal Adolf Eichmann, and his film is the grimmest possible precursor to the occasionally frivolous ''Court TV,'' which plays on the current fascination with watching the judicial process grind exceedingly slow, and exceedingly fine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, ROBERT LINCOLN

He also served as Treasurer of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. A funeral service will be held Friday, April 14, at 11 a.m. at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, P.O. Box 100, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724 in memory of Dorcas O. and Robert L. Cummings.

title: Sometimes the Station Pulls Away From the Train
description: ''I start with a world,'' the Italian architect and designer Massimo Iosa Ghini said about the way he designs things like curvy buildings and aerodynamic sunglasses. His wife and associate, Milena Mussi, explicated his explanation. ''Massimo never does a single object, but starts far away from it, making a lot of drawings of an environment the object might belong to,'' she said. For instance, when he was asked to design a new subway station for the Kropcke stop, above, in Hanover, Germany, he first invented a host city for the station: a futuristic urban landscape that he drew, then converted (via computer) to wall-size glass mosaic murals in light greens and yellows. He updated the station, designed in harsh 70's concrete, with four subfloors joining 10 subway lines with the main train station, in time for Expo 2000, the World's Fair that opens in Hanover on June 1. To further uplift the station, Mr. Iosa Ghini bounced light off ceilings, calmed the acoustics, improved maintenance (consulting with the cleaning company), gave the floors more friction and designed aluminum furniture and fittings to look dynamic.

description: MANGIARDI-Dr. Joseph Leonard age 82, of Timber Ridge Drive, Cashiers, North Carolina, died Wednesday, April 5th, 2000 in the Highlands-Cashiers Hospital. He was born in Brooklyn NY, the son of the late Dominic and Marie Mangiardi. He was a retired cardiovascular surgeon and a World War II Major and army surgeon. Dr. Mangiardi, the first cardiac surgeon on Long Island, New York, was a member of numerous medical and surgical societies. He was involved in the development of cardiac bypass, mitral valve replacement, and Dacron materials for vascular replacement surgery. He was a graduate of Fordham University and the Long Island College of Medicine. Dr. Mangiardi was Chief of Surgery and Cardiovascular Surgery at Winthrop University Hospital, (formerly Nassau Hospital) in Mineola, NY. He is survived by his former wife Patricia Pearson Mangiardi of New Smyrna Beach, FL; four daughters, Denise Mangiardi of New Orleans, LA, Celeste Mangiardi of Morrison, CO, Sharon Pearson of Newport, RI, and Maureen Mangiardi of New York, NY; five sons, Gerard Mangiardi of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, Eugene Mangiardi of Anchorage, Alaska, Dr. John Mangiardi of New York, NY, Robert Mangiardi of Los Angeles, CA; a sister, Terry Crofton of Long Beach, NY; and 12 grandchildren. The family received friends at the Bryant Funeral Home Chape in Highlands, NC on April 7th. Funeral services were held Saturday, April 8th at St. Jude's Catholic Church in Cashiers, NC. There was a brief service on April 11 at the Macken Funeral Parlor, in Rockville Centre, LI followed by burial at the Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, Long Island.

My son and his friends usually worked two or three times a week for about three to four hours per shift, with one or two shifts after school and one or two on the weekend. This practice started several years ago in response to requests by kids who wanted odd jobs to make a few extra dollars. Soon there was a waiting list for the jobs.

This ceramic Seder plate has no subtitles. But there are pictures. And the underside has instructions in English for the uninitiated, in case the pictures are not clear enough. A ceramic matzo plate decorated with a realistic rendering of a perfectly baked matzo square completes the holiday set, by Williams-Sonoma's New York design team. The Seder plate is $128, and the matzo plate $68, at Williams-Sonoma stores; store locations are available through (800) 541-2233. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Where Walls Once Stared Blankly, New Faces Peer Out
description: Houston Street has become a low-tech, ad hoc version of Times Square. Both signal an aesthetic crisis: big pictures -- whether built in, painted on or hung like banners -- have become more engrossing than the architecture that holds them up. That is especially true around Houston and Broadway, one of the ugliest parts of downtown. Ever since Houston was widened for subway work, the street has been plagued by empty space: blank brick side walls, gas stations, parking lots. But now, huge perforated banners and painted wall murals have arrived to make Houston Street feel less like an expressway, more like a town square -- complete with graffiti, the most ancient form of outdoor advertising.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN INFLATION DOWN
description: Mexico's inflation fell in the first quarter to 2.8 percent, the lowest rate since before the 1994 peso crisis, according to Guillermo Ortiz, the head of Banco de Mexico, the central bank. The inflation decline, which Mr. Ortiz predicted would continue throughout 2000, was helped by a strong peso and a fall in the prices of fruits and vegetables. A central bank survey of private sector analysts shows they now predict 9.67 inflation for this year, below Mexico's goal of 10 percent.

The production of ''The Year of the Baby'' by Mr. Long at SoHo Rep -- buoyed by 3 Foster songs and 10 or 11 other lyrical efforts that draw laughter when they threaten to plunge into hums and mumbles -- draws on several comic and satirical traditions from the era when Foster was selling songs to New York producers 150 years ago.
