title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DLUGOSZEWSKI, LUCIA
description: DLUGOSZEWSKI - Lucia. The 92nd Street Y mourns the loss of composer and choreographer Lucia Dlugoszewski, who, with her husband, Erick Hawkins, created an entirely new vocabulary of music and movement that stretched the boundaries of modern dance performance. After Hawkins' death in 1994, Dlugoszewski took the reins of The Erick Hawkins Dance Company, making her choreographic debut at the 92nd Street Y in 1999, as her husband had done in 1942. She died just as the company was beginning its second season at the Y under her direction, premiering the stunning ''Motherwell Amor.'' After the company performed last year, the New York Times called Dlugoszewski a modern dance choreographer of exceptional promise, while Dance magazine proclaimed that the Hawkins legacy was in good hands. The 92nd Street Y is honored to have provided a platform for her unique art. She will be missed. Sol Adler, Executive Director, 92nd Street Y Joan Finkelstein, Director, 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Center

title: Let Buildings Be Humane, Not Hollow

Franck and R. Bianca Lepori (John Wiley & Sons, $49.95), is for those who believe that architecture can be meatier and livelier, more human, less machine-made. Sure it's obscure. The authors write in a mild tone that soft-pedals their radical premise that architecture ought to be profoundly different. The message is that real profundity occurs only when you stop being so detached -- enough with the grids, already. (Above, from the book, the antigrid Shonandai Cultural Center, Fujisawa, Japan.)

title: Kicking and Moaning, the Louvre Goes Primitive

Five years ago President Jacques Chirac expressed the view that what was long called primitive art should have a permanent place in the Louvre Museum. The Louvre protested heatedly that it was not a universal museum, that specialist collections should be housed elsewhere. On Thursday, Mr. Chirac will open four newly renovated galleries of the Louvre dedicated exclusively to art from Africa, Asia, Oceania and the Americas.

title: SPECTRASITE PLANS TO EXPAND IN FLORIDA AND CALIFORNIA

Lodestar owns and operates 90 wireless towers and 10 broadcast towers in major markets, including Los Angeles and Orlando, Fla. The company, a unit of the Ontario-based LeBlanc & Royal Enterprises, also has 149 towers under management, mostly in Florida, and plans to develop 202 wireless towers nationwide. SpectraSite, based in Cary, N.C., owns 3,000 towers in 98 major markets. SpectraSite's shares fell $1.50, to $20 each, in Nasdaq trading.

Things that are hilarious to the mid-18th-century citizen do not necessarily survive a change in context, so it is worth noting when a stage piece meant to make listeners smile in 1745 can do very much the same two and a half centuries later.

title: Why Proust? And Why Now?; 2 Biographies Shed New Light on an Author Who Never Seems to Go Out of Style
description: Poor Proust! Lying in bed in a soundproof room swaddled in layers of wool, gasping with asthma, trying to recapture with words the lost sensation of his mother's kiss. But like Einstein, Marcel Proust was, in his own way, a theorist of time and space. ''An hour is not merely an hour,'' Proust wrote, ''it is a vase full of scents and sounds and projects and climates.''

title: VIATEL ACQUIRES STAKE IN TRANS-ATLANTIC CABLE SYSTEM
description: Viatel Inc., a provider of telecommunications services in Europe, agreed to buy a 25 percent stake, valued at $150 million, in a trans-Atlantic fiber-optic cable system being built by Level 3 Communications Inc. The accord gives Viatel access to the system connecting Europe and the United States, which is expected to be operating by September. New York-based Viatel's current network links 59 major European cities. Level 3, based in Broomfield, Colo., offers services in 27 United States markets. Shares of Viatel, which have lost more than a third of their value this year, fell $3.50, to $34.4375, in Nasdaq trading. Level 3 fell $12.5625, to $69.3125.

title: The Yankees Find a Victory Blowing in the Wind

Then they dispersed to their dugout for the first home game of the 2000 season, a revised roster facing new problems and obstacles, starting all over.

The tableware turns up at places like Ritz-Carlton and Four Seasons hotels, where chefs like the way the etched surface holds arty blobs of sauce. Pieces range from $20 to $50. IntelleSale sells new and used computers to businesses through the Internet and traditional retail channels. The combined company will be called IntelleSale.com. Applied Digital, based in Palm Beach, Fla., offers electronic business consulting services.

description: BILLOWS-Raymond E. Age 85, of Poughkeepsie, New York, on April 10, after a short illness. Beloved husband of Lynn VanBenschoten Billows. Loving father of Raymond, Jr. of LaGrangeville, NY and Barbara Tilles of Rye, NY, 3 stepchildren, 4 grandchildren, Ross and Mark Billows, Scott and Amy Tilles and 7 step-grandchildren. Mr. Billows was predeceased by his first wife, Elinor Jaminet Billows, and his sister, Marie Sewell Baily. He served in the U.S. Army during WWII. He was a retired sales executive with Western Publishing and a well-known amateur golfer. He reached the finals in the U.S. Amateur Championship 3 times, won a record 7 NY State Amateur Championships, was a two-time member of the Walker Cup Team and scored a hole-in-one in the 1940 Masters. He was a life member of Dutchess Golf Club and an inaugural member of the Dutchess County Golf Hall of Fame. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, April 14, 10 AM at St. Mary's Church, Poughkeepsie. Conexant, which is based in Newport Beach, Calif., and was once a unit of Rockwell International, makes semiconductor products used in communications electronics. Philsar is based in Ottawa.

As negotiations with Syria have stalled, and with Israel's July deadline for withdrawal from Lebanon nearing, Mr. Barak has sensibly shifted his attention to reaching preliminary agreement with the Palestinians on a peace deal. His four-hour meeting with President Clinton Tuesday night should help energize this new negotiating push.

Nitres is developing brighter, more efficient diodes. The deal, which was completed on Tuesday, is expected to close by the end of next month. As a result of the acquisition, Cree will take a charge of about $3.5 million in its fourth quarter, which will end in June. Nitres, which has operations in Westlake Village and Goleta, Calif., will become a unit of Cree, which is based in Durham, N.C., and it will be renamed the Cree Lighting Company. His early assertion that preservation is a popular, non-elitist pursuit, changed the way the movement was perceived and led to its current stature. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, MICHAEL P.
description: McLAUGHLIN-Michael P., a Darien resident since 1985, died suddenly in New York City on April 11, 2000. He was 49. Born January 12, 1951 in Brighton, MA, he was a son of Mary Driscoll McLaughlin of Marshfield, MA., and the late Gerald F. McLaughlin. Mike was raised in Brighton and graduated from Boston College. He was a Certified Public Accountant and a member of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and The New York Society of Certified Public Accountants. He was a partner with KPMG Peat Marwick which he joined in 1972. He left KPMG in 1983 for two years to become a Professional Accounting Fellow at the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington, D.C. He rejoined KPMG and was the lead partner for many of the firm's multinational clients. Mike was a resident and two-time president of Noroton Bay, he was also a past King of the Bay. He was a member of the Country Club of Darien. Mike was a avid golfer and also enjoyed sailing and fishing with his family. Mike was a founding member of the Board of the Obie HarringtonHowes Foundation. He was instrumental in forming the foundation after his friend Obie was paralyzed in a swimming accident. The foundation raises money for his friend and others with spinal cord injuries. Mike was the loving husband of 28 years of Nancy and the devoted father of three daughters, Meghann, Missy and Erin, and a son, Michael, all of Darien. In addition he is survived by two brothers, Gerald of Newton, MA and Paul of Scituate, MA and a sister, Mary Ellen Bradford of Ducksbury, MA. For information Lawrence Funeral Home in Darien. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Obie Harrington-Howes Foundation, P.O. Box 2221, Darien, Connecticut 06820.

But the intensity the Devils employed in the early stages evaporated, and they barely held on for a 4-3 victory over the Florida Panthers tonight at Continental Arena.

title: Delay Granted In Extradition Of Colombian
description: The son of a murdered Colombian senator will have to wait another month to find out whether he will be the first Colombian drug-trafficking suspect extradited from the United States under a treaty his father helped to write. Federal prosecutors sought and were granted a 30-day extension in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIE, JACK
description: LURIE-Jack. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Ellen and Brian Steklof, Ed and April Lurie, Bill and Susan Lurie. Cherished grandfather of Lisa and Eric Steklof, Elizabeth, Daniel, Jonathan and Korina Lurie. Mr. Lurie was the CEO of the Republic Lens Company in Englewood, New Jersey. He was a graduate of Cornell University. Services were held on April 14, 2000.

title: Playing It Safe Hasn't Helped Elian
description: So the ultimatum was given, and Elian Gonzalez is still not with his father. The Justice Department ordered that the 6-year-old boy be reunited with his father by 2 p.m. yesterday. But his family in Miami, which has the boy in its care, appealed to a federal appeals court, which granted a temporary stay.

title: Searching Death Row For Pithy Metaphors
description: ''Coyote on a Fence,'' Bruce Graham's coldly analytical drama about two prisoners bound for execution, has timed its New York premiere well. Illinois recently suspended its death penalty, and Tennessee is preparing for its first execution in 40 years. The relevance alone makes this Urban Stages production provocative theater that stirs the mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, URSULA M.
description: MURPHY-Ursula M. On April 13, 2000. Beloved daughter of the late Arthur H. and Mary Elizabeth Murphy. Loving sister of Sr. Catherine V. Murphy, S.C. and the late Arthur H., Elizabeth V., Mary M. Henze, John E., and Charles F. Also remembered as a devoted aunt, great-aunt, relative and friend. Reposing Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10AM at Convent of Mary the Queen, Yonkers. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Reed Gets Things Set Up Nicely And Mets Just Follow His Lead
description: Rick Reed has been rewarded with a victory only once this season, but each time he has pitched, he has lifted the Mets.

title: Slicing Off Mountaintops
description: Mountaintop removal is a type of coal mining, common in West Virginia, that requires exactly what its name suggests, the removal of a mountaintop to get at the coal seam lying beneath. The ''overburden'' -- a mining engineer's term for the earth above the coal seam -- is blasted and scraped away by enormous machines and dumped down the sides of the mountain into hollows and streambeds. This type of mining has the virtue of ruthless efficiency. It is highly mechanized, requiring relatively little manpower. But it also has the defect of ruthless efficiency. It buries streambeds and everything living in and around them in tons of rubble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICOLETTI, ROBERT V.
description: NICOLETTI-Robert V. While serving on the USS Sylvania, he received a National Defense Service Medal. He earned a Ph.D. in Economics from NYU. A talented econometric model builder, he recently was the chief economist at the NYC Office of Management and Budget. Viewing at Krtil F. H., 1297 1st Avenue at 69 St., Friday, April 14, 2-5PM & 7-9PM, Saturday, April 15, 9:30AM. Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66 St., Saturday, 10:45AM.

title: FORD PLANNING TO SPIN OFF AUTO PARTS DIVISION
description: The Ford Motor Company will announce today that it is filing paperwork with the Securities and Exchange Commission for spinning off Visteon Automotive Systems, its sprawling auto parts division. Ford plans to distribute 100 percent of Visteon's shares to Ford shareholders in a long-expected deal that is likely to be completed by midsummer. Visteon has $19 billion a year in sales, of which $17 billion are to Ford. Peter J. Pestillo, a vice chairman for Ford, will run Visteon as its chairman and chief executive. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on April 5 about Air France's decision to have its pilots speak English to air traffic controllers when approaching Charles de Gaulle Airport near Paris misattributed a statement denouncing the action as scandalous. It was made by Louise Beaudoin, Quebec's minister of intergovernmental affairs, not by the province's premier, Lucien Bouchard, who visited France last week. (Air France suspended the order last Thursday.)

title: A Rift Repaired
description: Two panels that form a 14th-century altarpiece by the Italian master Nardo di Cione are being reunited for the first time since 1851.

title: Home Videotape Becomes Networks' News of the Day
description: The Elian Gonzalez story officially moved to the level of total media frenzy yesterday, with all-news cable channels devoting their entire day's coverage to the situation in Miami, and even the three broadcast networks interrupting programs at noon to cover live the news conference of Attorney General Janet Reno.

title: 'Quantum' Leap To the Internet
description: One of the film's producers compares it, in historical importance, to the release of ''The Jazz Singer,'' the first talking motion picture. Its distributor says it harks back to the earliest days of the movie business, when nickelodeons were giving way to movie palaces whose owners were forced to produce their own films to insure a steady stream of flickering images for the new mass audience.

title: Sky Surveyors Find the Most Distant Object Ever Detected
description: Astronomers working on a vast survey of the heavens have discovered the most distant object ever detected, a fiery, reddish dot called a quasar that emitted its light less than a billion years after the universe was born.

title: Cleveland's No. 1 Pick: It's Brown (or Arrington)
description: The Cleveland Browns negotiated in New York yesterday with an agent for Penn State defensive end Courtney Brown and had talks scheduled for this morning with an agent for Penn State linebacker LaVar Arrington, said the Browns' president, Carmen Policy.

title: Foreign Affairs; Parsing the Protests
description: Washington is now playing host to protests against the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, globalization and free trade. If this were a baseball game, someone would sell programs to help follow the action. Here's how mine would read.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Briefing column on April 2 about the presidential campaign of Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate, understated his standing in the polls. At the time, polls showed his support at 3 to 5 percent of voters, not 1 percent.

title: Heroin Chic? Not in the Slightest
description: There are close-ups of needles and open sores on the junkies who populate a drug-saturated neighborhood in HBO's tough mini-series ''The Corner.'' More important, there are vivid individuals within each of those damaged bodies.

title: Summers Says Growth Is Trade Gap Solution
description: The best way for the United States to reduce its trade deficit is for Europe and Japan to increase growth, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said today.

description: ROSOW-Ethel. The Board of Directors of the United Hebrew Geriatric Center mourns the passing of Mrs. Ethel Rosow, beloved mother of Patricia and Malcolm Lazarus. As the esteemed Chairman and Past President of our Board, Malcolm Lazarus has been a leader and ardent supporter for many years. Our heartfelt sympathy and prayers are extended to the bereaved family. Donald Duberstein, President Rita C. Mabli, Exec. Vice President

description: Palm (verb): To play a trick, to cheat.

title: G.E. Reports Strong Revenue In First Quarter
description: General Electric, benefiting from resurgent global economies and its push into e-commerce, announced robust first-quarter revenue and earnings yesterday.

title: Endgame for Elian
description: Despite all the legal twists and emotional turbulence, the outcome of the Elian Gonzalez case should not be in doubt. He must and will be returned to his father's custody, and the federal government has the authority and power to enforce that resolution. The question before Attorney General Janet Reno, the two branches of the Gonzalez family and the people of Miami is how to make the transfer as painless as possible for the young Cuban boy. Yesterday's appellate court order temporarily barring his return to Cuba, while not directly related to the issue of his return to his father, helps to give everyone involved a few hours or days to search for a compassionate resolution.

title: That Dressage Is a Snap, if You Happen to Be a Horse
description: I have never been mistaken for a horsy type, particularly not by horses, which have tended to flatten their ears at my approach and swing their hindquarters around to try to land a good swift kick. They have often, I am sorry to say, succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, MICHAEL F.
description: DONOHUE-Michael F. April 10, 2000. Beloved husband of June Ann. Loving father of Michael, Jessica, Richard, June and Maureen. Cherished grandfather of 12. Devoted brother of Donald, Mary Clark of Maryland and the late Jack and the late Martin. He was the proprietor of Donohue's Steak House & Cafe for over 50 years. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Thursday & Friday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday April 15, 9:30 am St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Interment at Good Ground Cemetery, Hampton Bays, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to SloanKettering Hospital, NYC.

title: Times Co. Profit Is Up 35% On Strength in Advertising
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 35 percent, largely because of strong advertising growth at its flagship paper, The New York Times, and at The Boston Globe.

title: Track in Derailment Recently Cleared Test
description: As subway tracks go, the stretch beneath the wheels on the left side of the northbound No. 5 train Wednesday evening was relatively new, having been replaced in 1993.

title: Opening A Folio Of Faberge
description: Sometimes you can find buried treasure in your own library, as a show now at the Manhattan gallery A La Vieille Russie proves.

title: A Psyche in the Trenches, Bombarded by Life
description: C.R.W. Nevinson is often cited as the premier ''war artist'' of Britain and the term, odd as it sounds today, is apt. This is not only because Nevinson's greatest prominence has come from his grimly honest, formally rigorous scenes of World War I, which he painted in a distinctive hybrid of Futurism and realism. Perhaps more to the point, Nevinson (1889-1946) seems rarely to have been at peace, either with himself or the world.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro edged lower after the European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged, disappointing some investors. In New York, the euro settled at 95.42 cents, down from 95.67 cents on Wednesday.

title: FedEx Worker Charged In Girlfriend's Killing
description: A Federal Express employee at Newark International Airport fatally stabbed his girlfriend, a coworker, early yesterday morning when she tried to break off their relationship, and then ran to a New Jersey Turnpike toll plaza and confessed, the police said.

title: Serbia's Bickering Opposition Plans Rally Against Milosevic
description: Serbia's political opposition, superficially united after months of squabbling and pressure from the West, will hold a major political rally here on Friday but with no hope of pushing President Slobodan Milosevic out of power anytime soon.

title: Leader's Party Gains Seats in South Korean Vote, as Do Rivals
description: Buoyed by a diplomatic breakthrough with North Korea, this country's governing party picked up additional seats in mid-term parliamentary elections held Thursday.

title: Frank Jewett Mather III, 89, Developer Of Tagging System for Big Ocean Fish
description: Frank Jewett Mather III, a scientist who developed the first tagging program for large open- ocean fish, died on March 27 in Falmouth, Mass. He was 89.

title: Where a Crime Fighter Has to Be One Mean Dude
description: About half of the dialogue in ''Third World Cop,'' which opens today at Cinema Village, is accompanied by subtitles, in case viewers have trouble deciphering the characters' Jamaican accents. This is thoughtful but unnecessary, since the film's true idiom is the universal language of cop-movie cliche.

title: Giuliani Blames Democrats for U.S. Inquiry Into Police
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday accused the United States Civil Rights Commission of being ''a political operation of the Democratic Party'' and suggested that an unfinished commission report that is said to be highly critical of the New York City Police Department was meant to help the Senate candidacy of his political opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Having Fun Yet, Jazz Babies?
description: ORGIES are getting such a bad name these days. Those nasty pagans in the old Cecil B. DeMille movies at least got to enjoy their fleshpots before being squashed beneath the almighty heel. But from the sinister, group-grope soirees of ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' Stanley Kubrick's film about the joylessness of sex, to the blood-letting menage a trois of the current ''American Psycho,'' hard-working debauchees are being presented in ways that make Oliver Cromwell look like Mr. Happiness.

title: Mark Dion
description: Bonakdar Jancou Gallery

title: Woman and Son Charged In Bilking of a Hotel
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have charged Sandra Lynn Bennie of Sykesville, Md., and her son, Seutter von Loetzen, with posing as ambassadors to the United States Mission to the United Nations and running up $30,000 in hotel bills.

title: A New Age Protest Tackles Globalism With Polite Chants
description: Starbucks stayed open, keeping the latte flowing hot and thick as the global economy protesters turned the corner and made for the place to the syncopation of a bongo drum.

title: Sports of The Times; Sweep Up The Deck: Start Lucas
description: BRYAN COX was right on the money the Jets wouldn't pay Keyshawn Johnson when the linebacker went on television and charged them with contender's negligence, the act of trying to rebuild before they've collapsed. In the span of three-plus months, the organization has lost its head coach, defensive guru and game-breaking receiver. The Jets will go to training camp this summer with a rookie head coach and an uncertain front office under a brand-new owner.

title: Singer Joins Protesters and Calls for Calm
description: For Spanish-speaking pop fans, and particularly Cuban-Americans, Gloria Estefan is a symbol of perseverance and crossover success: proof that a Cuban-American immigrant can become an international music star.

description: Politics in Peru

title: Lawmakers In Japan Hear Grim Sex Case
description: In a jolt to the entertainment industry, a lawmaker peppered government authorities today with questions about how they had dealt with accusations that Japan's leading talent agent had sexually abused teenage boys he was grooming for stardom.

title: A Chorus of Alleluias and Glorias Herald Easter Season
description: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted (churches accept donations). This selection, compiled by the critic Paul Griffiths, represents what caught his eye and excited his expectations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.

title: House Clears Bill to Curb Plans for FM
description: Prodded by the nation's largest broadcasters, the House overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would curtail ambitious plans to open the FM airwaves to hundreds of new low-power stations for churches, community groups and schools.

title: Ventures Started At Two Agencies
description: Two agencies are undertaking new ventures.

title: H & M PROFIT FALLS
description: Europe's second-largest retailer, Hennes & Mauritz of Sweden, said its first-quarter net income fell 12 percent on costs for its expansion into the United States and Spain. The company, which has opened three stores in the New York area, said profit fell to 435.8 million kronor ($50.3 million) from 493.2 million a year earlier. It warned last month, when Fabian Maanson resigned as chief executive, that pretax profit fell to 670 million kronor from 759 million. Yesterday, that was revised to 670.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, JOHN J.
description: BARRY-John J. The Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of God's Love We Deliver are saddened by the loss of John J. Barry, beloved husband of the Honorable Maryanne Trump Barry, and devoted brother-in-law of Blaine Trump, Vice Chair of our Board of Directors. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Barry family and hope that loving memories of John will help ease their sorrow during this sad time.

title: A Safer City for Gays
description: To the Editor:

title: Unwavering Scrutiny of the Being Within the Skin
description: Novelty is one of the demands we make on living artists. An artist who sticks to a course for any length of time we tend to say has fallen into a rut. If the artist works in an old tradition, then he is an academic or a commercial entertainer, unless he nudges the tradition somehow or puts it in quotation marks, ironically, as if to say, ''Nothing is new any longer, and I am making this fact the subject of my art'' -- a strategy that is itself not exactly novel. Diaghilev wanted novelty when he famously asked to be astonished. Novelty is regarded as a value.

title: Nielsen Releases Local Internet Data
description: The first monthly data on Internet use in the 20 largest local markets from Nielsen Net Ratings, an Internet measurement service, show interesting variations among different parts of the country.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- No public appearances

title: FILM REVIEW; Volcanic Dad and the Seven Kids: Cheeky, Arty, Mindful, Creepy ...
description: As played by Om Puri, George Khan, the owner of a fish-and-chips shop in a gritty-genteel red-brick section of Manchester, is like an immovable object. ''East Is East,'' Damien O'Donnell's screen version of Ayub Khan-Din's play, explores what happens when George meets the irresistible force of modernity, as embodied by his seven unruly children and the strange country, England in 1971, in which he's trying to raise them.

title: Burrowing Down Deep In a Rough Bit of London
description: In the London art world of the last 20 or so years, a place of his own has been reserved for Leon Kossoff, a painter who was born in east London in 1925. For all practical purposes he has never left there, except from 1945 to 1948, when he was attached to the 2nd Battalion of the Jewish Brigade, which served in the British Army in Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany. He has dug deeper and deeper into the richness of experience that he had acquired from just one section of a great city and the nearness of just a handful of people.

title: In Draft, Opposites Get the Same Praise
description: This is Penn State linebacker LaVar Arrington. He is believed to be one of the only players to pat Coach Joe Paterno on the rear end. He once told an Ohio State offensive lineman: ''You will need divine help to block me today.'' He talks a lot. He leaps over tall players, punishes running backs and beats up on helpless kickers. He boasts that he is a better player than Florida State's Peter Warrick. He's probably right. He's been called ''LaVar Arrogant'' because of his brashness. That's right, too.

title: Some Enticed by Dot-Coms Now Have Second Thoughts
description: The recent tumble in technology stocks hasn't just unnerved investors -- it has made some employees in the thick of the dot-com whirlwind look warily over their shoulders.

title: Judge's Ruling Bars Contracts In Welfare Plan
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday blocked the city from awarding $104 million in contracts to a Virginia company chosen by the Giuliani administration to spearhead its landmark welfare-to-work programs, ruling that there was ''compelling evidence that the contracting process has been corrupted.''

title: President Gretzky? A Possibility in Rangers' Front Office
description: The Rangers' first priority is to hire a new general manager. At the same time, they are exploring the possibility of persuading Wayne Gretzky to become the team's president, according to a National Hockey League executive.

title: People
description: * Alan M. Waxenberg, executive vice president and publisher at Victoria, New York, part of Hearst Magazines, is retiring on April 30 after 23 years as publisher of five Hearst magazines. A successor has not been named. Mr. Waxenberg also headed Good Housekeeping, Motor, Redbook and Sports Afield.

title: W. Bruce Lincoln, 61, Expert Who Enlivened Russian History
description: W. Bruce Lincoln, a historian known for his gripping books about Russians and their history, died on Sunday at Kishwaukee Community Hospital in DeKalb, Ill. He was 61 and lived in DeKalb.

title: Goalies Off the Mark? Bure Foiled? Really?
description: In the hockey playoffs, the first game does not necessarily mean much in terms of who wins a series. The loser has time to adjust strategy and change momentum. But openers are filled with subplots that become major themes as two teams get familiar.

title: PROMINENT INTERNET EXECUTIVE QUITS
description: Nina Brink, chairwoman of World Online International, the Netherlands-based Internet access provider, resigned after shareholder anger over the disclosure that she had sold most of her shares in December, well before World Online went public last month. World Online said Ms. Brink had resigned ''in the interests of the company'' and would be replaced by its vice chairman, Simon Duffy. The shares have lost more than half their value since they were sold at an offering price of 43 euros, or $41.30, on March 17.

title: Giorgio Bassani, Novelist of Italy's Fascist Era, Dies at 84
description: Giorgio Bassani, the author of the classic modern novel ''The Garden of the Finzi-Continis,'' died today in the San Camillo hospital in Rome. He was 84.

title: Elle's Top Editor Will Lead Yaddo
description: Elaina Richardson, the editor in chief of Elle magazine, has been named president of Yaddo, the artists' community in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., its board announced yesterday. She will replace Michael G. Sundell, who is retiring.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: FedEx Employees Arrested in Drug-Ring Raids
description: Drug traffickers used a network of Federal Express drivers and couriers to ferry more than 120 tons of marijuana from California to the East Coast over the last two years, federal drug officials said yesterday.

title: From Druckman's Scores, A Celebratory Sampling
description: Springy with vitality and passion, the music of Jacob Druckman is unlikely to stay put on library shelves. Still, it is good to know that his scores and sketches are being looked after by the Public Library, and it was very good of that institution to present a concert to celebrate the acquisition. Quite a concert it was, too, with 20 of the city's finest musicians at Cooper Union on Monday evening.

title: Reissue of Gore Book May Be a Two-Edged Sword
description: Vice President Al Gore's 1992 environmental credo, ''Earth in the Balance,'' is being reissued next week in conjunction with the 30th anniversary of Earth Day, and Republicans say they could not be happier.

description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first drug to treat the most serious form of the disease that is the leading cause of blindness in elderly people.

description: A FUNNY thing happened to a leading creative executive on his way to San Francisco. He is instead heading about 340 miles south.

description: In an effort to strengthen its slumping stock price, British Telecommunications announced a wide-ranging plan today to reorganize into a half-dozen units and spin off its Yellow Pages business, with hopes of spinning off still other units as separate companies.

title: Mosquito Program Favors Prevention Over Pesticide Use
description: New York City has decided not to spray malathion, the pesticide it used against mosquitoes last year, in its campaign to prevent another outbreak of West Nile virus, and to use helicopter spraying only as a last resort.

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL BUYING STAKE IN SEQUOIA
description: Analysts International said yesterday that it planned to acquire 80.1 percent of Sequoia, an Auburn Hills, Mich., Internet services company, for $43.5 million in cash. The closely held Sequoia, which had revenue of $57 million in 1999, provides Web application development, electronic-business services and integration services. Sequoia's current management team will hold the remaining 19.9 percent interest in the company. Minneapolis-based Analysts International, which reported $596.6 million in revenue for the last 12 months, provides information-technology services.

title: Hartford Passes Bill Limiting Treasurer's Role in Investment Decisions
description: After two days of partisan wrangling, the Connecticut General Assembly passed a bill today that would significantly limit how the state treasurer makes investment decisions.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR CLIMBS. Sugar rose as Brazil, the world's biggest grower, withheld supplies from the world market to lift prices. In New York, sugar for July delivery rose 0.18 cent, or 3 percent, to 6.21 cents a pound.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

description: The physicist Richard Feynman, a Nobel Prize winner who died in 1988, was known as one of the great iconoclasts and original thinkers of the 20th century. description: The editor of one of America's best-known English-language Jewish newspapers, The Forward, announced his resignation yesterday after a dispute over content with some of the paper's owners, who demanded that he be fired.

title: First Lady Moves to Improve Relations With Jewish Voters
description: On Wednesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton hastily ended a news conference in a Rochester suburb so she could fly back for an unannounced meeting with Jewish leaders in Manhattan. The day before, the first lady called one of the city's leading Orthodox Jewish leaders, Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn, while he was visiting his father in the hospital to offer words of sympathy and arrange a meeting about her Senate candidacy.

title: Taking a Wagging Baton And Beethoven in Stride
description: Itzhak Perlman has taken up conducting in recent seasons and has accepted a position as principal guest conductor of the Detroit Symphony starting in 2001. In New York, a performance of the ''Nozze di Figaro'' Overture during a concert with the Israel Philharmonic last season left a generally favorable impression, but was not a lot to judge by. On Saturday evening Mr. Perlman offered a more complete picture of his progress on the podium when he led the New York Chamber Symphony in an all-Beethoven program.

title: Um, Just One O' Those Springs
description: It had the best reviews of the fall, a classic score by Cole Porter, and two glowing stars-in-making, Brian Stokes Mitchell and Marin Mazzie, wowing audiences nightly. So why isn't ''Kiss Me, Kate'' selling out?

description: Michael Parks, the editor of The Los Angeles Times, told his top lieutenants yesterday evening that he and the publisher, Kathryn S. Downing, would leave their posts after the completion of the sale of the newspaper's parent company, the Times Mirror Company, to the Tribune Company, editors briefed on the meeting said.

description: Republican and Democratic legislative leaders are nearing agreement on a plan to increase school aid by as much as $1.1 billion, according to their aides, setting the stage for the state's largest annual increase ever for education spending.

title: Containing Carter Is the Goal For Knicks
description: On every occasion this season, Vince Carter's total disregard of Latrell Sprewell's defense has unnerved the Knicks' hyper star to such a point that he has been too rattled for words.

title: Howard Simon, 37, Playwright Who Had Just Found Spotlight
description: Howard Simon, a playwright whose first major New York production opened on Sunday night, died on Wednesday at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 37 and lived in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Mrs. Clinton Suggests Bonuses To Attract More Teachers
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not make the morning announcements, patrol the cafeteria or give demerits yesterday when she acted as Principal for a Day at two Brooklyn schools. But she did tell students and teachers about her favorite education proposals, and she paid particular attention to students who asked how she would attract good teachers to New York City.

title: Agency Experts Open Way to Gene Search
description: Biologists at the Department of Energy have gathered raw DNA data sufficient to search for genes on three human chromosomes, Secretary Bill Richardson said yesterday.

title: N.Y.U. to Appeal Ruling On Grad Students' Union
description: New York University said yesterday that it had decided to ask the National Labor Relations Board to overturn a recent ruling that gave N.Y.U. graduate students who work as research or teaching assistants the right to unionize.

title: Nasdaq Gasps for Air, Then Faints Away Again, by 2.5%
description: A modest rebound in technology stocks vaporized in midafternoon yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index fell for a fourth consecutive day, dragging a broad swath of other shares down with it.

title: Waking Up the Butch Cassidy Inside Newman's Supposed Stroke Victim
description: ''Where the Money Is'' is a mild caper comedy that seriously trades on the audience's relationship to its star, Paul Newman, who makes one of the most unusual entrances in a movie this year. He is rolled into a nursing home, half his face paralyzed into a frown and his eyes -- once sparkling blue, now lusterless -- dead above those famous concave cheeks. His character, Henry, is a convicted bank robber whose salad days are behind him, and you can't look at him without thinking of the end of ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,'' where he played a good-natured rogue who outlived his usefulness. It's frightening, really, maybe one of the most daring gambits in a movie this year, certainly in the last couple of years (which is apparently how long this movie sat on a shelf before being released).

title: The $4 Million Colt Is Set for the Wood
description: His muscle tone is bulged and balanced -- so much so that when the colt runs, he looks like a perfect heart being pumped around the track by some unheard symphony. His conformation is nearly flawless, as his elegant but sturdy legs effortlessly skim the dirt. But Fusaichi Pegasus's most handsome quality may be his price tag.

title: Celebrating the Triumph Of the Human Spirit
description: Boris Eifman loves turbulent movement. For American audiences the most familiar expressions of this love are his flamboyant narrative ballets, and his Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg has already presented striking examples of this genre in a season that continues through Sunday at the City Center (131 West 55th Street, Manhattan).

title: A Gift of Life Bridges 2 Cultures and Families; After 8 Years of Letters, Brooklyn Rabbi Visits Italy and Meets the Boy He Helped
description: Ronald Barry, an Orthodox rabbi from Brooklyn, lay on an operating table eight years ago, as doctors extracted his bone marrow through scores of tiny punctures in his back. As a courier sped off with a cooler containing the jelly-like marrow for transplant to an unidentified stranger, the rabbi's wife, Miriam, slipped a letter inside.

title: They Don't Just Play Hockey Up There, Eh?
description: Some might call the ignorance of most Americans about political events north of the border a scandal. The general image of Canada here is a sedate neighbor that, except for its French-speaking population, is just like us. The joke behind the song ''Blame Canada!'' from the movie ''South Park, Bigger, Longer and Uncut'' is that there is nothing for which we can blame this polite serious country, the country that produced folk-rock artists like Joni Mitchell, Neil Young and Leonard Cohen. Now the Film Society of Lincoln Center has borrowed the song's title to label a 3-week, 31-film Canadian series, which opens today at the Walter Reade Theater.

title: The Evidence Arrives by Video: Knight Indeed Had a Choke Hold
description: When a former Indiana University guard named Neil Reed told CNN/SI last month that Coach Bob Knight choked him during a 1997 practice for not yelling out a teammate's name, the charge placed him against a powerful Hoosier icon.

title: MICROSTRATEGY SAYS IT IS UNDER S.E.C. INVESTIGATION
description: MicroStrategy Inc., a maker of data-delivery software, said yesterday that it was under formal investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission about its revenue figures, which it revised last month. The company, whose stock tumbled in late March after the revision, said the S.E.C. had notified it of the ''formal order of private investigation'' last month. MicroStrategy, based in Vienna, Va., yesterday changed its earnings results to losses for the last three years. MicroStrategy said it lost 44 cents a share last year, from net income of 15 cents; lost 3 cents a share in 1998, from earnings of 8 cents; and lost 2 cents a share in 1997, from breaking even. MicroStrategy's shares fell $3.4375, to $39.0625, compared with $333 in March.

title: Wake Up and Smell the Profits; A Singaporean Sees the World as His Coffee Cup
description: In the shadow of some dreary public housing developments, 16-year-old April Ong is whiling away another sweltering afternoon with friends at the Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf cafe, chatting about boys and nursing an icy coffee milkshake that cost the equivalent of $2.50.

Her innovative compositions and tireless dedication to the arts will continue to inspire many dancers, musicians and visual artists. She will be missed by us, and all who appreciate her unique spirit.

title: A Lengthy Weill Satire, Every Last Scrap of It
description: Kurt Weill's operetta ''Der Kuhhandel'' was a casualty of the turmoil in the Jewish composer's life in the months between his sudden flight from Nazi Germany in 1933 and his emigration to the United States in 1935. A satirical work about neighboring banana republics on an imaginary Caribbean island that are manipulated into war by a wily arms dealer, ''Der Kuhhandel'' was first conceived as a two-act operetta for the German theater, with a libretto by Robert Vambery. But when Weill took refuge in London in early 1935, he turned it into a disastrously received one-act West End musical comedy called ''A Kingdom for a Cow,'' the title referring to the plight of a young villager, Juan, whose only cow is confiscated by the government as payment of a new tax to support the war.

title: Murderer! Fiend! (But Well Dressed)

In adapting Bret Easton Ellis's turgid, gory 1991 novel to the screen, the director Mary Harron has boiled a bloated stew of brand names and butchery into a lean and mean horror comedy classic. The transformation is so surprising that when the movie's over, it feels as if you've just seen a magician pull a dancing rabbit out of a top hat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGEN, CAROLYN
description: HOGEN-Carolyn. Died peacefully on March 27 in Lenox, Massachusetts. A native of Cleveland, Carol graduated from Smith College in 1932. She married Charles ''Sonny'' Hogen, also of Cleveland, with whom she shared 66 years of marriage. She is survived by her adoring husband, their five children, Tim, Sherrill, Lyn, Robin and John, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. ''Nina'' was active in the Smith College Alumni Association for over 40 years and was a founder of the Mountain Valley Health Center, to which gifts can be made in lieu of flowers at Mountain Valley Health Council, Box 310, Londonderry, VT 05148. Her ashes will be buried in Peru, Vermont where Carol and Sonny spent their golden years.

title: Korea's Burden Of Unity
description: The news that North Korea and South Korea will hold a meeting in June is of course welcome. Yet I was struck by one issue on the agenda -- the reunification of separated families. I wonder just what will happen if these families, divided for more than 50 years, finally face one another. Although it would obviously be an occasion for joy, the prospect also brings with it painful and complex issues that no family may be able to overcome.

description: Funco, which sells new and used video games, has given Electronics Boutique Holdings five days notice to sweeten its $110 million buyout offer, or it will accept a higher bid from Barnes & Noble. Barnes & Noble, the largest United States bookseller, last week offered to pay $21 a share, or about $135 million, for Funco. That beat Electronics Boutique's bid, which was accepted April 3 by Funco. Barnes & Noble made the cash offer through its Babbage's Etc. unit. Shares of Funco rose 81.25 cents, to $20.8125.

description: The police broke up a demonstration today in Tiananmen Square by adherents of Falun Gong, the banned spiritual movement.

description: In the current restaurant boom, it's not always the big, flashy spots that make the most noise. Lately there's been an upsurge of small, quiet, carefully focused restaurants, like 71 Clinton Fresh Food, Eight Mile Creek and Tocqueville, that offer short menus and a highly personal point of view. Blue Hill, off Washington Square, is the latest in this group.

title: Cuban's Family Defies Reno; Court Issues a Stay

title: Committee Approves 'Contact' For Tony Award Consideration
description: The Tony Administration Committee voted yesterday to allow ''Contact,'' Lincoln Center Theater's acclaimed dance play, to be considered as a new musical, instantly making the show a favorite to win this year's Tony Award in that category.

title: SEPRACOR SHARES UP AFTER LICENSING APPROVAL
description: United States regulators gave clearance yesterday to an agreement by Sepracor, a biotechnology company, to license to Eli Lilly & Company an improved version of Lilly's antidepressant Prozac. Sepracor's shares rose $16.25 a share, to $85. The Federal Trade Commission action rejected a recommendation from its staff lawyers, who argued the agreement could undercut generic Prozac competition. The F.T.C. action will let Lilly sell Sepracor's version of Prozac, which may have fewer side effects than the original, and pay Sepracor royalties. Lilly could introduce the new Prozac in 2002, two years before the older drug faces generic rivals in the United States.

title: CHINA TELECOM NET FALLS
description: A company that operates mobile phone networks in six of China's richest provinces, China Telecom (Hong Kong), said its 1999 profit fell 30 percent because of a writeoff of 8.24 billion yuan on older network equipment. The China-backed company, headed by Wang Xiaochu, earned a net profit of 4.8 billion yuan in 1999, compared with a profit of 6.9 billion yuan in 1998. But it said its subscriber base grew robustly in the first quarter of 2000, swelling to about 18 million by the end of March, marking a faster monthly growth rate than 1999.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO BUY SPANISH COMBAT VEHICLE MAKER
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire ENSB, a Spanish maker of combat vehicles and munitions. The price was not disclosed. ENSB, a unit of state holding company Sociedad Estatal de Participaciones Industriales, will become a part of the combat systems unit of General Dynamics. General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., is a military contractor and manufacturer of business aircraft. It said it would invest $60 million in ENSB in the next five years.

title: Iran Postpones Trial of 13 Jews Accused of Spying for Israel
description: After a brief closed hearing, an Iranian judge today postponed the trial of 13 Jews accused of espionage in a case that is seen as a test of human rights in Iran and the strength of the hard-liners who control its judiciary.

title: PHOENIX GROUP TO SELL REMAINING DENNY'S RESTAURANTS
description: The Phoenix Restaurant Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its remaining 97 Denny's restaurants to various buyers. The deals are worth about $76 million, including cash and the assumption of debt and certain lease obligations. Phoenix Restaurant Group, the largest franchisee of Denny's restaurants, said it wanted to focus on its Black-eyed Pea restaurant chain. It owns and operates 93 Black-eyed Pea restaurants in eight states. The company said that the largest proposed purchaser of its Denny's restaurants is Huntington Restaurant Group of Scottsdale, Ariz.

description: A convicted robber who was recently released from prison for good behavior was charged yesterday with two subway robberies in the city, including one in which he is accused of holding a pistol to a toddler's head while demanding the mother's jewelry.

description: Early this year, when the presidential race was gathering steam, the reporters who covered Gov. George W. Bush flew in a different plane than he did, run by a company with a name just begging to be spoofed.

title: History in Court
description: For years David Irving, the controversial author of ''Hitler's War,'' has called himself a historian. But his real contribution to history, and to historiography, will be the libel suit he brought in London against Deborah Lipstadt, the American author of ''Denying the Holocaust.'' Under England's libel laws, Ms. Lipstadt, as the defendant, was required to prove that she did not libel Mr. Irving when she wrote that he ''is one of the most dangerous spokespersons for Holocaust denial.'' Her proof has been incisive and abundant, and this week she was rewarded with a telling victory.

title: Alcan Revises Its Blueprint For Giant Aluminum Merger
description: Alcan Aluminium of Canada abandoned plans to merge with Pechiney of France today, but said it still intended to acquire Algroup of Switzerland in a two-way deal.

title: Andre Deutsch, 82, Publisher Who Invigorated British Scene
description: Andre Deutsch, a Hungarian emigre who moved to Britain before World War II and parlayed his love of literature into an independent publishing house that bore his name, died on Tuesday at a hospital here. He was 82.

May the Almighty console the beareaved family with the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; By Some Measures, Highway Deaths Fall
description: THE preliminary statistics for highway deaths in 1999 are out, and they show substantial safety progress, if you look at them the way the Department of Transportation does. Looking differently at the same numbers, though, some safety analysts see stagnation.

title: DRESDNER EXECUTIVES REPLACED
description: Still reeling from the collapse of its $29 billion merger with Deutsche Bank, Dresdner Bank of Germany replaced three top executives. Dresdner announced the resignations of Gerd Hausler, head of the investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson; Ernst-Moritz Lipp, who oversaw corporate finance and corporate banking; and Andreas Bezold, who was in charge of risk management. Leonhard Fischer, head of asset management, will oversee investment banking, the main source of profits. In recent weeks, more than 100 executives have quit Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, and the bank is now guaranteeing bonuses to retain people. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

description: Most people are familiar with the Oscars, the Emmys and the Grammys. Now it's time for a new award: the BAMmys. And the jury will comprise some of the most demanding critics around: children.

title: Flag Compromise Resisted in South Carolina House
description: Even as the South Carolina Senate gave its overwhelming final approval to a compromise plan that would remove the Confederate battle flag from the State Capitol's dome, the bill ran into heated opposition today from black members of the state's House of Representatives, who said the flag's location in front of the building would be no less an affront to black citizens.

title: General Motors Says Profit Fell Slightly in First Quarter
description: General Motors announced today that its profits fell slightly in the first quarter as an unexpected turnaround in its international operations was not enough to offset unusually heavy discounting in the United States and rising costs at its Hughes Electronics subsidiary.

title: Newman's Opening Trick
description: In ''Where the Money Is,'' Paul Newman (above) makes his entrance in a wheelchair as an old bank robber paralyzed by a stroke. But looks are deceiving: before long, Mr. Newman has reverted to Butch Cassidy type, joining Linda Fiorentino in one more caper that is not the only daring move in Marek Kanievska's film.

title: When Heavy Breathing Is a Job Requirement
description: ''The Girl Next Door,'' Christine Fugate's melancholy documentary portrait of the porn star Stacy Valentine, suggests that the intersection of pornography and cosmetic surgery has given birth to a new genre of performer: the porn star as human approximation of an inflatable sex toy. With her platinum hair, fat-injected lips, breast implants and body planed by liposuction, Ms. Valentine doesn't look entirely real. Of course, that's probably the way her fans like it.

title: F.T.C. Approves Merger of BP Amoco and ARCO
description: The government approved BP Amoco's purchase of ARCO today, ending one of the most important antitrust cases in years and creating the third-largest oil company in the world.

title: The Conservative Approach to Pitching Is Taken With Pettitte
description: Andy Pettitte could have pitched Sunday against the Kansas City Royals. He could have taken the mound with the muscle strain below his left armpit and he may have pitched without aggravating the injury. But rather than risk having the nagging injury become something more serious, Pettitte was placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to April 8.

title: U.S. Commerce Secretary Postpones China Trip
description: Commerce Secretary William M. Daley has postponed a trip to China this weekend, apparently unable to round up enough members of Congress willing to accompany him on the politically sensitive visit.

title: Block by Block, a Wall Rises in Little Havana
description: Thousands of Cuban exiles, some faint from heat, others ablaze with conviction, poured into Little Havana here today, leaving work and school behind, to form a human wall around Elian Gonzalez's house.

title: Greenspan Says Investors Are Puzzled by Stock Woes
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that he views investors in the gyrating financial markets of the last few weeks as having been ''groping'' for the proper valuations of stocks, especially those of technology companies.

title: Doubts About the High-Risk Osprey
description: The V-22 Osprey aircraft is supposed to lift off the ground like a helicopter and fly like a plane. But the crash of an Osprey last weekend in Arizona, which killed 19 marines, raises fresh doubts about the viability of this politically popular but technically temperamental aircraft. Before billions of additional dollars are invested and more lives are put at risk, Defense Secretary William Cohen should appoint a panel of independent experts to review whether the Osprey is as mechanically sound and militarily advantageous as its champions assert.

title: A Genteel Land of War and Heroes
description: Present-day Virginia is a perfectly respectable state, but in Colonial times and through the early 19th century, Virginia was a powerhouse, unsurpassed in population, wealth, political influence and taste. Later, during the Civil War, it was the colossus of the Confederacy and the key battleground of the war.

title: Your Life's a Soggy Mess? Well, Thanks for Sharing
description: ''28 Days'' begins with such a flurry of promise that it comes as a sharp disappointment when this drug-rehab comedy skids out of control and begins to weave around as unsteadily as its central character does in the movie's opening scenes. Until that moment, about 40 minutes into the picture, the film follows its fast-living heroine, Gwen Cummings (Sandra Bullock), on a lurching pre-rehab joy ride that scarily evokes her life of reckless self-endangerment.

title: CENTRAL BANK LEAVES RATES ALONE
description: The European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged but made clear that an increase would be necessary to cool signs of inflation. Economic growth across the 11-nation euro region has accelerated in the last several months, but prices are climbing at nearly 2 percent a year, the upper limit of what the bank considers acceptable. The euro, Europe's common currency, slipped against the dollar on the news. The euro has fallen about 17 percent since it was introduced 16 months ago.

title: Album of the Week
description: FELA KUTI: ''Shakara/Fela's London Scene'' (MCA). For a foreign musician who didn't have a serious audience stronghold in the United States during his life, MCA's reissue program of Fela Anikulapo Kuti's 1970's and 80's records -- there will be 10 CD's by the end of the year -- borders on extraordinary.

title: Security Council Approves New Arms Inspection Agency for Iraq
description: The Security Council quickly approved a streamlined arms inspection commission for Iraq today. But Russia warned that it would be on the lookout for anyone named to the panel who might be troublesome to Iraq.

title: Large Crowd in Belgrade Heartens Yugoslav Opposition
description: At least 100,000 people jammed sunny central Belgrade today for an opposition rally demanding early elections to oust the government of President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: A Russian Affirmation of Arms Control
description: The belated ratification of the landmark 1993 nuclear arms reduction treaty by Russia's lower house of Parliament yesterday marks a decisive step in reversing the cold-war weapons spiral. The treaty, approved by the United States Senate in 1996 and now expected to be endorsed by Russia's upper house, will slice the number of nuclear warheads on both sides nearly in half from current levels. Its ratification should spur Washington and Moscow to intensify their efforts to negotiate substantial further cuts in the months ahead.

title: Many Voices Instead of One Big One
description: There's a big, torchy voice inside Shelby Lynne, but she doesn't show it off any more. At the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, she mostly sang in other tones: a drooping twang, a bluesy moan, conversational asides or the confiding delicacy of a jazz singer. Every so often, a phrase rose with a soul belter's affirmation or a down-home throb, only to fall to earth again. They were the voices of the people in her songs: women who have been let down or cheated by friends, lovers and life itself. ''Oh, life is bad,'' she sang with sly resilience. ''Oh no, worst I ever had.''

title: Steinbrenner Cannot Equal Katz's Control
description: Despite earlier reports that he was trying to do so, George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, cannot gain decision-making power equal to that of the Nets' principal owner, Lewis Katz, by buying out the team's minority owners.

title: The Molting of a Boy Band: 'N Sync Spreads Its Wings
description: Until last month 'N Sync was the second-banana boy band, seen almost universally as a Backstreet Boys knockoff. It had followed an accelerated version of the Boys' game plan: grooming by Trans Continental Management in Orlando, Fla., material from the same pop factories that serve the Backstreet Boys and Britney Spears and an album released first in Germany, yielding European hits and then a big American payoff. A 1998 Christmas album, ''Home for Christmas,'' garnered additional sales but not much more respect.

title: Conseco Lowers 1999 Profit 38%
description: The Conseco Corporation, which had said it would restate its 1999 profit because it was writing down the value of one asset, yesterday reported sharply lower profit and changed numerous figures from the numbers it had announced in February.

title: Stopping the World
description: In Washington this weekend, a disparate gathering of protesters will be rallying against what they view as the malign forces of economic globalization. The dissidents' message is sometimes confused and misplaced, especially in wanting to dismantle essential institutions like the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization. But the protesters, who call themselves the Mobilization for Global Justice, also represent a popular response -- misguided but heartfelt -- to a worldwide economic transformation that is not fully comprehended even by the experts. To be sure, some interest groups are trying to manipulate public concern for their own advantage. But it would be dangerous to ignore a growing popular unease over these trends and the need for broader educational efforts.

title: Putin Wins Vote in Parliament On Treaty to Cut Nuclear Arms
description: Vladimir V. Putin, in his first legislative initiative as Russia's elected president, today won approval of the long-delayed nuclear arms reduction treaty known as Start II from the lower house of Parliament. The landmark agreement, which was negotiated seven years ago, calls for cutting the American and Russian nuclear arsenals by half.

title: Health Care Coalition Readies Ad Campaign for Tougher Laws on H.M.O.'s
description: The coalition of hospitals and health care workers that persuaded the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki to adopt the most ambitious health care program in recent memory said today that it was ready to pump millions of dollars into an advertising campaign directed at health maintenance organizations.

title: ONLINE FINANCIAL DATA SERVICE MAY PUT ITSELF UP FOR SALE
description: The Track Data Corporation, an online financial data service, said yesterday that it had hired the investment banker Veronis Suhler to help advise the company on its strategic options, including a possible sale of the company. Track Data, which on Thursday canceled a pending 3-for-2 stock split, did not elaborate. Shares in Track Data fell $1.78125, to $3.59375, on Nasdaq. At the current price the company's stock is worth almost $230 million. Track Data, based in New York, provides financial data and analysis to institutional and individual investors. Veronis Suhler, also in New York, is a private merchant bank that focuses on media, communications and information.

title: Mayor and Wife Earned $413,155 Last Year
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his wife, Donna Hanover, released tax returns yesterday showing that they earned $413,155 last year, or nearly $100,000 less than in 1998.

title: Deal Reached on Bill to Help African and Caribbean Trade
description: House and Senate leaders have reached broad agreement on a bill to give African and Caribbean countries wide-ranging trade benefits intended to help their flagging economies by opening new markets.

title: SARD VERBINNEN PUBLIC RELATIONS AGENCY TO BE BOUGHT

Sard Verbinnen specializes in finance and advises companies on mergers and acquisitions. Incepta will pay $58 million initially. The rest of the payment will depend on Sard Verbinnen's financial performance the next five years.

title: B. F. GOODRICH TO CLOSE TEXAS FACILITY WITH 500 WORKERS
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company, a maker of aircraft parts and specialty chemicals, said it planned to close its landing-gear plant in Euless, Tex., eliminating 500 jobs. The facility, which will close in October, employs about 400 union workers and 100 in engineering, sales, marketing and administrative positions. The job cuts represent about 2 percent of the company's total worldwide work force of 27,000. Goodrich, which has struggled to stem declining profit, said in December that it planned to reduce its Euless operation, partly because demand for landing gear has declined. The company, based in Charlotte. N.C., had sales of $5.5 billion in 1999. Goodrich shares fell $2.1875, to $30.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mr. Adsit was 90 years old. He was in charge of Borrowings, Overseas Operations and Public Relations. Mr. Adsit was born in Baltimore, Maryland, the son of Dr. Henry Adsit and Peachey Polythress Brown Adsit. He spent his early years in Buffalo, New York, where he attended Nicholas School. Mr. Adsit is a graduate of Williams College in Williamstown, Massachusetts in 1930, with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics. He retired from GMAC in 1974 and divided his time between Lake Wales, Florida and Dorset, Vermont. Mr. Adsit is survived by his wife of 61 years, Harriet McNulty Adsit. Private service will be held in Florida. Friends may make contributions to Williams College, Williamstown, Massachusetts 012676, or the Good Shepherd Hospice, P.O. description: Tate & Lyle P.L.C., the world's biggest starch and sweeteners company, agreed yesterday to sell its United States grains unit to J. D. Heiskell & Company, a closely held concern in Tulare, Calif., for an undisclosed sum as part of its drive to shed poorly performing businesses. The sale includes five feed and grain milling facilities in California, Washington and Idaho that Tate & Lyle values at $58 million and should be completed by June. Proceeds will be used to reduce the company's debt. Tate & Lyle is cutting costs and restructuring its business as increasing supplies of sugar erode prices.

title: SOFTWARE MAKER E.PIPHANY ACQUIRES AN E-MAIL CONCERN
description: The business software maker E.piphany Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire privately held eClass Direct for $59.9 million in stock in a move to expand e-mail marketing services. EClass, based in Half Moon Bay, Calif., makes software used to send marketing messages by e-mail. E.piphany said it would transfer eClass's 30 employees to E.piphany's San Mateo, Calif., headquarters. About half of eClass's employees are engineers. E.piphany makes software used to collect and analyze customer and supplier transactions.

title: DUTCH RETAILER BUYS 51% OF ONLINE GROCER PEAPOD
description: Royal Ahold, the Dutch food retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 51 percent of Peapod, an online grocer, for $73 million. Ahold would initially acquire convertible preferred Peapod stock for $3.75 a share, representing 51 percent of Peapod's outstanding common stock. Ahold has also committed to a $20 million revolving credit line. Peapod's chief executive recently resigned and a group of private investors withdrew $120 million in new financing. Under the agreement, Peapod would continue as a stand-alone company and Ahold would supply Peapod with goods and services. Peapod, based in Chicago, had a loss of $29 million in 1999 on sales of $73 million. Ahold owns five supermarket companies in the eastern United States, including Stop & Shop and Edwards.

Citadel, which sells products and services to CompuCredit's Aspire Visa cardholders, can help the card company sell more products and services to cardholders, CompuCredit said. Shares of CompuCredit, which is based in Atlanta, fell $3.5625, or 10 percent, to $32.6875, on Nasdaq.

title: GERMAN UTILITY MERGERS STYMIED

The German Federal Cartel Office blocked RWE A.G.'s $4 billion purchase of VEW A.G., while the European Commission's competition panel blocked Veba A.G.'s $14 billion merger with Viag A.G. Both regulators are demanding that the companies let rivals have better access to their markets, and German officials want the companies to divest their holdings in local utilities. RWE said it remained in discussions with German officials and hoped to have an agreement by the end of June. Edmund L. Andrews

In March 1999, it settled in at Tonic for two weeks as an unplugged trio of piano (John Medeski), bass (Chris Wood) and drums (Billy Martin) and recorded a live album, ''Tonic'' (Blue Note). On Wednesday night, for the album's release, the trio started a five-night engagement, using primarily acoustic instruments (with Mr. Wood on electric bass at times), at the Angel Orensanz Foundation, 172 Norfolk Street, near Houston Street, on the Lower East Side.

title: A Sojourner In the Past Retraces His Steps; In a New Cultural History, Jacques Barzun, 92, Finds the West Decadent Though Not Hopeless
description: Before coming to the United States to begin his studies at Columbia University in 1923, Jacques Barzun perfected his English by studying Swift's ''Gulliver's Travels.'' It was an unusual primer, but Barzun's childhood, like Swift's, had been shattered by war, and disarray and darkness were on his mind. A few years earlier, at the age of 12, the young Barzun had contemplated suicide. The First World War had left many he knew dead or maimed. His parents' salon in their house in Creteil, near Paris, at which artists and writers like Apollinaire and Cocteau gathered, had come to an end. The French universities at which he would have studied were decimated. So he devoted himself to learning English under the tutelage of the sardonic Swift before beginning his own travels among peoples that were to him only a bit less exotic than Gulliver's Yahoos and Brobdingnags.

title: The Treachery That Lurks In Psychic Bidders' Hearts
description: About 70 years ago, Dorothy Rice Sims had a small verbal confusion. She was an expert in motorcycle racing, flying and sculpturing, but her bridge ability was just moderate, unlike that of her husband, P. Hal Sims, a well-known expert. When she happened to bid, perhaps by accident, a suit she did not have, she wanted to say that her effort was ''psychological.'' The shares of PlayCore jumped 40 percent, gaining $2.75 each, to $9.50, on the American Stock Exchange. The company, which is based in Janesville, Wis., hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette last fall to advise it on options for improving its share price. title: The Market's Breathtaking Plunge
description: Economists have warned for years that stock prices are unrealistically high, needing to fall by about a third, by one prominent estimate, to regain financial sense. But no amount of warning could take the fright out of yesterday's record drops in all major stock averages. Investors lost more than $2 trillion this week. Besides the horrific blow to personal wealth, there is the added threat to the health of the overall economy.

title: A Weakened I.R.S.
description: Years of pummeling by Congress have so weakened the Internal Revenue Service -- eroding its budget, staff and spirit -- that the agency has largely abandoned efforts to detect tax fraud among the rich and powerful, or even among ordinary taxpayers. The threat that the agency will audit an individual's tax form is shrinking toward zero. The odds that the I.R.S., having caught you in a mistake, will seize property or even levy a fine are also plummeting. Even the threat that a diligent collection agent will pressure people who owe back taxes is quickly disappearing.

title: Wagner's Inexhaustible 'Ring'

His music is alternately raw as cedar bark and mordantly aware -- like a character in a Cormac McCarthy novel who reads Cormac McCarthy novels. She's anguished and ethereal at the same time, more folk or rock than anything recognizably country.

title: The World: Beyond Protest; Making Room for the Poor In a Global Economy
description: ON all sides of the debate about globalization, in rich and poor nations alike, there lurks a disturbing, shared sense that even as industry expands around the third world, something is going tragically wrong in the poorest economies and most disadvantaged societies. The dispute is about how and why this is happening, and what can be done about it -- and these questions threaten to divide world opinion as nothing has since the collapse of Communism.

title: Citizen Canine
description: I lost a 9-year-old golden retriever to cancer in December, despite expensive surgery (Charles Siebert, March 26). My surviving dog, which we suspect may be part coyote, is now enjoying top-dog status. I mix his dry food each night with something home-cooked -- oatmeal, scrambled eggs, chicken. I swear his coat is shinier, his eyes brighter and his somewhat skittish personality more mellow. Your article reinforced my feeling that dogs do indeed deserve the best, so I'll continue my indulgences.

title: They Did Windows
description: Just over a century ago, a struggling actress -- the more artistic of two women sharing a New York town house -- read ''The Decoration of Houses'' by Edith Wharton and the architect Ogden Codman Jr. This subversive volume recommended a return to European ideals of purity and elegance -- Vanderbiltian baroque was labeled out; Versailles or 18th-century English country style was going to be in. The actress took a long look at her dark rooms decorated in gloomy, overstuffed 1890's style and made some very radical changes.

title: NO SALE IN NEWARK
description: On the heels of the deals in the last two weeks that removed major obstacles to the construction of a downtown sports arena in Newark, there are signs of a small land rush along the nearby waterfront. Last week Public Service Electric and Gas decided it could hold out for more money for a six-acre parcel it has owned on the Passaic River waterfront for more than 100 years and turned down two bids for the land. Paul Rosengren, a spokesman for the utility, said the bids ''were not reflective of the market value'' of the parcel that includes a soon-to-be-replaced substation serving downtown, Pennsylvania Station and the river. The property is practically in the path of the proposed Joseph G. Minish Riverfront Park, a ribbon of green that is to run two miles along the river's edge amid envisioned new office and other commercial uses. The bids that the utility rejected came from the Millenium Group, which envisioned developing a 300-room hotel there and the Newark Economic Development Corporation, which also proposed a hotel and apartments on the site just southeast of the city's New Jersey Performing Arts Center. The economic development group is a public-private venture involving the city and locally based corporations including PSE&G. RONALD SMOTHERS

Can the time cop who took Woody Allen to task for putting the psychoanalytic term ''conflicted'' into the mouth of a character ostensibly speaking in 1928 be unaware that Allen routinely exploits the comic value of psychobabble in absurd contexts? title: Footnotes

Among her clients was the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. ''I met him when he was starting out,'' she says. ''I could tell he had great talent but absolutely no money. I don't think I even charged him. I wanted him to do a head of me, but all I could afford was $150.'' title: IN-VITRO TWINS ARE HEIRS

Mr. Kolacy died of cancer in 1995 at age 26, after his sperm was preserved. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: Sidney Poitier's Demons

At breakfast recently at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Los Angeles, Poitier consumed an omelet made of egg whites, to avoid cholesterol, and a side dish of broccoli, in keeping with his habit of eating vegetables at every meal. But the highlight was the serving of granola topped with blueberries. Instead of milk, Poitier poured water into the bowl.

title: Red Ken Rising
description: Just to the east of the center of London, across the mud-brown Thames from Parliament, there is a great gray ghost of an office building. It is almost a century old, and its heavy columns and doorways and row upon row of unlighted windows extend along the riverbank for hundreds of yards. From a distance, it might be an abandoned palace or an emptied party headquarters in Eastern Europe; up close, there is dust on glass doors and piles of debris in hallways. Here and there, rooms are occupied: by a shop selling soccer memorabilia, a Marriott hotel, a busy riverside McDonald's. But the refurbishments feel thin, temporary. And along two sides of the building, more carefully drawn than the corporate logos, is a message from the past in carved gold capital letters. ''County Hall,'' it reads. ''The Home of London Government From 1922 to 1986.''

title: Shirts on the Web: To Infinity and Beyond
description: Since November, Angela Baldanza and her husband, Sandy, have sold their brand of shirts, nyshirts.com, at more than 400 stores across the country. At the end of March, their Web site, www.nyshirts.com, officially went live. The site features a standard boxed shirt (No. 212) in different sizes, colors and fabrics ($59 to $89), as well as shirts in other cuts and styles, like a wrap and shirt that is secured with Velcro. ALLISON FASS

description: H. J. Heinz and Del Monte Foods are trading barbs over a ketchup cap.

Vintage Norman Bel Geddes cocktail sets are selling for upwards of several thousand dollars online. But the tidal Hudson River, which reaches from the Battery in Manhattan up to the Troy dam, has forever been an entrancing mystery to anglers and anyone else who ever wondered what the bottom actually looks like.

description: THESE days, everyone assumes that the serious music fan is an arrested adolescent. Nick Hornby's 1995 novel, ''High Fidelity,'' devastatingly captured the paralyzed mental state of smart males whose emotional lives revolve around cultural product, not people. Now his characters have been made into Hollywood archetypes by the director Stephen Frears and the actor John Cusack. Once, record geeks made fun of themselves. Now mainstream America is talking about how lovably pathetic they can be.
