title: Candyland
description: Even as a grade-school child living in Los Angeles in the early 1960's, I was keenly aware of the crucial relationship between food and aesthetics that defines any truly great eating experience. I loved the gleaming golden arches that framed our local McDonald's (back when the arches were actually part of the restaurant) and the sky-blue uniforms, cinched with wide, copper-toned belts, worn by the waitresses at the International House of Pancakes (not to mention the little wire caddies that sat on your table, bearing pitchers filled with six different kinds of syrup).

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: SATCHEL PAIGE. By Lesa Cline-Ransome. Illustrated by James E. Ransome. Simon & Schuster. $16. (Ages 6 to 10) What better way to celebrate the season than an engaging picture biography of the great baseball pitcher? Satchel Paige was the first black pitcher in the major leagues, the first to pitch in the World Series. Leroy Paige got his nickname when as a boy in Mobile, Ala., he would greet arriving railroad passengers and hang their satchels on a long stick balanced on his shoulders. His pitching was so good he used to tell his catchers, ''All you gotta do is show me a glove and hold it still, I'll hit it.'' Fine, evocative illustrations.

It is on view at the St. Louis Art Museum through May 14, and will be at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art from June 25 through Sept. 11. The photographs for this article -- of the drawers, filled with collections of everyday objects, that were in the graphics room of the Eameses' workshop in Venice, Calif. -- were taken when the exhibition was at the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution in New York last winter. However, this rule has caused friction between the board and residents who wish to sublet for a longer period. The reason for the friction is that one apartment in the building is exempt from this rule. Special consideration is being accorded the shareholder of this apartment (who has not lived here for some 15 years) because he works in the Foreign Service. He is a also a very good friend of the board president. Is this legal? . . . Gerard Craigsyn, Manhattan.

Wagner and Bach have been doing well at Lincoln Center, but hibernation deserves some serious thought. The flowering pear trees are acting up on city sidewalks, and nothing going on under any roof can compete with them.

description: The broken deadlines for the installation of the E-ZPass toll collection system on the Garden State Parkway and New Jersey Turnpike have prompted the subcontractors doing the work to ask for nearly three times as much money as called for in the original contract, but there is no chance of them getting the pay increases, according to the consortium overseeing the work. Firms working under Adesta Transportation of Mount Laurel asked for nearly $117 million to complete the system, rather than the original $42.6 million called for in the contract. The system was supposed to be operational on the turnpike and parkway by next month. Now the deadline has been pushed back to September. Both applicants were granted patents. A letter from the doctor, dated March 10, alerted The Times to the error, and patent research delayed this correction.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Hard and the Soft
description: Best known for lavish sculptures that fuse fiber and bronze, Barbara Chase-Riboud has pursued an artistic career that spans three decades. Her production ranges from intimate works to grand public projects. In BARBARA CHASE-RIBOUD: Sculptor (Abrams, $39.95), Peter Selz and Anthony F. Janson examine the various sources of her work, including archaeology, classicism, baroque Rome, African and Egyptian culture, spiritualism, Surrealism, modern sculpture and the artist's own life. While Selz, an emeritus professor of art history at the University of California, Berkeley, traces Chase-Riboud's precocious beginnings and sculptural evolution, Janson, an art historian, focuses on her ''Monument Drawings,'' a series of large-scale works dedicated to diverse literary and historical figures from Pushkin to the Queen of Sheba. Chase-Riboud is shown to be a great reconciler who deftly merges opposites in her work, a goal that the artist set for herself early on: to make art that ''unites opposing forces -- male/female, negative/positive, black/white.'' The authors also seek to establish links between Chase-Riboud's literary and visual production, and her writing and poetry are interspersed throughout the book. The eloquence of Chase-Riboud's own words underlines the rather prosaic quality of the main texts, which do not share the finesse and complexity of the artist's work. The book is nonetheless valuable for its wealth of images and as a general introduction to Chase-Riboud's socially engaged and sensually satisfying art. Suzanne Ramljak

title: An Offbeat Outpost Attains Longevity And Ponders Why

Others are fueled more by can-do spirit and make-do inventiveness. In New York, some seemingly well-financed places flounder or disappear even after presenting good, memorable shows. (Remember the IBM Gallery or the short-lived Center for International Contemporary Arts?) And then there are the offbeat, sometimes more impulsive art outposts that pop up and, despite the odds, hang on for years and unexpectedly become important, even treasured institutions.

title: HEALTH INSURERS

But last week the insurer reached agreements to continue with the hospitals. Aetna U.S. Healthcare is New Jersey's largest health insurer with 1.1 million clients. If the contracts were terminated, those people who are part of Aetna's H.M.O. would not have been covered for care at the hospitals. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, CHARLES A.
description: WALKER-Charles A. Age 85, of New Haven, CT on April 12, after a short illness. Beloved husband of Bernice Rolf Walker and loving father of Allen, John and Larry. Cherished grandfather of Karin, Jessica, Courtney and Meredith. Charlie was raised in the Texas panhandle and made his way to the University of Texas in Austin for a BS and MS in Chemical Engineering. He taught at Texas A&I where he met Bernice and at the University of Arkansas. In 1942, he and Bernice were married and embarked on a 57 year love story; he also began a career of teaching and leading at Yale where he earned his doctorate. He was named full professor in 1954, Master of Berkeley College in 1959, Chairman of the Engineering and Applied Science Department in 1974, and Raymond John Wean Professor in 1979. All who knew Chuck, as he was called in his later years, speak passionately of his gentle nature, great intelligence, capacity for caring and his ability to inspire others by his example and his words. He was an accomplished wood carver and an avid fan of classical guitar music. Memorial service, May 13, 2:00 PM at Dwight Chapel, Yale. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to Yale University for the Bernice Rolf and Charles Allen Walker Berkeley College Master's Discretionary Fund at Yale University Office of Development, PO Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521-2038.

title: Church Of Fashion
description: Every five years, it seems, crosses as fashion icons enjoy a rebirth. But this year, they're multiplying like bunnies. No longer settling for dainty danglers, fashionistas and celebrities are wearing crosses down their backs, threading them on leather lanyards and draping them around their waists (as Cher did at the Oscars). Barneys New York is carrying about 50 percent more crosses than last season, in an array of styles, left, from Mizuki's austere diamonds in a channel setting ($1,295) to Devon Page McCleary's ornate version with pearl-studded chain ($3,235). Funky crosses are in demand at H. Stern, where rough-hewn pave diamond crosses ($2,200) and hammered yellow gold crosses ($330) are big sellers hung from thick matte chains, wire strands or even burlap twine. And Cartier's popular two-and-a-half-inch cross with white diamonds comes in white or yellow 18-karat gold; $25,000 without a chain. That's a heavy you-know-what to bear.

title: Low May It Wave
description: The seemingly endless effort to remove the Confederate flag from South Carolina statehouse may have begun in earnest when the state Senate voted to move the flag to a Confederate monument in front of the Capitol. Although many black legislators, along with the N.A.A.C.P., complained, a nearly unanimous group of black senators said the compromise would pass the House when lawmakers realized that it was the only way to get the flag off the dome and out of the nation's glare. DAVID FIRESTONE

title: Mission of Mercy for April: Curing the Form 1040 Blues
description: THE SETTING -- Room 205, a dusty classroom at Baruch College, filled with last-minute tax return filers, forms in hand, yearning for advice. Accounting majors from the school volunteered their on help Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday as the frenzy to get those forms filled out and filed escalated.

title: ASSESSING STATE STANDARDS
description: State officials will hire an outside firm to evaluate the effectiveness of the state's student assessment methods, which were introduced nearly five years ago. Achieve Inc. will receive $100,000 to compare the language-arts and math standards with those in other states and evaluate the effectiveness of teaching methods and testing. New Jersey was one of the first states to implement statewide school standards. Each 4th, 8th- and 11th grader in the state is required to take standardized tests. WENDY GINSBERG

title: Information Sought On Racetrack
description: The YankeeNets have requested the financial information of the Meadowlands Racetrack from the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, although the track is not officially for sale, a spokesman for the authority said yesterday.

title: A Color Only a Fan Could Love
description: HENRY FORD said customers could have any color car they wanted as long as it was black, but Mr. Ford never went to college, which explains why he never made anything of himself.

title: SOAPBOX; Lost at Grand Central
description: ELEVEN million cubic feet of some of the world's most magnificent interior public space stands framed within the Beaux-Arts columns, Tennessee marble floor and cathedral-high ceiling of constellated stars of Grand Central Terminal. This is much more than a train station, and up to half a million people walk through its concourse daily. The restoration of Paul Helleu's winter night zodiac, including fiber-optic illumination, is an appropriately lauded achievement of the Metropolitan Transit Authority's renovation.

title: Livery-Cab Driver Shot to Death In Latest in a Rash of Killings
description: A livery-cab driver was shot and killed early yesterday morning in Brooklyn, the police said. It was the second killing of a cab driver in New York City in two days and the seventh this year, the authorities said.

title: The Case of the Dozing Diplomats
description: Now the world knows how Alain Dejammet, France's just-departed ambassador to the United Nations, was amusing himself during those long Security Council consultations. He was thinking about naps.

title: Pictures From a Politically Correct Institution
description: Blue Angel By Francine Prose. 314 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $25.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-16-00; Clone of Silence
description: Perhaps I should start by saying that I have never had a dog I would have wished to replicate. There was Nappy, the poodle-shaped blur of my toddler years. Sweet little Woof, never the brightest bulb in the canine kingdom. Lawrence, the labrador, who barked at suitcases on wheels. My sister's Irish setter, who gathered up the ripest of our unwashed laundry and slept in it. I won't bore you with the rest of my dog-owning history, except to add that I liked all my dogs, toilet-drinkers though they were, mourned their passing -- and trooped cheerfully off to the animal shelter when the time came for a new one.

title: Building a Home For a Fragile, Fiery Community
description: THE sound of a hammer. I hear it when I think of Dance Theater Workshop during the 1960's. For those of us who performed in Jeff Duncan's very small loft on West 20th Street, the hammering was both a ritual and a necessity. Vigorous rehearsing inevitably caused the nails that held the Masonite panels to the scabby old floorboards to work their way upward, a menace to bare feet.

title: It's Closing Time for a Club and Its Unsavory Reputation
description: Much to the rejoicing of residents and businesses around West 43rd Street, the Kit Kat Klub will have no more lives. The nightclub, which went through several incarnations in recent years, closed on Tuesday.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Justin Kerrigan; Rolling Stoned
description: WHEN the Welsh hyphenate writer-director-actor Justin Kerrigan blew into New York on Sunday night, the people at Miramax, which is releasing ''Human Traffic,'' his film on the rave scene, must have gone for the Advil.

title: Pop in the Pews
description: CHURCHES around the state, not content to just traditionally perform the classic hymns that were written 100 or so years ago, are composing their own music. Often using the talents of the professional musicians who are members of their congregations, churches are creating a body of work that the experts say is new and vibrant and points to a revitalization of worship.

title: Drama of a Fading Mind, a Fighting Spirit
description: WHEN people congratulate Kenneth Lonergan for truthfully portraying the ravages of Alzheimer's disease in his new Off Broadway play, ''The Waverly Gallery,'' he credits Eileen Heckart and Maureen Anderman with much of his success.

title: Neighbors Mourn the Blight Of Two Abandoned Houses
description: In this quiet community of single-family homes, two houses stand out conspicuously. Both are boarded up, dilapidated and shrouded in weeds and debris. Many residents say the decaying houses are fire hazards and magnets for vandals, and will lead to a decline in property values.

title: Pacers' Veterans Have to Prove Their Value
description: Reggie Miller and Mark Jackson asked for contract extensions earlier this season, requests that went nowhere. Donnie Walsh was candid and honest with the two proud Indiana veterans, but Miller and Jackson viewed the wait-and-see approach of Walsh, the Pacers' president, as genuine disrespect for their longevity and loyalty to the franchise.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Hadley's Neighborhood
description: Albert Hadley is in his ''no-furniture furniture'' phase, as he put it. ''I'm getting rid of everything,'' Hadley, 79, said in his slightly drowsy voice, still paced by his Nashville boyhood. ''The only things I'm keeping are my books.''

title: Mossadegh: Eccentric Nationalist Begets Strange History
description: Except for Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, father of its revolution, no leader has left a deeper mark on Iran's 20th century landscape than Mohammed Mossadegh. And no 20th century event has fueled Iran's suspicion of the United States as his overthrow has.

title: Israel Called Ready to Offer Deal on New State
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel is prepared to promise Israeli recognition of a Palestinian state as part of a final peace agreement with the Palestinians in May, a senior Israeli official said tonight.

title: An Economist in Demand
description: For the third time in six years, Paul Krugman, economist and author, is changing universities, joining Princeton and leaving the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''I am surprised at myself that I am doing this,'' Mr. Krugman said. ''My wife and I did not want to make a change now, but there was the offer on the table, and we asked ourselves, 'Would our lives be a little easier?' ''

title: THE GUIDE

title: Ideas & Trends: Why Is This Man Smiling?; Executive Pay Drops Off the Political Radar
description: IN 1992, Bill Clinton denounced the soaring salaries of America's chief executives and vowed to do something about them if he won the presidency. Sure enough, in his first year in office he pushed through a law that slapped a new tax on some companies paying their top executives more than $1 million. At the time, the typical chief executive of a large company was making about $3 million a year in salary, bonus and stock awards.

title: As They Really Might Have Been

description: THE latest issue on business school campuses? It's not whether to start your own dot-com before graduation, but whether you should be allowed to use your laptop in the classroom as you please.

title: Word for Word/Unmasking Mental Illness; 'I'd Never Really Hurt Anybody': Perched on the Razor's Edge of Anger
description: IN a high-wire act performed daily by many psychiatrists, patients are assessed for their potential danger to themselves or others. Recent publicity about mentally ill people who were evaluated and released before committing violent acts has put that process under scrutiny. Psychiatric professionals say predicting violence accurately is impossible, but there are tools that help them make clinical judgments. Most important is the individual interview.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Education Life section last Sunday about problems with high-stakes testing referred incorrectly to a test used by the Philadelphia school district. It is a customized Stanford Achievement Test, not an unmodified Iowa Test of Basic Skills.

title: Penn State Delivers A 1-2 Punch

Back and forth the Browns went, sometimes in heated discussions. Arrington possesses explosive athletic ability, but Brown is the kind of player who can dominate a game.

title: C.R.W. Nevinson, Bold Interpreter Of the Great War
description: THE artist C. R. W. Nevinson (1889-1946) had his day in the sun. But that day was also World War I, which means, paradoxically, that this painter's triumphant period was also a storm. Following the war, Nevinson's art became merely ordinary or strained.

title: Jets Bolster Pass Rush, and Snag a Passer
description: The Jets, coming off one of the most shocking trades in franchise history, entered yesterday's National Football League draft hoping to quiet the din surrounding the trade of Keyshawn Johnson by finding his replacement. But by the time the Jets had exhausted their unprecedented four first-round picks, they still had not filled Johnson's spot in the lineup. Instead, they hoped they had found their next quarterback.

title: Global Storm: Loan Agencies Under Siege

Wolfensohn, the bank's Australian-born president, gathered his staff members this week and told them to ''remember to stand tall, because we are way ahead of the protesters.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKMAN, MIRIAM BERGER

A beautiful, loving mother, grandmother and friend, she cherished babies, bagels and butterflies. Service Sunday, 1 PM, Riverside Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: It is common enough, and easy enough, to reserve a seat on an airliner from your computer's keyboard, but we don't always want to travel by air. At times we want to get from here to there by rental car, or to have one waiting for us at the airport; there are even souls who prefer to or must travel by train or bus. How easy is that to arrange from the screen?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, ALICE ALBERTS (NEE WEINER)

Beloved wife of the late Martin Alberts and the late Arthur Rogers, adored mother of Phyllis and Aron Katz, loving grandmother of Martin Katz and Margaret Cann, doting greatgrandmother of Hondo, Cisco, Harrison and Simon. description: THE bad news these days about travel to eastern Asia is that the region has reverted from being the certifiable steal that it was at the height of the economic crisis two years ago to once again being comparably priced with many other parts of the world -- or even pricier.

description: When a sign went up last year at 640 Broadway, at Bleecker Street, inside the newly created NoHo Historic District, neighbors and local businesses rallied against it even as the illuminated billboard beckoned advertisers. Now, opponents are outraged that the sign is hawking sexually oriented entertainment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALGUS, ROSE
description: ALGUS-Rose. On April 14, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Karen (Marc) and Michael (Anne). Dear sister of Terry, Gertie, Harry, Sy, Bill and the late Norman. Loving grandmother of Aron, Elise, Ariel, Alexandra and Gabrielle. Services private.

title: A Depression-Era Diner Collides With Today's Real Estate
description: The Jones Diner may not get a perfect score from Zagat for food or decor. In fact, it does not get an entry at all. Yet, the lunchbox-size eatery at Lafayette and Great Jones Streets has a loyal following.

The New York Times had suggested they talk together about Ms. Taymor's theatrical life after ''The Lion King'' musical. Her production of the play ''The Green Bird'' opens on Tuesday at the Cort Theater on Broadway. Here are excerpts from their tape-recorded conversation.

title: Taunt Turns a Town Into Spin City
description: When an 11-year-old boy was suspended from the Chatsworth Avenue School in Larchmont, N.Y., this month, the decision was portrayed in the news media as political correctness run amok. But for many local parents, the episode illustrated how a parent can distort public perception of a school's decision, and how a school, constrained by federal privacy law from giving its version of events, can be forced to back down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, SAMUEL
description: SIEGEL-Samuel. At age 88. On March 26, 2000 in Brooklyn, New York. Devoted husband of Sylvia. Beloved father of Irwin, Arnold and Howard. Devoted grandfather of Adam, Lisa, Andrew and Aaron. Cherished brother of Irving, Milton, Harry and Gertie. Loyal member of H.A.D., Workmen's Circle and New York Typographical Union. Printer, magician, comedian. In our hearts, you live forever. Memorial donations to Hebrew Institute for the Deaf and Exceptional Children, 1401 Avenue I, Brooklyn, New York. 11230. Attention Mr. Ebstein.

It turns out -- and New York is great at schooling you in obscure civic responsibilities you never knew about -- that if your property happens to become a crime scene, for whatever reason, you get to bat cleanup.

Is this the confused jumble of half-forgotten vacations? No, it's right here in Lake Mohawk Village, frozen in time on the banks of Lake Mohawk, a few minutes north of Interstate 80 in Sussex County.

A Robsjohn-Gibbings tripod table lamp that first cost $74.25 recently sold on eBay for $610. Collectors should also check with Evan Lobel at Lobel Modern, and with Donzella, both New York sources.

title: Germany Plays Host To a World's Fair

Forty million people are expected to visit the city's 400-acre exhibition site for the five-month fair, whose theme is ''Humankind, Nature and Technology.'' With a record 172 countries participating, Expo 2000 organizers promise a diverse, ecologically oriented fair.

title: The World: A New Age?; Europe's Men of Power Hold Open a Door for Women
description: SHE blushed bright red and managed an embarrassed smile. Her arms dangled awkwardly, until, overwhelmed by the ovation from the congress of her Christian Democratic party, Angela Merkel managed a wave so rigid it suggested an East German leader from the Soviet days.

title: Dismissal of Guards at Complex Saddens and Angers Residents
description: The entire security staff of Independence Plaza North, a Mitchell-Lama housing complex on Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, will be replaced this week. Some tenants, angered by the dismissals, are exploring ways to resist the move.

title: Hero of Versailles? It's New York
description: The best place to find businesspeople to support repairs to Versailles, where Louis XIV's gardens were blasted by storms last Christmas? Try New York. And so last week more than 100 guests including Richard and Kathy Hilton (as in the hotels); Lawrence Herbert, chief executive of Pantone Inc. and his wife, Michele; and the investor Peter Price and his wife, Judy, raised several hundred thousand dollars to mend the estate, as well as to keep up Claude Monet's Giverny. At the Carlyle hotel, this slice of mostly American royalty was welcomed by Prince and Princess Michael of Kent, sipped vintage Taittinger in the Versailles Room, then dined in the Trianon Room.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-16-00: On Language; Legacy
description: Certain words and phrases become taboo in the White House. Out of the loop, amiable dunce, malaise and crook come to mind.

title: Knife and Cuffs Used in Rape On West Side
description: A 37-year-old woman was attacked at knifepoint and raped early yesterday in her apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, officials said. They said the attack seemed to match the pattern of the East Side rapist, who has been linked to 16 sexual attacks, including 7 rapes, between 1994 and 1998.

title: Angola's Need, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: The New American Worker
description: The corporate hierarchy of the 1950's was hardly a model environment. But when most workers did their jobs in the same location, they at least had to figure out how to get along with others or they didn't get very far. In today's world of free agency and telecommuting, many relationships are lived out in cyberspace. As a marriage and family therapist with 15 years' experience working in corporate employee-assistance programs, I have seen the effects of the loss of relationship skills in the workplace.

title: 'Seeing Mary Plain'
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum Hailing Some Word-of-Mouth
description: Newark cabdrivers are taking a side trip to the Newark Museum as part of an effort by the museum to get the word out to visitors about what it has to offer.

title: Edward Keefer, a Surgeon, Is Dead at 84
description: Dr. Edward B. C. Keefer, a surgeon who set up the first transplant bank for human blood vessels and was the first to fit a horse with an artificial leg, died on April 3 at his home in Brookville, N.Y. He was 84.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: Snow aside, as spring has come upon us, our prose contributers must be moved to work in their gardens rather than write to the Diary. At the same time, there has been a burst of poetry. The recent snow has been front and center in the verse, as have the change of seasons and some current events. So here is an all-poetry Jersey Diary.

title: Putting His Body Into It (Minus His Face)
description: LIKE many established actors, Derek Smith has worked for years without becoming a household name. That anonymity takes on real meaning in Julie Taymor's Broadway production of ''The Green Bird,'' opening on Tuesday at the Cort Theater.

title: For Cuban Boy's Uncle, Both Reverence and Scorn
description: For four months now, Lazaro Gonzalez, the great-uncle of Elian Gonzalez, has zigzagged his way through a phalanx of lawyers and government officials, Cuban-American leaders and politicians, calling the shots as he sees fit, day in and day out.

title: Occupational Radiation
description: Big, unregulated and dirty, the nationwide complex of factories that built nuclear weapons for more than five decades employed about 600,000 people, and, the government now admits, made some of them sick. The Clinton administration announced a plan to offer compensation for medical expenses and lost wages, and anticipates that about 3,000 cases will be filed, half claiming exposure to radiation and half claiming other hazards. In many cases, reimbursement, if it comes, would be posthumous. MATTHEW L. WALD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, RUTH R.
description: KLEIN-Ruth R. On April 14, 2000. Of Royal Palm Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Arthur H. Devoted mother of Robert Mark Klein of Great Neck, LI, and Paul Michael Klein of Aventura, FL. Dear sister of Anita Putterman, Irma Tyson and the late Raymond Ratnoff. Cherished grandmother of Keith Jaret Klein. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

title: When the Personal Is Commercial
description: 'Na Vota, in Piedmont dialect, means ''olden times.'' At Cantine Sant'Agata this label relives yesterdays when locals turned backyard grapes like the obscure, rustic ruche into homemade wine. In the late 1980's, the authorities endowed a few villages with an appellation, Ruche di Castagnole Monferrato, and the personal grape went commercial.

title: Home Prices: Upward, Ho!
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Give Away $21.8 Billion
description: One of the ways in which the very rich are different from you and me is that they become public property. Just about everyone has an opinion about Bill Gates's business tactics, products, motives, character, house -- and about what he should be doing with his immense fortune.

title: The Search For Money To Preserve The Land
description: NED ELLIS'S dairy farm in Hebron has been in the family since 1903. When real estate developers make lucrative offers for parcels of his land, he turns them down.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 2 about a discussion of global affairs at Wetlands, a nightclub, referred incorrectly to the presidential endorsement of the Green Party of New York State. The musician Jello Biafra is not the state party's ''official nominee'' for president. He finished second in the party's presidential primary on March 7, behind Ralph Nader.

title: Birthday Parties at the Library of Congress
description: In celebration of the bicentennial of its founding on April 24, 1800, the Library of Congress in Washington will present two exhibitions.

title: Portfolios That May Need A Diversification Push
description: If you're wondering why your diversified stock fund seems to be tracking the fortunes of the fast-imploding Internet sector, it may be because (surprise) it is not particularly diversified.

title: Holbrooke's Campaign
description: In his ''behind Dayton'' memoir, ''To End a War,'' Holbrooke revealed confidential United States strategies about how to persuade the Serbian dictator, Slobodan Milosevic, to do the right thing in Bosnia. Milosevic had to be embarrassed by the revelations that showed him outsmarted. It is no surprise that Milosevic remains firmly in power today. Milosevic continues to use Kosovo to show the Holbrookes of the world that dictators -- not mouthy diplomats -- get the last, rueful laugh in this post-cold-war world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENTWORTH, ALFRED R.
description: WENTWORTH-Alfred R. Of Sarasota, FL. Born in Reno, NV. March 9, 1920. Attended Williston Academy, Easthampton, MA. Graduated 1939. Served on their Board of Trustees from 1954-1958 and 1963-1973, also serving as Vice President from 1964-1970. He was elected Life Trustee in 1970 and received the Distinguished Service Award in 1974. Attended Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, graduated 1943. Served in W.W. II, First Lt., 28th Infantry. Captured Battle of the Bulge. Spent the rest of the conflict in prison camp. Joined Chase National Bank, 1946. Opened first U.S. Bank Representative Office in Moscow, USSR, 1972. Became President and CEO of Chase Manhattan Canada, Ltd. 1977. Retired to Sarasota, 1980. Active in local Sarasota County Republican Club, President of Sara Bay Country Club. Survived by wife Nancy, in Sarasota, Florida, and two sons Alfred R., Jr. of Jackson, New Jersey, and Robert T. of Gainesville, Florida, and four grandchildren. Memorial service to be held at Palm Funeral Home, Sarasota, Florida.

title: A Labor of Love
description: On a hilltop in Caracas, Venezuela, overlooking the city and the mountains that surround it, sits one of the postwar era's most exuberant works of domestic architecture. The Villa Planchart was designed for Armando and Anala Planchart by the Italian architect Gio Ponti (1891-1979) and completed in 1956. Ponti designed not only the 10,000-square-foot, six-bedroom house, but all the furniture and many of the objects within it with the spirit and sensuality that were the hallmarks of his humanistic brand of modernism. Still occupied by Anala Planchart, the house is a testament not just to a couple's happy marriage, but also to an enduring friendship between clients and architect.

title: Settlement Is Reached in Feud Over Writers in Los Angeles
description: After years of heated conflict, the union that represents screenwriters and the city of Los Angeles have reached a truce over imposing local taxes on writers, artists and other self-employed people who work at home.

title: Citizen Canine
description: I love my mutt, but every time I take her to the vet for her annual visit and shots, it costs more than I, as a pediatrician, charge my patients. As long as we do not have national health care in this country, I will make a contribution to a children's health or welfare agency in an amount equal to whatever my vet bill is.

title: Preserving Vibrancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Emmett, 78, Who Wrote 'That Was the Week That Was'
description: Robert Emmett, an actor and writer for the stage and screen whose credits include the 1960's satirical television news show ''That Was the Week That Was,'' died April 8 at St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Runoff in Peru
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori, the longest-serving Latin American leader after Fidel Castro, fell just short of winning an outright first-round victory for a third five-year term in an election tainted by accusations of fraud from international monitors. When a runoff for June was announced, crowds of tens of thousands of protesters dispersed and international observers expressed relief. CLIFFORD KRAUSS

title: My I.R.A. Needs Viagra
description: SOME people have hip financial managers. I have an accountant named Ronald McDonald, of all things.

title: A Postmodern Borrower Who Goes Her Own Way
description: SALLY SILVERS calls herself a dancer and a choreographer, but by many conventional measures she resembles neither. She has never succeeded at an audition, or joined a professional dance company, or started a troupe of her own. Even so, Ms. Silvers exerts a palpable force within the downtown dance scene, both as a performer of striking intensity and as a creator of wildly original movement. Working mostly with pick-up troupes, she has gained an ardent following over the last 20 years. Her choreography -- marked by dense layers of imagery and sudden shifts of weight and mood -- owes as much to improvisational music, independent film and experimental poetry as it does to modern dance.

title: Elan Kaplan, Jeffrey Barish
description: Elan Price Kaplan, the daughter of Leslie Price Hayes of Palisades, N.Y., and Arnold Kaplan of Manhattan, was married last evening to Jeffrey Stewart Barish, a son of Rhonda Ninfo of Royal Palm Beach, Fla., and Carl Barish of Los Angeles. Rabbi Howard I. Needleman officiated at the TriBeCa Rooftop in Manhattan.

title: APRIL 9-15; Raising the Bar on Seizures
description: Congress completed legislation that will make it harder for prosecutors to confiscate homes and other property before they bring charges in narcotics and other cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, HAROLD
description: BROWN-Harold. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Harold Brown, associated with The Times from 1962 until retiring in 1978.

title: Investing; For Net's Incubators, A Market Overheating
description: LAST year, investors couldn't lose with Internet incubators: Stocks of companies like CMGI, Internet Capital and Safeguard Scientifics climbed 5-, 10-, even 25-fold, and those who bought shares on any weakness were quickly rewarded.

title: Litigation Is Taking the Wind Out of Some Sails
description: In the 6,000 or so years since the first sailors set fabric off a spar to harness the wind's pure energy, the art and science of sailmaking has evolved from a rudimentary, needle-and-thread endeavor to a high-tech business. It's one that uses exotic materials such as Kevlar, Mylar and carbon fiber, and employs sophisticated manufacturing processes that can literally mold sails into sleek, flawless foils that are as efficient as an airplane wing.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Highlighting Student Art

title: Eden Abrahams, Steven Bruner
description: Eden Abrahams, the daughter of Leah Broyde Abrahams and Dr. Paul P. Abrahams, both of Green Bay, Wis., was married last evening to Steven Wayne Bruner, a son of Janet and Robert Bruner of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Company Again Wins Bidding for Land on L.I.
description: A Melville, N.Y., real estate investment trust that accused the state last month of improperly reneging on a deal to develop hundreds of acres of prime land on Long Island will be allowed to buy the site after all, state officials said on Friday.

title: Taking Your Cell With You
description: HIKING through the silent, wooded pathways of Batsto Village, where ancient carpets of moss wind their way to the old mill BREEP where the lake empties beneath the bridge in a thundering waterfall BREEPBREEP. . . . Ah, the gentle call of the cell phone.

title: POSTINGS: 43 Condos at 18-Story Former Warehouse in TriBeCa; From Butter and Eggs to Lofts
description: Punching holes in the thick skin of a well-insulated antique refrigerator of a building, developers are creating 43 loft condominiums in the Atalanta Building, an 18-story former warehouse for butter, cheese and eggs at 25 North Moore Street in TriBeCa.

title: Books in Brief: Poetry
description: Midnight Salvage

title: Barbara Burby, Samuel Wang
description: Barbara Derina Burby and Samuel Wei-Teh Wang were married yesterday by the Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: The New Old Thing: Doctored Denim
description: IN ancient times, when I was a teenager, parents had two perennial questions: ''When are you going to cut that hair?'' and ''When are you going to wash those jeans?''

title: Fishing for Answers
description: The Last Marlin

title: Cardinals Must Rely On Pitching Coach
description: The scenario is ripe for a recurring nightmare. Darryl Kile escapes from Colorado after being trapped there for two grueling, punishing, agonizing years. Just when he begins to flourish in his new home, he finds himself back in Colorado and again spends a grueling, punishing, agonizing night.

title: INSIDE
description: Envoys Return to Belgrade

title: Bookend; Bookspotting
description: HOWEVER gloomy the pronouncements about their growing obsolescence, books continue to multiply defiantly. In recent years, as though to confirm their continuance, a clutch of national book towns has appeared throughout Europe -- small, many-shelved outposts to reassure us, particularly those who still regard books as sacred objects, that they will never disappear. The first of these to flourish, in the early 60's, was Hay-on-Wye, a town on the English-Welsh border. It soon became a Mecca for book pilgrims and the curious, even a national institution, with its own literary festival. The transformation proved so satisfying and exemplary that the idea was taken up in France, Germany, the Netherlands and Norway, and the European book towns have now found their way into the tourist guidebooks and are much visited.

title: Ideas & Trends; Back to the Future: Medicine and Our Genes
description: SINCE the invention of the stethoscope by the French physician Rene Laennec in 1816, medicine has been troubled by a predicament: the technological advances that have enhanced our ability to diagnose and cure have also distanced us from our patients.

title: On Africa's Fluid Borders, My Land Is Your Land
description: When Abdoulaye Sowe built his mud house along a dirt road that links this country with Senegal a year ago, he chose a spot a few hundred feet north of the Senegalese border guard's straw shack.

title: Uphill Climb in Financing Church Music
description: THE music was soulful on the second Sunday of Lent at St. Thomas Episcopal Church here, from the six hymns sung by the white-robed choir to the resonant sounds of the organ.

title: Larger Than Life
description: All my life, I've had heroes. Not famous -- but famous to me -- they make up my own personal pantheon. Christine Rae, whom I met in the 1970's when I was a novice editor and she was a seasoned publicist for the furniture company Knoll, would impart sardonic wisdom about design and life in a tobacco-tinged growl that I can hear to this day. Eleanore Phillips Colt, for more than four decades the West Coast editor of Vogue, personified no-nonsense elegance (I always saw her in flat shoes, no matter how fancy the dress) and knew inside-out the nearly vanished world of Old Hollywood royalty. The older my mentors were, the better I liked them. No overnight sensations for me. What becomes a legend most is time.

title: Access to Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMSON, DR. BERNARD W.
description: GAMSON-Dr. Bernard W. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a longtime friend and supporter, distinguished scientist, industrialist, and leader of the Jewish community, and a founding member of the Yeshiva College Board of Directors-serving as cochair of its Academic Affairs Committee. He was on the organizing committee for our Sy Syms School of Business. With his wife, Deborah Sobel Gamson, he was a YU Guardian and Fellow of YC, SSSB, and Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. They established scholarships at YC, SSSB, and our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Deborah; children, Mark (and Sandra) Gamson, Michael Gamson, Miriam (and David) Cohen, and Alan Gamson; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Jay Schottenstein, Chairman YC Board of Directors

title: The World; Living in the Past: Cuba Si, Korea No
description: THROUGHOUT 40 years of cold war and its aftermath, Fidel Castro has cast himself as the man who really understands the world, the intellectual scold of the rich and powerful, the nemesis of the world's last superpower. And there he was again last week, preaching to the world's rich nations about their obligations to the world's poorest nations.

title: A Forefather of Venture Capital
description: AT 84, Alan K. Ruvelson has every reason to dismiss those bumper stickers that read ''Lead, follow or get out of the way.'' Ever since he was a teenager in Minnesota, he has been a chronic joiner.

title: 20-20 Revision Not Allowed: In Hindsight, the Draft Is Never a Sure Thing
description: To demonstrate just how much a game of chance the National Football League draft is, these were the top 10 players picked in 1992: Steve Emtman, Quentin Coryatt, Sean Gilbert, Desmond Howard, Terrell Buckley, David Klingler, Troy Vincent, Bob Whitfield, Tommy Vardell and Ray Roberts.

title: Wendy Zuckerwise and Nat Ritter
description: THERE are two things almost every dentist seems to have. One is hands so clean they look recently manicured. The other is framed pictures of family members -- children on swings or bicycles, spouses on Caribbean beaches, everyone happy and far away from Novocain needles.

title: Mayor Reports Heavy Spending on Direct Mail
description: With seven months before Election Day, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate campaign has already spent $10 million, more than half the money it has collected, largely because it has relied on costly direct-mail efforts for its fund-raising.

title: Bensonhurst Journal; In Brooklyn, a Quiet Avenue With Dirty Laundry
description: It would be hard to find a business more tied to its community than the Bath Avenue Dry Cleaning and Tailoring Shop.

title: North Korea Opens Its Door, Just a Crack
description: FOR anyone who has ever dreamed of going behind the Iron Curtain, or at least what is left of it, Communist North Korea now allows foreigners to visit its magnificent Kumgang Mountains, which were closed to the outside world at the end of the Korean War 50 years ago.

title: Ikea and New Rochelle
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking a Little Time Out for Making Amends
description: Gov. George W. Bush met with a dozen gay Republicans and pronounced himself psychically refreshed. ''I'm a better person for the meeting,'' Mr. Bush said.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: No film has ever done more for the self-esteem of middle-aged men without gym memberships than THE FULL MONTY (1997), directed by Peter Cattaneo. Robert Carlyle heads a group of unemployed steelworkers in Sheffield, England, who decide to earn some much-needed money by becoming male strippers. Tom Wilkinson, as the dignified former foreman, is also memorable in this irresistibly endearing comedy - Thursday at 8 p.m. on Channel 5.

title: Allowing His Guitar To Sing
description: WITH his latest CD, ''Little Lion,'' Brooks Williams separates himself from the acoustic herd of singer-songwriters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, RUTH K.
description: REISS-Ruth K. On April 13, 2000 at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Georges Bernard Reiss. Loving mother of Elizabeth Baecher and Jeanne-Marie Byington. Adoring grandmother of John and Edward Baecher, and great-grandmother of two. Devoted sister of Martin L. and Robert D. Kay, dear aunt and wonderful friend. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Monday 6-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76 St., Tuesday, 11 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Edward Gorey, Eerie Illustrator And Writer, 75
description: Edward Gorey, whose eerie black-and-white cross-hatched drawings of hapless children and Victorian ministers charmed and haunted readers, died yesterday in Hyannis, Mass. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAZDA, LOUIS S.
description: GAZDA-Louis S. Of Forest Hills on April 15, 2000, in his 96th year. NYS Funeral Director for 70 years. Owner of Glascott Funeral Home, Forest Hills. Beloved husband of the late Ann. Loving father of Louis W. Gazda and the late Marylin Serpe Gazda. Dear grandfather of James and Thomas Gazda. Visiting Glascott Funeral Home, 102-03 Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills, Sunday, 7-9 PM, Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass Our Lady of Mercy Church, Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Our Lady of Mercy School appreciated.

title: Where the Shirts Are Scanned, Not Stuffed
description: IN 1996, David Fraser Walker and Martin Brighty were enjoying success as sales executives in the venerable British neckwear business when their company, Holliday & Brown, went through a downsizing and they found themselves out on the street.

title: Of Spiritual vs. Urban Renewal
description: THE REV. FRED JENKINS'S legacy, a home for his Pentecostal congregation after 21 years of moving from one site to the next, is now in the hands of a State Supreme Court justice.

title: Holbrooke's Campaign
description: Holbrooke states that the administration ''got 90 percent of what we wanted'' (the payment of United States dues to the U.N.). He goes on to say, ''The women have emphasized the 10 percent we didn't get.''

title: Corrections
description: A letter in the Ethicist column on March 26 included an erroneous claim about ''mad cow'' disease and a medical study. The writer of the letter now says that its assertion -- that information had been withheld from patients in a study involving blood transfusions -- was hypothetical.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-16-00: Word & Image; The Ides of April
description: Every year at this time, I conjure an image of tens of millions of us rushing dutifully, but also proudly, to send off our 1040's to feed and protect our prized democracy. The image persists even though it has grown quaint, wrong in almost every respect.

title: Ideas & Trends; Returning the Spoils Of War, With Immunity
description: IN the closing days of World War II in Germany, Cameron Anderson, a young American Army private, casually pocketed a valuable 14th-century manuscript from the castle of Grossgrundlach on the outskirts of Nuremberg. It troubled him for years.

title: Citizen Canine
description: Charles Siebert struck a responsive chord. As a member of the newly formed Tompkins County Dog Owners Group, in Ithaca, we are embarked on a quest for an off-leash area of our own, after being hounded from our usual haunts by more vigorous enforcement of the leash law.

title: Vigil Honors Lives Of Murder Victims
description: THEY are members of a group that no one wanted to join, attending an event they wish did not need to be held. Calling themselves ''homicide survivors,'' the group of about 60 attended a vigil last week to remember family members who had been murdered.

title: Voting For Boards In a Co-op
description: ELECTIONS for board members in a co-op can be as combative and controversial as those for public officials. And co-op elections, with complex rules that often allow such things as proxies and cumulative voting, can also be confusing.

title: Colombia to the East End: A Tale of Success
description: IN these heady days of stock-market surges and overnight millionaires, success stories are everywhere. Most are high-tech, dot-com tales, but they often feature young, hard-working businessmen, like Fredy Bedoya, a landscape contractor who held tightly to the reins of the galloping economy and rode it to success.

title: Citizen Canine
description: History is replete, from the time of the pharaohs, with examples of affluent cultures that overindulge canine and feline companions. But, hey, relax, take a Prozac (or steal one of your dog's); everything will come into perspective. One good recession, a couple of kids, maybe some geriatric parents to care for, and pretty soon that plain old can of dog food and a bowl of fresh water will look downright sensible and nutritious.

title: Why Nassau County Is No New York City
description: SITTING in southbound traffic on Glen Cove Road, waiting for a vast tractor-trailer to make a tight right turn through the tangled traffic onto Old Country Road, one forgets there was life in Nassau County before the internal combustion engine.

title: Breast Cancer Incidence by Zip Code, 1993-1997
description: A year late and still lacking details sought by Long Islanders involved in fighting cancer, the state Health Department issued maps last week showing the incidence of breast cancer by ZIP Code.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What I find demoralizing is that there is no organization on earth that is doing more for the poor than we do.''

title: Pass the Inhaler: I Feel a Chic Attack Coming On
description: TREE season 2000 is upon us, the harbinger of pollen counts to come. But I say to you, my fellow allergy and asthma sufferers, do not be ashamed or embarrassed by your wheezing, runny noses and rheumy eyes. Own your symptoms! These most geeky of afflictions are on the verge of becoming chic.

title: A Ceiling for Drugs Prices
description: The Maine legislature is the first in the country to just say no to drug prices. It overwhelmingly passed a bill requiring that medications sold in the state cost no more than those in Canada. The bill is expected to face legal challenges, and the pharmaceutical industry argues that it could hinder Maine patients's access to drugs and chill research efforts. CAREY GOLDBERG

title: TEWELL LEADS BY FOUR
description: Doug Tewell assumed a four-stroke lead, but rain stopped the P.G.A. Seniors Championship yesterday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., before the second round could be completed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRANEY, SR. F. BONNIE, O.S.M.
description: STRANEY-Sr. F. Bonnie, O.S.M. On April 14, 2000. Born Flavian Bonnie on February 7, 1920. Daughter of Marguerite Gail McNamara and Charles Nicholas Straney. Beloved sister of Joseph Patrick, Abigail Irene, Rosarii Marie, Therese Martin, James Aloysius, Charles Nicholas, Laurence Vebert and Paul Francis. Entered Order, Servants of Mary in 1936.

title: A Lighthouse That Was a Beacon for Wireless Communication
description: April 24 is International Marconi Day, when amateur radio operators around the world celebrate the achievements of Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of the wireless telegraph, by exchanging messages for 24 hours. One of the stations participating will be in the Navesink Light Station in Highlands, now known as the Twin Lights State Historic Site. In 1899, Marconi used the lighthouse to prove to America just how useful wireless telegraphy could be. He put an antenna near the northwest tower to telegraph reports of the return of Admiral George Dewey and his fleet from the Battle of Manila Bay on Sept. 30, and the progress of the America's Cup race offshore in October. In 1900, he set up a full-time telegraph station there, and it stayed in operation until 1907. The lighthouse was decommissioned by the Coast Guard in 1949. Thomas Laverty of the park service spoke about the lighthouse, where he has lived for 15 years.

title: Bang! You're Suspended
description: DENNIS FYFFE'S office was littered with pink telephone message slips with calls from reporters. Dateline NBC, MSNBC, Channel 2, Channel 11, Channel 12.

title: IN PERSON; From 'The Edge of Night' To 'Now and Again'
description: AS Margaret Colin, one of the stars of the CBS series ''Now and Again,'' sat on a small sofa in her modest two-room trailer in the Silvercup Studio in Long Island City, she seamlessly straddled the world of work and family as she wondered out loud whether she could make the trek home to Montclair Township in time to take her two young sons to church.

title: How Fast They Grow: Clothes for the Playground Set
description: When Baruch Moscovici was growing up in Israel, he helped out at the children's clothing store his mother, Ester, owned. When he moved to the United States, he continued working in retail fashion. And 15 years later, at the beginning of this month, Mr. Moscovici opened Peek a Boo Kids, his own children's clothing store, at 90 Seventh Avenue (between Union and Berkeley Streets) in Park Slope, Brooklyn. This time Mr. Moscovici's mother is his partner. Mr. Moscovici's wife, Shana, whose family owns the vintage clothing stores Andy's Chee-pees, is also assisting. With clothing for newborns through age 7, like socks ($3) and T-shirts ($3 to $30), as well as carriages ($22 to $130) and blankets ($15 to $40), Mr. Moscovici said he offers a range of prices because the neighborhood is diverse.

title: PLAYING
description: MIDTOWN

title: Style; A Hot Time In the Old Town House Tonight
description: With the cast of 'The Wild Party' and assorted celebrity extras, a little dress-up 'do' at the Sonnenberg manse turns into an affair to remember.

title: In China Pact, Executives Sense a Hornet's Nest
description: NEARLY 100 chief executives applauded mildly when Gene Sperling, the White House economic adviser, finished his pitch for the China trade agreement. Mr. Sperling had been preaching to the choir: no one wants Congress to ratify the agreement more than the nation's top business executives. But their first question to him afterward revealed a concern that, in backing the trade bill, they are stepping on a hornet's nest.

title: The Bus Stops Here
description: A few of the thousands of New Jersey Transit commuters may soon have more comfortable surroundings in which to wait for the bus. The agency has approved $2 million to spruce up 16 of its 17,000 bus stops in a handful municipalities, not yet designated, though the stops will be busy ones. Depending on what the community wants, the shelters could be designed in a colonial or modern motif, and will include additional lighting, heat, areas for schedules and maps, pay telephones, newspaper dispensers and, in rural areas, landscaping. The sites could include bicycle racks or parking spaces, said Kelly Stewart Maer, a New Jersey Transit spokeswoman. The money also will be used to provide additional maintenance for the new shelters. More shelters will be redone in the future, if possible, Ms. Maer said.

Ripken had already punched his ticket to Cooperstown by playing in a record 2,632 consecutive games; that streak made him unique. Stan's daddy, an upright Baptist minister, is having an affair with a local lawyer, and when Stan's mom finds out, there'll be murder to pay. Meanwhile, another man's run-around wife turns up dead in the Orchid Motel, strangled with a piece of naughty underwear, and every philandering husband in the county is suspect. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITOFSKY, LYNNE (NEE MARY LINN BELLER)
description: PITOFSKY-Lynne (nee Mary Linn Beller). April 13, 2000 at Greenwich Hospital, CT. Lynne was the essence of goodness and sweetness. She was the most devoted, loving, caring wife, mother, daughter, ''nonni'' and friend. Her heart was full of love for so many people. One of her legacies was that she got great joy in bringing happiness to other people. She valued the happiness of the people she loved above her own. She had a joy of life that was unique. She saw each day as an adventure, filled with great promise and joy. Her bubbly effervescence was infectious. She entered a room with a sense of fun and exuberance. She lit up the lives of all the people she ever touched. She was such a sensitive person that, in her entire life, she never intentionally, every wanted to do or say anything that would hurt another person. We shared a love that we called ''our secret''. We felt that no other person could understand that two people could love so completely. She was a success at everything she did in her life. She enjoyed every stage of her life. She was a very successful actress, tennis player, real estate agent, but her greatest accomplishment was that she was the most wonderful, loving and devoted wife and mother. She leaves behind three wonderful sons who she poured love into and who will carry her in their hearts forever. I have been blessed to be able to share my life with someone who has brought me more happiness than I ever knew could exist. She loved her three wonderful grandchildren with all her heart. She only regretted that she wouldn't be here to share their lives. She was so thankful that her sons' wives became such wonderful, loving daughters. The moral of her life was to give and receive love freely and to make the most of every day as she did-Lynne, I love you, my wonderful soulmate.

Of course, further calculation would reveal that this means roughly three-fourths of American workers are not free agents, which hardly qualifies as the hype-glazed factoid she accuses me of confecting.

title: Children's Books; Monkey Business
description: ''Caps! Caps for sale!'' Baby boomers remember that popular refrain from the classic children's book ''Caps for Sale,'' the 1947 version by Esphyr Slobodkina. Based on a folk tale, that much loved and best-selling book tells the story of a distinctly Slavic hat peddler who finds his wares stolen by a treeful of devilishly naughty monkeys. In his new book, The Hatseller and the Monkeys (Scholastic, $15.95; ages 3 and up), Baba Wague Diakite has returned this simple story to its African roots. Diakite, who was born and raised in a small village in Mali, recalls hearing the story of BaMusa and the monkeys as a boy. In this version, the hat seller, BaMusa, is a peddler who traverses the countryside, his head piled high with wide-brimmed dibiri hats and closefitting fugulan caps. The progeny of a long line of hat sellers, the joyful BaMusa sings ''Hee manun nin koi kadi sa'' (''What a wonderful business hat selling is'') as he walks from town to town. One day, rushing off to a festival, BaMusa skips breakfast. Hungry and tired, he stops to nap under a tree, and while he is sleeping, mischievous monkeys steal his hats. But it isn't until BaMusa fills his stomach with mangoes the monkeys have thrown at him that he is able to outsmart them and get his hats back. The moral of the story: it is with a full stomach that one thinks best. As he did in his earlier book, ''The Hunterman and the Crocodile,'' Diakite has beautifully illustrated ''The Hatseller and the Monkeys'' with vivid, African-inspired ceramic-tile paintings. Each double-page spread is completely framed by a black-and-white frieze of playful monkeys linked tail to tail, adding energy and wit to the colorful, detailed illustrations and text. A word of advice for parents and other adult narrators: Before you read this book aloud to your children, go through it once without a young audience. Otherwise you may find yourself stumbling over some of the tongue-twisting West African speech sprinkled throughout. And check the author's note for help pronouncing BaMusa's song, which you may want to sing yourself. ''Hee manun'' is both ''an expression of joy and a plea for help.'' Linda Villarosa

title: Opening Eyes To a Kubrick Masterpiece
description: STANLEY KUBRICK'S death last spring, followed by the release of ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' revived a long-running argument among critics and fans about whether Kubrick was one of the most important contemporary filmmakers or merely among the most self-important -- an avatar of cinematic perfection or a cold, detached perfectionist. The debate shows no signs of ending any time soon. Last month, Vanity Fair published a long, passionate defense of Kubrick, and in particular of his widely unloved last work, by his friend and sometime collaborator Michael Herr. And beginning Friday, Film Forum will provide fuel for many nights of heated cafe-table contention as it mounts a three-week retrospective of the director's work, ranging from the limpid black-and-white of ''Killer's Kiss'' to the deep red of ''Eyes Wide Shut'' -- from Kirk Douglas to Jack Nicholson to Tom Cruise.

title: Amid the Stock Market's Losses, A Sense the Game Has Changed

Mullin, a 23-year-old broker, tugged at his tie as he explained how he had spent much of Friday afternoon. As the market plummeted, Mr. Mullin was making ''margin calls'' on investors who had bought losing stocks with borrowed money. Those investors now had to put up more cash as collateral or sell their shares to pay off their loans.

title: With Friends Like Saul Bellow

Chicago was entering a renaissance under a new mayor; this official party was a symbol of progress, so a local television station covered it. The results are unremarkable. You see a provincial celebration of a hometown boy -- ''Chicago's greatest writer'' -- made good. An opera singer comes out (Bellow and Bloom both loved opera) and performs ''Che gelida manina'' from ''La Boheme,'' rattling the microphone in its stand. Bellow looks more frightened than pleased.

title: SECRETS OF HISTORY: The C.I.A. in Iran -- A special report.; How a Plot Convulsed Iran in '53 (and in '79)

One by one, participants have retired or died without revealing key details, and the Central Intelligence Agency said a number of records of the operation -- its first successful overthrow of a foreign government -- had been destroyed.

title: Ousting Snowmobiles From Yellowstone
description: Most midwinter days, a triple or quadruple line of snowmobiles gathers on the snow-packed roadway at the West Yellowstone, Mont., entrance to Yellowstone National Park. In some ways, the scene looks much the same as it does in midsummer, when the entrance is crowded with cars and R.V.'s. But there is a difference. Snowmobiles are much noisier. They snarl and whine and pop. They also run on two-cycle engines, which emit far greater amounts of hydrocarbons and particulate matter than automobiles do. In winter, fresh air is pumped to the ranger station at the entrance, so bad is the pollution there. Once inside the park, snowmobilers travel snow-packed highways that are the main corridors for bison, which find it hard to negotiate Yellowstone's deep snows. Encounters between machine and beast occur every day, and harassment is routine.

title: Putin Wins START-2
description: Vladimir V. Putin, president-elect of Russia, won ratification of the START-2 treaty, which calls for halving American and Russian nuclear arsenals. The parliament had blocked the treaty for seven years. The passage, Mr. Putin's first legislative initiative since his election, was viewed as a sign that he seeks not only a constructive relationship with the West but also intends to fight hard to block American efforts to revise or abandon earlier arms-control treaties. The treaty must still be approved by the upper house, and the United States Senate has yet to approve several features. MICHAEL R. GORDON

title: Outside the Temple, Old Japan for Sale
description: WITH their clusters of pagoda-roofed structures set among groves of trees, temple and shrine enclosures in the cities and towns of Japan are like small ancient kingdoms left behind from another time as the bustle of modern life eddies around them. During the Tokugawa period (1603-1867), so writes the historian Sumiko Enbutsu in ''Old Tokyo,'' temple towns were first built on the periphery of old Edo, now Tokyo, to fortify the city against military invasions, which never happened. The forecourts of these compounds, once populated with religious pilgrims, eventually became gathering places and fairgrounds for people of fashion.

title: Books in Brief: Poetry; Arriving Inside the Object
description: In SELECTED EARLY POEMS (Braziller, $22), an expanded and revised edition of his ''Selected Poems, 1963-1983,'' Charles Simic shows that he is among the very few poets for whom surrealism is a genuine vision, a tool of discovery, rather than a collection of arbitrary shocks. Like the ''explorers'' in his poem of that name, who ''arrive inside / The object'' as ''The lamps they carry / Cast their shadows / Back into their own minds,'' his skewed vision manages both to capture the alien concreteness of things and to make them reflect his own consciousness. In a series of early poems, an ordinary ''old spoon'' is seen ''Ready to scratch / Today's date / And your name / On the bare wall''; a fork ''resembles a bird's foot / Worn around the cannibal's neck.'' Sometimes this vision turns into black comedy, as in ''Bedtime Story'': ''When a tree falls in a forest / And there's no one around / To hear the sound, the poor owls / Have to do all the thinking. / They think so hard they fall off / Their perch and are eaten by ants, / Who, as you already know, all look like / Little Black Riding Hoods.'' And when Simic, who was a child in Yugoslavia during World War II, recalls the horrors he saw there, his hard, plain style and dark vision are both explained and confirmed: ''I'm told but do not believe / that that summer I witnessed / men hung from telephone poles.'' His skill and sure instinct make this book one of the important poetic achievements of our time. Adam Kirsch

title: King Pops Into Picture As Vargas Joins Elite
description: Fernando Vargas joined boxing's elite Saturday night and was rewarded with more than a unanimous decision over Ike Quartey.

title: Youths From Australia Light the Old, Dare the New
description: The Australian Chamber Orchestra turns 25 this year, but one would never think it looking at its members onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night. Few of the 17 string players looked over 30, and some, I suspect, were scarcely born when this band began. Appropriately youthful as well is its leader both as violinist and conductor, Richard Tognetti.

title: Critic's Notebook: Winner Is . . . the Prize and the Architect; Koolhaas, a Guiding Force in Modern Theory Since 1978, Gets the Pritzker
description: Rem Koolhaas, perhaps the most influential architect of his generation, has been awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize for 2000, which the Hyatt Foundation, sponsors of the award, plans to announce today. The prize includes a $100,000 grant and will be presented in Jerusalem on May 17.

title: Talks to Avert Strike by Doormen Intensify
description: Negotiators for the real estate industry and the union representing workers at 2,900 New York City apartment buildings said yesterday that they made modest progress in talks last week, but still need to settle some major differences to avoid a strike this Friday.

title: Willard J. Smith, 89, Ex-Coast Guard Chief
description: Adm. Willard J. Smith, who was commandant of the Coast Guard from 1966 to 1970, died on April 1 at a nursing home in Atlantic Beach, Fla. He was 89.

title: Mr. Bush's New Look
description: A month ago, Gov. George W. Bush was a battered victor in the presidential race, seemingly beholden to right-wing leaders who had rescued his candidacy. Vice President Al Gore appeared set to dominate the issues with proposals on health, children, schools and the environment. But lately Mr. Bush has shifted tactics -- releasing a barrage of domestic proposals, appearing at urban schools and meeting with gay Republicans. He seems eager to retrieve the ''compassionate conservative'' label and flesh it out. The governor's proposals have good features and flaws. They are also costly and somewhat undercut by his Texas record. But they bring a welcome new phase to the campaign.

title: China Makes Gains in Spurring Growth
description: China's economy showed surprising signs of strength in the first quarter, suggesting that a slide in the nation's economic growth rate may be ending.

title: Jones Begins Olympic Quest With Stunning Victory in 400
description: The 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, are still five months away, but Marion Jones held an important audition today. And she passed with astounding success to send a message that her attempt at five Olympic gold medals must be taken seriously.

title: In America; A Blue Web
description: Zaher (Zack) Zahrey was a police detective with a spotless record when certain malevolent forces of the criminal justice system in New York began to close in on him. It was a case of a corrupt and treacherous system devouring one of its own. Detective Zahrey would spend several humiliating months in jail and his career would be ruined before he was finally exonerated by a jury that took only 10 minutes to reach a verdict.

title: Man Arrested in Assault Of 9-Month-Old Baby
description: A 9-month-old girl was assaulted by her mother's boyfriend on Saturday night, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; Valentine Revisiting Mistakes of Martin
description: THE similarity is inescapable. Call them birds of a feather or two of a kind, two peas in a pod, psychological twins. Billy Martin was and Bobby Valentine is one of the most tactically accomplished managers in baseball. Both, however, have had damaging ways of undermining their talent. Martin did it and Valentine does it with his mouth. For Martin, it was ingesting alcohol; for Valentine, it is disgorging words.

description: The sweet scent of jasmine wafted up the leafy hillsides, the lights of Los Angeles twinkled below, and the cash register ca-CHINGed until it was stuffed with $2.8 million.

title: No-Stars Provide Final Touch on Perfect Homestand
description: These were your defending World Series champion Yankees yesterday. The starting pitcher had not started a game in almost four years. The starting catcher had not started behind the plate in 10 months and had no hits this season. The starting left fielder had managed a grand total of four hits. The first pitcher out of the bullpen was making his second major league appearance. Welcome to Yankee Stadium.

description: The phrase most often used by friend and foe alike to describe British Prime Minister Tony Blair is ''control freak.''

title: Chat Rooms Pin the Blame On Analysts and the Media
description: As the technology-heavy Nasdaq market rose to stratospheric heights, nowhere was the cheering harder than in the investing chat rooms on the Internet. The many investors who helped propel new Internet shares to great heights crowed about their trading successes in these online forums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITUCHY, PHILIP HAROLD
description: LITUCHY-Philip Harold. Born February 15, 1926 after a long and bitter struggle with emphysema, April 14 in FL, formerly of Oceanside, NY. Source of great inspiration to sons Richard and Barry, adored father-in-law to Barbara and Roberta, beloved Grampa to Max, Sam, and Rebecca, Natasha and Nicholas. Cherished friend to all. We love you. Your accomplishments are numerous and significant to thousands. A builder of buildings, a builder of homes, and most important, a builder of dreams and happiness to all those who were honored and privileged to know you. Funeral Monday, April 17, 12:00 PM; Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

description: To the Editor:

title: For the Devils, Sounds of the Past Have Returned
description: Lou Lamoriello, that old boat rocker, wants to change the system. A conservative on many hockey issues, the president and general manager of the Devils is bucking a trend by expanding the role of a real, live organ player for the Stanley Cup playoffs in Continental Arena.

title: An Appraisal; From the Guggenheim, a Bold Vision for a Lower Manhattan Museum
description: How many ways can you say ''Wow''? In the weeks ahead New Yorkers will certainly find more articulate words to describe Frank O. Gehry's design for a museum that the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation hopes to build along the East River in Lower Manhattan. Silence would be eloquent, too. But only for the repressed. Otherwise, this is the moment to look for noisemakers left over from New Year's Eve and give them one more toot. Here comes architecture.

title: Mayor to Sign Bill Renaming Street for Police Choking Victim
description: Calling the death a ''terrible thing'' that ''should never have happened,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he intended to sign a City Council bill renaming a Bronx street in honor of a 29-year man who died in 1994 after he was choked by a New York City police officer during a dispute over a late-night football game.

title: From Cell, Coalition Looked Like a Movement
description: As he sees it, Mike Saltz spent Saturday night in jail for exercising his natural-born rights of free speech and peaceable assembly.

title: Ex-Coke Workers Start Trip To Publicize Racial Dispute
description: A busload of about four dozen former employees of the Coca-Cola Company and activists began a five-day trip Saturday to draw attention to their frustrations with the soft drink company. Their journey will end Wednesday at the Coca-Cola annual shareholder meeting in Wilmington, Del.

title: New Economy; The big recording companies might be able to embrace Internet sales if they could just find the right technology.
description: THE major record companies BMG and Sony Music Entertainment recently announced long-awaited plans to sell their music online via digital downloads. But the fine print suggests mainstream Internet users are not going to buy their music digitally any time soon.

title: Miami Area's Mayors Ride a Volatile Political Wave
description: What excites Miami's Cuban-Americans about Elian Gonzalez is that his case presents the best opportunity in decades, since the failed Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, to humiliate Fidel Castro. But domestic conflicts are stirring this pot, too, and threatening Miami and its two top politicians with their own Bay of Pigs.

title: Family in Texas Challenges Mandatory School Drug Test
description: For three years, people in this tiny farming town fretted that stopping the local drug problem was like trying to lasso the winds that blow day and night off the flat Texas plains. Teachers complained of students' getting stoned at lunch. Parents worried about peer pressure at school to get high.

title: Giants Go Long Shot in the 3rd Round
description: For all but one pick during this weekend's National Football League draft, the Giants made choices that were reasoned, rational and, perhaps most surprising of all, predictable.

title: Editors Struggle to Increase Ethnic Mix of Newsrooms
description: Rick Rodriguez, the executive editor of The Sacramento Bee, got the bad news shortly after arriving at the annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors last week. Twice in the last few months he had fended off competitors who wanted to hire away one of his best young reporters; now the same reporter was calling to say he was leaving to join a flourishing magazine, with salaries much higher than The Bee's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANOM, WAYNE T.
description: BRANOM-Wayne T., Ed.D, died on Saturday, April 8th, 2000 at age 91 in Lakewood, New Jersey. Beloved husband of the late Marie Speth, devoted father of Wayne T. Branom, Jr., M.D. of Greenwich, CT and Nancy Branom Genieser, M.D. of New York City. Devoted father-in-law of Helen Louise Branom & Werner Genieser. Devoted grandfather of Janice Holappa, Hillary Cassidy, Wayne T. Branom III, W. Robert Genieser, Jr., Kevin Genieser and three great-grandchildren. Former superintendent of schools Carteret, New Jersey, and Hillside, NJ. Taught post graduate courses at Northwestern University, New York University, and Keene College. Received doctorate of education degree from New York University in 1941. Member of Phi Beta Kappa, Kappa Delta Phi. Past President of the New Jersey Association of School Administration, Hillside Rotary Club. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABRIN, GEORGE J.
description: SABRIN-George J., M.D. 86, of Manhasset and Westhampton Beach died peacefully March 31. He is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Alma; his children Russell of Atlanta, GA, Douglas of Manhasset, Amy of Washington, D.C., and Pamela of NYC; grandchildren Adam, Michael and Lucy; and sister Alice Gordon of Great Neck. Dr. Sabrin was a retired General Practitioner who served his patients for over 50 years. Born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, he attended Boy's High School and Columbia College. He earned his medical degree from the University of Edinburgh, College of Physicians & Surgeons and completed his residency at Mt. Sinai Hospital. During WWII, Dr. Sabrin served as a Major in the Air Force, stationed in the South Pacific. Dr. Sabrin played semi-pro baseball in the UK with the Wembley Lions and was a founding member of the Aspatuck Tennis Club of Westhampton Beach. Services were held April 2, Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Mt. Sinai Alumni, Box 1015, 1 Gustav L. Levy Pl., NY, NY 10029.
