title: Ulster Unionist Leader Disavows Militants
description: In a determined move to free himself from growing internal opposition to the Northern Ireland peace agreement, David Trimble, Ulster's most prominent Protestant politician, said today that he would rid his party governing council of members of the traditionally militant Orange Order.

title: I.M.F. Points to Big Accomplishment: It Met as Scheduled
description: Delegates looked bleary-eyed after their predawn wake-up calls, and a handful arrived several hours late. But the member nations of the International Monetary Fund achieved a major breakthrough today: They met.

title: Pentagon Urges Delay Of Arms Sales To Taiwan
description: The Pentagon has recommended deferring for at least a year a decision on Taiwan's request to purchase four sophisticated American destroyers, as well as diesel submarines and surveillance aircraft, a senior defense official said tonight.

title: Corrections

He was Gordon Scott. (Jock Mahoney was the first of Mr. Weintraub's Tarzans to appear in a non-African setting, in the 1962 film ''Tarzan Goes to India.'')

title: New Orleans Epitaph: Dead Man Shirts
description: Most of the people who gathered this morning for Donald Ray Davis's funeral were dressed in their Sunday best. But younger mourners, like Tara Lewis, 21, wore matching white T-shirts with a picture of Mr. Davis, 25, who died in a motorcycle accident last week, on the front.

description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Roba Is 26.2 Miles From a Spot in Boston History
description: Fatuma Roba's hair is pinched back, and small gold ovals dangle from her ear lobes, framing a regal face, with eyes that seem constantly fixed on the finish line.

title: Strategists in a Strange Land
description: Thomas McManus, equity strategist at Bank of America Securities, spent a lot of time on the phone over the weekend talking to clients and some time thumbing through two books from his library: ''The Great Crash, 1929'' by John Kenneth Galbraith and ''Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds,'' Charles Mackay's 19th-century classic about investment mania.

title: Corrections

A member proposed that an award category be created for short films -- not that it necessarily be given to Eugene Richards. (The jury created the award and gave it to Mr. Richards, for ''But, the Day Came.'')

title: The Wrong Way to Prevent Gun Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rebel Flag in South Carolina
description: When South Carolinians brag about their state, they typically talk about the beautiful beaches and the bustling industrial corridor between Spartanburg and Greenville. But the attempt to portray the Palmetto State as a good place to vacation and do business has been tarnished for years by the Legislature's refusal to remove the Confederate flag from the Statehouse dome. The flag continues to fly despite condemnation by the state's major business leaders and an economic boycott that has prompted sports figures and entertainers to decline appearances in the state.

title: Another Rain Delay
description: The rain-plagued PGA Seniors' Championship endured another delay yesterday, its sixth in four days, with the leaders barely under way when third-round play was suspended. Weather permitting, they will resume early today in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and the tournament, the second senior major of the year, will be reduced to 54 holes from 72.

title: Bach Rarity Hardly Sounds Like Bach
description: The juggernaut of a Bach year has already covered a lot of ground in New York, most of it down the middle of the road. For all the series and concerts commemorating the 250th anniversary of his death with blockbuster works or compilations of masterpieces, few attempts have been made to explore byways or to place Bach's music in the context of its time.

title: Brooklyn Politicians Ponder Borough President's Exit
description: While the cocktails and conversation swirled at the Brooklyn Democratic Party's annual dinner last week, and even when Hillary Rodham Clinton addressed the hundreds of people in the ballroom, there was one overwhelming topic of conversation: whether Howard Golden, the borough president, intends to step down before the end of his term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, HELEN FIRSTBROOK (HECTOR)
description: FRANKLIN - Helen Firstbrook (Hector). Died at Winter Park Memorial Hospital Tuesday, April 11. Mrs. Franklin was born in Plainfield, NJ, and grew up in Asbury Park. Mrs. Franklin worked as a reporter for the Asbury Park Press and the New York Herald Tribune. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin with a B.A. in Journalism. She was an editor with Reader's Digest, specializing in Latin America. She worked in the Reader's Digest editorial offices in Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires and Mexico City. Upon retirement, Mrs. Franklin was a Senior Editor, having been associated with the Reader's Digest for 38 years. Besides her editorial work, Mrs. Franklin was an accomplished photographer and has sold her photos through the Shostal Agency in New York to McCall's as well as travel magazines and the textbook markets. Mrs. Franklin is a member of the Board of the Americas Foundation, the U.S. Foundation of the University of the Valley of Guatemala, Museum of Northern Arizona and the Wisconsin Alumni Association. Mrs. Franklin is survived by her stepson Robert Hector of Farmington, CT, and two stepgrandchildren. Memorial service will be announced later.

title: Nets to Dismiss Casey as Coach at Season's End
description: The magnificent surviving act of Nets Coach Don Casey will come to an end shortly after the conclusion of what can only be categorized as a terribly disappointing season.

title: Zimbabwe's Leader Reverses Call for Squatters to Leave
description: Overruling his own deputy, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe announced today that his government would not ask black squatters to leave hundreds of white-owned farms despite escalating political violence this weekend that left three people dead.

title: Year Later, Columbine Is Learning to Cope While Still Searching for Answers
description: Almost a year has passed since a killing rampage here by two students thrust an otherwise ordinary high school into the vortex of national debates over gun rights, parental responsibilities, cultural violence and the nature of evil.

title: Justice Shepro, Connoisseur Of Old Clocks, Dies at 74
description: Justice W. Shepro, a lawyer and businessman who used his real estate fortune to transform himself into one of the nation's leading collectors of antique clocks, died in an automobile accident near Chicago on March 30. He was 74 and lived in Roscoe, Ill.

description: MONDERER-Max. Devoted husband of Jetty. Beloved father of Helen Adler and Leah Schulgasser. Adored grandfather. Shiva at 320 Riverside Dr., through Wednesday morning.

title: Fear of Prosecution Hinders Crash Inquiries, Some Say
description: Fear of prosecution or civil liability is stopping people in transportation industries from cooperating with crash investigators and making them hesitate to collect data that could aid safety efforts, senior accident investigators say.

title: FINANCIAL LEADERS MEET AS PROTESTS CLOG WASHINGTON
description: Thousands of protesters trying to shut down meetings of world financial leaders swarmed through the streets of the capital today, sealed off from their target by a virtual wall of police officers. A few brief clashes ensued, but for the most part, a day that some had feared would descend into chaos passed peacefully.

title: Conrad Black Assails Strikers' Allies, Too
description: Conrad Black, Canada's mightiest press baron, has long delighted in a muscular give-and-take of insults. But in his latest round, he may have overreached, going beyond usual left-wing and unionist targets, and landing a punch on the hierarchy of his adopted faith, Roman Catholicism.

description: Hannah Komanoff, the first woman elected to the Board of Supervisors in Nassau County, N.Y., died on Sunday at a hospital in Long Beach, on Long Island. She was 89.

title: Woman at Train Station Is Raped and Robbed
description: A woman was raped early yesterday by a man who followed her from a subway train onto a station platform, the police said.

title: Cabbies Ply Streets Warily on Tense Night Shift
description: It's Sunday morning, just after 2 -- a scant 24 hours after Jean Scutt, the new driver at Commodore Car Service, was shot dead -- and Brandi Turner is frazzled because Car 72's driver is squeezing the radio transmitter as he barrels across Brooklyn in his Lincoln Town Car.

title: Media Talk; Fashion Editor to Leave for Artists' Hive
description: John Cheever once wrote that Yaddo, the 107-year-old artists' colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., attracted ''all kinds -- lushes down on their luck, men and women at the top of their powers, nervous breakdowns, thieves, geniuses, cranky noblemen, and poets who ate their peas off a knife.''

title: Media Talk; Cigar Aficionado Tries a New Blend

description: Antonio Pinto of Portugal won the London marathon yesterday in 2 hours 6 minutes 36 seconds, defeating Khalid Khannouchi, the world record-holder, who finished third.

title: Impending Famine in Ethiopia
description: The images from the Horn of Africa are sadly familiar -- the hollow eyes of emaciated mothers, the stick-like limbs and distended bellies of dying children cradled in their arms. Fifteen years after a million of its people perished in a devastating famine, the specter of famine looms again in Ethiopia. A repeat of that disaster need not happen if the world reinforces a relief effort that could save hundreds of thousands of lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINREB, HERMAN
description: WEINREB-Herman, M.D. Passed away suddenly on April 14. A Clincal Associate Professor of Neurology at the NYU School of Medicine, Dr Weinreb was deeply compassionate and intensely devoted to his patients. The quintessential academic, he was an engaging teacher and innovative course director. He provided energetic leadersip to the Neurology Service of the Manhattan Veterans Administration Medical Center for many years and diligently fostered linkages between Psychiatry and Neurology. Herman was humble, kind, generous and full of humor. He will be sorely missed. Our faculty and staff mourn his untimely death and extend deepest sympathies to his beloved family. Edwin H. Kolodny, M.D. Department of Neurology NYU School of Medicine

title: Savvy Moves From Heroines, Night Owls and Flip-Flop Toys

No one style predominated, refreshingly, and the choreographers came from companies scattered throughout the nation.

title: A Foundation of Precision and Structure, With an Improvisational Sound on Top

This could be a benefit of working on commercial film scores, as Mr. Blanchard has done for a decade, in which moods have to be as clearly delineated as the visual scenes they accompany. But his music also upholds a jazz tradition of sharp, clear writing that has been languishing since the 1950's.

title: How I Lost My Good Name
description: I am one of some 30,000 people who discovered last year that their Social Security numbers had been pilfered. The theft of my identity actually began in 1996, when I was living overseas. Without my knowledge, someone had used my Social Security number to order telephone service in Los Angeles County, then disappeared, owing the phone companies thousands of dollars. I moved back to New York City in 1997 and rented an apartment, but in time, the phone companies sent the unpaid bills to collection agencies and the agencies, unable to recover the debts, passed the information on to three major national credit bureaus. I was labeled a financial delinquent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOODY, ALFRED G. S., JR.
description: MOODY-Alfred G. S., Jr. Age 69 of Ridgewood, died Saturday, April 15, 2000, at the Valley Hospital, Ridgewood. Alfred grew up in Brooklyn and lived in New York City before moving to Ridgewood 33 years ago. He was a 1948 graduate of Poly Prep Country Day School, Brooklyn, a 1952 Graduate of Yale University and a 1955 Graduate of Harvard Law School. Mr. Moody was a Vice President of the Irving Trust Company, now the Bank of New York in New York City for 35 years before retiring in 1989. He was a member of Westside Presbyterian Church, Ridgewood, where he served as a Deacon. He was a member of Activities Unlimited in Wyckoff and the Hobbyists of Ridgewood. Surviving is his wife Judy (nee Vought) Moody; a son, Alfred G. S. Moody III of Montebello, NY; a daughter, Courtenay Szakats and son-in-law John of Skillman, NJ; 2 granddaughters, Caroline Moody Szakats and Kimberley Christine Szakats, and a sister, Caroline Moody Roberts of Sewickley, PA. Funeral service Wednesday, 11 AM, at Westside Presbyterian Church, 6 South Monroe St., Ridgewood, NJ. Interment will be private in the Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn. Visiting Tuesday, 6-9 PM, at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to Poly Prep Country Day School, 9216 Seventh Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11228-3698 or Westside Presbyterian Church, 6 South Monroe St., Ridgewood, NJ 07450 would be appreciated.

So in the hours between midnight and dawn, they sip rich, black Cuban coffee to stay alert, and occasionally scream ''Elian!'' and ''Libertad!'' just to remind the United States government that it better not try to break into the house in Little Havana and take Elian Gonzalez on their watch.

On the following Monday, so many of them decided to sell that the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 22.6 percent, or 508 points. Oct. 19, 1987, became known as Black Monday.

Whenever artificially generated clouds of gray start drifting moodily across a stage, abrading the eyes and throats of the audience while bringing to mind spook houses at school carnivals, it's usually an indication that the flame of imagination is burning low. This doesn't mean that your instinct to bolt for the nearest exit isn't a good one.

He was 75 and lived in Yarmouth Port, Mass.

Yet through isolation, entrepreneurship and stubborn good taste, it survives in certain enclaves, passing on its secrets to the musicians who value them. Galactic, from New Orleans, and the North Mississippi All Stars, from Independence, Miss., who shared a bill at Irving Plaza on Saturday night, are both dedicated to building a party with the lessons of the past.

title: Patents; An accidental harp, via eBay, sets off a successful search for the origins of 19th-century artisanship.
description: IN the 1890's, a man named George Durkee lived in Chicago and worked as a shop foreman at Lyon & Healy Harps Inc. Not much is known about him -- at one point, a fire destroyed company records -- except that he supervised workers who assembled harps. Some elegant concert harps were built from Mr. Durkee's own designs, and he won several patents just as the 19th century came to a close. Over the next few decades, and especially after the fire, his name disappeared from company documents and his contribution to harp design was forgotten.

title: CORPORATE PATRIARCH IS AILING
description: Enrico Cuccia, 92, founder and honorary chairman of Mediobanca S.p.A., is in intensive care in a Milan hospital. The poor health of Italy's most powerful financier prompted speculation that the company would be vulnerable to takeover. Under Mr. Cuccia, Mediobanca has pulled the strings of Italian finance for more than half a century through its shareholdings in many of Italy's biggest companies. Without Mr. Cuccia to hold the company together, many of those companies and Mediobanca itself could become takeover targets, analysts said.

title: ASHANTI'S PROFIT TUMBLES
description: Africa's No. 3 gold producer, the Ashanti Goldfields Company, said its fourth-quarter profit fell 73 percent because of lower gold prices. The company's profit from operations fell to $3.3 million from $12.2 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. After exceptional items, the company had a loss of $229.8 million in the fourth quarter. The Ghana-based Ashanti, which neared bankruptcy last year, received an average of $351 an ounce for its gold in the quarter, compared with $385 an ounce in 1998, more than offsetting a rise in production. The company's gold output rose 4 percent to 437,222 ounces in the three months ended Dec. 31.

The move comes less than a year after Carlisle tried to buy all of Titan for about $600 million in stock. That acquisition fell apart after the Carlisle's stock dropped almost a quarter last year. Carlisle, based in Syracuse, will become the top supplier of tires for all-terrain vehicles and riding lawn mowers. Titan's consumer tire and wheel business had more than $100 million in 1999 sales.

But apart from his curatorial and interpretive work on behalf of other composers, Mr. Sheffer has been writing works of his own. His latest, a chamber opera setting of Gertrude Stein's ''Blood on the Dining-Room Floor,'' which opened at the Peter Norton Space on Sunday evening, shows that he has an encyclopedic command of contemporary styles, if not a particularly original musical voice. More to the point, though, he has an ear for theatrical pacing and a sense of humor, both of which clarify Stein's stream-of-consciousness writing.

title: Foreign Affairs; BizCzarism
description: The Russian political analyst Sergei Markov was trying to explain to me over tea the other day the state of the Russian state: ''If you look at it from far away,'' he said, ''the Russian state looks like a big [Charles] Atlas, full of muscles. But as you get closer you realize that this Atlas is actually dead. Inside, this huge body is full of worms, who are eating the body and feeding off it. Sometimes an arm or a leg moves a little, but that's not because Atlas is alive, it's because the worms have moved an arm or leg. It's a very depressing and ugly state.''

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture grouping in some editions on Sunday showing the 31 players chosen in the first round of the National Football League draft reversed the identities of the second and third athletes chosen. LaVar Arrington, the second player selected, was shown in Picture 3, and Chris Samuels, selected third, was shown in No. 2.

title: AMERADA HESS INVESTS IN ALGERIA
description: The ninth-largest United States oil company, the Amerada Hess Corporation, agreed to spend $555 million in an Algerian venture as part of a plan to increase output abroad. The agreement is Amerada Hess's first exploration investment in Algeria. Hess will take a 49 percent stake in a joint venture with the state-owned Sonatrach to develop the El Gassi, El Agreb and Zotti fields in the center of Algeria, which are estimated to hold 300 million barrels of oil.

title: MYPOINTS.COM TO BUY CYBERGOLD FOR $157 MILLION
description: MyPoints.com Inc., an Internet-based direct marketer, said yesterday that it would pay roughly $157 million in stock for Cybergold Inc., a direct marketer that rewards customers with cash. Each share of Cybergold, based in Oakland, Calif., will be exchanged for 0.48 share of MyPoints.com. MyPoints, based in San Francisco, gives Web surfers who respond to advertisements points that can be used to buy merchandise. The stock of MyPoints was down $1.4375 a share at $13.50, while Cybergold's shares were up 18.75 cents at $5.6875.

title: A Literary Elder Statesman Savors Its Staying Power
description: The editor and the publisher of Harper's magazine, the oldest literary monthly in the United States, are not complacently waiting for the magazine's 150th anniversary to roll around in June. Starting tonight they are initiating a yearlong celebration, beginning with a Brooklyn Public Library exhibition of rare books, artwork and artifacts related to Herman Melville, Walt Whitman and other contributors to the magazine. The eveninglong event, which is for subscribers, friends of the library and invited guests, starts at 6.

title: Killings of Livery Drivers Prompt Police to Step Up Measures
description: The outcry over the slayings of livery-cab drivers prompted new steps to combat the attacks yesterday, as the Police Department fleshed out its plans to protect drivers and the mayor proposed further steps to safeguard them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Secrets of Fuel for Creative Fires Unlocked
description: The rich may be different, as the saying goes, but the richly creative are different still. Just what goes on inside the head of an artist or a poet, however, is a mystery.

title: Signs Point to a Delay in Cuban Boy's Case
description: The standoff between the United States government and Miami's Cuban exiles over Elian Gonzalez remained locked in place today, as the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit considered whether to grant family members here an emergency stay that would delay his return to Cuba until the court hears the full appeal in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, IDA
description: SIMON-Ida. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of the beloved mother of their devoted member Charlotte Simon and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Worlds of Difference in Facing Strike Threat; Upper East Side Co-op Goes on War Footing
description: The residents of 520 East 86th Street need not fear a strike of their building staff. They have, after all, a ''2000 Strike Preparedness Handbook.'' They have a route that paramedics can use if the service elevator is unmanned. They have memos to tell them what to do and memos reminding them about those memos.

title: Mets' Jones Is Placed On the Disabled List With a Calf Injury
description: The Mets will use the veteran knuckleballer Dennis Springer to take the place of Bobby J. Jones in their starting rotation. Jones, as expected, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with a strained right calf muscle, and General Manager Steve Phillips said he could miss up to four weeks.

title: Coach Says Knicks May Feel Lakers Are Invincible
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy has told the Knicks that they may not make it out of the first round of the playoffs if they do not play with more intensity, and he suggested today that they might be conceding this year's National Basketball Association title to the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISEL, SIDNEY
description: MEISEL-Sidney. On April 17, 2000. Beloved husband of Doris (Seligman) and the late Grace. Loving father of Louis K. and Susan P. Meisel, Elliott and Mimi Meisel, Claudia and Michael Whiteley, Michael and Laura Seligman, Abbott Seligman, Margo and Milo Pulde. Cherished and adored grandfather of Sara, Danny, Ari, Tanna, Kira, Travis, Jake, Jared, Mark, Harley, Averi, Sasha, and Mason. Services are on Wednesday at 9:45 A.M., ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: First-Quarter Earnings Beat Expectations At 2 Banks
description: Bank of America and Bank of New York reported first-quarter profits yesterday that beat expectations, powered by surging stocks. After last week's sell-off, however, they might be hard-pressed to post similarly strong future results.

description: April 18, 2000

title: Clouds of Insects
description: Q. When I was a child, clouds of bugs used to hit the windshield on vacation drives. What were they?

title: Hunt Oil Is Thwarted in a Canadian Hostile-Takeover Attempt
description: Ulster Petroleums Ltd. of Calgary foiled a hostile takeover attempt by the Hunt Oil Company of Dallas today, agreeing to a richer offer from a crosstown rival, Anderson Exploration.

title: TELEFONICA QUITS BRITISH AUCTION
description: With total bids soaring beyond $33 billion, Telefonica S.A. of Spain pulled out of a six-week-old auction for five licenses to operate a new generation of mobile phones in Britain. That left six companies including Britain's four existing mobile phone operators, Telesystem International Wireless of Canada and the New York-based NTL Inc., which is backed by France Telecom. Under the auction's rules, the bidding will stop when only five players remain. Alan Cowell

title: Clinton Hopes to Raise Indian Internet Use
description: Moved by the story of a young American Indian girl who won a free computer but lacked a telephone to hook it up to the Internet, President Clinton today announced a program to offer low-cost phone service on the nation's Indian reservations as a first step toward integrating American Indians into the information age.

title: Sotheby's Resumes Auctions of Fine Wines
description: Sotheby's resumed wine auctions on Saturday, five months after it broke with its longtime partner, the East Side wine merchant Sherry-Lehman.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Magazine
description: A federal judge said today that she intended to dismiss a lawsuit against Rolling Stone magazine over an article it published about an antidrug program that contained fabrications by its author, Stephen Glass.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''For us, it is a step forward in our relationship. But without the family and all that baggage.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CORNING INC., Corning, N.Y., which makes glass and fiber optic products, and PPG Industries Inc., Pittsburgh, which makes glass and coatings, said they would take $35 million charges to write off their investments in a joint venture, Pittsburgh Corning Corp., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, TRUDE
description: WEIL-Trude. On April 15, 2000. Loving wife of the late Fred Weil. Devoted mother of Simon and Joyce. Dear mother-in-law of Peter Holt. Cherished grandmother of Rachel. Loving sister of Anny. Services on Monday, April 17, at 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: KOREAN BAD-LOAN REPORT
description: The value of bad loans at South Korean banks, brokerage firms and finance companies rose 15 percent in the final three months of 1999, as the government tightened the classification of delinquent loans. Loans for which interest has not been paid for more than three months rose to 66.7 trillion won ($60 billion) at the end of last year, up from 57.9 trillion won in September. With 590.2 trillion won in total loans, the percentage of that turned delinquent rose to 11.3 percent, from 10.1 percent. Without the new banking rules, bad loans would have dropped 11 percent, as Korea's rapid economic recovery enabled more borrowers to pay interest and repay debt, the Financial Supervisory Commission said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about new icebergs that have formed in Antarctica included an erroneous calculation by scientists at the University of Wisconsin for the volume of water contained in the largest one. It is 600 trillion to 1,000 trillion gallons, not 3.4 trillion.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Protesters and the Bank
description: If the goal of protesters in Washington was to stop the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank from meeting, or shut them down entirely, they clearly failed. The numbers of people who descended on the capital were smaller than expected, and the Washington police engaged in pre-emptive arrests to stop disruptions. Still, the so-called Mobilization for Economic Justice did manage to create havoc throughout the capital over the last three days and call attention to tensions related to the growth of the global economy. There was little from the protesters about how the fund and the bank could be improved instead of scrapped.

title: FRONT ROW
description: Prada Gets a Prize Winner

title: Is Spending Rise Below Inflation? Depends on the Measure
description: The arrival of a new state fiscal year leads to another in a long series of lessons in how numbers -- normally so reassuringly immutable -- can become, in Albany hands, as easy to grasp as sand.

title: Anticipating Future Deficits, Giuliani Trims His Tax Cut Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani intends to release a budget today that dramatically scales back a three-year tax cut package he proposed in January, top mayoral aides said yesterday.

title: Taking a Leap Into Opera With a Rossini Chirpfest
description: Orpheus stepped out of its familiar role as a virtuoso chamber orchestra and offered itself as an accompanying ensemble on Saturday evening, when it offered a concert version of Rossini's ''Signor Bruschino'' at Carnegie Hall. For anyone who has followed the orchestra's progress over the years, this was a puzzling move: Orpheus has always prided itself on its performances of intricate, demanding orchestral scores, in interpretations reached by consensus, without the guidance of a conductor.

title: Kodak Net Up 15% For First Quarter
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest photography company, said today that its first-quarter profit rose 15 percent as cost cutting made up for stagnant United States film sales.

title: Missing State Dept. Computer Prompts Call for Investigation
description: A top Republican lawmaker vowed today to investigate security lapses at the State Department, a day after officials there disclosed the disappearance of a laptop computer containing highly sensitive information.

title: In Britain, Putin Finds Reform Popular, but Not Chechen War
description: In his first visit to the West since winning office, Russia's president-elect, Vladimir V. Putin, today courted foreign businessmen, met with the queen and offered some unsolicited advice on the stock market.

title: Abram Chayes, John Kennedy Aide, Dies at 77
description: Abram Chayes, a professor of international law at Harvard for more than 40 years and a top State Department official in the Kennedy administration, died on Sunday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 77.

description: PASSICK-Naomi. The Board of Trustees of The Village of Saltaire is greatly saddened by the passing of Naomi Passick, feisty, funny, loving, one-of-a-kind, friend to everyone. Our deepest sympathies to Irving, David and Louise and their families. Martin M. Berger, Mayor

title: VENEZUELA-CHINA FUEL DEAL
description: Venezuela reached an agreement with China to build a $300 million plant to produce an alternative fuel known as orimulsion. The China National Petroleum Corporation plans to use orimulsion, a fuel made from bitumen, an organic matter found in the Orinoco River region of Venezuela, to complement coal consumption. Simon Romero

title: Bethlehem Is Raising Steel Plate Price 6%
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the third-largest United States steel maker, said today that it would increase plate prices by 6 percent, or $20 a ton, after its No. 1 rival in the United States, the USX-U.S. Steel Group, announced the same move.

title: Ad agencies are warily sizing up their dot-com clients after the market maelstrom.
description: THE recent abrupt shift in how Wall Street and Main Street perceive the prospects of Internet companies is having a significant effect on Madison Avenue. As the dot-com shakeout proceeds with the gyrations of the stock markets, agencies are warily watching to see how they will be affected as the winners and losers in cyberspace are decided.

title: A Closer Look
description: To the Editor:

title: When Playoffs Get Going, So Does Devils' Stevens
description: When it's Stanley Cup playoff time, the Devils' Scott Stevens is at his best. At the age of 36, Stevens seems to be back in the form he displayed in 1995, when he combined with Claude Lemieux and Martin Brodeur to lead the Devils to a Stanley Cup championship.

title: Art + Physics = Beautiful Music
description: Can the sense of acoustic intimacy created by a fine concert hall be measured in how many milliseconds it takes sound waves to ricochet from the walls and balconies and reach a listener in the seats? Can a hall's aural warmth be calculated from how efficiently bass notes rebound from the same surfaces? Can the prized quality called resonance be estimated from the rate at which the entire hall fades to silence after a blast of electronic sound?

description: MONDERER-Max. Adler and Leah (and Rabbi Chanoch) Schulgasser; and cherished grandfather. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINER, IRWIN
description: CINER-Irwin. Of Harrison, New York, on April 15, 2000, at the age of 97. Beloved husband of the late Marian Goldschmidt, caring father of Pat Hill and Liz Jackson, and father-in-law of David Hill and Brooke Jackson, loving grandfather of Jean and Douglas Hill, and Jeffrey, Brett and Jennie Jackson. Irwin, and his late brother Charles, were a driving force in America's move from precious to fashion jewelry in the late 1930's. The 108 year old Ciner Fashion Jewelry Company is the last of the old time jewelry manufacturers to continue as a family business.

title: Bush Strategy Recalls Clinton on the Trail in '96
description: Gov. George W. Bush has let it be known that he considers it fighting words to be compared to Bill Clinton. Still, it is hard to watch the Texas governor wend his way from schoolhouse to health clinic without recalling President Clinton's 1996 campaign.

title: Poor Henry! He's So Clever, So Glib . . . So Vulnerable
description: Now here is a man you would surely love to have at your table at one of those insufferably self-important dinner parties. He speaks in sentences that might have been cut by a jeweler; he banishes conversational cliches by merely cocking an eyebrow, and he has somehow turned undergraduate self-consciousness into a highly evolved form of charm.

title: Bryn Terfel Cancels
description: The baritone Bryn Terfel has withdrawn from the New York Philharmonic's concert performances of ''Sweeney Todd,'' May 4 through May 6 at Avery Fisher Hall, because he is recovering from surgery. He will be replaced by George Hearn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELGAIS, MARISA
description: DELGAIS-Marisa. On April 14, 2000. It is with deepest sorrow and much regret that Valentina Lima Delgais announces the passing of her beloved mother and mentor. A pioneer of industry as the first woman ''builder and developer'' of New York real estate at a time when female executives were still thought of as ''glorified secretaries'' and ''honey'' was yet to be replaced with ''Ms.'' She earned the respect and admiration, and added a little magic, to those whose lives she touched. She will be particulary missed by her grandson Madison Marco Lima and Mr. Carlo Lima. Still too young. I love you, Mom. Visitation Tuesday 6-9 PM, John Krtil Funeral Home; Yorkville Funeral Service Inc., 1297 First Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday 10 AM, St. John the Martyr Church, 250 East 72 St., NYC. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: House Passes Campaign Bill In Hartford
description: Setting up a showdown with Gov. John G. Rowland, state Democratic leaders rammed a bill through Connecticut's House of Representatives today that would provide public money for state political campaigns and subject candidates to voluntary spending limits.

title: Conflicting Rulings Keep Cart Issue in Courts
description: The lawsuit brought by the touring golf pro Casey Martin against the PGA Tour has received most of the publicity, but another suit, filed by a club pro from Indiana, may well be the one that determines whether disabled players will be allowed to use carts in professional tournaments.

title: French Couples Take Plunge That Falls Short of Marriage
description: Aline Fesquet, a 27-year-old school teacher, and Frank Embert, a 29-year-old doctoral student, have been together for eight years, but say they do not feel ready yet for marriage. Both are children of divorce and they think marriage is a burdensome institution, weighed down with religious connotations, likely to end badly and at enormous expense.

title: From Proustian Rice Paper to a Point-and-Click Race
description: The other day, as the publishing world was aflutter with the appearance of the first big-name writer to hit the Internet, I happened on an account of a very different publishing phenomenon of a century ago. Taken together, these two contrasting examples of book marketing can be read as case histories of cultural democracy, for better or worse, ascendant.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on April 6 about the advent of 42-volt car batteries referred incorrectly to the energy requirements of current power steering and power brake systems. They will probably draw power from the battery in future cars; they do not now do so.

title: Confirming Second Opinions
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: MUSCLE GROUPS; For Whiplash Headaches, a Shot of Toxin
description: People suffering from chronic headaches after whiplash injuries got relief from injections of a bacterial toxin that acts as a muscle relaxant, researchers at the University of Toronto report.

title: Mendoza A Fixture In Bullpen
description: The Yankees' blueprint remains in place despite Ramiro Mendoza's six and a third perfect innings in his first start of the year last Saturday. In the Yankees' perfect world, Mendoza would be in the bullpen, bolstering the relief corps that is already one of the best units in baseball, and somebody else -- preferably, the left-hander Ed Yarnall -- would serve as the fifth starter in the rotation.

title: Leader to Meet With Farmers In Zimbabwe
description: President Robert Mugabe, shifting his tone yet again over efforts to seize white-owned land, reached out today to Zimbabwe's besieged white farmers, meeting with their leaders behind closed doors and expressing his regret over the killing of a farmer by squatters over the weekend.

title: ABB REPORTS STRONG RESULTS
description: Helped by rising customer orders and lower costs, ABB Ltd., the world's largest electrical engineeering company, said its first-quarter profit rose 26 percent, which was better than expected. The Zurich-based company also predicted higher earnings for the year. In the first three months of 2000, ABB's net income rose $381 million, up from $302 million in the corresponding period last year. Elizabeth Olson

title: Looking for Macho Rock? Not These Vintage Singers
description: VH1 gave a testosterone-stoked title to tonight's ''Men Strike Back.'' But if this concert's singers -- the Backstreet Boys, D'Angelo, Enrique Iglesias, Tom Jones, Sisqo and Sting -- share anything, it is their distance from the macho wing of current rock and hip-hop. These men are the nice guys: self-designated lovers, not fighters, who have thrived as objects of pop desire from the 1960's (Mr. Jones) and 70's (Sting) into the present. The front rows were primed with squealing young women when the concert was taped last Tuesday at the Theater at Madison Square Garden.

title: How to Tell Women's Clothes From Men's? Try Price
description: Thirty-five years ago, in an essay called ''The Secret Vice,'' Tom Wolfe revealed what is still, for my money, the essential truth about men and fashion.

title: Eberhard Bethge, 90, Writer, Theologian and Biographer
description: Eberhard Bethge, a German Protestant theologian who helped to make his countryman Dietrich Bonhoeffer one of the most influential Protestant theologians of the mid-1900's, died on March 18 in the Bethge home in Wachtberg, a suburb of Bonn. He was 90.

title: No 'Moon' Tonight
description: Tonight's performance of ''A Moon for the Misbegotten'' at the Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, has been canceled because of a television commitment by two of the principals, Gabriel Byrne and Roy Dotrice. Tickets can be exchanged or refunded at the box office or, for tickets bought over the telephone, by calling (212) 239-6200.

title: Janitors Struggle at the Edges of Silicon Valley's Success
description: From 6 p.m. to 2 a.m. each night, Guadalupe Herrera cleans offices at that pinnacle of high-tech success, Cisco Systems, and then she heads home to the garage where she, her husband and two sons live.

title: Australians Seek a Role in Their Region : 'The White Tribe of Asia' ?
description: HONG KONG  The nearly full-page picture shows three Australians, each with a beer bottle in his hand, each wearing shorts, sitting in a row of chairs. They are surrounded by muddy water up to their knees, and for all their nonchalance, they seem to be in the middle of a flood.

title: Another Right-Wing Conspiracy?
description: ''They need me!'' the familiar voice boomed by telephone. (Or was it a megaphone?) It was Rush Limbaugh discussing his aspiration to join ABC's Al Michaels in the ''Monday Night Football'' booth.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENTS; A Double Effort to Beat Incontinence
description: Older women suffering from urge incontinence can get better results from combining drug treatments and behavioral therapy than from either alone, a study in the April issue of the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society concludes.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Mexico Farmers Protest Cheap Imports From El Norte
description: Mexico is often viewed in the United States as the land of cheap imports. But in the eyes of Mexican dairy and grain farmers, the cheap imports are from the United States, and that is a problem.

title: Jewish Losses Cited
description: A report on assets seized from Jews in France during World War II concluded that the Nazis and French collaborators stole far more than was previously assumed. But it also found extensive efforts to return the property or to reimburse Jews after the war. The report was commissioned as part of an effort by the French authorities to render justice to survivors, and Jewish leaders in France generally praised it.

title: A Tangled History With Iran
description: If the United States and Iran are ever to restore good relations, both nations must understand the events that helped drive them apart. That history begins with the 1953 coup orchestrated by the Central Intelligence Agency that restored a reluctant Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi to power. The shah helped modernize his country and kept it firmly allied with Washington. But his harsh American-backed dictatorship suppressed dissent and stunted the development of democratic politics.

title: Impotence Is Given Another Name, and a Drug Market Grows
description: In the two years since the revolutionary drug Viagra reached the market, the medical condition known as erectile dysfunction has gone from something that was the seldom mentioned cause of hidden misery and embarrassment to the basis of a billion-dollar-plus industry.

description: As if Jon S. Corzine were not spending enough of his own money for his Senate campaign, today he got a $140,000 gift in the form of a radio advertisement attacking his Democratic primary opponent, former Gov. Jim Florio.

title: City Hall to Use $54 Million To Add Day Care Subsidies
description: Eight months after the state set aside millions of dollars for subsidized child care, city officials said yesterday that they would use the money to create child care slots in neighborhoods that need them most, offer coupons to parents who are required to work for their welfare benefits, and reward families who have waited the longest for child care vouchers.

title: Bushes Had $1.3 Million In Income
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and his wife, Laura, revealed some limited information about their income taxes yesterday, issuing a brief statement that they had income of $1.3 million in 1999 on which they paid $514,000, or 39.5 percent of their income, in federal taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEANE, GILBERT HARRISON

Gentle, cherished father and father-in-law to Susan and Dean Avery, devoted grandfather to Jennifer and Phoebe. His compassionate and courageous spirit endures forever. Contributions in his memory to Lighthouse of Broward County, 650 North Andrews Avenue, Fort Lauderdale, FL. 33311.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Nasdaq Index Clocks an Advance of 6.6%, But the Result Proves to Be Mixed
description: The Nasdaq composite index roared back to life yesterday, clocking an impressive 6.6 percent gain. Nevertheless, strategists say, it would be wrong to deduce that the speculative frenzy that drove technology stocks into the stratosphere has returned full force.

title: Albany Leaders Reach a Deal To Cut Taxes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders removed one of the last remaining obstacles to a state budget deal today, reaching tentative agreement on a broad array of tax cuts that would save New Yorkers $1.2 billion a year, according to aides involved in the negotiations.

title: Safeguarding Drivers In Wake of Slayings
description: An outcry over the slayings of seven livery-cab drivers so far this year has prompted New York City officials to announce an array of measures, from requiring safety equipment in cars to putting police on patrol in ''safe zones,'' to protect drivers.

title: A Young George Bush, P., on the Political Stage
description: When Gov. George W. Bush paused in a recent campaign event here to announce that the audience included ''a star in our family,'' several possible points of light -- his father, his mother, even his brother Jeb, the Florida governor -- came quickly to mind.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Police Search Ruled Unconstitutional
description: Law-enforcement agents who walk the aisles of a bus squeezing passengers' carry-on bags to see if any contain contraband are conducting an unconstitutional search, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS TO BUY HAC GROUP FOR $200 MILLION
description: The Reynolds & Reynolds Company, an information manager for auto dealers, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held HAC Group for as much as $200 million in cash and stock to add to its Internet services. Reynolds & Reynolds agreed to pay $108 million in cash and about 1.2 million shares for HAC. It may also pay $60 million over the next three years, based on performance targets. HAC, based in Philadelphia, had 1999 revenue of $65 million. Last week, Reynolds & Reynolds, based in Dayton, Ohio, took steps to help it sell or spin off its business-forms printing unit. Shares of Reynolds & Reynolds rose $1.3125 each, to $27.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: PRESSBURGER-Selly. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a longtime friend and supporter who, with his late wife, Lena, was a YU Guardian. A major supporter of Jewish tradition, higher Jewish education, and synagogue life, he will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

As our matriarch she was an inspiration to all of us. Her love for us was without reservation, and we loved her dearly. Remembrances may be made to a charity of your choice. Services Tuesday, April 18, at 10 AM at Riverside Chapel, Mount Vernon.

title: Italy's Leader Shaken by Right's Gains in Regional Voting
description: Weakened by severe losses in regional elections on Sunday, Italy's center-left prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, submitted his resignation tonight. But President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi rejected it, and told him to consult Parliament.

For further information, call ''Wien & Wien'', 800-322-0533.

title: European Markets End Day With Only Modest Losses
description: It was the worst day imaginable for offering shares of yet another dot-com company to the public. And yet the $3 billion offering of Deutsche Telekom's Internet subsidiary got a surprisingly strong reception today and may have been the catalyst that helped avert a panicky sell-off in Europe.

title: Profit Up at Citigroup, Merrill and Schwab
description: The sell-off in technology stocks in late March hardly put a dent in the earnings of some of the nation's biggest financial services companies. Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Charles Schwab all reported their most profitable first quarters ever yesterday.

description: SHACHNOW-Leonard. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Bracing For a Deluge, Getting a Trickle; Reaction Proves Calm To Friday's Big Sell-Off
description: In Owings Mills, Md., yesterday morning, T. Rowe Price prepared for a major accident. Expecting a flood of nervous phone calls, the mutual fund giant put 200 employees on standby to support its usual staff of 100 telephone representatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, GEORGE
description: BROOKS-George. Beloved husband of Rachel, devoted father of Robert and Stuart, father-in-law of Brenda, brother of Hank, brother-in-law of Charles and Lawrence Edell, died peacefully on April 17th, 2000.

title: Threat of Testicular Cancer Increasing
description: Notwithstanding Lance Armstrong's spectacular victory in the 1999 Tour de France three years after treatment for advanced testicular cancer, there is no question that this disease, which primarily afflicts young men, is best detected and treated while in its early stages, still confined to the testicle in which it developed.

title: Nets' General Manager Shrugs Off the Rumors
description: With the job titles of Don Casey and Michael Rowe certain to be removed or changed after the Nets' season crawls to an end, only one man from the realm of the team's front office will remain standing. But he is on rocky ground.

Brother of Judith Chayes Neiman of Baltimore, MD. Grandfather of Lynne Lyman, Christoper Lyman, Valery Lyman, Justine Gude, Chloe Swenson and Connell Swenson, Victoria Chayes and Edward Chayes. Private services in the Berkshires. A memorial service will be held at Harvard University in September. Information Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors, Newton, MA.

title: Struggling to Fill Ranks, Army Moves to Find Ways to Keep Its Officers
description: Complaining about confusing missions, low morale and the stress of seemingly constant separations from their families, junior officers are leaving the Army in such record numbers that the Army's leaders created two panels today to figure out how to keep them in the ranks.

title: Murder Case Dismissal Sought After Witness Says She Lied
description: Defense lawyers have asked a judge to dismiss the capital murder charges against a man accused of ordering the killings of an 8-year-old boy and his mother. The lawyers pointed out that the state's sole eyewitness has said that she lied to investigators.

title: Accounts
description: Charles Schwab & Co., San Francisco, to BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle planning in all media and buying in print, which had been handled in-house and by Media Edge, New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc. BBDO New York handles creative duties for most Schwab accounts. Broadcast-media buying remains divided between Media Edge, for local, and Rubin Postaer & Associates, Santa Monica, Calif., for national. Schwab spends about $250 million annually on advertising.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES SAYS COACHMEN REBUFFS OFFER
description: Thor Industries said yesterday that a rival recreational vehicle maker, Coachmen Industries, was refusing to discuss a buyout offer that values Coachmen at $18 a share, or a total of $289.6 million. Thor, based in Jackson Center, Ohio, released the text of a letter to Coachmen's chairman, Claire C. Skinner, detailing its cash and stock offer. The combined company, Thor said in the letter, would be the second-largest recreational-vehicle builder and the nation's biggest producer of modular homes. Coachmen's shares rose $2.8125 each, to $15.50, and Thor was up $1.8125 a share at $26.25. Coachmen, based in Elkhart, Ind., earned $29.5 million on sales of $847 million in 1999.

Calling Wednesday 11:00-12 at the Glackin/Saul Funeral Home, 136 Morrison Avenue, Hightstown. Contributions to the Leukemia Society of America, New Jersey Chapter, 419 North Black Horse Pike, Mt. Ephraim, New Jersey 08059 or a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, BARRY A.
description: SPENCER-Barry A. On April 16, 2000. Beloved husband of Joyce. Loving son of Lillian and the late Charles Spencer. Dear brother of Bruce. Cherished uncle to Ellen, Alex, Marc and Eric and cousin to Steve and Marge. Services Tuesday 9:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty or North American Conferece on Ethiopian Jewrey (NACOEJ).

title: Letters Push Garbo Slightly Into View
description: For close to 40 years film scholars and biographers of Greta Garbo have waited for the day when 55 letters and 32 cards and telegrams that the actress wrote to Mercedes de Acosta, a playwright, screen writer and poet, would be unsealed at Philadelphia's Rosenbach Museum & Library.

title: Colonel Says He Used Cash From Wife's Drug Smuggling
description: A United States Army officer who once oversaw the government's antidrug wars in Colombia admitted yesterday that he had paid his household bills with thousands of dollars he knew his wife had received from smuggling heroin from Bogota to Manhattan and Queens.

title: U.S. STOCKS RALLY AFTER PRICES SLIDE IN GLOBAL MARKETS
description: Stock prices stabilized and then soared in the United States yesterday after plunging in Asia and sliding in early European trading. The recovery eased fears of a collapsing market that had intensified after the Nasdaq composite index lost a quarter of its value last week.

title: Broadway Goes To School to Get 'Em Young; A Drive to Turn Children Into Avid Theatergoers
description: ''The Lion King'' math curriculum (''Swahili counts!''). The ''Annie Get Your Gun'' study guide (''Ya gotta learn!''). ''Footloose'' literary themes (''The individual vs. society'').

title: Police Agency Returned To Local Control
description: The Somerset County prosecutor returned the South Bound Brook police to local control yesterday, more than a year after taking over the department.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PREVENTION; Strong Bones From Hardy Gardens Grow
description: Gardening and yard work rank with weight training and ahead of activities like swimming and walking in helping to prevent osteoporosis in women, a University of Arkansas researcher has found.

title: Senate Votes for Bill Requiring Self-Extinguishing Cigarettes
description: The State Senate unanimously passed legislation today that puts New York on the verge of becoming the first state to require that cigarettes extinguish themselves when smokers stop puffing on them.

title: Ripple Effect Expected as Rocker Makes His Return to the Braves
description: Can it be an annoyance?

title: Worlds of Difference in Facing Strike Threat; Harlem Tenants Are Used to Pulling Together
description: Jose Gough had just finished one repair at Harlem's vast Riverbend Houses when Mrs. Mitchell called. Stopped-up toilet, he said to himself, reaching for a five-foot metal hand snake before heading back to the elevator.

title: Medical Residents, Yes, but Workers, Too
description: As a medical resident at a private hospital, am I an employee or a student? Do I have the right to form a union? In a reversal of decades of federal labor policy, the National Labor Relations Board recently said yes to the latter question, casting a new backdrop to an old debate about the status of young doctors at teaching hospitals, and emboldening residents at some hospitals to press for collective bargaining rights.

title: VITAL SIGNS: IN PRACTICE; Doctors Bending Rules on Managed Care
description: Almost 40 percent of physicians say they have manipulated insurance reimbursement rules to allow patients to receive needed care, according to a study published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: On a Day of Protests, K Street Takes the Day Off
description: The protesters marching downtown today failed to disrupt the spring meeting of the International Monetary Fund and its partner organization, the World Bank. But the protesters managed to halt the business of another influential Washington institution: the law firms and lobbying shops of K Street.

title: VITAL SIGNS: NOSTRUMS; Deflating the Myth of Sharks and Cancer
description: Shark cartilage has become a widely used alternative treatment for cancer, based on the idea that sharks do not get cancer. But they actually do, including cancers of the cartilage, according to research presented this month at a San Franciso conference of the American Association for Cancer Research.

title: Town's Plan for Excess Deer: Ship Them Out
description: Like many of their neighbors across the suburbs, the people of Millburn have had it with Bambi.

description: SILBER-Albert. On April 16, 2000. Devoted husband of the late Phyllis. Loving father of Robin and Walter. Cherished grandfather of William and Eugene. Loving friend of Joan G. Smith. Dear brother of Cecile and Barbara. Services on Tuesday, 1 P.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Temple Israel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Caring Community.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hoffmann-La Roche Reviews an Account
description: Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., part of Roche Holding, said yesterday that it had begun a review for the account of its Xenical weight-loss drug after deciding to part ways with units of the Lowe Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $80 million.

title: Learning To Love The I.M.F.
description: I recognize the people who have been getting tear-gassed in Washington the last few days. I recognize their Birkenstocks and tie-dye shirts and their idealistic rhetoric. Seven years ago, as an idealistic Ivy League undergraduate, I, too, was a radical. And while I know these protesters are well-intentioned, I also think they are wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, HARVEY
description: BRODY-Harvey. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Merryl Katz and family on the loss of her beloved father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Public Interests; While You Were Sleeping . . .
description: One of the great things about a modern presidential election is the amount of down time it allows the average citizen. Really, how long has it been since Al Gore or George W. Bush crossed your mind? And it's O.K.! They know you've forgotten all about them, and they respect you more for it.

title: Dutch Concern Is in Deal
description: The Dutch company Vedior N.V. said today that it had agreed to acquire Acsys Inc. for $76 million in stock to combine the two staffing companies. Vedior said the deal would give it 40 new offices in the United States, doubling the number of its offices in North America to 80. The Atlanta-based Acsys provides temporary and permanent staffing in the accounting and information technology fields.

title: Rebound, and Relief, in the Markets
description: Friday's largest-ever point loss on the Nasdaq stock market was followed yesterday by the largest-ever point gain -- putting to rest, for now, fears of a meltdown on Wall Street. No one could know before trading started yesterday morning whether stocks would continue to plunge or, as has become the rule in recent years, recover as investors swooped in to buy what they perceived to be newly undervalued stocks. By the same token, no one can know if yesterday's snapback will last. By historical standards, stock prices still remain high.

title: After Taking a Beating, Dot-Coms Now Seek Financial Saviors
description: After weeks of battering in the stock market, many e-commerce companies -- drained of cash and unable to recapture investor interest -- are rushing around in search of a deal that will help them survive another day.

title: Kiehl's Cosmetics Company Bought by France's L'Oreal
description: After 149 years as a small but intensely popular independent cosmetics company, Kiehl's said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by L'Oreal S.A., the French beauty products giant.

title: Op-Art
French Issue First Detailed Study of Wartime Thefts From Jews
description: A long-awaited study of assets seized from Jews in wartime France said today that the Nazis and French collaborators stole far more than previously assumed. But the report also found that efforts to return the property or to reimburse Jews after the war were extensive.

title: Special Counsel Likely In Case of Freed Rapist
description: Legislators said yesterday that they were likely to hire a special counsel to review a State Department of Corrections report on how a convicted rapist was released from prison without notice to prosecutors.

title: Microsoft Will Challenge Palm's Hand-Held Computer Dominance
description: With impressive new software for hand-held computers, Microsoft will start tomorrow what industry analysts regard as its first serious challenge to Palm Inc., the leader in the fast-growing market for pocket-sized machines.

title: The Dolphin's Secret: Just Sink, Don't Swim
description: New research is unraveling the old mystery of how air-breathing animals manage to dive so far beneath the waves and stay down so long. Seals, dolphins, whales and other marine mammals can plunge up to a mile or more into the abyss and stay there as long as two hours on a single breath of air, a feat that has baffled scientists for centuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, HELEN JEAN POWERS
description: STEVENS-Helen Jean Powers. Died Saturday, April 15, at the Amsterdam Ave. Nursing Home. The widow of John Morris Stevens and former kindergarten teacher of PS 197. The funeral Wednesday, April 19, 2000 at Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave, corner of 141 St. Viewing 10 AM. Services at 11. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, 233rd St. and Webster Ave., Bronx.

title: How Aspirin Works Its Magic
description: In 1982, the British chemist Sir John Vane shared the Nobel Prize in Medicine in part for figuring out how aspirin worked, but some researchers now think that his work may have been only a good beginning.

title: Leaving the Crisis Room for the Classroom
description: EDWARD J. BLAKELY, dean of the School of Management and Urban Policy at the New School, used to be a force in California government, advising mayors in the Bay Area and Los Angeles, lawmakers in Sacramento and commissions convened to rebuild cities after earthquakes, fires, riots or military base closings.

title: LITTLE CONCERN OVER CANADIAN INFLATION
description: Rising energy prices pushed Canada's inflation rate to 3 percent in March, up from 2.7 percent in February, the largest increase in the consumer price index since May 1995. But Statistics Canada said higher prices for fuel oil and gasoline were not reflected in prices for other goods. Excluding energy, the inflation rate was only 1.4 percent, a small drop from February. ''Even with the economy operating at virtually full capacity, there still appears to be little cause for concern on Canada's inflation front,'' said Marc Levesque, an economist at Toronto Dominion Bank. Timothy Pritchard

title: GE Financial Deal
description: GE Financial Assurance, the largest United States long-term care insurer, said today that it had signed an agreement to acquire 90 percent of the long-term care business of Citigroup's Travelers Life and Annuity unit. Terms of the acquisition, which includes premium volume of about $34 million, were not disclosed. GE Financial will also take over administration of the 10 percent of the business Travelers Life and Annuity is holding onto.

title: Giants Are Comfortable Picking Big Ten Players
description: While the Giants followed the west Tennessee back roads to the little-known football outpost of Lambuth University to find wide receiver Ron Dixon in the college draft last weekend, they also pursued a well-worn path to their most familiar recruiting base, the Big Ten Conference.

title: NORTHROP GRUMMAN IN TALKS TO SELL FUSELAGE BUSINESS
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, which makes the fuselages for Boeing 747 jetliners, said yesterday that it was in talks to sell the fuselage business now that jetliner sales appear likely to decline. Northrop hired Salomon Smith Barney Inc. to help with the sale. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Northrop was talking with Carlyle Group, a closely held Washington-based venture-capital company. Carlyle Group did not return calls seeking comment. The business had sales of $1.44 billion last year. Northrop's shares rose $4.375 each, to $63.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Britain Plans a Public Offering of Its Military Research Unit
description: Risking a breach with the United States military establishment and braving the swings of an uncertain stock market, the British government said today that it would sell a 75 percent stake in a secret military research unit, the Defense Evaluation and Research Agency, in a public offering.

title: Astronomers Celebrate A Super Stargazer
description: Ten years after its launching and halfway through its currently planned lifetime, the Hubble Space Telescope has circled Earth more than 58,000 times, made 271,000 observations and investigated 13,670 celestial targets. It has looked near and far, seeing a comet bombard Jupiter and capturing the faint light of hundreds of young galaxies near the edge of the observable universe.

description: ADOBE SYSTEMS INC., San Jose, Calif., named Bruce Chizen, executive vice president for worldwide products and marketing, to the additional post of president, succeeding Charles M. Geschke, who is retiring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTCHEON, SYLVIA BECKER
description: GUTCHEON-Sylvia Becker. April 14, 2000. Much loved wife of Jack, mother of Jeffrey and of Peppi Graves, grandmother of David Gutcheon and Lucy Graves. She was born in New York City, lived her adult life in Washington Heights, and summered at Lake Oscawana in Putnam County. She was a consummate homemaker, and a member for many years of the Netty Leaf Bailin League. She preferred the bus to the subway because she liked to see where she was going, and no one in her family will again hear ''Tea for Two'' played on the piano without missing her. Loved and mourned by family and friends.

title: Nothing Against Old Art, but Gallery Rats Hunger for New
description: WHEN most people think about art, they think of museums, of climbing the grand stairs to the Met or spiraling down the ramps of the Guggenheim. But the adventure of art is hardly confined to Fifth Avenue. The throngs pouring into museums have little, if any, connection to the small, dedicated crowd of people who follow the contemporary art scene, and who tend to believe that museums have as much to do with supporting the life of art as the circus does with propagating wildlife.
