title: Vermont Moves Step Closer To Same-Sex Civil Unions
description: By almost 2 to 1, the Vermont Senate gave preliminary approval today to a bill creating marriagelike ''civil unions'' for gay couples. The 19-to-11 vote signaled that the Legislature was likely to clear the few apparently minor political hurdles remaining and pass the most sweeping law in the country protecting same-sex couples.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOVER, MICHELINE C.
description: GLOVER-Micheline C., of White Plains, New York, age 76 passed away at White Plains Hospital April 15, 2000. Born in Paris, France to Lambert Blum-Picard and Josephine Berthet, Nov. 29th, 1923. Beloved wife to Garlan for 53 years, sister to Gilbert (deceased) and Pierre, loving mother to Francoise (deceased), Derek, Brian, Christiane, Renny, Wayne. Loving grandmother to Carly, Julien, Kyle, Scott, Claire, Paige. Micheline, at the age of eighteen, was active in the French Underground during WW II as a courier between different battalions, then as a resistance fighter and nurse. She was awarded the Croix de Guerre, the Medaille de la Resistance, and a citation from General Eisenhower for her part in rescuing downed allied aircrews. A Mass will be said for her at Mt. Saint Michael Church in Greenwich, CT, 469 North Street, at 11 AM, May 1st, followed by a brunch. A memorial reunion will be held at Orienta Beach Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y. on April 22nd from 2 to 5 PM. In lieu of flowers make contributions in her memory to any society for the protection of animals.

title: The Sweetest Words of All: No Charge
description: WHEN the ''Angels at the Vatican'' exhibition toured the United States two years ago, it drew an average of 918 visitors a day to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, 964 to the Baltimore Museum of Art and 1,804 to the Detroit Institute of Arts. But the St. Louis Art Museum dwarfed the others, with 2,420 people a day.

title: Big Strides for Sicilian Reds
description: HISTORIANS tracing the story of winemaking in Italy say that Sicilian vineyards flourished around 2,500 years ago. Wine lovers might say it's been all downhill from there.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Monday with an article about food shortages in Ethiopia carried an erroneous caption. The photograph showed 4-year-old Fashiyo Muhammad as she was being given water by her mother; a different picture, of Ethiopians surveying livestock carcasses, appeared in some regional editions.

title: Many Are Called, and More Than a Few Are Women
description: Step into a confessional booth to unburden yourself and you will talk to a man. But while the Roman Catholic Church still requires that its leaders be male, most other religious groups in the United States have flung their doors open to women.

title: Where's the Rest of the Iceberg? It's Stored in the Basement
description: IN the basement of the Franklin Institute, behind a heavy door secured by a combination lock, in a cinder-block vault, in an acid-free cardboard box, tucked into a bed of tissue paper, rests a gnarled, bent piece of iron about two feet long, chunks of mica-flecked stone fused to its base by an awesome collision of natural forces.

title: INSIDE
description: Jet Crashes in Philippines

title: Who Said Plumbing Doesn't Belong On a Pedestal? Not These Museums
description: FIREFIGHTERS who get misty-eyed over vintage fireplugs and police officers who are aficionados of shiny old badges can find the histories of their professions enshrined in small museums across the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, MARY E.
description: BRADLEY-Mary E. The employees of International Registries, Inc. deeply mourn the loss of our dear and respected colleague, Mary E. Bradley, on April 14, 2000. Our sympathies and heartfelt condolences to her wonderful mother Margaret, brothers Bill and Mike, and their families.

title: Wall St. Ads Taking Detour On Wary Path
description: On Super Bowl Sunday, viewers expected a spate of wacky commercials from the E*Trade Group, the upstart online broker, and they weren't disappointed. One spot showed a hospital patient who didn't have to worry about health insurance because he had ''money coming out the wazoo.''

title: Put On These Glasses, and You'll See More Than the Painting
description: MUSEUM directors are looking toward technology and studying how the latest gallery gadgetry -- from digital ''eyeglasses'' embedded with tiny screens to handheld computers with Internet access -- can enhance exhibitions and keep visitors coming back.

title: GERMAN BUSINESS CONFIDENCE WEAKENS
description: One of Germany's most closely watched economic indicators, the monthly index of business confidence of the research institute IFO, showed an unexpected drop that helped depress the euro. Analysts had expected business confidence to strengthen. Germany's six leading economic research institutes raised the prediction for economic growth for this year to 2.8 percent from 2.7 percent; German growth was only 1.4 percent in 1999. The euro slipped from 94.5 cents to 94.45 cents, less than a penny above its all-time low of 93.9 cents. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Once Confined to the Wings, Photography Becomes a Star
description: THE Museum of Photographic Arts in Balboa Park here used to be confined to a cramped 7,000-square-foot space tucked behind a stodgy sports museum carpeted in AstroTurf. The photography museum's new home, which opened April 4, has not only a highly visible entrance on the park's main avenue, but also state-of-the-art quarters with four times as much space.

title: Guardians of a Demanding Jazz Style
description: Avant-garde jazz firebrands from the 1960's and 70's have become proven figures in the jazz world. No longer a self-consciously rebellious vanguard, they have become the guardians of a demanding style that has remained on jazz's fringe but can still yield audacious performances.

title: Housing Starts Slip 11%, but Higher Rates Escape Blame
description: Housing starts plunged 11.2 percent in March, the largest monthly drop in six years, but the decline was attributed entirely to a slowdown in construction of apartments and other multifamily housing, while single-family housing starts were unchanged.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the conflict over farmland in Zimbabwe referred incorrectly to a meeting between President Robert Mugabe and white farmers, some of whose land has been invaded by squatters. That meeting took place on Monday; the meeting proposed for the future was one between farmers and war veterans who have been leading the takeover of land.

title: SOFTWARE MAKER SIEBEL TO BUY OPENSITE FOR $444 MILLION
description: The e-business software maker Siebel Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire OpenSite Inc. for about $444 million in stock. OpenSite, which is based in Durham, N.C., provides a range of software products and services for customers who need so-called dynamic pricing capabilities. Dynamic pricing can include options like forward auctions, reverse auctions, auction networks and exchanges. Siebel said the acquisition would allow it to offer customers the option of interacting with companies through dynamic or traditional pricing. The stock of Siebel, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., rose $14.125 a share, to $126.875.

title: The Minimalist; Pasta Treated Like a Cousin
description: I RECENTLY cooked with a friend who had a novel idea that immediately seemed sensible and appealing: Why not cook pasta like risotto? Adding broth a bit at a time and stirring frequently certainly seemed as if it should create a creamy pasta dish in less time (no waiting for the water to boil).

title: TRANSFORMATIONS; Artists Inherit Steel and Ore To Produce Art, Of Course
description: IT is an oddly appropriate spot for an artists' colony, in the hulking shadows of Republic Steel's abandoned Thomas works, where iron-ore blast furnaces and coke ovens once inflamed the sky of this former steel town.

title: Joy and Seriousness for Mozambique
description: The performance that the National Song and Dance Company of Mozambique gave on Sunday night at Town Hall was both high-minded and high-spirited. The event was a benefit to provide food, shelter and medicine for the flood-devastated nation of Mozambique, and proceeds went to the Africa Fund, which will turn them over to the Mozambique Red Cross.

title: Keep Your Big Shows: Low Profile Suits Fine At the Homey Phillips
description: AT the Phillips Collection, 2,400 works of modern art housed in a row of three- and four-story buildings in a stately residential corner of Northwest Washington, the hurly-burly of a great museum as a marketplace for art is absent.

title: Family Planning Politics
description: President Clinton recently called on Congress to raise aid for international family planning by $169 million next year, bringing the total to $541 million in the 2001 budget. That substantial increase, coming after years of cuts, would merely restore funding to 1995 levels. Far more is needed. Nearly 600,000 women die annually from complications of pregnancy and childbirth. Many of them could be saved by services that help women avoid unintended pregnancies.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Stock-Trading Cheerleader Now Faces $45 Million Debt
description: Among the many evangelists for online investing who have appeared in recent years, few have been as ubiquitous as Baruch Israel Hertz. His New York company, with its constant advertisements on CNBC, promises to make investing a cinch even for novices, providing stock quotes, market information and easy access to electronic trading. ''You don't have to be a pro to trade like one,'' he says on the Web site of his stock-trading system, MyTrack.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Chef in Transition

title: Corrections
description: Headlines yesterday about a decision by officials who oversee the World Bank to step up efforts against AIDS referred to them incorrectly. As noted in the article, they are finance officials, not trade officials.

title: Librarian, Long an Internet Booster, Sees Clouds on Web Horizon
description: April 19, 2000

title: Young & Rubicam Opens a Radio Unit
description: Media Edge in New York, the media services unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., said yesterday that it would open Radio Edge, a division devoted to local and network radio.

title: NEW YORK SENATE EASES BALLOT LAW FOR G.O.P. PRIMARY
description: The State Senate approved a plan today that would knock down New York's notorious barriers to putting candidates on the Republican presidential primary ballot, and would make the primary a winner-take-all contest. The Senate's action makes it very likely that the bill will become law.

title: Runner With Impaired Sight Sets Olympic Berth as a Goal
description: Her boyfriend downloaded an article about her first road race and handed the printout to Marla Runyan in their tiny apartment with the Olympic rings on the living room wall. She placed the story in a magnifying device and scanned the paragraphs, knowing that somewhere it would prominently be mentioned that her vision was severely impaired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, HENRY ''HANK'' EBERHARDT
description: ABBOTT-Henry ''Hank'' Eberhardt of Caldwell, NJ on April 17, 2000. Beloved husband of Lauretta (nee Terhune), loving father of Gwenn Terhune Abbott of Caldwell, NJ, dear brother of Marilyn Gentile of California and Lynn Sebbard of Madison, NJ. Friends may call at the Dancy Funeral Home, 9 Smull Avenue, Caldwell on Wednesday 2:00-4:00, 7:00-9:00 PM. A memorial service will be held on Thursday at 4:00 PM in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Roseland Avenue, Essex Fells, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10022 or to St. Peter's Episcopal Church Memorial Fund, PO Box 96, Essex Fells, NJ 07021 or to The Leukemia Society, Northern Chapter, 45 Springfield Avenue, Springfield, New Jersey 07081-1317 would be appreciated.

title: McCain Regrets Silence on Flag Issue
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona is expected to tell South Carolinians on Wednesday that the state should remove the Confederate battle flag from over its Statehouse and that he should have said so during the primary campaign there, Republicans who have been briefed on the event said.

title: BITS AND BYTES; Teas, From Green to 'Black Dragon'
description: TEA soothes, as everyone knows, but it also may be good for you. Green tea, especially, contains potent antioxidants called polyphenols. Researchers believe polyphenols prevent cell damage and may treat or protect against rheumatoid arthritis, skin tumors, heart disease and oral and digestive-tract cancers. (So far, laboratory rodents have shown the best results.) Second to green tea for antioxidant content is oolong tea, and last is the fully oxidized black tea, which is the favorite of American tea drinkers.

title: Deal Gives More to M.T.A., Keeping Fare Increases at Bay
description: In a deal that will almost certainly mean no fare increase for subways, buses and commuter rail lines this year, state lawmakers have agreed to nearly double the amount of operating money the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will receive from Albany.

title: Gorey's Macabre Art
description: To the Editor:

title: The Four-Star Kitchen Workout Program
description: DON'T say he didn't warn you. On Page 2 of ''The French Laundry Cookbook,'' Thomas Keller, the author, chef and owner of the Napa Valley restaurant of that name, makes his approach quite clear: ''Cooking is not about convenience, and it's not about shortcuts.''

title: Assured of His Role, Posada Seizes the Moment
description: Watch Jorge Posada bounce from the dugout each inning. Listen closely to broadcasts of Yankee games and the shouted voice you hear will belong to Posada. He will be yelling at the pitcher to cover first base, directing the infielders, cussing vigorously. He is moving with exceptional energy, like a colt released to pasture on the first day of spring.

title: U.N. Warns It Will Enforce Angola Trade Ban
description: The Security Council today put on notice any country or leader breaking international sanctions by trading with a rebel movement in Angola that has sustained itself by selling diamonds and smuggling weapons and oil.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about an agreement by Anderson Exploration Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, to buy Ulster Petroleums Ltd., also of Calgary, misstated the price. It is $445 million, not $45 million.

title: Foul Was Fair and Everything Strange in the Yanks' 11-Inning Victory
description: Among the many eccentric moments in the Yankees' 5-4 victory against the Texas Rangers here Monday night, there was an instance in the 11th inning when the home-plate umpire interpreted the score differently than everyone else in the ballpark, including the other umpires.

title: The Taymor Wizardry Takes on Ribald Fantasy
description: If the Tony Awards had a category for best performance by a piece of fruit in a musical role, there's no question about which current Broadway show would provide the winner. Ditto for best performance by an actor denied the use of the upper two-thirds of his face. And for best use of eyelids by an oversize broken statue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, HELEN P.
description: ROSENBLUM-Helen P. Beloved mother of Jeffrey and mother-inlaw of Meryl and grandmother of Michael and Jaclyn. Graveside service Wednesday, 11:30 AM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Renovators Count on Revival of Herald Square
description: For more than 75 years, the Marbridge Building has faced Macy's flagship department store across the bustling intersection of Broadway, the Avenue of the Americas and 34th Street.

title: Sewer Plant Repairs Lag Near Reservoirs
description: A failure to modernize New York City's waste water treatment plants in areas near reservoirs is jeopardizing an effort to avoid having to build a $6 billion filtration plant, officials say.

title: A Clear Choice on China Trade
description: By permanently awarding China the normal trading status it has enjoyed for two decades, Congress can advance America's economic interests without diluting its support for human rights on the mainland or the defense of democracy on Taiwan. Yet while Senate passage seems assured, the House is wavering as both liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans withhold support. Both groups should reconsider their opposition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SADIN, CONCEPCION
description: SADIN-Concepcion. April 17, 2000. Age 89. Born in Cuba, lived in Manhattan. Beloved mother of Emma; adored grandmother of Amanda. Reposing at Buckley Funeral Home, New York 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Will the New Economy Leave Australia Behind?
description: SYDNEY  Living Up to Expectations/Last of a series

title: Van Gundy Says Knicks Are Awed by Raptors
description: Using strokes of hyperbole, Coach Jeff Van Gundy painted a picture of a cowering Knicks team that may be mentally shaken and physically intimidated by its first-round opponent, the ominous Toronto Raptors.

title: Bush Unveils a Proposal to Encourage Development in Struggling Neighborhoods
description: Adding to a series of recent proposals that he says are intended to give low-income people a firmer purchase on the American dream, Gov. George W. Bush today unveiled a plan to encourage private developers to build and rehabilitate houses in run-down, struggling neighborhoods.

title: The Census' Race Problem
description: The 2000 census, bedeviled by poor compliance and charges of intrusiveness, has at least pleased some Americans by giving them far more choices than ever before on the question about race. While this change may have satisfied some of the critics of the rigid racial classifying the census used to demand, it has not made the process more scientifically accurate. No matter which racial box you checked, no one will be able to prove you wrong by any scientific measure, for the simple reason that there is none.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUMAN, MARY. (NEE KAISER)
description: BRUMAN-Mary. (nee Kaiser). April 17, 2000. Forever in our hearts. Cousins Grace and Bob.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: East Meets West, Satisfying a Yen for Both
description: IT'S easy to miss Kori. This attractive little Korean restaurant and bar fades into the background on its drab block in TriBeCa, which is practically deserted after dark. Consider yourself lucky if you find it, though, because Kori is unusual, a Korean restaurant that succeeds in merging East and West, old and new.

title: Take Tea With Alice
description: A tea based on the Mad Hatter's tea party in ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' will be held from 3 to 5 p.m. through Sunday in the lobby lounge at the Four Seasons Hotel, 57 East 57th Street. The tea, $32 a person, features lobster quadrille sandwiches, March Hare carrot cake and chocolate mock turtles. Hats are encouraged and there will be a display of ones designed by Eric Javits. Reservations: (212) 758-5700.

title: National News Briefs; Emergency Broadcasts To Get Captions for Deaf
description: The Federal Communications Commission has adopted a rule requiring television stations to accompany any announcements about emergencies with text messages for deaf viewers.

title: Museums: Firsts, Facts and Figures
description: Museums have come a long way since their beginnings as cabinets of curiosities -- motley collections of knickknacks assembled by the nobility of Renaissance Europe. These days, museums have clearly defined missions, specializing in everything from folk art to beer cans. And as their rising numbers, endowments and attendance can attest, they are big business. Below, a cabinet of curiosities (along with some useful information) about them. STEPHEN MIHM

title: F.D.A. Approves New Drug To Attack Resistant Germs
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a drug that is considered an important new weapon in the fight against antibiotic-resistant germs.

title: Stock Rally Continues
description: Bolstered by strong corporate profit reports, investors flooded back into United States stocks for the second consecutive day. The Nasdaq composite index rose 254.41 points, or 7.2 percent, to 3,793.57, the index's second-biggest gain ever. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 184.91 points, to 10,767.42

title: State Official Pleads Guilty To Bid-Fixing
description: The state official in charge of some of the largest courthouse construction projects in the city pleaded guilty yesterday to rigging bids, accepting bribes and stealing more than $500,000 in city funds, dealing a substantial blow to a struggling city effort to refurbish New York's cramped and antiquated courthouses.

title: How Many Dots on a Seurat? Just Ask the Museum Docents
description: THE pay is nonexistent, the time commitments are fixed, the training is rigorous, and there is always the threat of being fired. So who would want to be a docent, a position that in the insular world of museums is frequently compared to that of a stepchild?

title: THE CHEF
description: COD and mashed potatoes are perfectly balanced partners, each so subtly flavored that one never overshadows the other. When the cod is fresh, the mild-mannered ingredients enhance each other. But when the marriage is made with salt cod, in brandade, the potatoes mellow the briny aggressiveness of the fish.

title: Too Young to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKER OF WEB SECURITY SOFTWARE TO BUY ENCOMMERCE
description: Entrust Technologies Inc., a maker of Internet security software, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held enCommerce Inc. for about $586 million in stock, to gain software that lets companies do business online. Entrust said it would exchange 10.25 million shares for enCommerce, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., and makes software for companies that want to let customers and suppliers access corporate networks online. Shares of Entrust, which is based in Plano, Tex., rose $11.0625, to $57.125.

title: The Big City; Public Spaces Uncluttered By People
description: SEVERAL dozen urban planners from across the country were busy yesterday morning studying public spaces in Manhattan, but they did not linger in the usual crowded spots. They went briskly across Rockefeller Center and up Fifth Avenue past St. Patrick's, stopping only when they reached the building just north of the cathedral, Olympic Tower.

title: Greyhound's Parent Company Suspends Dividend Payments
description: Trapped in a deepening financial hole, Laidlaw Inc., the Canadian company that runs Greyhound Lines and North America's largest fleet of school buses, suspended dividend payments on its common stock today and won some temporary relief from bankers who are renegotiating a long-term loan agreement.

title: Bush Expects to Miss Conservatives' Party
description: It looked like a great coup.

title: From Smithsonian, a Program For Exhibitions With Legs
description: IT took 13 billion years for light to travel from the edge of the observable universe to Earth. It will take just another year for it to get to Bettendorf, Iowa.

title: A Springtime Rite Worth a Year's Wait
description: AMONG golfers, this town of 10,000 about an hour's drive east of Pittsburgh is known for Arnold Palmer, who was born here. Among beer drinkers, it is known for Rolling Rock, the malty lager in the long-neck green bottles, which is brewed here. Among serious sundae scholars, all three of them, it is known as the birthplace of the banana split.

title: Protesting, but Why?
description: The anarchist Emma Goldman is supposed to have defiantly cried that she wouldn't join the revolution if she couldn't dance; nearly 100 years later, her spiritual descendants decided that they wouldn't join the revolution if they had to get wet.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: When Easter Baskets Need a Little Something

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSSEM, JACK A.
description: JOSSEM-Jack A. Of Boynton Beach, Florida died April 17, 2000. Devoted husband of the late Nancy; longtime companion of Sophie Lipsitt. Beloved father of Steven, Carl and Margo. Cherished grandfather, in-law, uncle, cousin, friend. A complicated man who was difficult to know yet easy to adore! Having enjoyed a long career on Wall Street and a long fulfilling retirement, he will be remembered for his unparalleled honesty, integrity, humility and generosity. How fortunate were those who knew him.

title: L'OREAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE MATRIX FROM BRISTOL-MYERS
description: L'Oreal S.A., the seller of cosmetics, agreed yesterday to buy Matrix Essentials from the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, for an undisclosed price in its second purchase this week of a United States luxury-products company. L'Oreal will acquire Matrix, which had 1999 sales of $342 million and employs 1,000, through its New York-based Cosmair unit. Paris-based L'Oreal said the purchase of Matrix, which is based in Solon, Ohio, would make it the top United States seller of professional hair products, adding such brands as Biolage and Opticurl. On Monday, L'Oreal agreed to buy Kiehl's, a cosmetics company that is based in New York.

title: A Sign of Judaism Gets a Swoosh; Commercial or Trendy Skullcaps Add Fad to a Ritual
description: Samuel Goldberg has 51 skullcaps -- and counting. He has Knicks, Mets, Bulls, Michigan, Duke and Penn State. But for the month of March he wore Tar Heels and only Tar Heels, a blue suede number bearing the logo of his favorite college basketball team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, IAN
description: HOCHBERG-Ian. On April 13, 2000. Beloved son of Martin Hochberg and the late Ann Hochberg. Loving brother of Robin, uncle of Derek, & brother-in-law of Eddie. Service on Wednesday April 19, 9:30 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapels on 76th St. & Amsterdam.

title: America Online Reports Its Best Earnings in Latest Quarter
description: America Online reported record revenue and earnings yesterday for its third fiscal quarter, crediting subscription growth, advertising sales and online commerce fees in handily beating analysts' estimates.

title: Sabres Stave Off Elimination
description: Stu Barnes scored on an off-balance shot 4 minutes 42 seconds into overtime as the Buffalo Sabres stayed alive with a 3-2 victory over the visiting Philadelphia Flyers last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMAN, ESTHER
description: RAYMAN-Esther. Independent Suwalker Benevolent Association mourns our beloved Hospitaler, Esther Rayman, and sends condolences to her family and friends. Arthur S. Leonard, President Leslie Sherer, Honorary President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, SARAH
description: KRAFT-Sarah. The Board of the Jewish Campus Life Fund at Columbia University mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our good friend, benefactor and esteemed board member, Robert K. Kraft. Our deepest sympathy to Robert, Avram and Elizabeth, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Professor Robert Pollack, President Earle W. Kazis, Chairman of the Board Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Chair, Executive Committee Rabbi Charles Sheer, Joanne Ben-Avi, Director of Development

title: Fighting for a Home for All the Presidents' . . .  Busts
description: Rushing about a cavernous warehouse here, David Adickes, a sculptor, scrambles up and down ladders putting the finishing touches on Ulysses S. Grant's necktie and Franklin D. Roosevelt's ears. He doesn't seem the least worried that six of his 18-foot presidential busts -- he has done one for each president -- sit forlornly atop flatbed trailers on the outskirts of Williamsburg, Va.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: To Go; What's Inside That Counts
description: THAT Lollobrigida is quite the tasty dish. No, not Gina Lollobrigida, the actress. Lollobrigida, the sandwich, which has a starring role at SANDWICH PLANET , a trim little takeout shop near the Port Authority Bus Terminal that is devoted to America's favorite portable meal. Counterintuitively, there's no ham in a Lollobrigida ($6.25). It's a combination of bresaola, the air-dried Italian beef, and goat cheese and truffle oil, a perfect blend of salty, creamy and earthy, served on your choice of excellent breads, which come from the Sullivan Street Bakery or TriBakery.

title: Setting Is Ripe for Upsets, Sweeps and Fits
description: After one week, the Stanley Cup playoffs have provided a lot of goals in several games, strange goals in some games and one grand episode of bizarre behavior by a goalie.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Book Impresses Levy

title: SBC Communications Sued By Workers on Stock Sale
description: California employees of SBC Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, sued the company yesterday, accusing it of costing 45,000 employees and retirees $1.1 billion by selling shares of a lucrative investment that was in their company-controlled retirement accounts.

title: Saving the Miranda Rule
description: The Supreme Court will hear a challenge today to its pivotal Miranda ruling of 1966, which requires police to advise suspects of their rights before beginning an interrogation. As most viewers of television crime shows can recite, the Miranda rule requires that criminal suspects be told of their right to remain silent and have a lawyer present, and that any statement they make can be used against them. For the court to overturn Miranda would be an unwarranted rollback of safeguards against coercion in the criminal justice system.

title: Study Rules Out Environment As Cause of Autism in Town
description: In the first study in the country on the incidence of autism among young children, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed yesterday that there was a striking number of autism cases in Brick Township, N.J., but found no link to environmental factors in the town.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decision by the United Nations Security Council to review its policy on sanctions misstated the flight number of the Pan American jet that was blown up over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, leading to sanctions on Libya, since suspended. It was Flight 103, not 101.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Leader Warns Against Confrontation
description: As Zimbabwe rolls toward more violence, the worst thing that could happen, in the estimation of its main opposition leader, is to create a martyr out of its founder and once popular hero, President Robert Mugabe.

title: Haggling Stifles Any Hope For Budget Deal This Week
description: Negotiations over a new state budget came to a sudden halt today after a series of minor squabbles erupted between Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature, dashing any hopes that the budget would be completed this week, as lawmakers went home for a nearly two-week break.

title: Chicago Market Names an Interim Chief
description: The Chicago Board of Trade today selected the head of its securities clearinghouse to become interim chief executive after the resignation last week of Thomas Donovan.

title: Tories Trying To Top Labor In Toughness On Asylum
description: For months, Conservatives have accused the Labor government of turning Britain into a ''soft touch'' for ''bogus asylum seekers,'' saying that most refugees come here to exploit British generosity, not to escape persecution at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERN, ROBERT
description: KERN-Robert, 65, a Professor of History at The University of New Mexico, died of cancer on April 15, 2000. He had taught at UNM for over 30 years. He graduated with a B.A. from Antioch College, obtained an MA and Ph.D in History from The University of Chicago. Of Mr. Kern's ten books, his dissertation provided the material for two of the earliest, both of which dealt with the problems connected with the modernization of political structures in the Spanish speaking world. He later created and coedited ''The Historical Dictionary of Modern Spanish History'' and ''The Regions Of Spain: An Historical And Cultural Guide''. His study of The Spanish Civil War, ''Red Years/Black Years: A Political History Of The Spanish Anarchists, 1911 To 1937'', was particularly well-known. In addition, Mr. Kern wrote about New Mexico, and his ''Labor History Of New Mexico'', was published by the UNM Press. He co-edited with Jane Slaughter, one of the first collections to deal with women in radical politics, ''European Women On The Left''.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLLENDER, SELMA
description: HOLLENDER-Selma. April 18, 1994. Dear Selma, the memory of your love and smile keeps us going everyday. Alex, Jane, Beth, Wendy, Herb and Pearl

title: Digital Revolution in Iran
description: I was working on my computer science graduate project in Tehran when the Islamic revolution broke out in Iran in 1979. It was so exciting; it's hard to describe the feeling. I was 28. Everyone took part in the revolution, hand in hand. There was no difference between religious people and those who had their own ideas. We just hoped for a better country.

title: Echoes Across a Great Divide
description: Two species of musical language eyed each other across a cultural divide at Peter Serkin's piano recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. Stefan Wolpe, Stravinsky and Schoenberg stated their cases before intermission; Mozart and Beethoven responded later on. This is my description of an interesting program, and one that Mr. Serkin might disagree with. Here, I expect he would say, were the products of a single culture: one language, different dialects.

title: At the Getty, A Family Room For Dressing Up And Drawing
description: A FUNNY thing happened to Oliver Boxall, 13, of North Vancouver, British Columbia, as he was enduring his parents' visit to the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles.

title: Pulp Mill Being Sold
description: Willamette Industries, a maker of office paper, agreed today to buy a mill in Port Wentworth, Ga., from the Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation for an undisclosed price to supply the raw material for a new paper machine. The mill will provide pulp for a paper machine being built in Kingsport, Tenn. Willamette plans to spend $475 million over four years to replace two paper machines and build a pulp mill in Kingsport.

title: State Court Judge Rebuffs a Ballot Ploy by Florio
description: Democratic party leaders in many North Jersey counties gave Jim Florio's opponent, Jon S. Corzine, their endorsement in the June primary for Senate, and with that came the coveted county line, the top position on the ballot.

title: Ellington's Songs (Though Hardly Ellingtonian) in Search of a Theatrical Setting
description: Duke Ellington wasn't particularly remembered for his musical-theater work, and ''Renaissance Man,'' the program of 17 previously unheard songs with his name on them, performed at St. Peter's Church on Saturday night, often didn't sound all that Ellingtonian beyond some recognizable melodic intervals.

title: An Upstart Upsets The Old Book Cart; Alibris Stakes Its Claim Online
description: For decades, the antiquarian and used book trade has remained the dusty, genteel corner of the book market, attracting fiercely independent booksellers who savor the musty fragrance of brown-spotted rag paper and the eureka moment of spotting a rare first edition dumped in a garage sale heap.

title: Quick, Call the Astrophysicist: The Heavens Need Updating!
description: YOU may be forgiven for mistaking the space show at the rebuilt Hayden Planetarium in New York City for a 10-billion-light-year roller-coaster ride. The curving, plunging trip through a simulated three-dimensional universe has much in common with that most elemental and mindless of entertainments -- and the final drop into the blaze of the Big Bang is a doozy.

title: G.O.P. Criticizes White House on Aid for Taiwan
description: Leading Republican lawmakers accused the Clinton administration today of caving in to pressure from China by refusing to sell high-tech destroyers and other advanced weapons to Taiwan.

title: New York And First Just Fine For Zeile
description: Todd Zeile did not come to New York to hide, and he has been around long enough to know just how public his big adventure must be.

title: Owner of Chemical Dumper Gave to Mayor

Giuliani, according to federal records.

title: Coca-Cola Reports a Loss Of $58 Million in Quarter
description: One day before Coca-Cola's annual meeting with shareholders, which is expected to include protests by black Coca-Cola employees, the company said yesterday that it lost $58 million in the first quarter, much of that because of one-time charges for reorganization.

title: Devils Closer to Banishing Playoff Demons
description: It took the Devils 12 attempts before they scored a power-play goal in the series against the Florida Panthers. But the one Alexander Mogilny got tonight in a 2-1 victory not only wiped out a 1-0 deficit but may also have erased three straight years of early playoff futility for New Jersey.

title: Sewage Work Lags at Source Of Tap Water
description: A program to modernize 102 sewage plants discharging waste water into New York City's reservoirs is drastically behind schedule, jeopardizing the city's efforts to avoid having to build a $6 billion water filtration plant, according to federal and state officials monitoring the city's plan to cut pollution of its water supply.

title: Last week's stock debacle may point to a consolidation in the online booking business.
description: LAST week's train wreck in technology stocks drew a sharper bead on predictions, long ignored by many in the hubris-heavy realm of online travel commerce, that the future belongs to a relative handful of Internet companies that can establish themselves as major brands, with easy-to-use technology to provide the best service within well-defined travel niches.

Charter Member of Local Hadassah Chapter at Jewish Community House, Brooklyn, N.Y. She will be missed by those who knew her.

title: AVIS AGREES TO ENTER VENTURE WITH FRENCH BNP PARIBAS
description: The car rental company Avis Group Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to form a joint venture with the French bank BNP Paribas to offer vehicle fleet management and leasing services in North America and Europe. Under the pact, BNP Paribas will acquire an 80 percent stake in the joint venture, which will own Avis's PHH Europe subsidiary. In return, Avis will receive $800 million in cash. Within the next year, PHH will be folded into Paribas's Arval operations, which include fleet management and leasing services. The venture will license Avis's fleet management technology for an undisclosed royalty fee. Avis, based in Garden City, N.Y., had $3.3 billion in sales last year. Its stock rose $1.50, to $19.375.

title: MetroStars Leave Matthaus Puzzled
description: Tony Meola was on the phone line, listening like everyone else, as Lothar Matthaus tried to explain his frustrations with the MetroStars' miserable start. Meola understood, having seen the same problems during his own frustrating stay with the MetroStars.

title: NOMURA BUYS WELSH UTILITY
description: Continuing its shopping spree in Britain, the Nomura Securities Company of Japan said it would acquire Hyder P.L.C., a water and power utility in Wales, for $:402 million in cash, or $643 million. Nomura already owns British pubs and hotels. It plans to use Hyder to sell securities backed by the company's cash flow. Nomura will also assume debt of $:1.9 billion, about $3 billion, in the Hyder deal. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: TransPro to Sell a Unit
description: TransPro Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its Crown specialty metal fabrication division to the furniture parts maker Leggett & Platt Inc. for $28.6 million in cash. It will also assume $8.9 million of debt. TransPro, based in New Haven, said the deal was part of its strategy to focus on its core heating and cooling systems business. Leggett & Platt, which is based in Carthage, Mo., makes such furniture parts as springs for mattresses and chairs, wood products and aluminum die castings. It had $3.8 billion in sales last year.

title: Justices Force 2 New Hearings On Death Row
description: The Supreme Court today set aside the death sentences of two convicted murderers in Virginia, indicating in two separate decisions that despite sharp restrictions imposed on federal courts by a 1996 law, federal judges still have a significant role to play in reviewing the quality of justice administered by the states.

title: The Affair Between Fashion and Art? Definitely On Again
description: ON a Friday evening in March at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the galleries of Egyptian art were as silent as King Tut's tomb. But one floor down, where the jeweled white suit of another king -- Elvis -- held pride of place in the Costume Institute's ''Rock Style'' show, the joint was jumping.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER GAINS. Copper rose as surging United States stocks signaled investors expect the economy to keep growing. In New York, copper for May delivery rose 2.1 cents, or 2.8 percent, to 76.45 cents a pound.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column last Friday about the threat of famine in Ethiopia misstated the title of Meles Zenawi. He is prime minister, not president.

title: Capitalist Roaders
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIP MAKER'S PROFIT DOUBLES
description: Europe's biggest chip maker, STMicroelectronics N.V., said its first-quarter profit more than doubled, helped by demand from makers of mobile telephones, car parts and computer modems. Net income rose to $238.4 million, or 78 cents a share, from $105.1 million, or 36 cents, in the period last year. Sales rose 53 percent, to $1.7 billion from $1.11 billion. The company is benefiting from an industrywide recovery driven by surging sales of consumer electronics. Pasquale Pistorio, chief executive since ST was formed from the merger of two state-owned companies in 1987, has put ST at the forefront of chips for such products.

title: U.N. RIGHTS GROUP FOILS U.S. EFFORT TO CONDEMN CHINA
description: In an embarrassing defeat for the Clinton administration, the principal United Nations body on human rights voted in Geneva today not to act on a United States resolution criticizing China's human rights record.

title: A Ham With an Element of Surprise
description: LIKE actors, foods can become typecast, so closely identified with a particular approach that we never think of them any other way. Often, though, an unrecognized but exciting player lurks behind the familiar guise.

title: Private School Reassesses in Wake of a Departure
description: Peter Bloom knew he had made the right school choice five years ago when he visited his son's kindergarten class and reached for a batch of muffins the students had just baked. His son gave him a reproachful look. ''Dad,'' he said, ''those are for the homeless shelter.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARA, ALFRED P. ''PETE''
description: O'HARA-Alfred P. ''Pete'' O'Hara of Patterson, New York died April 15 at home with his family at his side, after a brief illness. He was born in Patterson, New York to the late Peter and Anna (Peck) O'Hara. He loved the law. After being admitted to the bar in 1942 his practice would span the next 58 years. From 1953-56 Mr. O'Hara was Chief of the Civil Division of the U.S. Attorneys' Office for the Southern District and participated in many of the important cases of that era. He served as President and Chairman of Bacardi Corporation from 1976 to 1987 as well as being a director of several other corporations. He was currently of counsel to Kelley, Drye and Warren Law firm. He is survived by his wife Martha (Marti), four children: Jane Ann, Margaret Kathleen, Peter James, and John Edward; ten grandchildren, four great grandchildren and many others whose lives Pete influenced. He was predeceased by his first wife Muriel (Sandy) in 1969. A special private service will be held on Wednesday at the Patterson Baptist Church. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Cancer Care, Inc., 275 7th Avenue, New York, New York 10001.

title: Stocks Register Impressive Gains For Second Consecutive Session
description: With corporate earnings soaring, investors flooded back into United States stocks yesterday for the second consecutive day, retracing much of the ground lost last week.

title: Reckonings; A Real Nut Case
description: When Seattle Man went to Washington, his activities were coordinated in large part by a Web site, www.a16.org. Browsing the site, I was struck by the critique of the World Bank, written by Robert Naiman -- the activist who threw a pie in the face of Michel Camdessus, the former International Monetary Fund chief, a few months ago. Mr. Naiman's favorite -- indeed only -- example of how bank-imposed policies inflict economic damage is the way the bank ''destroyed Mozambique's cashew nut processing industry, by forcing Mozambique to remove export tariffs on raw cashew nuts.''

title: Mr. Giuliani's New Budget
description: The $37 billion budget presented by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani yesterday lays out a sound financial blueprint for New York City and a potential showcase for his campaign for the Senate. The budget combines targeted growth in spending, particularly for police and schools, with a call for limited tax cuts. For the first time in years, Mr. Giuliani has decided to forgo his ugly annual fight with the City Council over cutting funds to libraries and neighborhood cultural institutions. On the other hand, he has set himself up for a big battle with municipal unions over his demand for merit pay instead of across-the-board wage increases.

title: City to Crack Down on Standing Water in War Against West Nile

title: RUSSIAN OIL STOCK SWAP
description: One of Russia's largest oil companies, Surgutneftegaz, announced the terms for a stock swap as part of its plans to acquire its parent company, Surgut Holding, and other units. Surgutneftegaz would issue 12.3 billion new shares, and shareholders would get 1,000 new Surgutneftegaz shares for each holding company share. The swap is also structured to increase the control management has over Surgutneftegaz. Management currently controls about 67 percent of Surgutneftegaz's shares with voting rights. After the swap, its stake is expected to exceed 70 percent. Neela Banerjee

title: Technology Share Plunge Hurting Stock Options

To lure employees from secure jobs at solid companies, it has handed out thousands of stock options that have the potential to make an annual salary look like loose change.

description: Inside a hotel meeting room here, terrorism experts from Israel, France, the United States and other countries gathered today to share information and ideas.

Wood and stone need to breathe, almost like living things.

description: HELSINKI  As head of electronic banking at the world's most successful Internet bank, Bo Harald uses a surprisingly old-fashioned metaphor to describe his strategy.

title: A Shopping Mall at the Louvre? The French Say, Bien Sur

description: Mike Sillinger looked around the Florida Panthers' locker room. The only sounds were the shuffling of television cameras and tape recorders.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN POWER CONVERSION CORP., West Kingston, R.I., a maker of devices to protect computer networks from power surges, said it had bought Advance Power, a British company, for $75 million in cash.

title: Jiang's Cordial Visit to Turkey Overshadowed by Ethnic Dispute
description: President Jiang Zemin of China arrived today in Turkey for a long-awaited state visit. But hopes that the two countries can build a new alliance were overshadowed by a dispute over ethnic Turks who live in China.

title: After the Tourists Leave, Sun Studios Rocks Into the Night
description: TO some people, Sun Studios is a little piece well, 1,000 square feet -- of heaven. Under the watchful eye of the legendary producer Sam Phillips, this is where, in the 1950's, Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, B. B. King, Carl Perkins and Roy Orbison made their first recordings, and, great balls of fire, rock 'n' roll was born.

title: More Managed Care Clients Seen in Higher-Risk Hospitals

description: THEY can look. But they can't touch.

title: John Paul Blewett, 89, Physicist And Designer of Accelerators
description: John Paul Blewett, a nuclear physicist who played a significant role in the development of particle accelerators, died at a hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C., on April 7. He was 89. A Chapel Hill resident, he had lived in Manhattan and New Suffolk, N.Y.

description: The United States men's national team added Marcelo Balboa, Jason Kreis and Brian West to its roster for its April 26 match in Russia, the team said.

description: Pfizer, one of the largest American drug companies, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 45 percent, exceeding estimates, as it sold more drugs like the anti-impotence treatment Viagra and heart medicines like Norvasc and Lipitor.

The initial results were promising. ''Chicago Hope,'' which had averaged 9.9 million viewers last season, grew to more than 13 million.

title: Raising Guilt to an Art Form
description: IF you have been brooding about all the exhibitions you have missed lately, or, worse, about not spending adequate time at museums, you may suffer from what psychologists have now identified as ''Museum Guilt Syndrome.''

title: Livery Driver Killings on the Increase, but Not Robberies, Leaving Police Puzzled
description: Obscured by the public outcry over the killings of livery-cab drivers, and by the city's actions this week to protect them, lies a curious fact. While the pace of driver homicides has been rising, the larger crime pattern, which shows the number of reported robberies in livery cabs, has not changed, according to police data.

title: A Singer at Ease in Opera and in Song Repertory
description: No doubt many of those who packed the house at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon for the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham's only New York recital this season had come to hear a singer best known for her important work in opera. But Ms. Graham is utterly at home in the song repertory as well. This was no diva recital. She worked in true collaboration with an excellent pianist, Malcolm Martineau, and showed uncommon intelligence in choosing her program: songs to French texts on the first half and English-text songs by four American composers after intermission.

title: Tangling of Jewish Roots Bars Ethiopians From Israel
description: The Jewish center was packed today, the day before Passover: children sang in Hebrew. The ritual bath was filled. Three rows of workers flattened dough for matzos, baked in 30 ovens so smoky that the place seemed on fire.

title: Isolated in Miami
description: To the Editor:

title: National News Briefs; 2 Killed in Michigan At High-Rise for Elderly

title: Board May Sell Schools Chief's Residence
description: Just a few weeks after the New York City Board of Education began weighing the sale of its often maligned headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, another piece of board property -- with almost as intriguing a history -- has been suggested as a candidate for the selling block.

title: Sobbing and Kind Words for a Slain Cabby, Then the Trip Home
description: ''Ayyyy, Papito!'' sobbed Isabel Perez, calling out the childhood nickname of her son, Luis Francisco Perez, a slain livery-cab driver, as two family members escorted her away from his coffin at the Ortiz Funeral Home in Washington Heights yesterday. With livery cabs double-parked along four blocks of Broadway, waiting to escort Mr. Perez's body to Kennedy International Airport, her outburst came as a private expression of grief over a death with public significance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBLASIO, GUIDO ALFRED
description: DeBLASIO-Guido Alfred, M.D. Of Pelham, N.Y. on April 18, 2000. Practicing surgeon at Mount Vernon Hospital for forty years. Beloved husband of Patricia. Dear father of John, Claire Foss and Robert. Loving grandfather of Jennifer, Matthew, Rebecca, Amanda, Michelle and Nicholas Guido. Graduate of Cornell University and Yale Medical School, he served as a Major in the Army Medical Corp. in WWII. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9PM Thursday. Service at the funeral home on Friday, April 21st, 10AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Houston Finds His Touch After a Troubling Stretch
description: For two weeks, the same resident All-Star player who had once been the center attraction on the Knicks was turning into a wallflower. As April unfolded, Allan Houston's touch began to vanish, his defense started fading and his confidence took as many hits as a web site.

description: A Condolence Call Beats a Fax

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, LEONARD
description: KRAMER-Leonard. On April 17, 2000. The Office of Cohen and Kramer, MD, PC is deeply saddened by the death of Leonard Kramer, father of our founding partner Mark Kramer, MD. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Bernice, daughter Susan, grandchildren Jonathan, Jeremy, Keith, Chad and Katie and to the entire family. Jeffrey Cohen, MD

title: A Crusader Carves a Niche With Boy's Case
description: For 30 years, Ramon Saul Sanchez, the man now behind the army of Little Havana demonstrators, waged war with a cabal of likeminded warriors. The men, who belonged to a network of paramilitary groups, practiced armed combat in the underbrush, plotted violent overthrows of Fidel Castro and, in some cases, planted real bombs that did real damage.

title: Blue Chips of the Internet Increase Quarterly Profits
description: The engine makers, parts suppliers and plumbers of the Internet have been responsible for the snap back this week in technology stocks. Companies like Cisco Systems, Oracle and Sun Microsystems can be seen as the ballast of the new economy, established concerns with steadily growing profits as opposed to the bubble of fledgling dot-com companies with their uncertain hopes of survival.

title: The Beat Goes On for a Harbinger of Spring
description: The Ballet Tech Company presented two works for small casts to repetitive recorded scores on Friday night at the Joyce Theater. Both pieces, choreographed by Eliot Feld, appeared to reflect a belief that as long as a musical beat goes on, dancers should keep dancing. And Mr. Feld was inventive enough to make relentless movement look interesting. Indeed, he created two types of relentlessness.

title: Treasury's Planned Debt Buyback Helps to Lift Bond Prices
description: Bond prices were mostly higher yesterday, lifted on one hand by the Treasury's announced intention to buy back debt this week yet restrained on the other by the allure of rising stocks.

title: Sherwood Washburn, Pioneer In Primate Studies, Dies at 88
description: Dr. Sherwood Larned Washburn, an anthropologist and pioneering primatologist who linked the evolution of human behavior traits to the actions of apes and monkeys, died on Sunday at a hospital near his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOURAN, MAE
description: YOURAN-Mae. Died peacefully on April 17, 2000 at the age of 90. Beloved sister of Evelyn Meade, loving companion of Vincent Marino for 43 years. Mae loved her beagles, David and Bagel. Her zest for life took her traveling far and wide, her strength gave us all hope and inner peace. Mae will remain close to our hearts forever. Services, Wednesday, April 19 at 9:30 A.M. at ''Schwartz Brothers Jeffer'' Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Layoffs at Hutchinson
description: Layoffs at Hutchinson

title: Clinton Uses High-Tech Show to Push Plan for Internet Parity
description: During a visit to the country's largest computer trade show today, President Clinton wore an ergonomic pillow around his neck, fiddled with a pager that sends and receives electronic mail and examined a Web site that a computer expert told him could retrieve confidential files from the Oval Office while he was on the road.

title: Nicolas Bongard, 91, Executive at Tiffany
description: Nicolas Bongard, a former Tiffany & Company executive and a business partner of Jean Schlumberger, a jewelry designer, died on April 7 at his Manhattan home. He was 91.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about regional elections in Italy misidentified the man standing next to Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema. He was Gaetano Gifuni, an official at the Quirinal Palace. He was not President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, with whom Mr. D'Alema met.

title: Brazil Is Allowing U.S. Companies to Use Launching Site
description: Brazil reached an agreement today with the United States to allow American companies to use an equatorial launching site, advancing the ambitions of Latin America's largest country to tap the lucrative satellite-launching industry.

title: School District Rethinks Its Soda-Pop Strategy
description: THE school district of Madison, Wis., thought it could have its Coke and drink it, too.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORE, CHESTER
description: GORE-Chester. Whether three years or 30 years since you stopped sharing our lives, we still glow in the warmth of our memories of you. All our love forever. Gerie and Eloise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLOWIN, EUGENE M.
description: PERLOWIN-Eugene M. Husband of Sanky. Father of Lisa, Carla and Robert Chadwick. Passed away Tuesday, April 18, 2000. Memorial service will be held June 1, 2000,, 7PM, City Island Yacht Club, Bronx, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to New Hope Community, POB 289, Loch Sheldrake, New York 12759.

title: Cisco and SBC Expect Alliance
description: Cisco Systems, the data networking company based in San Jose, Calif., is expected to announce today that it has entered into a multibillion-dollar alliance with SBC Communications, which is based in San Antonio.

title: Driver Who Tried to Hit Officer Is Shot, Police Say
description: A police officer shot and wounded a man who tried to hit him with a car last night, the police said.

title: Oh, the Psyches and Personalities He Has Seen
description: Blind people can't easily tell if a job candidate is white or black, thin or obese, plain or pretty. So if they should happen to assess an applicant's professional qualifications, they might well focus on a more mundane matter: Is she actually suited for the job?

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro dropped after a business survey showed an unexpected drop in confidence last month in the economy of Germany. In New York, the euro settled at 94.80 cents, down from 95.38 on Monday.

title: In This Washington, No 'Seattle' Is Found, by Police or Protesters
description: In the end, Washington was not Seattle.

title: Giuliani Budget Plan Scales Back Tax Cuts and Restores Spending
description: In a gesture of compromise to the City Council, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $36.7 billion city budget yesterday in which he sharply scaled back his earlier proposal for tax cuts and restored spending he had proposed to cut for libraries and other cultural institutions.

title: Tax Return Shows Patakis Made Record $400,266 in '99
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife, Libby, reported earning a record family income of $400,266 in 1999, a 62 percent increase from the year before, according to a copy of their tax return made public today.

title: 2 Found Stabbed to Death
description: A man and a woman were found stabbed to death in a Staten Island apartment last night, the police said.

title: Bon Appetit. Now Get Out!
description: NOW that ''No Smoking'' and ''No Cell Phones'' icons have become standard signage at New York restaurants, it may be time for one more admonishment.

title: Doctor Sees Mental Abuse of Cuban Boy
description: A pediatrician who is advising the United States government on the Elian Gonzalez custody standoff said the 6-year-old was being psychologically abused in the home of his Miami relatives and should be immediately removed from the home.

title: Three Stooges as Alumni Of School of Hard Knocks
description: Who doesn't know those numskulls Moe, Larry and Curly? The Three Stooges -- whose pies in the face, punches in the gut, headlocks, insults and pratfalls have been embedded in popular culture since the 1930's -- are back.

title: Vacherin: Pleasure by the Spoonful
description: I DON'T think I have ever been served anything so uncompromised in New York City. On a white plate was a dollop of pale cheese, Vacherin, as relaxed as a spoonful of whipped cream, as dense and shiny as soft butter. Next to it were four thick slices of yellow potato, sprinkled sparingly with olive oil, seasoned with fleur de sel.

title: Greet Your Fish and Eat It, Too
description: AT Avra, the fish tour starts just after the aperitifs. It makes for a highly entertaining and educational five minutes, and throughout the evening, you can see Avra's enthusiastic waiters bringing one group after another up to the seafood counter for a brief, meaningful encounter with handsome daurades, soot-colored red porgies, sullen-looking Dover sole and a school of chipper little rougets. The tour combines the best of the Discovery Channel with the pleasure of picking out a pet at Bide-a-Wee. There's no question about it: meeting your fish and picking it out somehow doubles the fun in dinner.

title: Accounts
description: * Egghead.com, Menlo Park, Calif., a Web site selling office and home technology products, to the San Francisco office of Grey Advertising to handle its account. That account had been at the Cupertino, Calif., office of the USWeb/CKS Group, now MarchFirst. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: OPERATOR OF SENIOR COMMUNITIES REDUCES BID FOR REIT'S
description: The Capital Senior Living Corporation, an operator of communities for senior citizens, cut its bid yesterday for ILM Senior Living Inc. and ILM II Senior Living Inc. to $155 million in cash as more competition and higher interest rates have hurt Capital Senior Living's share price. Capital Senior first said in February 1999 that it would buy the closely held real estate investment trusts for $174 million in cash and preferred securities. In August, the Dallas company adjusted the price to $172 million in cash or stock. The deal would add 2,100 residents to communities owned by Capital Senior, which has managed the 13 ILM communities for a fee since 1996. The company currently owns and or operates 36 communities in 18 states with a total capacity of about 6,100 residents.

description: Teenager Charged in Web Attacks

title: Gatti Triggers a Return To Same-Day Weigh-Ins
description: Arturo Gatti conceded yesterday that when he is not in training, his usual weight is ''160 or 165 pounds.''

title: Sports of The Times; Claimed, but Oh, the Heartache
description: Leah Gyarmati received the bad news moments after the race. She could live with finishing second -- she is, after all, 10 for 10 in the money since becoming a trainer -- but having her horse claimed was enough to rock her backward.

description: MARIA ROSSI'S search for a fulfilling career took her around the world -- and home again.

description: WHEN technology stocks took their sharp tumble last week, many companies appeared to lose one of their most important assets -- the ability to lure talented employees with options. To attract and hold the best, you have to offer the chance to strike it rich.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about two first-person accounts of life under the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia misspelled the given name of one author and at some points used that name as her surname. The author of ''First They Killed My Father'' is Loung Ung, not Luong Ung.

title: A Bid for Compromise in Ulster
description: With Northern Ireland's season of emotional anniversaries and marches nearing, the Good Friday peace agreement remains stalled. The Irish Republican Army refuses to commit itself to giving up its arms, and the province's hopeful experiment in self-rule stands suspended. But amid this bleakness, one positive development stands out. David Trimble, Northern Ireland's most important Protestant politician, unmoved by a militant minority in his Ulster Unionist Party, is seeking creative ways around the arms impasse.

title: WISCONSIN ENERGY CHANGES THE TERMS FOR WICOR BUYOUT
description: The Wisconsin Energy Corporation, which had planned to buy Wicor Inc. for $1.2 billion in cash and stock, said yesterday that it would pay all cash for Wicor, Wisconsin's largest natural-gas utility. Wisconsin Energy, owner of the state's biggest power company, agreed in June to buy Wicor for $31.50 a share. The agreement entitled Wicor's shareholders to get all cash if Wisconsin Energy's average stock price during a 10-day period ending yesterday fell below $22 a share; it averaged $20.73. Both companies are based in Milwaukee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, DOROTHY (NEE JACOBS)
description: ROSEN-Dorothy (nee Jacobs). Age 82. Beloved wife of the late Irving Rote Rosen. Cherished mother of Michael, Sheila, Elaine and Anita. Devoted mother-in-law of Heather, Markell and Alan. Proud grandmother of ten and great grandmother of five. Brilliant, beautiful and charitable, she left a lasting impression wherever she went. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Rutland Jewish Center, Rutland, VT. 05701.

title: For Tennessee, First Execution In 40 Years
description: Tennessee executed its first death row inmate in 40 years early this morning. The inmate, Robert Glen Coe, 44, was killed by lethal injection for the 1979 rape and murder of 8-year-old Cary Ann Medlin in the west Tennessee town of Greenfield.

title: Flag Fighters See Momentum in South Carolina
description: The banner that has convulsed South Carolina flies from a single flagpole. But next door in Georgia -- often regarded as the template for a New South state -- the symbol of the old Confederacy flies from a thousand poles as the main element in the official state flag, and the movement to change it is gathering strength.

title: Radical Environmentalist Convicted of Gas Well Blast in Canada
description: Canada's most famous environmental radical, Wiebo A. Ludwig, went to prison today after a judge here convicted him of bombing a gas well in 1998 and encasing another wellhead in concrete.

title: New Subway Line in Transit Budget
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved a new, $17.1 billion version of its five-year budget for capital improvements, including money for a full-length Second Avenue subway line in Manhattan and for cleaner-running buses.

title: Fashion Price Break
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on April 11 about Remedios Varo, a painter who metaphorically depicted scientific concepts like Einstein's special theory of relativity, misspelled the name of the physicist whose equations were used in the theory. He is Hendrik A. Lorentz, not Lorenz.

title: Albany's Back Rooms
description: With much fanfare two years ago, New York's state legislators celebrated a new budget process that was supposed to be more open and democratic. But when a $77 billion budget package failed to win agreement this week because of Gov. George Pataki's last-minute insistence on debt reform, any pretense of legislative democracy in Albany evaporated. While budget conference committees debated in public, the real deals were being engineered by three men in a room -- Governor Pataki, the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver. This deprived the public, and most legislators, of any chance to understand the implications of all the horse-trading.

title: Interpublic Group Combines Two Units
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York said yesterday that it had merged Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco into Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, with offices in Boston and New York.

title: VIRTUALFUND AGREES TO SELL ITS DIGITAL-GRAPHICS UNIT
description: VirtualFund Inc., an investment company with holdings in Internet services and graphics businesses, said it would sell its digital-graphics unit to specialty-chemicals maker MacDermid Inc. for $50 million. VirtualFund, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., said it planned to use the proceeds to develop Internet businesses. The unit sells color printers, ink, film and other products. MacDermid, based in Waterbury, Conn., makes chemicals for graphic arts, electronics and metals and plastics finishing.

title: Voyeur Cams in Nests Offer Bird's-Eye Views Of Fine Feathers
description: Here's a voyeur cam that the whole family can watch. Cornell University's ornithology laboratory is again presenting its Nest Box Cams, small birdhouses equipped with internal video cameras so Web surfers can observe as birds settle down and raise a family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLER, PHYLLIS
description: BUCKLER-Phyllis. On April 19, 2000. Beloved wife of Bruce. Loving and loved mother of Keith and Susan. Adored grandmother of Joseph. Precious sister, cousin, friend. Service on Friday, April 21, 12 Noon, Temple Emanuel, Hicks Lane, Great Neck, New York.

title: Ex-Union President Admits Taking More Than $2 Million
description: A former union president who was once one of New York's most prominent and powerful labor leaders pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $2 million from the public workers he represented and spending it on no-show jobs for friends in Georgia, vacations in Europe and his family's credit card bills.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday, Good Friday and the first and second days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: NORTEL BUYS ARCHITEL
description: Furthering its ambitions in e-commerce, Nortel Networks, the Canadian telecommunications equipment maker, agreed to buy Architel Systems for about $395 million in stock. Architel, a Toronto company with sales of only $47 million last year, makes software for Internet service providers and has worked on several projects with Nortel, which is based in Mississauga, Ontario, a suburb of Toronto. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: After Slow Start, Return of Census Material Shows Improvement
description: Sixty-five percent of American households have returned their census forms, matching the mail-in rate of 10 years ago and enhancing prospects for a successful count, relieved federal officials said today.

title: CREDITORS TAKE OVER THAI CONCERN
description: Lenders to Thai Petrochemical Industry, the largest corporate debtor in Thailand, ousted the company's founder and chief executive in favor of the Australian management concern Ferrier Hodgson, ending two decades of family management and more than two years of dispute over the company's $3.5 billion in debt. In a decision heralded as a bellwether for vital financial restructuring, Thailand's bankruptcy court declared Thai Petrochemical insolvent in March, but left it to the company's more than 100 creditors to vote on who should plan Thai Petrochemical's court-supervised rehabilitation. Thai Petrochemical's chief executive, Prachai Leophairatana, had proposed a venture with Ernst & Young that would have left him in charge. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Giuliani and Clinton Argue On Gifts and Environment
description: Seeking to draw links between the candidates and the donations they receive, the Clinton and Giuliani Senate campaigns today accused each other of accepting soft-money contributions from questionable donors.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Mass of Nuclear Friction; Tension and Mistrust at New High for British Complex
description: When John Storer took over a new high-profile job at Britain's most dispute-ridden nuclear complex in September, he expected ''a fairly steep learning curve.'' Instead, he said, ''World War III started shortly afterward.''

title: SHAREHOLDER GROUP WITHDRAWS BID FOR HAYES LEMMERZ
description: Hayes Lemmerz International Inc. said yesterday that its majority shareholders had withdrawn their $131.3 million bid for the company, the world's largest maker of automobile wheels, because the sides could not reach an agreement on price. The shareholder group led by Joseph Littlejohn & Levy Inc. in January offered $21 a share for the 25 percent of the common stock it does not already own. The group had been in talks with Hayes Lemmerz and its financial advisers since mid-February. Shares of Hayes Lemmerz, which is based in Northville, Mich., fell $2.3125, to $15.3125 each, in Nasdaq trading. They have fallen 14 percent since Jan. 7, the last trading day before the shareholder bid was announced.

title: Nets Lose And Wait For the Ax To Fall
description: As sad as it was, it was perhaps only fitting that this abysmal Nets season of blown leads and last-minute losses concluded as it did tonight at Continental Arena. With all of the faults and shortcomings that have dogged Coach Don Casey's team converging to form one ugly, disheartening finale, the Nets lost to the Cleveland Cavaliers because, of all things, a late-game collapse.

title: New Victories in Parliament Show Strong Hand of Putin
description: Last week, President-elect Vladimir V. Putin pushed the long-awaited ratification of a major arms control treaty through a compliant lower house of Parliament. Today, he scored a victory with regional bosses in Parliament's upper chamber, easily winning a vote to get rid of a prosecutor who was the scourge of former President Boris N. Yeltsin's Kremlin.

title: Investor Raises Questions on Sotheby's Board
description: Ronald Baron, the New York money manager whose funds are the largest shareholders in Sotheby's Holdings Inc., has questioned the auction house board's independence in a filing with the government.

title: Breaking, Not Making, the Mold
description: Traversing the iron and glass arcaded gallerias that canopy the 19th-century shopping arcades like grand hotel palms, a visitor to Milan's furniture fair encountered an unsettling fact: the 20th century is now the past, too.

title: ROYAL AHOLD BUYS ANOTHER CHAIN OF CONVENIENCE STORES
description: The Dutch company Royal Ahold N.V., one of the world's largest retailers, agreed yesterday to acquire Golden Gallon Inc., a chain of 134 convenience stores and gasoline stations in the Southeast. The price was not disclosed. The purchase of Golden Gallon, which is based in Chattanooga, Tenn., and had $300 million in sales last year, follows Royal Ahold's acquisition of Sugar Creek, a similar company, which is based in New York state. Royal Ahold, which had $31.8 billion in sales last year, is one of the largest supermarket companies on the East Coast. It owns the Stop & Shop, Finast and Giant chains. Golden Gallon will operate as a division of BI-LO, the supermarket chain Royal Ahold acquired in 1997.
