description: To the Editor:

title: Lila Kedrova, Known for Oscar-Winning Role in 'Zorba,' Dies
description: Lila Kedrova, the Russian-born actress whose portrayals of an aging French prostitute in screen and stage versions of ''Zorba the Greek'' won her an Academy Award and a Tony, died on Feb. 16 in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. She was believed to be around 82.

title: Smith & Wesson's Word Game
description: It is disappointing, though not really surprising, that Smith & Wesson would try to retreat from some parts of its deal with the Clinton administration to change the way it designs, distributes and markets guns. The company's embrace of a sensible menu of safety restrictions in exchange for ending threatened lawsuits against it brought fierce criticism and financial pressure from other firearms manufacturers, distributors and gun dealers. But Smith & Wesson cannot change the clear meaning of the legal settlement simply by posting implausible ''clarifications'' on its Web site.

title: Stryker Plans Stock Split
description: The Stryker Corporation, a surgical and medical products maker, said today that it would split its stock 2 for 1. The split will double the number of shares to 194.4 million while halving the value of each share. The new shares will be issued May 12 to shareholders of record as of May 1. The company had revenue of $2.1 billion in 1999. Shares of Stryker were up $5.75 today at $73.9375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Arguments on Miranda Rights
description: Following are excerpts from the official transcript of the arguments today before the Supreme Court in Dickerson v. United States, as recorded by the Alderson Reporting Company. The Times has supplied the identity of the justices who asked questions, because that information is not part of the official transcript.

title: BLUE CIRCLE BID RAISED
description: The world's largest building-materials maker, Lafarge of France, raised its hostile bid for Blue Circle Industries, the biggest British cement maker, to $:3.65 billion ($5.76 billion). Lafarge offered 450 pence in cash for each Blue Circle share, 7.1 percent more than its previous bid. The company, which has been buying stock on the market, probably owns 29 percent of Blue Circle, said Lafarge's chief executive, Bertrand Collomb. Blue Circle rejected the latest offer.

title: Lamps Ease Back From High Tech To Cast a Mood Instead
description: AT Euroluce 2000, the international lighting exhibition last week in Milan, it was the year of ambience, with mood overshadowing wattage. It was refreshing to see a swing toward lyrical fashion lighting, and away from itty-bitty task lights and superfluous technology. (Of course, the designers at Droog were already parodying fussy ''fashionable'' matches of lighting and decor, with a night light by Jaap van Arkel (3) that takes a swipe of floral wallpaper for its shade.)

title: Detectives Find Clues in Killing of a Livery-Cab Driver in Brooklyn
description: Detectives have recovered a chain, key ring and pendant from the scene of the killing of a livery-cab driver in Brooklyn that may provide clues to the crime, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGENSTERN, FELICE BENEDICT
description: MORGENSTERN-Felice Benedict, beloved wife of Frederic Morgenstern, devoted Mother of Catherine and Michael Benedict, and proud of her grandchildren, Nicholas, Matthew & Jonathon Benedict passed away on April 17. She will be painfully missed not only by her family, colleagues and friends but also by the Martinez School District where she was appreciated by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALES, DECOURSEY JR.
description: FALES-DeCoursey Jr. Archaeologist and Professor of History, died in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on 12 April, 2000, of a heart attack. He was born in New York City on 9 March 1918, the son of Dorothy M. and DeCoursey Fales. He was enrolled in the Knickerbocker Grays, attended the Buckley School in Manhattan, St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., and Harvard, where he graduated magna cum laude A.B. 1941, he received his M.A. in Classics in 1948 and his Ph.D. in 1957, both at Harvard also. He served in the Army during World War II, and afterwards in the Army Reserve with rank of Lieutenant Colonel. Under the auspices of the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Fales excavated on Cyprus, near Episkopi on the south coast, between Paphos and Limassol, in ancient Kurion on Episkopi Bay. On his return to the U.S., Mr. Fales worked for several years as Junior Fellow at Dumbarton Oaks in Washington, D.C. Mr. Fales taught classics and history, first at Oberlin College, and subsequently at Emerson College, Boston, for 25 years. For many years, Mr. Fales was a member of the Visiting Committee for the Department of Greek and Roman Art in the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. He was also the treasurer of the Scholarly Quarterly ''Greek, Roman and Byzantine Studies.'' In 1966, he married Iten Noa Scott of Martha's Vineyard and Boston, a program producer for WGBH Radio. He is survived by his wife, two younger brothers, Haliburton Fales II of Manhattan and Gladstone, New Jersey, and Timothy Fales of Paris, France, seven nieces and nephews, four stepchildren, nine step-grandchildren and two step-greatgrandchildren, to whom he was a loving, understanding father.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CHARLES E. SMITH RESIDENTIAL REALTY INC., Arlington, Va., a real estate investment trust, said it had bought a high-rise apartment tower in Chicago and would start development of another for a total cost of about $128 million.

''I tightened my belt,'' she said. ''The kids know not to ask for a lot of things. And I haven't paid my health benefits yet.''

description: ELECTRICITY bills depend on how much electricity is used each month. Soon auto insurance premiums, too, may be metered, based partly on how much the car is driven.

title: Billions of Pages? That's the Job for Software Reading Census Forms
description: IN his 30-year career, Richard Taylor, an information technology architect with Lockheed Martin Mission Systems, has taken on some extremely complex jobs. He has helped turn the F.B.I.'s fingerprint files into an electronic database, designed systems for airlines that make sure there is a gate free for every arriving flight and developed an archive of high-quality digital images for the National Gallery of Art.

title: Praise for Court Ruling and Prayer From a Jubilant Crowd Gathered in Little Havana
description: In the crisp, navy blue T-shirts of the private Our Lady of the Rosary School, 16 children, 3 to 5 years old, fidgeted with their beads today and pressed their hands in prayer at the chain-link fence in front of Elian Gonzalez's home in Little Havana.

title: No Motive Found in 2 S.I. Stabbing Deaths
description: Two friends found stabbed to death in a Staten Island apartment Tuesday night had not been seen in nearly four days, officials said.

title: Increases in Price of Oil Widen U.S. Trade Deficit
description: The United States trade deficit widened to a record in February, elevated by surging oil prices and growing demand for imports, government figures showed today.

title: Canada Arrests 15-Year-Old In Web Attack
description: Canadian law enforcement officials said yesterday that they had arrested a Montreal high school student in one of the computer attacks that crippled some of the Internet's biggest sites in February, exposing deep vulnerabilities in the fledgling world of electronic commerce.

title: The Court's Picayune Power
description: The Supreme Court gave two Virginia death row inmates reprieves on Tuesday. But its opinions invoked neither the grand theme of justice possibly miscarried nor the historical importance of the great writ of habeas corpus, which permits federal judges to review the work of state courts. Instead, victory for the prisoners, a rare event in the current court, turned on the meaning of such everyday words as ''unreasonable'' and ''failed.''

title: Look, Doc, No Pad! An Rx for Prescriptions
description: The poor quality of doctors' handwriting has long been a source of jokes. But to Glen Tullman, chief executive of Allscripts, a company in Libertyville, Ill., doctors with poor penmanship are also a serious health risk. ''A significant number of medical errors come from physicians' handwriting,'' he said. ''When you rent a car they use a computer because they don't want to make an error. Here you're dealing with something that's a life-and-death issue.''

Devoted mother to Emily, Cookie, Carolyn and Seth and beloved mother-in-law of Fernando, Alan, Joe and Lynn. She is lovingly remembered by her nine grandchildren David, Jason, Nancy, Carolyn, Julia, Rachel, Fredda, Andrew & Sari. Also remembered by her three great grandchildren Jack, Brandon and Hannah. With courage, grace and dignity, she waged a one year battle with cancer, lovingly cared for by her friend Deborah Grant. Her family and friends will forever cherish her memory for her intelligence, humility, charm and inherent goodness. She was a much loved wife, remarkable mother and grandmother, devoted sister to Alice, Miriam and Ethel and loyal friend. She always put the concerns and wellbeing of others before her own. Contributions may be made in her name to the Cabrini Hospice care of Mary Cook, 227 E. 19 St., NY, NY 10003. Funeral Services Sunday, April 23rd at 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. NYC.

title: APPLIED MICRO TO PURCHASE SEMICONDUCTOR DEVELOPER
description: The Applied Micro Circuits Corporation said yesterday that it agreed to buy YuniNetworks Inc., a privately held semiconductor developer, in a stock deal valued at $241 million. Applied Micro will issue up to 2.25 million shares of its common stock and options in exchange for all outstanding shares of YuniNetworks' preferred and common stock. Applied Micro's shares fell $4.125 each, to $103.125, in Nasdaq trading. The San Diego-based manufacturer of integrated circuits said the acquisition would expand its markets for high-speed communications products.

description: A bomb exploded beside a McDonald's in a small town in Brittany today, killing a restaurant worker. The Interior Ministry suggested that it was the work of an obscure Breton separatist movement.

But the Compassion Flower Inn also boasts an elaborate marijuana mosaic in the tile surrounding the hot tub in the lovers' suite, and walls stenciled with marijuana leaves in the ''hemp bedroom.''

title: A Story Still Painful After Repeated Tellings
description: One day a successful play might appear about Leo Frank, who was killed by a lynch mob after his death sentence had been commuted to life for a murder he insisted he did not commit. An incident that helped revive the Ku Klux Klan and was instrumental in the founding of the Anti Defamation League of B'nai B'rith must have some dramatic value.

title: Plan for Hudson River Institute Gains Ground
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki outlined plans in Albany in his State of the State speech in January for a world-class science center along the Hudson River -- a kind of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution for rivers -- there was applause, but no one ran for the exits to spread the news. Such speeches are generally full of trial balloons.

title: Dadaist's Heirs Also Fight Marlborough Over Estate
description: Marlborough, the international art gallery heavily fined in 1975 for defrauding the Mark Rothko estate and accused in court last month of cheating the Francis Bacon estate, is also fighting a legal battle over the estate of Kurt Schwitters, the German Dadaist known for his collages, who died in 1948.

title: Sacrificing Beauty for Anger
description: A few seconds after Peter Brotzmann sounded his first tenor saxophone notes at Tonic on Monday night, his face matched the color of the wine-dark velvet curtains bracketing the stage. And it stayed that way as he employed 10-finger fluttering motions and swiped up and down at the instrument's keys, playing long, screaming lines. There is beauty, certainly, in some nonmelodic, freely structured, high-energy jazz. But Mr. Brotzmann doesn't care about beauty at all -- or, more probably, he sees it as all of a piece with darkness, tension and irritability.

title: Mexican Election Spotlights Ailing School System
description: The Alfredo del Mazo elementary school has no running water or phone, and a short circuit knocked out the electric power for most of this year. Rain blows in on the pupils through broken classroom windows when thunderstorms sweep across the cactus outside.

description: Europe's largest consumer-electronics maker, Royal Philips Electronics, said its first-quarter profit rose 61 percent, driven by rising sales of mobile phones and semiconductors as well as falling costs. Profit from operations rose to 493 million euros ($466.7 million) from 306 million euros in the corresponding period a year ago, beating analysts' estimates. The company's chief executive, Cor Boonstra, above, has slimmed Philips down to six divisions, returned the phone unit to profit and started ventures like LG.Philips, the biggest maker of liquid-crystal displays. Philips said profit would rise at least 10 percent this year.

After the publishers told her that finding an audience for the book would be difficult, Ms. Shapiro, who writes under the name M. J. Rose, set out to prove them wrong. She created a Web site where the book could be downloaded for a fee, then waited for her audience to come to her. Few came.

Warwick Community Bancorp, the holding company for Warwick Savings Bank, in Orange County, N.Y., owns 8.4 percent of GSB Financial, based in Goshen, N.Y. Buying the 1.8 million shares it does not own at $18 would cost Warwick $32.4 million. GSB said its board was reviewing the offer. GSB's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $15, after rising $3.50 each on Wednesday. Warwick's stock was up 43.75 cents at $10.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARTIN H., M.D.
description: STEIN-Martin H., M.D. The members of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague, Dr. Martin H. Stein, a revered and honored clinician, an educator who trained and guided several generations of psychoanalysts. He was constantly sought after as a supervisor and mentor. He will be deeply missed for his brilliance, clarity and wit. As past president of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Chairman of the Education Committee, for many years, he was a guiding spirit of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. His renown was international and his contributions to psychoanalytic thinking were significant and numerous. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Mrs. Lucille Stein, and his family. There will be a memorial service at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, 247 East 82 Street, New York to be announced at a later date. Albert M. title: Under the Microscope: Ty Cobb's Shifting Self-Image
description: ''Cobb,'' a generally effective if bite-size new play by Lee Blessing, is not a stage biography so much as it is the parsing of a man's self-image. The man in question happens to be Ty Cobb, the ballplayer whose unparalleled achievements were shadowed by the misanthropy of a man who believes his greatness to be earned and unappreciated. And as in the like-titled 1994 film by Ron Shelton, it is the connection between those things that is the focus of Mr. Blessing's exploration.

title: United and Divided by the Basketball Hoop
description: ''Love and Basketball'' equates those two things with happiness, and the use of Al Green's song ''Love and Happiness'' at the very beginning underscores that point. The film, the directorial debut of the writer Gina Prince-Bythewood, often has an enchanting, lived-in homeyness as it follows the lives of Monica and Quincy. They meet at age 11, when she moves next door to him in what looks like the Baldwin Hills section of Los Angeles, an upper-middle-class African-American enclave. She's a skinny, surly tomboy (played at this age by the charismatic young Kyla Platt) with a surefire touch with a basketball: she hits from the top of the key just like her hero, Magic Johnson, and she already has a showboat trademark, letting her wrist hang after she shoots.

The broccoli's thrown in next to the carrots, the former Communists with the capitalists, and most of all, says the Italian commentator Lucio Caracciolo, no beef anywhere.

title: FUNCO SAYS ELECTRONICS BOUTIQUE HAS RAISED ITS BID

Electronics Boutique initially offered $17.50 a share, a bid that Funco accepted on April 3. Barnes & Noble made its higher bid three days later through its Babbage's Etc. video-game software retail unit. Funco said on April 13 that it planned to accept the higher proposal if Electronics Boutique did not raise its offer. The bidding war has driven up the stock price of Funco, which is based in Eden Prairie, Minn. The shares closed yesterday at $21.28125, up 53.125 cents, compared with a price below $12 on March 31.

title: KOREAN JOBLESS RATE DROPS
description: South Korea's unemployment rate posted its biggest decline in six months in March as the construction and agriculture industries stepped up hiring and start-up companies generated more jobs. The seasonally adjusted rate fell to 4.1 percent from 4.4 percent in February, the Finance and Economy Ministry said. That was the biggest drop since September. Without adjustment for seasonal variations, the rate fell to 4.7 percent from 5.3 percent. Unemployment has fallen since January 1999, when it reached 7.8 percent, as a return to economic growth generates more jobs.

She was also a member of the Adirondack League Club and the Altar Guild at Christ's Church till the time of her death. She is survived by a son Samuel L. Brookfield Jr. and his wife Pauline of New York, NY. Two daughters Nancy and her husband Duncan Burke of Greenwich, CT; Lee and her husband Jim Rafferty of Medfield, MA and 8 grandchildren. The service is Saturday April 22 at Christ's Church, Rectory Street, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to Christ's Church or Osborne Home, both in Rye, NY.

title: A Violinist Takes Risks In His Debut Recital
description: Timothy Fain, a violinist from California who won the Young Concert Artists International Auditions last year, played his New York debut recital on Tuesday evening at the 92nd Street Y. His program was a straightforward blend of the thoughtful and the showy, with sonatas by Beethoven, Faure and William Bolcom, and a touch of Sarasate fireworks as a finale.

title: The City Life; Where the Ginkgos Grow
description: New York is a city of boxes stacked upon boxes -- boxes of glass and steel, concrete and brick -- pyramids and pillars of architectural boxes piled up to the sky. Everywhere you look you see the riser and tread of the skyline, the sheer vertical escarpment of the streetline, offset, wherever possible, by architectural details and by plantings that relieve the city's inherent cubism. This is just as true in the far streets of outer Brooklyn and Queens as it is in Midtown Manhattan. On Woodhaven Boulevard in Queens, just before it turns into Cross Bay Boulevard, the rows of flat-roofed rectangular houses wear single eyebrows -- inverted V's -- on their second stories. Those shingled circumflexes are meant to suggest gable-roofed domesticity, a sign of the buildings' purpose and a redirection from pure rectangularity.

title: Balance and Brains Show Who's Boss
description: I hadn't been studying Brazilian jiujitsu all that long (only two years) when, on a recent evening, I lay on the mat, face up, grimacing, with a big guy I'd never met before yanking my arm in a direction the muscles were not exactly pleased to go. The position was known as an arm bar, and it called for an arm (mine) to be gripped at the wrist by a pair of hands (the big guy's) and then pulled slowly down over a fulcrum (the big guy's pelvic bone) so the arm bent counter to nature much like the blade of a pocketknife bending too far back against its hinge.

title: Russian Banks Hold Enigmas Within Mazes; U.S. Tries to Follow Path Of Suspected Wrongdoing
description: Not long ago, MDM Bank, one of the hundreds of modest-sized banks that sprang up here after the collapse of communism, offered a service that allowed Russian companies to cut costs, at the government's expense. Instead of paying salaries to their employees -- and the associated pension contributions to the government -- they gave the employees interest payments on company deposits in the bank.

title: War Memorial Is Stolen From a Brooklyn Park
description: A seven-foot bronze war memorial statue, with an estimated weight of 1,000 to 1,500 pounds, has been stolen from Saratoga Square Park in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Marshaling Early Insights In Veneration of the Tree
description: Any time is a good time to look at the photographs of William Henry Fox Talbot and marvel anew at a man who invented a photographic process in the 1830's and straightaway created images of astounding modernist artistry. This year is the 200th anniversary of his birth, and as if it needed an excuse, Hans P. Kraus Jr. Inc., on the Upper East Side, has organized an exhibition of about a dozen of Talbot's images, which are shown alongside those by a dozen or so of his contemporaries. The theme is trees, and if only God can make a tree, then photographers working in the early days of this medium did surpassing homage to his creation.

title: A Rich Culture With Shallow Roots
description: The continued persecution of Gypsies -- or Roma, as they call themselves in their own language -- has become a pressing human rights concern in post-Communist Eastern Europe. Jasmine Dellal's new documentary confronts the prejudice and misperception that the Roma face in this country. It may surprise you to learn that the United States is home to one million Roma, who speak variations of the Romani language and continue to live according to traditions that remain mysterious to outsiders.

Happily, ''Don't Let Me Die on a Sunday,'' a grim little morsel of charcuterie directed by Didier Le Pecheur, makes the job easy. A simple summary of its first few scenes will render any judgment superfluous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSHER, DOROTHY (NEE COLE)
description: GREENSHER - Dorothy (nee Cole), 84 years old, of Delray Beach, Florida, died April 17, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Irving Greensher and Max Kleinman; mother of Barry Kleinman and the late Sandra Raynor; grandmother of Jeff Kleinman, Daniel and Robert Raynor, and great-grandmother of four. Her eternal optimism, warmth, good humor and generosity will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 23, at 1:30 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St., NY, and interment will be at Sharon Gardens, 273 Lakeview Ave., Valhalla, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Deborah Hospital Foundation, 1515 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL. 33432, Suite 304, Delray Chapter 1108.

title: Ernst Knobil, 73, a Physiologist Who Helped to Treat Infertility
description: Dr. Ernst Knobil, a physiologist whose studies of the hormonal system led to a better understanding of the female reproductive function and improved treatment of infertility, died on April 13 at the Texas Medical Center in Houston. He was 73 and lived in Houston.

title: AmSouth in Buyback
description: AmSouth Bancorp, a regional bank based in Birmingham, Ala., said today that it would buy back up to 35 million of its shares. The buyback represents about 9 percent of AmSouth's stock outstanding. AmSouth's stock was up 25 cents, at $14.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: INTEREST IN PHONE CONCERN
description: The chairman of France Telecom, Michel Bon, reaffirmed his interest in acquiring Orange P.L.C., Britain's third-largest mobile phone operator. Orange must be sold or spun off by Vodafone AirTouch which acquired Orange as part of its purchase of Mannesmann. Mr. Bon said France Telecom would wait until the auction for third generation wireless licenses before bidding for Orange. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: It's Over For All That Elegance
description: Karl Lagerfeld, the Paris couturier, recently cut off his signature silver ponytail. Instead of looking like an 18th-century prince, he now resembles a movie star. And why not? A new cut for a new life. After living with 18th-century French antiques for decades, he has decided to purge himself of the 18th century and begin again in the 21st.

title: Mora's Shot Warms Mets At Cold Shea
description: Melvin Mora dropped his bat and acted as if he had just hit a single. He motored to first base while keeping his eyes focused on center field, watching his booming shot off Curtis Leskanic sail higher and higher. Could it go? Would it go?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATENSTEIN, MARVIN
description: SATENSTEIN - Marvin. Passed away April 20, 2000 after his courageous battle with cancer. Loving husband & best friend of Edna for forty-six years. Cherished father of Lisa, David and Paul. Devoted ''Papa'' to Christina, Ryann, Taren, Cody, Kyle and Jaden. He was a self-employed paper broker in NYC. He served as a fighter pilot in the U.S. Air Force in WWII and Korea. Recipient of the Distinguished Flying Cross and other high honors, and retired as a Major in 1980. His other achievements include being an Eagle Scout, on the Board of Directors of Camp Poyntelle & Hexter and United Jewish Federation. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Saturday 6-9PM with service Sunday 10AM. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to any cancer-related cause.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 12 about the acquittal of Patrick Griffin, a Manhattan doctor accused of having molested a patient, misstated one reason an appellate court had ordered the retrial. The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled that Justice Marcy L. Kahn had improperly prevented defense lawyers from asking his accuser about her prior lawsuits, her finances and what the lawyers contended was her false testimony in a landlord-tenant case. Justice Kahn did not forbid them to ask about a $10 million civil lawsuit making the same accusation that the patient had filed against the doctor.

title: AETHER SAYS IT WILL PAY UP TO $90 MILLION FOR NETSEARCH
description: Aether Systems, which provides a broad range of wireless data services, said yesterday that it was acquiring NetSearch for $25 million in cash and an additional $65 million payable over 13 months if the company meets specified revenue targets. NetSearch, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., has developed a system that enables companies to receive and respond quickly to inquiries made on Internet sites via hand-held devices. Aether, based in Owings Mills, Md., said NetSearch's system had been widely adopted in the automotive industry and was being quickly embraced in other businesses like real estate and insurance.

title: Microsoft Sees Some Bumps In Its Earnings
description: Microsoft reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings were a couple of cents above Wall Street's expectations, but the number everyone was watching from this bellwether of the PC industry was revenue, which trailed most analysts' estimates.

title: Legal Fight Over Boy Could Last For Months
description: The federal appellate court decision on Wednesday preventing Elian Gonzalez from leaving the country showed that the courts are rarely a place to get quick answers to the kinds of volatile questions raised by the battle over 6-year-old Elian.

title: Lane Is Sent To the Colts
description: The Carolina Panthers traded running back Fred Lane to the Indianapolis Colts yesterday for linebacker Spencer Reid.

title: Sports of The Times; For Knicks And Carter, A Stretch
description: MORE and more in sports, television is the tail that wags the dog.

title: One Life's Restless End
description: When Mai O'Hara opens her eyes, serenity runs away. Not that this 53-year-old Irishwoman looks peaceful as she sleeps; even in repose, her chalky face speaks of a discontent that goes beyond her physical pain. But once the eyes open -- preternaturally blue eyes that her husband describes as ''potent, dense, hard'' -- the room jangles with her restlessness. In the midst of death, Mai O'Hara is ferociously alive.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Candid Matthaus a Bit Too Candid for MetroStars
description: After enduring what might be the most trying month of his illustrious career, Lothar Matthaus is scheduled to board a flight to Germany shortly after the MetroStars play D.C. United on Saturday night, with the renowned sweeper going to his homeland to play in an exhibition game with the German national team.

title: Christopher Wilmarth
description: Robert Miller

title: Can a 6-Year-Old Apply for Asylum?
description: To the Editor:

title: Surfside Sidelined By a Bone Chip
description: Surfside, the 3-year-old filly who was considered a candidate for either the Kentucky Derby or the Kentucky Oaks, was found yesterday to have a bone chip in her left front ankle that will keep her from racing for several months.

title: Robert Melee
description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: Citizens to Buy Back Stock
description: Citizens Utilities said this week that it planned to buy back as much as $100 million of its stock and up to $25 million worth of shares of Electric Lightwave, its 82 percent-owned unit. Citizens is expected to buy back about 6.5 million, or 2.5 percent, of its outstanding shares. It will also buy about 1.3 million shares, or 15 percent, of Electric Lightwave's Class A shares. Shares of Citizens Utilities, which is changing its name to Citizens Communications on May 18, rose 18.75 cents today, to $16.0625. Electric Lightwave rose $1, to $20.

title: People-Smuggling Suspect Is Held After 5-Year Hunt
description: After a five-year pursuit spanning Asia and the Americas, the authorities say the Hong Kong police have captured a ringleader of the Golden Venture human smuggling operation, in which 10 illegal Chinese immigrants died after a freighter ran aground off Queens in 1993.

title: Regulators Confront Web Role in Politics
description: If a New York businessman running for Congress puts a link in his corporate Web site to his campaign Web site, does that run afoul of laws restricting corporate political activities?

title: Outbreak of TB Afflicts Transgender People
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has identified an outbreak of H.I.V.-related tuberculosis among young transgender people in New York and Baltimore. The first cases turned up in Baltimore in the summer of 1998, and 26 cases in the two cities have since been diagnosed. Four of those infected have died.

title: Ex-Bear Stearns Executive Is Barred From Securities Industry
description: Richard Harriton, the former chairman of the securities clearing subsidiary of Bear Stearns, will pay $1 million in penalties and be barred from the securities industry under a settlement disclosed yesterday by securities regulators.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Suit Against Anonymous Pest Revives Online Speech Law
description: April 21, 2000

title: De Coursey Fales, 82, Expert on Ancient Vase
description: De Coursey Fales Jr., an archaeologist and professor of history whose in-depth study of a single Greek vase shed light on the art and mythology of the ancient world, died on April 12 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, MAX (AUFRICHTIG)
description: ALBERT-Max (Aufrichtig). On April 19th, 2000. Age 84. Beloved husband of the late Alida. Loving father of Marv, Al and Steve. Cherished grandfather of Kenny, Jackie, Brian, Denise, Casey and great-grandfather of Amanda. Dear companion to Anne Zeide. Services on Sunday 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Beth Moses cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Cardiovascular Institute of Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, SAMUEL I.
description: HARRISON-Samuel I. Died April 17, 2000 in Albuquerque, formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Survived by his wife Mina, daughter Myrna Changar, grandchildren, Christopher Kaufman, David Changar, Susan Changar, Seth Kaufman & Hillary Kaufman, & great-grandchildren Zoe and Samuel Kaufman, and brother Louis Harrison. President Emeritus of DKFBA. Services Sunday, 11:30 A.M., I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Elmont, New York.

title: Pat de Groot
description: Pat Hearn

title: An 80's Story Of Gay Life
description: Steve Buscemi savors Bill Sherwood's ''Parting Glances'' for several reasons. ''As an actor it's the best role I've ever been offered,'' he said. More than that, as a film released in 1986 about AIDS and gay life in New York, it was one of the first of its kind. ''What impressed me about the writing was that the characters just happened to be gay,'' Mr. Buscemi said. ''It just seemed close to a lot of people who were living in New York then.''

title: Pipilotti Rist
description: 'Open My Glade'

title: A City Bedazzling Generations
description: NORA MILLER and Emily Ryals, separately making their first trips to New York, each went to the top of an amazingly tall building, caught some theater, visited cathedrals, admired the Statue of Liberty, walked through Chinatown and poked their heads into the New York Stock Exchange. Both had a swell time.

title: Cities Failing To Heed Call Of the Census
description: Despite a fierce campaign by federal and city officials, mail responses to the census ranked among the lowest in the nation in Hartford and Newark, both cities with large pockets of poor residents who do not speak English fluently and who may not trust the authorities.

title: When Rome Was (a) Cultural Pacesetter or (b) Has-Been
description: When, artistically speaking, does a great city know its time has passed? I couldn't help thinking a little of New York while I was meandering through ''The Splendor of 18th-Century Rome'' at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: Haitian-Americans March To Protest Brutality by Police
description: Thousands of Haitian-American protesters marched through Brooklyn to City Hall yesterday in an all-day rally to protest police brutality and demand the resignation of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Addressing Concerns, Bush Is Said to Assemble Team of Washington Insiders
description: After months of questions and criticisms about how fully Gov. George W. Bush would integrate nationally seasoned veterans into his presidential bid, the Bush campaign has tapped six prominent Republican strategists in Washington to help Mr. Bush's associates here chart their course, Republican officials close to the campaign said today.

title: Sprewell's Style Thriving In Knicks' Fast Lane
description: The scattered lights across the San Francisco Bay seem as distant as stars when a black Lamborghini pulls out of the night sky and crawls onto the San Mateo Bridge.

title: ROGERS'S LOSS NARROWS
description: Canada's largest cable television and wireless phone company, Rogers Communications of Toronto, reported a smaller operating loss in the first quarter, although it failed to meet analysts' forecasts, and assets sales again produced a profit: 19.3 million Canadian dollars, or 5 cents a share. On operations alone, Rogers lost 33.1 million Canadian dollars, or 21 Canadian cents a share, in the latest period. Analysts surveyed by First Call had expected a loss of 5 Canadian cents a share. A year earlier, the loss was 62.9 million Canadian dollars, or 42 Canadian cents. Revenue for the first three months of 2000 rose by 14 percent to 808 million Canadian dollars. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, RICHARD J.
description: MAYER-Richard J. On April 19, 2000. Loving husband of the late Helen Aberson Mayer. Cherished father of Andrew. Dear grandfather of Andrew. Beloved father-inlaw of Carmen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Saturday 11AM to 1PM. A brief memorial service to follow. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association and National Parkinson's Association.

title: COCAINE WAR: A special report.; A Web of Drugs and Strife in Colombia
description: Nearly half the world's supply of cocaine originates within 150 miles of this isolated Colombian military outpost on the Putumayo River. So when Lt. German Arenas and his anti-drug troops recently set out by boat, they knew that finding a target would be the easy part.

title: Coach Of Raptors Not Ruffled By Camby
description: Raptors Coach Butch Carter today played down critical published remarks directed toward him by the Knicks' Marcus Camby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADLEY, MARY E.
description: BRADLEY-Mary E. The employees of International Registries, Inc. deeply mourn the loss of our dear and respected colleague, Mary E. Bradley, on April 14, 2000. Our sympathies and heartfelt condolences to her wonderful mother Margaret, brothers Bill and Mike, and their families.

title: Tactical Odyssey of George Wallace
description: A deathbed conversion may save a person's soul, but it can't erase the actions of his life. How late-life changes affect the historical record is a muddier issue, as illustrated by the case of George C. Wallace, who had one of the most explosive careers and one of the most curious final acts in American politics.

title: Finding Succor At the Cinema
description: ''Set Me Free,'' the moving new film by the Canadian director Lea Pool, immediately feels intensely autobiographical: it is the story of a 13-year-old Montreal girl (the gifted newcomer Karine Vanasse) whose adolescent quest for identity is complicated by a difficult family life but soothed by her visits to the movies. One rainy day she discovers a magnificent role model in the figure of Anna Karina, playing a strong-willed prostitute in Jean-Luc Godard's 1962 New Wave classic ''Vivre Sa Vie'' (''My Life to Live'').

title: There's a Model on the Hood of My De Soto
description: WAY before the term ''politically incorrect'' was coined, auto shows epitomized it. The director of the New York Auto Show in 1970, Charles Snitow, wrote that ''girl watchers'' need not be reminded that ''the show is a paradise of pulchritude on all five floors of the Coliseum.'' He was a man who knew his audience.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This means our entire conception of dinosaurs may have to be revised.''

title: Parent Files Complaint, Saying Schools Lack Diversity
description: Frustrated by the low number of minority teachers in the Westport public schools, the father of an elementary school student here has filed a formal complaint with the federal Department of Labor charging the school district with discriminatory hiring practices.

title: Born for Gambling, in a Casino and Metaphysically
description: Even while wearing the poker face that is an occupational necessity for his juicy title role in Mike Hodges's film ''Croupier,'' Clive Owen conveys a sharp, cynical intelligence that rolls off the screen in waves whenever he widens his glittering blue eyes. Mr. Owen's character, Jack Manfred, spends much of the movie dealing cards and raking in chips at a posh London casino where he takes a malicious pleasure in observing the well-heeled punters (gamblers) who flock around his table, compulsively throwing away their money. But the pressure for Jack to maintain an impermeable mask takes its toll; by the end of an evening, the accumulated tension leaves him a frayed, quivering wreck.

title: Evanescent Trees and Sisters In an Enchanted 1970's Suburb
description: Lux Lisbon, one of the five self-doomed sisters whose lissome dance toward extinction is the subject of Sofia Coppola's first movie (and of Jeffrey Eugenides's first novel, on which it is based), is first glimpsed in the act of finishing a red Popsicle. As played -- incarnated might be a better word -- by Kirsten Dunst, Lux is at once a blond icon of girlish suburban innocence and an emblem of womanly eroticism. Like Sue Lyon in Stanley Kubrick's ''Lolita,'' with her lollipop and her heart-shaped sunglasses, Ms. Dunst turns Lux's every glance and gesture into an ambiguous provocation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LYNCH, DONAL
description: LYNCH-Donal. April 21, 1932-November 17, 1994. Happy birthday, dad. I miss you every day. Love, Danielle

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campaign Briefing column yesterday about Representative James P. Moran, Democrat of Virginia, referred incorrectly to the Republican challenger who called on Mr. Moran to apologize to the family of a boy he accused of trying to steal his car. The challenger, Demaris H. Miller, is a woman.

title: GOLDMAN MAY BE BARRED
description: The No. 1 underwriter of Asian stocks in the first quarter, the Goldman Sachs Group, may be disqualified from arranging Nippon Telegraph and Telephone's planned $13 billion share sale because of a soured stock offering in Europe last month. The Japanese Finance Ministry, headed by Kiichi Miyazawa, above, said it might bar Goldman from managing the sale of a million state-held shares in N.T.T. -- one of the world's biggest stock offers, paying fees of $216 million. The possible disqualification is related to the fact that documents for World Online International, a Dutch Internet access provider that Goldman took public in March, did not clearly say that its chairwoman had sold much of her stock before the offering.

title: So Lost Looking for Easy Money
description: In many ways, Sasha, the cocky 17-year-old street hustler at the center of Constantine Giannaris's pungent film ''From the Edge of the City,'' is every lost boy, spurred by Day-Glo fantasies of easy money, scrounging for a living in the sleazier districts of any large city in the Western world. Portrayed by Stathis Papadopoulos with such a natural mixture of innocence and hardness that he has the aura of a youth plucked off the streets, Sasha blithely sells his skinny, chiseled body to men while having lollipop dreams of one day living happily ever after with his 15-year-old sweetheart, Elenista (Panagiota Vlachosotirou).

title: Looking for That Union Label
description: A day after announcing a tentative contract for 26,000 doormen, janitors and handymen at New York City apartment buildings, Michael Fishman was already mapping plans for his next big fight.

title: Walter Anderson
description: Luise Ross Gallery

title: DDB Worldwide takes on the daunting task of changing consumers' ideas about J. C. Penney.
description: ONE of the most successful campaigns that changed consumer perceptions about a retailer was created by the old Doyle Dane Bernbach agency, for the Ohrbach's department store chain. Yesterday, the successor shop to Doyle Dane, DDB Worldwide, was named to handle that daunting task for perhaps the most troubled of large contemporary retailers, J. C. Penney.

title: MOTOROLA PLANT IN SCOTLAND
description: A big United States cellular phone maker, Motorola, said it intended to spend $2 billion to refit a Hyundai factory near Edinburgh to create a manufacturing plant for silicon chips. The area, which has become known as Silicon Glen, has become a hotbed for chip makers. The factory will be the largest semiconductor plant in Europe, employing 1,350 people. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: The Protest in a Global Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, HERMAN
description: ROSENBERG-Herman. 4/21/024/1/98. Today would have been your 98th birthday. How proud you would have been. We miss you. Ruth and Carla

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRADY, ELINOR T. (NEE REGAN)
description: GRADY-Elinor T. (nee Regan). On April 18, 2000. Beloved wife of the late James J. Loving mother of the late Michael. Dear sister of the late Alice Regan, Doris Civale and Joan Keane. Loving aunt of Cathleen, Christopher and Kevin Civale. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, on Saturday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10 AM at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Some Investors Critical of Marriott Accord on Suits
description: When the Marriott hotel chain agreed in February to pay more than $400 million to settle a series of lawsuits brought by disgruntled investors in its hotels, lawyers on both sides were quick to praise the deal.

title: MEDICARE SPENDING FOR CARE AT HOME PLUNGES BY 45%
description: Federal payments to provide home health care for the elderly have plummeted in the last two years, forcing many Medicare patients to spend more time in hospitals and nursing homes, health care providers say.

title: VITESSE SEMICONDUCTOR AGREES TO ACQUIRE SITERA
description: Vitesse Semiconductor, a chip maker, agreed late on Wednesday to acquire the privately held Sitera Inc. for $750 million in stock. Sitera, based in San Jose, Calif., makes hardware and software that processes data on computer networks and helps route traffic over the Internet. Vitesse, of Camarillo, Calif., makes chips that accelerate telecommunications and data transmissions. Vitesse had $189.4 million in revenue in the six months ended March 31 and has a market value of more than $9.1 billion. Its stock fell $4.9375, to $57.875.

title: Cuban Boy's Presence Felt At School He Left Behind
description: Elian Gonzalez's life will be normal someday. He will return to his desk here where his 27 classmates await him. The poster of him above his teacher's desk will vanish. The bulletin board festooned with classmates' drawings of him -- ''the Cuban sun will shine again when our Elian returns,'' says one -- will come down, too, as will the display at the city museum that is a virtual shrine to him.

title: Marconi of Britain Jumps Into Wireless Market With Deal
description: Marconi P.L.C., Britain's largest telecommunications equipment maker, said today that it would acquire Metapath Software International for $618 million. The move is an effort by Marconi to push into the wireless market where it will provide support software and other services to the major wireless telephone operators.

title: The Euro Falls Below 94 cents On Talk Rates May Not Rise
description: The euro fell to a record low against the dollar yesterday and could fall further on prospects that the European Central Bank will not raise interest rates next week or try to prop up the currency by intervening in the market to buy euros.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Good Friday and the second day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Dawn of a New Dynasty?
description: They are not as dominant or as sure-fire a pick as Michael Jordan and the Bulls used to be. Yet with Tim Duncan ailing and Portland still searching for chemistry and heart, the Los Angeles Lakers may give Phil Jackson a head start on his second dynasty. They should run into some obstacles in the West before vanquishing a proud John Stockton and Karl Malone for good. In the East, Vince Carter TV will make it through only two Sundays: he and the Toronto Raptors simply don't have enough inside game in the first round to thwart the Knicks, who will take care of both the Miami Heat and the Indiana Pacers in six games. In the finals, it's Shaq's and Kobe's Show.

title: Gillette Earnings Drop as Retailers Cut Orders
description: Gillette said yesterday that first-quarter earnings fell 4.1 percent, less than expected, as retailers in Europe and Latin America cut orders to clear out excess inventory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, LAWRENCE EUGENE
description: GOODMAN-Lawrence Eugene. Of Saint Paul, Minnesota. Born in Manhattan, only son of the late Commissioner and Mrs. Joseph Goodman. Died on April 17, 2000, age 80, in College Station, Texas. 1st Lt. USS Missouri, U.S. Navy, World War II. Record Professor of Civil Engineering at the University of Minnesota. Member of the American Society of Civil Engineers. Beloved husband of Katherine. Dear father of Jennifer, Jeanne & Alice, & their husbands Jeff Wallock, Charles Herzog and Geoffrey Hill. Adored grandfather of Joscelyn and Linnea Herzog, and Alberta Hill. Loved and respected teacher and colleague of many scores of engineers around the world. His life was a blessing to all who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, SELMA E.
description: ABRAHAM-Selma E. Age 82, on April 18,2000, peacefully in her home in Manhattan, where she wanted to be. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother to Emily, Cookie, Carolyn and Seth and beloved mother-in-law of Fernando, Alan, Joe and Lynn. She is lovingly remembered by her nine grandchildren David, Jason, Nancy, Carolyn, Julia, Rachel, Fredda, Andrew & Sari. Also remembered by her three great grandchildren Jack, Brandon and Hannah. With courage, grace and dignity, she waged a one year battle with cancer, lovingly cared for by her friend Deborah Grant. Her family and friends will forever cherish her memory for her intelligence, humility, charm and inherent goodness. She was a much loved wife, remarkable mother and grandmother, devoted sister to Alice, Miriam and Ethel and loyal friend. She always put the concerns and wellbeing of others before her own. Contributions may be made in her name to the Cabrini Hospice care of Mary Cook, 227 E. 19 St., NY, NY 10003. Funeral Services Sunday, April 23rd at 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. NYC.

title: Where Insanity and Modernism Intersect
description: IN the often rancorous field of outsider art, a terrain whose very boundaries and name are frequently debated, most people agree on the importance of the legendary Prinzhorn Collection. One of the largest collections of art by the insane, and maybe the first, it is the subject of an extraordinary exhibition at the Drawing Center in SoHo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLER, PHYLLIS
description: BUCKLER-Phyllis. Cherished wife of 56 years to Bruce. Adoring mother to Susan and Keith. Delighted grandmother of little Joey. Loving sister of Roslyn and Lester, and siblings who have passed on; Helen, Edith, Abe and Ralph. Devoted aunt of Phyllis, Sonny, Jonny and Meryl. A woman of extraordinary beauty, both physical and spiritual, there was always a very large place for others in her heart, and this is what truly defined her. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Services Friday, 12 noon Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, New York.

title: Mr. McCain's Message on Race
description: Senator John McCain displayed political courage -- belatedly, but powerfully -- in apologizing for his failure to protest South Carolina's official use of the Confederate battle flag. Commentators are busy analyzing the impact of Mr. McCain's public confession on his chances for a future presidential run or winning a spot on the ticket in 2000. But there is a deeper, more serious question raised by this episode. Are the national Republican Party and its designated presidential nominee, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, ready to end almost four decades of pandering to lingering segregationist sentiment in the Deep South?

description: Opposing Views Emerge On Aetna's Deal in Texas

description: Government Begins Protecting Children From Web Site Queries

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: $10 Million Is Awarded To Boy in Suit Over Palsy
description: A pregnant Maria Lara had already given birth to three children, and one afternoon 10 years ago, nearing the end of her term, Ms. Lara felt sure the fourth was about to be born. But, she said, the staff at Metropolitan Hospital Center turned her away three times, saying the moment had not come.

title: China Sect Persists
description: China acknowledged for the first time that it is having trouble stamping out the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement, even as new accusations emerged about brutality toward practitioners under detention.
