description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JURNEY, MADELINE
description: JURNEY - Madeline Merritt Hobeika, of Myrtle Beach, SC died April 18, 2000 at Duke Medical Center, Durham, NC. Surviving are husband James C. Jurney, one son James C. Jurney Jr. and daughterin-law Gwendolyn of New York City, New Yprk, and one daughter Jamie C. Jurney of Myrtle Beach. Mrs. Jurney was the daughter of the late Ellis Merritt and the late M.E. and Mary Sarkis Hobeika of Myrtle Beach, S.C.

title: Abroad at Home; The Corruption Of Power
description: Twenty years ago this week the country that had been Rhodesia, ruled by a tiny white minority, became Zimbabwe. After a brutal civil war, the handover of power was remarkably calm. Units of the white army and of the black guerrillas marched together in a stadium. A few hours earlier Robert Mugabe had reassured whites in a radio address.

title: Children of 'Operation Pedro Pan' Recall Painful Separations From Parents
description: It was 1961, in the nascent days of the Castro revolution, and 10-year-old Michael Musa stood in the Havana airport, waiting to board an airplane for America, not knowing if he would ever see his parents again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, THEDA
description: MARSHALL-Theda. Of Riverdale. Devoted mother of John and Pamela. Daughter of Abraham and the late Lilly Spector. Sister of David Spector & Renee Richman. Loving grandmother of Madison. Services Sunday 9:30 ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam.

title: Oakley Gives Raptors Brawn and Attitude
description: Charles Oakley, who played power forward for the Knicks for a decade before being traded to the Toronto Raptors, used a football analogy today to emphasize how his new team can continue its mastery over his former one when their first-round playoff series begins on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, JANET
description: GERSON-Janet. We mourn your untimely passing. You will always be in our hearts. Anne and Lenny

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSKIN, SAMUEL
description: ROSKIN-Samuel. Past-President of the Board of Directors for Workmen's Circle MultiCare Center for 10 years. He was devoted to the quality of life and care of the residents. He will be missed by all who knew him. The Board of Directors and Administration of the Center wish to express their condolences to the family.

title: Renegade In a Most Secretive World
description: There he sits, Jimmy Marks, two rows of diamonds on the bridge of his glasses, diamond cuff links, gold and diamond rings. He won't give up his fight, this Don Quixote, this deposed prince of the Gypsies of Spokane, Wash. Most of Spokane's Gypsies would just like Mr. Marks to be quiet. He has brought too much exposure to their secretive world, they say, and he plays into Gypsy stereotypes. Now he is ''marime'' -- ''unclean'' in Romany, the Gypsy language -- an outcast.

title: News Media Debtors Barred From Traveling With Clinton
description: President Clinton has been hopscotching the nation and the world in the final year of his presidency, following a frenetic schedule that shows no signs of letting up. But dozens of news organizations have been barred from traveling along because of outstanding debts, and the list may be growing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGERSEN, LOUIS BALDWIN.
description: BERGERSEN - Louis Baldwin. Composer and entertainer at the piano. Died of cancer on April 17, 2000 at age 86. He was born of American parents in Vienna, and resided in Manhattan. He composed music for a number of shows that were produced in New York and London, including ''All in Fun'' (1940), ''Carib Song'' (1945), the series entitled ''New Faces'' produced by Leonard Sillman in the 1930's & 1940's, and ''Small Wonder'' (1948). His song ''Love and I'' was on Your Hit Parade for ten weeks; ''That Man and Woman Thing'' became Bill Robinson's signature dance tune, and ''Sleep, Baby, Don't Cry'' was recorded by Bobby Short. Baldwin Bergersen was an accomplished arranger and performer of popular songs, especially Gershwin, and remained active almost until the end of his life. He will be remembered by the many who loved him for his extraordinary musical gifts, and for his understanding and generosity of spirit. Donations in his memory may be made to Covenant House, POB 731, Times Square Station, New York, New York 10108.

title: ROBERTSON-CECO ACCEPTS $56 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: The Robertson-Ceco Corporation, a building-products maker, accepted a sweetened offer of $11.50 a share, or $56 million, for the rest of its shares from its majority shareholder, the Heico Company. Heico, a closely held company based in Chicago, and its affiliates already own about 69.5 percent, or 11.2 million shares, of Robertson-Ceco, which has 16.1 million shares outstanding. The offer represents an 18 percent premium over Robertson-Ceco's closing price of $9.75 on Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. Heico owns more than 30 companies. Robertson-Ceco is based in San Ramon, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: A television review in Weekend yesterday about the documentary ''George Wallace: Settin' the Woods on Fire,'' to be shown tomorrow and Monday on PBS, misidentified the opponent in Wallace's televised confrontation with the United States government in 1963 over desegregating the University of Alabama. He was Deputy Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, not Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUELL, ANGELA B.
description: BUELL-Angela B. of Bronxville, NY on April 20, 2000. Wife of Hal Buell, mother of Barbara Radcliff of Sunnyvale, CA. Grandmother of Will & Regan Radcliff. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Monday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Tuesday, April 25 at 10 AM.

title: AIRLINE EARNINGS IMPROVE
description: Asia's biggest air carrier, Japan Airlines, said its earnings for the year that ended in March 2000 would be 46 percent better than earlier thought because of higher revenue and lower operating costs. The company now expects net income of 16 billion yen ($151 million) for the fiscal year that just ended, up from a previous target of 11 billion yen. JAL estimates sales of 1.6 trillion yen, 1.3 percent above the 1.58 trillion yen forecast it released in November.

title: 2 Cable Companies Plan $400 Million in Improvements
description: In the next two years, the two largest cable companies in the New York metropolitan region plan to make more than $400 million in improvements, providing most of their four million customers with new services, many of which are fully in use in other parts of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERMAIN, ELAINE
description: GERMAIN-Elaine. The Board of Directors of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City mourns the loss of their loyal Program Director. For over 25 years Elaine made a significant difference in the lives of people with disabilities and their families. Our condolences to her husband, Bob, and sons Robert and Ralph. Leo Hausman, Chairman

title: The Earth Day Challenge
description: Today, on the 30th anniversary of the first Earth Day, there is much to celebrate and much to remind us of the unfinished business of protecting the planet. While the job of cleaning the water, air and land continues, the world must begin tackling the less visible threat of global warming, an issue largely unknown 30 years ago. This new threat is less immediate and less easily solved, and therefore will require an even stronger commitment in the years ahead. This is essentially the message of the organizers of Earth Day 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIZZIO, IGNATIUS G.
description: LIZZIO-Ignatius G. Passed away April 19. Nat was a retired Chief Inspector of Construction for the NYC Buildings Dept, an avid golfer, and a Korean War veteran. Survived by Barbara van der Vloed, longtime companion; sisters Lucy Marcoccio and Angela Lizzio; sister-in-law Nancy Lizzio; & nephews, John and Gary Lizzio. Services Saturday, April 22, 9AM at St. Agnes Church, E. 43 St., NYC. Contributions may be made to the American Lung Association.

title: Gateway Investment
description: Rent-Way said today that it would receive an investment of $7 million from Gateway as part of an exclusive rental supply agreement. Rent-Way will offer Internet-equipped Gateway computers for a weekly rental of about $20 in its 1,100 stores under the three-year agreement. That is half the fee that the rest of the industry charges, Rent-Way's chief executive, William Morgenstern, said. Rent-Way sells weekly and monthly rentals with purchase options for home-entertainment equipment and furniture.

title: Camby Expects the Raptors to Get Physical
description: When practice ended at SUNY-Purchase today, Marcus Camby walked off the court by himself and unfolded his long body against the wall under a basket. He had made it through his first workout since reinjuring his right knee last Saturday, and was certain he would be ready for the start of the playoffs against the Toronto Raptors on Sunday afternoon.

title: Firms Going Casual Help Job Seekers Suit Up
description: As New York's major law firms, banks and consulting firms shift to a casual dress code, the question arises: what are they doing with all those suits?

title: A Children's Adventure in a Deaf World
description: On Monday, ''Blue's Clues,'' the Nickelodeon TV series for preschool children, will focus the adventures of its puzzle-solving puppy on a young girl who is deaf, and in the process teach its viewers a handful of words in American Sign Language. The episode will be the first of many allowing children to learn some signing basics.

title: Devils Don't Buckle, and Credit Their Coach
description: When it was over on Thursday night, when the Devils had swept the Florida Panthers out of the playoffs with four straight victories, it was time for a few admissions. Yes, the Devils said, there was real relief that they had avoided the humiliating first-round exits of the previous two seasons. And yes, the calm guidance of Coach Larry Robinson had made a real difference for a team that in recent years had found a way to underachieve at the worst possible moments.

title: For Iran, Dark Pages of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombians Flee Into Panama as War Fears Rise
description: Bertilda Castro Tejada and her family are living in this small Panamanian village where time and trouble are all they have. The place may be dreary, but, unlike the home they left in Colombia, it is not deadly. At least not yet.

title: Nothing Fancy Onstage Except the Relationships
description: The production values were simple and the theater a bare-bones affair. An air of youngsters' getting together to put on a show hung over ''Lil' This, Lil' That,'' a program presented by Earl Mosley's Diversity of Dance company on Thursday night at the Chernuchin Theater. But out of those homemade materials came an evening of crackling imagination, hilarity and terrific performing.

title: Software Can't Make School Safe
description: Imagine a software program that would let schools predict which students will commit acts of horrific violence. Imagine a program that could have spotted Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris, the gunmen who attacked Columbine High School a year ago, before they could act. If it sounds too good to be true, that's because it is.

title: TODAY'S SCHEDULES
description: GEORGE W. BUSH -- No events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, DR. PHYLLIS COLLINS, ED.D,
description: WILSON-Dr. Phyllis Collins, Ed.D, 92, of Hanover, NH, formerly of New York City, died April 13th in Hanover. Dr. Wilson was born June 16, 1907 in Wallingford, Vermont and spent most of her childhood in Hingham, Massachusetts. She was the daughter of the late Orvis K. Collins and May (Burditt) Collins. She was a 1926 graduate of Radcliffe College, and received master's and doctorate degrees in education from Columbia University. Dr. Wilson ran a private counseling psychology practice in New York City. She was also a professor emerita of Queens College of the City University of New York. Between 1952-1977 she instituted and administered the two year graduate program to qualify Guidance Counselors for the City and State of New York. She was the widow of Stanley K. Wilson, a WWII veteran who died in 1981. Her only child, Phyllis Ruth Wilson, died in 1973 at the age of 38. In 1996 Dr. Wilson initiated and funded the STAR (Steps Toward Adult Responsibility) Program for adolescents with chronic illness through the Pediatrics Department at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center. Dr. Wilson moved to Kendal, a retirement community in Hanover, NH in 1993 and continued active involvement with the Ethical Culture Society and the Academy of Counseling Psychology. She also traveled extensively. She leaves a great-niece, Sarah C. la Cour of Amherst, MA, a great nephew, R. Bruce Donald of Farmington CT, & two sisters-in-law, Virginia Wilson Miller of Laguna Hills, CA, and Adrienne Collins of Perkinsville, VT. A private service for the family will be held at Old Ship Church in Hingham, MA.

title: Mayor Finds Reason to Push Plan for Teacher Merit Pay
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani reopened the debate over merit pay for teachers yesterday, saying the flood of applications for summer school jobs proved that the city could afford to be selective by awarding bonuses only to those teachers whose classes perform well on standardized tests.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HARRIS CORP., Melbourne, Fla., a communications equipment maker, has agreed to buy the microwave radio business of Lucent Technologies Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., the largest United States phone equipment maker, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Todd Webb, 94, Peripatetic Photographer
description: Todd Webb, a photographer who documented the everyday life and architecture of New York, Paris and the American West, died last Saturday at Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston. He was 94 and lived in Auburn, Me.

title: 3RD PARTY JOINING EFFORT TO RETURN BOY TO HIS FATHER
description: Clinging to what appeared to be a gossamer hope for a last-minute settlement of the custody battle over Elian Gonzalez, Justice Department officials said tonight that unnamed intermediaries were working on a plan for the boy's Miami relatives to immediately turn over the child to his father.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Gowanus Canal Repair Helping Marine Life
description: The Gowanus Canal is flowing again. The propeller inside the canal's flushing tunnel, which was knocked out of service by a 10-foot-long piece of driftwood on March 14, was repaired on Tuesday, Department of Environmental Protection officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIZER, SAMUEL
description: BEIZER-Samuel. On April 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Laurel. Loving father of Chanan, Tamara, and Mordechai. Dear brother of Boris and Margo. Adoring grandfather of Kalanit, Ronit, Avraham Hoshia, Aidan, Elisheva, Nina, Alexandra and Victoria. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be sent to The Bay Street Theater, Sag Harbor, NY 11963. Service 10AM Monday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: ANOTHER LOSS AT BANGKOK BANK
description: Thailand's largest lender, Bangkok Bank, posted its eighth consecutive quarterly loss, as it set aside record reserves to cover loan defaults. The bank said it had lost 22.3 billion baht ($587 million) in the January-March quarter, more than double a 9.9 billion baht loss in the corresponding period a year earlier. A loss had been expected, as the bank needed more loan-loss provisions to meet central bank standards, which are being raised on Dec. 31.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the role of George P. Bush in the presidential campaign of his uncle George W. Bush misstated the name and station of a television talk show on which the nephew recently appeared. The show was ''Cafe California,'' not ''Cafi California''; it is on KWHY-TV in Los Angeles, not Telemundo.

title: Gore Has First News Conference in Months, Then Another
description: After two months of keeping his distance from the journalists who travel with him, Vice President Al Gore held his first news conference today in this auto city 30 miles from Detroit.

title: State of Fashion: Can Anybody Explain?
description: To the Editor:

title: Making a Fuss Over Opening Credits; Film Titles Offer a Peek at the Future in More Ways Than One
description: A new branch of history -- or is it merely a twig? -- has sprouted: the history of film titles. In case you are someone who talks through movie previews and credits, film titles generally appear after the film quiz, after the dancing hot dogs and popcorn, after the on-screen hushing and before the movie proper has begun.

title: Prospective Buyers Take a Look at Orange
description: The for-sale sign has not been put out yet, but interested buyers from around the globe are already swarming around Orange P.L.C., Britain's third-largest mobile telephone operator.

title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM SHARES SUSPENDED FROM TRADING
description: Fruit of the Loom, the biggest United States maker of underwear and T-shirts, which has struggled to emerge from bankruptcy, had its Class A shares suspended from trading on Thursday by the New York Stock Exchange. The company has said that it would sell assets and its licensed sports apparel division to try to return to profitability. Shares of the company have plunged 92 percent the last year. The New York Stock Exchange said it would apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission to have Fruit of the Loom's right to list its shares withdrawn because the company no longer meets the exchange's minimum requirements. Fruit of the Loom filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MARTA
description: GREENE-Marta. At Sharon, CT, April 21, 2000. Resident of Millbrook, NY and Siasconet, Nantucket. Survived by her husband Thurston Greene, her son Edward Davies, Charlotte, NC and a brother, William Brodie of Granville, OH. Memorial services will be held Tuesday at 11:00 AM, April 25 at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Millbrook, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATTRIDGE, TERRY
description: ATTRIDGE-Terry, Monsignor. On April 20, 2000. Pastor of Sacred Heart Church, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Survived by his parents Jim and Peg; one sister, Pat Bessette; three nephews, Kevin, Brian and Matthew O'Gorman; one uncle, Arthur Attridge. Visiting Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, (exit 17 Saw Mill) Monday 9:00AM to 9:00PM. Visiting Tuesday from 12:00 noon Sacred Heart Church, Broadway and Ashford Dobbs Ferry where the Mass of the High Priest will be celebrated Tuesday 7:30PM. Mass of the Resurrection Wednesday 11AM. Memorials to the Monsignor Terry Attridge Children's Assistance Fund, C/O Solomon Smith Barney, 4 Manhattanville Rd., Purchase, NY 10577.

title: Cardinal to Miss Easter at St. Patrick's
description: For the first time since he was named archbishop of New York in 1984, Cardinal John O'Connor will not celebrate Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Easter Sunday because of his failing health after the removal of a brain tumor late last summer and subsequent radiation treatment.

title: CREDIT LYONNAIS FACES PENALTY
description: Japanese regulators said Credit Lyonnais had violated Japanese securities law and should be disciplined, making Credit Lyonnais, France's fifth-largest bank, the latest foreign company to face punishment since July. Reports to customers were falsified by the Tokyo securities arm of Credit Lyonnais and customers solicited ''with the promise of special profits,'' according to the Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission. ''These are extremely bad actions,'' said Masatake Nishimura, director of the commission's coordination and inspection division. A penalty will be decided within a week.

title: Prosecutor Quizzes Clinton In Campaign Finance Case
description: A Justice Department prosecutor investigating campaign fund-raising improprieties conducted a wide-ranging interview with President Clinton today that included questions about electronic messages that were improperly handled by the White House. The prosecutor interviewed Vice President Al Gore on Tuesday, White House officials said.

title: Grand Old Pragmatists
description: In a retreat from recent Republican tenets, Gov. George W. Bush has been advocating an expansion of the federal role on programs ranging from education to low-income housing to health care. And he has made overtures to constituencies, like gays and gun control proponents, that have never been mainstays of his own party.

title: Inertia on Tort Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: For Iran, Dark Pages of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Caught in Lie Is Killed by Amtrak Train
description: A student who was suspended this year by Columbia University after he repeatedly lied to a professor to gain more time for an assignment was struck and killed Thursday night by an Amtrak train as he walked on the tracks near Iselin, N.J., said a lawyer for the student's family.

title: Stocks Off Nearly 4% In Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks tumbled today, as changes in the makeup of the benchmark Nikkei index forced investors who track it to raise money to buy the new components.

title: Argentina Holds 14 Officers in Beating of Labor Demonstrators
description: Fourteen police officers have been arrested for beating 35 union supporters and shooting another during a crackdown on a demonstration this week that has jeopardized the centerpiece of President Fernando de la Rua's economic policy.

title: New Wave of Writers Reinvents Literature
description: Sixty-one years ago, in a famous essay, Philip Rahv divided American writers into two groups: ''palefaces,'' like Henry James and T. S. Eliot, with high brows, oversize superegos and self-conscious, philosophical sensibilities; and ''redskins,'' like Whitman and Dreiser, with earthier styles and noisier, more populist outlooks. The first group specialized in heady, cultivated works, rich in symbolism and allegory; the second favored a blunter, more emotional naturalism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGH, SR. MARY (FORMERLY KNOWN AS SR. SAINT JAMES)
description: HUGH-Sr. Mary (formerly known as Sr. Saint James), R.S.H.M. Provincial Archivist. Died April 20, 2000, Tarrytown, N.Y. She was a Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for fifty years, taught at Mary Mount Academy and other R.S.H.M. schools, served as Administrator, Provincial and General Treasurer. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, April 24th, 10:30AM at Mary Mount Convent, Tarrytown, N.Y. No wake Saturday or Sunday.

title: Buying Modest Homes in Extravagant Times
description: Given the tendency in the last two presidential campaigns to treat housing as unmentionable, George W. Bush deserves praise for announcing a plan to help lower-middle class families buy homes. But even though all housing programs in recent years seem to aim low, Mr. Bush's goal of only 20,000 homes a year over five years takes incrementalism to a lower power.

title: A Prep Standout Decides That Home Is Where His Heart Is
description: When Nigel Wyatte finally made his decision to sign a letter of intent to attend Wagner College, he knew his mother would have been happy.

title: If There's a Bug in the Etymology, You May Never Get It Out
description: Last month Joe Trela became the third person to win $1 million on the hit television show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.'' But while Mr. Trela's final answer was correct, the question itself was wrong.

title: SOROS FUND SELLS STAKE IN SATELLITE PHONE VENTURE
description: Soros Fund Management L.L.C. liquidated its stake in the satellite telephone venture Globalstar Telecommunications Ltd. as of March 10, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Soros Fund Management is associated with the investor George Soros. The filing was made late on Thursday. In an earlier filing, Soros Fund Management reported owning 5.1 million shares, or a 5.33 percent stake, in Globalstar, which is based in San Jose, Calif., as of Feb. 10. Globalstar is a partnership of global telecommunications service providers and equipment manufacturers.

title: DANONE WILL LOOK AT NABISCO
description: Franck Riboud, of the cookie and yogurt maker, the Danone Group, said his company would consider buying Nabisco Group Holdings, a United States rival that is considering selling itself. ''It's in one of our main businesses -- we'll look,'' Mr. Riboud said. The Nabisco Group is seeking ways to raise its stock price, including selling itself or its 80.6 percent stake in the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the maker of Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies.

title: For Beleaguered Officers Now on Livery-Cab Duty, Gratitude
description: The yellow taxi bore medallion 6Y70, but it was not a yellow taxi.

title: Rentokil Selling U.S. Unit
description: The British company Rentokil Initial said on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its United States equipment-rental business to the Ashtead Group for $:320 million, or about $506 million in cash and securities. Rentokil, a pest-control and business-services company, is selling the unit, named BET USA Inc., for approximately $294 million in cash and $212 million in eight-year convertible notes. The purchase will push Ashtead, a plant- and machinery-rental company that is also based in Britain, into the top five in the United States rental market.

title: RUINED EAST TIMOR AWAITS A MIRACLE
description: People here have gotten used to the scene: a mob of unemployed young men shoving, shouting and weeping in anger outside the headquarters of the United Nations, held back by an impassive multinational police contingent.

title: Putting a Happy Face on an Often Unhappy Twain
description: When Mark Twain died 90 years ago this week, the machinery that would spin his posthumous image was already oiled and running. At the controls was his daughter Clara, who would spend the next half-century transforming her difficult, depressive father into the genial, doting patriarch that endures in the American mind.

title: Sports of The Times; One Warrior To Another: Keep the Faith
description: DON BAYLOR sat in the Chicago Cubs' clubhouse yesterday afternoon. The Cubs' game with the Mets had been postponed because of rain. Baylor had finished his audience with members of the news media, had said his piece about Mets Manager Bobby Valentine. Except for a couple of players and coaches reviewing tapes of previous games, the clubhouse was deserted.

title: ORDER FOR NEW AIRBUS JET
description: The European consortium Airbus Industrie will announce this weekend in Cairo that Emirates Airlines intends to order the giant jet, known as the A3XX, if it decides to build the model to compete with Boeing's 747. An official from one of the companies said Airbus would announce that Emirates, which is based in Dubai and is the international carrier of the United Arab Emirates, is the first airline to disclose its intention. The Airbus board will not make a decision on whether to build the aircraft, which would seat up to 600 people, until later this year. John Tagliabue

title: State Dept. Scrutiny After Loss of Laptop
description: The disappearance of a laptop computer with highly sensitive files about weapons proliferation from the State Department is prompting the agency to consider restructuring its security system, a senior official said.

title: Ray Vicker, 82, Author and Ex-Journalist
description: Ray Vicker, an author and former foreign correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, died on Wednesday at a nursing center in Tucson. He was 82 and had lived in Tucson for the last 10 years.

title: Calm Scene Isn't Really, Police Say
description: It is the picture of North American suburban normalcy: a new four-bedroom house on the edge of a golf course, an orange basketball left outside in the rain by the 15-year-old son, a soggy cigar butt left outside on a plastic chair by Dad.

title: BRUNSWICK TECHNOLOGIES WEIGHS SAINT-GOBAIN OFFER
description: Brunswick Technologies, a maker of industrial and construction materials, said yesterday that it would consider a $41.8 million offer from Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, Europe's biggest building-materials distributor. A Saint-Gobain unit, the CertainTeed Corporation, said on Thursday that it had begun an $8-a-share cash tender offer for Brunswick, which had 5.23 million shares outstanding as of March 15. Brunswick, based in Brunswick, Me., said it was urging shareholders not to take action until the board's recommendation.

title: VIDEO GAMES SELLER ACCEPTS A SWEETENED OFFER
description: Funco Inc., a seller of new and used video games, said yesterday that it had accepted Electronics Boutique Holdings's sweetened offer of $21 a share, or $135 million. Funco said on Thursday that Electronics Boutique had raised its offer from the $17.50 a share it offered on April 3 to match a higher offer from Barnes & Noble that came three days later. Funco said on April 13 that it would accept the higher bid, made through Barnes & Noble's Babbage's Etc. video-game software retail unit, if Electronics Boutique did not raise its offer within five business days. Funco is based in Eden Prairie, Minn. Electronics Boutique operates 628 stores in 46 states, Puerto Rico, Canada, Australia and South Korea.

title: Westpoint Energy Bought
description: The Alberta Energy Company, one of Canada's biggest independent oil companies, agreed today to buy Westpoint Energy Inc. for about 37 million Canadian dollars ($25 million) to add to its properties in northeastern Alberta. Alberta Energy will pay 8 Canadian dollars for each common share of Westpoint, an oil and gas explorer whose directors said they would recommend that shareholders accept the offer. The shares of Westpoint, formerly called Slade Energy, have not traded since September.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx to Shed a Symbol With an Odor of Decay
description: The Bronx has long had its share of image problems, what with a high crime rate and burned-out neighborhoods. In recent years, though, Bronx leaders have become optimistic that the borough may be finally shedding its old reputation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPER, JAMES B
description: ALPER-James B. Died on Earth Day, April 22, 1990. Happiness came on secret winds and surrounded him forever in the ways of beauty. (Inspired by American Indian proverb) Forever, Rit

title: A Silicon Valley Laboratory Shuts Down
description: An ambitious Silicon Valley effort to create computer industry breakthroughs ended in failure today when the Web site of the Interval Research Corporation was replaced with a stark press release stating that its co-founder, Paul G. Allen, had closed the advanced computer laboratory after eight years.

title: Baring a King to Embarrass a Rude Declarer
description: Those suffering from terminal illnesses seldom get any fun out of life, but, thanks to computers, bridge players are sometimes exceptions. When pain is ever present, and going out to clubs and tournaments is impossible, an on-line game can continue to be a welcome source of satisfaction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, MARGARET STRAUSS.
description: KRAMER-Margaret Strauss. Wife of the late Jean Kramer. She was a renowned chemist with degrees from John Hopkins and NYU, graduated from Goucher College. Formerly a member of Fairview Country Club. She moved to Palm Beach, Fla. in 1975. A Memorial Service will be held at Temple Israel, 1901 North Flagler Drive, Palm Beach, Florida, on Thursday at 11 A.M., April 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFT, MARION
description: SAFT-Marion, on April 19. Services Sunday, April 23, in Delray Beach, Florida.

description: Japan's Nikkei Index Posts A Decrease of 3.7 Percent

title: Blue Jays Have Taken Back Seat in Toronto
description: This was a holiday in Canada and schools and shops were closed across the city, but a small crowd arrived at the Skydome to watch the Yankees and Blue Jays. During batting practice, most of the fans were jammed together on the first-base side, the Yankees' side -- many of them probably transient baseball fans from western New York.

title: George Moore, 95, Ex-Banker Who Led Metropolitan Opera
description: George S. Moore, a banker who led the overseas expansion of what became Citibank and steered the Metropolitan Opera through turbulent financial times, died yesterday at his home in Sotograde, Spain. He was 95.

description: BASEBALL

title: All of the Many Versions of Shylock, Looking Into the Face of Anti-Semitism
description: Does the modern world have a place in it for Shakespeare's ''Merchant of Venice''? The question is raised but not resolved by tonight's inquiry on Bravo into the life and times of the character Shakespeare called Shylock.

title: Technology Helping to Revive an Old Idea: The Literary Journal
description: Small magazines that publish short fiction come and go, but Barbara Probst Solomon longs for the glory days of the ''little magazines,'' those literary journals that made a dent on the public consciousness.

title: Next Phase of the Census
description: The Census Bureau announced with relief this week that 65 percent of households had already mailed in their census forms, about the same as in 1990. That may not seem like a grand achievement. But the response rate has been dropping steadily for decades, and the bureau was predicting a further decline this year. Now it moves to the more difficult and expensive task of door-to-door canvassing of families that did not respond by mail. This phase will be especially critical for New York City, whose mail response rate fell to 52 percent this year from 53 percent in 1990. Accuracy is important because census counts serve as the basis for apportioning seats in the House of Representatives and state legislatures as well as distributing about $200 billion for education, health and other federal programs.

title: Mohawks Sign New Casino Deal, Leaving Catskill Plan in Limbo
description: The leaders of the St. Regis Mohawk tribe, who were awaiting final approval to build a $500 million casino in the Catskills, have turned their backs on their original plan and instead have signed a highly unusual agreement with the largest gambling company in the world.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you were to ask where I recommend telemedicine, it's wherever a psychiatrist isn't available. I still think face-to-face treatment, with three dimensions and all the textures that go on between doctor and patient, is much more important.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROBERT W.
description: WHITE-Robert W. Age 60, on April 19, 2000 at home. Beloved husband of Elissa; loving father of Matthew White and Martin Adler; devoted to the Waters family, and longtime friend to many. Author, inventor, artist and teacher, he took the road less traveled and we are the richer for it. We will miss him deeply and mourn the loss of one of the world's most loving, compassionate, intelligent and honest men. Even at the end his sense of humor uplifted us all.

title: New Cyber Galleries Hope to Lure Wider Clientele : Betting on Online Market
description: NEW YORK  Fine art and antiques are finding their way out of traditional bricks and mortar galleries and auction houses and onto the Web, and dealers, investors and entrepreneurs are rushing to capitalize on the projected burgeoning growth of the online art market.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODEL, JOSEPH
description: MODEL-Joseph. On April 21, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Annabelle. Loving father of Bennett and his wife Leslie and Roberta Amon and her husband Maurice. Dear grandfather of Summer, Brett, Tierney and Albert. Loving brother of Mark. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Fire Company Rebuked For Decision To Miss Fire
description: Fire officials yesterday chastised a Queens engine company that did not respond to a fire Wednesday afternoon, saying the company should have answered the call even though none of the firefighters on duty had been trained to drive a fire truck.

title: A PepsiCo Shareholder Meeting and a Very Unhappy Shareholder
description: Practically no one bothers to go to annual meetings these days except company executives and retired shareholders. And that, it seems, is pretty much the way corporate America likes it, considering that most companies have done away with perks like free food for those who do show up.

title: Connecticut's Campaign Finance Bill
description: The cause of campaign reform has long commanded broad support in Connecticut. Last week the Legislature passed an ambitious bill to impose voluntary limits on campaign spending, require disclosure of donors and provide public financing of campaigns. The measure would go a long way toward cleaning up the state's politics, which were marred by a scandal involving a former state treasurer last year. However, Gov. John G. Rowland has said he finds the bill flawed and may not sign it. Mr. Rowland should sign, and if necessary work to correct any problems that emerge as the measure is put into effect.

title: Playoff Pop Quiz
description: The future of renewable energies such as wind, solar and geothermal is uncertain because gas-fired plants produce electricity more cheaply. Geothermal energy uses hot water coming from deep in the earth.

title: American Men Take a First Step Toward the Olympics
description: Two goals by Chris Albright and one by the second-half substitute John Thorrington gave the United States a 3-0 victory over Honduras tonight at Hersheypark Stadium, putting the Americans in the driver's seat to advance to the Summer Olympics in September.

title: Religion Journal; In a Time of Renewal, An Awareness of Others
description: For Western Christians, today is the midpoint of three days freighted with enormous spiritual power. Yesterday was Good Friday, which commemorated the crucifixion of Jesus, and tomorrow will be Easter, when believers proclaim his resurrection.

title: FAMILY TIES
description: The story of Elian Gonzalez's feuding clan is extreme, but it is not all that different from what most Cuban families divided by Castro's revolution have experienced: bitter feelings, thwarted love and ever painful efforts at reconciliation. In The Times Magazine: A report by Tim Golden on the Gonzalez family history and a memoir by Mirta Ojito on the Mariel boat lift.

title: Insurer Fighting Microsoft Over Claims
description: Microsoft's primary insurer wants to bar the company from claiming coverage for the cost of defending a barrage of private antitrust lawsuits.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SELLS CANADIAN CONDOM BUSINESS
description: Johnson & Johnson agreed yesterday to sell its Canadian business that makes Shields condoms to Pacific Dunlop's United States.-based unit for an undisclosed amount. Pacific Dunlop's Ansell Healthcare Products, a maker of LifeStyles brand condoms, said the addition of the Shields brand would give it 20 percent of the condom market in Canada. Pacific Dunlop, which makes products from batteries to condoms, is based in Melbourne, Australia. Ansell is based in Red Bank, N.J. Johnson & Johnson is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: G.O.P. Senators Tell Clinton They Oppose Him on ABM Treaty and Defense System
description: Senior Republican senators told President Clinton this week that they opposed his efforts to renegotiate an arms control treaty with Russia and to build only a limited antimissile defense system.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the Supreme Court's review of the Miranda decision misspelled the surname of a lawyer who met with reporters outside. He is Paul D. Kamenar, not Kamenas.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Wednesday about two first-person accounts of life under the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia misstated the estimated death toll under that regime. A widely accepted figure, from Yale University's genocide project, under the auspices of the State Department, is more than one million, not two million.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAITZMAN, ALEXANDER BENJA
description: WAITZMAN - Alexander Benja min. 92 years old, died on April 21, 2000. Beloved husband of Irene. Cherished father of Daniel and father-in-law of Mona. Dearest brother of Dorothy Levy, Fritzi Kamens and the late Samuel and Milton Waitzman. Services Sunday 12 noon at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: FRENCH OUTPUT RISES
description: French industrial production rebounded in February after two months of decline as companies geared up to meet rising sales at home and abroad. Production rose 1.1 percent, after falling a revised 0.2 percent in January, Insee, the national statistics office, said. Economists had expected an increase of just 0.6 percent. Output for the three months ended in February rose 3.8 percent from the year-earlier period.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a related article on Thursday misstated the country's previous status. Two decades ago, blacks won their struggle for independence against a white minority government, not against Britain.

title: Ex-Lawman Ponders a Prison Legacy He Doesn't Want
description: NO one told Charles T. Terrell that his name would adorn death row. He heard whispers, but no one called. Maybe no one realized he was still alive. After all, many prisons in Texas are named for a crime fighter or lawmaker gone to his great reward. Maybe no one thought a man who once ran the prison system would mind.

title: Incident Is Over, Not Forgotten
description: Cubs Manager Don Baylor was more at ease last night discussing the common ground he has with Bobby Valentine than he was in resuming his criticism of the Mets manager.

title: Court's Ruling Is Giving Experts Pause About Rights of Children to Be Heard
description: The federal appeals court ruling on Wednesday in the Elian Gonzalez case has startled experts on family law because it suggests that immigration officials should ask 6-year-old Elian whether he wants to return to Marxist Cuba or remain with his Miami relatives, regardless of the wishes of his father.

title: Working People Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, HANNO
description: FUCHS-Hanno. April 18, 2000. Survived by his beloved Judith, loving father of seven children and stepchildren and grandfather of four. Also devoted husband of the late Carol. Following a distinguished career in advertising, he graduated law school at the age of 67. Hanno was an active tennis advocate and player. His family and all the people who loved and respected him will miss him dearly.

title: Adding Arias to the Three R's; Brooklyn School Uses Opera to Stimulate Young Minds
description: Four fifth-grade girls from Public School 314 escaped class one recent afternoon in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, not to buy sweets at the corner bodega, or to swap secrets over blush in the bathroom, but to slip into a music room to work on their opera, a three-act (six-page) work involving a popular girl, a class clown and a meteorite blazing toward Earth.

title: INSIDE
description: Chechnya Peace Proposals

title: Seeking to Safeguard California Mountains by Way of Congress
description: Postcards from this desert resort town often feature a golfer in full swing on a lush course, driving toward a majestic mountain range in the distance.

title: A Contractor For Workfare Faces Inquiry
description: The Manhattan district attorney's office has begun a criminal investigation into a Virginia company's decision last year to hire the father-in-law and a family friend of New York City's welfare commissioner just as the company prepared to bid on more than $100 million in city welfare contracts, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Man Fatally Shot in a Brooklyn Grocery
description: A man who had harassed the workers in a Brooklyn bodega for months and was rebuffed when he demanded that he be allowed to sell drugs in the store returned early yesterday and fatally shot a cousin of the owner, the police and relatives of the victim said.

title: Returns Show Spitzer Sold Apartments to Pay Off Debt
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer last year continued to liquidate his personal assets to pay off campaign debts, selling more than $6 million worth of Manhattan real estate for that purpose, according to tax returns he made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEEN, LILLIAN S.
description: VEEN-Lillian S. On April 20, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Bram C. Veen. Loving mother of Nikki Gasparre & grandmother of Richard B. Gasparre. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Monday 2-5 and 79PM with service Tuesday, 12Noon. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAINE, MARY C.
description: CRAINE-Mary C. On April 20, 2000 of Hempstead, NY. Survived by three children; Mary Bachner, Kevin and Michael Craine and three grandchildren; one brother, Thomas Cronin. Wake: Hartnett Funeral Home, 561 Jerusalem Ave., Uniondale, Monday April 24, 2-4, 7-9PM. Funeral Mass St. Martha's RC Church, 546 Greengrove Ave., Uniondale, NY, 10AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Cancer Care or St. Martha's RC Church would be appreciated.

title: Russia Seizes Japanese Vessel In Maritime Boundary Dispute
description: The Russian Coast Guard fired on and seized a Japanese fishing boat today near Japan's northernmost main island, according to Japanese and Russian officials.

title: Editorial Observer; Mr. Bellow Writes On, Wrestling With the Ghost of Edward Shils
description: A new novel from the Nobel laureate Saul Bellow generates interest just about everywhere -- but nowhere as intensely as at the University of Chicago and the surrounding neighborhood of Hyde Park, where Mr. Bellow was a fixture for 30 years before decamping to Boston University in 1993. In the living rooms and coffee shops of Hyde Park, novel readers have always seemed less interested in Mr. Bellow's philosophical opinions than in sleuthing out the evidence of the ex-wives, faculty colleagues and former friends who are routinely caricatured and kidnapped into his pages.

title: High-Tech System Installed to Filter Air at Padua Chapel : Preserving Giotto's Frescoes
description: PADUA, Italy  In March 1944, Allied bombs hit the Eremitani Church, reducing the side chapel containing Mantegna's earliest major frescoes to a pile of rubble. As the dust settled, it became evident that the freestanding Scrovegni Chapel, just a 100 meters away, had survived the blast and shock waves unscathed.

title: Lawyer Auction in an Auction Suit
description: For two months the federal judge presiding over mountains of litigation against the auction giants Sotheby's and Christie's knew that he faced a thorny problem: how to select the lawyers from at least 25 firms across the country to lead the growing class-action suit charging the two houses with price-fixing.

title: Defending Home Turf From Attack; Fannie Mae Is Facing Assault By House Panel and Business Rivals
description: Fannie Mae, the giant company created by the government decades ago to help make mortgages available to home buyers, is no stranger to hardball politics or high-stakes finance, having established itself as a power to be reckoned with both in Washington and on Wall Street.

title: 3 African Leaders Urge Britain To Aid Zimbabwe Land Reform
description: Rallying behind Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, the leaders of three of this country's closest neighbors called on Britain tonight to follow through with financial pledges to support land reform here in its former colony.

title: Blue Jays Snap Yankees' Winning Streak
description: Fastballs thrown with intent to bruise are often senseless coded messages, but the mild exchange of hit batsmen today will allow the Yankees to remember their 8-3 loss to Toronto for something other than how badly they played.

title: Renault Agrees to Buy Troubled Samsung Motors of Korea
description: Renault, the French automaker, reached an agreement today to acquire the ailing Samsung Motors of South Korea, concluding its second major acquisition in Asia in the last year.

title: China Sets Up Office to Regulate Internet News
description: China Sets Up Office to Regulate Internet News

title: For Iran, Dark Pages of History
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Hey, Hey, Hey, Save My Caffe Latte!
description: After finding a community among anarchist squatters on the Lower East Side, [Sascha Scatter] decided to forgo college and became obsessed with riding freight trains. . . . [His zines] combine adventure-travel tales with thoughtful observations about the global economy. [In Seattle he] was tear-gassed seven times. His mission in D.C.: Guerrilla gardening -- activists planted trees, vegetables, and flowers on abandoned lots and lawns. His point: self-sufficiency. As Scatter sees it, there's plenty of food -- it just doesn't get to the people who need it.

title: Putin Acknowledges Chechnya's Peace Moves
description: In a sign that Russia is looking for a political solution to its war in Chechnya, President-elect Vladimir V. Putin acknowledged today for the first time that Moscow had exchanged peace plans with the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov.

title: Online Therapy: An Arm's-Length Approach
description: When the mayor of a small Midwestern town and his wife decided they needed marriage counseling, they were wary of seeking out a local therapist, for fear of gossip. So without ever leaving their home, they turned to the place where millions of anonymous business and personal transactions take place each day: the Internet.

title: Yankee Fan's Trip From Web to Stadium
description: Daniel Pomerantz wants to make one thing clear: He's not some money-hungry ''cybersquatter'' looking to get rich quick at the expense of the Yankees.

title: Samuel Block, 60, Civil Rights Battler, Dies
description: Samuel Block, who was repeatedly beaten and imprisoned as he fought for voting rights for blacks in his native Mississippi Delta during the 1960's, died April 13 in his Los Angeles apartment, his sister Margaret said. He was 60.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, SELMA E.
description: ABRAHAM-Selma E. Age 82, on April 18,2000, peacefully in her home in Manhattan, where she wanted to be. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother to Emily, Cookie, Carolyn and Seth and beloved mother-in-law of Fernando, Alan, Joe and Lynn. She is lovingly remembered by her nine grandchildren David, Jason, Nancy, Carolyn, Julia, Rachel, Fredda, Andrew & Sari. Also remembered by her three great grandchildren Jack, Brandon and Hannah. With courage, grace and dignity, she waged a one year battle with cancer, lovingly cared for by her friend Deborah Grant. Her family and friends will forever cherish her memory for her intelligence, humility, charm and inherent goodness. She was a much loved wife, remarkable mother and grandmother, devoted sister to Alice, Miriam and Ethel and loyal friend. She always put the concerns and wellbeing of others before her own. Contributions may be made in her name to the Cabrini Hospice care of Mary Cook, 227 E. 19 St., NY, NY 10003. Funeral Services Sunday, April 23rd at 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. NYC.

title: Countertenor Cancels
description: The countertenor Andreas Scholl has canceled his May 1 concert at Lincoln Center's Walter Reade Theater because of a scheduling conflict. Tickets can be exchanged for a refund at the box office or by mail, at the Alice Tully Hall box office, 1941 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10023. Information: (212) 875-5020.

title: State of Fashion: Can Anybody Explain?; It's Not Just Clothes
description: To the Editor:

title: Even at Top Speed, Angels Are at Ease
description: Kathleen Dyer sent dancers rushing through mostly happy rites of spring when her company, KDNY, presented ''Ain't Never Silent'' on Thursday night at the Clark Studio Theater.

title: It's Time to Chase the Moment in the Sun
description: Vince Carter arrives at Madison Square Garden tomorrow, carrying a nation and a television network. Tim Duncan trudges into a San Antonio training room, a franchise's hope tied to his injured left knee.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the first anniversary of the shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado misstated the relationship of Michael Shoels, who is suing the Jefferson County Sheriff's Department, to Isaiah Shoels, a victim. Michael Shoels is Isaiah Shoels's father, not his stepfather.

title: Journal; America Finds Another JonBenet
description: Of the zillions of words spilled in the cause of Elian Gonzalez, only those of Nathan Lane cut to the chase. Doing standup at a benefit in New York three weeks ago, the actor asked: ''Now if he wasn't so adorable, do you think there'd be such a dilemma? If he looked less like Haley Joel Osment and more like Herve Villechaize, would we still be talking about this?''

title: INTERDENT HIRES LEHMAN BROTHERS TO HELP IN FINANCING
description: InterDent Inc., the dental practice-management company, said late on Thursday that it had hired Lehman Brothers to help it pursue various strategic options, including finding alternative financing. The company has a refinancing and buyout agreement with the merchant bank Leonard Green & Partners, but the transaction can be terminated by either company if not completed by April 30. InterDent said it had hired Lehman Brothers to be prepared to find another partner if the agreement with Leonard Green fails.

title: Police Release Man After Arrest Over Protest
description: Police officers have released a man whom they arrested Thursday at a rally outside City Hall park.

title: Let's Play Two, but Will Weather Cooperate for Mets?
description: The Mets and Cubs have scheduled a doubleheader for today after last night's game was postponed because of rain. The first game will start at 1:10 p.m.

title: Expand Medicare For Care at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, STELLA
description: GOLDSTEIN-Stella. (nee Levi). On Thursday, April 20, 2000. Of West Orange, NJ. Wife of the late George. Beloved sister-in-law of Bella Goldstein. Aunt of three nieces & three nephews. Funeral service on Sunday at 10:30 A.M. in Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey. Interment in B'nai Jeshurun Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, The American Jewish Committee, Millburn, NJ, or your favorite charity in her memory.

title: NYT Article
description: NYT Article

title: White House Aides Criticize Republican Drug Proposal
description: The White House has sharply criticized the House Republican proposal for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, saying it ''seems like a Swiss cheese plan with more holes than substance.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARTIN H.,
description: STEIN-Martin H., M.D. The members of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague, Dr. Martin H. Stein, a revered and honored clinician, an educator who trained and guided several generations of psychoanalysts. He was constantly sought after as a supervisor and mentor. He will be deeply missed for his brilliance, clarity and wit. As past president of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Chairman of the Education Committee, for many years, he was a guiding spirit of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. His renown was international and his contributions to psychoanalytic thinking were significant and numerous. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Mrs. Lucille Stein, and his family. There will be a memorial service at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, 247 East 82 Street, New York on Saturday May 6th at 2pm. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the New York Psychoanalytic Institute or to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. Albert M. Sax, M.D., President/Society Eslee Samberg, M.D., President/Institute

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE DEMOCRATS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, CECELIA M.
description: TAYLOR-Cecelia M. (nee Campbell), on April 21, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Joseph M. Loving daughter of the late James and Catherine (nee McLaughlin). Natives of Inishowen County Donegal, Ireland. Fond sister of Josephine M. Coffey and the late Daniel J., Helen A., William E., Margaret B. Noone and Catherine M. McLoughlin. Also survived by three generations of nieces and nephews. Visitation Sunday, 7-9pm and Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97 St, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10:15am, Our Lady of Angels Church. Interment Saint John's Cemetery.

title: BAAN TO SPLIT OFF UNIT
description: A troubled Dutch software maker, the Baan Company, expects to complete plans for a separate stock listing of its Aurum unit by the end of the second quarter, the chief financial officer, Rob Ruijter, said in an interview with Het Financieele Dagblad. Baan is planning to list Aurum, its customer relation management software unit, as part of its effort to restructure and generate cash. Baan said on Thursday that its first-quarter loss widened to $25.8 million on sales of $106 million from a $19 million loss on sales of $176 million a year earlier.

title: Gore's Campaign, Confident on the Issues, Still Struggles With His Image
description: George W. Bush may be portraying himself as an unconventional Republican, but Al Gore plans to portray him as really unconventional.

title: State Sues to Shut A Brooklyn Dye Plant
description: The state attorney general's office has sued the owner of a fabric dying plant in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, saying the plant should be shut down for violating the state clean air laws, officials said yesterday.

title: Period of Adjustment For Players in Europe
description: The Giants have three players in the National Football League's European league: cornerback/kick returner Bashir Levingston, defensive end Frank Ferrara and linebacker O. J. Childress. The three have been assigned to the Amsterdam Admirals.

title: RUSSIA IS PUTTING PRESSURE ON U.S. OVER ARMS PACTS
description: In an unusual display of political unity, the Russian Parliament today handed President-elect Vladimir V. Putin his third overwhelming vote in a week ratifying a major arms control accord. The vote set the stage for a diplomatic campaign to put the United States on the defensive in nuclear disarmament talks.

title: Ameritrade Offering Free Electronic Trading
description: A few years ago, the chairman of Ameritrade Holdings said the price war among online brokerage companies might eventually drive trading commissions to less than zero. To undercut Ameritrade's latest discount, competitors will have to go that low.

title: Singing About the Saints
description: Los Papines were two parts tradition, one part show business when they performed at S.O.B.'s on Monday night as part of this Cuban group's first visit to New York since the 1970's. Ricardo (also called Papin), Luis, Alfredo and Jesus Abreu are brothers, percussionists and singers who have been performing together since the 1950's, polishing the Afro-Cuban rumba rhythms that are the foundation of salsa. While Jesus deploys an assortment of bongos, bells and woodblocks, his brothers play conga drums, building rhythms that are at once a conversation and a propulsion system.

title: Security Faces Review After a Laptop Vanishes
description: The State Department is considering a reorganization of its security system after a laptop computer vanished from an intelligence office with highly sensitive files about weapons proliferation, a senior administration official said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the dispute over land in Zimbabwe misstated the title of Nomore Sibanda, who described an attack that killed two political opponents of President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Sibanda is the information officer for the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions, not spokesman for the opponents' party.

title: Waves of Chinese Masterpieces Storm Market
description: NEW YORK  Like an unstoppable tide, China is looming ever larger on the art scene. Without anyone taking much notice, Chinese objects have now become the most expensive of all in the international market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGAMO, JAMES JOSEPH
description: BERGAMO-James Joseph. On April 20, 2000. Beloved father of Anthony Bergamo and Leslie Oster and their spouses. Dear grandfather, uncle and friend. Reposing at St. Joseph's RC Church, 404 East 87 St., NYC on Monday, 59PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10AM. Interment at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. In lieu flowers donations preferred to St. Joseph's RC Church. For further information, contact Krtil Funeral HomeYorkville Funeral Service, Inc. at 212-744-3084

title: Reed's Left Hand Still Hurts, and He May Miss Next Start
description: Rick Reed reached into his locker with his feeble left hand. With his thumb and forefinger, the Mets' right-hander gently picked up a shoe. Then he tried slipping on his baseball glove, working his fingers inside and pulling it over most of his palm. Close the glove? No way, not unless he used his right hand to squeeze it together.

title: BENEFITS
description: For Urban Health

title: A Safety-Environment Clash in Long Beach
description: WITH various proposals to build additional erosion protection on Long Beach Island languishing on the drawing boards for more than three decades, Madeleine Salgo of Point Lookout and John White of Long Beach agree that additional measures are desperately needed to prevent the next big storm from wreaking havoc with the barrier island, which is home to 43,000 people.

title: China Trade Unpopular
description: To the Editor:

title: Amargosa Valley Journal; A Land's 'Caretakers' Oppose Nuclear-Dump Plan
description: If the desert were a city, the ground near the Yucca Mountain ridge would be the lonely part of town where you hope the car doesn't break down. Less than 30 minutes on a winding, pitted road from Interstate 95, the Yucca flats are a different world, scorched and scarred. From here, trucks racing through the hard dirt off the highway, deafening at close range, sound like buzzing bees, and dusky brown rabbits browsing around the spotty brush look like kings of the world.

title: THEATER: Bravura Roles of Moods and Memories; Street Talk Complete With Glossary
description: AS is often the case by this point in the Broadway season, London playwrights are having their say. This year, three of England's senior dramatists are represented in plays both new and in revival: Michael Frayn (''Copenhagen''), Peter Shaffer (''Amadeus'') and Tom Stoppard (''The Real Thing''). On Wednesday they will be joined Off Broadway by one of Britain's younger generation when Rebecca Prichard, 28, makes her American theater debut with her play ''Yard Gal.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STECKER, WILLIAM
description: STECKER-William. 102 glorious years. April 15, Hollywood, FL. Oldest alumnus Columbia School of Engineering. Dedicated civic activist. Dearest father and grandfather. Joye and Bob Murphy, Kenneth Stecker, Penny Haft and Bill Thomason, Patricia Haft and Mark Anderson. Cherished in our memories forever.

title: A Wealth Of Tarkovsky On DVD
description: CONSIDERING that DVD's are in their infancy, it shows how much cinephiles esteem the Russian director Andrei Tarkovsky that four of his seven feature films are already available in that format. Indeed, no less a luminary than Ingmar Bergman called Tarkovsky ''the greatest.''

title: The Bases Are Loaded; Minor League Baseball Is on a Streak, but How Many Teams Are Too Many?
description: THERE will be speeches. A politician or two will limber up a rusty arm to lob ceremonial first pitches. An umpire will shout the traditional command, and minor-league baseball will come to Long Island, following a trend that has swept the New York region.

title: In a Land of Want, an Expensive War
description: There are few issues as sensitive in Ethiopia but none as obvious. The nation is waging a hugely expensive war, estimated to cost at least $500,000 a day in salaries alone, while eight million of its people struggle through the worst food shortage here in nearly 20 years.

title: Knicks Aim To Get a Jump On Raptors
description: The image is always the same. It is the opening minutes of the game, and an exasperated Jeff Van Gundy is standing in front of his team, with his jaw clenched as tight as a fist.

title: An Artist's Largess
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fan's Angry Notes
description: Joseph Nocera's scheme to pay collegiate athletes a wage for their services may indeed redistribute the vast wealth ''flowing into the N.C.A.A. coffers'' (The Way We Live Now, April 2). But it would also end once and for all the masquerade that collegiate athletes are anything other than hired hands for the universities they represent. I suppose more than a few university administrators would be reluctant to admit that their high-profile profit makers are little more than mercenaries.

title: Correspondence/To Have and Have Not; What Can the New Economy Do For Places Without an Old One?
description: IN early February, on assignment to seek out diamond smugglers, I traveled straight from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, to a place in central Africa where the borders of three nations -- Congo, Angola and Zambia -- fuse in a triangle of poverty and strife. It was a trip in every sense of the word, across the chasm separating the truly rich and the achingly poor.

title: The He Hormone
description: You gave a lot of ink to someone hooked on testosterone. How about equal time for an estrogen junkie? I've been popping estrogen pills for years now. The effects are not as immediate as those of testosterone -- the female chemical is, of course, less aggressive. But the high of the Big E is like no other. Within days, I feel more mature, more thoughtful and less impulsive.

title: April 16-22; Report on Theft From Jews
description: The seizure of Jewish assets in wartime France was so extensive that all Jews, whether the richest bankers or the poorest tailors, were touched by it. This was among the conclusions reached by the Matteoli Commission, which began the first major study on the subject three years ago. The study found that the theft of assets was far greater than previously assumed. But it also found that efforts to return the property or to reimburse Jews were extensive. SUZANNE DALEY

title: THE WHITMANS' TAXES
description: Governor Whitman last week disclosed her family's combined taxable income for 1999 as $1.17 million. That is a 37 percent drop from 1998, when she and her husband John, who manages an investment account, reported earning $1.86 million. She also reported that her family gave $213,000 to charities in 1999, up from $35,672 the year before. The Whitmans estimate they will pay federal taxes of $350,000 and state taxes of $95,000.

title: Personal Business; Road Warriors
description: As cities continue to sprawl, the trip to work, by whatever mans, consumes more and more of the day. And that leaves more room for all manner of mishap and adventure. What has been your own most extraordinary, or annoying, experience in commuting, and what was the response when you dragged into work? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: THEATER: Bravura Roles of Moods and Memories; A Showpiece For Sinead Cusack
description: IT would be an easy assumption to make, but a wrong one, to think of Sinead Cusack as famous by association. In her native Ireland, her surname evokes immediate associations to that country's eminent acting clan. Not only was her father, Cyril, one of the last century's best-known Irish performers, but having been born into celebrity, Ms. Cusack proceeded to marry a man who became one: Jeremy Irons, the film star.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Arts Center Events

title: Of Reason and Executive Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the West Was Filmed
description: MONUMENT VALLEY has been used as a backdrop for so many movies, car commercials and magazine advertisements that its rock cathedrals, craggy spires and wind-sculptured buttes are immediately recognizable. Part of the credit goes to the director John Ford, who filmed the 1939 western classic ''Stagecoach'' there and returned to make seven more westerns.

title: Gufeld Is One of Lucky 13 At Top of the National Open
description: A real crowd, 13 players, tied for first in the National Open 2000 Tournament at the Riviera Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, March 17 to 19.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-23-00: Phenomenon; While Nasdaq Burns
description: 'This is big -- really big,'' said Bill Sarpalius, a former Texas congressman, taking in the scene at Boot Camp for Start-Ups, a seminar recently held in Manhattan and currently making its way around the country. While the Nasdaq was imitating sine waves on computer screens around the world, Sarpalius, like everyone else in sight, was networking wildly and conferencing on his cell phone. He was on the line with his board working out a merger with a rival while his employees were back at Lobbyforme.com, a Web site that, come May, will allow citizens to pool their resources and hire former congressmen as lobbyists. Getting voted out of office, he decided, was ''the best thing that ever happened. Now I'm part of a new frontier. There was the gold rush, the land rush and the oil boom. Now it's the Internet. I'm staking my claim.''

title: A Bumpy April for Mr. Gore
description: All presidential campaigns have ups and downs, making it dangerous to predict a candidate's fortunes based on the latest smooth or rough patch. After looking the awkward rookie in the primary season, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has been campaigning confidently for several weeks. By contrast, Vice President Al Gore has looked listless and unfocused since he muscled Bill Bradley out of the Democratic race. Some polls show him once again trailing the Texas governor by a significant margin, and his pandering to the Miami Cuban community's view on Elian Gonzalez reinforced the perception that Mr. Gore too quickly puts politics ahead of principle.

The one-room cabin was built sometime between 1638 and 1643, one among a few similar buildings put up by Swedish and Finnish immigrants who arrived by way of the Delaware River to trap and farm.

title: A Helping Hand on the Mouse
description: The urge to serve can wither without an outlet. To help potential volunteers find a cause that needs them, the Rutgers Citizenship and Service Education Program (Case), which integrates public service with college coursework, earlier this month set up a Web site, www.njserves.org. Rutgers students spent months buttonholing community groups to fill out surveys and have included 3,000 of them so far; the goal is 40,000. Students will also help organizations build a Web site if they don't have one. Clickers-on can search by geographic area or by subject, in the areas of youth, the elderly, the environment, housing and health. The home page includes a list of events and a featured organization. Last week, the organization was the Summit Speech School in New Providence, which works with hearing-impaired babies and children. The school needs toys and volunteers to work in the office or assist in teaching, with training provided.

Either way, it could be the biggest thing to hit the music business since rock itself. But it is early yet, and figuring how it will play out is like trying to extrapolate ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' from ''Love Me Do.''

A sofa and chairs are grouped around a coffee table with a glass display top; the furniture, bland and half-familiar, turns out to be mail order. A museum guard perches in a chair near the sideboard that holds refreshments. A vaguely Victorian jungle of potted palms and blooming clivia looms in back. Finches in two hanging cages chirp and hop from perch to perch; Mrs. Gardner, Mr. Lee tells me, kept birds.

description: STONE - FRIEDLANDER - Judy, M.D. The Partners and staff of Concord/Kips Bay Medical Group extend their deepest sympathies to our colleague and partner, Charles Friedlander, on the untimely passing of his wife. The quintessential 20th century woman, Judy Stone-Friedlander somehow managed to fit motherhood of six wonderful children and three separate, extremely successful careers into her all too short lifetime. She was a physician, loved and respected for her tenderness and sensitivity to her patients during her medical career, and equally known and respected for her financial acumen in her business career. title: A Madeleine With Two Straws, Please
description: Proust's madeleine, that overused image, is about a familiar taste that unlocks a flood of lost memories. For much of my adult life, I've been searching for the converse: I already have the memories, but the taste has been lost. That flavor is of a milkshake that my father would order for me on our occasional trips to a soda fountain when I was a boy. No dramatics, no long book; it was just nice for the two of us to be together, sharing a milkshake made with root beer syrup and coffee ice cream. Try these days to find a fountain that has root beer syrup. I certainly have. Well, I finally found it, in Montclair, at the Soda Pop Shop.

And Unshaded, who was never nominated to run in the Derby, would have to pay a supplemental fee of $150,000 to enter.

description: Amid increasing concern over ''superbugs'' that can outsmart even the most powerful germ-fighting medicines, the Food and Drug Administration approved a new antibiotic, Zyvox, that doctors say could save thousands of lives.

title: A Journey Begun in Opera Continues in Symphony
description: THE crooked side road, the whispering pines, the flagstone path: I have passed this way before. Snow was hanging heavy on the branches then. Today, the first fragrant lilacs shiver in icy breezes that slice like a knife. The Finnish composer Einojuhani Rautavaara, 71, stands framed in the doorway, looking nothing like the solitary misanthrope of legend, an icon of contentment: slightly stooped but tall, thick dark hair mixed with gray, deep-set eyes sparkling in welcome.

title: Ingrid Kuo, Paul Kuo

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-23-00: ShopTalk; What Would Jesus Do in This Scene?
description: The revival of ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' opened on Broadway on April 16, starring Glenn Carter in the title role. And on May 14, CBS will broadcast the first installment of ''Jesus,'' a two-part mini-series that stars Jeremy Sisto. By any standards, the son of God is a daunting role to step into. Does playing Jesus pose any special dramatic challenges? And does it present any special hazards for the typically impressionable egos of actors? Here,Carter and Sisto discuss what it's like when your agent calls you and tells you you're the Savior of all mankind.

title: Acknowledging That Early Age Of Awkwardness
description: MY version of a Kafka nightmare is waking up in junior high and being unable to find my gym locker. So it's curious that I am so fond of ''Caitlin's Way,'' the best and brightest of ''tween'' television.

title: Lives; Home Improvement
description: Sweeping the streets where he used to sleep, John Hodge tries to live a cleaner life. After spending nine and a half years in jail for armed robbery and another four years living on the streets, begging for change and shooting heroin, John Hodge heard about a nonprofit program called Ready, Willing and Able -- which provides homeless people with housing and a paid job -- and decided to sign up. For the last 10 months, Hodge, 45, has been cleaning the same 10-block stretch on First Avenue where he used to panhandle. ''It's a beautiful thing,'' he says. ''My job is a blessing.''

title: Remember Fountain Pens?
description: It's Friday, just before noon, at the Montblanc customer service center here in Hunterdon County. Seven technicians in starched white lab coats repair gold nibs on fountain pens or casings on ballpoints that owners have sent in. Except for the sound of pens gliding across paper, all is still.

title: April 16-22; Solving a Royal Mystery
description: Examining all that remained of the young boy who died in France's Temple prison in 1795 -- a dried heart -- scientists ended one of the nation's most enduring historical debates. The boy, the scientists said, was indeed Louis XVII, the 10-year-old uncrowned king of France, and not an impostor placed there so the young dauphin could escape into exile.

title: Elvis Is Leaving the Garden State
description: After appearing with the likes of Marilyn Monroe and Cher -- look-alikes that is -- one of the state's best-known Elvis impersonators has hit the big time in Hollywood and is headed for Las Vegas.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Lost World
description: When the New York Yiddish newspaper The Jewish Daily Forward published Alter Kacyzne's photographs of shtetl life from Europe in the 1920's, he fought with the editors over money and expenses. No one knew this work would be his final legacy. POYLN: Jewish Life in the Old Country (Metropolitan/Holt, $50) includes about 150 of Kacyzne's exquisitely detailed, haunting black-and-white portraits of the lost world of Polish Jews at the rustic shops, town halls and synagogues where they toiled and prayed. Born Alter-Sholem Kacyzne in 1885 to a poor family of laborers, he went to work as a photographer's apprentice when his father died. Following his mentor, the famous Yiddish writer I. L. Peretz, to Warsaw, Kacyzne became a poet, playwright and well-known photojournalist in Poland, at the time the home of three million Jews. For The Forward he took photographs in 120 locations, from the crowded quarters of Warsaw to the barren countryside. Kacyzne was killed in a pogrom on July 7, 1941, in Tarnopol (now Ternopil, Ukraine). His wife, Khana Khachanov, died in the Belzec death camp. Only their daughter, Sulamita, survived -- along with 700 photographs from which this selection was made. It restores Kacyzne's original, idiosyncratic captions; for example, under a photograph of an intense-looking Hebrew teacher wearing a black hat, Kacyzne wrote: ''More than once his students have nailed his beard -- the longest in Byale -- to the table when he has dozed off. Perhaps that's why he has such wonderful, sad eyes.'' Susan Shapiro

He also caused me to try to buy stock in Unimed, maker of AndroGel, the Next Great Thing. Unfortunately, it's owned by Solvay, a Belgian company that is not listed on United States exchanges.
