description: SPRING demands a light touch with pasta. Instead of hearty, long-simmered ragus and dense tomato and game sauces the stage shifts to sheer, herbaceous mixtures that cling lightly to strands of fresh fettuccine, slender tagliarini or penne. Tender vegetables like garden peas and baby artichokes tossed with the pasta add seasonal flavors.

Attorney General Janet Reno should have given the two branches of the Gonzalez family more time to try to resolve the case amicably, and she should have applied more legal pressure on the Miami relatives before battering down their door to remove Elian.

First came the tubs of berry-colored lip gloss that could smother a fly. Then I bought a pair of denim flares with braided detailing at the waist, a flowing chiffon blouse and tinted aviator sunglasses. And finally I went to the drugstore and spent $6.99 on that instrument of torture I hadn't braved since I was 12, a curling iron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATVIG, ARTHUR G.
description: NATVIG-Arthur G., age 84, native of Brooklyn, New York and along time executive at Citibank, died on April 18, 2000 at New Port Richey, Florida after a lengthy illness. Mr. Natvig began his career with Citibank as a 15 year old office boy in 1931 in New York City and retired in 1976 as a Vice President of one of the world's largest banks. He attended Brooklyn College at night for seven years graduating Summa Cum Laude. During World War II he served in the U.S. Army. In the early 1950's he joined Citibank's Comptroller's Domestic Inspection Division and within a few years moved to International Inspection, where he was to spend the remainder of his banking career. During that period he traveled around the world nearly 50 times. During his tenure in the Comptroller's Division, Mr. Natvig was regarded by many as the bank's foremost expert on Foreign Exchange. In addition to being instrumental in establishing Citibank branches around the world, he created and maintained the Inspector's Handbook, which reportedly was considered of incalculable value to the Inspection effort throughout Citibank's International Operations. After his retirement Mr. Natvig remained with Citibank in an advisory capacity for five years working in Asia, Australia, Europe, South America, Canada and the Caribbean. Mr. Natvig leaves two sisters, Ruth Halstead of New Port Richey and Joan Shuman, of Centerville, Massachusetts; four nieces and two nephews; 10 great nieces and nephews. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Pasco, Inc., 3539 Universal Plaza, New Port Richey, Florida 34652. A memorial service will be held at the North Meadowlawn Funeral Home, 4244 Madison Street, New Port Richey, Florida on April 27, 2000 at 10 AM. Immediately following this service, burial will take place at Florida National Cemetery.

title: REDUCING GREENHOUSE GASES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINSON, LUCINDA PINA
description: WILKINSON-Lucinda Pina. April 21, 2000. Age 61, died peacefully April 21 at her home in Manhattan of breast cancer, which she had been fighting for the last two years. Born in Madrid, Spain, Luly received her master's degree in physical chemistry from the University of Madrid and studied at Oxford University and the University of Geneva. Continuing her education in the U.S. Luly attended Harvard University and met her husband while attending Mary Baldwin College in Virginia. She performed research in the field of molten salts using nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometry at the University of Virginia from 1964-1966. She and her family moved to New York in 1969. From 1977 to 1987 Luly taught Spanish grammar and literature at the Brearley School. Luly was a fixture on the Upper East Side, well known by many for her beloved Labrador Retrievers: Powhattan, Amelia and Augusta, who she enjoyed walking daily. She was involved in student affairs at the Collegiate, St. Bernard's and Brearley Schools, which her children attended. Nothing gave her more pleasure than the children's summer swimming races at the Lawrence Beach Club on Atlantic Beach, Long Island. As the family grew and children moved from home, Luly was instrumental in gathering every member, including additions through marriages and births, for memorable birthdays and holidays at a country home in Oxford, Maryland. Luly was proud of her heritage. Her Spanish family was instrumental in advancing education for women. Her grandfather founded the first co-ed, non-sectarian private school in Spain in the 1920's. Luly's parents were both Olympic athletes in the Republic of Spain in the 1930's. Luly shared their love for the mountains and skiing, a passion she continued to pursue with her husband and children. Her favorite family destination for over 20 years was the pistes in Klosters, Switzerland. Luly was known for her Castillian determination and her contagious smile that inspired everyone around her. She was loved by many and will be missed all the more. Luly is survived by her husband, Donald McLean Wilkinson, her children Donald McLean Wilkinson III and his wife, Lauren Doyle Wilkinson, of Manhattan, Duncan Austin Wilkinson of Arlington, Virginia, Charles Carroll Wilkinson of Dallas, Texas, and Margot Carolina Wilkinson Kaye and her husband Jason Philip Kaye of Fort Collins, Colorado, and her grandchildren Donald McLean Wilkinson IV and Ian James Wilkinson of Manhattan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81 St on Monday, the 24th of April 4-8 PM. There will be a Requiem Mass at 11AM on Tuesday the 25th of April at St. Thomas More Church in New York and she will be interred at the historic Hollywood Cemetery in Richmond, Virginia with a burial service at 11AM on Friday the 28th of April. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in her memory to a needy church, Santa Rita, 448 College Avenue, Bronx, N Y. 10451.

title: Reckonings; How To be A Hack
description: Oh, the outrage! The Web site maintained by Mobilization for Global Justice, the umbrella organization for last week's Washington protests, gave precisely one example of the economic evil the World Bank does. I looked into that story, and found that it doesn't quite have the claimed moral. Actually, the bank -- not always a lovable organization, to say the least -- in this particular case comes out smelling like a rose. But clearly, to say this in last Wednesday's column was terribly unfair. If a story confirms what the protesters believe, it is a telling example; but if it doesn't, explaining the truth of the case is a cheap shot.

description: The Canadian Pacific Railway has brought its fleet of vintage rail cars back into service for a new luxury tour of the Canadian Rockies.

title: A Sitcom Savant Branches Out

She's 17, very pregnant and even barefoot -- since her shoes fell through a huge hole in the car floor somewhere between Tennessee and Oklahoma. On the drive from her trailer-park home to a new life in California, she makes the mistake of asking her boyfriend to stop at a Wal-Mart so she can go to the bathroom. When she returns to the parking lot, he and the car are gone.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-23-00: Salient Facts Oil Prices; Crude Economics
description: OVER A BARRELAmericans' summer vacations threatened, the press accounts claimed -- that's when the high price of oil really got scary. All winter the price had been climbing, until on March 7 it reached a 10-year high of $34 a barrel. Government experts predicted that it wouldn't come back down to the more tolerable level of $24 till March 2001. As it turned out, however, it took only a couple of weeks for prices to drop to that point. Cheaper gas prices will follow -- it usually takes about eight weeks. So go ahead and make those motel reservations from here to the Grand Canyon.

title: Dot-Coms: A Way to Burn Money, or to Fuel the Future?; Venture Capital Is Opening Doors
description: Does the start-up machinery of the new economy inevitably yield wasteful companies, doomed to flame out after their early backers cash in? A dot-com chief executive and a prominent venture capitalist argue the point.

title: The He Hormone
description: I enjoyed Sullivan's article. But I got a little creeped out toward the end when he started suggesting testosterone supplements for the gender- and age-disadvantaged.'' Frankly, now that I'm getting older, I am finding my hormonally challenged state a relief.

title: Newark Gets Grant to Buy Back Guns
description: Newark is to receive $715,000, more than double any other city's stipend, in a program by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to finance gun buyback programs.

title: 'Doktor Faust' Captures a Composer's Paradoxes
description: IT is strange enough that such a phenomenon appeared in our time,'' Kurt Weill wrote of his teacher, Ferruccio Busoni, in 1925 on the first anniversary of Busoni's death. ''Even in the past we find few figures in whom the man and the work are thus unified. . . . We are bound to think of Leonardo. In him also we find that comprehensive spirituality which strives to open up all attainable spheres. . . . Such individuals are immortal not only through their work but through the radiation of their personality, through the gradual influence of their humanity.''

title: Just Off Britain, A World Apart
description: THE Manx double-decker's motion lulled me into a near sleep. A half-day ramble earlier through Cregneash on the Isle of Man left me tired, and from my second-deck seat on this hurtling Peel-bound bus, I drifted in and out. Narrow hedgerow-lined roads, tidy fieldstone villages, villagers, schoolchildren, dogs, cars, farms, sheep, cows, green hills and slivers of the Irish Sea blurred until the scenery winked out all together.

title: Jets Would Want Rice if 49ers Do Not Keep Him
description: There is a great debate within the San Francisco 49ers organization -- to keep Jerry Rice or not to keep him. Depending on whom you talk to on the team, the 49ers either want to cut Rice after June 1 to save valuable salary-cap room, or have Rice take a dramatic pay cut so he can stay one more season and then retire as a 49er.

title: Evernham to Help Usher In Dodge Era for Nascar in 2001
description: Nascar's Winston Cup Series is taking a pause this week before moving on to Los Angeles for next week's race, the 10th of 34 this season. But Ray Evernham, who is shaping Dodge's debut in the series for next year, is busier than if he had remained the celebrated crew chief for Jeff Gordon.

title: Don't Quit the Night Job
description: DUMB MONEY

title: Middlebrow Art
description: To the Editor:

title: For Women, A Clean, Well-Lighted Place to Paint
description: ONE of this season's more rewarding sleepers is ''Overcoming All Obstacles: The Women of the Academie Julian'' at the Dahesh Museum, 601 Fifth Avenue. Niched on the east side of the avenue between 48th and 49th Streets, this little museum is an oasis of quiet and comfort. Visitors, though not always numerous, tend to be keenly attentive. The subject matter makes very good points at every turn but does not set out either to bully or reproach us.

title: A Weighted System?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Women in Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGIDOFF, RUTH
description: MAGIDOFF-Ruth. Passed away April 20, 2000. Widow of Davis. Survived by loving daughter, Natalie Sheffler, and son-in-law, Frank; adoring son, Alan Magidoff, and daughter-in-law, Iris; 7 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. She lived almost a century of loving and being loved. Graveside services Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, Sunday, 11 AM.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles last week about Hollywood stars who support social and political causes misstated the name of a group with which Leonardo DiCaprio met in his effort to become an environmental spokesman. It is the Natural Resources Defense Council, not the National Resources Defense Council.

title: Mosquitoes Are Coming! Mosquitoes Are Coming!
description: Soon the mosquitoes will come out, scarier this year because of the emergence of West Nile virus in the region last year. Next week the bait will come out: flocks of chickens in every county, left out in hutches where they can be bitten and then tested for the mosquito-borne encephalitis virus.

title: At Cabby's Funeral, a Call for a Community Solution
description: A funeral procession of about 170 people on foot and 15 livery cabs traveled several miles from East New York, Brooklyn, to a Queens cemetery yesterday morning, to bury the seventh livery-cab driver to be killed on duty this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a public monument at the Jersey City station of the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail system referred incompletely to the site of the foundry work. Some casting was done at the Johnson Atelier in Trenton; the rest was completed at the New Foundry New York, in Brooklyn.

title: The World In Queens
description: DIMPLE

title: Turkish Fish House That Knows Its Way
description: IT'S Easter-time and a new restaurant that opened on Main Street in Huntington looks, for all the world, like a Faberge egg: attractive enough on the outside with a surprising wonderland within. It is Dardanelles, a Turkish fish house that gives new meaning to the word storefront.

title: An Exhaustive Work by Mahler, Not Meant for the Faint-Hearted
description: WHEN the composer Gustav Mahler visited Niagara Falls for the first time in the early 20th century, he exclaimed, ''Fortissimo at last!'' Translation: ''That's what I mean by very loud.''

title: The Anticommunity Effects Of Uniform School Tests
description: As a former middle-school science teacher, I feel Robert Ricken's pain as he laments the testing for standards in middle schools [''The Death Knoll of Middle School,'' April 16].

title: Where Authentic German Food Sells Out
description: TWO regulars, Frances and Peter Myressi, sat at their usual table at the Saturday night dinner held twice a month by the proprietors of the Chilmark German Delicatessen here and waited for their meals to arrive. In the interim they drank from sizable mugs of draft beer.

title: Bookend; Heaven, They're in Heaven
description: THE usual questions about heaven are: Where is it? How do you get there? What's it like when you do? Some of the answers are provided in a substantial new anthology, ''The Book of Heaven'' (Oxford University, $30), edited by Philip Zaleski and Carol Zaleski, who has also produced books on ''Otherworld Journeys'' (answers to the second question) and ''The Life of the World to Come'' (third question). (Philip's books include ''Gifts of the Spirit.'') The Zaleskis are cheerfully learned. Distinctly pro-heaven themselves, they wish everybody else were (''We neglect heaven at our peril''); but they claim that even skeptics will find pleasure in these accounts of it, especially if they ''savor the comic elements,'' here represented largely by satirical or jocular contributions from Henry Fielding, Lord Byron, Rupert Brooke and Mark Twain, none of which, if one may say so without falling into heresy, is particularly funny. The pleasures of the anthology must be sought elsewhere.

title: Unequal Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: A Breath of Spring
description: Indeed, you can't judge a book by its cover, as the McGuffey Reader might have said. But you can almost tell the 1999 Macari Vineyards sauvignon blanc from its suggestive packaging. The clear bottle displays the pale wine to advantage, and the light gray-green two-part front label, embellished by gold design and lettering, imply refreshing flavor.

title: Taking His Beat From the Bible
description: WHEN Richard Shindell was a student at Union Theological Seminary in New York, he had no idea that his study of the Bible would richly inform a future songwriting career. All he knew was that the Bible made great reading.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Benefit Boxes

title: The 'Perfect Knight' in the Country of Poetry
description: It's impossible to write about Knopf poetry without writing about Harry Ford.

title: Soul Brothers for Carnivores
description: Discriminating carnivores thrive on meaty reds, too. Charolais beef and New Zealand lamb require wines that express their regions; indeed, cultures. Two such hearty reds, soul brothers, are the 1998 Cuv'ee Alb'eric Bouvet, Crozes-Hermitage, from Domaine Gilles Robin in the Rhone, and the 1998 Vega Brav'ia from Bodegas Anta'no in Castile.

title: Swing, You're on Very Candid Camera
description: Outside the psychiatrist's office, those most interested in self-analysis are golfers, who pay pros big bucks to scrutinize the pluses and minuses of their game with special cameras, camcorders and even computer readouts. But this golf season, players can have their swings picked apart without expensive lessons or photo equipment, using Fuji's 35-millimeter QuickSnap Golf Camera, a disposable model that captures their technique frame-by-frame.

title: PrivateSector; Executive Pay Gets a Second Look
description: When Charles B. Wang, founder of Computer Associates, received more than $600 million in stock, and two other executives -- Sanjay Kumar, the president, and Russell J. Artzt, the executive vice president -- a total of more than $400 million in 1998, shareholders screamed, asking why so much to so few. Had these shares, equal to 3.75 percent of the company's value, been divided among all employees, each would have received $113,000.

title: What's for Lunch, Class? Stay Tuned
description: YOU never know where you might find innovation.

title: A Berkeley Brat, Seeking Structure
description: WHEN the writer and director Lisa Krueger was 19, she fled to Paris and lived there for five years. What was she escaping? Freedom. Namely, the kind engendered by being raised in Berkeley, Calif., a university town famous for its love of radical politics, social experimentation and A-to-Z religions.

title: Penn Defends Blackwell Cup
description: Pennsylvania's men's varsity heavyweight crew successfully defended the Blackwell Cup on the Harlem River yesterday, defeating Columbia by 4.4 seconds and Yale by 5.1 seconds for its first victory of the season.

title: The Andes in Tumult, Shaken by Political Tremors
description: Guerrillas and the cocaine trade batter Colombia. A strongman rides roughshod over a discredited Congress and courts in Venezuela. Ecuador reels from an economic crisis and a coup. Bolivia has just emerged from a state of siege. And Peru awaits an election between an autocrat accused of trying to steal the presidency and a political firebrand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURANTE, CARL
description: DURANTE-Carl. 76, of Hasbrouck Heights, NJ on April 19. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Mary, Michael and Mark. Devoted grandfather of Christopher Durante, Katharine and Michael O'Donnell, Matthew Durante. Brother of Theresa Gulotta, Regina Stavola. Funeral Mass 11 AM, Corpus Christi R.C. Church. Interment St. Theresa Mausoleum Summit. Visiting Sunday, 2-4 and 79, Hennessey-Powell, 232 Kipp Ave., Hasbrouck Heights. For information call 201-288-1362.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARTIN HOWARD
description: STEIN-Martin Howard. April 19, 2000. Husband of Lucille. Father of Maurine and her husband, Stephen, and Nora and her husband, Paul. Grandfather of Harold, Sophie and Isabel. A memorial service will be announced shortly. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Psychoanalytic Institute and the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

title: American Histories: Chasing Dreams And Nightmares; Sailing The Stream Of Black Culture
description: When August Wilson wrote his first full-length play, ''Jitney,'' in 1979, he did not realize that it was the beginning of a major cycle on the black experience in America. His subsequent decision to write a play for each of the 10 decades of the 20th century is an idea that has borne fruit: eight dramas so far, six of them on Broadway. A newly revised version of ''Jitney,'' about gypsy cabdrivers in 1977 in Pittsburgh, opens on Tuesday Off Broadway at the Second Stage Theater, directed by Marion McClinton.

title: Let the Screams Begin
description: The Cyclone, the famed wooden roller coaster at Coney Island, starts up another white-knuckle season. With other reports from the West Village, Upper West Side, Upper East Side, Midtown, Greenwich Village, SoHo, Broad Channel, Downtown Brooklyn, South Brooklyn, Hunts Point and Pelham Parkway.

title: April 16-22; Vermont Gay Union Bill
description: Vermont's legislature reached the verge of creating the closest thing in America to gay marriage -- but left the final step until this week, and no one is saying its over until its over. The state Senate, in a 19-to-11 vote, passed a bill creating marriage-like civil unions, but its bill was slightly different from the one passed last month in the House. That means the House takes up the question again in a session on Tuesday. Gov. Howard Dean has said he will sign the bill. CAREY GOLDBERG

title: Lack of Maintenance Cited for Golf Courses
description: Regarding the article ''Plan for a Golf Course Draws Fire'' last Sunday, the reason most golfers are opposed to Hudson Hills is the lack of maintenance on the five courses that are open now. Until the county shows they can properly maintain these, it would be foolish to open another course. We would rather have five good than six bad.

title: Views of Vietnam, Here and There
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring the Importance of Being Oscar
description: SOMETIMES the world of academia goes wild in selecting subjects for scholarly symposiums. The agendas of interdisciplinary conferences, as they are often called, can smack of pedantry and pretension.

title: Waiting, and Praying, for Tuna
description: For many years, I arrived with the bluefin at Favignana, a small island off the northwest coast of Sicily. Every spring for untold centuries, great schools of giant bluefin tuna have swum through the Strait of Gibraltar to spawn in the Mediterranean. And for 1,100 years, the tonnaroti, the tuna fishermen of Favignana, have waited for them with an enormous seven-chambered trap: la tonnara. For weeks before the arrival of the tuna, a 63-man crew drops miles of net and thousands of anchors. They build their trap slowly, with songs, prayers and ancient rituals. This ancient hunt is holy.

title: The Lure Of a Lush Desert
description: I'M of two minds about the desert. I appreciate its quirky, independent, prickly beauty, and the minimalist survival that goes on there.

title: Louisville
description: Spring is Kentucky Derby season in Louisville. Heralded by blooming azaleas and magnolia trees, the Derby at Churchill Downs is an annual excuse to drink mint juleps and don diaphanous hats. The race since its inception has drawn all classes, thrilled at the prospect of those two minutes on the first Saturday in May, when 3-year-old Thoroughbreds run the race of their lives.

title: Cone Is Battered And Bewildered Against Blue Jays
description: The damage was done, and David Cone, burdened for five more days with the internal questions on why he keeps getting pounded and why he cannot win, leaned forward on the stool in front of his locker today, his right hand propping his chin. Jim Leyritz, the catcher, sat next to him, commiserating, counseling, consoling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, JACOB D.
description: WEINTRAUB-Jacob D. Died April 21, 2000. Survived by his loving wife Bronka Weintraub. A member of Temple Emanuel. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: In Havana, Calm Belies Private Glee
description: They are calling it the rescue of Elian.

title: The Good Father
description: Halfway through the first quarter of the Feb. 29 game between the Portland Trail Blazers and the Los Angeles Lakers, with Portland having just gone up, 8-6, Phil Jackson, the coach of the Lakers, called timeout. Before the teams met, Jackson said he had never seen ''a bigger game in my 33 years'' in the N.B.A., which, coming from such an exponent of understatement and indirection, seemed improbable hyperbole. True, the game did involve two teams with identical records -- 45-11, the best in the National Basketball Association -- and identical 11-game winning streaks. And Los Angeles had lost the last seven games in Portland. But it still seemed a rather abrupt and alarming timeout.

title: Admitting To Our Other Obsessions
description: WHAT do we really talk about with our friends when we're not discussing the vicissitudes of our personal lives? Why, popular culture, of course! Much of the conversational glue that binds us together comes from the stuff that wafts off television, movie and computer screens, from our stereo speakers and headsets. It's an endless torrent of gossip and opinion filtered through personal taste. The focus of conversation could be the Academy Awards, a diva fest on VH1, a sports hero's latest feat, Oprah's newest inspirational gambit, a Jerry Springer freak show or the guys in 'N Sync.

title: Great Dress, Dear. Did You Make It Yourself?
description: STEPPING out recently in a certain strapless taffeta gown, I felt a mixture of embarrassment and anticipation. Not that the shirred olive-colored dress wasn't flattering. But I was wearing a knockoff of the endlessly photographed gown Hilary Swank had so stunningly preened in three and a half weeks earlier at the Academy Awards -- a copy ginned up by an ever nimbler arm of the fashion industry specializing in reproductions from runways and awards ceremonies.

title: Jerks in the Ads, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: A Beloved East Side Pharmacy Closes Its Doors  . . .
description: After 43 years of serving friends and neighbors from the familiar corner of York Avenue and East 81st Street, Wenbar Pharmacy suddenly and without warning closed its doors for good two weeks ago. The owner, Murray Gallahou, said a huge rent increase and competition from national drugstore chains moving into the area had finally forced him out of business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTARELLI, ERNESTO
description: COSTARELLI-Ernesto. The Officers, Directors and Employees of Parkside Memorial Chapels, Inc. mourn the passing of their friend ''Ernie''. Our deepest condolences are extended to his devoted wife Sue and his loving children Linda Morelli and Tommy. We will all miss his good nature & friendship. Edward S. Goldstein, Secretary

title: The He Hormone
description: This article can be read as a tendentious apology for the worst forms of male behavior. It is no small irony that it ran right before Steven Erlanger's article about an American soldier accused of the rape and murder of a Kosovar child.

title: Volunteering on Behalf Of Patients Like Themselves
description: Melinda Kuhn was 12 when she had her first pelvic exam. The experience was so traumatic, she says, that she didn't return to a gynecologist for eight years. ''No one took the time to tell me what was happening,'' recalled Ms. Kuhn, a 30-year-old actress and hair and makeup artist. ''Strange people were talking about me in the third person. They got angry and yelled at me to relax.''

title: Under the Arizona Sun
description: IT was not yet noon, but the thermometer in our rented sport utility vehicle showed it was 102 degrees outside when my friend Georgia and I arrived at the top of First Mesa, a forbidding-looking plateau of rock in the northeastern Arizona desert and a thriving traditional center of Hopi Indian life.

title: The View From/White Plains; Life With Lizards, Snakes and Turtles
description: FROM the eccentric to the earnest, lovers of scaled vertebrates were out last Sunday at the New York Metro Reptile Expo. Held at the County Center here, the event featured hundreds of varieties of lizards, snakes and turtles (no venomous ones allowed) for display and sale along with the equipment to keep them healthy.

title: Mets Keep Their Minds On the Games and Win
description: Bobby Valentine is not a proponent of clubhouse speeches, so he does not remember specifically the last time he gave one. He thinks it was during the last days of spring training or after the Mets returned from Japan, but he is not sure.

title: Works That Reveal Reactions to Family Ties
description: THE family is often thought of as the cornerstone of society. The kaleidoscope of events and the ensuing memories that fill people's lives makes its way through the psyche, playing a pivotal role in who people are and what they become. How visual artists record or respond to this process is the subject of the current exhibition, called ''Family Tales,'' at the Pelham Art Center here.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-23-00: The Ethicist; Caveat Employer
description: I recently received a job offer, which I orally accepted. When I approached my current employer with my resignation, he made a counteroffer. I now wish to remain with my current employer. Is it correct to revoke my acceptance of the original offer? -Anonymous

title: Toujours Provence
description: REFLEXIONS

title: Cell Phone Addiction Has a Sad Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Denver Airport Easing Hunt for Computer Jack
description: Nearly all airports have pay telephones with credit card readers or jacks for a laptop computer, but travelers can have trouble finding an open one. Denver International Airport decided recently to ease that problem by putting those features on every phone. In a few weeks, technicians will begin pulling out all of the airport's 800 pay phones and replacing them with 1,000 that will have a card reader and a data port.

title: Sarah Landsman, Lee Evers
description: Sarah Eden Landsman, a daughter of Miriam and Donald Landsman of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Lee Evers, the son of Katie and Charles Evers of Greenville, Miss. Judge Angelique A. Reed, a civil court judge in New Orleans, officiated at the Boucvalt House, a 19th-century home there.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a Supreme Court case over the Boy Scouts' right to expel a gay scout leader referred incorrectly to the United Methodist Church. As a denomination, the church took no position. Two Methodist organizations did file briefs, on opposing sides -- the United Methodist Board of Church and Society opposing the Scouts' policy and the General Commission on United Methodist Men favoring it.

title: Liberties; Spite Or Art?
description: We anticipated a New York Senate race perfumed with romantic vengeance.

title: Putting Technology Jobs On Women's Career Radar
description: MY wife, Christine Negroni, has just published a book. After she's done with the signings and interviews, she moves to the mundane world of the once-published. What, she has to decide, will she do next?

title: Ostrich and Buffalo Burgers, and More
description: FIRST impressions deceive at the new Sweetwaters Bar and Bistro in Hauppauge. Knowledgeable diners will notice that the restaurant, at 470 Wheeler Road (631-348-0808), has a small dark dining room and a big handsome bar room, holds daily happy hours from 4 to 7 p.m. and promotes disc jockey entertainment every Thursday, Friday and Saturday. A look into the woody dining room -- with its pressed tin ceiling, overhead fans, bare shiny floors, dome lighting and photos of bygone American roadhouse eateries (my favorite is Posey's Topless Oysters) -- reveals burgers in baskets, butter patties in foil wrappers and ketchup in bottles. All this leads one to conclude that Sweetwaters is much more about drinking than eating, that it is a burger and Bud, big television, loud music hangout.

title: Where Garfield, Elvis and Buddha Rub Noses
description: Broad Channel, a working-class island community where many houses stand on stilts and jut out into Jamaica Bay, is unusual enough in New York City. But Denis Macrae, a 61-year-old photographer and avid birdwatcher who moved there from Brooklyn 20 years ago, goes a step beyond unusual.

title: The He Hormone
description: Reading Sullivan's article, I flipped to the end, half-expecting an April Fool's disclaimer. I was instead irritated by Sullivan's anecdotal recountings and wild extrapolations on testosterone's effect on race and patriarchy.

title: Advice to Teenagers Called Helpful to Parents
description: I found the Q & A that appeared on April 2 [''Advice to Teenagers on Date Abuse''] one of the most provocative and helpful articles I've read in a long time. While the issue of domestic violence is highly pervasive in our society, teenagers characteristically feel immune and invulnerable to such a threat.

title: Narrow Abortion Case Before Court Leads to a Wider Debate
description: When the Supreme Court agreed in January to review Nebraska's ban on so-called ''partial-birth abortions,'' the justices made it clear that they were not interested in revisiting the court's precedents that established the constitutional right to abortion. As part of the state's case, Attorney General Don Stenberg of Nebraska had asked for a reconsideration of Roe v. Wade, and the court turned him down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISMAN, MARTHA
description: EISMAN-Martha. On April 20, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Heime. Loving mother of Roberta and Arnold. Dear aunt of Linda Loftus. She will be profoundly missed and will always be in our hearts. Service Sunday, 2 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Other Buzz Caused By Bill and Hillary
description: The article ''The Buzz That Comes With Bill and Hillary'' on April 9 missed another kind of buzz that neither the writer nor the Clintons may be aware of.

title: The He Hormone
description: Interesting article by Andrew Sullivan. However, it seemed to me to be one more way of telling us that we are not responsible for our actions -- to say, in effect, that testosterone made me do it. I reject the implication that we are helpless pawns of our hormones. Sullivan describes losing his temper in the park. I understand he was surprised by his reaction to the testosterone shots. But if he does it a second time, then he is responsible. We don't have to act on every feeling we have.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALBERA, VIRGINIA
description: BALBERA-Virginia. Eight years gone, never forgotten. Always in our hearts. Irwin, Stefanie, Gregg & family

title: The Latest Soundtrack To Spring
description: If you were locked in an underground cave, with no sunlight, clock or DSL lines, and the sole contact you had with the outside world was a radio that could receive only Casey Kasem's ''American Top 40'' countdown, how would you know what time of year it was?

title: Dune
description: BEING DEAD

title: Federal Welfare Overhaul Allows Albany to Shift Money Elsewhere
description: In the four years since the overhaul of the nation's welfare laws, New York has taken at least $1 billion given to it by the federal government for new antipoverty programs and used it instead to indirectly finance huge tax cuts and other programs that appeal to middle-class voters, according to government and private estimates.

title: Shakespeare for Young Actors
description: To be or not to be a Shakespearean actor is the question young aspirants can study in the 10-year-old Summer Professional Training Program of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival, which is now accepting applications.

title: Dot-Coms: A Way to Burn Money, or to Fuel the Future?; Winners Always Get Out in Time
description: Does the start-up machinery of the new economy inevitably yield wasteful companies, doomed to flame out after their early backers cash in? A dot-com chief executive and a prominent venture capitalist argue the point.

title: A Walk in the Woods, With Eyes Newly Opened
description: AS I wander the woods in Maryland these days, I find myself bending down to admire tiny little flowers I never noticed before, counting petals, noting the shapes of leaves.

title: The Devils Speak Softly About Their Next Series
description: Expressing preference between two teams has never been the policy of coaches and players in any sport because they know any statements can fire a team up.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE DREAMHOUSE

title: Popov's Loyalty to Russian Ways Comes at an Immeasurable Price
description: Aleksandr Popov was talking about his wife and young son, about the demands of being a new International Olympic Committee member and about struggling to find the motivation to keep pulling his long, lean, extraordinarily supple body out of bed and through the water well before dawn. And as he talked about the changes in his life and his attitude on the terrace of a hotel in this mountain resort, he calmly brushed away fly after fly.

title: Beware the Side Effects Of Spraying Pesticides
description: The article ''Mounting Big Defenses Against Tiny Pests'' [April 9] tells only part of the story. The consequences of exposure to insecticides is much greater than the slight chance of ever contracting encephalitis, even if bitten by an infected mosquito.

title: Sports of The Times; Again This Spring, the Knicks Are Impinging on Baseball's Time
description: SOMEBODY, please tell the Knicks to either be very good or very brief. They and their entire league are indulging in their annual habit of getting interesting just when it is time to go outdoors and sniff the pollen.

title: The He Hormone
description: I think that many women, including feminists, would be happy to accept and celebrate the biological differences between the sexes and move on, but not until writers of articles like this stop repeating the same old sexist claptrap: that maleness is the desirable norm, while femaleness is a ''disadvantage'' and an inadequacy to be medicated.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Brent Sterling Nemetz; Video's Studs Terkel
description: BRENT STERLING NEMETZ has perfected the art of hanging from cables on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and climbing backward up the ladder in the Statue of Liberty's arm, all the while asking questions and shooting from a Sony video camera. Wednesday night found him going the wrong way down the stairs from the 110th floor of the World Trade Center, Tower No. 2, looking for the night's interview subject, Samantha Hue, a tour guide at the observation deck.

title: The Nation: The Lock and Load Myth; A Disarming Heritage
description: IN the rancorous national debate over gun control, both sides assume that America's earliest experiences with guns shaped the modern American character. Where they differ is on whether Americans should embrace their frontier heritage and reliance on guns, or resist it.

title: A Carter Is Convicted
description: A jury in White Plains has found Stephen DiSalvo, president of A. & S. DiSalvo Company, guilty of second-degree grand larceny for dumping trash from the company's private customers at the town of Ossining's expense.

title: High Fidelity
description: LET IT BLURT

title: More Access to the Sound at Kings Park
description: VISITORS to Long Island's newest state park will find little has changed since the site was part of a psychiatric institution. But the trees, rolling meadows, waterfront vistas and imposing buildings that characterize the property will go under a different name.

title: Food; By Bread Alone
description: How the modern epicure swoons for the yeasty aroma, firm crust and dense honeycomb texture of a good loaf of bread. But is it the full wheat flavor or what the loaf represents that has made ''old-fashioned'' or ''artisan'' bread the rallying point of good taste?

title: Pushing Tulips And Pulling Roots
description: Tulips require at least six hours of sun a day and good drainage. Small flowers are a sign of inadequate light or nutrition. Mulch with compost or well-rotted manure in fall, or apply high-nitrogen fertilizer in spring just as shoots emerge. Foliage provides nutrition for next year's flowers and must be left, unbraided and untied, to die back naturally.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: England, England

title: MUSIC; A Celebration of Diversity Through Performing Arts
description: WHEN the Grammy-winning jazz musician Paquito D'Rivera led 13 other musicians and vocalists representing nine countries to the rhythms of three cultures below the towering triptych stained glass windows in Westminster Hall at Bloomfield College this month, it was more than just a free two-hour concert.

title: Sierra Club Sues Hawaii On Tourism Promotion
description: IN a move that shocked the Hawaii tourist industry and caused jitters among tourist officials on the mainland, the Sierra Club has sued the Hawaii Tourism Authority in the Hawaii Supreme Court. The suit, filed Jan. 11, seeks to force the state agency to perform a statewide environmental assessment, which it claims is required by law, before allocating $114 million to the Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau for marketing and promotion.

title: Ideas & Trends; Snooping's Not Just For Spies Any More
description: NOT so long ago, it seems, nations were able to hide their armaments, misdeeds and fortresses from the eyes of nosy civilians, while militaries could pry into most corners of the globe from spy satellites, knowing they could control who could take a peek.

title: Meals That Zing With a Caribbean Flair
description: THE buzz continues in New Haven about Roomba. This Caribbean-fusion restaurant has brought tropical excitement to the local dining scene with its snappy flavors and food combinations. As Connecticut taste buds have become jaded with various ethnic onslaughts, Roomba adds a fresh element, a hobnobbing of standard cooking techniques with lively island ingredients and accents. The results can be fun, fanciful, even fantastic.

Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:30 AM, in St. Anthony's Church. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

But Ms. Norman, who has lived in northern Westchester since 1987, prides herself on also giving voice to the homeless, the poor and the sick.

title: NUDE DANCING BAN
description: North Brunswick Township last week became the first municipality in New Jersey to prohibit nudity in business establishments, thereby banning nude and topless go-go dancing. The ordinance was based on one in Erie, Pa., that was upheld recently by the United States Supreme Court. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Optimistic Pricing Can Be Realistic, Too
description: SO what are technology stocks worth? The short answer -- more today than a week ago, in the wake of their alarming slide -- is unsatisfying. And if investors are reassured by the rebound last week, the question of how to value technology companies is likely to remain important for some time. These are the companies, after all, that led the stock market's long climb and are responsible for so much economic growth.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: MAKING LOVE TO THE MINOR POETS OF CHICAGO By James Conrad. St. Martin's, $25.95.

title: The Ballad of Woody Guthrie
description: HAL ASHBY'S 1976 film biography of the militant singer-composer Woody Guthrie, ''Bound for Glory,'' misses critics' four-star ranking by a fraction, which isn't bad for a film with some weaknesses to go along with its considerable strengths. Ashby, who died at age 59 in 1988 and whose credits include ''Harold and Maude'' (1971), ''Shampoo'' (1975) and ''Being There'' (1979), had a feeling for quirky characters. Guthrie, played with a lanky, languid grace by David Carradine, is more paragon than quirk, but the performance is strong and unusual enough to carry the film even when the narrative occasionally fails it.

title: April 16-22; Bad News on Fiber
description: For nearly 30 years, many doctors and most of the public have believed that high-fiber diets prevent colon cancer. But now two studies involving thousands of people randomly assigned to eat either high-fiber diets or their normal diets failed to find that the high-fiber diets protected against polyps, which are tiny lumps in the colon that precede many colon cancers.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, an article on April 9 about the play ''Copenhagen'' misspelled a theory formulated by the physicist Niels Bohr. It is complementarity, not complimentarity.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Dining Out column last Sunday added a word to the name of the restaurant under review. It is Eastchester Fish Gourmet, not Jennifer's Eastchester Fish Gourmet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, SHIRLEY R.
description: BRANDT-Shirley R. Passed away March 27 after a long illness. Daughter of the late David and May Brandt. Sister of Dorothy Brandt and the late Helen B. Marshall and Louis E. Marshall, M.D. Aunt of Jessica and Jerold Tepper, David B. Marshall, M.D., and Roberta Marshall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICKDYKE, BERNADETTE
description: LICKDYKE-Bernadette. Of Morris Township, on Wednesday, April 19, 2000. Survivors include five nephews and two nieces. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the visitation, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Madison Memorial Home, 159 Main St., Madison. A Funeral Mass will be offered at 10 AM, on Tuesday, at St. Thomas More Church, Convent Station. Interment to follow at St. Vincent's Cemetery, Madison.

title: Newtown Vows to Fight Prison Expansion
description: A NEED to expand the state's prisons to accommodate a burgeoning criminal population is arousing an alarming sense of deja vu in Newtown. The Connecticut Department of Correction said that with the number of inmates growing 22 percent since 1995, from 14,246 to 17,443 now, the state simply needs more jail cells and putting some of them in Newtown could be one of the options.

title: Nassau Budget Talks With State Overseer
description: Nassau County officials are to meet Wednesday to review plans to close this year's deficit, which a Wall Street executive appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki estimated last week at $117 million.

title: Camera Chain Opens A Flagship, Not Just a Store
description: Wolf Camera, a photography chain based near Atlanta with more than 700 stores across the country, opened its second store in New York, at 120 East 86th Street (between Park and Lexington Avenues), on April 4. The showroom has a dark blue floor, ramps between levels, spotlights, and glass showcases for the cameras, all of which remind one faintly of the Hall of Gems at the American Museum of Natural History.

description: THE prospects seemed bright when the Internet was recently introduced in a remote part of the mountainous Cotopoxi region in Ecuador. Under the guidance of aid workers, Quichua-speaking peasants planned to gather crop information and sell their crafts over the Web.

description: The more Americans know about the world, the more likely they are to favor diplomacy over punitive sanctions in dealing with troublesome foreign countries, a poll has found. Embargoes, they say, not only isolate the nations at which they are aimed but also hurt American business.

title: London's Tiny, but Mighty, Almeida
description: AS a theater reporter for The Times of London wryly wrote the other day, ''The Almeida's bid for world domination progresses apace''; and that seems no great exaggeration. Right now, the tiny but hungry playhouse is reaching out from mission control in North London to colonize a bit of East London, a bit of Central London, eventually a bit of New York, and, if NASA ever opens up the planetary system to space thespians, one day no doubt bits of the Moon or Mars or both.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TASHKOVICH, VIRGINIA (NEE HARLOW)
description: TASHKOVICH-Virginia (nee Harlow). On April 14, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Gligor and stepmother of the late Vuko and Otto, loving mother-in-law of Stefanie and Cassandre and grandmother of Felicia, Mark and Gligor Tashkovich. Known professionally as Virginia Harlow, she had a long career as an interior decorator. She brought a sense of integrity to her work. The rooms she created were warm and welcoming. She was an elegant woman and a trustworthy friend. She enjoyed witty conversation, visits with young children, games of bridge and Scrabble and long walks in Pound Ridge. We will all miss her kindess. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Tashkovich Scholarship Fund, Office of University Development, 55 Brown Road, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850-1247.

title: Wrigley Is Old-Fashioned, But Packed With Panache
description: They call this area Wrigleyville, and fans swarmed here on opening day on April 10 to see the ballpark that remains a symbol of old-fashioned baseball.

title: Gaffney Asks $20 Million For Low-Cost Housing
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, has proposed spending $20 million to buy sites for low-cost housing and turn them over to towns and villages, which could then pass the sites to not-for-profit groups that would build houses for first-time owners. The plan, which is intended to revitalize commercial areas while curtailing sprawl, needs approval from the legislature.

title: Rapping in Whiteface (for Laughs)
description: MC PAUL BARMAN, a 25-year-old Brown University graduate from Ridgewood, N.J., is pioneering a new hip-hop persona: the rapper as schlemiel. On Mr. Barman's debut EP, ''It's Very Stimulating,'' we meet a character unlike the heavies, braggarts and smooth lotharios who normally narrate rap songs -- a white, Jewish, Woody Allenesque neurotic who is nerdy, girl crazy and sexually hapless. ''My sex life is pathetic,'' Mr. Barman announces at the record's outset. ''That's why I fantasize in four out of five songs.'' The first of those songs, ''The Joy of Your World,'' sets the tone. It is a catalog of self-deprecating ''boasts'' and romantic misadventures: ''I'm pond scum,'' he raps. ''If you want sex with me/ Be prepared for bad sex/ And slapstick.''

title: Poet, Editor, Working Girl
description: In the fief of poetry, where status is a coin of the realm, Knopf is the high castle, the publisher of Modernist leviathans like T. S. Eliot, Ezra Pound and Wallace Stevens and contemporary stars like Philip Levine, W. S. Merwin, Sharon Olds and Mark Strand.

title: Designer's Store Sells Line Developed in India and Israel
description: Six years ago when Lior Nahum was living in Jaipur, India, he began designing and producing his own clothes. After a year in India he returned to his native Israel, where he and a friend cultivated his design ability. Now, after four years in New York, he has created his own line of clothing, Fuchsia, and set up a store by that name Feb. 19 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The clothing, made on McDonald Avenue, includes pants and skirts in vivid reds, pinks, blues and greens. A 24-inch-long red quilted skirt is $60, and a 31-inch olive and orange wrap skirt $55.

description: DARWIN'S GHOST ''The Origin of Species'' Updated. By Steve Jones. 377 pp. New York: Random House. $25.95.

title: Say It in Swedish
description: Throngs of stylish bargain-hunters have been queuing up to shop at Hennes & Mauritz, known as H&M, the new Swedish store at 640 Fifth Avenue, at 51st Street. But the appeal of disposable chic is nothing new to Carina Wretman, a fashion model who grew up outside Stockholm and has been wearing H&M for years. On a recent Tuesday, she stood in line outside the store to check out the new New York branch -- though such waits are unheard of in Sweden. Ms. Wretman later explained that it is the sellout status of certain designs that gives cachet to H&M's mass-produced clothes. ''One good thing about H&M is they keep getting new things,'' she said. ''Even though everyone buys a lot, someone who comes the week after can't get the same thing.''

title: Remember Rees
description: To the Editor:

title: American Histories: Chasing Dreams And Nightmares; In Making Myths, Betraying Our Past
description: MY mother used to tell me that it was a grave sin, perhaps the gravest, to question the interior spiritual life of another human being; it was also a very serious matter to speak ill of the dead. As I sat in my living room watching a tape of the PBS American Experience biography ''George Wallace: Settin' the Woods on Fire,'' which will be shown tonight and tomorrow night, I found myself striving mightily to live up to these instructions, and failing. I was also wondering why I was allowing the filth of Wallace's invective and racist posturing into my home -- the documentary clips are that scalding -- even in the good cause of education.

description: To the Editor:

title: Love Found on the Barricades
description: I FIRST met my fiancee at a political demonstration in Battery Park on a sunny summer afternoon in 1987. We were 15, and little about the meeting indicated romance in the stars. As she recalls it, I rudely brushed her off without a thought. Eight years later, when we met again at a Valentine's Day party in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, I was a little more humble. We've been together ever since.

title: Dot-Com Leaders Await A Shakeout of Losers
description: Jackie Erickson, the customer retention manager for drugstore.com, an online pharmacy, has no problem with the notion that a shakeout is looming in the Internet industry. ''Pretty soon,'' she said, ''the market will separate the men from the boys.''

title: Phoenix: Diversity Blooms in the Desert
description: TEN years ago, fine dining in Phoenix was largely confined to chain restaurants, most of them in frosty air-conditioned malls. Aside from a batch of scorching Tex-Mex chili parlors, the food in this shimmering city in the sand was as flat as a bus ride to Yuma. Or as one local culinary writer put it, ''Back then, people here thought free-range chicken was something you didn't have to pay for.''

description: Tonia Hilary David and Steven Sinatra, lawyers in Manhattan, were married yesterday. Dr. Bob Kaufman, the interim senior leader of the Ethical Culture Society in Manhattan, officiated at Manhattan Penthouse.

title: Business; State Castoffs Are Going, Going, Gone, on the Internet
description: FOR a year and a half, Massachusetts officials tried and failed to dispose of a 128-foot lightship, the Nantucket I, most recently used as a floating museum. ''This was something we couldn't give away,'' said Paul Guerino, coordinator of the state's surplus property.

description: Shares of Yahoo may have fallen from a high of 240 on Dec. 31 to barely half that level last week, but the company's fans are as confident as ever in its future.

description: KIPNESS-Dorothy, 96, a very special woman of valor. Will always be cherished by those she touched. -Her Loving Family

description: AT Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, patients can enjoy a live midday classical music concert between chemotherapy treatments. In Newport Beach, Calif., Dr. George Brennan, a dermatologist, sells his skin-care creams out of his office. At a hospital on Long Island, nurses are learning how to massage premature babies, a skill they will pass on to new parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, DR. SHERWOOD B. ''WOODY''
description: SLATER - Dr. Sherwood B. ''Woody'', Assistant Executive Director of the Joseph L. Morse Geriatric Center, died Thursday, April 20, 2000. He was 63. Dr. Slater served as Associate Executive Vice President of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, and was a social scientist with the World Health Organization. Dr. Slater was born in Bronx, NY. He is survived by his wife Carol; his sister Rosalind Horodi of Israel; his son Steven (Monica) Slater of Maryland; daughter Beth (David) Sokoloff of Virginia; and grandchildren: Rachael and Erica Slater, and Stuart and Harrison Sokoloff. Donations may be made in Dr. Slater's memory to the Joseph L. Morse Geriatric Center, 4847 Fred Gladstone Memorial Drive, West Palm Beach, FL 33417.

title: On Artificial Rarity and Fakery
description: THE market for fine-art photography, an estimated annual $200 million slice of the art business, is bedeviled by a curious paradox. The medium itself tends toward iconic democracy: from one negative hundreds of prints can be made, all identical if need be and, in theory, of equal value. The art market, on the other hand, operates by a much older, aristocratic set of rules: an elite caste of images and objects are elevated above others of their class as collectible art. Only when people believe they are buying rare or one-of-a-kind things will they pay exorbitant prices to own them.

title: Streetscapes/AT&T Headquarters at 195 Broadway; A Bellwether Building Where History Was Made
description: WE didn't find anything that was in keeping with its history,'' said John Heath, a spokesman for AT&T, explaining its decision, which became known last week, not to move its signature Golden Boy statue back to Manhattan.

description: No new-economy sector has taken a worse smack on the chin than Internet retailers. description: The District of Columbia has agreed to reduce misdemeanor charges against hundreds of protesters arrested in demonstrations against the World Bank to a jaywalking charge and a $5 penalty.

title: In Praise of Urban Landscape
description: THE oil painting of St. Augustine's Church at Sixth Avenue and Sterling Place in Park Slope (shown) was done in 1997 by an artist who walks past the landmark site almost daily. Gregory Frux, 42, is a resident of Park Slope and an architect with a Master of Fine Arts from Brooklyn College. A show of his work from the last five years is at the New Prospect Cafe in Park Slope. The show includes paintings, prints and drawings of the urban landscapes of Brooklyn, from Grand Army Plaza to the Gowanus Canal, including images of classic bronwstone stoops, Halloween trick or treaters, the emerald canal waters and night views of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Opposites With Much in Common
description: EDGARD VARESE and Olivier Messiaen were born 25 years apart, in 1883 and 1908, but many accidents brought them together. Since Varese started out late on his public career and Messiaen early, they both made their beginnings as composers in the 1920's. They both spent formative years in southern France, both studied in Paris and were both indelibly influenced by the music they heard there, especially Debussy's orchestral works and the early ballets of Stravinsky. Both were drawn to distant cultures, ancient and exotic. Both loved the sounds of wind instruments and percussion.

title: Not Really a Stretch

title: April 16-22; World Trade Officals Vow Effort to Fight Aids
description: Some 50 million poor people in developing nations are infected with the AIDS virus, and the number is rising so quickly that the disease has become a leading impediment to economic development in Africa and South Asia. That's the way the World Bank sees it. After a spring strategy session in Washington, world finance ministers endorsed a World Bank plan to spend ''unlimited money'' to finance programs to prevent the spread of AIDS and treat its victims in poor countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LILLIAN
description: BERMAN-Lillian. On April 21, 2000. Survived by two sons, seven grandchildren and eleven great grandchildren. She had a long and productive life. In lieu of flowers donations to Cabrini Hospice in her name would be appreciated. Services private.

title: Alexander H. Cohen, Producer of 101 Theatrical Hits and Flops, Dies at 79
description: Alexander H. Cohen, one of the last old-time independent theatrical producers, who produced 101 shows on Broadway and in London's West End and originated the national Tony Awards telecast in 1967, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: A Sampling of What's Hot in Flower Fashion
description: THE Philadelphia Flower Show is to flowers what fashion week in New York is to cloth. Every year in Philadelphia thousands of blossoms coalesce into a medium that transmits a message of fashion and fantasy, with a little technology thrown in as an accent. Given the enormous number of lilies, hyacinths and other spring flowers on display, the message floats around the Pennsylvania Convention Center on a wave of glorious fragrance.

title: Barbara Manfrey, John Vogelstein
description: Barbara Louise Manfrey, a director of Apax Partners & Company, a London-based venture capital firm, was married yesterday to John L. Vogelstein, the president and vice chairman of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, the venture capital firm in New York. Justice John T. Buckley of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the couple's home in New York.

Their quarry is too coy and would slip under the surface at the slightest disturbance. Sitting patiently in towers set up near areas where seals haul themselves out of the water, watching from boats offshore or studying film made during aerial surveys, these counters are taking part in a long-term census and monitoring of the seal population in Long Island Sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MARTA
description: GREENE-Marta. The members of the board and staff of Scenic Hudson, Inc. remember with affection the exemplary service, loyalty and wit of our beloved board member Marta Greene. Her unwavering support and commitment to Scenic Hudson over many years have been a source of inspiration to all her colleagues. Our hearts are with her beloved husband, Thurston.

title: In Japan, Start-Up and Risk Are New Business Watchwords
description: Starting this week, music fans across Japan will be stepping up to a gadget that resembles a souped up, stand-alone automated teller, plugging in a blank minidisk, dropping in some coins and, 30 to 40 seconds later, walking away with their favorite recordings. title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; The Terrain of Memory
description: The rough landscape of northern Ontario takes on universal dimensions in SUMMER GONE (Crown, $23), David Macfarlane's expertly controlled first novel. A divorced magazine editor in Toronto named Bay Newling heads north with his 12-year-old son into the territory of summer memory. On a canoe trip together, Bay reaches back to his own youthful confusion and tells his resistant son about the woodsy metaphysics of a boys' camp he attended in 1964. Gently, as with a fine ghost story, Bay's complicated past is lived and relived from different points on a shadowy timeline. The pain of lost innocence ripples through this remarkable novel. A lone instance of infidelity troubles the middle-aged protagonist in ways that illustrate the price of lust, and the eroding splendor of the Canadian wilderness reflects the greed of reckless developers. Yet the book wears its themes lightly. Macfarlane animates ''Summer Gone'' with exacting descriptions of natural life (''branches as fine and dark as cracks in old china''). The novel's language -- perfectly tuned to guilt, responsibility and transcendence -- evokes the freshwater lakes and rivers that the characters navigate. Stories-within-stories gather force like tributaries. Finishing ''Summer Gone'' leaves the reader with a sense of loss -- not only the loss that inheres in Bay Newling's quiet tragedy, but the loss of the narrator's good company upon reaching the final page. Katherine Wolff

title: Camby's Harsh Words Come During Game

After the second one, a jumper from the top of the key, he looked toward the Toronto bench, glowering and mouthing words. While the expressions and the words seemed ill-tempered, Camby was careful after the game to guard his remarks.

title: Strength Through Restraint
description: With Elian Gonzalez reunited with his father, the nation has begun an important debate about the government's handling of the case, especially the forcible seizure of the Cuban boy by heavily armed federal agents before dawn on Saturday. Few actions in recent times have so powerfully drawn the attention of Americans to the exercise of authority by the federal government, a fundamental issue in the governance of a democracy. The Justice Department acted rashly and unwisely in ordering the raid, and its decisions now require the most careful evaluation by Congress and the American people.

title: Playing in Two Seats at Once? Well, Maybe Not Quite, but . . .
description: Four decades ago Rixi Markus, who won several world titles representing first Austria and then Britain, announced during a championship, ''On this deal I made a slam in both rooms.'' She was unable to prove this remarkable claim, but something comparable was managed at the Forbo Team tournament in the Netherlands in February by Bill Eisenberg, who has won several world titles for the United States. On the diagramed deal he claimed for both the defense and the declarer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, BERNARD
description: FEIN-Bernard. Born July 11, 1932, died April 22, 2000. Beloved husband and best friend of Carol (Rosenberg) Fein. Devoted son of Mollie Fein. Loving father of Neil and Michele (Fein) Weinman and dear son-in-law Mark, and like a second father to Jacky Fein. Adored ''PA'' to granddaughter Alyssa Joelle Weinman. Caring brother-in-law to Phyllis and Stephen Stolar and loving uncle to their children. A graduate of City College of New York and Brooklyn Law School. Recipient of the 1972 Good Scout Award and the 1986 Silver Beaver Award of the Greater New York Council of Boy Scouts of America-Construction Industry Division. He was affiliated for 43 years with the Rudin Management Company as a Vice President. He was a Hadassah Associate. Donations in his memory may be made to the Fair Lawn Chapter of Hadassah, 10-10 Norma Ave, Fair Lawn, NJ 07410, designated for Melanoma Research at Hadassah Hospital Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURAD, RACHEL
description: MURAD-Rachel. Beloved mother of six; cherished grandmother of 11 and adored great-grandmother of 20. Passed away on April 20, 2000. Rachel was born in 1906 in Baghdad and immigrated to NYC in 1946. She was married for 74 years to Albert Murad who preceded her in death in 1996. Her memory will be cherished and her legacy to all who knew her was her strength of character and desire for all to be well. Donations in Rachel's memory would be appreciated to the Albert Murad Educational Fund, Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87th St, NY, NY 10128.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HOWARD S.
description: HARRIS-Howard S. On April 22, 2000, at the age of 57. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Scott. Devoted son of Sidney and Ruth. He chaired the Social Sciences Department at Bronx Community College for the past 20 years and taught psychology for more than 30 years. He was the Vice President for Publications for the Council for Standards in Human Services Education, as well as founder and President of the Metropolitan New York Association of Human Services Education. He was the 1997 recipient of the NOHSE's Lenore McNeer Award for outstanding contributions to Human Services Profession. He was a trustee and President of the Yonkers School Board and had assumed a wide range of leadership roles in faculty organizations, the Professional Staff Congress/CUNY, education, community service and environmental advocacy. He directed projects funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities, the New York State Council for the Humanities, and the National Institutes of Health. He co-edited, Human Services: Contemporary Issues and Trends, first and second editions. Howard also played four wall handball, the ''perfect game.'' Services Tuesday, 12 PM, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERLING, CLIFFORD
description: STERLING-Clifford. Age 41, artist and nature enthusiast, died at home in New York, on April 16. Devoted and beloved husband of Ann. Dear son of Enid and Abraham (deceased), brother of Adam and Benjamin. A memorial recepetion for family and friends will be held on Friday, April 28, from 68 PM, at the Parish House of the Church of St. Luke in the Fields, 487 Hudson St, NYC. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Mohonk Preserve, Inc., PO Box 715, New Paltz, NY 12561. He will be remembered and loved always.

title: Little Havana Ponders Life Without Cuban Boy Cast in Its Anti-Castro Drama
description: As she always does on Sunday, Amelia Rodriguez, 82, went to church today. But this time, as she lighted a candle and made the sign of the cross in a landmark church in the heart of this city's Cuban-American community, she asked a special favor of God: to watch over Elian Gonzalez, the 6-year-old Cuban boy whose removal from the Little Havana home of his relatives by federal agents shook the community to its core.

title: As Carter Falls, McGrady Rises for Raptors
description: When reporters entered the Toronto Raptors' locker room and descended on a smiling Vince Carter before the game, the locker next to him was conspicuously empty. Tracy McGrady did not need the attention. He needed to give himself a pep talk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, PATRICIA MOTLOW BOYD
description: MARTIN-Patricia Motlow Boyd. Of Dallas, died April 20, 2000. Mrs. Martin was born on January 13, 1941. She was a founding officer of General Cryogenics. She is survived by her husband, Patrick Stephen Martin; a daughter, Evans Motlow Smith Martin; her mother, Mary Motlow Boyd of Lexington, Kentucky; two sisters, Betty Boyd Kinkead of Lexington and Judith Boyd Terjen of Virginia Beach; one brother, James Robert Boyd of Lexington. She was predeceased by her father, James Clinton Boyd. Mrs. Martin was a graduate of the Holton-Arms School, Washington, D.C., Bradford Junior College and the University of Mississippi where she was a member of Kappa Kappa Gamma. Memorial donations may be sent to University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas, c/o Development Office for Caroline Muller, M.D., Dept of Gynecologic Oncology, 5323 Harry Hines Blvd, Dallas, Texas 75235-8889.

title: Life After the Dead, With Affection but Not Deference
description: Phil Lesh was the Grateful Dead's self-effacing bassist. He kept his bass lines tucked under the Dead's guitars, keyboards and voices; he wrote only a few songs, usually sang harmonies and didn't record with his own band on the side. As the leader of Phil Lesh and Friends he's still an ensemble player, ignoring the spotlight. But he's definitely doing something right. On Wednesday night at the Beacon Theater, Phil Lesh and Friends played Dead songs and jams that rivaled the Grateful Dead in their prime.

title: Decrepit Station Houses Erode Police Morale, Officers Say

For the 6-foot-3-inch Childs, that meant the defensive rebound belonged to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINSMORE, ARTHUR H.
description: DINSMORE-Arthur H., 88, of Tarrytown, New York, died on April 7, 2000 while visiting his daughter, in San Diego, California. A 1933 graduate of Lafayette College, he worked in the insurance business all of his life, and at the time of his death was connected with Hagendorn & Co. in New York City. He was pre-deceased by his wife, Hazel M. McClarity Dinsmore, and is survived by one brother, Richard Dinsmore of Malibu, California, two daughters, Diane Schroeder of San Diego, California, Judith Coppola, of Bisbee, Arizona, two grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, three nieces and three nephews. A scholarship has been set up at Lafayette College, ''In the memory of Arthur H. Dinsmore''. Please send donations to the attention of Susan Bradlau, Lafayette College, 307 Markle Hall, Easton, Pennsylvania 18042.

title: Man or Woman? Final Answer?
description: Hoping to get more women as contestants, the hit ABC television quiz show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire has begun asking people who call its contestants' hotline to identify themselves as men or women. Reporters for The New York Times called the hotline 41 times to see if there were gender differences in the questions. Many were similar -- history, literature, famous names and phrases -- but there were some differences. title: Guys With No Class but a Lotta Fun. Nyuk! Nyuk!
description: The Three Stooges (all six of them) were lucky. That luck lifted their infectious slapstick from the fringes of vaudeville to the fringes of Hollywood, where they found steady work churning out ragged two-reel shorts. The Stooges were merely a footnote to a vanished era when their luck kicked in again, flinging them from retirement to the fringes of television, which gobbled up the films as cheap fare to distract baby boomers from their homework.

title: No Headline
description: A front-page article last Monday about the shortage of primary-care doctors in New York City's poorest neighborhoods referred to a clinic in the Bronx run by Dr. Hoi Yat Kam, describing it as cramped and unkempt. Dr. Kam was given an opportunity to comment on the depiction of his practice, but his response was omitted in editing. Dr. Kam, one of the few private doctors in the South Bronx willing to accept Medicaid patients, says he cannot afford renovations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODEL, JOSEPH
description: MODEL-Joseph. Beloved husband of Annabelle. Loving father of Bennett and Roberta. Dear grandfather of Summer, Brett, Tierney and Albert. Loving brother of Mark. The President for 15 years of the Fur Center Synagogue. He received numerous awards from B'nai Brith, the UJA and the ADL. Received the highest civilian award given by the State of Israel (the Prime Minister's Medal). Served in World War II, landing on Omaha Beach and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Received a battlefield commission to 1st Lieutenant and received many other citations. He will live in the hearts of his family and all the people who loved him.

title: Ballot Reform in Albany
description: The New York State Senate's approval last week of a ballot reform plan that would knock down the state's notorious obstacles to getting candidates on the Republican presidential primary ballot was a significant breakthrough for fair and open elections. Just two months ago the prime author of the legislation, Gov. George Pataki, was busy manipulating ballot rules to try to keep Senator John McCain from competing in the state. Now, working with the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, the governor has begun to make amends. But the battle for reform is not yet over. The measure must still be approved by the Democratic-led Assembly. It is now largely up to the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, to make sure presidential ballot-rigging is made a thing of the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINSON, LUCINDA PINA
description: WILKINSON-Lucinda Pina. April 21, 2000. Age 61, died peacefully April 21 at her home in Manhattan of breast cancer, which she had been fighting for the last two years. Born in Madrid, Spain, Luly received her master's degree in physical chemistry from the University of Madrid and studied at Oxford University and the University of Geneva. Continuing her education in the U.S. Luly attended Harvard University and met her husband while attending Mary Baldwin College in Virginia. She performed research in the field of molten salts using nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometry at the University of Virginia from 1964-1966. She and her family moved to New York in 1969. From 1977 to 1987 Luly taught Spanish grammar and literature at the Brearley School. Luly was a fixture on the Upper East Side, well known by many for her beloved Labrador Retrievers: Powhattan, Amelia and Augusta, who she enjoyed walking daily. She was involved in student affairs at the Collegiate, St. Bernard's and Brearley Schools, which her children attended. Nothing gave her more pleasure than the children's summer swimming races at the Lawrence Beach Club on Atlantic Beach, Long Island. As the family grew and children moved from home, Luly was instrumental in gathering every member, including additions through marriages and births, for memorable birthdays and holidays at a country home in Oxford, Maryland. Luly was proud of her heritage. Her Spanish family was instrumental in advancing education for women. Her grandfather founded the first co-ed, non-sectarian private school in Spain in the 1920's. Luly's parents were both Olympic athletes in the Republic of Spain in the 1930's. Luly shared their love for the mountains and skiing, a passion she continued to pursue with her husband and children. Her favorite family destination for over 20 years was the pistes in Klosters, Switzerland. Luly was known for her Castillian determination and her contagious smile that inspired everyone around her. She was loved by many and will be missed all the more. Luly is survived by her husband, Donald McLean Wilkinson, her children Donald McLean Wilkinson III and his wife, Lauren Doyle Wilkinson, of Manhattan, Duncan Austin Wilkinson of Arlington, Virginia, Charles Carroll Wilkinson of Dallas, Texas, and Margot Carolina Wilkinson Kaye and her husband Jason Philip Kaye of Fort Collins, Colorado, and her grandchildren Donald McLean Wilkinson IV and Ian James Wilkinson of Manhattan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81 St on Monday, the 24th of April 4-8 PM. There will be a Requiem Mass at 11AM on Tuesday the 25th of April at St. Thomas More Church in New York and she will be interred at the historic Hollywood Cemetery in Richmond, Virginia with a burial service at 11AM on Friday the 28th of April. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in her memory to a needy church, Santa Rita, 448 College Avenue, Bronx, N Y. 10451.

title: Trills and Rolls in a Mysterious World of His Own
description: In describing Evan Parker's music, sooner or later you're going to use a circle metaphor -- a wheel, a mandala, a spiral. For 35 years he's been rigorously attached to a particular kind of soprano saxophone language, one more or less of his own devising. In it the normal jazz-improviser's code of conversational broken phrases is discarded in favor of long, continuous statements; Mr. Parker uses the technique of circular breathing, and can blow without pausing for 20 minutes or more. But rather than droning, he gives you bunches of notes that come stippled with ornament, making low tones and high overtones collide, trilling them and rolling them together so closely into line that he sounds as if he's playing two instruments at once.

The company, based in Madison, Ga., owns Hops Restaurant Bar Brewery, Don Pablo's Mexican Kitchen, Canyon Cafe Southwestern Grill as well as McCormick and Schmick's restaurants. title: A Vietnam Premonition
description: As the nation reflects this week on the meaning of the Vietnam War 25 years after the fall of Saigon, a few fateful words of Lyndon Johnson's tumble across the decades to remind us that a senseless conflict might have been avoided. On a May morning in 1964, as Johnson was weighing whether to expand American military involvement in Vietnam, he confided in a conversation with Senator Richard Russell that he did not really know why Washington should go to war in Southeast Asia. Referring to Sgt. Kenneth Gaddis, who was one of his valets, Johnson said he was troubled by the idea of sending this father of six children to war. ''And what the hell are we going to get out of his doing it?'' Johnson asked himself. ''And it just makes the chills run up my back.''
