title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, GERALD
description: AUERBACH-Gerald. We mourn the loss of this dear friend and Director of MDA's Television Production Division. An extraordinarily talented film and television director and producer, Jerry created his first film for the Association in 1956. He produced thousands of educational videos during some forty-five years of helping the family's MDA serves-many of which were featured on and contributed to the success of the Jerry Lewis MDA Telethon. For decades, Jerry traveled the country each year to create the Telethon profiles of families served by MDA that brought an intimate, warmly human dimension to MDA's appeals. Many of his profiles were so powerful that pledge phones from coast to coast were jammed following their airing. Similarly, Jerry created for MDA some of the most impactful TV public service announcements ever seen, and educational video material that informed physicians and their patients alike, and inspired tremendous volunteer support of MDA throughout the nation. Jerry's indefatigable creative genius has immeasurabely advanced the battle against neuromuscular diseases. Millions affected by these progressive disorders worldwide are in his debt. Jerry's unparalleled productions played a key role in MDA being honored by the American Medical Association with a Lifetime Achievement Award ''for significant and lasting contributions to the health and welfare of humanity''. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Elaine, and to their four children. Jerry Lewis, National Chairman Robert Bennett, President Robert Ross, Executive Director Jerry Weinberg, Director of Field Organization Muscular Dystrophy Association

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMPSON, HILLES MORRIS
description: TIMPSON-Hilles Morris, on April 23, 2000, after a long illness. Mrs. Timpson was born in Quogue in 1907, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish Morris. She was a direct descendant of Martin Van Buren, 8th President of the United States, and of Lewis Morris, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. A permanent resident of Southampton since 1978, she became a member of the summer community in the 1920's. Mrs. Timpson committed a great deal of her time and resources to the well being of children and animals and she served for many years as a board member and was a pastpresident of the Southampton Fresh Air Home. Mrs. Timpson was married to L. Gordon Hamersley who died in 1942. She was also married to George L. Bartlett and Robert C. L. Timpson who are deceased. Pre-deceased by her son, James Hooker Hamersley, she is survived by the children of her first marriage, L. Gordon Hamersley, Jr., Stuyvesant M. Hamersley, and Hilles Martin. She also leaves nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Graveside services and interment in Quogue will be private. Those who wish to do so may make memorial contributions to the Southampton Fresh Air Home or to the Animal Rescue Fund.

description: International Specialty Products Inc. has added a sweetener to its bid to acquire the Dexter Corporation for $50 a share.

title: 500 Years Later, Brazil Looks Its Past in the Face
description: It was envisioned as a feel-good patriotic festival like the American Bicentennial. But the Brazilian government should have known that its plans to mark the 500th anniversary of the landing of the Portuguese were doomed when an irate Indian chief marched into Congress earlier this month, drew his bow and arrow and threatened to kill the Senate president.

title: Bioprospecting Deal Gains in Yellowstone
description: In a decision that could give a boost to ''bioprospecting'' in national parks, a federal judge has upheld a precedent-setting agreement in which a biotechnology company will pay Yellowstone National Park for the right to search its geysers and hot springs for commercially valuable microbes.

title: High-Risk Areas
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Islander Sale Expected Today
description: Barring an unforeseen problem, the sale of the Islanders to Charles Wang and Sanjay Kumar for $185 million to $190 million is expected to be announced today.

title: Our Towns; Florio Carries Big Baggage And a Lead
description: THE motorcycle club meeting was a collection of Harley hats and shaved heads, a suit jacket or two amid much leather, and one head of chemically assisted bright red hair. One sticker on the wall read ''Support the Clinton Agenda,'' the C made into a hammer and sickle. Another read, ''I'm a motorcyclist and I vote.'' The evening's featured speaker had an old boxing scar on his left cheek and brushed-back black hair, and wore a black mock-turtleneck shirt and dark pants.

title: Senior PGA Tour To Switch Networks
description: After 18 years on ESPN, the Senior PGA Tour will move to CNBC, the business channel, next year. It is a strange move, to leave the comfort of an all-sports cable network for one that carries no sports on a regular basis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, LILLIAN
description: ROTH-Lillian. On Monday, April 24, 2000. Beloved mother of Stanley Roth and his wife Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Lori Schnadig, Jodi Wasserstein & Steven Roth. Great grandmother of Jennifer, Michael and Matthew. Services 3PM Thursday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Keep the Meter Running
description: To the Editor:

title: When Illness Is a Blame Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Watching Elian Gonzalez
description: It seems as if the television news divisions just can't get enough of the Elian Gonzalez saga. But, then again, neither can the public.

title: Brendel Traces Connections And Illuminates Transitions
description: In an expansive series at Carnegie Hall last season, the pianist Alfred Brendel showed the breadth of his creative interests, offering chamber music, concertos and recitals, with vocal accompaniment and a poetry reading for good measure. Every engagement can't be a minifestival, though: when Mr. Brendel returned to Carnegie on Monday evening, it was to play a single, conventional recital of sonatas by Haydn, Mozart and Schubert.

title: Drkoop.com May Run Out of Cash This Summer
description: Drkoop.com May Run Out of Cash This Summer

title: New Superintendent at District 1
description: The board of Community School District 1 on the Lower East Side accepted the resignation of SONIA DIAZ-SALCEDO as district superintendent earlier this month and named HELEN C. SANTIAGO, formerly a deputy superintendent in District 9 in the Bronx, as acting superintendent. Dr. Diaz-Salcedo resigned after the district's board decided to not renew her contract, which was to expire in June. The resignation also came shortly after the Board of Education discovered that the district ran a deficit of $1.5 million for the 1998-1999 school year.

title: Take Your Feminism to Work Day
description: TOMORROW, 19 million girls are expected to play hooky from school for a lesson their parents consider even more important. It's the eighth annual Take Our Daughters to Work Day, which was created to give adolescent girls a peek at a limitless future.

title: FINANCING FOR KOREAN TRUSTS
description: In an effort to stabilize its financial industry, the South Korean government will inject billions of dollars in additional public money into two of the nation's three largest investment trust companies, the nation's chief financial regulator said. The decision to provide more financing comes after the government spent three trillion won ($2.7 billion) last year to keep the Korea Investment Trust Company and the Daehan Investment Trust Company afloat. Financial problems at the two investment trusts have worsened because of the Daewoo Group's failure to repay $78 billion of debt. ''The bailout of Korea and Daehan Investment Trusts will be less than seven trillion won,'' said Lee Yong Keun, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission. ''The government has no plans to raise additional public funds for financial reforms.'' Samuel Len

title: Camby Suit Is Dropped
description: ''It's over,'' Butch Carter said with a nod at the end of today's practice, signaling the end of his five-day legal crusade against Marcus Camby.

title: Campaign Briefing
description: THE REPUBLICANS

title: WOLSELEY SELLS UNITS
description: A British building-materials distributor, Wolseley P.L.C., sold most of its manufacturing businesses for about $215 million to the British buyout firm Cinven Group Ltd. Proceeds from the sale will be used to help finance acquisitions within Wolseley's core building-distribution activities. Wolseley will sell the agricultural, cable management, industrial, motor and photographic businesses of its manufacturing division. The company will hold onto its energy businesses.

title: Live by Bread Alone? Worth a Try
description: FOCACCIA is to the Liguria region of Italy as soft, salted pretzels are to New York: it's a street snack. In Portofino and Camogli near Genoa, for example, big squares of the flat bread, slathered with verdant local olive oil and seasoned with garlic and herbs, are sold by vendors and from storefronts everywhere.

title: U.S. Chamber To Offer Plans Of SunAmerica
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce, the largest organization of small businesses, is making a push to increase retirement plans among its members and said yesterday that it was turning to SunAmerica Inc., one of the biggest variable annuity companies, to do the job.

title: Considering Abortion and Gay Scouts
description: There were encouraging signs yesterday that a majority of Supreme Court justices are prepared to defend women's health and reproductive freedom against the proliferating bans on a vaguely defined surgical procedure dubbed partial birth abortion. But it was hard to tell from comments by the justices how far the court will go to discourage further attempts by Congress and the states to ban particular abortion procedures or tinker with the still-sound architecture of Roe v. Wade.

title: Editorial Observer; The Murderous Era of George C. Wallace
description: The calculated racism and financial corruption of the George Wallace regime in Alabama has been amply recorded in Dan Carter's 1995 biography, ''The Politics of Rage,'' and in a new two-part television documentary, ''George Wallace: Settin' the Woods on Fire.'' The documentary, broadcast earlier this week as part of the Public Broadcasting Service's ''American Experience'' series, is particularly good on Mr. Wallace's decision to abandon the progressive racial views he espoused in a 1958 campaign for governor and to re-invent himself as a segregationist in time for his successful candidacy in 1962. Mr. Wallace's own daughter, Peggy Wallace Kennedy, even provides an explanation for this cold sacrifice of principle: ''He loved the power.''

title: Heroin and the West
description: To the Editor:

title: Houston and His Defense Can Still Be Distant
description: In the frozen middle of February, Allan Houston received the All-Star stamp of approval as a result of the coaches' vote. He was a certified great, guaranteed to meet all standards of the label, including defense, offense and congeniality.

title: Where the Biscuits Meet the Gravy
description: ONE of the things that brightens the lives of itinerant scribblers like me is breakfast.

title: Collecting Criminal Debt To Raise Defenders' Fees
description: For years, New York State has paid some of the lowest fees in the country to the private lawyers whom criminal courts appoint to represent poor defendants. This has sharply cut the number of experienced lawyers willing to take on such work.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Monday about Elian Gonzalez referred incorrectly to a legal aspect of the raid to seize him. The government did indeed have a search warrant.

title: Juno Online Selects Agency
description: Juno Online Services named Hampel/Stefanides in New York, part of the Envoy Communications Group, to handle its brand account. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $20 million.

title: Grant Unleashes Fighting Words in the Battle of Hype
description: After the heavyweight champion, Lennox Lewis, shadowboxed in his workout at Madison Square Garden Monday, the challenger, Michael Grant, did something unusual yesterday, not to mention risky. He sparred two rounds.

title: Andre Jarrot, 90, Co-Leader Of French Resistance Group
description: Andre Jarrot, a hero of the French Resistance against the occupying Germans in World War II who became a cabinet minister in the 1970's, died on Friday at his home in the Burgundy region of France. He was 90.

title: MANAGEMENT; Business Students Seem to Be Keeping Their Cool
description: Today's stock market chaos has left tomorrow's corporate chieftains curiously unfazed.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Cartier Spruces Up to Show Off Its Jewels in Style
description: When your name is Cartier, you don't worry about stirring with every new breeze in fashion. Still, it is probably about time to freshen up Cartier's landmark store at Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street.

title: ICAHN MAKES BID TO BUY THE REST OF STRATOSPHERE
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn, who already controls an 89.6 percent stake in the Stratosphere Corporation, offered to buy the rest of the casino operator for $44.35 a share, about $9.4 million. Mr. Icahn's offer, which would value the entire company at $90 million, was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The offer values Stratosphere shares at almost twice as much as they are currently trading. Stratosphere shares today rose $2 each, to $23. Stratosphere, based in Las Vegas, is a casino, hotel and entertainment complex. It is centered around the Stratosphere Tower, billed as the tallest free-standing observation tower in the United States.

title: Nets Look To Add Director To Mix
description: Rather than spend the last few weeks searching for a coaching replacement for the soon-to-be-fired Don Casey, Lewis Katz, the Nets' principal owner, instead summoned a group of advisers and confidants throughout the league to aid in the search for a director of basketball operations.

title: Plenty of Reasons to Say, 'Please Pass the Fiber'
description: FIBER has suffered some serious blows in the past year or so. Findings from the Nurses' Health Study published early last year and from two studies announced last week showed that those who consumed the most fiber were no better protected against colon cancer than those who consumed the least.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TISHMAN, MARCIA
description: TISHMAN-Marcia. Mom, it has been 5 years and we think of you every day. Your lessons of love and family survive. Love always, Steven, Andy, Michael and Robert

title: Zoning Revisions Are Widely Supported at Planners' Meeting
description: For city planners, finding common ground on the divisive issue of zoning can be a far-fetched dream.

title: At Last, A Pipe Fitter's Wrench Of Her Own
description: It used to take Nannette Cooper about an hour every morning to curl her hair, put on foundation, eye shadow and lipstick and pick out just the right business suit and three-inch heels for her job as a hotel manager in Tampa, Fla.

title: A LAGARDERE OFFER FOR HACHETTE
description: The big French military contractor and media conglomerate Lagardere made an offer of about $1 billion to buy the one-third of Hachette Filipacchi Medias that it does not already own. Hachette, a French magazine and advertising company, publishes Elle magazine in the United States. Lagardere is offering Hachette shareholders 11 of its shares for every 10 Hachette shares. The move will help Lagardere shore up its nonmilitary interests. Lagardere's chairman, Jean-Luc Lagardere, has said the company intends to invest heavily in the new economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARANOF, GENE
description: BARANOF-Gene. Beloved husband of Iris. Heroic father of Marla and the late Lisa. Brother of Alfred and Ruth Ann. He will be missed by all who loved him and inspired by his courage. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., on Thursday, April 27, 11:45 AM.

title: Bush Showcases Democrats To Bolster Bipartisan Image
description: With four Texas Democrats campaigning at his side, Gov. George W. Bush said today that he was sending a ''signal to America'' about his ability to work across party lines. He allowed the members of Vice President Al Gore's own party to parry Mr. Gore's attacks on the Bush record in Texas.

title: Missile Defense May Have Price Of $60 Billion
description: The Congressional Budget Office estimated today that the cost of building a proposed national missile defense system would be nearly $60 billion.

title: Mayor Says 'Storm Trooper' Reflects Truth in Miami Case
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would not apologize for characterizing the federal agents who seized Elian Gonzalez as ''storm troopers,'' adding that it was ''an appropriate criticism'' directed not at the agents but at President Clinton and Attorney General Janet Reno.

title: Zhdanovo Journal; Intoxicated With Religion (and Quite Literally)
description: There is trouble in the one-room matchbox home of Anatoly Montusov and his wife, Yekaterina, two grizzled middle-aged residents of this mud-road farming village. And, like many families in trouble, they have summoned a priest.

title: Volvo Buying Renault Truck and Bus Unit for $1.5 Billion
description: Volvo of Sweden is acquiring the truck division of the French automaker Renault in a $1.5 billion deal that will create the world's second-largest maker of trucks and buses.

title: Decision on Regulating Coal Ash Is Put Off
description: The Clinton administration staked out a careful middle ground today in a hot environmental debate, postponing for months, if not for years, a decision about putting waste from coal-burning power plants under federal pollution regulations for the first time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Renault to Sell Truck Unit To Volvo and Focus on Cars

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISSANE, LUCILLE PAOLILLO
description: KISSANE-Lucille Paolillo. The administration, staff and Franciscan Missionaries of Mary at St. Francis Hospital, The Heart Center, of Roslyn, mourn the loss of our friend and colleague. As Vice President for Development since 1992, Lucille's talent for building lasting relationships transferred well to her efforts on behalf of the Hospital, guiding a program that raised nearly $50 million and securing the largest single gift of $3 million. Lucille's life was filled with many accomplishments, including being named a 1985 Fulbright scholar. We honor Lucille as a beloved wife, loving mother, devoted daughter and caring sister, aunt, sister-in-law and friend. May she rest in peace.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIAL CORP., Scottsdale, Ariz., a consumer products company, agreed to acquire the Coast soap brand from the Procter & Gamble Co., Cincinnati, the biggest maker of household products in the United States, for an undisclosed amount.

title: CENTRICA TO OFFER PHONE SERVICE
description: As several British utilities seek to expand their businesses into telecommunications, Centrica P.L.C., the main supplier of natural gas, said it would provide mobile and fixed-line telephone services offering Internet access. Centrica will work with Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C., Torch Telecom and Cable and Wireless P.L.C. Its stock rose after the announcement. Alan Cowell

title: Colombia Agrees to Turn Over Territory to Another Rebel Group
description: Hoping to advance peace talks aimed at ending 35 years of fighting, the government of Colombia has agreed to withdraw its troops from a remote but strategically situated northern region and turn the area into a safe haven for the country's second-largest guerrilla group.

title: Metro Business; Bancorps to Merge
description: Hudson River Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cohoes Bancorp for $91.7 million in stock. Hudson River said it would pay 1.185 shares of its common stock for each share of Cohoes .

title: What Joy! A Child Learns to Make Music
description: To the Editor:

title: UNOCAL WILL SHED ITS GRAPHITE AND CARBON BUSINESSES
description: The Unocal Corporation, a California company that explores for oil in Asia, South America and the Gulf of Mexico, plans to shed its graphite and carbon businesses to focus on oil and natural gas drilling. Unocal said it had hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to advise it on a possible sale of Poco Graphite Inc. in Texas and part of its petroleum coke business in Illinois. The businesses Unocal plans to sell have annual sales of $123 million. Unocal had total sales of $6.1 billion last year. The company, based in El Segundo, Calif., agreed in January to sell its fertilizer units to Agrium Inc. of Calgary, Alberta, for $325 million in cash and stock.

title: Erle Cocke Jr., 78, War Hero Who Led American Legion
description: Erle Cocke Jr., a decorated World War II soldier who was the national commander of the American Legion in 1950 and 1951, died on Sunday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 78.

title: Guides for the Perplexed
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about a butcher shop, Pino Prime Meats, on Sullivan Street in Manhattan rushing to fill orders before Easter misidentified the neighborhood. It is SoHo, not Little Italy.

title: City Presents Labor Proposals But Union Says It Is Insulted
description: Seeking to push citywide labor negotiations forward, the Giuliani administration presented its first formal contract proposals yesterday, but the union local that received the proposals, one that represents school safety officers and Housing Authority workers, called the proposals an insult.

title: Doctor Who Carved Initials Gets Probation
description: With the blessing of his victim, a Manhattan obstetrician was granted a plea bargain yesterday that sentences him to five years' probation for carving his initials into the belly of one of his patients after delivering her child. The doctor, Allan Zarkin, 62, will not go to jail, but will be barred from applying for a medical license for five years.

title: With Spotlight on Griffey, Mets Are the Real Stars
description: Bobby Valentine sat behind his desk at Shea Stadium after last night's game, satisfied with his team's ninth successive victory, and talked somewhat wistfully about the Lineup That Never Was.

title: Foundation Ventures Into Cyberspace
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, one of the largest supporters of research on higher education, is about to take a leap into cyberspace. It is hiring an Internet technology expert, IRA H. FUCHS, a Princeton University vice president, to help the foundation find new uses for digital technologies in research, teaching and learning.

title: The Last Advice You'll Need?
description: SELLING a book called ''How to Cook Without a Book'' (Broadway, $25) seems like the publishing equivalent of shooting oneself in the foot. Yet there couldn't be a better title for Pam Anderson's new book. She attempts heroically to give cooks the clues they need to get a meal on the table without dizzying themselves between book and stove.

title: Poverty in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Were We in Vietnam?
description: Twas in another lifetime, full of toil and blood,'' began Bob Dylan's ''Shelter from the Storm'' in 1974, when ''blackness was a virtue, and the road was full of mud.'' The fall of South Vietnam 25 years ago seems to me a scene from another lifetime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBER, FRANCIS J.
description: WERBER-Francis J. April 24, 2000. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York, Tuesday 7-9, Wednesday 3-5 and 79, Thursday 3-5 and 7-9.

title: Microsoft Management Tells Workers There Will Be No Breakup
description: As some industry executives declared that a government move to break up Microsoft could inject new competition into the software business, Microsoft's top management confidently assured its 34,000 employees yesterday that there was no chance the company would be split up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUPONG, WILLIAM G.
description: DUPONG-William G., M.D. On April 24, 2000. Of Park Slope, Brooklyn and Amagansett, LI. At age 89. Received B.S. from Columbia University and M.D. from Long Island College of Medicine. Medical Director of the New York Telephone Company for 30 years. Served on the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board. Taught at Downstate Medical Center. Member of the Board at Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn, as well as staff member. Member of Midwood Lodge #

title: Little Havana Locks Its Doors In Quiet Protest
description: Little Havana's shops, restaurants, cafes and markets were shuttered today as thousands of Cuban-Americans infuriated by the federal removal of Elian Gonzalez heeded a call by exile leaders for a one-day work stoppage.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Out West, More Adventures in Winemaking
description: I WILL say this about West Coast winemakers: They are never boring. Well, almost never. Some of their latest experiments are transforming old techniques and old varietals into surprising innovations.

title: Two Families, Joined by a Death and Questions of Why
description: John Rivera struggled yesterday afternoon to understand how his son could have crossed over from hanging out with the wrong people to becoming one of them.

title: JACKSON FEDERAL BANK WILL ACQUIRE HIGHLAND BANCORP
description: Jackson Federal Bank said yesterday that it would buy Highland Bancorp Inc., for $25.45 a share, or a total of $120 million. Highland's stock shot up $6.8125 a share, to $24.0625. Highland Bancorp, based in Burbank, Calif., owns Highland Federal Bank, which has seven branches in Southern California. The combined company will operate 14 branches with nearly $1.1 billion in assets. Jackson Federal, based in San Bernardino, Calif., is owned by the Jackson National Life Insurance Company of Lansing, Mich., a subsidiary of Prudential P. L. C., a British insurance company.

title: Dining in a Grand Central Perch
description: IN a city with no shortage of stunning views, there are few prospects more impressive than Grand Central Terminal's main concourse. Seen from the marble-railed balconies, the frantic choreography of New Yorkers moving at top speed seems like the very pulse of the city. In the language of Hollywood film, this is the camera shot synonymous with Manhattan at its most dynamic.

title: Accounts
description: * Simple Wishes, San Carlos, Calif., a maker of collectible dolls and bears, to Towne Silverstein Rotter, New York, to handle its first account. Spending was estimated at $10 million to $12 million.

title: Slaying Shows Police Efforts Are No Cure-All for Cabbies
description: When a livery cab driven by Jose R. Olivares veered out of control and slammed into a building in the Bronx late Monday, it contained all the elements of a string of crimes that has confounded the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, ROBERT T.
description: ROBBINS-Robert T. Of Boca Raton Florida, age 62, entered into Rest on April 18, 2000. He was born in Long Island on July 24, 1937, the son of the late Dr. Abner and Bebe Robbins. Mr. Robbins, an outstanding athlete in his youth, was a graduate of the Wharton School. He was a caring and loving father for his two sons, Gregory and Steve Robbins. He is survived by his brother, Jay Robbins, as well as two nephews. A grave site ceremony will occur at Beth Moses Cemetery (516-295-3100) on Sunday, April 30 at 2 P.M. Relatives and friends are invited to attend.

title: THE CHEF; Wylie Dufresne
description: IT has become nearly impossible to surprise food-savvy New Yorkers. The collective attitude might be summed up as ''been there, tasted that.''

title: A Career Choice at Age 7
description: I realized I wanted to be a scientist when I was 7. My uncle, a librarian, would send me a book every week, and books on science interested me most, especially ones on Einstein and astronomy.

title: They Can Get It for You Resale; Secondhand Stores Moving Into the Retail Mainstream
description: Shopping secondhand stores, once the passion of an eccentric minority, is becoming a mainstream activity.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about pilgrims in Rome for the Catholic Church's Holy Year celebrations misstated the destination of the pilgrims in Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales.'' It was Canterbury, England, not Santiago de Compostela, Spain.

title: Plane Forced to Return After Takeoff at Newark
description: A mechanical problem forced a Continental Airlines DC-10 to land shortly after taking off from Newark International Airport yesterday evening. None of the 220 passengers or 10 crew members aboard the plane, Flight 60 to Brussels, were hurt, said Alan Hicks, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Exit La Grande Dame

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SURGES. Copper rose as a decline in inventories signaled strengthening demand from pipe and cable makers. In New York, copper for May delivery rose 2.35 cents, or 3.1 percent, to 78.95 cents a pound.

title: Industry Fears The Internet
description: Almost everybody involved with music has admitted that the Internet is going to change the business significantly. But not all of those changes are coming in ways that have been anticipated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIAS, SR. GERALDINE, R.G.S. (NEE ANGELA MARIE TOBIA)
description: TOBIAS-Sr. Geraldine, R.G.S. (nee Angela Marie Tobia). Sister of the Good Shepherd, Co-Founder with Sister Mary Paul Janchill of The Center for Family Life in Sunset Park, Brooklyn since 1978. The Center is a neighborhood based social service organization offering support to children, youth and families. The Center for Family Life has been recognized both locally and nationaly, most recently by the Annie E. Casey Foundation ''Family Honors'' award. Sister Geraldine is survived by her mother Bridget Cappozzi Tobia and by many cousins. Funeral Friday 10:15AM at the Schaefer Funeral Home, 4123 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Funeral mass 11AM, St. Michael's R.C. Church. Interment Sisters of Good Shepherd cemetery, Dix Hills, NY. Visiting Wed 7-10PM and Thursday 2-5PM and 7-10PM. In Lieu of flowers Donations may be made in Sr Geraldine's name to the Center for Family Life, 345 43rd Street Brooklyn, N.Y. 11232.

title: This Time, the Mayor's on the Left
description: The real Rudy? In the picture on the front page, he's the one on the left, with a touch more hair, and without the ring.

title: BELL MICROPRODUCTS PLANS TO BUY IDEAL HARDWARE
description: Bell Microproducts Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the British computer products reseller Ideal Hardware P. L. C. as it expands into European markets. The purchase price was not disclosed. Like Ideal Hardware, Bell Microproducts specializes in reselling computer storage equipment and helping customers set it up. Ideal Hardware, which is owned by InterX P. L. C. of Britain, had about $500 million in sales in its latest fiscal year, which ended in July. Bell Microproducts, in San Jose, Calif., had $1.06 billion in sales last year. Its stock rose 37.5 cents, to $15.3125.

title: Pursuing 800 Murder Cases, and Pocahontas
description: HE has 800 unsolved murder cases crammed into scrapbooks that line the walls of his offices, his laboratory, even his bathroom, like so much incriminating wallpaper: no wonder the man Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut calls the most famous detective since Sherlock Holmes -- the man whose devil-in-the-details testimony helped get O. J. Simpson off the hook -- feels pressed to retire from his day jobs and get on to his second career.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the special Museums section last Wednesday with an article about the recent transformation of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts misidentified the buildings shown. They are refurbished museum galleries and the home of the Children's Theater Company of Minneapolis, not a new wing of the museum.

title: Uninspired and Unimpressive, the U.S. Advances
description: Essentially guaranteed a spot in the semifinals of the regional Olympic soccer qualifying tournament, the American under-23 men's team played a largely uninspired but unthreatened match against Canada tonight. Still, the game was as potentially costly as it was ugly.

title: A Little Understanding, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: Tense Days in Tehran
description: A fateful struggle is now going on in Iran between the reform forces allied with President Mohammad Khatami and the religious conservatives who control the country's most powerful institutions. The outcome, still in doubt, will be crucial to realizing the hopes of most Iranians for greater tolerance, respect for the rule of law and more openness to the outside world. The conservatives may succeed in their efforts to thwart the will of the electorate. But they cannot prevail for long against the millions of young Iranians who increasingly demand a better, freer life.

title: Aiding an Indian Village With an Electric Chair
description: When a poor Indian village in the state of Kerala learns of a wonderful American product that will make life better and put the village on the international map, what could that item possibly be? A modern sanitation system? A medical clinic? A supercomputer? Think again.

title: Capital's Confidence Is Jolted by Shooting At the National Zoo
description: The shooting of seven youths outside the gates of the National Zoo, one of Washington's top tourist attractions, has jolted the sense of self-confidence that the city built with a new mayor, a budget surplus and reduced crime.

title: Leafs Pose A Difficult 2nd Round For Devils
description: The Devils' regular-season results against the Toronto Maple Leafs -- three losses and one tie -- are just the clearest indication that this second-round encounter in the Stanley Cup playoffs is not the best thing that could happen to the Devils. And even though the Devils matched up well in the sweep of Florida in the opening round, when Pavel Bure was the main threat, the Devils face several threats from the Maple Leafs.

title: Vermont Gives Final Approval to Same-Sex Unions
description: The Vermont House of Representatives gave its final approval today to a bill creating same-sex marriages in almost everything but the name. The State Senate approved the bill last week, and Gov. Howard Dean said he would sign it into law within days.

title: International Paper Offers $6.2 Billion for Champion
description: The International Paper Company offered yesterday to buy the Champion International Corporation for a combination of cash and stock worth $6.2 billion, or $64 a share, just two months after Champion agreed to be acquired by the Finnish paper giant UPM-Kymmene Corporation.

title: Musical Bum's Rush
description: To the Editor:

title: Administration Using Study To Push Elderly Drug Plan
description: Prices for the 50 drugs most frequently used by older Americans increased last year at nearly twice the rate of inflation, a study to be issued on Wednesday at the White House says.

title: Accidental Deaths on Rise as the Population Ages Fast
description: The number of accidental deaths in homes and public places other than roads rose 21 percent from 1992 to 1999, according to the National Safety Council, which attributed much of the increase to a larger number of elderly people prone to falls, and more drug overdoses.

title: Rightist in Canada's West Has Eyes Set on Ottawa
description: In Canada, a social welfare nation that has more tax collectors than soldiers, Stockwell Day has commanded a fiscal revolution in his province in the shadow of the Rocky Mountains.

title: How the Taliban Got Their Way in Afghanistan
description: TALIBAN

title: Corn's Higher Calling: Grits
description: IN a dimly lighted corridor just beyond the bustling kitchen of Anson Restaurant, the executive chef, Michael Lata, is feeding corn into a mill the size of an exercise bicycle. He reaches inside a bulging sack and lifts a fistful of yellow kernels, sun-puckered and as hard as glass beads, and drops them into a conical hopper to fall between two pink granite stones. What emerges is a coarse meal that will very soon be transformed into a creamy plate of yellow grits like none Northerners ever see.

title: Griffey's Shea Debut Surrounded by Hubbub

But except for a couple of good ones, like Meltemi and Rafina on the Upper East Side, they have been invariably disappointing. description: A Russian tanker chartered by one of the world's largest oil companies, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, was carrying Iraqi oil on April 5 in violation of the international embargo against Iraq when it was stopped by American sailors, American and company officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DATEK ONLINE HOLDINGS, Iselin, N.J., named Thomas F. Robards chief financial officer. He had been chief financial officer, executive vice president and treasurer at Republic New York Corp., which was recently acquired by HSBC Holdings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNEY, CECILE CESIA
description: KEARNEY-Cecile Cesia. On April 24, 2000. Holocaust survivor and retired buyer of handbags for Saks Fifth Avenue. Beloved wife of Peter and step-mother of Jeffrey Kearney. Dear sister of Isaac and Nathan Kistenberg, daughter of the late Samuel and Rachel Kistenberg and loving friend to manay. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Wednesday, April 26th, 11:30AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory. May be made to God's Love We Deliver, The New York Times 100 Neediest or the Alzheimer's Association.

title: The Next Party Speaks
description: To the Editor:

title: AKZO NOBEL NET RISES
description: The Netherlands' biggest chemical maker, Akzo Nobel, said its first-quarter profit rose 30 percent as it dropped an unprofitable fibers unit and benefited from demand for the antidepressant Remeron. Net income rose to 219 million euros ($206 million), more than expected, from 169 million euros a year earlier. Akzo Nobel said it expected to post profit growth of 10 percent to 29 percent for this year. Akzo Nobel's move from bulk chemicals to more profitable drugs and paints is paying off, analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, HELEN (NEE BASLOW)
description: PEARCE-Helen (nee Baslow). My beautiful, loving, precious, wonderful mother, who loved me and my husband so passionately & unconditionally, and who adored her precious David and Marilyn, passed away April 24, 2000. She was the most devoted caring wife, mother, and Nana Helen. She was self-sacrificing and full of joy especially when she made other people happy. She fearlessly brought about remarkable changes in our mining town in Virginia. She was fiercely devoted to her only child, Siema, Siema's husband Arnold, and especially her grandchildren. She set a sterling example of love of Judaism, Tzedaka, and sharing of one's self. She will always remain our idol. We will try to live our lives patterned by her countless examples and inspiration. We will always remember her beauty, grace, and endless, boundless love and devotion. Services will be held Friday, April 28, 2000 at 12 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Boy, the Raid And the Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: China Seizes 100 in Sect Trying to Celebrate Anniversary
description: The Chinese police detained more than 100 members of the banned Falun Gong movement today in Tiananmen Square. The defiant devotees were commemorating the anniversary of a huge demonstration that transformed the once obscure spiritual group into a target of the government's wrath.

title: What a Smile Hides: Unknown Effects Of Cuban Boy's Ordeal
description: Smiling is something that a 6-year-old boy can do, even a boy at the center of a political hurricane. And during the last few weeks, surrounded by adults whose own faces have often been contorted with anger, Elian Gonzalez has done a lot of smiling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOWITZ, SHIRLEY
description: LEBOWITZ-Shirley. The Executive Committee, Board and Staff of the Jewish Labor Committee note with sorrow the death of Shirley Lebowitz, mother of our dear friend and colleague, Lawrence (Arieh) Lebowitz. A devoted and loving wife to her husband, Sey, who passed away this past December, devoted mother to Arieh and Janet and Shaul Yamin, and loving grandmother of Daniella and Ilana, she leaves warm memories. We extend deepest condolences to all her relatives and friends. May her memory be a blessing. Shiva will be observed from Thursday evening, April 27, until Wednesday evening, May 3, but minyans only on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday at 7:30 PM. (Further details are available by calling (212) 477-0707.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, PETER
description: THOMPSON-Peter. The Kobal Collection is deeply saddened by the loss of our good friend. His gentle light will always be remembered.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Gains in European Stocks Being Swept Away by the Sinking Euro
description: Americans who have invested in European stock markets this year have been dealt a cruel blow by the euro, which seems to be on a relentless decline.

title: Spinach of a Different Color
description: LET Popeye have his spinach. Orach, used like spinach until the real thing came along centuries ago, would probably delight Olive Oyl.

title: Mexico's Candidates Hold First Presidential Debate
description: Comparing Mexico to South Africa under apartheid and to Germany divided by the Berlin Wall, Vicente Fox, the leading opposition candidate, urged Mexicans during a presidential debate tonight to summon the courage to vote for democratic change after 71 years of rule by one party.

title: Once Scorned, Far West 42nd St. Is Now Much in Demand
description: Jules Demchick, the developer, is doing what even a few years ago would have been unthinkable: building a 17-story corporate office tower in a neighborhood of low-slung warehouses, lumberyards, parking lots and a horse stable on the far west end of 42nd Street, near the Hudson River.

title: President Vetoes Measure to Send Nuclear Waste to Site in Nevada
description: President Clinton this evening vetoed a bill that would have required the Energy Department to move nuclear waste to Nevada before a repository it plans to build there had been completed.

title: Chief Executive Is Named at British Airways
description: British Airways, Europe's largest airline, announced today the appointment of Rod Eddington, the former managing director of Cathay Pacific Airways of Hong Kong, as chief executive.

title: Rowland's Stand on Campaign Finance in Question
description: Suspense and suspicion are mounting at the Connecticut Statehouse over whether Gov. John G. Rowland, a popular Republican, will sign or veto a Democratic-sponsored bill that would use public money to finance state political campaigns and impose voluntary caps on how much candidates could spend.

title: Van Gundy Needs to Lighten Up
description: At some point during the playoffs, with the Knicks comfortably ahead, you will catch a glimpse of their sideline. After scanning a row of smiling millionaires in shorts and high tops, you may turn to a friend and ask: ''Why does Jeff Van Gundy look so miserable? They're winning.''

title: CALENDAR
description: Toasting New York Tech

title: At U.N., Russia Hardens Line On Changes to Missile Treaty
description: Russia hardened its line today against any American attempts to modify a 1972 missile defense treaty and appealed for broad support from other nations, saying the United States was putting three decades of arms agreements in jeopardy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, JUDGE FRITZ W. II
description: ALEXANDER-Judge Fritz W. II. The Respect For Law Alliance, Inc, mourns the loss of our Incorporator, friend, advisor and colleague, Judge Fritz W. Alexander, II. In addition to being one of our organizers, as a Founding Director, Officer, and active Member, Judge Alexander was a guiding light in the development of The Alliance and its programs. We shall miss the wisdom, and friendship of this respected jurist and public servant. The Nation will be poorer for his loss, but The Alliance will carry on his pattern of offering service, fraternalism, scholarship, and mutual understanding for a stronger and friendlier City, State, and Nation. Those of us in the law, law enforcement, judiciary and public service will miss him greatly. Our condolences to his loving wife, Beverly, and to his family. Brig Gen Arthur Gerwin, USAF (Ret) President and Chairperson Chief Judge Gregory W. Carman US Court of Int'l Trade Vice Pres & Co-Vice Chairperson Judith A. Livingston, Esq Co-Vice Chairperson RESPECT FOR LAW ALLIANCE, INC

title: Still No Deal on Park for Mets
description: The sight was jarring: a smiling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Yankees superfan, wearing a Mets jacket and cap yesterday and playing catch with Fred Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, and Tom Seaver on the field at Shea Stadium.

title: Officials Working to Contain West Nile Virus
description: A sound public health plan is in place nationally to combat further spread of the mosquito-borne West Nile virus, which caused an outbreak of encephalitis in New York City last year, federal health officials said here today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLEIBERG, LOUIS
description: BLEIBERG-Louis. 10/27/1888-4/ 26/1960. Forever in our hearts. Your children; Blanch, Harry, Frances, Eleanor and Jerry

title: Spectators Earn Sweat Equity Chasing Upstairs and Down
description: Zvi Gotheiner choreographically filled ''The Amber Room'' with lots of ideas. Some were good ones in this production, which Zvi Gotheiner and Dancers offered on Friday night at the Angel Orensanz Foundation. Nevertheless the work occasionally became an ordeal when it should have been an adventure.

title: Nobel Economists Back China's Joining Global Trade Group
description: A group of 13 Nobel Prize-winning economists signed a letter today that backs China's bid to join the World Trade Organization. But the letter, released in a ceremony with top Clinton administration officials, was at least as notable for what it left out.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for the seventh day of Passover, tomorrow for the eighth day of Passover and for Orthodox Holy Thursday, and Friday for Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Charter Schools Win Approval Over Misgivings
description: Despite concerns from the State Board of Regents, three new charter schools, intended to serve children in Queens, Roosevelt and Rochester, received approval yesterday to open in the fall from the trustees of the State University of New York.

title: RACIAL DISPARITIES SEEN AS PERVASIVE IN JUVENILE JUSTICE
description: Black and Hispanic youths are treated more severely than white teenagers charged with comparable crimes at every step of the juvenile justice system, according to a comprehensive report released yesterday that was sponsored by the Justice Department and six of the nation's leading foundations.

title: Prize Numbers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Leaky Boiler at Shelter Sends 17 to Hospitals
description: A carbon monoxide leak at a city homeless shelter in the Bronx made 17 people ill last night and forced the temporary evacuation of the shelter, fire officials said.

title: City Ballet Opens in a Blaze of Balanchine
description: High art and popular culture were not mutually exclusive in George Balanchine's mind. This idea, shared by Igor Stravinsky, made itself felt on Tuesday night when the New York City Ballet opened its spring season at the New York State Theater. Cowpoke tunes in Balanchine's ''Western Symphony'' shared the evening with the music Stravinsky intended for movies in his ''Symphony in Three Movements.''

title: Sports of The Times; Ewing's Play Won't Pass Unnoticed
description: HELLO to you, too, Jeff Van Gundy. We, the people, the true Knicks fans, know all too well that your team was 8-3 with Patrick Ewing in the playoffs last season, and 4-5 without him. We know we can't win the championship without him. Know what, Coach? We like what we saw last night better. We loved the sight of Latrell Sprewell on the left side of the basket, sizing up Vince Carter, readying his game-winning drive and jumper in the lane, while not a groan could be heard in the house.

title: A Sprint Across the Keyboard
description: It is hard to know what was being celebrated most in ''Piano Century,'' a sequence of 11 concerts of 20th-century piano music that Bruce Brubaker put together for the Juilliard School this academic year and that ended on Tuesday evening. The instrument that survived the century? The century that survived the instrument? Or the school that can present 101 pianists playing 101 pieces by 101 composers, all the way from Debussy and Scott Joplin to Lois V. Vierk and Thomas Ades?

title: Tokyo Journal; TV Invents What Japan Sorely Lacks: Impoliteness
description: The show began with a clamor befitting a three-ring circus as the host, one of Japan's most famous comedians, entered the set shrouded in smoke and dressed up as a stick of dynamite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HOWARD S.
description: HARRIS-Howard S. A faculty member at Bronx Community College of the City University of New York for over 30 years, succumbed to cancer on April 22, 2000. Professor Harris distinguished himself as an Professor, researcher, author and Chairman of the Social Sciences Department for the past twenty years. He also created several nationally recognized programs, including the establishment of a Human Services Associate Degree curriculum and a child welfare worker certificate program. He was active in the PSC/CUNY Union and served as Chapter Chair at the Bronx campus. Professor Harris is survived by his wife Carol, his son Scott and his parents Sidney and Ruth Harris. A gregarious person by nature and a collaborative colleague, he will be missed. President Carolyn G. Williams Bronx Community College Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBER, FRANCIS J.
description: WERBER-Francis J. April 24, 2000. Friends may call at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York, Thursday 3-5 and 7-9.

title: ALPHARMA TO PURCHASE ROCHE'S ANIMAL DRUG BUSINESS
description: Alpharma Inc., a specialty pharmaceutical company, agreed yesterday to buy Roche Holding's animal drug business for $300 million. Alpharma said the transaction would make it the leading producer of medicated feed additives by doubling its sales. The Roche business, which makes products used in livestock and poultry feed to prevent disease, had about $200 million in sales last year. About 55 percent of Roche's sales are in North America, 20 percent are in Europe, and Southeast Asia and Latin America each represent 12 percent. The announcement was made after Alpharma's shares closed at $40, up $2.125 each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ethics Eclipse
description: The House Ethics Committee has quietly rescinded a 10-year-old reform that required the committee to issue a report on its findings when an investigation fails to result in charges against a lawmaker. Members of the committee play down the change as a mundane ''housekeeping matter'' that merely institutes a rule approved by the full House in 1997 that gave the committee discretion to withhold findings in such cases. But an ethics watchdog group, the Congressional Accountability Project, points to conflicting disclosure provisions in House rules and suggests the committee's change may be timed to avoid issuing a potentially embarrassing report in the event no charges result in the case of Representative Bud Shuster, the powerful Transportation and Infrastructure Committee chairman. The committee has been conducting a prolonged review of Mr. Shuster's financial and legislative dealings with a major transportation lobbyist, Ann Eppard.

title: To Be Young And British And Female And in a Gang
description: Their laughter precedes them onto the stage: big, bright hoops of noise with sharp and jagged edges. If you heard this sound on an urban sidewalk, part of you would feel like smiling; another part would urge you to cross to the other side of the street.

title: City Reassigns Some Foster Care Caseworkers
description: Over the last week, the city's child welfare agency has ordered 30 caseworkers to be transferred from its Bronx and Queens foster care offices, in a move that agency officials say will more evenly spread caseloads across the city. But the workers and their union say the transfers will not only disrupt their lives but also could pose a risk to the foster children in the city's care.

title: U.S. SAYS RUSSIANS MAY WANT A DEAL ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: After a second round of intensive meetings with the Russian foreign minister about the missile defense system that the United States wants to develop over Russian objections, senior administration officials said today that they had detected a readiness by Moscow to explore all avenues of a possible resolution to the looming standoff.

title: Casey Is Fired by Nets as Shake-Up Begins
description: Don Casey spent his last night as the Nets' head coach entertaining reporters at one of his favorite restaurants in Hoboken, N.J. Casey was laughing, joking and dominating the conversation with humorous tales and anecdotes. In between stories, he spoke with several people around the National Basketball Association on his cellular phone, hoping desperately that one of them would have good news, that one of them was certain that the rumors of his imminent firing were false. No one could help him.

title: Thomas Has Room to Roam North of Border
description: In terms of the Conn Smythe trophy, the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs is like an early presidential primary.

title: Wendell Is Workhorse Who Thrives on Exertion
description: Turk Wendell hates treadmills, so he runs outdoors every day, in every city, even Tokyo at the start of this season.

title: Versailles Signature
description: When Marie Antoinette played shepherdess at her toy hamlet at Versailles, she decorated the balconies with cachepots from the Luneville and Saint-Clement factories in Lorraine. The pots and matching plates are being reissued by the Blachere Group, the distributor of Luneville and Saint-Clement in the United States. Priced from $24 to $72, they are at Gracious Home, 1217 Third Avenue (70th Street) and 1992 Broadway (67th Street), (212) 988-8990.

title: States Said to Back Proposal From U.S. To Divide Microsoft
description: The federal government and the states that are partners in the antitrust suit against Microsoft agreed today to file a joint proposal on remedies in the case and back a plan to break Microsoft into two companies, officials said.

title: Playing to the Cameras in Miami
description: Picture this: The Gonzalez house in Little Havana, Miami, at 1:30 p.m. on a tense Tuesday during the Elian Gonzalez custody standoff. The police man the barricades; the surrounding area has been closed. Directly across the narrow street, close to 100 cameras dominate the neighborhood, lenses trained like weapons on the house 24 hours a day.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Saving Easter Lilies

title: Cubans Get Back to Business
description: A day after honoring a Cuban-American orchestrated work stoppage to protest 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez's removal from the home of his Miami extended family last weekend, a pair of Cubans who are best friends -- Livan Hernandez and Vladimir Nunez -- yesterday resumed doing what they do best: pitch.

title: Under the Big Tent, Finding Whatever Your Heart Desires
description: If you have ever wanted to snuggle up with a pillow designed by Cindy Crawford, sleep in pajamas by Todd Oldham or gaze at a handblown glass flower by Dale Chihuly, get yourself a ticket to the Great Bazaar next Thursday night under the big tent at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center. Step through the beaded curtains and you will be on a street of shops whose sales will benefit the Design Industries Foundation Fighting Aids (Diffa).

title: Frank Rothman Is Dead at 73; Lawyer Defended the N.F.L.
description: Frank Rothman, a trial lawyer who represented the National Football League in some of its most important cases and who once ran the MGM movie studio, died Tuesday in a hospital here from complications following surgery, his family said. He was 73 and had continued to practice law until early this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIA, SR. MARY GERALDINE
description: TOBIA-Sr. Mary Geraldine. The March of Dimes Foundation honors the magnificent life and work of Sr. Mary Geraldine Tobia. As co-founder of the Center for Family Life in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, her legacy continues in the lives of the families she served. Dr. Jennifer L. Howse, President

title: Rights Panel Scolds Police On Race Issues
description: A draft report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights says that the New York Police Department's own data suggest that its officers engage in racial profiling and recommends that the city consider creating a law enforcement ''mechanism,'' independent of local prosecutors, to pursue serious accusations of police brutality.

title: DANISH COMPANY TO BUY BELTONE, MAKER OF HEARING AIDS
description: GN Store Nord said yesterday that it would buy the Beltone Electronics Corporation, an American maker of hearing aids, for $392.5 million in cash and stock. GN Store Nord, owner of Denmark's second-largest mobile-phone operator, will pay $196 million in cash and 1.9 million shares. The Danish company said it would add enough cash or stock to guarantee its offer is worth at least $392.5 million. Last May, GN Store Nord bought another American maker of hearing aids, the ReSound Corporation, for $180 million in cash. GN Store Nord bought Beltone from John W. Childs, a former executive at the Thomas H. Lee Company, who runs an investment firm in Boston.

title: Company to Stop Operating Troubled Prison
description: The Wackenhut Corrections Corporation, the world's largest private for-profit prison company, announced yesterday that it was abandoning a contract to run a juvenile prison in Louisiana after a New Orleans judge and the Justice Department found that the inmates were being physically abused and deprived of adequate food and clothing.

title: Schools Chancellor Proposes to Recruit New Teachers From Other Professions
description: Seeking to recruit new teachers from the ranks of other professions, the New York City Board of Education is working on a plan to train prospective teachers itself, qualifying them to meet state certification requirements without having to go back to school.

title: Diet Product Maker to Refund $10 Million
description: ''You can eat what you want and never, ever, ever have to diet again.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, WALTER
description: SNYDER-Walter. On April 25, 2000 of Forest Hills Gardens, New York. Beloved husband of the late Rita. Adored father of Abyna Zimmerman. Cherished grandfather of Matthew. Loving father-in-law of Mel. A loved uncle to many nieces and nephews. Reposing Fox Funeral Home Inc., corner of Metropolitan Ave. and Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church on Friday, April 28th, at 10:15 A.M. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEMAN, MARIE S.
description: ALLEMAN-Marie S. Foley, on April 23rd, 2000, Easter Sunday. Her life has drawn peacefully to its close. Memorial service will be held Saturday, April 29th, 3 PM, at St. Thomas More Church, The Foley Chapel, East 89th Street.

title: Amazon.com Reports a Loss of $308 Million
description: Amazon.com, the biggest retailer on the Internet, said yesterday that it lost $308 million in the first quarter, five times its loss a year earlier, but that its sales rose 95 percent, beating forecasts.

title: The New, Flexible Math Meets Parental Rebellion
description: Three years ago, one of New York City's most adventurous school districts set out to tackle a nagging problem: the math phobia that afflicts many students, and the disparity between the test scores of white middle-class students and their poorer black and Hispanic counterparts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Turner Way Is Known As the Hard Way for Grant
description: FOR a boxer, Michael Grant has a bad habit. He drops his hands, leaving his chin hanging out there like a punching bag, begging to be hit. But whenever the 6-foot-7-inch, 250-pound heavyweight is sparring and drops his hands, his trainer, Don Turner, yells, ''Start the whole round over.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS, New York, named Gary Crittenden chief financial officer, succeeding Richard Goeltz, who is retiring. Mr. Crittenden had been chief financial officer at Pharmacia.

title: A Georgia Daughter's Lullaby of the Pines
description: THIS probably won't be too thrilling to you, a wrecking yard like this,'' Franklin Ray said, stepping out of his jumbled homemade house and leading the way through piles of tires and aluminum cans, decades of rusting cars and tractors, entwined in wisteria and wild grapevines, sunk to their hubcaps in years of pine needles and magnolia leaves. Like Mayan ruins slumbering in the Yucatan, the detritus of a civilization is piled here in his backyard, awaiting some archaeologist -- or daughter -- to reveal its meaning.

title: As the Odometer Turns: Photographs of the Nation, Mile by Mile
description: THANKS to the Internet, a Texas engineer named Matt Frondorf has done the impossible. Mr. Frondorf's highway snapshots of his coast-to-coast auto trip have been put on the Web, singly and in slide-movie form, and instead of inspiring a race to the door, they have turned the mundane into a picaresque work of art.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about potential effects of trauma on Elian Gonzalez's mental health misstated the timing of his parents' divorce and the role of a psychiatrist who was a consultant to the government in the case. Juan Miguel Gonzalez and Elizabet Brotons divorced before Elian was born, not afterward, but were living together at the time of his birth. The psychiatrist, Jerry Weiner, was part of a team of mental health experts assembled to advise the government, but he was not present the day of the meeting with Mr. Gonzalez.

description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the placebo effect and antidepressant drugs misstated the given name of a psychologist who has done research in this area. He is Dr. Roger Greenberg, not Robert.

title: Aetna's New Chief Wants To Be Consumer-Friendly
description: William H. Donaldson is driving hard to transform Aetna, the nation's biggest health insurer, into a warm, consumer-friendly company that makes more profits and fewer enemies. In his first 60 days as chief executive, he has sidestepped fights with belligerent trial lawyers, embarked on what he calls first steps toward healing strained relations with doctors, and hired an executive search firm to find a leader for Aetna's health care business.

title: Castro Emerges as Conflict's Clear Winner
description: At the corner of Flagler Street and 22nd Avenue, a procession of cars filled with teenagers, salsa music blaring, crawled slowly across the intersection with Cuban flags fluttering from radio antennas and a big American flag flying upside down, in scorn.

title: The Incredible Lightness of Soaring Sculpture
description: THEY were expecting some kind of experimental house like the one I built in Kobe,'' said the architect Shigeru Ban on Monday, referring to the cardboard ''log'' houses he designed, along with a paper church, for victims of the earthquake in Japan in 1995.

title: National Parks Will Ban Recreation Snowmobiling
description: In a new attempt to protect public lands, the National Park Service will impose a broad and immediate ban on the recreational use of snowmobiles at nearly all of the country's national parks, monuments and recreational areas, Interior Department officials said today.

title: McCain, in Vietnam, Finds the Past Isn't Really Past
description: As he strode through the shadowy hallways and incongruously sunny courtyards, gesturing here, pointing to a detail there, Senator John McCain might have been a father showing his son his alma mater.

title: Staying in Sync: All the Data, Up to Date, All the Time
description: IT happens all the time: You arrive home from a long day at work and realize you left something at the office. On your computer. In a folder. Something you wish you had now, be it a memo you need to revise, or maybe a recipe for Jamaican jerk chicken you saved as a Web favorite while browsing during your lunch break. So much for that exotic dinner you were going to fix.

title: Going From Carmen Sandiego To an Online Recruiting Site
description: What do you do if you are a software engineer looking for life after Broderbund Software, the computer game company of Myst and Carmen Sandiego fame?

title: Pork and beef producers are moving to freshen up their long-running consumer campaigns.
description: PORK is still the other white meat and beef is still for dinner, but the associations that created those long-running campaigns are planning multimedia efforts to help freshen them up.

title: Exile's Heirs Claim a Picasso at the Modern
description: The heirs of a Jewish art collector whose home was looted by German occupation troops in October 1940 believe that one of hundreds of paintings seized on that occasion now hangs in the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The painting, Picasso's ''Still Life: Job,'' of 1916, is among 15 works recently identified by the museum as having incomplete provenance records from the World War II era.

title: Tiger Camp Rebuffed on License; 26 Cats May Need a New Home
description: New Jersey's Tiger Lady lost another round yesterday in her effort to renew her license to keep and exhibit the big cats on her property.

title: Show Houses, From Farmhouse to Town House
description: STYLE seekers, take a number. Beginning this month, dozens of budding decorators and amateur renovators throw open their homes, gardens, 18th-century estates, 19th-century row houses and contemporary apartments to visitors, as the show house season opens. Some show houses display the work of designers who are established, others the efforts of those now making names for themselves. Either way, look for these houses to be less overwhelming than the annual Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club Decorator Show House. Here is a sampling of tours in the Northeast. Unless otherwise noted, they are self-guided. For advance tickets, telephone for information.

title: Buyout of Acme Electric
description: The Acme Electric Corporation, a maker of power conversion equipment, said today that it had agreed to a buyout offer of $7.65 a share, a total of $39.5 million, from an investment company formed by its chairman and chief executive Robert J. McKenna. Acme's stock rose $1.375 a share, to $7.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Sister Mary Geraldine Tobia, 59, Leader of Family Agency
description: Sister Mary Geraldine Tobia, a longtime co-director of the Center for Family Life in Sunset Park, a social service agency serving people in that section of Brooklyn, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 59 and lived at the center, which is at 345 43rd Street in Sunset Park.

title: King Day Becomes Official in Connecticut
description: An hour before the Rev. Jesse Jackson was scheduled to arrive at the Capitol today to urge lawmakers to pass a bill requiring municipalities to observe the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, Gov. John G. Rowland signed the expedited bill into law.

description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Publisher Sat In on Leaders' Conference Call With Reno
description: The Miami Herald's coverage on Monday of the fallout from Saturday's predawn raid that took Elian Gonzalez from the home of his Miami relatives focused in part on the failure of efforts by community leaders to broker a peaceful settlement of the custody dispute over the 6-year-old Cuban boy.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES

Based on their descriptions, can you guess who designed which handle? Mr. Meier said his goal was ''something as simple and straightforward as possible,'' while Mr. Tihany said he wanted something leverlike that could be opened with an elbow and yet felt nice to grip. Answer: 1) B; 2) A. The handles, for $250 to $300, come in different finishes at Valli & Valli, 150 East 58th Street. Information: (877) 326-2565.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAAMOT, TONIS
description: RAAMOT-Tonis, 68, renowned civil engineer. Tonis Raamot, CEO, of Raamot Associates, P.C. died on Wednesday 26 April 2000 at New York University Medical Center. Dr. Raamot established the firm in 1969 and was a recognized authority on soil mechanics and foundation engineering in the United States and more than 20 foreign countries. Prior to establishing his own firm, Dr. Raamot was Chief Civil Engineer of the Raymond Concrete Pile Division of Raymond International Inc. His teaching experience included a professorship in soil mechanics and foundation engineering at Newark College of Engineering (now AJIT). Dr. Raamot also served on active duty in the U.S. Navy Civil Engineering Corps, retiring as a Lieutenant Commander. Dr. Raamot was also an alumnus of Columbia University (BA, BS, MS) and the University of Illinois (Ph.D.) He was a fellow of the American Society of Civil Engineers and also a member of the National Society of Professional Engineers and the Society of American Military Engineers. Dr. Raamot is survived by his wife Annette, his daughters Anne, Kristin and Liia, his brother Jaan, and his grandchildren Maggie, John and Marin. Viewing to be held at Scarpaci Funeral Home, 1401 86 St, Brooklyn, NY on April 27 and April 28, 2-5 & 7-9:30PM. Interment at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn on Saturday, April 29 at 10AM.

title: The City Life; Eye Contact
description: Is there such a thing as a fragmentary gaze? A fractional stare? Some days, in a Manhattan street crowd, not an eye meets mine. Everyone plows the straight-ahead furrow to work or home. But some days, watching the eyes in a crowd is like watching a school of reef fish, flashing as they catch my glance and then dart away in pairs. The eyes slip past, frictionless. Even though they look into mine, there is no look there, no intent, just accidental contact, the brief coincidental meeting of what John Donne calls ''eye-beams.'' Any longer glance and there is a hint of belligerence or beckoning. It's a rule that everyone knows.

Last week, Minneapolis-based Funco accepted a buyout offer from the Electronics Boutique Holding Corporation for $21 a share, an offer that matched Barnes & Noble's initial bid. Electronics Boutique, based in West Chester, Pa., initially offered $17 a share for Funco; Barnes & Noble then offered $21 a share. Funco has more than 400 video game retail shops. Funco's shares were up $3.1875, to $24.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Clearest Picture of Infant Universe Sees It All and Questions It, Too
description: Scientists yesterday released the clearest pictures yet taken of the infant universe, before stars and galaxies had formed and when space was filled with hot turbulent gases. The images confirm one major prediction of the leading theory of the explosive birth of the universe, but they failed to reveal another crucial feature that scientists had hoped would buttress that theory.

title: Dissident Mohawks Sue to Overturn Chiefs' Deal With Casino Operator
description: A dissident group of St. Regis Mohawk Indians filed suit in tribal court yesterday seeking to overturn a secret agreement in which six Mohawk chiefs turned over rights to build and manage casinos in New York State to the largest gaming company in the world.

title: KOREAN PHONE DEAL APPROVED
description: The South Korean Fair Trade Commission approved the SK Telecom Company's takeover of the Shinsegi Telecom Company, adding conditions aimed at reducing their combined market share in the mobile phone service industry. After the merger, SK Telecom will have to cut its combined market share to 50 percent from 56.9 percent by the end of June next year. Also, SK Telecom will have to limit the production capacity at its mobile phone handset-making affiliate to less than 1.2 million a year until the end of 2005.

title: SMALLER LOSS AT EURO DISNEY
description: Helped by increased spending by guests at its theme park and hotels near Paris, Euro Disney reported that its net loss decreased in the first half of its fiscal year. For the six months that ended on March 31, the loss was 31.3 million euros, or $28.8 million, down from 45.3 million euros the year before, on an 8 percent increase in revenue, to 403.1 million euros. Euro Disney, in which the Walt Disney Company owns a 39 percent share, said the results assumed that insurers would reimburse it for losses after fierce storms in December forced the park, Disneyland Paris, to close for a day. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: BRAZILIAN GAS AUCTION

The company's bid beat out one made by TotalFina Elf S.A. of France, which offered 200 million reais for the area. Under the sale terms, Gas Natural will have to invest at least 100 million reais over the next five years to increase distribution networks. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: M (Mathematics) + E (Expostulation) - C (Clarity) = ?
description: The number to remember in ''The Five Hysterical Girls Theorem,'' a new play by Rinne Groff at the Connelly Theater in the East Village, is 147,573,952,589,676,412,927. That's 147 quintillion. Don't think you can remember it? Well, it's the same as 2 to the 67th power minus 1. Which is not a prime number, as it turns out, and that is also of some pertinence, though why it is pertinent I'm not sure. It does, for some reason, cause a romantic young mathematician to drown himself in the ocean.

title: As Scheherazade Was Saying . . .
description: ''Aladdin'' is a tale so perfectly conceived it is nearly impossible to mess up. The latest telling, the centerpiece of ABC's mini-series ''Arabian Nights,'' is a witty and sumptuous version, with Jason Scott Lee tremendously engaging as the poor young con man who finds a magic lantern. John Leguizamo goes delightfully over the top playing two genies, a cheerful roly-poly and his cousin, a growling demon (more of a softy than he sounds). And though the genies change Aladdin's fortunes with trunks of jewels and a palace that appears and vanishes in a flash, the tale is irresistible because of its good-hearted, scheming hero. Aladdin falls for a princess and learns that magic is nothing without love.

title: Sleepwalking to Dreamy Rhythms in Sumptuous Rio
description: Bruno Barreto dedicates ''Bossa Nova'' to Antonio Carlos Jobim and Francois Truffaut. He is out to create a film that has a similar becalmed magic, the subtleties of rhythm that pull you slowly but deftly into Jobim's music and Truffaut's films. But Mr. Barreto's film is too wan to achieve a rhythm. This anonymous romantic farce may leave you exhausted, if only because your toes and knees have been bouncing along to the friendly bossa nova grooves of the songs selected for the soundtrack. It includes one of those world music tunes from Sting (who performs ''How Insensitive,'' a Jobim song), who apparently has a contractual obligation to include one such song on each of his albums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, PETER S.
description: O'BRIEN-Peter S. Marine, Educator, Unionist. After serving on active duty with the U.S. Marine Corps during the Korean War, Peter O'Brien continued his military service with the Marine Corps Reserve. He became proficient in all aspects of Marine Corps Air Control and retired as Lieutenant Colonel after 27 years of service. Following release from active duty, he taught and supervised in the New York City public schools for over 34 years as a teacher, Assistant Principal, Principal and retired as Community Superintendent of Community School District 30 in Queens. While teaching he became active in the teacher's union movement and helped found the New York City and national AFL-CIO unions of school supervisors and administrators. In 1977, as its President, he led the Council of Supervisors and Administrators of the City of New York on strike in support of the UFT. As a founding officer of the American Federation of School Administrators, he served as President until his return to the New York City public school system as Superintendent of Community School District 30. He is survived by his wife, Bernadette, their children, Peter, Bernadette, Michael, Christopher and Stephen, his daughters-in-law Suzann, Patty and Kristen, and grandchildren Michael, Jillian and Megan. As well as his sisters, Eileen Burke, Sister Ann Michael, and brother Shawn. Remembrances may be made to the Mother Theresa Order, Missionaries of Charity, 168 Sussex Avenue, Newark, New Jersey 07103. A wake will be held on the afternoon and evening of Friday, April 28, from 2 P.M. to 4 P.M. and 7 P.M. to 9 P.M. at Vander Plaat Colonial Home, 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fairlawn, New Jersey, with a Mass of the Requiem at 11 A.M. Saturday, April 29th at St. Catharine's RC Church, 905 South Maple Avenue, Glen Rock, New Jersey.
