title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, ROBERT L.B.
description: TOBIN-Robert L.B. The Metropolitan Opera Association mourns with profound sadness the death of our very dear friend, Robert L. B. Tobin. An honorary director at the time of his death, Robert joined the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association as a managing director in 1976. He has left a legacy of more than three decades of dedicated service, as vice president from 1991-1999, as a long-time member of the executive committee, as chairman of the production and art committees, and through service on the nominating committee. We recall with admiration Robert's prodigious knowledge of opera, theater, and contemporary art. These passionate interests were evident in his continual efforts to preserve the Met's heritage through his work with our archives, in his family's support for our pioneering production of Berg's ''Lulu,'' and in his own support for an all-Stravinsky evening designed by David Hockney. Robert's commitment to bringing the contemporary repertory to our stage is also reflected in his leadership gift for our production of ''Porgy and Bess'' and in his underwriting of our commission for Philip Glass's ''The Voyage.'' A founding member, with his beloved mother, Mag Tobin, of our Golden Horseshoe Program, he also gave leadership support to our first endowment campaign and to our current effort to secure the Met in the new century. A memorable presence whenever he was in the opera house, he particularly relished attending opening nights and premieres. We were especially touched this winter when, despite failing health, he remained almost to the conclusion of the supper he gave for the cast and the company after ''The Merry Widow'' premiere. We remember with deep affection Robert's abiding devotion to the Metropolitan Opera, his elegance, his passionate commitment to artistic excellence, his wise counsel during challenging times for our company, and his irreverent wit even in the most dire of personal circumstances. Robert's extraordinary personal courage during his extended period of ill health and his heroic effort to meet his Metropolitan Opera board responsibilities were an inspiration to all of us. Most of all, his passing is a profound loss to those of us who were privileged to know him as a friend. Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford, Honorary Chairman James Kinnear, Chairman Paul Montrone, President Joseph Volpe, General Manager

title: Giuliani Fighting Prostate Cancer; Unsure on Senate

description: ONE of the great racial divides of traffic safety is seat belt use; young African-Americans are about 50 percent less likely than other motorists to buckle up, and they have correspondingly higher death rates in highway crashes.

title: Can Young & Rubicam maintain its independence when WPP comes calling?
description: IN a deal that would combine two of the world's largest advertising companies, WPP Group, the British conglomerate that owns Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and J. Walter Thompson, acknowledged yesterday that it was in talks to buy Young & Rubicam in New York.

title: Senate Republicans Try to Delay Vote on Taiwan Security Bill
description: Some Senate Republicans are pushing to postpone consideration of a bill that would upgrade United States defense ties with Taiwan, arguing that it makes no sense to pass it when Taiwan's government is in transition and China has acted with relative restraint toward its neighbor.

title: Pesky Goal Posts Frustrate The Devils
description: When the Devils awaken in their hotel hideaway Friday, they may hear the buzzer of the alarm clock or the ring of a telephone wake-up call. But in their overnight dreams, they might have heard the ding! ding! ding! of pucks bouncing off goal posts.

title: On Long Island, New Team Is Ready to Give Game a Ride
description: Louis Valverde felt like a kid again. A retired postmaster from nearby Brentwood, he circled the room clutching a baseball covered with autographs, looking for yet another ball player. He did not know their names. He could not recognize their faces. But it did not matter.

title: Betsy Dworkin, 66; Taught Social Policy
description: Betsy Dworkin, a former senior lecturer in social policy and administration at the University of London's Chelsea and University colleges, died yesterday at her home in Greenwich Village. She would have been 67 today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLESPIE, GREGORY
description: GILLESPIE-Gregory. Forum Gallery, New York, honors the life and brilliant work of Gregory Gillespie. A great and unique American painter, he leaves a legacy of extraordinary art in public and private collections. His great courage and talent are an ongoing inspiration. We extend condolences to his wife, Peggy, his daughters Jay and Lydia and his son Vincent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARCE, HELEN (NEE BASLOW)
description: PEARCE-Helen (nee Baslow). My beautiful, loving, precious, wonderful mother, who loved me and my husband so passionately & unconditionally, and who adored her precious David and Marilyn, passed away April 24, 2000. She was the most devoted caring wife, mother, and Nana Helen. She was self-sacrificing and full of joy especially when she made other people happy. She fearlessly brought about remarkable changes in our mining town in Virginia. She was fiercely devoted to her only child, Siema, Siema's husband Arnold, and especially her grandchildren. She set a sterling example of love of Judaism, Tzedaka, and sharing of one's self. She will always remain our idol. We will try to live our lives patterned by her countless examples and inspiration. We will always remember her beauty, grace, and endless, boundless love and devotion. Services will be held Friday, April 28, 2000 at 12 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Siema Sollar

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, JUNE (NEE FISCHER)
description: KIMMEL-June (nee Fischer). Born in Brooklyn. A graduate of Brooklyn College and Columbia University Graduate School. She was a member of the Board of Trustees & an assistant treasurer of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. She also served as Chairperson of the Divisional Committee for the Adult Mentality Ill and on numerous other committees. She is survived by her beloved husband, David Kimmel, children, Robert Kraft and Diane Kraft Ward, grandchildren, Colin and Patrick, son-in-law, Philip Ward, and daughter-in-law, Ruth Breslin. She is the sister of the late Albert Fischer and widow of Leon Kraft. She is also survived by other loving family members. She died April 26, 2000 in her treasured NYC. Funeral services will be held 9:45 AM, Fri, April 28 at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, NYC.

title: National News Briefs; U.S. Announces Ban On Snowmobiles in Parks
description: The National Park Service announced today that it was banning the off-road winter vehicles from most of the park system, saying there was significant evidence that thousands of snowmobilers were causing environmental damage. The broad ban applies to 25 national parks, recreation areas, monuments and other park units where snowmobiles have been allowed for years.

title: 300 New Jobs at Corning
description: Corning Inc., the No. 1 maker of glass used in fiber optic networks, said today that it would double the manufacturing capacity at its plant in Bedford, Mass., to meet increased demand for network components. More than 300 new jobs will be created at the Corning Lasertron factory. The doubling of the plant's capacity will cost about $45 million, the company said. Corning also said its shareholders approved an increase in the shares of common stock to 1.2 billion from 500 million. Corning's shares rose $9.1875, to $189.9375.

title: Whitman Ends Plan to Shift 900 to Suburb From Trenton
description: Agreeing with critics who said the state was ignoring its own guidelines for so-called smart growth, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today abruptly canceled a plan to move more than 900 state revenue workers from the capital to a neighboring suburb, even after the government had spent $3 million on preliminary construction of a new office building.

title: OBITUARY : Antoine Geoffroy-Dechaume, 94, Pioneering Harpsichordist
description: PARIS  The French harpsichordist, musicologist and composer Antoine Geoffroy-Dechaume, 94, died April 15. He played a pioneering role in the renewal of early music (16th to 18th centuries) by publishing findings culled from school manuals of the period and by teaching the conventions governing the way music was written and performed in those days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBER, FRANCIS J.

Deeply devoted husband of the late Anne Sullivan Werber; beloved brother of Florence, Isabel and the late Charles Werber; wonderful father to his sons, Frank, Robert, John and Andrew; loving grandfather to Nicholas, Elizabeth and William Werber. A man of integrity who will be fondly remembered for his humility, his kindness and his truly extraordinary generosity. We will miss his cantankerous but always ready humor, his legendary idiosyncrasies, and that great heart that was always worn right on his sleeve. Funeral Mass at St. Aloysius R.C. Church, Middle Neck Road, Great Neck, Friday, April 28, at 9:45 AM. Interment All Saints Churchyard, Great Neck. Services to be held Monday, May 1,2000 at 2pm at The Old First Reformed Church, 126 Seventh Avenue at Carroll Street, Brooklyn, NY. description: Harrah's Entertainment Inc. said yesterday that it would add 450 rooms to the Harrah's Atlantic City hotel and casino.

title: Less Than a Country
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Vine, less than a month old, is already known as the restaurant that lets you eat in a bank vault. A detail like that somehow sticks in the mind when the neighborhood is Wall Street, where people like the feeling of being close to money, or at least the fleeting whiff of it. The vaults, intended for private parties, lurk below street level. The main dining room, at the corner of the Exchange Building, has nothing financial about it other than a view of the New York Stock Exchange. It's a small, cool room with big windows, a bar with a thick green translucent counter and waiters outfitted by A/X Armani Exchange.

title: Stoking the Fire for Molten Standards
description: The Welsh contralto Iris Williams exemplifies a decorous pop formality that British singers tend to bring to the performance of American popular standards. Standing at an ocean's distance from the Broadway and Hollywood traditions that produced the songs, these singers have an approach that is often reverent to the degree that even the slangiest numbers are translated into semi-art songs.

title: Father of Cuban Boy Gains Right to Join, Not End, Case
description: In a mixed decision in the Elian Gonzalez case, a federal appeals court today put off a request by the boy's father to serve as his sole legal representative, which would have effectively ended the court challenge.

title: In Miami, Some Cuban-Americans Take Less Popular Views
description: As a playwright in Cuba, Carmen Duarte knew all too well what state-controlled repression meant. Her work was often censored, Ms. Duarte said, and she and the actors in her theater troupe were once beaten by policemen incensed by the scathing social commentary in one of her plays.

title: VICORP HIRES SALOMON TO EXPLORE COMPANY'S OPTIONS
description: Vicorp Restaurants Inc., which operates and franchises Bakers Square and Village Inn restaurants, said yesterday that it had hired Salomon Smith Barney to help explore strategic alternatives. In February, Vicorp, based in Denver, said it received unsolicited bids from interested buyers. Vicorp formed a special committee to review the offers but has not accepted any of them. Vicorp operates and franchises about 370 restaurants in the Rocky Mountain region, upper Midwest, Florida, California and Arizona. The company had $359 million in revenue last year. Its shares were up 75 cents, at $21, in Nasdaq trading. At that price, the company's stock is worth more than $140 million.

title: Rate Increase Fails to Halt Euro's Slide Against Dollar
description: The European Central Bank raised interest rates today for the fourth time in six months but Europe's common currency, the euro, again defied its guardians and plunged to another record low against the American dollar.

title: U.S. Drops Case Against CUNY Professor
description: After charging a trailblazing anthropology professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice last year with embezzling money from a $2.6 million federal grant, federal prosecutors have abruptly moved to dismiss the charges, although they say they are still investigating the case.

title: Encircling Edward Weston With Modernist Friends
description: When photography was almost exclusively black and white and 8 by 10 inches, museum exhibitions of even the best images ran some danger of boring the audience's socks off with sameness. This was not all that long ago. As I recall an extensive Edward Weston retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in 1975, everything seemed to be just about the same size and color (black and white), and framed the same way. Eventually my impatient younger self found the wall-after-wall repetition of duly important photographs interminable, and I fled to the grand variety of the paintings galleries for a little relief.

title: No-Good Men, Foolish Choices and Childbirth on the Floor of a Wal-Mart
description: Young Novalee Nation (Natalie Portman), the unwed mother-to-be in ''Where the Heart Is,'' is terribly phobic about the number five, and about five minutes into this astonishingly shameless melodrama with its lower-class sweetheart heroine, you'll start to feel exactly the same way. The movie seems to be stuck with its own five fixation, too, because what feels like every five minutes, a new character or situation is introduced to keep things lively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIA, SISTER MARY GERALDINE
description: TOBIA-Sister Mary Geraldine. The board and staff of United Neighborhood Houses mourn the loss of Sister Mary Geraldine. Her dedication and tenacious advocacy on behalf of the city's poorest children and families will be missed. UNH and her settlement house friends and colleagues extend their condolences to the Center for Family Life and her family.

title: Sports of The Times; A Springtime Tale Of Two (Big-Time) Cities
description: In the next few days, men from Toronto and men from New York will be aggressing each other with sticks, elbows and the occasional hard slide.

title: Entering In Style
description: In anticipation of an encyclopedic exhibition devoted to Art Nouveau that opens on Oct. 8, the National Gallery of Art in Washington has acquired a turn-of-the-century entrance from a Paris Metro station, one of the few that were not destroyed after being removed in the 1930's and 40's. Of the 141 models designed by the French architect Hector Guimard and installed from 1900 to 1913, only 86 remain in place. This one, dating from around 1898, was a gift to the gallery from Robert and Arlene Kogod, Washington collectors.

title: Doubleheaders After MetroStars
description: A series of four doubleheaders featuring eight prominent international clubs will be played after MetroStars' games in Major League Soccer at Giants Stadium this season.

description: Growing up in the projects of East Las Vegas, Claudia Meza wore black lipstick, flashed gang signs and concealed knives and brass knuckles in her baggy pants.

title: Corrections
description: Charts in Business Day on April 18 and 19 showing the biggest one-day percentage gains in the Nasdaq composite index omitted some. The fifth-biggest was 6.02 percent, on Sept. 8, 1998; the eighth-biggest was on Oct. 9, 1998 (5.17 percent); the ninth-biggest was on Sept. 1, 1998 (5.06 percent); and the 10th-biggest was on Oct. 15, 1998 (4.55 percent). This Tuesday the index had its third-biggest increase, 6.57 percent.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISS, TIBOR, MD
description: KISS-Tibor, MD, 77. On April 26, 2000 after a prolonged illness, surrounded by his family Linda and their children Barbra and Andrew (Kim). Born in Novi Sad, Yugoslavia to the Chief Rabbi Henrik Kiss and Gizella. After surviving WWII he became a surgeon in Hungary and later immigrated to the United States during the Hungarian Revolution. During his career as a Physiatrist he was on the staff of Bellevue Hospital, the Manhattan VA Hospital and St. Vincent's Hospital Departments of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. Graveside services private. The family will receive visitors at 4 Washington Square Village, Apt. 4A on Friday afternoon from 1 to 6PM and on Saturday after sundown at 104-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, Apt 11E.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBARD, MILDRED W.
description: HUBBARD-Mildred W. of Riverhead, on April 26, 2000, age 94. Loving wife of the late Seth A. Hubbard. Cherished sister of Peggy Snow, of Waterford, Conn. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. On June 21, 1995, on her 90th Birthday, the Riverhead Bridge Club proclaimed this day to be Mildred Hubbard Day. Mildred was a member of the Riverhead Bridge Club for 40 years. Monies raised by the Bridge Club were donated to Central Suffolk Hospital. She was also an Officer of the Hospital Auxillary, Member of the Riverhead Garden Club and Riverhead Women's Club. Reposing Reginald H. Tuthill Funeral Home, Inc. 406 East Main St., Riverhead, NY, Friday, April 28, 2000, 2-4 & 7-9 p.m. Celebration of the Liturgy on Saturday, April 29, 2000, 9:30 a.m. St John the Evangelist R.C. Church, Riverhead, NY. Interment to follow in St. John's Cemetery, Riverhead, NY. Contributions may be made to Central Suffolk Hospital or The Hubbard Park.

title: Divine Form And Spirit
description: LIKE those roses known as repeat bloomers that appear first in spring, then in summer, the exhibition ''Art and Oracle: Spirit Voices of Africa'' opened twice this week at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. On Wednesday, it made its bow to the general public. But two days earlier it was introduced to a somewhat more rarified audience when a Yoruba priest, chanting prayers, welcomed the spiritual powers-that-be to view an ensemble of objects created long ago in their honor.

title: Herbert Wechsler, Legal Giant, Is Dead at 90
description: Herbert Wechsler, the Columbia Law School professor whose work on criminal and constitutional law helped shape the nation's legal system over half a century, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

description: In an unusual step for the diplomatic establishment, two major Foreign Service organizations are asking the Senate to lift a politically instigated hold on two ambassadorial appointments that have been blocked for nearly nine months.

Most were black or Hispanic, all were on parole or probation. More than a few saw themselves as casualties of pathologically racist courts.

title: McCain Aides Put Session With Bush in Doubt, Saying Agenda Is Sticking Point
description: Even as he continued to reach out to Democrats, Gov. George W. Bush suddenly had to deal today with new tension within his own party as aides to his onetime rival, Senator John McCain, threatened to cancel a scheduled reconciliation session.

description: Dr. Martin H. Stein, a psychoanalyst who was president of the New York Psychoanalytic Society in the 1960's, died on April 19 at New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: A Digital Prism Refracts Reality
description: Toward the end of ''Time Code,'' Ana Pauls (Mia Maestro), a fetching young avant-garde filmmaker in a minimal black dress, arrives at the offices of Red Mullet Productions to pitch a project to a roomful of harried executives. Accompanied by the spacey hip-hop stylings of her boyfriend (Alessandro Nivola), she drops names -- Leibniz, Eisenstein, Walter Gropius, Guy DeBord -- like a highfalutin gossip columnist or a desperately trendy graduate student giving her first paper at the Modern Language Association. In her heart-stopping, unplaceable accent, Ana explains that the advances of art and technology have made it necessary for filmmakers ''to go beyond the paradigm of collage.''

title: Chase Hires Executive for Equities Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Steven Black as head of institutional equities. It is his first position since he resigned from a similar post at Salomon Smith Barney Inc. over a year and a half ago.

title: Janet Cohen
description: 'Drawing the Perfect Game'

title: Defining Art as a Moment To Be Seized and X-Rayed
description: Conceptual art, with its emphasis on language, ideas and performance rather than fixed visual imagery, is nothing if not ephemeral. Its best friend is the still or video camera, which records and saves it for -- well, posterity. When Conceptual art came along in the 1960's, with its idealistic aim of emphasizing art as notion or process rather than product, Conceptual photography naturally sprang up as its handmaiden. Both joined the more traditional categories of painting, sculpture, printmaking and such as part of the contemporary art repertory.

title: Building Rome By Computer
description: When Russell Crowe, dressed in full Roman regalia, strides onto the dusty floor of the Colosseum, the camera follows his gaze in a 360-degree sweep of the scene, taking in the three tiers of cheering people, the rippling flags, the glinting armor. It is all very big, very imposing and very real.

title: EToys Loss Widens to $48.4 Million
description: EToys Inc., whose shares have dropped 91 percent from their high, said today that its fourth-quarter loss widened to $48.4 million as it spent more on promotion and the opening of distribution centers.

title: EXCEL LEGACY SAYS IT PLANS TO SELL $110 MILLION IN ASSETS
description: The Excel Legacy Corporation, a real estate developer, said late on Wednesday that it planned to sell some assets that are expected to generate up to $110 million in cash. The company said the assets to be sold included properties and small development projects. Excel, which has about $279 million in assets, added that it planned to use the cash from the sales to retire the company's estimated $48 million in short-term debt, to develop projects and to repurchase up to 10 percent of the company's 36.8 million shares. Excel's stock rose 18.75 cents, to $2.9375, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: The Next Thing, After DVD
description: Now that we're getting acquainted with digital video disc, or DVD, have you heard about digital videotape? The abbreviation is D-VHS, and it is a whole other system. A new device is promised.

title: Death of a Showman
description: Theatricality went to the core of David Merrick, who died Tuesday at 88 in London. As a producer, he dominated Broadway from 1954 until 1980 with a string of hits that included ''Gypsy,'' ''Hello, Dolly!'' and ''42nd Street.'' He possessed a keen commercial and artistic sensibility and an almost hostile business acumen, as well as a flair for publicity that will link his name forever with the likes of P. T. Barnum. He belonged in the glare of the footlights as much as any producer ever has.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRICK, DAVID
description: MERRICK-David, 88, died peacefully in his sleep in London, Tuesday, April 25, 2000. Beloved husband and cherished companion of Natalie Lloyd Merrick. Burial private. A memorial service will be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the David Merrick Arts Foundation Fund for New American Musicals, 124 East 71st Street, NYC, NY.10021.

title: What a Texas Record Can't Tell

I say this not as a proponent or a critic of Mr. Gore's proposals, but as a Texan, and a rather chauvinistic one at that. (Is there any other kind?)

title: Just a Couple of Salesmen, Going Nowhere, and Slowly
description: ''Here's to the profound religious experience that comes from doing a job well and being grossly underpaid,'' Larry (Kevin Spacey) says to his fellow salesmen in ''The Big Kahuna,'' a picture that from its low-budget looks guarantees the pleasure that can come only from a labor of love. If the movie looked any cheaper, you might think you were paying more to get into the theater than was spent on making the film.

description: The New Jersey Division of Investment is considering putting $200 million it oversees for state employees and retirees into its first emerging-market investments.

title: Rogue Sells Horns; Hope Is Free

He's carrying a virus so contagious that it will sweep through the whole town, making people behave as they never have before. Harold Hill's got it, all right; Harold Hill's got rhythm.

title: Janitors, Long Paid Little, Demand a Larger Slice

title: Mayor Giuliani's Prostate Cancer
description: One can only hope that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's battle with prostate cancer is successful and mercifully brief. New York's mayor, who has generally appeared in good health, surprised the political world yesterday by announcing that screening tests during his annual physical had shown signs of cancer and that a follow-up biopsy had confirmed that finding. Fortunately, the cancer seems to have been detected at an early stage, so the odds for successful treatment and cure may be good. But what impact the cancer will have on the mayor's health or his campaign for the United States Senate will not be known until he and his doctors settle on a course of treatment, which could range from surgery to radiation to hormones.

title: SCIENTISTS REPORT THE FIRST SUCCESS OF GENE THERAPY
description: For the first time, gene therapy has unequivocally succeeded, scientists say. Doctors used the treatment, which involves adding working genes to cells, to save the lives of several infants who might otherwise have died of a severe immune disorder.

description: Days before the opening of what promises to be one of the biggest trials in Westchester County in recent years, a defendant in the case accused federal prosecutors today of engaging in a ''smear campaign'' motivated by politics and intended to embarrass his wife, the district attorney of Westchester County.

title: Britain Ties Money for Zimbabwe to the End of Land Seizures
description: Eight hours of tense negotiations on Zimbabwe's deepening political crisis ended in impasse tonight after Britain refused to provide extra money for land resettlement until government-backed squatters end their occupation of hundreds of white-owned farms.

title: News Analysis; Big Choices, Little Time
description: The announcement by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday that he has been struck with prostate cancer presents him with a series of pressing medical decisions in the weeks ahead. But the confluence of the diagnosis and the state's election calendar could force Mr. Giuliani to make some pivotal decisions about his Senate candidacy rapidly, and over roughly the same difficult period of time.

description: After 150 rounds of frenzied bidding that pushed prices beyond seven times what had been expected, an auction for licenses to operate a new generation of wireless devices linked to the Internet came to a close today, reaping the British government a huge $35.5 billion windfall.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a meeting of religious and civic leaders in the Bronx to discuss recent killings of livery-cab drivers misstated the title of one participant, Keith L. Wright. He is a state assemblyman, not a city councilman.

title: Booming In Size And Brio
description: More than 150 years ago, San Antonio gave Texas its enduring symbol of us-against-them pride and courage, the Alamo. Austin's moment in the sun is now. Its technology boom has generated fortunes that surpass even the staggering riches earned by the state's cattle and oil barons.

title: Aetna's Operating Profit Rose 16% in First Quarter
description: Aetna, the nation's largest health insurance company, said yesterday that its first-quarter operating profit rose 16 percent, helped by reduced losses at its Prudential Health Care unit and a rebound in international business, including financial services in Asia and Latin America.

title: Fruit of the Loom Names Chief
description: Fruit of the Loom Ltd., which is still fighting its previous chief executive over a $65 million debt, gave the acting chief executive, Dennis S. Bookshester, the company's top job today.

title: Review Board Staff Faults Police on Stop-and-Frisk Reports
description: Investigators for the Civilian Complaint Review Board have determined that police officers routinely fail to file the required paperwork after frisking or searching people on New York City's streets. The board's staff has prepared a preliminary report that raises questions about whether the widespread violation of department policy has hampered police supervisors overseeing the judgment of officers on patrol.

title: CHECKFREE IN DEAL FOR BANK OF AMERICA ONLINE ASSETS
description: CheckFree Holdings, an electronic billing and payment services company, said yesterday that it would buy Bank of America's online bill payment service. In exchange, Bank of America will receive a 16 percent stake in CheckFree. The stake, valued at $325 million, would make the bank CheckFree's largest shareholder. CheckFree will get Bank of America's electronic billing and payment assets, including operating centers in Houston and San Francisco. Most of the centers' 600 employees will become CheckFree employees. CheckFree, based in Norcross, Ga., already has 400,000 of the bank's 2.1 million online customers as subscribers and will get 300,000 more from the agreement. CheckFree shares rose $14.8125, or 37 percent, to $54.375.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: A Huge British Telecom Latin Investment
description: In an indication of the appeal of the Latin American market for wireless communications, British Telecom said today that it planned to invest billions of dollars in the region.

title: 5 People Are Shot to Death, And a Lawyer Is Arrested
description: An immigration lawyer went on a shooting spree on the outskirts of Pittsburgh yesterday afternoon, killing five people, including a Jewish woman, two Asian men, one Indian and one black man and critically injuring a sixth, police officials said.

title: Execution Frays Canada-Vietnam Relations
description: Canada has withdrawn its ambassador from Vietnam and will boycott ceremonies tomorrow marking the 25th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War to protest Vietnam's execution of a Vietnamese-born Canadian woman for drug trafficking.

title: LATIN PURCHASES BY AES
description: In an effort to simplify control of its Brazilian holdings, the Virginia-based power company AES offered up to 1.1 billion reais to buy all outstanding nonvoting shares of Sao Paulo's largest electricity distributor, Eletropaulo Metropolitana. Separately, Electricite de France offered as much as 635.2 million reais for all of the voting shares of another Sao Paulo distributor, Light Servicios de Electricidade. In Venezuela, AES offered to acquire 51 percent of the ordinary shares of Electricidad de Caracas in a deal valued at $863 million. Jennifer L. Rich

title: A Broad Ban on Snowmobiles
description: On Thursday Donald J. Barry, the assistant secretary of the interior for fish and wildlife and parks, announced the effective end of recreational snowmobiling in all but a handful of America's national parks. The ban is not the result of new legislation or new regulations. It is the result of a new commitment to laws and rules that have been on the books for years, including executive orders that prohibit the use of off-road vehicles except where authorized. Secretary Barry's announcement represents one of those moments, so vital to the health of our national parks, when the Park Service stands back and compares its public mission with the status quo. Without such moments from time to time, we would still be feeding black bears along the roads in Yellowstone.

title: Police Say DNA Evidence Links Suspect to Rape on the West Side
description: Police officials said yesterday that DNA evidence indicated that the rape of a woman on the West Side of Manhattan two weeks ago had been committed by the same man they had arrested in a series of attacks on women on the East Side.

title: Personal Income Jumped 0.7% In March, Faster Than Spending
description: Americans' personal incomes rose in March at a faster rate than spending for the first time in five months, paced by wage gains and census hiring, government data showed today.

title: Devils, Hoping to Avoid 2-0 Deficit, Keep a Loose Profile
description: The Devils boarded the bus to the quaint, claustrophobic rink a half hour north of downtown this afternoon, feeling like carefree kids on a field trip revisiting their junior hockey days.

title: Cone Rewinds, and Stifles Blue Jays
description: It was as if a grainy newsreel image appeared on the mound at Yankee Stadium last night, the pitcher bent at the waist, swinging his arms up and down, up and down, the way Catfish Hunter and Don Drysdale used to do. After the pitcher pumped his arms in this antiquated style, he threw the ball.

title: A Mafia Family's Second Wind; Authorities Say Bonannos, All but Written Off, Are Back
description: Less than a decade ago, the Bonanno crime family -- once one of the nation's most feared Mafia organizations -- was galloping toward extinction. Undermined by deadly rivalries and by federal investigations, the family was shunned by the other New York Mafia families as a fractious, unreliable partner.

title: Miami Police Chief Quits in Raid Fallout
description: Saying he could no longer work for a divisive mayor in a city that needed to heal, the police chief, William O'Brien, tearfully resigned today, and became the latest casualty of Cuban-American anger over the federal government's raid to seize 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez.

description: Toon Hermans, a beloved Dutch stage performer who was as comfortable in poetry, song and folk philosophy as in making people ache with laughter, died last Saturday in a hospital in Utrecht, the Netherlands. He was 83.

title: The Shadow in Silicon Valley
description: Now that the stock market seems to have settled down, however briefly, we can turn our attention to a drama in Silicon Valley. Time is running out for the freshman class of start-ups that flooded the market three years ago. And the valley, built on start-ups since Fairchild Semiconductor paved the way for the microprocessor in 1958, is nervous.

title: 'Free' Music Can Free the Artist
description: Unlike many of my fellow artists, I support the sharing of music files on the Internet. The Recording Industry Association of America has sued Napster, an Internet application that helps people find, copy and share songs free of charge on the Web, arguing that it encourages users to violate copyright laws. Some artists have spoken out against Napster as a threat to their livelihoods, and most recently Dr. Dre and the band Metallica have become involved in lawsuits against the service.

title: Sports of The Times; Commission Has to Show Its Punch
description: ALTHOUGH most boxing aficionados will be concerned only with Lennox Lewis's ability to defend two-thirds of the world heavyweight title against Michael Grant tonight at Madison Square Garden, others will be scrutinizing the New York State Athletic Commission's attempt to strengthen its punch, alias its credibility.

title: Where Islam And Public Debate Have Often Bonded
description: For more than a century, the press in Iran has sporadically been more than a mere transmitter of news. It has also been one big open-ended conversation in which ideas are discussed and opinions shaped.

description: A group of American companies that had factories in Nazi Germany plans to establish a fund that would aid people who suffered persecution under Hitler's rule, a gesture that comes as more American multinational corporations acknowledge having benefited from forced and slave labor during World War II.

description: Determined to change the rules of competition in the software industry, the Justice Department and 17 states asked a federal judge today to break Microsoft into two parts and seriously restrain its behavior while the breakup is being carried out.

description: Donald L. Evans, a Texas oil and gas businessman who presided over the record-breaking fund-raising for Gov. George W. Bush during the Republican primaries, was named today as the chairman of Mr. Bush's presidential campaign.

title: MARRIOTT TO SELL 14 PROPERTIES TO WOLVERINE
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it would sell 14 assisted-living communities to affiliates of the Wolverine Equities Company for $194 million in cash. Although best known as a hotel-chain operator, Marriott is the largest operator of communities for older people in the United States, running 146 communities with more than 25,000 units. The 14 properties, known as Brighton Gardens, are in North Carolina, Maryland, Illinois, Mississippi, Ohio, New Jersey, Georgia, Kansas, Nebraska and Florida. Marriott has its headquarters in Washington. Wolverine is an affiliate of the Staubach Company, a Dallas-based real estate company formed by the former Dallas Cowboys quarterback Roger Staubach.

title: ERICSSON'S PROFIT QUADRUPLES
description: The Swedish wireless company Ericsson said its profit quadrupled in its first quarter as margins for its network business doubled. The company's mobile phone unit remained a sore point as profits continued to be weak. Pretax profit rose to 6.1 billion Swedish kronor, or $681.3 million, from 1.3 billion kronor during the corresponding period a year before. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: The Jets' First Two Draftees Will Go Through It Together
description: Their agents had taken over a sports bar in South Carolina for a draft party. Defensive end Shaun Ellis of Tennessee and linebacker John Abraham of South Carolina were together in the noisy room two weeks ago with their families when the Jets called. Ellis and Abraham were told that they would be selected as the 12th and 13th picks in the first round, giving the friends from South Carolina a chance to improve the Jets' anemic pass rush.

title: Stumbling Efforts in East Timor
description: In East Timor, where pro-Indonesian militias went on a rampage last summer, the United Nations has taken on an ambitious reconstruction mission with inadequate means. Not surprisingly, the results to date have been disappointing. Unless faster progress can be achieved in creating jobs, resettling refugees and establishing the rule of law, there is a serious risk of new violence.

title: Tapes Reveal Talks About Money for Higher I.B.F. Rankings
description: Federal prosecutors in the trial of the leaders of the International Boxing Federation today began introducing jurors to dozens of secretly recorded audio tapes and videotapes obtained by their star witness, who said he had received many of the illicit payments made by boxers and managers in exchange for higher rankings and more lucrative bouts.

title: Piazza Hurt; Mets Lose 3rd Straight
description: While the Mets played out the final innings of another dreadful game tonight, their franchise player was getting precautionary X-rays at a hospital.

title: Right's Anti-ABM Weapon: A Senate Clause on Russia
description: In their battle to scuttle President Clinton's limited national missile defense system, Senate conservatives have a little-noted weapon -- a clause they inserted into another pact leaving it up to senators, and not President Clinton, to decide whether Russia inherited the Soviet role in the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.

description: Intel to Phase Out Processor Serial Numbers Attacked by Privacy Advocates

title: The Casino Land Shuffle
description: The lure of a gambling casino to help underdeveloped areas reminds us of the fabled monkey's paw that promises largess, then delivers misfortune as part of the bargain. With the promise of money and jobs, the casino business carries with it costly social problems, siphoning cash from many who can ill afford to lose it and feeding the addictions of chronic gamblers. Still, a number of New York politicians have fallen under the spell of the casino industry, and they are supporting a land swap under phony pretenses to facilitate a new gaming center in one of the poorest areas of the Catskills.

title: Gregory Gillespie, 64, an Unflinching Painter
description: Gregory Gillespie, an artist whose probing, urgent, often bizarre paintings occupied a singular place in the history of late-20th-century representation, died on Wednesday at his home in Belchertown, Mass, an apparent suicide. He was 64.

description: All this week, Gov. George W. Bush campaigned with Democrats at his side to show he is sincere in his pledge that, as president, he would end the capital's ''cycle of bitterness.'' And certainly he had enthusiastic support from those who crossed party lines to stand with him.

title: Gore Would Link Federal Aid to School Performance
description: Venturing onto Gov. George W. Bush's home turf and grabbing a theme from his campaign agenda, Vice President Al Gore called today for using the power of the federal government's purse strings to pressure failing schools to raise test scores and to reduce dropout rates.

description: Stanford's track team, which rarely visits the Drake Relays, was out in force yesterday in Des Moines.

Jesse Jackson's visit to Wallingford, Conn., to urge town officials to observe Martin Luther King's Birthday referred incorrectly to a white supremacist's use of a bullhorn. He used it to shout, ''You people are inferior!,'' not to give his name to a reporter.

title: Troubled Center For Mentally Ill Will Be Closed In New Jersey
description: An aging New Jersey psychiatric hospital long criticized as substandard and recently plagued by a rash of escapes and assaults on patients will be closed over the next three years, state officials announced yesterday.

title: Cavorting in the Shower In Appropriate Costumes
description: Sarah Michelson and Julie Atlas Muz promised to address demolition, death without rebirth, high calorie intake and makeovers in ''Blister Me,'' a new performance-art piece they presented on April 21 at Dixon Place. Happily, none of that was apparent in this enjoyably silly 50-minute romp by two denizens of downtown dance and theater.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Post Decline of 2% on the Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market slipped 2 percent in the most recent month -- a period of great volatility for the Nasdaq -- the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the market, said yesterday.

title: At the Modern, a Strike Over a Traditional Issue: Wages
description: The Museum of Modern Art, bastion of the sublime, looked more like a battle zone yesterday, as more than a hundred striking museum workers picketed out front, shouting at museumgoers not to go in and even urging them to visit the rival Whitney instead.

title: NCR SAYS IT WILL ADD AROUND 1,000 EMPLOYEES THIS YEAR
description: The NCR Corporation, a computer and software company and the No. 1 maker of automated teller machines, said yesterday that it would add about 1,000 employees in 2000, expanding its work force 3 percent. NCR, which has 32,000 employees, plans to hire a total of about 4,000 people, accounting for normal attrition. Most of the new employees will install and run large databases and maintain A. T. M.'s. The rest will aid NCR in marketing and selling products. NCR is shedding its money-losing personal computer business to focus more on A. T. M.'s and so-called data warehouses, which collect information on a company's customers. The hirings come after NCR cut 1,500 jobs in October as it began phasing out the PC business.

title: ALLEN SYSTEMS, A SOFTWARE DEVELOPER, TO GET VIASOFT
description: A privately held software developer, Allen Systems Group, has agreed to acquire Viasoft Inc. for $8.40 a share, a total of $152 million. Viasoft, which is based in Phoenix, makes software used by businesses to manage their computer systems. Allen Systems, whose headquarters are in Naples, Fla., makes similar software. The deal was announced late on Thursday. Viasoft's stock jumped 47 percent yesterday, gaining $2.59375 a share, to $8.0625. Viasoft had $45.3 million in revenue in the nine months that ended on March 31.

title: Sweatshop Monitor Invites Corporate Input
description: Representatives of universities belonging to a new group set up by students to monitor apparel factories led a call yesterday to give companies a greater say in the group's work. The move came as Nike, the footwear giant, moved once again against a university that had joined the monitoring group.

The outburst by the woman, Sante Kimes, came after Justice Rena K. Uviller of State Supreme Court repeatedly told a defense lawyer, Mel Sachs, to stop asking certain questions and end his cross-examination of a detective.

title: Dentist Who Lost License Arrested in Midtreatment
description: A man whose dental license was suspended in 1990 was arrested yesterday for practicing dentistry without a license, after people he had treated developed mouth infections and their teeth turned black or fell out, prosecutors said.

title: A Claim-Buster by Calling; From U.F.O. Dreams To Federal Schemes, He Debunks Them All
description: Late one night in 1954, Robert L. Park was driving back to Walker Air Force Base in Roswell, N.M., on a desolate stretch of West Texas highway. News reports of U.F.O. sightings were practically a daily occurrence, but when he saw a dazzling blue-green light streak across the sky, he figured out precisely what it was. After all, he was an electronics officer, a lieutenant overseeing the installation of a new radar system in Roswell, and he recognized the fluorescent illumination of an ice meteorite plunging into the atmosphere.

title: Political Violence at Home Made Haitians Flee, Boat Survivors Say
description: Survivors of a shipwreck that stranded more than 250 Haitians on a barren island of the Bahamas 200 miles southeast of here said today that they had fled Haiti aboard a stolen boat in a desperate attempt to escape the mounting violence that has swept through their homeland as elections approach.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Stockwell Day, a conservative politician from Western Canada who hopes to become prime minister next year, misstated the precedent for Western Canadians. If elected, Mr. Day would be the fourth in nearly four decades, not the second. The article also referred incorrectly to Joe Clark, a former prime minister who would be left out of a proposed merger of conservative parties. He was not the last prime minister from Western Canada; Kim Campbell of British Columbia was, in 1993.

title: Sex, Disco Ducks and, Oh, Yes, Kent State
description: Don't blame the 70's for the fact that ''The 70's'' may be among the worst mini-series ever made. Sure, the decade wasn't one of the most memorable of the century -- in fact, it barely made the Top 10 -- but it had its moments of drama and inspiration. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAFIAN, HENRY J.
description: ZAFIAN-Henry J., a retired partner of the intellectual property law firm of Fish & Neave, New York City and Palo Alto, California, died on April 26, 2000. He was 78 years old and lived in New York City. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. Mr. Zafian joined Fish & Neave upon his graduation from Columbia Law School in 1948, was Managing Partner from 1970 to 1976 and remained in active practice with the firm until his retirement in 1988. He specialized in patent and related litigation, often of long duration such as the patent and antitrust litigation involving the antibiotic tetracycline in Federal tribunals from the early 1950's into the 1980's, including proceedings in numerous District Courts, the Federal Trade Commission, four U.S. Courts of Appeals and the U.S. Supreme Court. He was born in Bayonne, New Jersey and graduated from high school at age 14. Upon graduating in 1941 from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn with a degree in mechanical engineering, he was employed as an engineer by General Electric Company until, after World War II began, he enlisted in the United States Air Corps where in 1943 he received a degree in meteorology from New York University and thereafter served principally as a reconnaissance meteorology officer, including weather flights in the North Atlantic before D-Day in Europe and service in the first hurricane reconnaissance squadron in the Caribbean. Mr. Zafian is survived by five children: Lisa Weaver of Slingerlands, New York; Tracy Zafian of Cambridge, Massachusetts; Amanda Zafian of New York City; Peter Zafian of Denver, Colorado; and Colin Zafian of Telluride, Colorado; four grandchildren; and a sister, Louise Stone, of Santa Monica, California. There will be a gathering of family and friends to celebrate Henry's memory on Monday, May 1, from 6:00 to 8:00 pm at The University Club (One West 54th Street, N.Y. City).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, ROBERT L.B.
description: TOBIN-Robert L.B. The Metropolitan Opera Association mourns with profound sadness the death of our very dear friend, Robert L. B. Tobin. An honorary director at the time of his death, Robert joined the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association as a managing director in 1976. He has left a legacy of more than three decades of dedicated service, as vice president from 1991-1999, as a long-time member of the executive committee, as chairman of the production and art committees, and through service on the nominating committee. We recall with admiration Robert's prodigious knowledge of opera, theater, and contemporary art. These passionate interests were evident in his continual efforts to preserve the Met's heritage through his work with our archives, in his family's support for our pioneering production of Berg's ''Lulu,'' and in his own support for an all-Stravinsky evening designed by David Hockney. Robert's commitment to bringing the contemporary repertory to our stage is also reflected in his leadership gift for our production of ''Porgy and Bess'' and in his underwriting of our commission for Philip Glass's ''The Voyage.'' A founding member, with his beloved mother, Mag Tobin, of our Golden Horseshoe Program, he also gave leadership support to our first endowment campaign and to our current effort to secure the Met in the new century. A memorable presence whenever he was in the opera house, he particularly relished attending opening nights and premieres. We were especially touched this winter when, despite failing health, he remained almost to the conclusion of the supper he gave for the cast and the company after ''The Merry Widow'' premiere. We remember with deep affection Robert's abiding devotion to the Metropolitan Opera, his elegance, his passionate commitment to artistic excellence, his wise counsel during challenging times for our company, and his irreverent wit even in the most dire of personal circumstances. Robert's extraordinary personal courage during his extended period of ill health and his heroic effort to meet his Metropolitan Opera board responsibilities were an inspiration to all of us. Most of all, his passing is a profound loss to those of us who were privileged to know him as a friend. Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford, Honorary Chairman James Kinnear, Chairman Paul Montrone, President Joseph Volpe, General Manager

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, EUGENE ROBERT
description: BLACK-Eugene Robert, retired investment banker and longtime playwright, died April 24 at Mount Sinai. A memorial service will be held Sunday, 2pm, Saint Luke's Episcopal Church, East Hampton. Gene, as he was known, was born in Atlanta on July 19, 1924, the son of Eugene R. Black (later president of the World Bank) and Dolly Blalock Black. He got his bachelor's at Yale, served as an officer in the Marine Corps and attended Oxford University after World War II. Gene later worked for Lazard Freres, where he was an international general partner. He effected corporate mergers and acquisitions, helped invest for the firm's own account, managed Eurodollar loan syndications and represented Lazard at international meetings in Washington. He also worked for years in Brazil, advised Japan's Sanwa Bank and served the Carter Administration as Special Assistant to the Secretary of the Interior for Economic Development. Gene devoted great energy to public theater projects. He was at various times chairman of New York's Circle in the Square, chairman of the Mayor's Cultural Committee, chairman of the Mayor's Report on the New York Theater, and a board member of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company and Stratford Shakespeare Theater. Before and after retiring from Lazard he wrote 16 plays, usually under the pen name Franklyn MacGregor. Several plays, including ''Camelot Lost'' and ''The Cleansing of George Cuthbert,'' were produced off Broadway. He also wrote thrillers, screenplays and children's stories. His plots often turned on historical characters and scandals, from George Washington through the Kennedy and Clinton administrations. Gene was a man of huge good humor and zest for life. He seemed to know everybody and enjoyed dealing with people, ideas, food, golf, real estate and more. In addition to his wife, Susanne Hardwick Black, Gene is also survived by his three children, Susan Black Allen of New York, E. Robert Black of Beaufort, North Carolina, and Brittany Black of Palm Beach; two grandchildren, Lindsay and Clayton Allen; his sister Elizabeth Black Campbell; his brother William H. Black and his stepmother Susette Heath Black.

title: Decline of the Euro
description: The value of the euro has plunged more than 20 percent against the dollar in the 16 months since its adoption by 11 members of the European Union. The drop, from almost $1.20 in January 1999 to about 90 cents today, upsets Europeans who find a falling currency embarrassing. A deeper issue is that some Europeans fear the euro might be on the verge of free fall, which would raise the price of imports, thereby reducing living standards and adding to inflationary pressures. To keep inflation in check, the European Central Bank might decide to raise interest rates to slow the economy. American exporters worry that a falling euro -- which means a rising dollar -- will turn Europeans away from American products.

title: The Eroded Self
description: Monica Lewinsky is a most unlikely spokesperson for the virtues of reticence. But in addition to selling designer handbags, she has emerged after her internship as an advocate of privacy in cyberspace. ''People need to realize that your e-mails can be read and made public, and that you need to be cautious,'' she warned recently on ''Larry King Live.'' Lewinsky was unsettled by Kenneth Starr's decision to subpoena Washington bookstores for receipts of her purchases; in her underappreciated biography, ''Monica's Story,'' she points to the bookstore subpoenas as one of the most invasive moments in the Starr investigation. But she was also distraught when the prosecutors subpoenaed her home computer. From the recesses of her hard drive, they retrieved e-mail messages that she had tried unsuccessfully to delete, along with the love letters she had drafted -- but never sent -- to the president. ''It was such a violation,'' Lewinsky complained to her biographer, Andrew Morton.

The show's creator and co-writer, Aaron Sorkin, loves this stuff; he served up plenty of it in his stage drama ''A Few Good Men.'' title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Lot Like Us
description: For more than 30 years, the photographer Mary Ellen Mark has been preoccupied with depicting society's voiceless and disregarded, the tough, unkempt fringes of the culture, the outcasts as well as the unsightly. Mark has photographed runaway street kids in Seattle, prostitutes and pimps in Bombay, inmates of prisons and mental wards -- not with the intent of exploiting these images for their shock value, but to reveal the common spark of humanity that links them to us. In MARY ELLEN MARK: American Odyssey (Aperture, $50), the black-and-white photographs continue to challenge our preconceptions, though her focus is on our country's eccentric as well as its outcasts. Here are photographs of a baby beauty pageant and senior citizens in dance classes, rodeos in Texas, Coney Island bodybuilders and Christian bikers. Images of celebrities abound as well: an aged Henry Miller with a companion, the blues singer Etta James sporting a flamboyant black feather hat. Some of the most poignant photographs are those of the Damm family, homeless when Mark first shot them living in their car in 1987, and again in 1994, squatting on an abandoned ranch. Also haunting are several updated portraits of a woman called Tiny, first photographed in Seattle as a 12-year-old street child, now shown middle-aged and naked in her bathtub, a single mother of five. Unlike Diane Arbus, to whom she has been unjustly compared, Mark emotionally engages her subjects, and through this bond we, as viewers, are drawn in too. Andrea Barnet

title: Volunteering On Vacation
description: AH, vacation. If lounging next to azure water -- breeze in the coconut palms, cool drink in hand -- sounds boring, maybe it's time for something completely different. That's the opinion of an increasing number of altruists who are spending weeks on volunteer or service vacations, performing tasks from clearing waste ditches in Mexico to reintroducing Przewalski horses in Mongolia. Among them are college students seeking an inexpensive, meaningful summer abroad, professionals on sabbatical and retirees and others who want a grass-roots sense of the cultures they visit and an engagement that can't be had from a cruise ship or tour bus.

title: Tom Cruise, Team Player
description: THE anticipated through-the-roof success of the sequel to ''Mission Impossible,'' ''M: I-2,'' should soothe any hurt feelings in the Tom Cruise camp over the actor's Oscar loss for ''Magnolia.'' Generally the Academy swoons over beautiful stars who go into ugly mode to show they can act, but Mr. Cruise's strutting, pelvis-jutting television sex guru, out to seduce and destroy the female half of the species, was perhaps too far off the empathy curve when compared with Michael Caine's kindly doctor, patron of wayward women, in ''The Cider House Rules.'' The incongruity of the dimpled megastar in vinyl vest and ponytail running a boot camp for misogynists might have delighted the critics, but Mr. Caine was the sentimental favorite. That is something Mr. Cruise has never been and is not likely ever to be, as he tackles one steep career cliff after another, alternating between conventional action movies and decidedly riskier enterprises with such talented eccentrics as Stanley Kubrick and Martin Scorsese and Paul Thomas Anderson.

title: RUTGERS UNION VOTE
description: Rutgers University administrators may have to vote a third time on whether to unionize. An election last month was so close, a runoff was held earlier this month. But the Public Employment Relations Commission, the state agency that oversees union elections, last week discovered 114 ballots from the first election in its post office box. The vote was to determine whether 856 mid-level administrators would join the New Jersey Education Association or the American Federation of Teachers or choose not to unionize. No explanation was given by Postal Service or state officials as to why the ballots did not surface until this week. It has not been decided whether the March election will trump the results of the second one, which have not been released. WENDY GINSBERG

title: Tight Races for Governor in N. Carolina
description: It was only 7:30 a.m. when a group of Republican loyalists began gathering today at Bailey's Coffee and News, but it was not too early for State Representative Leo Daughtry to start calling his opponent for governor, Richard Vinroot, a liberal.

title: Club in Turmoil (Not Knicks)
description: It was a familiar situation for the Knicks, waking up in recent days to headlines of dissension and controversy. But these stories were about the Toronto Raptors and not them.

title: April 23-29; That Whining Sound Of Lost Money and Lives
description: Responding to a study showing malaria is a major impediment to African development, the World Bank announced that it would pledge $500 million toward the eradication of the disease. The announcement came in Abuja, Nigeria, at the first international summit on the disease, which kills 3,000 Africans a day, most of them children.

title: Mexican Costumes
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article by Katherine Ashenburg on Mexican costumes, museums and shops (''A Colorful Trove in Mexico City,'' March 26): As one who has been in Mexico many times, I was pleased to see mentions of my favorite museums and of my acquaintances Pilar Fosado at Casa Victor and Ruth Lechuga.

description: THE whole idea that Hartford finished dead last among large American cities in mail-back census returns rankles Bill Rocks.

description: That Light Isn't Yonkers

title: SUITING UP WITH/Marcus Camby; What to Wear For Long Run In the Playoffs
description: MARCUS CAMBY seems to think that he's a slam-dunk for the title of best-dressed New York Knick: ''You're looking at him,'' he declares, oblivious to the fact that he's decked out in typical at-home splendor: rumpled T-shirt, shorts, unlaced sneakers with lolling tongues. But wait. Mr. Camby, the 6-foot-11 clotheshorse, and his personal tailor, Troy McSwain II, are about to share an unscheduled Joan Crawford moment inside the colossal master suite closet at Mr. Camby's mansion in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: A Favorite Son Returns To New York City Ballet
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Helgi Tomasson, the celebrated dancer from Iceland, stood onstage at the New York State Theater for the last time as a member of the New York City Ballet, accepting flowers and a resounding ovation for his final performance. On Wednesday, if he goes against his innately modest and reticent nature, he should be back on that stage, this time taking a bow as the choreographer of a world premiere for the company's spring gala program.

title: Reckonings; Dirty Windows Policy
description: So now it's official. The Justice Department has requested a breakup of Microsoft into two companies -- one piece that gets the rights to Windows and a defenestrated rump that gets the rights to everything else, mainly Microsoft Office.

title: A Martha Stewart Site
description: Martha Stewart, the television personality, has signed papers to buy a multimillion-dollar estate on Girdle Ridge Road in Bedford with a working farm, 18th-century summer home and 144 acres, said Geoff Thompson, a spokesman for the listing agent Houlihan/Lawrence. The property was listed at $15.7 million.

title: Diesel Fuel Is Not Necessarily a Bargain
description: PRICES may be dropping at the pump, but diesel fuel still isn't the deal it used to be.

description: WALTER HAHN plays golf on a public course in Nassau County about three times a week, and the recent fee increases approved by county officials don't make him happy.

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-30-00; No Gain, No Pain
description: On Black Monday 13 years ago, the date of the last market collapse, I was preparing to buy a seat on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. My firm's chief had offered to lend me the money. When I asked him about it, though, he told me he no longer could. ''I don't know if I'll be in business tomorrow,'' he said. ''Or if there'll even be an exchange. You're on your own.'' So I retreated to our lounge and there watched the televised chaos with the wizened pit veterans who had seen the market tumble in 1929. They had learned their profession in an era when eggs and butter and pork bellies mattered, and they tracked prices as if every tick added to their life stories.

title: Centuries of Gardening in Silk and Gold
description: THE glorious gardens of the Ottoman Empire live on in the embroideries that Turkish women produced over a 400-year period. They made these pictures in thread to cover floors, walls, windows and furniture in their homes as well as to edge sheets, towels, tablecloths and fabrics for gift wrapping. They even devised riotously colorful needlework for the scarves, robes, head coverings and shoes that they wore.

title: Defining Nature Through Art
description: GIGANTIC steel-framed urns coated with AstroTurf and adorned with artificial flowers might not be what visitors expect at Wave Hill, the 28-acre public garden overlooking the Hudson River. The urns (pictured at left) are part of ''Arcadia Now,'' an installation by Roberley Bell that uses only man-made substances. The piece is part of an exhibition titled ''Welcome'' that explores the relationship between people and nature.

title: Close Race Entering Last Day of Trials
description: Kimberly Vinoski and Over the Limit teamed up for a fault-free ride over 32 obstacles on the 15-plus-mile cross-country course to take the lead after the first two phases of the Rolex-Kentucky Horse Trials at the Kentucky Horse Park yesterday in Lexington.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Bethel, Conn.; Small-Town Charm vs. Rising Demand
description: ASK people why they chose to live in Bethel, Conn., and chances are they will talk about affordability. Take the case of Karon Worthington-Gillin, 39, and her husband, William Gillin, 33. When they moved to Connecticut from England two-and-a-half years ago, they planned to settle in Stamford. Then they saw the housing prices.

title: How to Pooh-Pooh $70 Million War Chests
description: FOR anyone living inside Washington's Beltway during an election year, it often appears as though political campaigns are taking over the country. The hinterlands complain loudly about the number of advertisements on television and radio. Fund-raisers raise seemingly enormous sums.

title: The Plain Old Still Camera Is Still in the Forefront
description: WHILE new media advance faster than the century, photography, a 19th-century product of the Industrial Revolution, continues to blanket the earth. Threatened repeatedly by newer discoveries like moving pictures, television, video and the Internet, it refuses to disappear. In March, Fotofest, the biennial photography festival in Houston, presented strong evidence that the still camera, and specifically a festival devoted to it, continue to play important roles on both local and international levels.

description: The gate is about to open on the Triple Crown, Thoroughbred horse racing's three top events -- the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes. Each race is preceded by a festival: the one leading up to the Kentucky Derby on Saturday in Louisville is in its final week; the Preakness Celebration begins May 12 in Baltimore; and the 132nd Belmont Stakes Festival is set for May 20 in Elmont, N.Y.

description: Robert L. B. Tobin, a Texas art collector and patron who built one of the most important theater design collections in the country, died on Wednesday at a hospital in San Antonio. He was 66.

description: To the Editor: Regarding ''One Traveler's Credo: Don't Tell, Don't Ask,'' by Robert Packard (April 2), I love learning about places I have not been or reliving memories. I remain fascinated with other people's travel stories and photographs. Unfortunately, most people I know do not.

description: Suzy Favor Hamilton and Nathan Leeper came back today at the Drake Relays to open their 2000 campaigns in style.

Giuliani, the mayor of New York and presumptive Republican nominee, announced that he had been diagnosed with prostate cancer. The disease, Mr. Giuliani said, was caught in its earliest stages, when, medical professionals noted, chances for a cure are excellent.

title: Investing; Wireless Choices Rise Over the Static in Europe
description: WHEN Europeans talk technology stocks, they are wont to refer to T.M.T. -- for technology, media and telecommunications. And these days, many are pinning their hopes on the third one -- the titans of telecommunications, particularly the wireless market.

title: Evelyn Irons, War Reporter, Is Dead at 99
description: Evelyn Graham Irons, a war correspondent who had a romance with the Bloomsbury novelist and poet Vita Sackville-West, died April 3 at her home in Brewster, N.Y. She was two months short of her 100th birthday.

title: RECORD LOANS
description: Small businesses in New Jersey received a record $200 million in loans over the six months ending March 31, with 873 loans getting approval from the state branch of the Small Business Administration. The administration's district director, Francisco A. Marrero, said loans increased 31 percent from the same period last year, when 666 loans were approved. The report also showed a 25 percent increase in grants from last year, when $175 million was approved. Loans to minorities jumped 62 percent from last year's figures. Mr. Marrero said 254 loans went to minority applicants, with funds totaling $52.1 million. Loans to African-American increased by 120 percent, and loans to Asian Americans, 58 percent. WENDY GINSBERG

title: The Way We Live Now: 4-30-00: Encounter with Jamie Rubin; Diaper Diplomacy
description: As part of my never-ending and so far entirely fruitless campaign to get high-ranking Clinton administration officials to change my children's diapers, I recently dragooned Jamie Rubin to my baby girl's room in order to teach him a thing or two about the real world.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Women in Evidence

title: I Shop, and the World Is a Better Place
description: I WAS hooked on shopping even before I began to travel overseas, and travel has sharpened my addiction. I excuse my enthusiasm for material things by putting it in perspective. After all, the urge to acquire goods from distant lands has changed the course of scientific and intellectual history. How much longer would the world have remained flat if Columbus hadn't been so keen to go shopping in Asia?

title: Personal Business; Funeral Homes Branch Out to Catch No-Frills Wave
description: LINDA KLEHAMMER knew she was in trouble when the first thing she saw as she walked into a St. Petersburg, Fla., funeral home was a table full of literature on financing.

title: The Suburban Nation
description: If Ruth Cullison's views are indeed typical of suburban women and other swing voters who will determine the outcome of the next presidential election, I despair for the republic (''Soccer Mom 2000,'' by James Bennet). This was a little like observing an election for prom king: does he have his mother's warmth? Is he stiff and humorless? Does anyone vote anymore on the basis of deeply held convictions and political realities?

title: PULSE: SUNDAY IN THE PARK; Shoofly Cream
description: Outdoor Activities is a sweet-smelling body lotion that wards off mosquitos, fleas and deer ticks. The cream, by Joey New York, sells for $22 for four fluid ounces at Sephora and Saks Fifth Avenue. Ingredients include citronella; bergamot, a flower essence, thought to be energizing; anti-chapping Peru balsam; and anise, which, among other things, disguises human scents from fish and game. (As if you have to worry about that in Central Park.)

title: First, Call a Doctor, Then a News Conference; Politicians Open Up About What Ails Them
description: Americans once knew little about Franklin D. Roosevelt's paralysis from polio or John F. Kennedy's struggle with Addison's disease. Woodrow Wilson's failing health was kept dark and mysterious, and Senator Jacob K. Javits told voters less than they needed to know about his terminal fight with Lou Gehrig's disease.

title: Those New Beetles Are Mutating; A Diesel Is Good For Long Hauls

title: U.N. Delegation Winds Up Visit to Kosovo
description: The eight-member delegation from the United Nations Security Council, which came to Kosovo to give a stern message to all sides to stop the violence and to urge on the United Nations mission here, wound up its visit today somewhat muted by the complexities on the ground.

title: By Pedal and Paddle In Arkansas
description: REMEMBER: your wheels will follow your eyes,'' Steve Shepherd tells me. I'm one of 10 early-morning Fossil Flats bicyclists heading up a 60-degree incline over shale and baseball-size lumps of limestone, and my wheels are following their own minds. They slide into the Arkansas mud, taking me with them. ''Right,'' I say. I execute a downhill mount, train my eyes on the terrain five feet in front of me, and crank into first gear. I am being indulged, I know, but not pampered, and I am determined to make it across the hillside straightaway known as the Bench.

title: Visiting Nancy
description: To the Editor: We often visit Nancy, France. Regina Schrambling, with a brief stay (''Quick Trip to a French Gilded Age,'' March 19), well captured the city's beauty and essence.

title: Habitats/Bedford-Stuyvesant; Finding a Town House With a Sense of History
description: IT happened so fast it was easy to miss. Brownstones in places like Fort Greene and Harlem are no longer necessarily bargains. A nice house in Harlem might sell for $700,000, double the price of a year ago, according to Yvonne Maddox, manager of Charles H. Greenthal's Harlem office.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, JENNINGS, LUKE
description: DAVIS-JENNINGS-Luke. Son of Jeffrey Davis and Kevin Jennings. For 11 years, you brought us love, joy, and peace. You were our world, and now our hearts are broken and our home is empty without you. We love you always, your dads

title: Every Tune Tells a Story
description: Chuck Brodsky is a man who lives to tell a tale, and what tales this singer-songwriter from Philadelphia has. He worked as a migrant fruit picker, ice cream truck driver, Israeli kibbutz laborer, bank courier (he was fired after losing a $10 million check), and a street singer in Europe. With insight and good humor, he has taken these life experiences and distilled them into old-fashioned story songs (Mark Twain is a big influence) brimming with wit and compassion.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Chance Encounters; Who Says Gambling Is a Scourge?
description: THE prospect or hope or threat that a big new casino may be on the way to the Catskills, just 90 miles from Manhattan, stirs mixed emotions among New York's casino frequenters. Residing within 90 minutes of the Monticello Raceway, the proposed site of yet another gambling enterprise, means reducing by almost half the time it takes to get to the action in Atlantic City or in Connecticut. That is the promise. The threat is identical: in an hour and a half you can be dropping the family savings into the latest in slot machines or at old-style craps, blackjack and like diversions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSOFF, BURTON ''BUDDY.''
description: KOSSOFF-Burton ''Buddy.'' On April 29, 2000, at age 76 years. Beloved and cherished husband of Phyllis L. Kossoff, devoted and caring father of Mitchell and Pamela Kossoff and the late Stephanie Lynn Kossoff. Adored grandfather of Joshua, Alec, Noah and Jeremy. Extraordinary man and magnificent friend. As a young man, Buddy enlisted and served his country during WW II with extreme courage and valor. As first lieutenant in the Air Corps, he flew 36 missions in the Pacific and was awarded numerous commendations including the Distinguished Flying Cross. Burt was a graduate and honoray Trustee of Baruch College of the City of New York. He founded in 1949, as pioneer in the packaging field, the Burton Packaging Co, Inc, for which he served for over 50 years as President and CEO until the time of his passing. His loving and unique being imparted radiance and the joy of life overcoming challenges and bringing a rare enthusiasm to all facets of his endevors. In 1954 he, together with his wife Phyllis, were part of a smallband of parents who organzied, initiated and maintained the beginning effort in the now National Cystic Fibrosis Research and Care organizations. For over 45 years Burt was dedicated and esteemed member, director and currently officer of the Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater New York. A man of dignity and grace, Buddy touched all he met with his warmth and love of humanity. His strength of character, his keen intellectualism and his love of camaraderie embraced the myriad of his endeavors. An avid handball player until the end, he participated with joy as many years President of the Businessmen's Club at the YMCA and with unbridled pleasure in loyal support and love with many of his friends in the handball ''Killers Club,'' and the American Legion of the NYAC. Burt was a benefactor of many causes giving generously and selflessly in these efforts, all with a never-ending smile and with a personal banner of ''Carpe Diem,'' he marched fearlessly through life. Buddy dearest, you will be with us always in the shelter of your strength, your kind and gentle warmth and your unfailing, sweet smile. We love you. Services will be held at 1:15 PM, Monday, May 1, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Country, With Twang and Pop
description: WHILE not everyone believes in angels, it is difficult to deny that Alison Krauss has a heavenly voice. With her crisp, tremulous soprano, Ms. Krauss brings a welcome pop sentiment to country music.

title: A Cell Phone Symphony
description: TO alert them to incoming calls, owners of Nokia cell phones have a choice of more than a dozen tones and tunes, from Beethoven's Ninth Symphony (''Ode to Joy'') to ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game.'' But there is a signature melody, Francisco Tarrega's ''Gran Vals,'' written in the late 19th century, that unmistakably identifies the brand name.

title: Pennington's Education Has a Fast Start
description: The package of books and tapes arrived in Knoxville, Tenn., a few days after the draft ended, and the wrapping was being taken off the Jets' newest quarterback. Chad Pennington, with the mind of a Rhodes scholar candidate, waded into the stacks, carrying with him a comparison to Phil Simms and the hopes of a franchise.

title: Power Broker, Jersey City-Style
description: For more than a generation of Jersey City residents, Jan. 1 was Rice Pudding Day, when municipal and county employees as well as the Democratic Party faithful would line up at City Hall and pay homage to their patron, Frank Hague. A legendary power broker whose influence extended from Trenton to the White House, Hague ruled here from 1917 to 1947, and until the early 1950's held sway over all of Hudson County.

description: THE room was lighted with softly flickering candles. Six men and seven women settled onto silk cushions arranged in a circle around a low altar set with ritual tools, including a vase of Queen Anne's lace, a small dagger and a crystal chalice.
