title: A Little Disturbing, A Little Unnerving: Postmodern Lounge
description: THE black-clad brunette on the tiny bandstand beams invitingly at her black-clad audience. ''Here's a little ditty about bondage,'' she coos, sounding for all the world like a soccer mom offering milk and cookies to the kids on the block. The band strikes up a catchy major-key tune over a smooth walking bass, and Kelly Flint starts singing in a warm, appealing voice reminiscent of the girl-next-door pop canaries of the 50's. If you couldn't quite make out the lyrics, you might think she was doing a number from an Eisenhower-era musical. But every word comes through with hair-raising clarity: ''After I learned to trust him/ And gave him my heart to keep/ You went ahead and trussed him/ Now he sings Rigoletto/ Under a black stiletto.''

description: This was one of your scariest issues yet. And to think that many of these suburbanites dream of moving to Manhattan like Martha Stewart. There goes the neighborhood!

description: The head of the livery-cab drivers' association repeated his pleas to drivers yesterday to install bulletproof partitions, but then called for allowing such cabs to pick up passengers on the street.

title: Adding a Central Vacuum System to Your Home
description: A CENTRAL vacuum system is a convenience, especially in large homes, because it eliminates the need to drag a vacuum cleaner from room to room or up and down the stairs. The heart of the system is the power unit, which produces the suction for vacuuming. It consists of the motor and dust-collection canister, and is usually located in the basement, attic or garage. Because the unit remains in a fixed location and need not be carried about, it utilizes a larger, more powerful motor than portable ones.

title: Doesn't Anybody Know How To Be a Fugitive Anymore?
description: For nearly three decades, his wanted poster described him as ''armed and dangerous.'' But the clean-shaven man in the federal penitentiary here in Florence, Ariz., looks more like an aging Boy Scout. He wears the mud-brown polyester-cotton shirt and pants that are standard-issue prison garb. There is a pair of black reading glasses in his only pocket, and his blue canvas sneakers are the slip-on kind -- no laces allowed. After all those years in Birkenstocks, the closed-toe shoes feel odd on his feet. More disorienting still is his bare wrist. If he'd been wearing a watch when he turned himself in, he would have been allowed to keep it. But there are strict rules about what may be sent into a penitentiary.

description: Nalo Hopkinson's ''Brown Girl in the Ring'' (1998) brought a new sensibility to science fiction. The novel's characters, who spoke a mellifluous Caribbean patois, did not have to travel to other worlds to confront strange life-forms; the spirits of West African religious tradition were all around them in a decaying near-future Toronto, intervening in their everyday lives for good or ill. Without offering any scientific explanation for the witchcraft she evoked, Hopkinson treated the spirit world with the same rigor and respect other writers bring to rocket science or molecular biology.

title: Making The Waves
description: Five years ago, the Danish director Lars von Trier formed an impromptu collective with three colleagues and set out to tweak the glossy, high-tech conventions of Hollywood movies. Dashing off a set of rules he dubbed the Vow of Chastity, he called the project Dogma 95 and its founders the Brotherhood. Delivering a fashionable message well before it became the fashion, the back-to-basics rules said, in effect: simplify. Put down your fancy toys and get rid of the glitz. If the Brothers hadn't each agreed to make a film according to the vow, the project might have died at birth. As it is, Dogma 95 became a small but influential agent of change, while the restless man who started it continues to reinvent movies in ever more startling and outrageous ways.

This claim was never really credible and has grown steadily less so with a succession of reports criticizing the department's ''stop and frisk'' strategy, in which plainclothes officers sweep through mainly minority neighborhoods, searching and questioning people whom they deem suspicious.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; O'Brian Dry Shod
description: In the 1930's, decades before he won fame for his seafaring Aubrey/Maturin series, Patrick O'Brian published two small, entertaining novels. Each is set in Asia, but the land they truly inhabit is that of the imagination. CAESAR: The Life Story of a Panda Leopard (Norton, $21.95) is about a mythical animal who relates his tale with touching simplicity. O'Brian was only 15 when the book was published, but he already possessed an instinct for deft plotting and uncomplicated narrative. Caesar hunts prey, survives attacks in the wild and later lives in captivity with a benign master. His observations are generally limited to what an animal might actually perceive, yet there is never any sentimentality about the natural world. In HUSSEIN: An Entertainment (Norton, $23.95), published eight years later and set in India, nature also challenges the young hero, although human intrigue and emotions seem far more unpredictable and treacherous. Hussein is a young mahout, or elephant trainer, who sets out to make his fortune and to win Sashiya, the woman he loves. With courage, cunning and luck, he eludes everything from wild dogs to assassins, and he cleverly adapts himself to a number of professions, including snake charmer, storyteller and spy. O'Brian times the narrative perfectly; there is barely a moment to catch your breath before Hussein dives into another adventure. Love is treated with dry wit in this novel, and loyalty (man to man, man to elephant) is paramount. Although O'Brian had never been to India at the time he wrote ''Hussein,'' he convincingly conveys a sense of time and place. The pleasure O'Brian himself takes in the storyteller's art is evident in the energy and inventiveness in each of these early novels. Linda Barrett Osborne

A thinker, a philosopher, a teacher. A devotee of the NYT Puzzle. Not a moment passed that you were not there for us. Your passion for your friends and family will always be unsurpassed. title: The Movie That Created the 'Summer Movie'
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, Steven Spielberg's ''Jaws'' created the Summer Movie as we know it: the action-heavy ''thrill ride'' sort of picture, aimed at sensation-hungry younger audiences, which moves into theaters around Memorial Day and remains there, partying hard, until the school year starts up again in September. ''Jaws'' opened on June 20, 1975, and its phenomenal popularity -- it was the first movie to relieve American audiences of more than $100 million of their hard-earned money -- helped turn Hollywood into what is now largely a summer-business town, sort of like Amity, the New England beach resort where the film's dire events take place. Watching the picture today, you might interpret it as a kind of allegory, in which the business community of Amity, refusing to close the beaches after a couple of fatal shark attacks, eerily embodies the ethics and aesthetics of the entertainment industry. The distributors and exhibitors do not shut down the multiplex even when they know that something lethal -- a ''Speed 2,'' a ''Godzilla,'' a ''Wild, Wild West'' -- lurks within.

A K2 size 9 man's skate weighs 3 pounds, 2 ounces, while the average in-line skate of that size in plastic comes closer to four pounds. Besides being easier to carry, lighter skates are supposed to help you skate faster and fatigue slower. Even more convenient are Street Flyers (top right), a combination of street shoe and in-line skate. Street Flyers ($150 at Target and sporting goods stores in Manhattan) have retractable wheels and are designed to allow skaters to walk home or into a store in skate boots (granted, feeling a bit like Herman Munster). Another on-the-move look comes from Samsonite, the rejuvenated luggage company, which introduced its first line of ready-to-wear last year, designed by Neil Barrett, formerly of Prada Sport. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, ROBERT LYNN BATTS
description: TOBIN-Robert Lynn Batts passed away on Wednesday, April 26, 2000 in San Antonio from complications arising from cancer & respiratory failure. He was born to Margaret Batts and Edgar Gardner Tobin on March 12, 1934. He was named in honor of his grandfather, the distinguished Jurist Judge Robert Lynn Batts, who was the Chief Judge of the U.S. 5th Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans. Mr. Tobin was educated in the Alamo Heights School District and The University of Texas, where he was a member of the Kappa Alpha Fraternity. His father died in a tragic air crash in 1954, and he returned to San Antonio at the age of 19 to set goals and direction for Tobin Surveys, Inc. He built it into the nation's largest and highest quality mapmaker to the oil industry. In addition to his business interests, in his twenties he became president of the Children's Service Bureau. He shared his mother's enthusiasm for history preservation and combined the two by placing welfare agencies in historical buildings. He also became production coordinator for the annual opera in San Antonio where he learned the repertory and came to know the luminaries of the musical world through the years as he worked as a stage-hand and carried the prestigious gold card of honorary membership in the local. He became a member of the Board of Directors of The Metropolitan Opera in New York and a member of its Executive Committee, a Vice-President, and Chairman of the Production Committee of The Metropolitan Opera. The same day he accepted the Board membership to The Metropolitan Opera, he was asked to join the Board of Directors of the Museum of Modern Art in New York and became Chairman of its Drawings Committee. After a major operation, he returned to San Antonio and his beloved Oakwell, his principal residence in San Antonio, which was named after his ancestral manse, a fascinating structure which was celebrated by Charlotte Bronte in ''Shirley''. With Oakwell situated on the Salado Creek, he was a descendant of the Canary Islanders, who had used the same water. Although no longer a sheep farm, the farm's role as a planned real estate development community with allegiance to the earth was paramount in Tobin's thinking. To Tobin, there were two major pieces to his life: Oakwell Farms and chairmanship of the Board of the McNay Art Museum. Theater and art have been Robert Tobin's life. A life that he willingly shared with anyone who was willing to look and/or listen. Generous to a fault, Tobin continued the family legacy of leadership and vision in philanthropy and the arts, devoting his energy and resources to philanthropic pursuits and the international arts community. Tobin focused many of such efforts to support and benefit the McNay Art Museum, Metropolitan Opera and Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Santa Fe Opera. He served as a Regent of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. His gifts to the Tobin Collection of Theatre Arts at the McNay Art Museum has made the McNay Art Museum the leading center in the United States for the Exhibition and study of scene and costume design. Of his gift of the Tobin Collection to the McNay, Tobin stated ''Our world is limited only by our imagination, which being quite a lively phenomenon, is a living thing. The collection is not full of 'books and designs' but of 'creations' which fairly cry out to be seen, used, understood, and above all loved.'' For many years, Tobin was listed among America's Top 100 Collectors in Art and Architecture Magazine and in the top 200 collectors in ARTnews. Tobin is survived by his beloved dog, Samantha, and many friends and cousins. A public visitation will be at Oakwell, 3316 Oakwell Court in San Antonio on Wednesday, May 3, 2000, at 5:00 7:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the McNay Art Museum, Interfaith Center of New York, Santa Fe Opera or to a charity of choice. Following the private interment in Sunset Memorial Park, a private memorial will be held at a later date, with the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean Emeritus of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York officiating. For Information: Porter Loring, 1101 McCullough, San Antonio, Texas 78212 (210)227-8221.

title: Bookend; The Last of All His Kind
description: At 3 in the morning, Anthony Powell took a turn for the worse, and the doctor was summoned. He was a new man, youngish, and he turned out to be called Powell. While they were waiting, the novelist's elder son, the film director Tristram Powell, chatted to Dr. Powell about what part of Wales he and his ancestors came from. It was a Powellian moment: unexpected, genealogical, comical, melancholy. Tony Powell died later that night, quietly at a great age (94) after a long period of wandering frailty, surrounded by his two sons and his wife, Violet, to whom he had been married for over 60 years. He left behind him the slightly surprising instructions that his ashes were to be scattered on the lake below the Chantry, his Regency house in Somerset. The fishing syndicate would, however, need to be consulted, since at this season they had a tricky feeding program for the trout. Another Powellian moment: unsentimental, down to earth, not without a touch of the macabre.

title: Keeping Taxpayer Money Out of Baseball Teams
description: Baseball teams should steal bases, not taxpayer dollars or private property for stadiums. The Libertarian Party condemns the Suffolk County legislators who voted for the taxpayer subsidy of the Long Island Ducks' new stadium in Central Islip [''Suddenly This Summer,'' April 23] as guilty of legalized theft, while Frank Boulton, the team owner, is receiving stolen money. They are not alone. George W. Bush also got taxpayer (stolen) funds for the Texas Rangers. Subsidized sports, like the Long Island Ducks, are economic quackery. What would the taxpayers have done with the money to spend, save or invest as they see fit?

title: RABBI'S MURDER TRIAL
description: Prosecutors in the murder trial of Rabbi Fred J. Neulander of Cherry Hill, accused of arranging for his wife to be beaten to death five years ago, want to use statements made by the rabbi's wife to her daughter that they say link the rabbi to the killing. The rabbi's wife, Carol, was on the telephone with her daughter on two occasions when a deliveryman, supposedly sent by the rabbi, appeared at the door. James P. Lynch, first assistant Camden County prosecutor, would like to introduce the telephone conversations at the trial, which is set to begin in June. The rabbi has pleaded not guilty and denies sending a killer who pretended to be a deliveryman. The rabbi's lawyer opposes using the testimony because it is hearsay and the defense cannot cross-examine Mrs. Neulander. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Chickens Fleeing on Feet Made Of Clay
description: THE camera tilts down from a glowing full moon to sharp barbed-wire fencing. Ominous music chills the soundtrack as a bulky man with a flashlight, accompanied by surly guard dogs, inspects the locks. Suddenly one dog stops and snarls. Inside the fence, a small figure darts behind a shed, followed by the flashlight's beam. It is a tense moment; then, slowly, man and dogs move on. The small figure signals silently and several others rush toward a concealed opening.

She lives there with her guardian, a childless lawyer who rescued her from ''the Mountain,'' an uncivilized shantytown; the visitor is a sophisticate from the city. With his guidance, they learned who they were, and who they were to become. He captured their innocent passion, and combined with the essence of the moment, created fashion that shattered bourgeois conventions.

title: Icon Recast: Support for a Gay Athlete

Big, steady Dave Merrill quietly absorbed the almost physical shock, then began worrying if the revelation would divide the team. Merrill said he decided to take it on as a challenge, a test of the captaincy the two shared and a test of his own character. Jim Whelan, the artist, said he looked into Johnson's eyes and saw a need for instant support. He broke the silence by saying, ''More than being teammates we're your friends and we know you're the same person.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, MARTIN H., M.D.
description: STEIN-Martin H., M.D. The members of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute and Society mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague, Dr. Martin H. Stein, a revered and honored clinician, an educator who trained and guided several generations of psychoanalysts. He was constantly sought after as a supervisor and mentor. He will be deeply missed for his brilliance, clarity and wit. As past president of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and Chairman of the Education Committee, for many years, he was a guiding spirit of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. His renown was international and his contributions to psychoanalytic thinking were significant and numerous. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Mrs. Lucille Stein, and his family. There will be a memorial service at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, 247 East 82 Street, New York on Saturday May 6th at 2PM. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the New York Psychoanalytic Institute or to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. Albert M. Sax, M.D., President/Society Eslee Samberg, M.D., President/Institute

This month, Fleming publishes a very different account of that highly charged relationship in ''The Boy With the Thorn in His Side.'' Here, the two discuss airing family secrets and reading about one's self in someone else's words.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: Much of the business of a newspaper is business. Throughout the 20th century, from the age of J. P. Morgan and Theodore Roosevelt to the age of Bill Gates and Bill Clinton, The New York Times has reported on the people, places, events and issues of commerce high and low, from Morgan's denial that he controlled the company named after him to the colossal mergers and irrational exuberance of the very recent past. The New York Times Century of Business, edited by Floyd Norris and Christine Bockelmann (McGraw-Hill, $29.95), combines the original Times articles on oil trusts and New Coke, the Great Depression and Mickey Mouse, with new commentary that tries to restore the contexts and flavors of the events. Great issues and mighty affairs dominate the coverage -- it could hardly be otherwise -- but consumer technology landmarks are noted (KDKA in Pittsburgh opens as the first commercial radio station, 1920; Herbert Hoover appears, though crudely, on television, 1927; RCA exhibits its first pocket-size transistor radio, 1953; the Hula Hoop, invented by nobody, sweeps the nation irresistibly, 1958; McDonald's is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, 1966; Joe Camel dies, 1997).

title: NATION'S HIGHEST
description: A study released last week found that New Jerseyans paid the highest automobile insurance rates in the country in 1998. description: GEHAN-John J. (April 30, 1928April 9, 2000) Jack Gehan had a distinguished career in healthcare administration, rehabilitation and education. As Executive Director of the Central Labor Rehabilitation Council of NY, he made a lasting contribution to the field of chemical dependency services, as well as an indelible impression on students, friends and colleagues who were enriched by his intelligence and wit. As Director also, of the Community Services Committee of ''Labor Rehab'', Jack ran its summer camp program and the annual Community Services Institute. His awards and citations include the 1992 New York State AFL-CIO Harry Van Arsdale, Jr. Community Services Award. In 1988, Jack founded the Labor Institute for Training in Alcohol and Substance Abuse Services, his labor of love, known as ''Bayberry''. Jack said he would like his epitaph to read, ''He played a part in Bayberry...'' He did; and will be remembered with fondness and respect by those who learned from him, were encouraged by him and inspired by him.

title: The (Open) Garden State

The group, dedicated to making private gardens public, opens about 400 gardens nationwide each year, and the $4 admission fee often goes to the organization and other nonprofits or charities. On May 13, eight gardens will be display; among them will be a cottage garden in Oldwick, a riverside garden in Rumson with espaliered apple trees and a vegetable garden and a spot in Atlantic Highlands, with a view of Sandy Hook Bay and lower Manhattan. On May 20, gardens in Califon and Stanton will be on view and on June 10, 17 gardens will be open (some of them repeats). For information, call (888) 842-2442 or visit www.gardenconservancy.org.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAFIAN, HENRY J.
description: ZAFIAN-Henry J., a retired partner of the intellectual property law firm of Fish & Neave, New York City and Palo Alto, California, died on April 26, 2000. He was 78 years old and lived in New York City. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. Mr. Zafian joined Fish & Neave upon his graduation from Columbia Law School in 1948, was Managing Partner from 1970 to 1976 and remained in active practice with the firm until his retirement in 1988. He specialized in patent and related litigation, often of long duration such as the patent and antitrust litigation involving the antibiotic tetracycline in Federal tribunals from the early 1950's into the 1980's, including proceedings in numerous District Courts, the Federal Trade Commission, four U.S. Courts of Appeals and the U.S. Supreme Court. He was born in Bayonne, New Jersey and graduated from high school at age 14. Upon graduating in 1941 from the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn with a degree in mechanical engineering, he was employed as an engineer by General Electric Company until, after World War II began, he enlisted in the United States Air Corps where in 1943 he received a degree in meteorology from New York University and thereafter served principally as a reconnaissance meteorology officer, including weather flights in the North Atlantic before D-Day in Europe and service in the first hurricane reconnaissance squadron in the Caribbean. Mr. Zafian is survived by five children: Lisa Weaver of Slingerlands, New York; Tracy Zafian of Cambridge, Massachusetts; Amanda Zafian of New York City; Peter Zafian of Denver, Colorado; and Colin Zafian of Telluride, Colorado; four grandchildren; and a sister, Louise Stone, of Santa Monica, California. There will be a gathering of family and friends to celebrate Henry's memory on Monday, May 1, from 6:00 to 8:00 pm at The University Club (One West 54th Street, N.Y. City).

title: Missile Shield Illusion

Now as then, this Star Wars fantasy remains technologically unworkable. Unhappily, the notion of an impenetrable missile defense now threatens not only to impede further, highly desirable cuts in nuclear weapons, but also to stand in the way of future agreement with Moscow on permitting more modest technologies that could protect the country against a lesser attack by a rogue nation like North Korea.

description: LEVINE-Julius, on April 27, 2000. title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT'S an old story. He's married; she's young and virginal. He loves her; she finds him repellent. But he's the king of England so she takes him to wed anyway. Genevieve Bujold as Anne Boleyn is a match in every way for Richard Burton, at his grandest as Henry VIII early in his divorcing-beheading-remarrying cycle, in Charles Jarrott's ANNE OF THE THOUSAND DAYS (1969). The settings are gorgeous, the costumes are Oscar-winning, the romance is captivating and some of the history is accurate - Tuesday at 10 p.m., Tuesday/Early Wednesday at 3 a.m. and Wednesday at 1 p.m. on Bravo.

title: Special Unit Quells Gangs in Yonkers
description: LAST summer Officers Ray Montero and Jim Lloyd saw a man being beaten in front of a bodega on New South Main Street. They asked the victim if he wanted to press charges, but Officer Montero knew the answer would be no. He had been patrolling this street for 10 years and understood that the beating was an initiation for a new member of Chicano Nation, a Mexican street gang.
